-----Original Message-----
From: vicki ahern [mailto:vickiahernatc3@hotmail.com]
Sent: Sunday, December 30, 2001 7:18 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: What is a Developmental Disability?



  Dear Governor Bush,
I had written to you once before involving Florida's Medicaid Waiver. Again 
I am writing to you as I feel that this is a major problem for many families 
throughout Florida who have children with disabilities such as myself. As 
the bill is currently written, Medicaid Waiver only assists the 5 most vocal 
elite.  There are many other populations which have great need as well. In 
many other states throughout the U.S. Michigan and Ohio to name but a few, 
have already written a bill which protects all children irregardless of 
their disability. The premise behind their definition of what a 
Developmental Disability is, is that all children irregardless of their 
affliction are behind where they should be developmentally. Therefore they 
are developmentally delayed. For example a child who wears braces may take 
longer to get from point A to point B than his/her "normal" peers without a 
disability. A deaf child will learn to speak slower than his/her  hearing 
peer.
Not only has the insurance companies consistently discriminated against 
neurological disorders and other populations not included on the Waiver 
plan, but as the Waiver is presently written, families with children of 
disibilites are being discriminated once again by the State itself. If the 
bill was to be rewitten, it would serve to benefit all "isms"  and not just 
a select few. My son, Keith has Muscular Dystrophy. He wears braces and 
receives physical therapy as well as occupational and physical therapy. Blue 
Cross-Blue Shield refused to pay $1600 for my son's braces and over $3000 in 
therapy for 2 months of services, I could not turn to the waiver to help me 
out. Without the waiver my son is further excluded from a PCA/ respite care, 
transportation services which would allow my son a lift to and from Therapy 
so that I could continue to work in the capacity I was hired. I ended up 
losing my job as I used my lunch time to transport my son to and from and it 
usually took too long to return on time. Actually for me it was a blessing 
as I immediately applied for medicaid and the medical bills were paid, as 
were my son's braces. What about all of the other parents who can't afford 
to lose their jobs. It is unfair that we as parents of the underserved 
population struggle to be good parents and make ends meet and in the end it 
is a choice that has to be made. That choice being, to work, or get your 
child services. Why can't we work and be productive citizens and still get 
our children the services that thet need. Please help us to help our 
children. It is a matter of dignity as well as necessity.  I speak on behalf 
of all families of the underserved population, we need your help. This is a 
service that should be open to all special needs populations.
I thank you for your time and understanding im this matter.
My phone number is 954-452-7492 or 954-261-5117
My e-mail is vickiahern@iwon.com
    Respectfully,
    Vicki P. Ahern

From:	Carl Littlefield <Carl_Littlefield@dcf.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Monday, December 31, 2001 10:41 AM
To:	Jeb Bush; brankel@eog.state.fl.us; Respond@eog.state.fl.us
Subject:	Funding

Attached is the October 23, e-mail we sent to Ms. Bonvissuto.

Thanks,
Darlene Golden
Personal Secretary to Carl Littlefield
Developmental Disabilities Program Office
(850) 488-4877 ext. 121
fax (850) 922-6456
SC 278-4877 ext. 121


                                                                                            
                    Carl                                                                    
                    Littlefield          To:     dakotasgranny44@aol.com                    
                                         cc:     David Sokol@DCF                            
                    10/23/01 02:11       Subject:     RE: funding                           
                    PM                                                                      
                                                                                            
                                                                                            



Dear Ms. Bonvissuto:

Thank you for your August 25th email to Governor Bush regarding services
for your son, Justin.  The Governor asked me to reply on his behalf.

Let me begin by saying that I understand there has been a lot of
misinformation being circulated around the state and I would like to take
this opportunity to clarify some that which was evident in your e-mail.

You said in your e-mail that "one family in Miami filed a lawsuit and took
away all available funding."  The Developmental Disabilities Program within
the Department of Children and Families has been sued.    One of the
lawsuits was filed on behalf of a child in the Miami/ Ft. Lauderdale area
claiming that waiver services were not being provided equitably to all
individuals currently enrolled on the Developmental Services Home and
Community-Based Services waiver (the waiver).  This lawsuit became a "class
action lawsuit," which basically means that many other individuals
throughout the state fall under similar circumstances.  Therefore, the
Department had to show the court how it would make waiver services equally
available to all individuals who were currently enrolled on the waiver
throughout the state of Florida.

The one family whose name appeared on the lawsuit did NOT take away all
available funding.  Additionally, the Department has made every effort to
provide services that are medically necessary to all individuals currently
enrolled on the waiver.

Your e-mail also stated that since your son can "walk, talk, dress himself,
etc., he is at the bottom of the list for funding."  That too, is a
misconception.  Eligibility for waiver services is NOT based on individual
abilities.  An individual is eligible for waiver services when he/she:
1)   Is a consumer of the Developmental Disabilities Program;
2)   The individual's IQ is 59 or under;
3)   The individual's IQ is 60-69 and has a secondary handicapping
condition that includes cerebral palsy, spina bifida, Prader-Willi
syndrome, epilepsy, autism, ambulation, sensory, chronic health, and
behavior; OR, the individual's IQ is 60-69 and he/she has severe functional
limitations in at least three of the major life activities, including
self-care, learning, mobility, self-direction, understanding and use of
language, and capacity for independent living;
4)   The individual is eligible under a primary disability of autism,
cerebral palsy, spina bifida, or Prader-Willi syndrome.  In addition, the
condition must result in severe functional limitations in three or more
major life activities, including self-care, learning, mobility,
self-direction, understanding and use of language, and capacity for
independent living;
5)   The individual or the legal guardian must choose to receive home and
community-based supports and services.

All individuals applying for waiver services since July 1, 1999; who have
also been determined eligible based on the criteria mentioned above, have
been placed on a waiting list (with the exception of individuals considered
to be in a life-threatening crisis as identified on Florida's Crisis
Identification Tool).  When Governor Bush came into office in January of
1999, he became aware of the extensive waiting list for waiver services.
That waiting list consisted of thousands of individuals who for years were
told that they could not receive waiver services due to lack of funds.  The
Governor vowed to eliminate this waiting list by requesting additional
funding from the Florida Legislature during the 1999 Legislative Session.
Before releasing the funds, the Legislature asked the Department of
Children and Families, Developmental Disabilities Program Office for a
Spending Plan that would be acceptable to them.

That Spending Plan clearly identifies ways of eliminating the waiting list
in existence prior to July 1, 1999.  In order to eliminate that waiting
list, a new one had to be created for individuals who have become clients
of the Department since July 1, 1999.   Based on the Spending Plan and the
fact that your son applied for services after July 1, 1999 (our records
indicate he applied for services in September 2000) he is now on the new
waiting list.

The Governor continues to show his support to our program and we anticipate
to begin enrolling on the waiver individuals who applied for services since
July 1, 1999, on or about March of 2002.  We will begin to enroll
individuals in the order in which they became clients of Developmental
Disabilities.

While we are unable to enroll your son on the waiver right away, we hope to
serve him and meet those needs that are medically necessary and available
through the waiver pending availability of vacancies and funding this
spring.  The local Developmental Disabilities Program will stay in touch
with you and let you know when funds become available to enroll Justin.

In your e-mail you also stated that "people released from jail, who are
married, are automatically given funding."  That statement is not accurate
and I hope that the information I have provided above clarifies how an
individual is eligible for and receives waiver services.  Anytime you hear
information like the one you stated in your e-mail, you may call your local
Developmental Disabilities Program to seek clarification.

I do understand that your son meets the eligibility criteria for waiver
services and look forward to being able to serve him in the future.


cc:  David Sokol, Developmental Disabilities Program Administrator,
District 13



*****************************************************



I am very sorry that Carl has not been in touch. Notwithstanding Sept.
11th, you should not have to wait this long. I am asking him and his staff
to contact you asap.

Again, I am very sorry.



Jeb Bush

-----Original Message-----
From: Dean Kamen [mailto:dekamen@dekaresearch.com]
Sent: Friday, December 28, 2001 5:57 PM
To: 'brian.yablonski@myflorida.com'
Subject: FIRST


December 28, 2001

Brian Yablonski
Deputy Chief of Staff
Executive Office of the Governor
400 South Monroe Street
The Capitol
Tallahassee, FL 32399

Dear Mr. Yablonski,

Thank you for getting back to me so quickly today.  As we discussed, I was
very excited to learn that part of the President's agenda during his
upcoming trip to New Hampshire is to talk about his education plan.  I
appreciate your willingness to work with Governor Bush to emphasize the
importance of FIRST to the President.  

I am grateful that Governor Bush has been a great supporter of FIRST.  He
has both visited and spoken at our national championship at Disney's EPCOT
Center for the last few years and I understand he plans to do so again this
year.  

I know the New Hampshire audience would respond very well to comments the
President might offer regarding FIRST.  As you know, FIRST has become a
major, national partnership between business and the educational community.
However, FIRST is particularly relevant to a New Hampshire audience because
- 

*	FIRST was founded and has it's national headquarters in Manchester,
New Hampshire.
*	The University of New Hampshire, where the President will be making
his remarks, supports FIRST teams and is in the process of preparing a
national survey on the impact of FIRST.
*	There is great emotional commitment to FIRST's ideals within the New
Hampshire community.
*	Senators Gregg and Smith, and Congressmen Bass and Sununu, have been
long-term supporters of this homegrown, non-profit organization.
*	President Bush is aware of the program.  In fact, during an event at
my home he committed to recognize our winning students and their corporate
sponsors in a White House ceremony.
*	Both former Presidents Bush and Clinton have welcomed FIRST's
winning teams to the White House and this was received very well throughout
New Hampshire.

This year's FIRST competition will include nearly 700 corporate sponsors,
each with their own adopted schools from 44 different states.  There will be
17 cities across the United States, including New York, Los Angeles,
Chicago, Orlando and Houston, holding regional competitions.  Tens of
thousands of students who might never have otherwise seen science and
technology as exciting or accessible opportunities will participate in these
events, and millions will watch these events on television.

As you might guess, I will travel to the President's address on the 8th by
Segway HT to demonstrate that technology and education lead to exciting
possibilities.  When I spoke with Andy Card earlier today (I also asked him
to stress the importance of FIRST to the President) I offered the
opportunity for both he and the President to ride the Segway HT.  I would
also welcome the opportunity to demonstrate the Segway HT to you and the
Governor at your convenience.

Thank you for taking the time to speak with me today and I hope to see you
soon.

Respectfully,



Dean 


Dean Kamen
President
DEKA Research & Development Corp.
The Technology Center
340 Commercial Street
Manchester, NH  03101-1108

FAX: 603-666-3905

-----Original Message-----
From: Jerina Copsey [mailto:jcopsey@gumdropbooks.com]
Sent: Friday, December 14, 2001 6:54 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Florida approved book vendor list; 1% surchage issue



Dear Governor: 

Thank you for returning Harold Fitzgerald's telephone call so promptly.  It was a pleasure to speak with you and briefly acquaint you with two issues that are vitally important to Gumdrop Books.  

Issue One:  Being placed on the Florida approved book vendor list.  

Due to the fact that Florida changed its method of bid notifications from a packet to a postcard, several book vendors, including Gumdrop, did not receive the postcard inviting us to bid for a place on the approved vendor list.  When we realized that the normal deadline to apply was close, we contacted the Florida Department of Education and were told that the deadline had passed.  They said they were sorry that we had not received the postcard but that we would be able to apply in the autumn to get on the list along with other vendors who also did not received the postcard.  This we did in early September but we were told that a decision would not be made until early December.  With follow-up calls, we found that Genny Boynton with the State Purchasing Department (tel: 850-488-7996) was handling our application.  However, she had been out of the office for several weeks and our application sat on her desk.  

Last week we finally spoke with Ms. Boynton only to learn that she had misplaced our bid.  We immediately faxed her a copy and followed up with her the next day by which time she had found the original bid.  When we asked what the next step should be, she informed us that after our bid left her desk in about two weeks, it would go to someone else for approval.  This could take four to six weeks before we could be on the list.

We explained the urgency in getting on the list as we are unable to sell books to our Florida librarian customers who are growing impatient while waiting.  Naturally, impatience will become lost sales unless we can get this resolved immediately.  Ms. Boynton called our office on Monday, Dec. 10th to let us know that Gumdrop Books was not registered in Florida, which we immediately rectified.

Waiting another six weeks to get on the list will substantially add to the loss of business we have already incurred in your state.

Issue Two:  1% vendor surcharge fee on contractors' sales.  

This year the Florida Department of Management Services added this surcharge which must be paid 15 days after the end of each contract quarter.  Failure to comply with this new requirement will result in the supplier being removed from the state contract.  To the best of our knowledge, Florida is the only state that requires a quarterly payment in order to do business within its borders.  This surcharge will not help generate sales and in fact will increase our prices when the funds allocated to purchase our books are, in fact, normally state funds.

Again, thank you for your willingness to hear our concerns on both of these issues.  We are hopeful that with your assistance, some resolution to these issues may be found in a very timely fashion.

Our toll free number is 1-800-821-7199.  Vice President Jeff Fitzgerald's personal email is jeff@gumdropbooks.com.  He is looking forward to hearing from you.  Thank you again for taking time to consider these issues..



Have a good day! 
Jerina Copsey, Human Resources Manager 
jcopsey@gumdropbooks.com 
Gumdrop Books 
a division of Central Programs, Inc. 
100 N. 16th Street 
PO Box 505 
Bethany, MO 64424-0505 

Telephone:  (660) 425-7777 
Fax:  (660) 425-3929 
Email:  wecare@gumdropbooks.com

-----Original Message-----
From: Edrank70@cs.com [mailto:Edrank70@cs.com]
Sent: Tuesday, December 18, 2001 8:41 PM
To: Hedgcock@aol.com
Cc: Jeb Bush
Subject: Hospital closure


12/15/01 
Official: GPW closure not trouble-free 

7 jailed, 3 dead, 1 missing, official confirms 


The state's plan to shift G. Pierce Wood patients into community-based 
programs has gone very well, according to Celeste Putnam, director of 
mental health programs for the Florida Department of Children and 
Families. 

However, that doesn't mean the transition from the DeSoto County mental 
hospital has been trouble-free, she confirmed this week. 

Putnam, in a phone interview, responded to confirm that, of 215 patients 
discharged since January, seven have been jailed, three died and one was 
missing. 

Also, three of 22 Florida Assertive Community Treatment teams, which 
were 
launched in the past two years to provide supervision for discharged 
patients in their home communities, have run amok with problems. 

One of those teams, the Ruth Cooper Center's team in Fort Myers, 
disbanded 
and dropped its state contract. Putnam said DCF is working to hire 
another 
team "with a proven track record" to take over the Fort Myers clients. 

Another team, the Bolley Center's team in St. Petersburg, was barred for 
weeks from taking on new patients. But problems have since been 
corrected 
and the moratorium lifted. 

Another team also came under scrutiny elsewhere in the state until 
problems 
were corrected, Putnam said. 

But, she pointed out, the 22 teams now have 862 patients statewide, an 
average of 39 each. The teams will eventually supervise 100 each, or 
2,200 
patients statewide. 

"We're working with them very closely," Putnam said. "Overall, given 
that 
we have 22 teams, we think they are doing very well. 

"In fact, the Legislature in the last session asked us to start up three 
more FACT teams in the non-GPW areas," Putnam noted. 

Some 38 percent of GPW's discharged patients are now living 
independently 
under the supervision of the FACT teams, according to a report of a Nov. 
27 
GPW staff meeting. 

Only 6 percent -- 13 out of 215 -- were discharged to nursing homes, 
according to another DCF report. 

"Clients in independent living are maintaining," the GPW staff report 
said. 
"Most are taking (their) meds and keeping appointments." 

The closure plan calls for a GPW discharge outreach team to take a 
patient 
to the new community residence -- where a FACT team member was supposed 
to 
be waiting to meet the new client. 

Putnam confirmed reports, however, that on "a couple of occasions very 
early on in our discharge process" there was no FACT team member present 
to 
receive the patient. That problem was corrected, however, she said. 

"There were no serious incidents that resulted (from the failure to meet 
the patient)," Putnam said. 

Putnam confirmed, however, that a number of nursing homes and assisted 
living facilities turned away mental patients because they were too 
difficult to supervise. 

"The ALFs just could not meet their needs," Putnam said. 

However, she said, the candor of the ALFs allowed GPW staffers to find 
more 
suitable arrangements for the patients elsewhere. 

Since July, some 27 patients have been discharged to other state 
hospitals 
because they were too ill to be shifted into community programs. 

Since January, only two discharged GPW patients were involuntarily 
committed back into a state hospital, under the Baker Act. 

"We've reduced hospitalizations -- compared to 1999 -- by 77 percent," 
she 
said. 

At least nine patients left the state, and three left the country. 

Putnam said seven discharged patients wound up in jail. However, five 
have 
since been released, she said. 

None of the incarcerations were for "serious incidents, that I'm aware 
of," 
Putnam said. 

Three discharged patients have died. Putnam said she knows of no death 
due 
to neglect. The causes included heart attack, stroke and "progressive 
decline in a nursing home," Putnam said. 

The patient who apparently died of a heart attack, John Hicks, 56, stirs 
further questions, however. He died in the loft of his group home in 
East 
Fort Myers, according to a Lee County Sheriff's report. One of the 
paramedics who responded called an abuse hotline after noting the room 
was 
unsanitary. 

Putnam also said one patient disappeared from a Manatee County FACT team 
and hasn't been seen since. He left his apartment to visit his parents 
for 
Thanksgiving and never arrived. Police have been notified. 

"We are concerned about the fact he's missing but I don't think it's 
because of the FACT team," Putnam said. 

As of early December, the hospital had just 88 patients remaining. Of 
those, 38 were to be discharged into community programs and 50 to other 
state hospitals. 

There were 450 employees, with about 240 who have yet to line up new 
jobs, 
according to GPW newsletter.

-----Original Message-----
From: Sara Struhs [mailto:sstruhs@nettally.com]
Sent: Saturday, December 29, 2001 1:33 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: <no subject>



Governor:
Have reviewed in detail the latest e-mail you received from Gov. Barnes.
I think either the Governor has not been given the whole picture by his
staff, or Georgia is really
interested in simply extending the talks, while their real focus is on the
ongoing federal litigation (which they have argued successfully to keep
Florida out).

In summary:
#1
Gov. Barnes is incorrect to say that Florida is now asking for more water
than what was proposed in the May draft proposal.  In some periods it is
more, in some it is less ---but the net effect of the changes that have
occured since May is likely less water for Florida.

Basically if the next 50 years look pretty much like the last 50 in terms of
precipitation, then we are basically in agreement with Georgia over water
allocation.  Georgia's concern is that the next 50 years may as a whole be
less wet.  We have provided an "insurance policy" for them by creating a
substitute water allocation schedule if there simply is not enough water in
the tri-river system to meet everyone's needs.  This "insurance policy" --
in the event the future precipitation is less than historic -- works to
benefit Georgia.

#2
His argument that the federal govt. agriculture irrigation experts have no
better "guess" than his own scientists on an appropriate "drought year
multiplier" is simply wrong.  I am concerned the Governor is being given bad
information.  The federal scientists are not guessing...they base their
projections on actual historical data over a long period of record.
Georgia's technical team knows their proposed drought year multiplier of 2.2
(120% more irrigation water than in a normal year) is completely
indefensible. (It would be more like aquaculture than agriculture!)  They
have never offered a defense of their extraordinary proposal on this point.

#3
The argument that Florida always benefits when Georgia holds more water back
in its reservoirs is silly.  The whole point of an equitable water
allocation is shared abundance and shared adversity.  Reservoirs can (and
should) be used to manage some of the "peaks and valleys" (abundance and
adversity) -- but not completely insulate upstream interests from these
natural cycles, while placing the full brunt on the downstream interests.

#4
The issue raised about waiting for new data is spurious.  In December of
2001 (with two weeks left to negotiate), it suddenly becomes imperative to
review soon to be published data from 1994-2000?  The raw data has been
readily available to all interests.  Now they want to wait for it to be
published?  The data shows nothing unexpected; we have simulated it in our
model.

#5
Legal drafting issues are not a great delay.  Perhaps a week's work at most
-- nothing that would require a year's extension.

#6
I can't comment on Governor Barnes' argument to wait to "take the politics
out" of this issue since I don't know Georgia politics.  From our view here
in Florida, this is about the least political thing we are working on.  It
is driven by the scientists and engineers.

#7
The argument that somehow Florida is going to have to pay the federal
government because Georgia wants the reservoirs in Georgia to be
re-programmed from hydropower production to water supply is most unusual.
In any event, federal law governs these issues, and it is an issue apart
from the water allocation issue that falls under this Compact.

#8
Finally, it is troubling to see that Governor Barnes' staff has apparently
advised him that we have reached an agreement on the Lake Lanier issues,
apart from everything else.  Clearly, we are seeking a comprehensive,
basin-wide agreement.  We are pleased that Georgia likes the results they
are getting for Lake Lanier water elevations (I think this is their highest
priority), but the benefit of the bargain goes both ways.  Georgia must
agree to all of the other elements of the allocation formula as well -- not
just the parts that they feel benefit them.


I am not sure another round of e-mails between you and Governor Barnes will
accomplish much at this point.  I suggest we get our technical experts
together again next week and see if we can't further narrow the issues
before you have to spend more time on this.  We will then brief you on just
the remaining key differences.

I am taking a short trip to help support the Florida tourism industry this
weekend.  If you need any more information on this please call Teri
Donaldson, DEP's General Counsel.  Look forward to seeing you in the new
year.

David

From: Rita Ciavola [mailto:dmc1164@gate.net]
Sent: Saturday, December 29, 2001 10:53 PM

Subject: Wishes for a Peaceful and Joyful New Year


Dear Governor Bush,
 
I wish to send you wishes for a "peaceful" and "joyful" New Year.
 
With all that has happened this past year, especially since the "attacks" in September in New York, Pennsylvania, and especially in Washington D.C., I know that the State of Florida has felt the consequences, in many of the departments and agencies, as the affects of the economy "trickle" down to this "vacation" state.
 
I am sure that you and your staff have experienced a lot of confusion in trying to keep the lives of the residents of Florida as safe and prosperous as you can, and there are many of us who include you - and your brother, the President - in our daily prayers.
 
I ask in return, only that you and your staff remember the communities of people with disabilities in Florida, who are even more affected by this devastation and change, by all the "cuts" in the programs, which give their lives "just a little taste" of what we all receive, and sometimes that we "take for granted".
 
May God Be With You, and continue to "Bless You", in all that you do in your day-to-day decision making for this coming year, 2002.
 
Residents in Pinellas County, Florida
Rita E., and Denise M., Ciavola

-----Original Message-----
From: Martha Pratt [mailto:missmartica@hotmail.com]
Sent: Saturday, December 29, 2001 9:45 AM
Subject: Fwd: Editoiral: Voters will grade Gov. Bush on hasty education
reforms. TampaTrib. 12/30/01





>From: "Valerie Adams" <valadams@tampabay.rr.com>
>To: "Martha Pratt" <missmartica@hotmail.com>, "Martha Pratt" 
><martha@jeb.org>
>Subject: Editoiral: Voters will grade Gov. Bush on hasty education reforms. 
>Tampa Trib. 12/30/01
>Date: Sat, 29 Dec 2001 09:02:18 -0500
>
>Editorial (Sunday)
>Tampa Tribune
>12/30/01
>Voters Will Grade Gov. Bush On Hasty Education Reforms
>
>Published: Dec 30, 2001
>
>G ov. Jeb Bush's education reforms are going to be a primary target for his
>critics during the upcoming political year.
>The governor has been faulted for adopting many of his A-Plus reforms
>without allowing public debate. Teachers, in particular, have felt left 
>out.
>
>There is no question the impatient Bush likes to move fast, which results 
>in
>some high-handed directives that are resented by the people who must 
>execute
>them. His rapid and radical overhaul of the higher education system was
>particularly troubling.
>
>But Bush also promised before his election to change the way Florida 
>schools
>operate and no one can accuse him of not keeping his word.
>
>His zeal for quick change has unquestionably caused problems. The governor
>rightly sought to hold schools accountable for their students' performance.
>But his and Lt. Gov. Frank Brogan's plan initially graded schools solely on
>test results - ignoring the different challenges schools face. A school
>attended mostly by students from stable, middle-class homes may score
>impressively on the state's standardized tests, while a school attended
>mostly by poor children may score much lower. Yet the teachers of
>disadvantaged children - who may receive little academic guidance at home -
>may well be working harder and better.
>
>The flaw in the testing system was revealed by the Palm Beach Post in an
>analysis of test scores and family income at more than 2,000 public
>elementary and middle schools. It found that schools with the wealthiest
>students consistently received the highest scores.
>
>But to his credit, Bush has been willing to address such shortcomings.
>
>The other day the governor and the Florida Cabinet revised the testing
>program, putting more emphasis on an individual student's progress in
>reading, writing and math.
>
>Schools will be graded for improving students' performance, rather than
>simple test results.
>
>``This will mark the very first time that we've been able to track
>individual children from one year to the next and report on their
>progress,'' said Gerry Richardson, the Florida DOE's evaluation and
>reporting director.
>
>
>Tracking Progress
>
>The Florida Comprehensive Assessment Test originally given in grades 4, 5, 
>8
>and 10, will now be given to all grades from 3 to 10. The progress of each
>student will be tracked.
>
>The revised system will award schools points based on three measures: the
>latest student test scores, a comparison with those children's scores from
>the previous year, and the annual gain of the school's worst readers.
>Reading, so critical to a child's academic success, will account for half
>the grade.
>
>The changes should make the test a far more accurate measure of the child's
>academic progress and the school's effectiveness.
>
>All this won't quiet Bush's critics. The governor can be faulted for
>throwing the education furniture into the air. The question for voters next
>year will be whether this upheaval has resulted in better schools or chaos.
>
>


_________________________________________________________________

From:	Richalbert@aol.com
Sent:	Saturday, December 29, 2001 2:57 PM
To:	nodough@email.msn.com
Subject:	Thierry Kobes update, Hands on Parenting

December 29, 2001

To: Friends of Live the Life Ministries

From: Richard Albertson

1) Please continue praying for one of our Board members, Thierry Kobes, his wife Diane, and their 3 children.  Here is the latest update on his situation (Thanks to Suetta Clawson for the information):

Thierry's latest MRI shows his brain tumor to be a little larger and even a small change in its size can make a "big" difference.  It could mean two things...either the tumor has grown or there is more dead matter (meaning that the chemo has been working).  Thierry and Diane will be heading to Houston, TX for surgery on January 9th.  Thierry has stated his desire to go through with it.  His other option was to call Hospice... Of course, there are many risks connected with surgery--possible further damage to his speech, Thierry could be paralyzed and in a vegetative state, or he might not make it through the surgery.  He has had all the radiation his body can handle so that option is out.  

Right now Thierry is having a lot of difficulty speaking, still having seizures, cannot concentrate for very long, tires easily, is sleeping a lot, and is experiencing occasional disorientation.  His response to all of this is vintage Thierry:  ""Everyone's worried--there's no need to worry.  God is in control and on His Throne and I have a peace about all this.  It's all going to be okay."  What faith and assurance!  When we've exhausted all we can do, then it leaves no doubt about God's intervention and His divine, healing power. -- It just makes the miracle that much more spectacular! 

For those of you who have expressed a desire to do something for the Kobes Family--such as a meal, child care, etc. pleased contact Rebecca Eppinger at 893-8652.


2) Are you a "Hands-On" Parent?  Parents who are "hands-on" have a much better chance of keeping their kids drug-free.  That's what a new study by the National Center of Addiction and Substance Abuse (CASA) found.  CASA says "hands-on" parents do the following:  
 Monitor their kids TV-watching and internet use
 Put restrictions on which CDs their kids buy
 Know where their kids are after school and on weekends
 Give regular chores to their children
 Are "very aware" of their teen's grades
 Have a curfew
 Eat dinner together most every night - with no TV
 Have an adult present when their child gets home from school
 Are told the truth about their teenager's whereabouts
 Let their kids know they won't tolerate any drug use

The CASA survey found that teenagers with "hands-off" parents are at double the risk for smoking, drinking and using drugs.

Richard Albertson
President and CEO

-----Original Message-----
From: Randy Enwright [mailto:renwright@enwrightconsulting.com]
Sent: Friday, December 28, 2001 3:22 PM
To: Jeb Bush; Kathleen Shanahan
Subject: FW: CONPASS


Governor, I wanted to give you a brief heads up on a machine you are going
to hear about in the next couple of weeks.  For a couple of months, I have
been working with a firm in Miami that distributes a body scanner that is
applicable for airports, government offices, prisons, and so on for body
scanning of materials that a person has on or in them.  We have had several
conversations with the FAA, Secret Service, and so on at the federal level.
Kathleen and I discussed this a couple of months ago and she guided me to
Tim Moore who then got us together with Scotty Sanderson and Bill Butler at
FDLE.  They have been very receptive and are willing to see the machine
tested up here at the Knott Building, but obviously need approval and
guidance from you, the Senate, and the House.  I am forwarding below a
description from my colleague Jim Rimes of the process so far, and how this
was going to be in the Orlando Airport, but that is now on hold and he
explains why.  This is quite timely becuause this machine would have
detected the plastic explosives in the shoes of the terrorist last week and
is very appropriate for the kind of security concerns it appears we will
have in this country for quite some time.  I would love to see Florida be on
the cutting edge of this issue and so I wanted you to be fully aware of what
will be proposed soon.  The company's web sites are below as well as some
links to articles about the machine that could be helpful.  I appreciate
your attention to this and hope you are having a great time in Boca Grande.
Take care. Randy

>  -----Original Message-----
> From: 	Jim Rimes  
> Sent:	Wednesday, December 26, 2001 3:09 PM
> To:	Randy Enwright
> Subject:	CONPASS
> 
> Randy,
> 
> As you know we are working with Keith Carter at the Miami Based X-Ray
> Equipment Company to facilitate the deployment of the CONPASS product for
> increased security in Airports, Government Buildings, Prisons, etc. The
> CONPASS is a low-radiation full body x-ray machine that will allow
> security screeners to see inside the body and clothes.  This type of
> device could have prevented the incident on Friday, where a man with
> explosives in his shoes, got on a plane. 
> 
> We have been working with many different people at both the state and
> federal level to get this product deployed.  In Florida, to date, Mayor
> Glenda Hood of Orlando and Scotty Sanderson, Interim Director of the
> Capitol Police have been principal points of contact on the project.  We
> have also had support from Senator Peaden for the deployment of this
> machine.  At the Federal level people for the X-Ray equipment company have
> meet with the new Office of Homeland security, the FAA, the FDA as well as
> Congressmen Young and Mica's chief of staffs.  
> 
> At this point there are 2 major obstacles to their widespread use in the
> US.  The first is FDA approval that the machine is safe for repeated use,
> second it will be necessary for Congress to make a change in the FAA's
> charter to allow for internal body scans.  These types of concerns have
> been addressed before in other countries.  The machines are in use in
> several European and middle eastern countries.
> 
> X-Ray equipment company has brought one of the machines to Florida.  The
> ConPass machine was originally to be tested at the Orlando International
> Airport, however the FAA nixed the idea because of  a little known
> provision in the FAA charter that prohibits the FAA from conducting
> internal body searches.  This is not a new provision, just a little
> noticed one.  However, X-Ray Equipment company wants a unit in Florida so
> we have been working with Scotty Sanderson to deploy a test unit at the
> Knott Building in Tallahassee.  In fact Keith and myself will be meeting
> with Scotty tomorrow to discuss final plans and site prep for the machine
> to be installed.
> 
> X-Ray Equipment Company website:
> http://www.xec.cc
> 
> CONPASS Site:
> www.conpass.net
> 
> Below are links to a couple of articles about the machine:
> LA Times:
> <http://www.latimes.com/technology/la-111301xray-g.graphic?coll=la%2Dutili
> ties%2Dtechnology>
> 
> Washington Post:
> <http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/nation/graphics/attack/aviation_17.h

From:	Harry Stuart <skatetown@earthlink.net>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 28, 2010 11:09 PM
To:	skatetown@earthlink.net; Jeb Bush
Subject:	Re: Please help!

A brief update:

I spoke with Kevin Tang in your legal department.  He apparently spoke with someone
in the DOT about the no parking signs because I was contacted by a field rep.
However, nothing was ever done, I am still the only business on the entire length of
Orange Avenue in Ft. Pierce which the public cannot park in front of and the local
county commission, specifically one Mr. Bruhn is still doing everything in his power
t shut my business down.

To date, this has cost me in excess of $20,000.00.  I am almost bankrupt.  Our
county government at work.

I know this is trivial in the larger scheme of things but I felt compelled to bring
you up to date.

Thank you,

Harry Stuart

Harry Stuart wrote:

> I will give you a brief explanation of the events.  If you feel this warrants
> further investigation I would be more than happy to provide a more detailed
> explanation.  I just didn't want to waste your valuable time.
>
> First a short history of my business:
>
> Skatetown USA, a roller skating rink, built in 1976 by Emil Steele.  I became
> manager in Jan. of 1984, purchased the business in April of 1993 and finally the
> property in 1998.
>
> The problems began when I purchased a 5 acre piece of property located directly
> behind my rink within (but not part of) a housing development known as
> Sandalwood Estates.  The property was quite run down and located on the property
> were 2 homes, a pool and cabana and 7 clay tennis courts.  We bought the
> property at auction with the intention of converting it into a commercial
> recreation complex, tied to the rink, and adding another pool, a play ground and
> an indoor racquetball court.  During the rezoning process which would allow me
> to operate commercially the Sandalwood homeowner's association blocked my
> project by claiming it would increase traffic levels.  We then decided to
> develop the property by building 3 more homes.  One of these homes would border
> the property owned by a Mr. Chris Humphreys, a member of the homeowners
> association.  the association attempted to block this project also but found
> that they were unable to do so.
>
> During the fall of 2000, while all of the above was going on, we attempted to
> change our Saturday night skating sessions into a teen dance.  Our Saturday
> night business was down and there was little to nothing for teens in our
> community to do. On our opening night, October 28th, we were raided and closed
> down by 21 sheriffs deputies.  In their police report, and in the media, they
> claimed to find drugs in the trash cans and to have made 2 drug buys, by
> undercover deputies, during the evening.  They claimed we were operating an
> illegal "RAVE" which was totally untrue. Mysteriously, there was never a lab
> report done on any of the drugs they found, no one was ever arrested despite the
> fact that they made 2 "buys", they just closed my business down and intimidated
> my customers to the point that they were afraid to return.  My attorney feels
> they violated my constitutional rights (4th and 14th ammendments) however, he
> needed a retainer to pursue the case and I could not afford to continue.
>
> Despite the fact that there were no further raids, the teens were so intimidated
> that after 3 months of unsuccessful dances we needed to make a change.  In late
> 2000 we changed to "Soul Night" in an attempt to attract a 12 to 18 year old
> black clientle. This was very successful.  We began attracting 400 to 600 black
> kids every Saturday night.  This is when the complaints started coming frm the
> Sandalwood homeowners association.  Noise complaints which claimed we were
> operating above the legal decible level. A test was done by the sheriffs
> department in January of 2001 which showed that I was operating within the legal
> "commercial" decible limit.  The neighbors complained to code enforcement that
> because my music was coming from a commercial zone into a residential zone I had
> to operate within the residential limit of 60 decibles. (Despite the fact that
> the rink was here years before any homes were built).  Code enforcement cited me
> based on that fact and in May I went before the code enforcement board.  In the
> meantime I hired a sound expert who advised me on how by moving some of my
> speakers and by lowering my base levels I could get below the 60 decible limit.
> Code enforcement delayed any action until the results of further sound tests had
> been compiled by the sheriffs department. Further testing, done during my
> Saturday night dance and without my knowledge, showed I was operating between 53
> nd 58 decibles.  Code enforcement dropped their action. Three days later a group
> of 5 building inspectors including the head of the public works department,
> visited my rink writing me up on numerous code violations.  They gave me nine
> days to correct these violations or close down.  Many of the violations were
> electrical. An electrician I have known for 15 years dropped everything and
> helped me stay in business.  He said he had never seen anything like this in his
> 30 years in the county and that I must have really made someone mad at the
> county.  The corrections cost me $12,000.00.  The electrician had a friend in
> the building department who told him that one of the county commissioners had
> called the head of the public works department and told him "get your ass down
> to Skatetown and find enough things wrong to get the place closed down".
>
> When none of these intimidation tactics worked the homeowners association strung
> a wire cable accross a driveway which transversed an easement I had over
> association owned property to access my 5 acres. This virtually has land-locked
> my property.  We contacted the sheriffs department and in front of my wife,
> daughter and a deputy the president of the homeowners association stated, "we
> are tired of your husband bringing 500 black kids to this part of town every
> Saturday night".
>
> The noise complaints continued and at the request of the homeowners association
> I appeared before the county commision on Tuesday August 28th.  At this meeting
> code enforcement told the commissioners I had been very cooperative and was
> compliant with the current decible levels.  The sheriffs department also told
> them how cooperative I had been and that they had conducted 6 tests from June
> through August, all without my knowledge, and that all tests showed me operating
> under the 60 decible limit. The neighbors present claimed that the sheriffs
> department warned me when the testing was going to take place and that after
> they left I raised the decible levels.  The commissioners sided with the
> neighbors and are "investigating" the need to lower the maximum legal decible
> levels below the current number of 60. One commisioner claimed he could hear my
> music from his front lawn over 2 miles away.  Coincedently this is the same
> commissioner that had ordered the inspectors to "find enough violations to close
> me down".Any sound expert would tell you that at the levels I am now operating
> there is no way this could be possible. In the meantime, on Wednesday of this
> week, the DOT, at the request of the county commission, erected No Parking signs
> on the shoulder of Orange Avenue, only in front of Skatetown USA.  We have very
> limited parking and customers often park along the roadside on the shoulder.
> The sherriffs department never had a problem with this as long as the vehicles
> were not actually on the road itself. Along the entire length of Orange Avenue,
> from the Indian River to the Okeechobee County line the only stretch of shoulder
> that it is illegal to park on is right in front of my business.
>
> I can't take much more.  It seems obvious that they are trying to intimidate me
> enough to either close me down completely or to at least have me change my
> Saturday nights to something other than "Soul Night".  Since the rink has been
> here for 25 years and I personally have been here for 17 years and since none of
> this began happening until after I began "Soul Night"  my belief is that the
> truth is that certain commissioners, in conjunction with certain homeowners, are
> attempting to intimidate me into not bringing "500 black kids to tis part of
> town every Saturday night." In my meeting on September 5th with the executive
> committee of the local NAACP they agreed and are planning to give me some
> assistance at the local level.
>
> I don't know if or even how you could help me but this business is all I have,
> it's really all the community has for the children in this county, I am fighting
> but I am running out of energy and resources.  If you can help I owe you
> everything, if not, at least thanks for your time.
>
> Sincerely,
> Harry Stuart
>
> Jeb Bush wrote:

Dear Jeb,

First let me wish you and yours a wonderful peacefilled New Year's and may 2002 bring you all that you are hoping to accomplish. I am here to assist you in this venture in any way that I can. I will work with Mike Hamer and Linda Cooper as best as I can on your campaign. I have tried with my all my might to get you to implement the $3,950,000.00  dollars potentially allocated by BTI for your digital divide and other programs but no one has gotten this ball rolling and BTI has all but ruled the offer dead! It has been over a year and a half closer to two! and Frank Brogan was down in south Florida for a Broward Days event just to tell you how long it's been! 

Please get www.myflorida.com to comply with your brother's terrorism bill. If his brother won't comply who will?? 

all the best to you,

Dr. Laurie Nenortas, CEO

www.accurateinfo.com - Dedicated to the best internet service. Highest quality at moderate prices.
www.terrorismbuster.com - You need to protect yourself in cyberspace.

 

 

Patriotic Act of 2001

Public Law 107-56

It is our patriotic duty to try and protect our fellow Americans from the terrorists that committed the hideous crimes of 9-11-01. That is why President Bush signed into law on October 26th., 2001 Public Law 107-56 Terrorism Bill. We owe it to ourselves, and our country, to comply with this law.

It requires us to give our law enforcement agencies records of accounts, emails, and data files on activities that have happened within our web sites, should terrorists use your web site for information or promotion of terrorists activities. Without the proper tracking mechanisms and log files embedded in your web site or server, there would be no way for you to turn over this information.

Remember the 19 hijackers of 911 used our Internet web sites to find where to be trained, where to live, and where to buy crop dusters. They also stole peoples identities from job banks and job opportunity centers on-line. They stayed undetected for 18 months with the help of information gained from our web sites!

Showing our nation that your web site is in compliance with the Patriotic Act of 2001 is your patriotic duty and should not be set aside. We are making it easy for you.

1.Request a compliance analysis of your web site. The price for this service is dependent on the size of your web site. Not to be compliant is too high of a price for any of us to pay! Terrorists chose little companies first, so dont think you are too small to comply! 

2. Once the analysis has been performed, you will receive a detailed report of any areas of your web site that are not in compliance. You will also receive suggestions/solutions for compliance.

3.Either have your IT staff make the changes or hire an outside firm to fix your compliance issues. Accurateinfo.com can do this for you, but we are not the only ones.

4. Once the web site is in compliance with the Patriotic Act of 2001, put the "seal of compliance" on your web site. 

5. Fill out the request form for the seal, once compliance has been proven.

You are now letting all people who come to your site know that you are supporting our country and our President by complying with the Patriotic Act of 2001.

The choice is yours. Please dont let our nation down. We can all help prevent another disaster if we comply with President Bushs Terrorism Bill.

I am sending you this message that I have on my web site about HR3162 compliance. This is known as the terrorism bill. Please take a moment and make sure your web site is in compliance. Also do your patriotic duty and pass this information to any company which you know is not in compliance. Our entire country is depending on us (the IT community) to help them stay protected.
This is not a one man show, and I am not in any way saying or even implying that I have the only answer. I don't!! 
BUT I am committed to you and all Americans to see that we all do what we can to comply with President Bush's new law. 
 
Most people do not understand this law and furthermore, do not know what to do to comply with it. It is not well written and was put together in haste, but I feel our Congress and Senate did so in our best interest. 
It is up to us to help make this work. It will put a noose around the current al qaida's necks, since  they are  here, and we don't know where they are! Having our web sites monitor if any suspicious activities occur might tip our government off to where they are, and where they are going to hit again?
Mohammed Atta did just that,  had we had HR3162 in place we might have caught him!
Please help. 
Thanks and God Bless,

I will work with Mike Hamer and Linda Cooper as best as I can on your campaign. It has been over a year and a half closer to two! and Frank Brogan was down in south Florida for a Broward Days event just to tell you how long it's been! 

Please get www.myflorida.com to comply with your brother's terrorism bill. If his brother won't comply who will?? 

all the best to you,

Dr. Laurie Nenortas, CEO

www.accurateinfo.com - Dedicated to the best internet service. Highest quality at moderate prices.
www.terrorismbuster.com - You need to protect yourself in cyberspace.

 

 

Patriotic Act of 2001

Public Law 107-56

It is our patriotic duty to try and protect our fellow Americans from the terrorists that committed the hideous crimes of 9-11-01. That is why President Bush signed into law on October 26th., 2001 Public Law 107-56 Terrorism Bill. We owe it to ourselves, and our country, to comply with this law.

It requires us to give our law enforcement agencies records of accounts, emails, and data files on activities that have happened within our web sites, should terrorists use your web site for information or promotion of terrorists activities. Without the proper tracking mechanisms and log files embedded in your web site or server, there would be no way for you to turn over this information.

Remember the 19 hijackers of 911 used our Internet web sites to find where to be trained, where to live, and where to buy crop dusters. They also stole peoples identities from job banks and job opportunity centers on-line. They stayed undetected for 18 months with the help of information gained from our web sites!

Showing our nation that your web site is in compliance with the Patriotic Act of 2001 is your patriotic duty and should not be set aside. We are making it easy for you.

1.Request a compliance analysis of your web site. The price for this service is dependent on the size of your web site. Not to be compliant is too high of a price for any of us to pay! Terrorists chose little companies first, so dont think you are too small to comply! 

2. Once the analysis has been performed, you will receive a detailed report of any areas of your web site that are not in compliance. You will also receive suggestions/solutions for compliance.

3.Either have your IT staff make the changes or hire an outside firm to fix your compliance issues. Accurateinfo.com can do this for you, but we are not the only ones.

4. Once the web site is in compliance with the Patriotic Act of 2001, put the "seal of compliance" on your web site. 

5. Fill out the request form for the seal, once compliance has been proven.

You are now letting all people who come to your site know that you are supporting our country and our President by complying with the Patriotic Act of 2001.

The choice is yours. Please dont let our nation down. We can all help prevent another disaster if we comply with President Bushs Terrorism Bill.

I am sending you this message that I have on my web site about HR3162 compliance. This is known as the terrorism bill. Please take a moment and make sure your web site is in compliance. Also do your patriotic duty and pass this information to any company which you know is not in compliance. Our entire country is depending on us (the IT community) to help them stay protected.
This is not a one man show, and I am not in any way saying or even implying that I have the only answer. I don't!! 
BUT I am committed to you and all Americans to see that we all do what we can to comply with President Bush's new law. 
 
Most people do not understand this law and furthermore, do not know what to do to comply with it. It is not well written and was put together in haste, but I feel our Congress and Senate did so in our best interest. 
It is up to us to help make this work. It will put a noose around the current al qaida's necks, since  they are  here, and we don't know where they are! Having our web sites monitor if any suspicious activities occur might tip our government off to where they are, and where they are going to hit again?
Mohammed Atta did just that,  had we had HR3162 in place we might have caught him!
Please help. 
Thanks and God Bless,

-----Original Message-----
From: Lynn Pappas [mailto:LPAPPAS@PAPMET.COM]

Subject: growth manangement plan


Jeb  I see in the St. Pete Times that you will be pursuing some initative on the school funding as it relates to development approvals.  I think one of the most fundamental problems is the disconnect between the school need issue (driven by development to ssome extent but not exclusively) and the funding that is controlled at the state level.  Recently because of some litigation on a DRI we have reviewed extensively the process by which money is translated into new space and student stations at the state and local level.  Even to the extent that you obtain a contribution process from development there is no mechanism by which those dollars will improve school overcrowding on any immediate basis.   As a result housing costs continue to rise without achieving  a meaningful benefit.   To achieve any meaningful result you must look at the funding mechanism for both capital facilities and operations at the state and local level.  WIthout that all the development exactions in the world will not alter the outcome.  I was shocked to find in my analysis of the issue how little understanding exists on this subject..   My research showed that there is no rule or policy published by DOE which defines the basis upon which new schools are determined to be  built.  It seems as if it operates on some nebulous basis like incipient policy.   The school boards and DOE don't want to bring on new facilities as underutilized infrastucture and operating costs so the system is designed to have some degree of overcrowding to maxiimize efficiency.  I hope that you will include some further research on this point in any legislative proposals.   If I am off the mark I would be delighted to be educated.  I agree there is a problem that needs fixing but you have to look at the delivery side of the system at the same time you look at the cost side. Happy Holidays.

From:	Baur, Katie <katie.baur@myflorida.com>

Everglades Restoration Plan to Be Unveiled 
 _____Special Report_____ 

* Army Corps of Engineers: Documents, graphics and recent coverage. 
 
 
By Michael Grunwald
Washington Post Staff Writer
Friday, December 28, 2001; 12:58 PM 


The Bush administration is unveiling the long-awaited rules governing the
$7.8 billion restoration of the Florida Everglades this afternoon, and
environmentalists are already warning that the rules could imperil the
largest ecological effort in history.

A 58-page draft of the rules obtained by The Washington Post includes few of
the specifics and assurances that conservation groups had said were
necessary to make sure the project actually restores the parched South
Florida ecosystem. For example, Congress had requested interim performance
goals to help measure the project's progress over the next three decades,
but the rules only include a proposed process for setting goal-- no
timeline.

Instead, the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, the federal agency overseeing
this massive replumbing job, limited its "programmatic regulations" to
generalities, maintaining maximum flexibility for its own officials to run
the project according to unspecified "protocols." Florida Gov. Jeb Bush's
administration--backed by sugar farmers and urban water utilities who fear
that their water will be diverted to the Everglades at the expense of South
Florida's economy--had also complained that more detailed rules would
trample on the state's right to allocate water as it sees fit, and the Corps
cited those arguments in its documents.

"I'm sure plenty of groups are going to zero in on something they won't
like," said Stuart Applebaum, who is overseeing the restoration for the
Corps. "When you have something this extraordinarily complicated with this
many stakeholders, that's what you expect."

At first glance, though, it seemed like environmentalists were going to be a
lot unhappier than other stakeholders. Many of them do not trust the Corps,
which drained the Everglades at the behest of Congress in the 1950s,
ushering in an era of slow decline for the so-called River of Grass. Today,
half of the Everglades are gone, along with 90 percent of its storied wading
birds. The nationwide concern for "America's Everglades" inspired the
4,000-page restoration plan that Congress passed overwhelmingly during the
heat of the 2000 campaign.

However, that initial blueprint for 68 projects - eliminating canals,
storing water, building pumps - left much to be decided later, and
environmentalists were counting on these programmatic regulations to fill in
many of the blanks. For example, many conservationists believe that without
strict assurances that the Everglades will get the water it needs to recover
its health, the region's water will keep going to development and
agricultural interests instead. The regulations the Corps is releasing today
include no such guarantees - just another proposal for a process to help
"evaluate and identify water to be reserved for the natural system" under
state law.

"This just screams business as usual," said Shannon Estenoz, the World
Wildlife Fund's Everglades director. "They talk a lot about state's rights.
What about the rights of federal taxpayers to get what they're paying for:
Everglades restoration?"

Environmentalists had also hoped for assurances that scientists would be
insulated from the political process, and that the Department of
Interior--which runs Everglades National Park--would get an expanded and
well-defined role in the regulations. That didn't happen, either.

"Basically, this is a regulation to do everything outside the scope of the
regulations and congressional oversight," said Bradford Sewell, a senior
attorney for the Natural Resources Defense Council. "It's codifying a broken
process in federal regulations."

Applebaum said the Corps will seek public comment, and intends to float its
final proposal next March.

 2001 The Washington Post Company

Resolution: SUPPORTING---Central and Southern Florida Project Indian River Lagoon-South Feasibility Study----Draft--Integrated Feasibility Report Supplemental Environmental Impact Statement. The resolution is to be sent to Ms. Laura Mahoney, U. S. Army Corps of Engineers, PO. Box 4970, Jacksonville, Florida 32232-0019 not later than December 31, 2001. 

AGENDA ITEMS 

I. Loxahatchee River/Indian River Lagoon Feasibility Study--Debra Drum--Coastal Ecosystems and Patti Sime--SFWMD 

Patrick Hayes (Friends of the Loxahatchee and the Jonathan Dickinson State Park) and Lloyd Brumfield 
(Martin County Conservation Alliance) have registered complaints about the Loxahatchee River (Wild and 
Scenic River) running into the Jupiter Inlet through Martin County being totally ignored in the Southern Indian River Lagoon Feasibility and in the CERP plan as they understood. It appears that the south branch, Palm Beach County, is being very badly mistreated--ignored, too. 

Salt water intrusion is in the Martin County Loxahatchee up to Trapper Nelson's and cypress trees are dying from lack of fresh water. In the Palm Beach County fork of the Loxahatchee are huge developments being approved that will draw a lot of water from Canal 18 which will affect both the 'sick' branches of the Loxahatchee. 

Deborah Drum (SFWMD) reported that for the first time the Loxahatchee has received a small sum for some study. She said that a plan known as the NORTH PALM BEACH COUNTY PLAN has some restoration for the Loxahatchee, however, she indicated that restoration is yet to be fully defined. She said that she would get an electronic version of the North Palm Beach Plan for those who were on the EAC sign-in sheet. Lloyd Brumfield said he would pursue a printed copy, too.   Drum also said that the Loxahatchee Coordinating Council is studying the River. Hayes and Brumfield said they were not impressed with the Coordinating Council's results so far. 
[Post Facto response: To: Interested members of the Environmental Action Committee; Please find the following link to www.evergladesplan.org with some information regarding the North Palm Beach County plan as per your 
recent request. I am still working with SFWMD staff to get a copy of the draft plan to each of you electronically. In the meantime, this link may provide some useful background info on the project. Thanks for you patience. 
Sincerely, Deborah Drum 
Senior Supervising Planner, Coastal Ecosystems Division, SFWMD 
http://www.evergladesplan.org/the_plan/2lev_projects.shtml] 

Patrick Hayes said that the Florida Department of Environmental Protection appeared to be only interested in Minimum Flows and Levels which Hayes said he is under the impression the MFL would be about 200 feet per second which would cause significant harm. 

II. SCT (Science Coordinating Team) The Flow Paper--Nick Aumen--Everglades National Park---Mr. Aumen has worked on Lake Okeechobee, Loxahatchee and other water assignments in his 10 years in South Florida.  He is the SCT point of contact for smoothing a draft White Paper "The Role of Water and Sediment Flows in the Ridge and Slough Landscape," July 14, 2001.   Evidence in the White Paper suggest that in 1940 the Tamiami Trail (Miami-Dade, and Collier Counties) resulted in two artificial compartments, north and south, where once there has been continuous landscape and flow across same.   The central hypothesis is that water flow (sheet flow) and sediment transport, both unimpeded by man-made obstructions, must be present to maintain the Ridge and Slough landscape pattern originally presented.  It has been postulated by the SCT that Everglades restoration requires full elevation of the Tamiami Trail--Highway U.S. 41.   ]The CoE proposal is for a 5% solution (3000 feet in a stretch of some 10 - 11 Miles)].  The White Paper caused a great deal of criticism by the Corps of Engineers and the M-Tribe reps. The criticism was more about the process (not substance) of the White Paper being authorized, peer review and distribution through channels.  The Florida Game and Freshwater Fish Commission, many years ago noted the presence of the flocculent layer of loose organic matter and its detrimental effects on the Everglades in the Tamiami Trail dam effect.   Another draft of the White Paper is scheduled to be completed by December 14, 2001. This time the process will be pursued especially peer review.   (EAC Chair has requested an update.)    This is the first paper since the Conceptual Restudy, now CERP, Section 2.3, to fully document the need for flows in the Everglades. 
None of the Agencies involved has fully focused on the baseline as established in CERP Section 2.3 (Dynamic Storage & Sheet Flow), CERP Goals and Objectives (Section 5.5, Table 5-1 = The PROMISE, per the NEPA/WRDA process; See Attached) 

III. East Coast Issues---Rosa Durando 

The endangered Loxahatchee River and the Indian River Lagoon Feasibility have nothing to do with the Everglades restoration. Palm Beach County has been the victim of bad planning and political development permitting by the County Government, the SFWMD and the Corps. 

IV. West Coast Issues--Fran Stallings 

Two thirds of the development permitted in South Florida would not be allowed if the existing laws-rules-regulations were followed by local governments, SFWMD, the Florida Department of Environmental Regulations, the federal EPA, and the Army Corps. All of these agencies are scofflaws and rogues ignoring their own laws. 
In the Naples-Ft. Myers area five golf courses and several developments are full speed ahead with consumptive permits approved by all agencies. The aquifer is still low and will be put-upon even more during dry seasons when all of the new development comes on line.   Fran's assessment is that the only way the permitting agencies will do what is right is to take them into Federal court in a law suit; this seems to be the only thing respected. All of these agencies are dancing to the tune called by the development industry and the agriculture industry. The natural 
system is taking a real beating with official approval by the agencies. 

V. Members/Public Comments 

Mike Murphy---SFWMD---A retreat for strategic planning has been held that discussed the acquisition of property for the Everglades Restoration and the Indian River Lagoon Feasibility Study. The agencies, SFWMD, have the 
power of eminent domain but has decided to use the willing seller process. 

Steven Bell---Invasive Exotic Plant/Tree Issue is being ignored to a large degree. It will 2015 before any attention will be given to exotics and then the growth will have greatly expanded with the cost being tremendous to remove. 

John distributed to the EAC a memorandum (12/04/01) Public Comments to WRAC. The concerns of 
SW Florida citizens about unmitigated development on the Florida west coast and the loss of wetlands.  A second memorandum (11/31/01) was sent the to CROGEE  (Committee on Restoration of the Greater Everglades Ecosystem) to answer the question posed by CROGEE:  "How can help we help Everglades Restoration!" 

VI. Approval of Minutes of November EAC Meeting

John Arthur Marshall, 
Chair, EAC
