THE FOLLOWING ARE DRAFT REMARKS FOR THE GOVERNOR'S VIDEO-TAPED MESSAGE
TO
THE EVERGLADES COALITION MEETING.


Hello.  We have a tradition of reporting on progress and announcing new
developments at the annual Everglades Coalition meeting.  I didn't want
to
break that tradition, so I appreciate the opportunity to send this
message.

Let me begin by congratulating this year's conference co-chairs, Erin
Deady
and Frank Jackalone.  The agenda you organized highlights how far we
have
come these past few years, as well as the opportunities ahead.

I remember a year ago humbly receiving the honor of being designated a
"Steward of the Everglades."  Governors receive many recognitions --
some
more deserved than others.  But few have meant as much to me as that
honor.
That's because few things are more important to South Florida's
environment
and economy than restoring the Everglades.  And few things are more
important to me.

I also remember my first meeting with you, where it was duly noted (some
might say duly warned) that I was a conservative Republican born in the
Texas oil patch to an oil man father, and I then went on to become a
developer in Florida.  Well, all those things are still true -- as they
will
always be.

But we have some new truths we didn't have 3 years ago:  We have
launched
the largest environmental restoration project the world has ever known.
All
of our critical land acquisitions are on schedule.  Environmental
results
are exceeding expectations in the Kissimmee River headwaters.  The
first-ever pollution limits have been established for Lake Okeechobee.
And
six Stormwater Treatment Areas have been constructed on budget and on
schedule and are performing 50-percent better than expected.

And on that oil issue -- just for the record -- we have prevented new
drilling leases in the Everglades and off of Florida's coast.  Never
before
has Florida's coastline been so protected.

I think we have also established new levels of access and confidence
between
my office and yours.  This is going to help us as we work through some
important issues in the months ahead.  Three things come to mind:

First, how do we make sure that the water entering the Everglades gets
cleaned up?  The science has confirmed what many of you have long
suspected:
phosphorous levels in the Everglades must be brought down to 10 parts
per
billion.

I was pleased to personally appear before the Environmental Regulatory
Commission to make that recommendation.  It was an important step that I
will never forget!  But I also know full well that there is a big
difference
between setting a standard and achieving it.

We all know that it will take decades before such an exacting standard
can
be met across more than 2 million acres.  However, there will be no
backsliding; only forward progress with timely and measurable results.

Our challenge is to simultaneously ensure the retreat of cattails in the
Everglades Protection Area, while staving off the march of the red tile
roofs of development into the Everglades Agricultural Area.  This will
best
be accomplished with new investments in water quality, while limiting
new
and expensive opportunities for delay by lawyers and lobbyists.

The Second thing I want to mention is the agreement I need to sign with
my
brother that promises Florida will reserve the water necessary for
natural
systems before federal money is released for construction projects.

We will do this to make sure that federal money keeps flowing and
projects
stay on schedule.  More importantly, we will do this because it is the
right
thing to do.

If anyone questions Florida's resolve to reserve water for healthy
ecosystems, I direct your attention North to the Apalachicola River.
There
we have been in difficult discussions with our neighboring states over
equitable water allocations. Florida has been willing to give up
substantial
amounts of water to avoid the uncertainties of litigation.  However, my
instructions have been clear: there is no compromise when it comes to
the
minimum flows necessary to maintain the functional integrity of that
River
and Bay environment.

The same holds true for the Everglades.  The difference is we don't have
to
negotiate with another government, and the legal tools for water
reservations are already in place.

Finally, there is the need to keep paying the bills for Everglades
restoration.  We are starting the New Year off right:  All of the bills
are
paid.  There is money in the savings account (trust fund).  And we have
a
perfect credit record.  All of this in war-time while revenues have
temporarily fallen far short of the mark.

Given that, I found it amusing to read in the paper a recent quote from
one
of your members that referred to "the Everglades Funding Problem."  Some
"problem!"  There are plenty of other programs in Florida government
today
that wish they enjoyed the same strong position as the Everglades.

I suspect the real concern being expressed was, "WIll Everglades funding
always be in such great shape?"

Here again, the news is good.  Consider the fact that key legislators
(Republicans and Democrats; North and South Florida) have already
indicated
their support to borrow money if ever needed to keep restoration on
track.
I agree that we should be prepared to borrow the money if necessary.

However, I would go a step further.  If the Everglades are the priority
we
say they are, then let's do everything we can first to make sure we
don't
run out of money.  Let's use sound money management to make sure we have
revenues for this project that are secure and reliable -- and debt free.

Making Everglades restoration more expensive by taking on un-budgeted
interest payments makes it less likely, not more likely, that the
project
will be completed on schedule.  This is particularly true if debt is
taken
on in these early stages that will come due when we are in our peak
spending
years in a decade.

In a few days I will for the third year in a row propose to fully fund
the
Everglades at 100-million-dollars.  What will be different this year are
the
sources of that revenue -- sources that are more reliable and more
secure
than ever before.  It is a 3-part plan.

First, it continues the proven, reliable commitment of dedicating
25-million-dollars a year from our Florida Forever Program for
Everglades
land acquisition.

Second, it provides a dedicated source of funds by capturing the growth
in
document-stamp revenues in the state's subsidized housing program.
Because
of growing revenues, the housing program can remain fully-funded at
current
levels while providing increasing amounts for Everglades restoration.
Beginning with 13-million-dollars a year in the early years, this
dedicated
revenue source will grow to as much as 25-million-dollars by 2010.

Third, we will provide a secure source of funding by better managing
existing Florida Forever debt and by tapping excess document-stamp
revenue
before it rolls over into General Revenue accounts.

Currently, as a condition of bonding, susbstantial document-stamp
revenue is
held "in reserve" to help guarantee our Florida Forever debt.  We can
free
this money up for the Everglades today by insuring our debt rather than
keeping cash in reserve.  Using surety bonds to meet our reserve
requirements on existing debt is a more cost-effective strategy for
securing
additional resources than simply taking on additional new debt.

This, when combined with a commitment to direct a portion of the
predictable
growth in document-stamp revenue
 directly into the Everglades Trust Fund before it is placed into a
General
Revenue account, will make $50 to $60 million of reliable, debt-free
dollars
available every year for the Everglades for the rest of this decade.

Total it all up, and we have our first Billion dollar commitment for the
Everglades from the State of Florida!

I applaud the broad political commitment in Florida to fund this
project.
And I respect the need for contingencies -- including borrowing should
that
ever become necessary.  It is an option we will never give up.  But with
the
support of the Legislature and the Cabinet, we will first exercise every
option to make sure that reliable, secure, debt-free dollars are
available
as needed to pay for our highest environmental priority.

We have come a long way together these past few years.  This year is no
exception: a phosphorous standard of 10 parts per billion; a
confirmation
that water for natural systems always comes first; and a secure funding
plan
to meet the first Billion-dollar commitment.  Not bad.  And we
acknowledge
the Everglades Coaltion's role in helping us get there.  This year, you
are
all Stewards of the Everglades.

Thanks for listening, and Happy New Year.



From:	Doreen Rutledge <Doreen_Rutledge@dcf.state.fl.us>

As you all bask in the sun enjoying your well deserved vacations I just

pulled up in front of Holy Sacrament Church and " dumped out" 247 packing
boxes full of Pooh bear, The Gap, and Disney things. All part of this
wonderful Today show donation. The donation that never quits giving! Father
Hobbs was thrilled (not). I am no longer his favorite person. Today I just
returned from Sawgrass Mills where "GAMEWORKS" had a party for 30
Independent Living kids. Each rec'd $35.00 gift certificate to spend
anywhere in the mall, a 2 hour unlimited game card and a pizza party. When
I pulled in the driveway I was greeted by 105 boxes of books sitting in
front of my husband's garage door. They are wonderful coin collecting
books, very well done, and I'm sure my husband will be more than happy to
move them tonight when he gets in from work.
Something tells me his comment won't be "awesome!"
Luckily we don't have small, easily corrupted children.
This brings the number of Today Show donations to around the 160,000 pieces
level. Thank God for the Department of Corrections who saved my... life!
Enjoy your vacations!
Happy New Year
Doreen

-----Original Message-----
From: Sara Struhs [mailto:sstruhs@nettally.com]
Sent: Friday, December 28, 2001 12:28 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: bob.sparks@dep.state.fl.us
Subject: Please Review Draft Everglades Remarks



Governor:
I am forwarding this draft to the team (including OPB) for review and edits
Friday, but wanted to also get this draft to you.  Want to make sure I am
hitting all the right issues and had the right tone.  Please let me know if
we have missed anything you want to include.  The organizers have pleaded to
keep this short.  I have obliged them the best I can.
David

THE FOLLOWING ARE DRAFT REMARKS FOR THE GOVERNOR'S VIDEO-TAPED MESSAGE TO
THE EVERGLADES COALITION MEETING.


Hello.  We have a tradition of reporting on progress and announcing new
developments at the annual Everglades Coalition meeting.  I didn't want to
break that tradition, so I appreciate the opportunity to send this message.

Let me begin by congratulating this year's conference co-chairs, Erin Deady
and Frank Jackalone.  The agenda you organized highlights how far we have
come these past few years, as well as the opportunities ahead.

I remember a year ago humbly receiving the honor of being designated a
"Steward of the Everglades."  Governors receive many recognitions -- some
more deserved than others.  But few have meant as much to me as that honor.
That's because few things are more important to South Florida's environment
and economy than restoring the Everglades.  And few things are more
important to me.

I also remember my first meeting with you, where it was duly noted (some
might say duly warned) that I was a conservative Republican born in the
Texas oil patch to an oil man father, and I then went on to become a
developer in Florida.  Well, all those things are still true -- as they will
always be.

But we have some new truths we didn't have 3 years ago:  We have launched
the largest environmental restoration project the world has ever known.  All
of our critical land acquisitions are on schedule.  Environmental results
are exceeding expectations in the Kissimmee River headwaters.  The
first-ever pollution limits have been established for Lake Okeechobee.  And
six Stormwater Treatment Areas have been constructed on budget and on
schedule and are performing 50-percent better than expected.

And on that oil issue -- just for the record -- we have prevented new
drilling leases in the Everglades and off of Florida's coast.  Never before
has Florida's coastline been so protected.

I think we have also established new levels of access and confidence between
my office and yours.  This is going to help us as we work through some
important issues in the months ahead.  Three things come to mind:

First, how do we make sure that the water entering the Everglades gets
cleaned up?  The science has confirmed what many of you have long suspected:
phosphorous levels in the Everglades must be brought down to 10 parts per
billion.

I was pleased to personally appear before the Environmental Regulatory
Commission to make that recommendation.  It was an important step that I
will never forget!  But I also know full well that there is a big difference
between setting a standard and achieving it.

We all know that it will take decades before such an exacting standard can
be met across more than 2 million acres.  However, there will be no
backsliding; only forward progress with timely and measurable results.

Our challenge is to simultaneously ensure the retreat of cattails in the
Everglades Protection Area, while staving off the march of the red tile
roofs of development into the Everglades Agricultural Area.  This will best
be accomplished with new investments in water quality, while limiting new
and expensive opportunities for delay by lawyers and lobbyists.

The Second thing I want to mention is the agreement I need to sign with my
brother that promises Florida will reserve the water necessary for natural
systems before federal money is released for construction projects.

We will do this to make sure that federal money keeps flowing and projects
stay on schedule.  More importantly, we will do this because it is the right
thing to do.

If anyone questions Florida's resolve to reserve water for healthy
ecosystems, I direct your attention North to the Apalachicola River.  There
we have been in difficult discussions with our neighboring states over
equitable water allocations. Florida has been willing to give up substantial
amounts of water to avoid the uncertainties of litigation.  However, my
instructions have been clear: there is no compromise when it comes to the
minimum flows necessary to maintain the functional integrity of that River
and Bay environment.

The same holds true for the Everglades.  The difference is we don't have to
negotiate with another government, and the legal tools for water
reservations are already in place.

Finally, there is the need to keep paying the bills for Everglades
restoration.  We are starting the New Year off right:  All of the bills are
paid.  There is money in the savings account (trust fund).  And we have a
perfect credit record.  All of this in war-time while revenues have
temporarily fallen far short of the mark.

Given that, I found it amusing to read in the paper a recent quote from one
of your members that referred to "the Everglades Funding Problem."  Some
"problem!"  There are plenty of other programs in Florida government today
that wish they enjoyed the same strong position as the Everglades.

I suspect the real concern being expressed was, "WIll Everglades funding
always be in such great shape?"

Here again, the news is good.  Consider the fact that key legislators
(Republicans and Democrats; North and South Florida) have already indicated
their support to borrow money if ever needed to keep restoration on track.
I agree that we should be prepared to borrow the money if necessary.

However, I would go a step further.  If the Everglades are the priority we
say they are, then let's do everything we can first to make sure we don't
run out of money.  Let's use sound money management to make sure we have
revenues for this project that are secure and reliable -- and debt free.

Making Everglades restoration more expensive by taking on un-budgeted
interest payments makes it less likely, not more likely, that the project
will be completed on schedule.  This is particularly true if debt is taken
on in these early stages that will come due when we are in our peak spending
years in a decade.

In a few days I will for the third year in a row propose to fully fund the
Everglades at 100-million-dollars.  What will be different this year are the
sources of that revenue -- sources that are more reliable and more secure
than ever before.  It is a 3-part plan.

First, it continues the proven, reliable commitment of dedicating
25-million-dollars a year from our Florida Forever Program for Everglades
land acquisition.

Second, it provides a dedicated source of funds by capturing the growth in
document-stamp revenues in the state's subsidized housing program.  Because
of growing revenues, the housing program can remain fully-funded at current
levels while providing increasing amounts for Everglades restoration.
Beginning with 13-million-dollars a year in the early years, this dedicated
revenue source will grow to as much as 25-million-dollars by 2010.

Third, we will provide a secure source of funding by better managing
existing Florida Forever debt and by tapping excess document-stamp revenue
before it rolls over into General Revenue accounts.

Currently, as a condition of bonding, susbstantial document-stamp revenue is
held "in reserve" to help guarantee our Florida Forever debt.  We can free
this money up for the Everglades today by insuring our debt rather than
keeping cash in reserve.  Using surety bonds to meet our reserve
requirements on existing debt is a more cost-effective strategy for securing
additional resources than simply taking on additional new debt.

This, when combined with a commitment to direct a portion of the predictable
growth in document-stamp revenue
 directly into the Everglades Trust Fund before it is placed into a General
Revenue account, will make $50 to $60 million of reliable, debt-free dollars
available every year for the Everglades for the rest of this decade.

Total it all up, and we have our first Billion dollar commitment for the
Everglades from the State of Florida!

I applaud the broad political commitment in Florida to fund this project.
And I respect the need for contingencies -- including borrowing should that
ever become necessary.  It is an option we will never give up.  But with the
support of the Legislature and the Cabinet, we will first exercise every
option to make sure that reliable, secure, debt-free dollars are available
as needed to pay for our highest environmental priority.

We have come a long way together these past few years.  This year is no
exception: a phosphorous standard of 10 parts per billion; a confirmation
that water for natural systems always comes first; and a secure funding plan
to meet the first Billion-dollar commitment.  Not bad.  And we acknowledge
the Everglades Coaltion's role in helping us get there.  This year, you are
all Stewards of the Everglades.

Thanks for listening, and Happy New Year.

Subject: Retaliation of the DOC


Dear Governor Bush:
The DOC has been vindictive because of what I have done to try to help.  It
makes me physically ill. 

I called your attention, to a young incarcerated man -C. Elliott (Tomoka)
who requested the Doctor's continuance of adult diapers -- because he was
soiling himself.  He was embarrassed and afraid of going out on the compound
because of the inability of control of his incontinence problem.  When I
first learned of this young man's problem, he was emotionally stable and
working very well in the educational department with one of my student.  All
he was requesting was for his adult diapers to be continued.  He wrote a
formal grievance to the DOC.  He also wrote a letter asking me for help in
this problem.

Since my involvement he was restricted to the medical department-not allowed
to communicate with his family--kept in medical confinement -- sent to
Butler C I for temporary stay (with diapers), and then onto Lake C I into a
Behavioral program...(without diapers)...because they his say incontinence
is all in his head.  (Did they ever have a specialist review his back and
spine injury?) His emotional well-being has been shattered.  The treatment
he has received has obliterated his emotional stability. 

You know, it really shouldn't matter why a person is incontinent, if
emotionally you need the security of adult diapers-you should have them. The
American civil rights act under section 504, disability act, suggests that
it is his right to have them.

The DOC has taken a young man with an incontinence problem and has
emotionally abused him to the point of causing his mental health to
disintegrate.  Would I tell you this if it wasn't true?

Is this what you were thinking should happen when you wanted the DOC to look
into this?

This Christmas will not be a happy one for this young man and his mother.

Sincerely,
Marlene Nolte-Director
4907 Coral Blvd.
Bradenton, FL 34210
(941) 794-0197
http://www.starcoast-academy.com/
StarCoast-a distance learning Academy, Inc.

-----Original Message-----
From: Smith, William 
Sent: Wednesday, December 26, 2001 11:10 AM
To: Nimer, Richard
Cc: Taylor, Alex
Subject: RE: Kairos Horizons


Mr. Nimer,

I have spoken with Chaplain Perry Davis, the Chaplain for the Tomoka
Horizons Program at TCI.  Chaplain Davis indicates that nothing has changed
in regards to the choosing and processing of inmates eligible for the Kairos
Horizons program.  From the beginning of the Faith-Based Residential Program
there have been minimum standards to participate in the program, with
Classification determining which inmates met those standards.

With the passage of Senate Bill 912 it was mandated that 80% of inmates who
participate in Faith-Based Residential Programming be within 3 years of
release.  The remaining 20% may include inmates with life sentences and
others as long as they meet the other minimal requirements (such as being in
open population and having 3 months free of DRs).  The Chaplain makes the
final decision as to who will participate in the program when he interviews
the applicant at the institution.

The Kairos Horizons Program is not moving to the Work Camp.  I believe the
misunderstanding here is that when potential program participants are
transferred to Tomoka they are initially "staged" at the work camp until an
available spot is open.  I have asked Chaplain Davis to speak personally
with Mr. Gott to clear up any misconceptions.  Mr. Gott is a valued
volunteer and does an excellent job as a "Godparent."

Thanks,

Will Smith

Thanks
RJN

Dear Governor Bush
My name is Glen Gott and since it began I have been 
a "godparent" in the Kairos Horizons program at the 
Tomoka Correctional Institution here in Daytona Beach.
I heard a very distressing rumor the other day that the 
decision as to which inmates can apply for acceptance 
into the program has been taken out of the hands of the 
chaplain and is being decided by prison officials. It 
is also rumored that the program is going to be taken 
out of the main unit and transferred over to the work 
camp and application to the program will be limitted to 
only those inmates that have less than 3 years on their 
sentence.
First of all, haven't we learned yet that spiritual 
things belong in the hands of spiritual leaders? 1st 
Corinthians 2:14 says, "But the natural man receiveth 
NOT the things of the Spirit of God: for they are 
foolishness unto him: NEITHER can he (the natural man) 
know them, because they are SPIRITUALLY discerned."
Second, my "godson" has a life sentence and after 3 
weeks of showing him the Bible and by being an example 
to him he has accepted Jesus as his Savior. Can we deny 
ANY man the opportunity to see and accept Jesus just 
because he has a sentence of more than 3 years?
PLEASE Sir, don't let this happen! Spiritual things 
belong in the hands of spiritual people.
God bless you.
Glen Gott

>  -----Original Message-----
> From: 	Brown, Donovan  
> Sent:	Thursday, December 27, 2001 10:10 AM
> To:	McDonough, Jim
> Subject:	NYT article
> 
> December 21, 2001
> 
> NATIONAL 
> Few States Track Prescriptions as a Method to Bar Overdoses
> By MELODY PETERSEN and BARRY MEIER
> 	
> 
> In the mountain coal fields of eastern Kentucky, Sheriff Steve Duff of
> Harlan County recently noticed something curious - people driving to drug
> stores in neighboring states to fill prescriptions of a potent painkiller
> called OxyContin.
> Their reason, Sheriff Duff believes, was to evade a system in Kentucky
> that monitors who gets potentially addictive drugs and who prescribes and
> fills those prescriptions. 
> That system, the sheriff says, helped him arrest several dozen people last
> year on OxyContin-related charges. More significantly, it helped police
> stage Kentucky's biggest ever drug-abuse raid, resulting in the arrest
> last February of 252 people in a sweep called Operation Oxyfest.
> Public health and law enforcement officials have long argued that such
> monitoring can save lives by quickly identifying problem doctors who
> over-prescribe narcotics and problem patients who forge prescriptions or
> con unsuspecting doctors.
> But today, just 15 states have such programs because of decades of
> lobbying by drug companies, doctors, pharmacies and more recently, groups
> pushing for the greater use of narcotics to control pain. Even in states
> that monitor prescriptions, some programs are underfinanced, crippling
> their effectiveness.
> Federal drug agents say OxyContin played a likely role in the overdose
> deaths of at least 296 people since January 2000, in addictions that have
> overloaded drug treatment centers and in crimes like thefts at pharmacies
> and on the street. Public officials say OxyContin abuse is also costing
> taxpayers tens of millions of dollars because so many people who misuse
> the drug get it through Medicaid, a government-financed health care
> program for the poor.
> Law enforcement officials say that if more states had good monitoring
> programs they might have been able to crack down on OxyContin abuse before
> it claimed so many victims. States with such programs, like New York, have
> seen little OxyContin abuse, while many without them, including Florida,
> Maine and West Virginia, have been the hardest hit.
> Most of the groups that oppose the monitoring of prescriptions argue that
> it violates patients' privacy, costs too much or hurts those who really
> need the drugs by causing doctors to prescribe fewer and less potent
> drugs. But a report by the General Accounting Office in 1992 and a more
> recent survey by the Justice Department looked at several of those claims
> and could not substantiate them.
> Prescription monitoring has long had some powerful opponents.
> "Physicians do not want their activities monitored," said Carmen A.
> Catizone, executive director of the National Association of Boards of
> Pharmacy, which supports monitoring. "Drug companies are also a powerful
> lobby. Once a drug is monitored, sales decrease, and the drug companies
> don't like that."
> OxyContin, made by Purdue Pharma of Stamford, Conn., was originally
> thought to be less prone to abuse because its narcotic was locked in a
> time-release formula. But abusers found that they could crush the tablet,
> then swallow, inhale or inject the powder to give themselves a high as
> powerful as heroin's. 
> As a result of OxyContin abuse, there are renewed calls for more
> prescription monitoring. At least eight states, including Connecticut, New
> Jersey and Florida, are seriously considering it.
> Florida, for example, experienced a 40 percent jump in the number of
> people who died from drug overdoses in the first six months of this year.
> OxyContin is cited as a factor in many of those deaths.
> "This system will allow us to monitor prescription shopping and doctor
> shopping and any illicit prescribing by doctors," said Gov. Jeb Bush of
> Florida, who announced his support for such a system this month.
> For years evidence has shown that prescription monitoring works, health
> officials say. For example, when New York State began tracking
> prescriptions for certain tranquilizers in the late 1980's - a move
> opposed by four drug companies and the state medical society - emergency
> rooms in New York and Buffalo reported 47 percent fewer overdose
> admissions involving those drugs.
> "We saw a vast drying up of those drugs on the streets," said John Eadie,
> the former director of New York's program who now consults with states on
> setting up monitoring programs.
> But Dr. Russell Portenoy, chairman of pain medicine and palliative care at
> Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan, said there was a downside. Some
> doctors, he said, prescribed patients tranquilizers that the state did not
> track, drugs that had greater potential side effects than those that were
> monitored.
> When California sought to add certain tranquilizers to its monitoring
> program, lobbyists for drug companies and doctors were able to defeat the
> move.
> The drug industry's main trade group, the Pharmaceutical Research and
> Manufacturers of America, said it "generally supports" monitoring systems
> but said that individual drug companies should decide the issue for
> themselves. 
> In recent years drug stores and pain specialists have been the most vocal
> opponents of monitoring.
> In North Carolina, a drug tracking system was defeated this year, despite
> the state's recent problems with OxyContin. That loss frustrated John
> Womble, manager of the state's controlled substances regulatory agency,
> who had won the support of the state medical society, only to have the
> bill opposed by drug stores and some pharmacy chains.
> "As long as I'm in state government, we'll continue to try," Mr. Womble
> said.
> In New Mexico last year, the state pharmacy board repealed regulations
> needed to operate a tracking system after complaints by pharmacists and
> doctors. The New Mexican system had operated for just two years, said
> Jerry Montoya, director of the state's pharmacy board.
> Pharmacists say they worry about the cost of reporting prescription data.
> "How much burden do you want to put on pharmacies?" asked R. Dale Tinker,
> executive director of the New Mexico Pharmaceutical Association, which
> represents pharmacists.

From:	Tim Condon <ct236@gte.net>

Cc:	mkbmic@aol.com; bennett@transnational.net; bohicaman@imt.net; fmiley@worldnet.att.net; mccool1@earthlink.net; pcox@mpinet.net; sonjay@mindspring.com; QwaveQ@aol.com; res0092k@gte.net; ecurry@interaccess.net; david.hurley@gte.net; fredvollrath@aol.com; LesterAdams@Mailcity.com; colemanm001@hawaii.rr.com; nspector@kasslaw.com; kahuna@nji.com; jwyatt2@tampabay.rr.com; siegels1@mindspring.com; MsuPgaDad@aol.com; kerrybrown@compuserve.com; talktome@tampabay.rr.com; Grant Halliday; Michael Murphy; Marty Zupan; Jeb Bush
Subject:	Re: A Political Trap for Jeb Bush

At 08:13 AM 12/27/01 -0500, rexy wrote:
>just so you all know, it's my understanding that many (most?) media 
>outlets cannot read email with attachments and may not even RECEIVE email 
>that has attachments, for security reasons.
>         So, not only might forwarded copies with attached docs not make 
> it, if anyone bothers to do the "Florida Spending chart," (which someone 
> needs to do pronto) it will probably have to be put on a website, where 
> the media can be directed to a url in email articles to view a jpg or 
> graphic example of the chart. any volunteers?
>Rex

         Well, the Governor's office has it, and has responded, and I've 
asked them to send me a copy of the chart. If they can't come up with it I 
don't know who's better situated to do it. Maybe some local Republican 
big-guns? We got any statisticians with Florida population/spending info in 
the audience?


Tim Condon, Tampa, FL 33601 -- O: 813-251-2626 -- Fax: 813-254-2979

From:	Jeb Bush </o=Bush-Brogan 2002/ou=First Administrative Group/cn=Recipients/cn=jeb> on behalf of Jeb Bush
Sent:	Thursday, December 27, 2001 9:00 AM
To:	'Tim Condon'
Subject:	RE: A Political Trap for Jeb Bush

Tim, what you failed to mention in your greetings to Everyone is that we have cut around $5 billion in cummulative taxes during my four years as governor. The state now takes the smallest amount of personal income since 1991. In effect, our efforts have erased the tax burden that grew in the 1990s. 

You are correct that spending has grown in Florida. This is true in spite of the close to $1 billion in spending vetoes during my first three years as governor. 


Jeb Bush 

***********************************************************
Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law.
Most written communications to or from state officials
regarding state business are public records available to the
public and media upon request.   Your e-mail communications
may therefore be subject to public disclosure. 



-----Original Message-----
From: Tim Condon [mailto:ct236@gte.net]
Sent: Thursday, December 27, 2001 5:55 AM
To: mkbmic@aol.com; bennett@transnational.net; bohicaman@imt.net;
fmiley@worldnet.att.net; mccool1@earthlink.net; pcox@mpinet.net;
sonjay@mindspring.com; QwaveQ@aol.com; res0092k@gte.net;
ecurry@interaccess.net; david.hurley@gte.net; fredvollrath@aol.com;
LesterAdams@Mailcity.com; colemanm001@hawaii.rr.com;
nspector@kasslaw.com; kahuna@nji.com; jwyatt2@tampabay.rr.com;
siegels1@mindspring.com; MsuPgaDad@aol.com; kerrybrown@compuserve.com;
talktome@tampabay.rr.com; Grant Halliday; Michael Murphy; Marty Zupan
Cc: Jeb Bush
Subject: A Political Trap for Jeb Bush


Greetings to Everyone: What follows is an article I have written explaining 
the poltical trap that has been laid for Florida's Gov. Jeb Bush by the 
Democrats, the media, and a prominent leading Republican. Please send this 
article to every Republican, every conservative, and every media outlet 
you're in contact with. Attached are copies of the article, one in 
Microsoft Word format and one in WordPerfect format. They may be forwarded, 
copied, printed, and reproduced at will. And I hope they are. Merry 
Christmas and Happy New Year to you all!   Tim Condon

The Deadly Political Trap
By Tim Condon
Tampa, Florida
December 27, 2001
For immediate release

         NOTE: What follows below is an explanation of the same old trap 
set for Republican officeholders by Democrats. It happens all the time. It 
made George H.W. Bush a one-term President. It made Bob Martinez a one-term 
Florida governor. And now the trap is laid for Jeb Bush. It was perfectly 
set this time by a RINO Republican (who used to be a Democrat and worked on 
Lawton Chiles campaigns), but its still the same old trick. It goes like 
this: The Democrats endlessly pressure an elected Republican to raise taxes 
for the good of the country or for the good of the state because its 
necessaryand its the right thing to do. The Republican, who is 
susceptible to this kind of entreaty because he or she actually cares about 
doing the right thing instead of playing political games, falls for the 
trap, turns against the Republican low-tax, small-government principles, 
and helps to raise taxes. Happily for the Democrats, that destroys his 
conservative voting base. Then the Democrats attack him in the election 
campaign anyway, as always, for favoring the rich and not doing enough. 
The result is that the Democratic voters all vote Democrat, and the 
Republican voters, disgusted with their turncoat candidate, either stay 
home or vote for an alternative candidate, thus handing the election to the 
Democrats. READ BELOW AND HEED!

         On December 18, 2001 newspaper headlines throughout the state of 
Florida heralded a  new master plan for increasing state taxes unveiled by 
state senate President John McKay.
         A Republican from Floridas west coast in Bradenton, McKay started 
out as a Democrat  who worked on campaigns for Democratic Senator (and 
later governor) Lawton Chiles in the 1980's, and thereafter held a staff 
position with Terrell Sessums, a Democrat and former speaker of the house 
in the Florida legislature.
         McKay has also made a name for himself over the last two years as 
the president of the Florida Senate in Tallahassee. During that time, while 
Jeb Bush has been governor, McKay has sometimes distinguished himself as 
quite partisan in a Democratic direction, as he opposed modest tax cuts and 
other proposals by Gov. Bush. Im not accountable to the Governor, he 
once said.
         Most recently McKay pulled a political stunt by shutting down the 
Florida Senate early, thus forcing the state House, led by a conservative 
Republican and still in session, to either accept bills written his way 
or reject them entirely. Because of such political shenanigans, among 
Republicans McKay has earned the sobriquet of RINO, an acronym for 
Republican In Name Only. Not unexpectedly, at the same time McKay has 
become a political darling of Floridas liberal-leaning media, not to 
mention the vastly outnumbered Democrats in the state legislature.
         Because Floridas state constitution requires a balanced budget, 
Gov. Bush was required to call two legislative sessions in 2001 to trim the 
budget (necessitated by falling state revenues which  to a degree are 
dependent on tourism which has plummeted in the wake of the World Trade 
Center disaster). As a result, the state legislature was forced to cut 
about $1 billion from a total state budget of about $50 billion.
         Now Senator McKay has unveiled a plan to increase taxes, 
essentially a green light over the long run for ever-larger state 
government. Expect to hear repeated media references to McKays courage 
and foresight, not to mention praise from Democrats statewide.
         McKays taxing plan is politically crafty. It features a current 
reduction of the state sales tax from six to four percent. It ends taxes on 
individual alcoholic drinks and continues the phase-out of the state 
intangibles tax, which is slated to expire anyway. It provides for 
three-fifths super-majorities in the future for the state legislature to 
raise the sales tax rate or expand sales tax exemptions. And it is being 
touted as revenue neutral, at least in the short term. But the real guts 
of the plan is that it ends most sales tax exemptions, including those on 
services such as advertising, lawyers fees, architects fees, and real 
estate charges, thus opening the taxation floodgates so the state 
government can take in many billions more dollars than it does now.
         Media stories noted in a muted way that Floridas legislative 
Democrats supported the McKay taxing plan, but their support will be 
low-key said one admiring newspaper article.  We have to be careful so 
were not portrayed as tax-and-spend liberals, said state representative 
Bob Henriquez of Tampa. There seemed little chance of that happening 
with  the Republican state senate president carrying water for higher 
taxing and spending.
         But what is most interesting about senator McKays maneuvering is 
not that he has turned his back on the traditional Republican themes of 
smaller government and less taxation. No. What is most notable is that his 
taxing plan lays a clever and deadly political trap for Governor Jeb Bush.
         Consider these facts: In the younger brother of the current 
President, some already see a potential future President. Smart and 
economically savvy, Jeb Bush is a member of the entrepreneurial wing of the 
Republican Party. Hes also married to a Hispanic woman and fluent in 
Spanish, attractive characteristics for an expanding and increasingly 
important bloc of voters. It has not been lost on Democratsin Florida and 
elsewherethat Jeb Bush could be a formidable future candidate for 
President of the United States. Thus, Democrats in Florida hope to destroy 
Bushs future potential by making him a one-term governor.
         With respect to the political trap being laid for Gov. Bush, 
consider the three possible outcomes: The plan for more taxes can win, be 
defeated, or pass in a modified state. Its fate lies first with the 
Republican-dominated state legislature. But more particularly, its fate 
lies in the hands of the governor himself. If Jeb Bush supports the plan, 
or some modification, it will most likely pass. If he opposes it, it will 
most likely  fail.
         If Gov. Bush supports McKays plan or some modification of it, the 
liberal media line will be paeans to his farsightedness, leadership, 
and courage. Butjust as his father did on the national stageby 
supporting higher taxes and bigger government he would alienate his 
conservative Republican base and be defeated in his re-election bid, to the 
relief and delight of Democrats everywhere. Truly a win-win situation for 
the Democrats.
         But what if Gov. Bush opposes the taxing plan, in any form? Then 
it will most likely go down to defeat, and he will be greeted by the hoots 
and catcalls of the Democrats and virtually all of Floridas left-leaning 
media outlets. As the conventional political wisdom goes, he would empower 
not only his Democratic opponents, but also alienate many of the states 
Republicans who are supposedly lusting after higher taxes and bigger state 
government.
         In other words, Jeb Bush, a rising star in the national Republican 
firmament, is damned if he does, and damned if he doesnt. Either way, it 
would seem, the Democrats and RINOs win.
         The plan seems so slick, and is being unveiled at such an 
opportune time, that its not too farfetched to foresee a triumphant 
Democratic Florida governor appointing Senator McKay to some important 
state post as a grand and magnanimous gesture of bipartisanship. It is even 
more interesting to note that McKay has announced that he wont run for his 
seat in the next election, which removes the potential distress of seeing 
what his own constituents think of his legislative shenanigans and big 
taxing plans. By doing that he has also effectively shielded himself 
from  political pressure by the state Republicans. Very slick.
         What is Jeb going to do? A victim of the failure to rein in state 
spending in the past  halcyon days of economic boom, Jeb Bush is now being 
blamed by Democrats and their media allies for economic conditions far 
beyond his control.
         What is Jeb going to do? In a typical lead paragraph after the 
Florida legislature finished a recent budget-cutting session, one newspaper 
article trumpeted McKays tax plan by writing, Hundreds of state workers 
are losing their jobs, school systems are canceling summer sessions and 
seventh periods, and at-risk youngsters are losing critical counseling 
services. Those are consequences of the $1 billion in budget cuts the 
Legislature made recently. In another article, the reporter intoned that, 
Gov. Jeb Bush must assure voters his tax cuts have not been damaging to 
the economy.
         Tax cuts? Damaging to the economy? This is the typical media line 
that Bush will have to deal with, and in Florida, as elsewhere, state media 
outlets often follow the lead of Democrat spinners.
         What is Jeb going to do? McKays tax-increase trap is almost 
exactly the same as that faced by former Florida Governor Bob Martinez, 
only the second Republican governor in modern state history. He was a 
one-term governor, thanks to the tax-and-spend issue, losing his 
re-election bid to Democrat Lawton Chiles after Martinez endorsed and the 
legislature passed a sweeping tax reform in the 1980's. Strikingly 
similar to McKays plan to increase sales taxes, the Martinez gaffe 
provoked such outrage that the state legislature hastily reversed it. 
During the following  two terms of Democrat Lawton Chiles there was nary a 
peep from the state capitol about increasing taxes. Lets face it, 
Democrats arent fools. And the economy was booming anyway, increasing the 
states tax-take every year.
         But now, like a gift from heaven for the states outnumbered 
Democrats, Republican John McKay reprises history, unveils what will 
eventually be a huge tax increase, and moves to put Jeb Bush in a deadly 
political bind.
         What is Jeb going to do? Well, there is good news: It is possible 
for Governor Bush to  escape the trap. The solution is powerful, visual, 
simple, and unarguable. All that is needed is a simple chart. It probably 
already exists. On this chart will be shown just two lines: One will show 
the growth of Florida population from, say, 1970, through to the present 
(it increased by about 235% over that time). And the other line will show 
yearly state government revenues/budgets during the same  period (which 
increased by thousands of percentage points).
         Just look at that chart! Saying Florida politicians have been 
spending like drunken sailors for 30 years would be a slander on drunken 
sailors. And the chartlike the now-famous Bush Country map showing how 
each county in the U.S. voted in the 2000 Presidential electionwill be 
everywhere.
         So let it begin. The Florida Runaway Spending Chart will appear 
on billboards, in newspapers, on flyers,  in advertising, on placards, on 
television, in magazines, on the Internet, on silk-screened T-shirts...let 
it be seen everywhere. And let the question be asked: Do we really need 
more state taxing and spending, like the Democrats and media are telling us?
         And then lets let the people of Florida decide.

 ### 

From:	Jeb Bush </o=Bush-Brogan 2002/ou=First Administrative Group/cn=Recipients/cn=jeb> on behalf of Jeb Bush
Sent:	Thursday, December 27, 2001 8:54 AM
To:	'jpaul'
Subject:	RE: 

see you in a couple of hours.
 

Jeb Bush 

***********************************************************
Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law.
Most written communications to or from state officials
regarding state business are public records available to the
public and media upon request.   Your e-mail communications
may therefore be subject to public disclosure.

Jerry

To:	Tim Condon
Cc:	mkbmic@aol.com; bennett@transnational.net; bohicaman@imt.net; fmiley@worldnet.att.net; mccool1@earthlink.net; pcox@mpinet.net; sonjay@mindspring.com; QwaveQ@aol.com; res0092k@gte.net; ecurry@interaccess.net; david.hurley@gte.net; fredvollrath@aol.com; LesterAdams@Mailcity.com; colemanm001@hawaii.rr.com; nspector@kasslaw.com; kahuna@nji.com; jwyatt2@tampabay.rr.com; siegels1@mindspring.com; MsuPgaDad@aol.com; kerrybrown@compuserve.com; talktome@tampabay.rr.com; Grant Halliday; Michael Murphy; Marty Zupan; Jeb Bush
Subject:	Re: A Political Trap for Jeb Bush

just so you all know, it's my understanding that many (most?) media
outlets cannot read email with attachments and may not even RECEIVE
email that has attachments, for security reasons.  
	So, not only might forwarded copies with attached docs not make it, if
anyone bothers to do the "Florida Spending chart," (which someone needs
to do pronto) it will probably have to be put on a website, where the
media can be directed to a url in email articles to view a jpg or
graphic example of the chart. any volunteers?
Rex
From:	Tim Condon <ct236@gte.net>
Sent:	Thursday, December 27, 2001 5:57 AM
To:	mkbmic@aol.com; bennett@transnational.net; bohicaman@imt.net; fmiley@worldnet.att.net; mccool1@earthlink.net; pcox@mpinet.net; sonjay@mindspring.com; QwaveQ@aol.com; res0092k@gte.net; ecurry@interaccess.net; david.hurley@gte.net; fredvollrath@aol.com; LesterAdams@Mailcity.com; colemanm001@hawaii.rr.com; nspector@kasslaw.com; kahuna@nji.com; jwyatt2@tampabay.rr.com; siegels1@mindspring.com; MsuPgaDad@aol.com; kerrybrown@compuserve.com; talktome@tampabay.rr.com; Grant Halliday; Michael Murphy; Marty Zupan

Subject:	A Political Trap for Jeb Bush
Attachments:	Political.Trap.wpd; Political.Trap.doc

> each county in the U.S. voted in the 2000 Presidential electionwill be

>         So let it begin. The Florida Runaway Spending Chart will appear 
> on billboards, in newspapers, on flyers,  in advertising, on placards, on 
> television, in magazines, on the Internet, on silk-screened 
> T-shirts...let it be seen everywhere. And let the question be asked: Do 
> we really need more state taxing and spending, like the Democrats and 
> media are telling us?
>         And then lets let the people of Florida decide.
>

From:	Tim Condon <ct236@gte.net>
Sent:	Thursday, December 27, 2001 5:55 AM
To:	mkbmic@aol.com; bennett@transnational.net; bohicaman@imt.net; fmiley@worldnet.att.net; mccool1@earthlink.net; pcox@mpinet.net; sonjay@mindspring.com; QwaveQ@aol.com; res0092k@gte.net; ecurry@interaccess.net; david.hurley@gte.net; fredvollrath@aol.com; LesterAdams@Mailcity.com; colemanm001@hawaii.rr.com; nspector@kasslaw.com; kahuna@nji.com; jwyatt2@tampabay.rr.com; siegels1@mindspring.com; MsuPgaDad@aol.com; kerrybrown@compuserve.com; talktome@tampabay.rr.com; Grant Halliday; Michael Murphy; Marty Zupan
Cc:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	A Political Trap for Jeb Bush

Greetings to Everyone: What follows is an article I have written explaining 
the poltical trap that has been laid for Florida's Gov. Jeb Bush by the 
Democrats, the media, and a prominent leading Republican. Please send this 
article to every Republican, every conservative, and every media outlet 
you're in contact with. Attached are copies of the article, one in 
Microsoft Word format and one in WordPerfect format. They may be forwarded, 
copied, printed, and reproduced at will. And I hope they are. Merry 
Christmas and Happy New Year to you all!   Tim Condon

The Deadly Political Trap
By Tim Condon
Tampa, Florida
December 27, 2001
For immediate release

         NOTE: What follows below is an explanation of the same old trap 
set for Republican officeholders by Democrats. It happens all the time. It 
made George H.W. Bush a one-term President. It made Bob Martinez a one-term 
Florida governor. And now the trap is laid for Jeb Bush. It was perfectly 
set this time by a RINO Republican (who used to be a Democrat and worked on 
Lawton Chiles campaigns), but its still the same old trick. It goes like 
this: The Democrats endlessly pressure an elected Republican to raise taxes 
for the good of the country or for the good of the state because its 
necessaryand its the right thing to do. The Republican, who is 
susceptible to this kind of entreaty because he or she actually cares about 
doing the right thing instead of playing political games, falls for the 
trap, turns against the Republican low-tax, small-government principles, 
and helps to raise taxes. Happily for the Democrats, that destroys his 
conservative voting base. Then the Democrats attack him in the election 
campaign anyway, as always, for favoring the rich and not doing enough. 
The result is that the Democratic voters all vote Democrat, and the 
Republican voters, disgusted with their turncoat candidate, either stay 
home or vote for an alternative candidate, thus handing the election to the 
Democrats. READ BELOW AND HEED!

         On December 18, 2001 newspaper headlines throughout the state of 
Florida heralded a  new master plan for increasing state taxes unveiled by 
state senate President John McKay.
         A Republican from Floridas west coast in Bradenton, McKay started 
out as a Democrat  who worked on campaigns for Democratic Senator (and 
later governor) Lawton Chiles in the 1980's, and thereafter held a staff 
position with Terrell Sessums, a Democrat and former speaker of the house 
in the Florida legislature.
         McKay has also made a name for himself over the last two years as 
the president of the Florida Senate in Tallahassee. During that time, while 
Jeb Bush has been governor, McKay has sometimes distinguished himself as 
quite partisan in a Democratic direction, as he opposed modest tax cuts and 
other proposals by Gov. Bush. Im not accountable to the Governor, he 
once said.
         Most recently McKay pulled a political stunt by shutting down the 
Florida Senate early, thus forcing the state House, led by a conservative 
Republican and still in session, to either accept bills written his way 
or reject them entirely. Because of such political shenanigans, among 
Republicans McKay has earned the sobriquet of RINO, an acronym for 
Republican In Name Only. Not unexpectedly, at the same time McKay has 
become a political darling of Floridas liberal-leaning media, not to 
mention the vastly outnumbered Democrats in the state legislature.
         Because Floridas state constitution requires a balanced budget, 
Gov. Bush was required to call two legislative sessions in 2001 to trim the 
budget (necessitated by falling state revenues which  to a degree are 
dependent on tourism which has plummeted in the wake of the World Trade 
Center disaster). As a result, the state legislature was forced to cut 
about $1 billion from a total state budget of about $50 billion.
         Now Senator McKay has unveiled a plan to increase taxes, 
essentially a green light over the long run for ever-larger state 
government. Expect to hear repeated media references to McKays courage 
and foresight, not to mention praise from Democrats statewide.
         McKays taxing plan is politically crafty. It features a current 
reduction of the state sales tax from six to four percent. It ends taxes on 
individual alcoholic drinks and continues the phase-out of the state 
intangibles tax, which is slated to expire anyway. It provides for 
three-fifths super-majorities in the future for the state legislature to 
raise the sales tax rate or expand sales tax exemptions. And it is being 
touted as revenue neutral, at least in the short term. But the real guts 
of the plan is that it ends most sales tax exemptions, including those on 
services such as advertising, lawyers fees, architects fees, and real 
estate charges, thus opening the taxation floodgates so the state 
government can take in many billions more dollars than it does now.
         Media stories noted in a muted way that Floridas legislative 
Democrats supported the McKay taxing plan, but their support will be 
low-key said one admiring newspaper article.  We have to be careful so 
were not portrayed as tax-and-spend liberals, said state representative 
Bob Henriquez of Tampa. There seemed little chance of that happening 
with  the Republican state senate president carrying water for higher 
taxing and spending.
         But what is most interesting about senator McKays maneuvering is 
not that he has turned his back on the traditional Republican themes of 
smaller government and less taxation. No. What is most notable is that his 
taxing plan lays a clever and deadly political trap for Governor Jeb Bush.
         Consider these facts: In the younger brother of the current 
President, some already see a potential future President. Smart and 
economically savvy, Jeb Bush is a member of the entrepreneurial wing of the 
Republican Party. Hes also married to a Hispanic woman and fluent in 
Spanish, attractive characteristics for an expanding and increasingly 
important bloc of voters. It has not been lost on Democratsin Florida and 
elsewherethat Jeb Bush could be a formidable future candidate for 
President of the United States. Thus, Democrats in Florida hope to destroy 
Bushs future potential by making him a one-term governor.
         With respect to the political trap being laid for Gov. Bush, 
consider the three possible outcomes: The plan for more taxes can win, be 
defeated, or pass in a modified state. Its fate lies first with the 
Republican-dominated state legislature. But more particularly, its fate 
lies in the hands of the governor himself. If Jeb Bush supports the plan, 
or some modification, it will most likely pass. If he opposes it, it will 
most likely  fail.
         If Gov. Bush supports McKays plan or some modification of it, the 
liberal media line will be paeans to his farsightedness, leadership, 
and courage. Butjust as his father did on the national stageby 
supporting higher taxes and bigger government he would alienate his 
conservative Republican base and be defeated in his re-election bid, to the 
relief and delight of Democrats everywhere. Truly a win-win situation for 
the Democrats.
         But what if Gov. Bush opposes the taxing plan, in any form? Then 
it will most likely go down to defeat, and he will be greeted by the hoots 
and catcalls of the Democrats and virtually all of Floridas left-leaning 
media outlets. As the conventional political wisdom goes, he would empower 
not only his Democratic opponents, but also alienate many of the states 
Republicans who are supposedly lusting after higher taxes and bigger state 
government.
         In other words, Jeb Bush, a rising star in the national Republican 
firmament, is damned if he does, and damned if he doesnt. Either way, it 
would seem, the Democrats and RINOs win.
         The plan seems so slick, and is being unveiled at such an 
opportune time, that its not too farfetched to foresee a triumphant 
Democratic Florida governor appointing Senator McKay to some important 
state post as a grand and magnanimous gesture of bipartisanship. It is even 
more interesting to note that McKay has announced that he wont run for his 
seat in the next election, which removes the potential distress of seeing 
what his own constituents think of his legislative shenanigans and big 
taxing plans. By doing that he has also effectively shielded himself 
from  political pressure by the state Republicans. Very slick.
         What is Jeb going to do? A victim of the failure to rein in state 
spending in the past  halcyon days of economic boom, Jeb Bush is now being 
blamed by Democrats and their media allies for economic conditions far 
beyond his control.
         What is Jeb going to do? In a typical lead paragraph after the 
Florida legislature finished a recent budget-cutting session, one newspaper 
article trumpeted McKays tax plan by writing, Hundreds of state workers 
are losing their jobs, school systems are canceling summer sessions and 
seventh periods, and at-risk youngsters are losing critical counseling 
services. Those are consequences of the $1 billion in budget cuts the 
Legislature made recently. In another article, the reporter intoned that, 
Gov. Jeb Bush must assure voters his tax cuts have not been damaging to 
the economy.
         Tax cuts? Damaging to the economy? This is the typical media line 
that Bush will have to deal with, and in Florida, as elsewhere, state media 
outlets often follow the lead of Democrat spinners.
         What is Jeb going to do? McKays tax-increase trap is almost 
exactly the same as that faced by former Florida Governor Bob Martinez, 
only the second Republican governor in modern state history. He was a 
one-term governor, thanks to the tax-and-spend issue, losing his 
re-election bid to Democrat Lawton Chiles after Martinez endorsed and the 
legislature passed a sweeping tax reform in the 1980's. Strikingly 
similar to McKays plan to increase sales taxes, the Martinez gaffe 
provoked such outrage that the state legislature hastily reversed it. 
During the following  two terms of Democrat Lawton Chiles there was nary a 
peep from the state capitol about increasing taxes. Lets face it, 
Democrats arent fools. And the economy was booming anyway, increasing the 
states tax-take every year.
         But now, like a gift from heaven for the states outnumbered 
Democrats, Republican John McKay reprises history, unveils what will 
eventually be a huge tax increase, and moves to put Jeb Bush in a deadly 
political bind.
         What is Jeb going to do? Well, there is good news: It is possible 
for Governor Bush to  escape the trap. The solution is powerful, visual, 
simple, and unarguable. All that is needed is a simple chart. It probably 
already exists. On this chart will be shown just two lines: One will show 
the growth of Florida population from, say, 1970, through to the present 
(it increased by about 235% over that time). And the other line will show 
yearly state government revenues/budgets during the same  period (which 
increased by thousands of percentage points).
         Just look at that chart! Saying Florida politicians have been 
spending like drunken sailors for 30 years would be a slander on drunken 
sailors. And the chartlike the now-famous Bush Country map showing how 
each county in the U.S. voted in the 2000 Presidential electionwill be 
everywhere.
         So let it begin. The Florida Runaway Spending Chart will appear 
on billboards, in newspapers, on flyers,  in advertising, on placards, on 
television, in magazines, on the Internet, on silk-screened T-shirts...let 
it be seen everywhere. And let the question be asked: Do we really need 
more state taxing and spending, like the Democrats and media are telling us?
         And then lets let the people of Florida decide.

 ###

-----Original Message-----
From: MCLEANED@aol.com [mailto:MCLEANED@aol.com]
Sent: Wednesday, December 26, 2001 3:24 PM
To: Jeb Bush; president@whitehouse.gov
Subject: Airport Security


I would like to make the following suggestion--In order to maintain better 
security at our airports, I suggest that we have a VOLUNTARY program where 
frequent travelers can obtain a special security card. This way people who 
volunteer to answer necessary questions can move through the screening at an 
accellerated pace. A program similar to the e-pass system that we have in 
Florida. You would actually have two lines, one for those with a pass and one 
for those who don't and require additional screening. The speed that those 
who have the pass move through the lines would encourage people to obtain a 
pass and move people on to planes more quickly. This in my opinion would be a 
much quicker and better way of loading airplanes.
Ed McLean
470 Seneca Trail
Maitland, Fl 32751

-----Original Message-----
From: Barnes, Roy <Roy@gov.state.ga.us>
To: Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>
Sent: Mon Dec 24 14:38:01 2001
Subject: RE: Water

Dear Jeb,

Thank you for your thoughtful reply to my last e-mail message.  I
appreciate your taking the time to review my ideas and to respond.  I
agree that only you and I can finally resolve this matter, and I think
that we will have a much better chance to do so, if we continue to share
our thoughts.  In the hope that our dialogue can either produce
agreement by January 15, or otherwise allow us to find a basis for
extending the negotiations until they are successful, I would like to
set out some basic premises on which I am operating, so that we can try
to isolate why we are not in agreement.  Perhaps then we can find a
better solution.

	 Your observation that the Georgia reservoir levels under either
proposal will be higher than historical while Florida will have flows
below historical may sound fair, but it  oversimplifies what is truly
involved here.  Higher reservoir levels result primarily from limiting
hydropower production, something I believe Georgia will have to pay
dearly for, although I do note that the federal government has recently
suggested that it may be necessary for Florida and Alabama to share in
this cost, since hydropower curtailment is being used to support your
flows as well as our water supply needs.  The important point is that
higher reservoir levels are equally important to both of us because it
is only with these higher levels that your instream flow demands can be
met in dry periods.  If  you change the agreement to provide for lower
reservoir levels, Florida would be hurt as much as Georgia.  As for
lower than historical flows at the Florida line, it has always been
recognized in law and in our negotiations that Georgia, as an upstream
user, is entitled to make reasonable use of the waters that originate in
and flow through its borders, and this usage over time will necessarily
reduce downstream flows to some extent. The growth, development and
economic prosperity of our State (just like yours, which has grown even
more than Georgia) would not be possible otherwise, and we have both
supported economic development in our States. In the compact
negotiations, we are simply trying to determine together what is and
what is not reasonable at this time.

	 We seem to share the view that resolving our differences by
joint work, study and negotiations is preferable to leaving these issues
to be resolved by a special master appointed by the Supreme Court.  That
is why I am having difficulty understanding your insistence that these
historic discussions must be concluded by January 15.  Our Compact is
unique in delegating to the Governors the ability to determine what the
allocation formula should be.  There is no other Compact like this one,
and I do not want to let this opportunity slip from us because our teams
have not yet found the solution.  I know  that we can find one that
works for both us, and when we do, the Compact will require that  it be
respected by all the federal agencies, so long as it does not violate
federal law. 

	Here are some reasons that I think we cannot conclude
successfully by January 15:

 First, Georgia's concern about modeling errors, extended droughts, and
lower inflows, which you referred to as "soft" issues, is a direct
result of the increase in the flows which Florida has demanded.  You
will recall that your public proposal of May 15, which we indicated
would be acceptable to us, included target flows substantially below
those you are now requiring.  Your demands now are such that we must
focus on what can go wrong, what could cause your higher flows not to be
met--because those higher flows would endanger our future if we are not
protected against historic droughts or modeling input errors, etc. What
you see as our new-found "lingering hesitance" is a direct result of
Florida's demand for increased minimum flows. 
 
Secondly, your team has stated flatly that it will make no change in
your numbers.  We do not accept this as a reasonable way to negotiate,
but it has required us to re-analyze the circumstances that might cause
those numbers to be impossible to meet, and to see whether we can come
up with some agreement on an acceptable level of exceptions.  Your team
has offered a concept of augmentation caps, and we have always thought
that concept might be the key to make this work.  So far, we have not
been able to figure out  how this approach can work, but we are
certainly diligently pursuing it.  That is not easy, and it takes time
of technical people to get it done. 
 
Thirdly, within months, we will have the new information about the
1994--2000 period, and I believe it would be irresponsible to move
forward without this information.  This information is important to both
of us, and your team should recognize that.

Fourthly, I am informed that your team has proposed significant language
changes from your May 15 draft that are not acceptable in their current
form to us.  Our respective legal teams have not been able to resolve
these differences, but I am assured by our team that, given enough time
and commitment, this could be done.

	  I still believe that it would be in the mutual best interests
of all three States to extend these discussions for a year or so, to
take the politics out of them and to allow ample time to give each State
the assurances and protections it needs.  Whether or not you can accept
a one year extension, I nevertheless sincerely hope that you will not
prematurely terminate these discussions.  As I have suggested before,
all the constituencies in both States support the continued negotiations
(except perhaps the federal preference power customers and the
navigation interests, but I don't think we should side with them to the
exclusion of all the other important interests).

5.  A couple of minor points:  You mentioned Lake Lanier.  I thought we
were fully agreed on how Lake Lanier should operate.  On issue of the
dry year multiplier for agriculture, the National Resource Conservation
Service has no more information than the experts on which we rely.  And
we pay the price, not them, if their guess if wrong.

Jeb, I know our teams are still working together, and I am glad for
that.  Let's stay in touch and help make these discussions a success for
our States and their futures. Have a Merry Christmas and I hope we both have

a more prosperous New Year. I have had enough of sagging revenues. 

Roy

-----Original Message-----
From: Jeb Bush [mailto:jeb@jeb.org]
Sent: Saturday, December 22, 2001 4:07 PM
To: Barnes, Roy
Subject: RE: Water


Dear Roy,

I appreciate all your efforts on this water allocation matter.  I agree
with you that modeling by all interested parties will continue for
decades, and some refinements may be necessary based on improved
scientific information.  This is true today, and it will be true one
year from today.  For this reason, the Compact allows the parties to
review and modify the allocation formula.

In the end of course, we, not the modelers, must decide if the initial
allocation is equitable.  At this point, Florida has done all it can to
ensure not only an equitable allocation but one with an abundant margin
of protection for Georgia.  Georgia's reservoir levels will remain above
historical levels 80% - 90% of the time.  Florida has agreed to accept
flows that are below historical flows about 65% of the time.  This is
more than fair.

Please recognize that no scientist will be able to precisely describe
the impacts of lower flows in Florida because such low flows have never
before been experienced.  This made our decision to accept lower than
historical flows a very difficult one.  The only reason Florida agreed
to accept an unprecedented low flow is to avoid the uncertainties of
litigation.

I am concerned that your team's lingering hesitance to endorse an
allocation formula that fully meets all of Georgia's own projected water
demand for the next half century suggests that Georgia is actually
seeking to consume substantially more water than ever discussed in our
work over the past 4 years.  Why, for example, does Georgia insist on a
dry year irrigation multiplier of 2.2 when the National Resource
Conservation Service has established a dry year multiplier of 1.3 - 1.5?
Even in the driest of years, the level of irrigation proposed by Georgia
would drown the crops.

My concern is compounded by the fact that after 4 years and 4
extensions, Georgia is raising "soft" issues of uncertainty such as
global warming.  It is widely recognized that climate change cycles
occur over a time span far greater than a 50-year term.  Further, some
studies have suggested that global warming is predicted to cause slight
increases in precipitation.  This new issue is clearly not one to take
us off course now. 

I was also surprised that your team informed you that water storage at
Lanier is not critical to Florida.  In times of low flow, the
contribution from Lanier is necessary to maintain the state-line flows.
There can be no allocation agreement without considering the operation
of all the federal reservoirs, including Lanier.  I thought this has
been well understood by all parties from the beginning of our
negotiations.

I understand that our staffs met this week to review modeling efforts
demonstrating that Georgia can meet Florida's state-line flows 100% of
the time, thus achieving perfect compliance while maintaining the
reservoirs in a healthy condition.  This held true using both the
Florida and Georgia models and assumptions about the future.

Your team requested some additional information, which the Florida team
will provide asap.  We have come such a long way in this process.  After
the New Year, let's plan on resolving this thing one way or the other.

Jeb



***********************************************************
Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law.
Most written communications to or from state officials
regarding state business are public records available to the
public and media upon request.   Your e-mail communications
may therefore be subject to public disclosure. 



-----Original Message-----
From: Barnes, Roy [mailto:Roy@gov.state.ga.us]
Sent: Saturday, December 15, 2001 3:51 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: RE: Water



Jeb:

Thanks for your message.  First, I want to assure you that I am fully
dedicated to finding a solution that works for both of us.  I agree that
we have made a great deal of progress and are down to a much smaller set
of issues, but of course the ones left are the hardest ones.  The very
nature of the most recent development, which in this case turned out to
be a positive one, is what makes me nervous, namely, the discovery at
this very late date of an input error in the Corp's model.  What if
there are other errors, or major climate changes such as a continuing
warming trend that further reduces inflows of water?  On that point, I
believe we are about to receive new information from the Corps covering
the period from 1994--2000, which will allow our teams to see how our
formulas would have fared in this difficult period.  But I don't think
that this information will be available until February at the
earliest--after the current deadline.

We (both our team and yours) are looking for a way to provide Georgia
with a comfortable margin of safety, while preserving necessary flows
for Florida that can be reliably assured.  Neither of us wants to make
or receive commitments that are not needed or that cannot be met.  I
understand we are still waiting to meet with your experts, which your
team offered several weeks ago, to hear their explanation for the
increases in your minimum flow demands.  And, Jeb, keep in mind that
healthy reservoir levels are critical to both of us, not just Georgia,
in low flow periods.

I hope we can reach final agreement by January 15, but I am skeptical.
My email was intended to suggest a back-up plan if final agreement is
not reached by then.  The Compact provides the best possible vehicle for
a negotiated settlement among the states.  I am not aware of a single
constituent who wants the Compact to expire without agreement.  Some of
your strongest stakeholders are even now putting forth new suggestions
for consideration in an almost frantic attempt to ensure that we will
keep working together.  I think we should keep working together until we
find the answer.  We should not give up, but at the same time, I am
concerned with the potential that political considerations could
interfere with sound policy decisions if we try to finalize an agreement
with three re-election campaigns going on.  Alabama wants to extend the
ACT and the ACF for a year.  I think that is worth considering, and I
hope that you and I will talk directly before you make a final decision
to abandon the negotiating process.

With respect to the federal litigation, please remember that we did not
start this litigation, but filed our case only after the federal power
customers raised all the critical issues affecting Georgia in another
case in Washington, D.C.  We did not want to be in Court, as your folks
know.  More importantly, we are asking for no more water in court that
we are asking for in our discussions with Florida.  And, it has already
been acknowledged in the draft agreements that Lake Lanier is not to be
used to support flows at the Florida line and that in fact Florida is
looking to the lower reservoirs for its flows.  Finally, this litigation
does not involve an allocation of waters between Florida and Georgia.
Anything this Court decides will still be subject to challenge by
Florida any time Florida desires.

I look forward to seeing you and talking with you about these and other
important matters affecting our great States.

Merry Christmas to you and your family.

Roy

-----Original Message-----
From: Jeb Bush [mailto:jeb@jeb.org]
Sent: Friday, December 14, 2001 5:21 PM
To: Barnes, Roy
Subject: RE: Water


Dear Roy,

Thank you for the note.  I understand that our teams are getting closer
and that a recent model correction improves your reservoir levels.  Good
news for you.  In fact, both states' proposals are now predicting that
Lanier will be above its historic levels 90% of the time, while the
lower federal reservoirs will be above their historic levels 80% of the
time.  

As I understand it, the only real question remaining is unrelated to any
modeling or scientific issue.  The only remaining question is, does
Georgia need a margin of error so large that it allows for Georgia to
use substantially more water than any of the states have modeled?  If
so, let's be honest, and not prolong it.  This decision won't be any
different a year from now.

Roy, this federal litigation also troubles me.  I think that Florida's
interests are not served by delaying this matter while Georgia litigates
important issues without us.

I hope you and your family are going to have a wonderful Christmas. Are
you going to pass out presents this year?

Jeb Bush 

***********************************************************
Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law.
Most written communications to or from state officials
regarding state business are public records available to the
public and media upon request.   Your e-mail communications
may therefore be subject to public disclosure.

I hope everything is going well even in spite of budget cuts and tough

are

still
modeling some alternatives and have been working well together. However,
if

talks
for a year and take it out of  discussion during an election year. This
issue does not need to come up during the heat of a political campaign,
and
the only way I know to do it is to take a year and do all of the
modeling
that is necessary and then restart the negotiations after the 02
election.
Alabama wants to do this on the ACT, and I agree. I think Ga and Fla
should
do the same ACF. Let me have your thoughts. 

REB
