From:	Jeb Bush
Sent:	Tuesday, December 25, 2001 4:35 PM
To:	Michael Hansen (E-mail)
Cc:	Arduin, Donna (OPB) (E-mail)

is this true? I don't remember a $10 million cut.
 
State slashes services for low-income AIDS patients

The Associated Press (Ran in the Ft. Lauderdale Sun-Sentinel)

December 25, 2001

ST. PETERSBURG  A special Medicaid program for 6,000 of the state's sickest 

AIDS patients is facing a $10 million cut, nearly half its funding.

Project AIDS Care is losing its funding as part of the more than $1 billion 

cut from the state budget. The program was designed to save the state money 

by allowing poor patients with full-blown AIDS to continue living, and to 

die, in their own homes, rather than in nursing homes or hospitals.

Officials with hospice groups and other agencies contend the reductions are 

shortsighted and likely will force more patients into institutions, costing 

more in the long run.

"I'm just at a complete loss. I am convinced somebody in Tallahassee does 

not understand the ramifications," said Lorraine Langlois, executive 

director of Metropolitan Charities Inc. in St. Petersburg, which has 250 

clients in the program.

Medicaid administrator Bob Maryanski said agency staff tried to choose cuts 

that would disrupt patients as little as possible.

"The last thing we wanted to do was to cut services to this population," 

Maryanski said. "It's a fragile population, and most of the patients who use 

this service have serious medical problems. They can't do a lot for 

themselves."

As proposed, the cuts would eliminate five in-home services: physical 

therapy, housekeeping, health assessment, pest control and therapeutic 

massage. Several more would be significantly reduced, including in-home meal 

service.

But the toughest loss, advocates say, would be a two-thirds cut in case 

management.

For sick people who rely on public assistance, a case manager helps the 

patient navigate the bureaucracy and find free or low-cost services to 

augment government aid.

Currently, Medicaid pays case managers $44 per hour. A typical case manager 

has about 40 clients and spends about three hours a month on each, Langlois 

said.

Under the proposed cuts, Medicaid will pay just $50 per client per month. 

That will force agencies to fire some case managers and give the rest more 

clients than they can adequately serve, officials said.

 

Copyright  2001, South Florida Sun-Sentinel

Jeb Bush

-----Original Message-----
From: Maryann_Fiala@aeanet.org [mailto:Maryann_Fiala@aeanet.org]
Sent: Thursday, December 20, 2001 4:49 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: High Tech Legislator of the Year Award from AeA


Dear Governor Bush,

I wanted to take a moment to share with you  a page from our  website.
A
link to view the page where you are featured is included, along with a
word
file of the same. AeANET will relaunch on January 2, 2002 with
completely
updated content and greater flexibility.

Governor Bush, the AeA, as the nation's oldest and largest high tech
trade
association, works quite effectively with governors throughout the
United
States.  In Florida, the AeA has two offices.  One in South Florida and
one
in Orlando.  We hope that you will look to us for information concerning
the high tech industry on a local, regional, state, national and
international basis.  The AeA has over 3500 member companies
representing
over 3.5 million high tech workers.  Fortune magazine ranked the AeA as
the
60th most effective lobbying organization on Capitol Hill. The AeA was
the
only technology association on that list.  Earlier this year, the AeA
hosted a meeting for 28 technology company CEOs with President Bush (I
know
you are well acquainted with our President)  to discuss the need for
legislation granting TPA.  Included in that number were several Florida
CEOs.  AeA led the coalition of high tech industry concerns that was
instrumental in securing a victory in the House for TPA.  We are working
hard to make this happen in the Senate as well.

In addition to our efforts on the Hill, the AeA has lobbyists in
fourteen
states, including Florida and in Florida we formed the AeA Tech Florida
PAC
to allow technology companies to support candidates that are pro-high
tech.

Governor Bus, the AeA is here in Florida to promote the interests of the
high tech industry, one that already plays a vital role in Florida's
economy as evidenced by the fact that over 36% of all Florida's exports
are
from the high tech industry (Source: Cyberstates 2001).

I ask that you include the AeA as part of your ITFlorida initiative.  We
can be a tremendous resource for this group.

I am honored to extend an invitation to you to attend our Technology
Executive Forum: A Conversation with Florida's Technology Leaders, in
Orlando Florida on February 21, 2002.  This event is for CEOs of
technology
companies across the High Tech Corridor.  It will be held at Portofino
Bay
Hotel from 11:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m. We have several of our industry's
leaders presiding over a panel discussion on the business climate for
high
tech companies in Florida.  We would be pleased to have you address the
group as well to discuss your vision of Florida's high tech future.   It
is
anticipated that we will have 100 - 150 CEOs in attendance.

My best regards to you and your family for a wonderful holiday and peace
and prosperity in the New Year.  I hope that you will call upon the AeA
to
be of service to the great state of Florida.


Maryann Fiala
Executive Director, Florida Council
AeA - Advancing the Business of Technology
12565 Research Parkway Suite 300
Orlando, Florida 32826
Phone: 407-882-2425

From:	Jeb Bush

-----Original Message-----
From: Paul Ferguson <paulferguson@worldnet.att.net>
To: Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>
Sent: Mon Dec 24 09:49:32 2001
Subject: SR 200 law suit

Several weeks ago, I emailed you about the county;s plan to sue DOT for the
miserable contract administration on SR 200 west of Ocala -- in the heart of
thousands of good GOP voters!
Here is today's editorial from the star banner from their on line site . . .
. Merry Christmas and may god bless the Bush family and all Florida. pwf

		Our Opinion Editorial for 12/24/2001 Push comes to shove on SR 200   It's
amazing what a law suit can do? Consider the legal action recently taken by
the Marion County Commission to sue the Florida Department of Transportation
over work that had slowed to a snail's pace along State Road 200. Suddenly,
the highway has become a beehive of activity, say those who requested that
the county sue.  "It looks like a real road project now,'' said Glenn Lane,
one of those who approached the commission about the problem. "Before, it
looked like if workers didn't have anything else to do, they sent them over
here to SR 200. The law suit may very well have had a beneficial affect."
At the urging of Lane and business owners who ran out of patience with the
ongoing construction of additional lanes along SR 200, the Marion County
Commission went where no other county had gone before on such an issue. It
decided enough was enough. The commission is suing Florida's Department of
Transportation. People and businesses along SR 200 have been inconvenienced
for so long that some businesses have closed down.  But the main bone of
contention has been White Construction. On June 14, 1999, the DOT awarded
the $17.8 million contract to White. But DOT officials have acknowledged
this company has had a dismal record on road projects. Substandard work and
chronic delays have put White Construction in ill-favor with the state and
county.  Still, the DOT claims its hands are often tied because of the
state's competitive bid process. Also, DOT officials say they have little
power to put pressure to White. The DOT can fine the company for every day
it's late completing a project. But even that hasn't brought results. White
has simply filed counter claims  often prevailing. Even an $850,000 bonus
to complete SR 200 by this past June failed to move White forward on the
construction.  Recently, Steve Homan, public information officer for DOT
District 5 in DeLand, made an implied threat in a letter to the editor of
this newspaper.  "The county's suit could have significant negative
consequences with regard to future funding of transportation projects; is
essentially a criticism of the department for obeying the laws; damages
relationships on hosts of other projects throughout the county; represents
an unnecessary and pointless expense for Marion County taxpayers and the
FDOT; and can accomplish absolutely nothing with regard to accelerating work
on State Road 200,'' Homan wrote.  Interesting, in light of the work pace
suddenly picking up along the highway.  It does not bode well with a
community when the DOT suggests looking at this county with disfavor when it
comes to state road projects.   Lane said Homan's letter simply, "proves
just how negligent they (DOT) are. If you say anything about it, then they
say they won't give us any projects. That they think they have the right to
do anything they want with taxpayer's money, shows their arrogance. It's
their obligation to help fund roads in Marion County. The DOT's cavalier
attitude is heinous."   Lane believes the state will avoid going to trial
over this issue because it would send a negative message to counties
experiencing similar problems with contractors hired by the state. Other
county's might also decide to stop accepting DOT excuses and file suit.  The
DOT's feathers are no doubt ruffled, but that's a small consequence compared
to the misery drivers have endured year after year on SR 200. Marion County
is tired of excuses

-----Original Message-----
From: Kanga30@aol.com [mailto:Kanga30@aol.com]
Sent: Monday, December 24, 2001 8:15 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: GOPCHIC@aol.com
Subject: College and Minorities


Dear Governor Bush:
An article in this morning's Miami Herald is taking you to task because only 
43 students have been helped byte Talented 20 program.  

Where does it say that everyone must go to college?  I am not sure whether or 
not my mechanic has a college degree but who cares.  I certainly am glad that 
he chose to be a mechanic.  Not everyone is an Einstein or a Hemingway and 
who cares.  

My husband and I are both college graduates-I am a retired teacher and my 
husband has his degree in education but retired from Sears.  He was a 
department manager.  

I have five children, ranging in age from 49 to 38.  They all attended 
college but there is not a graduate among them.  However, they are all wage 
earners and living rather well.

  My oldest daughter recently became an Assistant Manager at Washington 
Mutual. 
She has an AA degree from Miami-Dade Community College.  She worked for 
Eastern Airlines but chose to be a stay home Mom for her three children.  Now 
she is working to put her three children through college.

 My oldest son has an AA degree but due to some physical handicaps, he does 
not have an outstanding job.  He works for Publix and he gives a good days 
work and the customers love him.

My second son works for the Assurant Group, formerly American Bankers 
Insurance Group.  He joined the Marine Corps when he was 17, graduated from 
Boot Camp as Honor Man and served four years in the corps.  When he returned 
home, he went to work for Southeast Banks.  Not knowing a bit from a byte, he 
was a night manager in their Data Processing department with expertise in 
Disaster Recovery.  He attended the community some but does not have an 
entire year to his credit.  

My middle daughter was employed by Royal Caribbean Cruise Lines for 22 years. 
 She joined them when she was 19.  As a result of the 9/11 attack, she was 
severed in October.  When she left, she was earning $24.00 an hour or in that 
bracket.  The department in which she was working was consolidated with 
another department and only one person out of five was retained by RCCL.  She 
is receiving a substantial severance pay and is planning to hone her computer 
skills after Christmas by attending computer classes.

My youngest daughter is a lieutenant with Miami-Dade Fire Rescue.  She is a 
paramedic and earning a salary equal to her brother-in-law, a lieutenant with 
Miami Dade Police department, holding a Master's degree in Law enforcement.  
She attended Florida State but did not graduate because she was too immature 
to go away from home.  

We were not eligible, at that time, for financial because we owned our home.  
This was 1981.  Of course, my husband is a first generation American of 
Portuguese descent.  His parents came to this country from Madeira Island.  
Our disadvantage was that we are white and not considered Hispanic even 
though our last name is Silva.  

I may be drifting from my original thoughts.  I apologize.  I am so 
distressed to read about the lack of minorities in college.  Did anyone think 
that maybe they didn''t want to go or did not apply themselves after they got 
there?  

My point, I suppose, is that where there is a will, there is a way.  I 
started college in 1948 at the University of Miami because my grandmother 
paid for one semester.  Then due to transportation and finances, I did not go 
back the following semester.  I received a grant from the University of Miami 
for another year of college because they were trying to encourage Dade County 
students to attend the UM.  But I met my husband and after deciding to marry. 
did not feel right about accepting more money.

We raised the five children.  I did attend another semester and with two 
years of college was able to become a substitute teacher.  In 1962, I 
received an NDEA loan and completed two years of college in 14 months.  I 
graduated from the University of Miami in August 1963, a month before I 
delivered my fifth child.  I taught for 29 years at the school where I did my 
student teaching.  I am now retired and enjoying my grandchildren.

I just feel that my family is a good example of what one can do when one 
wants to do.  College is not necessarily the path for everyone.  The world 
needs some Indians, we can't all be chiefs.

Thank you for taking time to read this.  You are doing a great job as 
Governor.  I am at ease with you and President Bush at the helms of our state 
and nation.  

Merry Christmas and Happy New Year.

Mrs. N. Jane M. Silva

From:	Dana, Pamella <pamella.dana@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Sunday, December 23, 2001 5:11 PM

Subject:	FW: Costs for SOUTHCOM HQ

 

-----Original Message-----
From: Rhodes0711@cs.com
To: pamella.dana@myflorida.com; RhodesM@hq.southcom.mil
Sent: 12/22/01 10:54 PM
Subject: Re: Costs for SOUTHCOM HQ

Pam...am on holiday vacations...thus my home e-mail. 

Purchase valuation was based on private sector real estate company
estimation as part of late 1999 study (which recommended we purchase in
lieu of continued leasing or moving, most cost-effective alternative). 

Valuation was by the Staubach Group (out of Texas I believe).  They were
asked to give us an appreciated valuation for 2002 purchase...their
estimation was $36.1 million (which we added 10% to for submission to
Congress knowing the existing owner would never settle for actual
valuation...from past experience he probably wouldn't have accepted 10%
over either...would have been up to courts to make him accept fair
valuation...nevertheless, that's where we came up with the $40 million
almopst requested from Congress last year).  The valuation by Staubach
Group was based on actual recent sales of similar office space and raw,
unimproved land in the local market.   

We have not had a newer valuation done (though we are in the midst of
trying to get a validation on the old valuation...this probably won't be
completed until April  2002). 

As an aside, Beacon Council thinks the cost/value is a bit high...they
also would love to work a fallback option whereby we (federal
government) get a great deal to use the Ryder headquarters across the
street...since they are looking to move to a smaller building in 16
months). 

Hope this provides the info you needed.  Happy holidays. 



In a message dated 12/21/01 7:44:37 PM Eastern Standard Time,
pamella.dana@myflorida.com writes:

The Governor wants to know the following: 

How was cost and value of SOUTHCOM land and headquarters established? 

On the $40 million purchase figure floating around Congress last
year...how 
did that number come about? 

What is market value now?  How is this figure derived? 

-----Original Message----- 
From: Rhodes, Michael, SES (L) [mailto:RhodesM@hq.southcom.mil] 
Subject: Costs for SOUTHCOM HQ 



Current lease costs.  Total for HQ property is $3.1 million per year.
Total 
for additional space (office/warehouse) in the area, $1.2 million per
year. 

~ HQ Building.  Current lease expires Feb 2008.  Lease costs are 
approximately $2 million per year. 

~ Land.  Land for security buffer surrounding the HQ (19+ acres) is 
currently has authorityto lease (through condemnation proceedings) 
year-to-year through Feb 2008 for $1-$1.1 million per year. 

~ State land.  Land from State to complete security buffer (15 acres) is
$0 
per year for 50 years. 
to leased and land Purchase. 

~ Additional neighboring leases.  Currently a patchwork of seven 2 - 5
year 
leases to supplement HQ space at a cost of $1.2 million per year.  These

leases account for 30% of our total office space, and there is a small 
amount for warehouse.  Ideally we would develop an Annex next the the 
current HQ and eliminate these other leases.     

Purchase. 

~ The last time DoD considered pursuing authorization to purchase (last 
year...for FY02 purchase) the cost was estimated to be $40 million.   

~ This would have purchased the HQ building and land.  A logical
follow-on 
would have been to develop the Annex structure at a cost of around $16 
million.   

~ As an aside...truth in lending requires that I say, it is likely
purchase 
would require some type of court proceeding based on the experience with
the 
buffer land.  In the case of the buffer land the Corps of Engineers
(they 
are our agent for real estate issues) offered 125% of valuation for the
land 
lease but the owner countered at approximately 200% of value for best
offer. 
Thus the Corps had to execute a lease through condemnation (whereby the 
courts ensure fair value compensation to the owner).

Subject: airplane


Dear Governor Bush,  I have a question for you. I heard a radio talk show person yesterday here in Orlando going on and on about an airplane that is being refurbished to be on display at the entrance to the Sanford Int Airport in Sanford. He was totally upset because he said so much money had been cut from the state budget, including $300 million dollars from the education budget, and yet you did not veto the bill for the state government to pay $150,000 for the refurbishing of this airplane, just for a momento to the veterans who flew in it, and for an unnecessary display.  I would also tend to think of this as an extravagence, when there are so many higher priorities. Please let me know what you know of this expenditure and if the information is true. This radio personality reaches alot of people in our area and has alot of influence on how people react to the issues.  Thank you for your time. Teresa Young.

Sent: Thursday, December 20, 2001 4:49 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: High Tech Legislator of the Year Award from AeA


Dear Governor Bush,

I wanted to take a moment to share with you  a page from our  website.  A
link to view the page where you are featured is included, along with a word
file of the same. AeANET will relaunch on January 2, 2002 with completely
updated content and greater flexibility.

Governor Bush, the AeA, as the nation's oldest and largest high tech trade
association, works quite effectively with governors throughout the United
States.  In Florida, the AeA has two offices.  One in South Florida and one
in Orlando.  We hope that you will look to us for information concerning
the high tech industry on a local, regional, state, national and
international basis.  The AeA has over 3500 member companies representing
over 3.5 million high tech workers.  Fortune magazine ranked the AeA as the
60th most effective lobbying organization on Capitol Hill. The AeA was the
only technology association on that list.  Earlier this year, the AeA
hosted a meeting for 28 technology company CEOs with President Bush (I know
you are well acquainted with our President)  to discuss the need for
legislation granting TPA.  Included in that number were several Florida
CEOs.  AeA led the coalition of high tech industry concerns that was
instrumental in securing a victory in the House for TPA.  We are working
hard to make this happen in the Senate as well.

In addition to our efforts on the Hill, the AeA has lobbyists in fourteen
states, including Florida and in Florida we formed the AeA Tech Florida PAC
to allow technology companies to support candidates that are pro-high tech.

Governor Bus, the AeA is here in Florida to promote the interests of the
high tech industry, one that already plays a vital role in Florida's
economy as evidenced by the fact that over 36% of all Florida's exports are
from the high tech industry (Source: Cyberstates 2001).

I ask that you include the AeA as part of your ITFlorida initiative.  We
can be a tremendous resource for this group.

I am honored to extend an invitation to you to attend our Technology
Executive Forum: A Conversation with Florida's Technology Leaders, in
Orlando Florida on February 21, 2002.  This event is for CEOs of technology
companies across the High Tech Corridor.  It will be held at Portofino Bay
Hotel from 11:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m. We have several of our industry's
leaders presiding over a panel discussion on the business climate for high
tech companies in Florida.  We would be pleased to have you address the
group as well to discuss your vision of Florida's high tech future.   It is
anticipated that we will have 100 - 150 CEOs in attendance.

My best regards to you and your family for a wonderful holiday and peace
and prosperity in the New Year.  I hope that you will call upon the AeA to
be of service to the great state of Florida.


Maryann Fiala
Executive Director, Florida Council
AeA - Advancing the Business of Technology
12565 Research Parkway Suite 300
Orlando, Florida 32826
Phone: 407-882-2425
Fax: 407-737-2512
Maryann_Fiala@aeanet.org
(See attached file: GovernorBushonAeANET.jpg)   (See attached file: AeA
Florida Council Awards.doc)

From:	Jeb Bush
Sent:	Saturday, December 22, 2001 3:35 PM
To:	'Maryann_Fiala@aeanet.org'
Subject:	RE: High Tech Legislator of the Year Award from AeA

Thank you Maryann. I appreciate the information on AeA. I will make sure our economic development folks get in touch with you next week or the first week of january. Merry Christmas.

Jeb Bush 

***********************************************************
Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law.
Most written communications to or from state officials
regarding state business are public records available to the
public and media upon request.   Your e-mail communications
may therefore be subject to public disclosure.

-----Original Message-----
From: N T Lupo [mailto:ntlupo@hotmail.com]
Sent: Thursday, December 20, 2001 12:44 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Happy Holidays


Dear Honorable Jeb Bush:
 
Would like to wish you, your family and your staff and Happy Holiday and Best Wishes for the New Year.
As I/we all know, you as any representative of the people have a challenging job, I thank you for listening to my concerns/views of the last year. As we may sometimes have different views, we must keep an open mind to the opinions of others. I thank you for your good service in always responding to me.
 
Lastly, on a safety note, driving yesterday on I-75, from Venice North to the Skyway Bridge, I must say in my 40 years of driving, and proud to say with a 100% safe driver record, we clearly need more law enforcement on our highways. It is sad that some drivers don't respect the posted speed limit and other traffic laws. I must say, I  have never seen it so bad with speeders [going the posted 70MPH, many fly by and must be going 80 or more! Many seen cutting in and out of traffic and coming up behind you to close, etc. Suggestion, anything you could do to provide more assistance to our hard working State Patrol division as in more enforcement officers and radar units would be wonderful. Without question, we need to get the bad drivers off the road to include those that are drunk or reckless. Just an idea for your consideration.
God Bless and thank you for your interest. Norm Lupo

Marie

In Remembrance


President Bush: 
THE WORLD WILL ALWAYS REMEMBER SEPTEMBER 11

"For those of us who lived through these events, the only marker  we'll ever need is the tick of a clock at the 46th minute of the eighth hour of the 11th day. We will remember where we were and  how we felt. We will remember the dead and what we owe them. We  will remember what we lost and what we found."  


December 11, 2001

"Marines raised the Stars and Stripes ...

... over the long-abandoned embassy on a cold Monday morning, inaugurating what U.S. envoy James F. Dobbins vowed would be a lasting commitment to the rebuilding of war-ravaged Afghanistan.  'Today's ceremony symbolizes the return, after more than a decade of absence, of the United States to Afghanistan,' Dobbins said, presiding over a rain-soaked ceremony in the embassy's front courtyard. 'We are here, and we are here to stay.'"  (MS-NBC, 12/17/01)

The flag originally flew over the Twin Towers on September 11, and was sent to the Marines by the New York Police Department.  Facts about the  <http://www.grassroots-usa.com/us_flag_sent_to_afganistan.htm> Flag from Ground Zero

Today's Message from the White House...

  <http://www.grassroots-usa.com/_themes/grassroots-1-2000-stars-2-/bullet.gif> 	
Osama bin Laden is a coward who sends people to their deaths without their knowledge.

  <http://www.grassroots-usa.com/_themes/grassroots-1-2000-stars-2-/bullet.gif> 	
Al Qaeda murders innocents including women and children and Muslims.

  <http://www.grassroots-usa.com/_themes/grassroots-1-2000-stars-2-/bullet.gif> 	
We are a long way from finished in Afghanistan.  

  <http://www.grassroots-usa.com/_themes/grassroots-1-2000-stars-2-/bullet.gif> 	
Much difficult and dangerous work is yet to come. 

  <http://www.grassroots-usa.com/_themes/grassroots-1-2000-stars-2-/bullet.gif> 	
Many terrorists are still hiding in heavily fortified bunkers in rugged territory. 

  <http://www.grassroots-usa.com/_themes/grassroots-1-2000-stars-2-/bullet.gif> 	
They are said to be prepared for a long stay underground. 

  <http://www.grassroots-usa.com/_themes/grassroots-1-2000-stars-2-/bullet.gif> 	
But they are in for a sudden change of plans - because one by one, we are going to find them. 

  <http://www.grassroots-usa.com/_themes/grassroots-1-2000-stars-2-/bullet.gif> 	
Piece by piece, we will destroy their network of terror.

  


  <http://www.grassroots-usa.com/images/military/marines_26th_expeditionary_unit.jpg> 


READY OR NOT HERE THEY COME - U.S. Marines with the 26th Marine Expeditionary Unit (Special Operations Capable) deployed off USS Bataan's Amphibious Ready Group arrive ready at an undisclosed location with field gear and weapons. Photo by Chief Photographer's Mate Johnny Bivera, USN 

Send  <http://www.defenselink.mil/afis/afrts/video/Dec2001/20011217.ram> Greetings to Troops - Video 




 <http://www.grassroots-usa.com/send_holiday_greeting.htm> To: Any service member. Send our troops your Holiday Wishes. Go. 
The traditional holiday letter-writing program to the men and women serving in the U.S. military had to be suspended this year because of concerns about mail delivery. But now there's a new way to contact them.  

  <http://www.grassroots-usa.com/images/bullet.gif> 	 <http://anyservicemember.navy.mil/MessageSend.html> Send a holiday message to our troops.	
  <http://www.grassroots-usa.com/_themes/grassroots-1-2000-stars-2-/bullet.gif> 	Read  <http://anyservicemember.navy.mil/MessageSelect.html> holiday messages to our troops.	
	

  <http://www.grassroots-usa.com/_themes/grassroots-1-2000-stars-2-/hrule.gif> 


 <http://www.nytimes.com/2001/12/16/nyregion/16WIDO.html> 
Victims' Families Find No Salve in Holidays


New  <http://www.nytimes.com/2001/12/16/nyregion/16WIDO.html> York Times, By SHAILA K. DEWAN, December 16, 2001

Thanksgiving was hard enough. And now there are the dozens of little rituals that make up a Christmas, each one a sugared plum with a bitter center.  So Elizabeth Kovalcin knelt before her fireplace in Hudson, N.H., to hang up stockings labeled with names: one for Rebecca, 4; one for Marina, 1 1/2; and one for herself. But, surveying her work, she realized she would have to put up one more. The one that read "David," the name of her husband, who died on Sept. 11.  "I could not not have it up," she said.  Rebecca, spotting the arrangement, made her change it once more, insisting, "I want Daddy next to me."  Full  <http://www.nytimes.com/2001/12/16/nyregion/16WIDO.html> story


 <http://www.nytimes.com/pages/national/portraits/> Portraits of Grief


New  <http://www.nytimes.com/pages/national/portraits/> York Times Special Section.  Provides personal profiles of victims of September 11th attack.

From:	Jeb Bush
Sent:	Saturday, December 22, 2001 3:13 PM
To:	'Matthew Gomez'
Cc:	'jjohn78196@aol.com'
Subject:	RE: CollegisEduprise higher education technology deals / Merry Christmas

Thank you Matt. I will try to make it to your office in 2002.
 
Jeb Bush 

***********************************************************
Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law.
Most written communications to or from state officials
regarding state business are public records available to the
public and media upon request.   Your e-mail communications
may therefore be subject to public disclosure. 
-----Original Message-----
From: Matthew Gomez [mailto:mgomez@collegis.com]
Sent: Wednesday, December 19, 2001 4:51 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: 'jjohn78196@aol.com'
Subject: CollegisEduprise higher education technology deals / Merry Christmas


Gov. Bush:
 
Hi, it's Matt Gomez in Orlando. I want to keep you up-to-date on some recent technology deals in higher education signed by my company, CollegisEduprise, Inc. ( www.collegiseduprise.com <http://www.collegiseduprise.com/> ) in the past several weeks.
 
As you may already know by having met Tom Huber, our president and COO, CollegisEduprise is based in Maitland and works exclusively with colleges and universities to improve technology on campus and online. We are proud to announce two recent deals with Salt Lake Community College and Slippery Rock University of Pennsylvania that have netted $29 million in contract revenues for our corporation, and should stand to raise our profile in Central Florida and beyond as an industry leader: http://www.collegiseduprise.com/root/pages/29.asp
 
Our efforts prove that there is a wealth of talent and opportunity in our state and we welcome the chance to spread the word of our successes so many other Florida companies and entrepreneurs may be inspired to do the same.
 
During your next Central Florida visit, we'd love to have you stop by our offices to view our Network Operations Center, which provides security monitoring systems for more than 120 higher education clients, and to meet the people who are fine examples of how a Florida high tech company is helping to improve educational opportunities for people throughout the world.
 
Please accept my best wishes and blessings for a joyous Christmas holiday for the entire family.
 
Regards,
 
Matt Gomez
Director of Media Relations
Collegis - A CollegisEduprise company
2300 Maitland Center Parkway, Suite 340

Subject: Kairos Horizons


Dear Governor Bush
My name is Glen Gott and since it began I have been 
a godparent in the Kairos Horizons program at the 
Tomoka Correctional Institution here in Daytona Beach.
I heard a very distressing rumor the other day that the 
decision as to which inmates can apply for acceptance 
into the program has been taken out of the hands of the 
chaplain and is being decided by prison officials. It 
is also rumored that the program is going to be taken 
out of the main unit and transferred over to the work 
camp and application to the program will be limitted to 
only those inmates that have less than 3 years on their 
sentence.
First of all, havent we learned yet that spiritual 
things belong in the hands of spiritual leaders? 1st 
Corinthians 2:14 says, But the natural man receiveth 
NOT the things of the Spirit of God: for they are 
foolishness unto him: NEITHER can he (the natural man) 
know them, because they are SPIRITUALLY discerned.
Second, my godson has a life sentence and after 3 
weeks of showing him the Bible and by being an example 
to him he has accepted Jesus as his Savior. Can we deny 
ANY man the opportunity to see and accept Jesus just 
because he has a sentence of more than 3 years?
PLEASE Sir, dont let this happen! Spiritual things 
belong in the hands of spiritual people.
God bless you.
Glen Gott

Good Morning, Jeb,

It was a pleasure seeing you last week to hear your speech at the 22nd
annual TaxWatch meeting at the Ponte Vedra Inn.  You have done an excellent
job as Governor of our fine state.  I was especially interested in your
remarks about the 'Hot Mantra' of the time:  "Hire the Right People For the
Right Job'!

I am a Telecommunications Consultant who has learned that all organizations
face 2 kinds of problems:  Systems (whether telecom, data, utilities, etc.)
and People!  I have partnered with experts in all these arenas to be able to
solve these problems.  Undeniably, People problems are the first priority.

I have assessment tools that are used for pre-Hire and post-Hire that are
EEOC compliant and ADA and psychologist certified and validated as recently
as this year.  These tools give the organization the capability to correctly
Job Match and Career Path those high quality individuals you want to retain.
If employees are happy in their job and see the organization is interested
enough in them to develop a career strategy, they will perform at top
levels!

I have prepared a Power Point Slide Show for you to review showing
Department of Labor statistics and proven reduction of job turnover thus
improving the "Bottom Line"!

I have also set up your own sample assessment Website:  Please go to
www.profilesontheweb.com, click on Login.  User name is State of Florida and
password is 12345.  You will be able to see the full range of tests
available and sample reports to be used in coaching your staff.

call for an appointment?

-----Original Message-----
From: Ronald D. Jones [mailto:serc@fiu.edu]
Sent: Tuesday, December 18, 2001 12:51 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: South FL Ecosystem Restoration Task Force


Dear Governor Bush,
 
As you know I was appointed to the Working Group of the South Florida Ecosystem Restoration Task Force by your office through Allison DeFoor.  As such I was told that I represented your/Allisons office on the Working Group and reported directly to Allison.  In addition I also conducted a number of other tasks, including developing the Acceleration Plan for Phase 2, PSTA development, and other tasks as assigned.  I conducted all of these activities under the auspices of your/Allisons office and represented myself as such.  After Allison left I was left without a Task Force member to report to and thus represent no one on the Working Group.  This has put me in a very difficult position as no matter how hard I work on issues I do not have a senior person to report to.  I have been told that the Secretary of the Interior will be sending you a letter shortly asking for confirmation of your appointments to the Task Force.  I would greatly appreciate it if you could let me know who you will be appointing to take Allisons place and if you wish me to report to this person.  I feel that I can be of significant service to your office and wish to continue in my role on the Working Group, but without a Task Force member to report to this activity seems futile.  Although I currently serve as an advisory consultant to FDEP (Denver) it would not be appropriate for me to report to him as FDEP is represented on both the Task Force and Working Group already.
 
I know you have not requested my advice but, I would like to suggest to you that the office Allison held in your administration was very important and that without someone outside of FDEP looking at Everglades issues specifically, these matters are not being handled as effectively as before.  I would recommend that you reestablish this position as it would greatly assist in the coordination of Everglades restoration.
 
Thank you for your time and consideration.
 
Sincerely,
 
Ron 
 
Dr. Ronald D. Jones, Director and Professor
Southeast Environmental Research Center and
Department of Biological Sciences
Florida International University
University Park, OE 148
Miami, FL 33199

-----Original Message-----
From: Joseph Michael [mailto:Michael.Joseph@HCAHealthcare.com]
Sent: Tuesday, December 18, 2001 12:39 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: 'kathleen.shanahan@myflorida.com'; 'brian.yablonski@myflorida.com'
Subject: Trauma Program at Westside Regional Medical Center


Dear Governor Bush:

	I am the Chief Executive Officer of Westside Regional Medical
Center.  I am writing to you regarding a matter that is of significant
importance and urgency to Westside and HCA, East Florida Division.  Westside
has filed its Letter of Intent to make application for a trauma center to be
located in its facility.  Westside is located in Plantation, West Broward
County, Florida.  There are currently three trauma centers in Broward
County, all of which are located at the I-95 boundary.  Although the
Department of Health rule allows for "a minimum of 4" trauma centers in
Broward, the Department has indicated that it intends to reject the
applications to establish a fourth trauma center.

	As you are aware, 55% of Broward residents live west of I-95.  As
you can imagine, in a trauma situation travel time can be a matter of life
and death.  I am personally aware of this critical issue.  My nephew's life
was in jeopardy while waiting one hour for transport to the trauma facility
in Dade County.  Unfortunately, Dade only has two trauma facilities.
Additionally, the transport issues involved from west to east Broward create
an unnecessary burden on the EMS and firefighters.  Our demographic data
indicates that 39% of the trauma cases in Broward County could be better
served by a facility west of I-95.  The Department's rejection of this
proposal unnecessarily weakens the medical service to these trauma victims.

	I understand that the public hospitals very carefully guard their
trauma business.  However, both the taxpayers of Broward County and the
citizens of the State of Florida underwrite that business.  It seems prudent
for the Department to permit the establishment of the fourth trauma center,
not only to serve those west Broward residents but also to alleviate the
financial burden on the county and state.  Westside/HCA would receive no
public funds to create this necessary trauma center.  Shareholders NOT
taxpayers would underwrite the costs associated.

	I would welcome the opportunity to discuss this matter with you and
your staff at your convenience.  I sincerely hope that we could have that
chance before the Department takes some action that closes the door to this
opportunity.

Michael G. Joseph
Chief Executive Officer
Westside Regional Medical Center
8201 West Broward Blvd.
Plantation, FL  33324
Phone: (954) 476-3915
Home: (305) 273-0882
Cellular: (305) 773-8887

From: MNoltePEC@aol.com [mailto:MNoltePEC@aol.com]
Sent: Friday, December 21, 2001 9:51 PM

Subject: Retaliation of the DOC


Dear Governor Bush:
The DOC has been vindictive because of what I have done to try to help.  It makes me physically ill. 

I called your attention, to a young incarcerated man -C. Elliott (Tomoka) who requested the Doctor's continuance of adult diapers -- because he was soiling himself.  He was embarrassed and afraid of going out on the compound because of the inability of control of his incontinence problem.  When I first learned of this young man's problem, he was emotionally stable and working very well in the educational department with one of my student.  All he was requesting was for his adult diapers to be continued.  He wrote a formal grievance to the DOC.  He also wrote a letter asking me for help in this problem.

Since my involvement he was restricted to the medical department-not allowed to communicate with his family--kept in medical confinement -- sent to Butler C I for temporary stay (with diapers), and then onto Lake C I into a Behavioral program...(without diapers)...because they his say incontinence is all in his head.  (Did they ever have a specialist review his back and spine injury?) His emotional well-being has been shattered.  The treatment he has received has obliterated his emotional stability. 

You know, it really shouldn't matter why a person is incontinent, if emotionally you need the security of adult diapers-you should have them. The American civil rights act under section 504, disability act, suggests that it is his right to have them.

The DOC has taken a young man with an incontinence problem and has emotionally abused him to the point of causing his mental health to disintegrate.  Would I tell you this if it wasn't true?

Is this what you were thinking should happen when you wanted the DOC to look into this?

This Christmas will not be a happy one for this young man and his mother.

Sincerely,
Marlene Nolte-Director
4907 Coral Blvd.
Bradenton, FL 34210

-----Original Message-----
From: LGKeegan@aol.com [mailto:LGKeegan@aol.com]
Sent: Friday, December 21, 2001 3:49 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: frank.brogan@myflorida.com; jim.horne@fldoe.org;
brownb@eog.state.fl.us
Subject: Teacher Professionalism/ELC



Dear Governor Bush,

I first want to welcome you as the Education Leaders Coucil's newest and
most prominent member.  I greatly appreciate your confidence in our work. We 
are very proud of what has been accomplished in Florida over the last three 
years and look forward to continuing to support your efforts to improve the 
quality of education for all of Florida's children.

I am writing to request a meeting with you, Lieutenant Governor Brogan and
Secretary Horne to discuss a promising new joint venture the Education
Leaders Council is forming to provide high quality, research driven teacher
professional development/certification courses in reading (for k-3 teachers)
and in using technology effectively to improve student achievement.  ELC is
moving aggressively to play a direct role in providing quality services to
our members that actually make a difference in improving student
achievement.

We strongly believe this is an important moment of opportunity to build on
successes like Florida's strong accountability system created by you and
Lieutenant Governor Brogan and the President's "No Child Left Behind" bill 
(please see attached - self-aggrandizing and hopefully thoroughly true - 
press release), passed earlier this week, which have created a "culture of 
achievement."  We believe that improving instructional quality is critical to 
maintaining and building on the momentum created by leading states and now at 
the federal level for serious accountability and a focus on results for 
children.

As you are aware, research consistently supports the premise that a quality
teacher is the most important element in determining success in any
instructional environment.  Unfortunately, however, our education schools
have largely failed us in preparing significant numbers of high quality
teachers and most professional development opportunities for teachers have
had very limited or no success in impacting the overall quality of public
school teaching.

We are creating a program that will change that dismal trend in teacher
professional development that can be delivered cost-effectively.  I would
very much like to meet with you, Lieutenant Governor Brogan and Sec. Horne 
along with Randy Best, Chairman of Voyager Expanded Learning, to discuss how 
ELC might serve your needs in this area.  If this is of interest to you, 
please let me know how best to follow up in arranging a meeting.


We are grateful for your leadership and for the leadership of your family.  
God bless you and yours this season.

SIncerely,

Lisa Keegan

From:	Dana, Pamella <pamella.dana@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Friday, December 21, 2001 7:44 PM
To:	'Rhodes, Michael, SES (L)'
Subject:	RE: Costs for SOUTHCOM HQ

The Governor wants to know the following:

How was cost and value of SOUTHCOM land and headquarters established?

On the $40 million purchase figure floating around Congress last year...how
did that number come about?

What is market value now?  How is this figure derived?

-----Original Message-----
From: Rhodes, Michael, SES (L) [mailto:RhodesM@hq.southcom.mil]
Subject: Costs for SOUTHCOM HQ



Current lease costs.  Total for HQ property is $3.1 million per year.  Total
for additional space (office/warehouse) in the area, $1.2 million per year.

~ HQ Building.  Current lease expires Feb 2008.  Lease costs are
approximately $2 million per year.

~ Land.  Land for security buffer surrounding the HQ (19+ acres) is
currently has authorityto lease (through condemnation proceedings)
year-to-year through Feb 2008 for $1-$1.1 million per year.

~ State land.  Land from State to complete security buffer (15 acres) is $0
per year for 50 years.
to leased and land Purchase.

~ Additional neighboring leases.  Currently a patchwork of seven 2 - 5 year
leases to supplement HQ space at a cost of $1.2 million per year.  These
leases account for 30% of our total office space, and there is a small
amount for warehouse.  Ideally we would develop an Annex next the the
current HQ and eliminate these other leases.    

Purchase. 

~ The last time DoD considered pursuing authorization to purchase (last
year...for FY02 purchase) the cost was estimated to be $40 million.  

~ This would have purchased the HQ building and land.  A logical follow-on
would have been to develop the Annex structure at a cost of around $16
million.  

~ As an aside...truth in lending requires that I say, it is likely purchase
would require some type of court proceeding based on the experience with the
buffer land.  In the case of the buffer land the Corps of Engineers (they
are our agent for real estate issues) offered 125% of valuation for the land
lease but the owner countered at approximately 200% of value for best offer.
Thus the Corps had to execute a lease through condemnation (whereby the
courts ensure fair value compensation to the owner).

-----Original Message-----
From: Herb Caskey [mailto:herbc@libertyhealth.com]
Sent: Friday, December 21, 2001 1:15 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Thank you for meeting with us



Dear Governor Bush,

I thank you for taking time to meet with us on 12/19/01.  Liberty has 
valued the opportunity to work closely with the Department of Children and 
Families to implement and manage the Jimmy Ryce program from its inception. 
 Liberty is the only private organization in the country that has 
successfully operated large-scale treatment programs for civilly committed 
sexual predators for state mental health authorities.  Liberty has 
established state-of-the-art programs for sexually violent predators for 
two of the biggest states in the country - Illinois and Florida.  We look 
forward to a continuing collaboration with the Department on this important 
project.

In addition, we have also been providing health services at Landmark 
Developmental Center for over 10 years.  As described in the literature we 
left with you, we are also the only private organization in the country 
that has extensive experience with right-sizing and/or closing state 
developmental centers.  Clearly, our model supports your plan for reducing 
the number of state employees.  In fact, we have already successfully 
transitioned state employees as part of our mission of providing health 
services at Landmark, and created employment opportunities at the Jimmy 
Ryce program for over 60 state employees of G. Pierce Wood Hospital during 
its current closure.

Not only can Liberty close the Landmark facility for the Department of 
Children and Families, we believe we can save money for the state during 
the closure, while successfully transitioning individuals with 
developmental disabilities into the community.

I appreciate your time and can assure you that we will continue our 
commitment to serving the unique program needs of these special populations 
in Florida.

Sincerely,

Herb Caskey, M.D.
President

-----Original Message-----
From: Jeeeperzz@aol.com [mailto:Jeeeperzz@aol.com] 
Sent: Monday, December 17, 2001 11:07 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Problems collecting child support...help!


I have been without a child support payment since Sept 1 for my 3
children.  I waited the required 30 days before contacting my attorney
to get an income deduction order to have the child support payments
taken straight out of my former husbands salary.  It took another 6
weeks to get the order signed by a judge.  On November 30, 2001, I was
told by my former husband's employer that a check would be maild out
that day and be sent to the state depository.  That was 16 days ago
and
when I call the hotline number to check on the status of the payments,
they tell me that it has not been received or posted.  I now have to
wait another 7 business days so they can run a trace on the check to
see
where it went. 
This is RIDICULOUS!  I have 3 children that depend on the child
support
payments to eat, have clothing, shelter, school, and then some.  I was
wary about going through the state for collection of the child support
because this has happened to so many of my divorced friends.  As it
stands now, they will have no Christmas!  I have exhausted my savings
to
support them the last few months.  And to make matters worse, I have
to
go back to my attorney to get the back child support caught up along
with collecting the back medical bills I am owed for the last year!
That will cost me another $725.00 that I do not have! 
Any help in expediting my payment through the system will be greatly
appreciated.  My kids might be able to have a merry Christmas. 

Sincerely, 

Sonya C. Adkins 
8241 Glasgow Court 
Jacksonville, FL  32244 

Case # 98-0001910

Dear Rodney,

The Hollywood Police Dept is proudly hosting this Conference in July
2002.  The site for the Conference is the brand new Diplomat Hotel on
Hollywood Beach and we are anticipating over 300 Police Chiefs from all
over the State to attend. In addition to the Chiefs and their families,
Senior staff members from Law Enforcement Agencies are also invited and
expected.  This is a four day Conference which will include Law
Enforcement equipment vendors, Training Seminars, and opportunities for
professional interaction and information sharing.

This Summer's Conference is also the 50th Anniversary of the Florida
Police Chief's Association and we are seeking a dynamic personality and
speaker for the Installation Dinner on Wednesday, July 03 (6:30 pm -
8:30pm).  With all that has happened this year in Law Enforcement, and
specific to our State, we would love to have Governor Bush honor us with
his attendance and address the attendees on July 03.  Is there anything
you can do to assist?  It would certainly be appreciated.

Jim Scarberry
Chief of Police, Hollywood Fl.

Subject:	Teachers-Are Heroes - Proposal Approval


To the "Teachers-Are-Heroes" Proposal Team, 
the Florida Consortium of Education Foundations,
The Citigroup-Florida Leadership Council Members &
the Honorable Jeb Bush, Governor -


I have the pleasure of announcing the approval of our "Teachers-Are-Heroes"
program grants ($100,000 & $25,000) by the Citigroup Foundation!
Congratulations to the proposal team and to the Citigroup Florida Leadership
Council for their support and encouragement.

Teachers-Are-Heroes presents us all with a community and corporate
opportunity to recruit, retain and reward one of Florida's most valuable and
most at-risk populations - our public school teachers.  We at Citigroup
Florida are enthusiastically looking forward to the roll-out and
vitalization of this wonderful state-wide initiative!

More details to follow, but we didn't want this holiday season to pass
without sharing the good news quickly!

Happy holidays to all!


Lou Buccino

Subject: Leon County Unemployment 

Just in case anyone is keeping tabs (like me :)), AWI released labor 
statistics for month of November yesterday. 

Leon County's unemployment rate actually WENT DOWN from October -- from 
2.7% to 2.6% -- again, Leon has the second lowest unemployment rate in 
the state behind Alachua County. 

Franklin County fell to fourth lowest behind Sarasota County which is at 
2.8%. 

Just trying to put everything into context! 

Is there anyone out there with me!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Subject:	Fw: finalreportdraft2
Attachments:	finalreportdraft2.pdf

Cyber Citizens For Justice Dispatch - Distribute Widely -
http://www.ccfj.net/ 
 
Dear members and friends, 
 
As you know, the State Tax Reform Task Force will complete its mandate and provide a final report to the Governor, President of the Senate and Speaker of the House by February 1, 2002.  
 
The 2nd draft of the task force proposed recommendations, an (8) eight page document, is available online and provided for your perusal. 


http://www.state.fl.us/edr/taxref/finalreportdraft2.pdf
 
If you detest attachments (as I do) let me know and we'll try to get the report to you in another way. We're sure to have the reports posted on our Website in the near future. Right Jan? 
 
BTW, you might recall our recent inquiry of Senator John McKay, President of the Senate, re tax reform proposals he decided to provide which seem to circumvent the mandate of the task force of which he's a member? 
 
Although we did not receive a response from his office we have found a copy of his (39) thirty nine pageTax Reform Proposals. 
 
Because of the difficulty encountered while downloading we've provided the home page of the Senator. From there you can access the report by clicking on the Tax Reform Proposal line. 
 
* SEE BELOW * 
 
WARNING: The .pdf format utilized to prepare this document, with all the colorful pages, icons, pictures, Senate Seal, etc., is very time consuming to download. Maybe it's my AA software?
 
It took approximately (16) sixteen minutes for the first two pages to download. Let me know if you have better luck. Thank you.  
 
Internally, the report has dark blue backround pages that aren't weren't user friendly. We contacted his office and requested a review and/or revision and a preparation in .html format. 
 
Anyhow! 
 
It's interesting to compare these reports to learn how State Tax Reform might affect the Citizens of Florida. Several bills have been prefiled that intend to deal with this issue during the 2002 Legislative session but it's doubtful anything significant will happen because the Legislators are going to be quite busy 'carving up the state' for political gain.  
 
However, 'Skeletons,' as in, 'bare bones' do exist for tax reform as is the case for the possibility of deregulating the electrical industry. 
So, Stay Tuned! 
   
Good luck with the McKay report!  
 
Your comments and suggestions are always appreciated. Thank you. 
 
The best to you and yours, 
Bob, 
Ocala, FL 
Public Relations - CCFJ, Inc., 
http://www.ccfj.net/ 
--------------------------------------- * SEE BELOW * ------------------------------
President of the Florida Senate; John McKay 
*Tax Reform Proposals 
 
http://www.leg.state.fl.us/Welcome/index.cfm?Mode=Senate <http://www.leg.state.fl.us/Welcome/index.cfm?Mode=Senate&Submenu=2&Tab=welcome> &Submenu=2&Tab=welcome

-----Original Message-----
From: Steve Mayberry [mailto:SMayberry@floridabusiness.com]
Sent: Monday, December 03, 2001 6:09 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: Pam Dana (E-mail); John Anderson; Roger Miller
Subject: CONFIDENTIAL: Prospect follow up



Regarding the prospect you called me about this morning: 

After researching the company and recent history in Florida, I called the 
contact the CEO gave you. We had a brief conversation before he had to 
leave, but he will get back to me this evening or tomorrow. I also left a 
message for Stu Turley, to let him know you had followed up and see what 
else he could tell me.  

Here's a stroke of luck that we may, if we get the chance, use at the right 
time:  Manny Fernandez (Gartner, UF Trustee) is on the prospects Board, 
their executive committee, and chairs their "Corporate Governance" 
committee. 

Regarding the permitting issues, I spent considerable time getting briefed 
by their local attorneys, Wade Hopping and Gary Hunter. I asked Gary to 
provide me with a written summary of their issues which will probably be 
more accurate than my retelling of the story.  Hopefully, the client will 
allow this, and you can use it to assess the situation.  This is one side of 
the story, and I am sure DEP has a different perspective. 

The permitting problem that I was aware of when you called me had to do with 
the company not getting air permits before they began an expansion about 2 
years ago. They were under the impression that their existing permits would 
be sufficient.  That situation was corrected.  [FYI: this is a "Title V" air 
emission facility....fiberglass emissions are a bit nasty.] 

More recently they have had problems with manatees and US Fish and Wildlife 
and local manatee clubs.  I am told the company has asked for help from your 
office to get US F & W  to respect Florida rules (speed) within the barge 
canal.  This issue has been very difficult for them, and remains a problem. 

But they are really unhappy about the "raid" you mentioned.  And if their 
lawyers account is reasonably accurate, they have every reason to be. 
Apparently a busload of DEP law enforcement officers, complete with flack 
jackets and guns, with press there to witness, descended upon one of their 
plants in response to a caller who alleged they were dumping hazardous 
waste.  DEP reps apparently mentioned to the press, and they reported, that 
this was a "criminal investigation" involving "suspected felonies".  That 
was in February, '01.  My understanding is that prior to the "raid", when 
the company first heard about the allegations, they did their own testing 
(after informing DEP in case they wanted to witness) and found nothing.  And 
apparently DEP didn't either.  The company feels their reputation was 
needlessly damaged and that the whole thing was mishandled.  

So, we have a lot to overcome to convince the CEO to invest more in Florida. 


Steve Mayberry 
Senior Vice President 
ENTERPRISE 
FLORIDA, Inc. 
The Atrium Building, Suite 201 
325 John Knox Road 
Tallahassee, Florida 32303 
850.488.6300 FAX 850.922.9595 



From:	Hirst, Elizabeth <Elizabeth.Hirst@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Thursday, December 20, 2001 5:11 PM
To:	Jimenez, Frank; Tinker, Teresa; Jeb Bush; Shanahan, Kathleen
Cc:	Kane, Dick; PRESS OFFICE
Subject:	FW: Amtrak FEC Statement

and voter education.

-----Original Message-----
From: Nina Oviedo [mailto:oviedon@sso.org]
Sent: Thursday, December 13, 2001 7:50 PM
To: Jeb Bush; Brian Yablonski; Frank R. Jimenez; Kathleen Shanahan
Cc: Melissa Freedman
Subject: Election reform passes the House
Team, see summary below re election reform.
 
-----Original Message-----
From: Freedman, Melissa [mailto:freedmm@SSONet.sso.org]
Sent: Thursday, December 13, 2001 10:41 AM
To: Oviedo, Nina
Subject: Election reform passes the House
 
Nina, 
The House approved election reform legislation last night by a vote of 362-63. The Help America Vote Act of 2001 (H.R. 3295) authorizes funding to states and counties to replace and update voting systems, and establishes mandatory election standards for states.
Federal standards under the bill would require that states do the following: 
o        Implement a statewide voter registration system linked to local jurisdictions; 
o        Permit provisional voting, or an alternative that achieves the same objective, in all precincts; 
o        Maintain and update voter registration records; 
o        Adopt uniform vote tabulation standards; 
o        Tabulate all military and overseas ballots; and 
o        Provide new voting systems for voters with disabilities. 
These standards are not optional and would apply whether or not a state received federal funding. 
Funds authorized under the bill include a one-time payment or reimbursement to states and counties of approximately $400 million to replace existing punch card voting equipment and a $2.25 billion "Election Fund" to provide payments to states over three years. States would be required to provide a 25 percent matching payment before receiving monies from the fund. The Election Fund would be administered by a bipartisan "Election Assistance Commission" comprised of state and local election officials, election experts, and other interested parties.
The Senate has not yet approved election reform legislation and is continuing with internal negotiations to develop a compromise, bipartisan reform package.
Melissa Freedman 
Florida-Washington Office 
(202) 624-5885 
From:	Robert Janauskas <wishfer@worldnet.att.net>
Sent:	Thursday, December 20, 2001 3:55 PM

Subject:	Final Report - FL Energy 2020 Study Commission

Cyber Citizens For Justice Dispatch - Distribute Widely - 
http://www.ccfj.net/ 
 
Dear members and friends, 
 
The 131 page Final Report is available online. It is a MUST READ!
 
****************************************************
"The Study Commission recommends a comprehensive framework for the industry that is sensitive to consumers and all other stakeholders. The commission's vision for the next 20 years is; 
 
Florida's supply and use of energy promotes economic prosperity, limits environmental impacts and enhances the quality of life of Floridians." 
 
In it's conclusion the commission opines further; 
 
"The recommendations in this report will bring about competition in Florida's wholesale market without the problems encountered in California. The recommendations can be expected to result in adequate reliable suppokes of electricity, price stability and reasonable costs." 
****************************************************
 
How we get 'from here to there' might be found in the 131 page Final Report of the study commission? Adobe Acrobate software required. If you have a problem let us know.  
 
* SEE BELOW * 
 
Incidentally, the pursuit of commission goals will surely be found in the current language of prefiled bills and, once included, in the 'skeleton' bills prefiled in time for the 2002 Legislative session. Stay tuned!  
 
Thanks for your interest. We look forward to your comments and suggestions. 
 
The best to you and yours, 
Bob, 
Ocala, FL

From:	Jimenez, Frank <frank.jimenez@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Thursday, December 20, 2001 12:09 PM
To:	'Palmer, Mollie'; Stutler, Denver; Bedwell, Allan
Cc:	Cooper, Cameron; Llewellyn, Janet; Yablonski, Brian; Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: water use and conservation reporting

Thanks, Mollie.  I don't think we need to hire water efficiency experts, as
long as you're satisfied the agencies are employing water conservation
measures.

-----Original Message-----
From: Palmer, Mollie [mailto:Mollie.Palmer@dep.state.fl.us]
Sent: Thursday, December 20, 2001 12:06 PM
To: jimenef@eog.state.fl.us; Stutler, Denver; Bedwell, Allan
Cc: Cooper, Cameron; Llewellyn, Janet
Subject: water use and conservation reporting


As planned,  I have worked with DMS and contacted all the rest of the state
agencies from whom I had not yet requested water use and conservation
reporting, and we have combined such reporting with the DMS energy tracking
project as they had included water in their reporting form.

Although DMS is only requiring the energy report annually, after
consultation
with you, Frank, I have asked for the water use and conservation report
twice
a year, with the heads up that we might need more often during serious
drought times.  The water reports will be due on February 15 and on August
15, which is DMS's annual due date.

I hope to get an interim report to you soon on agencies that have been
reporting then should have a more comprehensive report after February.

The governor's letter on the energy reporting mentioned bringing in energy
efficiency experts to help conduct an efficiency review and make energy
savings recommendations.  I do not know where funding would come from or who
would be the project manager for such an effort, but should we consider the
same thing for water use?

mollie

-----Original Message-----
From: Nina Oviedo [mailto:oviedon@sso.org]
Sent: Wednesday, December 19, 2001 7:43 PM
To: Mike Hansen; Donna Arduin; Governor Bush; Brian Yablonski; Frank R. Jimenez; Kathleen Shanahan
Cc: tnoviedo; Stephanie Kopelousos; Michelle Cangelosi; Melissa Freedman; Lauren Burke; Karen Hogan; Jill Hill Randolph; Bill Buckey; Adam Moniz
Subject: economic stimulus agreement


An agreement was reached on a bi-partisan basis for House passage of the economic stimulus package.  The Administration has 5 Senate Democrats but need another 5 to hit the magic 60 cloture vote.which several Senate Democrats say will never happen.so this bill could still die.
 
Nonetheless attached is a summarythe key issues we were focused on were the 30% depreciation (could cost Fl $200M), some form of offset to the depreciation cost and TANF Supplemental Grants.  The compromise includes the depreciation allowance for 3 years; the offset is labeled Temporary State Health Care Assistance and after discussions with the team, the state can use the one time, $164,619,369 in general revenue; and TANF Supp is included (+$60M).  Also included are the National Emergency Grants.
 
NGA gave us lots of credit today on getting the Administration to move to some form of rational balance.  I honestly believe that our meetings yesterday with Chairman Thomas staff, WH, OMB and everyone else in the hallway that would listen to KS, and our continuous calls to the Hill, made a big difference!
 
Ive been waiting all day to hear from Chairman Youngs staff on seaport security.  At 7 pm tonight he was still in final drafting stages and was unavailable.  We will try to reach him first thing in the a.m.  
 
We will work to get a weekly report out before we leave tomorrow and will hopefully have more details by then.

Subject: economic stimulus agreement


An agreement was reached on a bi-partisan basis for House passage of the economic stimulus package.  The Administration has 5 Senate Democrats but need another 5 to hit the magic 60 cloture vote.which several Senate Democrats say will never happen.so this bill could still die.
 
Nonetheless attached is a summarythe key issues we were focused on were the 30% depreciation (could cost Fl $200M), some form of offset to the depreciation cost and TANF Supplemental Grants.  The compromise includes the depreciation allowance for 3 years; the offset is labeled Temporary State Health Care Assistance and after discussions with the team, the state can use the one time, $164,619,369 in general revenue; and TANF Supp is included (+$60M).  Also included are the National Emergency Grants.
 
NGA gave us lots of credit today on getting the Administration to move to some form of rational balance.  I honestly believe that our meetings yesterday with Chairman Thomas staff, WH, OMB and everyone else in the hallway that would listen to KS, and our continuous calls to the Hill, made a big difference!

Subject:	GOVERNORS ONLY: Economic Stimulus Conference Call Today at 1:00	EST

progress of the economic stimulus package.
Mark Weinberger, Assistant Secretary for Tax at Treasury, and Mark McClellan
from the President's Council of Economic Advisors will be on the call.

I spoke with a number of you last night, and as we discussed, the latest House
version is very good for states (or at least as good as it can get at the
moment) -- it includes $4.6 billion in "Temporary State Health Care Assistance"
-- a one time distribution to states to help meet health care costs -- and the
best thing about this is that as soon as the President signs the bill, states
would immediately receive this money.

I will shortly send out a state by state breakdown of this money.

The latest House version also includes $9 billion in accelerated Reed Act
distributions for states and $4 billion in National Emergency Grants.

The House version, passed last night, is essentially what was agreed to by the
President and Senate centrists yesterday.

If states and Governors need economic relief, this economic stimulus package is
the only way to go.  The House has acted, the President has agreed, and now we
need the Senate to act immediately.

THE CALL IN INFORMATION IS AS FOLLOWS:

NUMBER:   800-659-6183
PASSWORD: Economic

Please confirm your parcipation with Keith Brancato at 202-456-2896.

As we spend time over the holidays with our loved ones, I know that each of
us will be thinking about those we know only in our hearts.  The many men
and women who are so proudly serving this nation in the war against
terrorism include fine pilots from the Florida Air National Guard.  While we
enjoy the comforts and security of  being at home with our loved ones, they
will be spending the holidays protecting our families and keeping us safe.
Mrs. Bush and I, along with so many other Floridians, send each of them our
prayers and blessings during a holiday season when they cannot be with their
own families.  This state greatly appreciates the job they are doing and the
sacrafices they are making this holiday season.

Jeb Bush

-----Original Message-----
From: Openshaw, Mary Laura [mailto:OPENSHM@mail.doe.state.fl.us]
Sent: Wednesday, December 19, 2001 6:46 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: Kathleen Shanahan
Subject: Update from the Governor's Longhorn Committee
Importance: High


Governor,

Here is a quick update from our first day in Texas:

First of all, we have some ideas on infrastructure that we would like to
discuss with you in person.  Are you available Friday the 21st?

Preliminary game plan:
1.  Must agree and adopt research that underpins initiative.  We
envision
bringing an expert/technical group together to re-confirm Florida's
basic
research foundation already in place.  Every single part of this
initiative
must be aligned with this research, and now that HR 1 has passed
Congress,
we can move forward.

2.  We need to tie the 4th grade social promotion issue to your reading
initiatve goal that every child must be reading on grade level by the
end of
3rd grade (we can change legislation to 3rd grade now that we have 3rd
grade
FCAT testing.) This involves legislative buy-in and policy makers
establishing target dates and percentage of students who must achieve
this
goal (not this year).

3. The Florida Board of Education needs to require all Colleges of
Education
to align all reading teacher prep programs to the research-based
curriculum
of Just Read, Florida!

4.  The Commissioner or Secretary needs to issue a "List of Approved
Early
Diagnostic Reading Instruments" (K-3).  This list should include the two
that DOE already provides to districts at no cost, as well as the Texas
version (which they have offered to us at a competitive price.)  The
second
piece to this is that we need to immediately train teachers/principals
on
how to use this assessment data to inform diagnosis and classroom
instructionh.  We are investigating how much of the new federal money
can be
used for this training.

5.  The number one recommendation from Texas is that we train Leadership
before classroom teachers.  We have the infrastructure in place to
utilize
our Area Centers for Educational Enhancement (ACEE's) for training.  But
we
need to revamp and revitalize them ( we have a plan -- which is part of
our
face to face discussion.)  We want to recognize principals who complete
this
training -- one way to do that would be to require that in order for a
school to get Reading First money (the federal dollars) the principal
must
complete this training.

For any/all of the above to work, we have to adopt the philosophy that
the
best way to attack the crisis in reading is to come out guns slinging,
taking no prisoners, and letting people know that our plan is
non-negotiable.

Tomorrow we are meeting with Reed Lyon, and will have much more to
offer.

If you need to talk to us about any of the above, we can be reached at
Cheryl's cell phone 591-3311.  We don't know if you have to use the area
code or not....

Bye for now from your special ops forces in Texas,
Mary Laura, Cheryl, and Don

 

This is from our first day here.  Tomorrow we are meeting with Reed
Lyon,
and will have more to share.

Governor Bush, as you can see from the e-mail below many of our very good 
people are upset over Sen. MCkay's suggestion-however intended-that someone

-----Original Message----- 
From: Frazer, Nat [ mailto:FrazerN@wec.ufl.edu] 
Sent: Tuesday, December 04, 2001 2:26 PM 
To: 'mvm@gnv.ifas.ufl.edu'; 'jcj@gnv.ifas.ufl.edu' 
Subject: McKay's "shotgun" comments 


FYI Several staff and faculty members in my department have stopped me in 
the hall today to express their outrage over Senator McKay's comments in the 
Gainesville Sun encouraging folks to take their shotguns into IFAS on a 
Friday after 4PM..  

1.  They resent the implication that IFAS folks do not work hard for their 
paychecks (and they are not aware that the Senator ever visited our building 
before making such a remark). 
2.  They feel that if any of them had made similar comments about the 
Florida Senate, that they would have been slammed into jail for threatening 
public officials carrying out their duties in a public building.  They want 
to know how anyone can get away with making such comments, especially in the 
wake of September 11th. 
3.  Several of the women who work on the first floor in my building  have 
said they now feel unsafe -- from crazies who might "take the hint" from 
McKay; I would not be surprized if some of my employees do take off this 
Friday and go home before 4PM. 

In the best of times, folks would be worried about losing their jobs; in 
these times of terrorism and other acts of public violence, this was an 
especially insensitive remark for a leading public official to make. 

Folks in my department have been pretty calm and fearless about all this 
budget-cut stuff -- they're pulling together, willing to endure the 
belt-tightening for the sake of the IFAS team, etc. (Several have inquired 
about the possibility of voluntary furloughs or going part time to prevent 
others from losing their jobs, etc.) But this latest cavalier comment from a 
key Florida legislator has REALLY ticked them off and contributed to a 
marked decline in morale. 

I know my staff and faculty are not alone in their feelings about this 
issue.  I assume other personnel in other departments are equally outraged. 

-- 
Nat B. Frazer, Professor and Chair 
Department of Wildlife Ecology and Conservation 
Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences 
University of Florida 
PO Box 110430
