-----Original Message-----
From: Openshaw, Mary Laura [mailto:OPENSHM@mail.doe.state.fl.us]
Sent: Wednesday, December 19, 2001 6:46 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: Kathleen Shanahan
Subject: Update from the Governor's Longhorn Committee
Importance: High


Governor,

Here is a quick update from our first day in Texas:

First of all, we have some ideas on infrastructure that we would like to
discuss with you in person.  Are you available Friday the 21st?

Preliminary game plan:
1.  Must agree and adopt research that underpins initiative.  We envision
bringing an expert/technical group together to re-confirm Florida's basic
research foundation already in place.  Every single part of this initiative
must be aligned with this research, and now that HR 1 has passed Congress,
we can move forward.

2.  We need to tie the 4th grade social promotion issue to your reading
initiatve goal that every child must be reading on grade level by the end of
3rd grade (we can change legislation to 3rd grade now that we have 3rd grade
FCAT testing.) This involves legislative buy-in and policy makers
establishing target dates and percentage of students who must achieve this
goal (not this year).

3. The Florida Board of Education needs to require all Colleges of Education
to align all reading teacher prep programs to the research-based curriculum
of Just Read, Florida!

4.  The Commissioner or Secretary needs to issue a "List of Approved Early
Diagnostic Reading Instruments" (K-3).  This list should include the two
that DOE already provides to districts at no cost, as well as the Texas
version (which they have offered to us at a competitive price.)  The second
piece to this is that we need to immediately train teachers/principals on
how to use this assessment data to inform diagnosis and classroom
instructionh.  We are investigating how much of the new federal money can be
used for this training.

5.  The number one recommendation from Texas is that we train Leadership
before classroom teachers.  We have the infrastructure in place to utilize
our Area Centers for Educational Enhancement (ACEE's) for training.  But we
need to revamp and revitalize them ( we have a plan -- which is part of our
face to face discussion.)  We want to recognize principals who complete this
training -- one way to do that would be to require that in order for a
school to get Reading First money (the federal dollars) the principal must
complete this training.

For any/all of the above to work, we have to adopt the philosophy that the
best way to attack the crisis in reading is to come out guns slinging,
taking no prisoners, and letting people know that our plan is
non-negotiable.

Tomorrow we are meeting with Reed Lyon, and will have much more to offer.

If you need to talk to us about any of the above, we can be reached at
Cheryl's cell phone 591-3311.  We don't know if you have to use the area
code or not....

Bye for now from your special ops forces in Texas,
Mary Laura, Cheryl, and Don

 

This is from our first day here.  Tomorrow we are meeting with Reed Lyon,
and will have more to share.

From:	Bernd Wollschlaeger,M.D. <info@miamihealth.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 19, 2001 11:00 PM
To:	Moore, Tim; Domestic Security Co-Chairs; Domestic Security Advisory Panel; Lauer, Stephen
Cc:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Re: Domestic Security Advisory Panel Mail List Very Productive Meeting with INS Today

Dear Tim:
Just returned from a meeting with the staff of the Department of Health in
Tallahassee and gained a comprehensive overview about the Emergency
Preparedness and Disaster Response activities.
I am very impressed and I suggested that all such activities should be
conveyed to the public as part of the Public Awareness campaign. Also
submitted to Dr. Agwunobi my proposal for an  Emergency Preparedness and
Disaster Response Manual called the " Family Defense Manual".
It is modeled after the Israeli experience with such a public awareness
education campaign prior and during the Gulf War.
I can have the book ready within 30 days and will continue to discuss the
funding strategy of such a project.
It should be made available to every resident in Florida for a self-cost
price.
Furthermore I want to inform you that I was invited by the American Jewish
Congress Commission on Law & Social Action to discuss "National Security and
Civil Liberty" on January 7, 2002 at the Finkelstein Auditorium- Nova
Southeastern University in Fort Lauderdale. I will discuss the topic with
Prof. Johnny Burris, Assistant Professor of Law. I will attempt to present
the different challenges that our state and judicial system is facing to
fight terrorism and obviously will take the Pro and Dr. Burris the Contra
argument.
Will keep you posted.
Bernd

----- Original Message -----
From: "Moore, Tim" <TimMoore@fdle.state.fl.us>
To: "Domestic Security Co-Chairs" <dstf@flcjn.net>; "Domestic Security
Advisory Panel" <DSAP@flcjn.net>; "Lauer, Stephen"
<StephenLauer@fdle.state.fl.us>
Cc: "Governor Jeb Bush (E-mail)" <jeb@jeb.org>
Sent: Tuesday, December 18, 2001 5:14 PM
Subject: Domestic Security Advisory Panel Mail List Very Productive Meeting
with INS Today


> This message is for members of the Florida Domestic Security Advisory
Panel.  Only members of the Panel and others designated by the Panel will
receive this message.
>
> We a had a very productive meeting with INS Acting Director Jim Goldman
> today.  Director Goldman is in charge of INS operations for Florida.  This
> meeting was a follow up to a conference call Governor Bush and i had late
> last week with INS Commissioner James Ziglar ( which was also very
> productive!)
>
> In short, Director Goldman agreed to assign his Deputy Director Jim
Spearman
> to FDLE Headquarters effective January 4, 2002, to iron out the details
for
> a "pilot program" here in Florida that would accomplish the following:
>
> 1. Assign an INS Officer full time to each of our (7) Regional
> Domestic Security Task Forces;
>
> 2. Deputize at least (5) local/state law enforcement officers
> in each of our Domestic Security Task Forces.
> This would require the completion of an abbreviated
> (estimated 2-3weeks) special INS training that
> would be provided by INS and, if necessary, paid for the
> State of Florida;
>
> These deputized officers would not only help in domestic
> security enforcement operations, but would
> help to provide the much needed training in INS related
> matters for ALL Florida law enforcement
> officers in each Region.  Additionally, these officers will
> be of tremendous assistance in immigration
> emergencies that we face all too often;
>
> 3. Provide direct access to critical information in  INS
> databases  directly via the FCIC System (or some
> other to be identified on-line mechanism) for each of our
> Domestic Security Task Forces and the
> members assigned.  This would initially be accomplished via
> the assigned INS Officers and the
> deputized local/state law enforcement officers in each of
> the Domestic Security Task Forces;
>
> This interim access solution would NOT eliminate the need
> for (nor our pursuit of) on-line immediate
> access to information on all "Out of Status" illegal
> immigrants for all law enforcement officers in
> Florida.
>
> This "pilot" is not attempting to make Florida law enforcement officers
INS
> Agents, but rather an attempt to provide the authority and information
> necessary for us to strengthen our domestic security.  It would represent
> the first of its kind in the Country according to Director Goldman, and
> could very well serve as a model to export to the other states.
>
> While this "pilot" concept still has to be approved by INS Commissioner
> Ziglar, it very much consistent with his commitment to Governor Bush to
work
> our an arrangement that recognizes the unique immigration challenges that
> Florida must deal with.  And these challenges are even more difficult now
> given the fact that the terrorist responsible for the 9.11 attacks
arguably
> used Florida as home base to plan and prepare for there crimes.
>
> It is our hope to have this concept for a "pilot"  in front of INS
> Commissioner Ziglar for approval by mid January and immediate
implementation
> thereafter.
>
> Today's events represents solid progress in helping us deal with what is
> among our most pressing public safety concerns.  However, it remains
> critically important for all of us to continue reminding our elected
leaders
> and policymakers that this issue is central to our efforts to strengthen
our
> domestic security and to ready us to deal with mass immigration
emergencies
> as well.
>
> We will keep you briefed on our progress.
>
> Many Thanks.......
>
> tim
> This mail list is maintained by the FDLE Office of Statewide Intelligence
and is intended for use by Panel members to share information concerning the
duties of the Panel.  Any questions should be directed to FDLE at
850-410-7060.

From:	Nina Oviedo <oviedon@sso.org>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 19, 2001 7:43 PM
To:	Mike Hansen; Donna Arduin; Jeb Bush; Brian Yablonski; Frank R. Jimenez; Kathleen Shanahan
Cc:	tnoviedo; Stephanie Kopelousos; Michelle Cangelosi; Melissa Freedman; Lauren Burke; Karen Hogan; Jill Hill Randolph; Bill Buckey; Adam Moniz
Subject:	economic stimulus agreement
Attachments:	eco-stimulus Summary.doc

An agreement was reached on a bi-partisan basis for House passage of the economic stimulus package.  The Administration has 5 Senate Democrats but need another 5 to hit the magic 60 cloture vote.which several Senate Democrats say will never happen.so this bill could still die.
 
Nonetheless attached is a summarythe key issues we were focused on were the 30% depreciation (could cost Fl $200M), some form of offset to the depreciation cost and TANF Supplemental Grants.  The compromise includes the depreciation allowance for 3 years; the offset is labeled Temporary State Health Care Assistance and after discussions with the team, the state can use the one time, $164,619,369 in general revenue; and TANF Supp is included (+$60M).  Also included are the National Emergency Grants.
 
NGA gave us lots of credit today on getting the Administration to move to some form of rational balance.  I honestly believe that our meetings yesterday with Chairman Thomas staff, WH, OMB and everyone else in the hallway that would listen to KS, and our continuous calls to the Hill, made a big difference!
 
Ive been waiting all day to hear from Chairman Youngs staff on seaport security.  At 7 pm tonight he was still in final drafting stages and was unavailable.  We will try to reach him first thing in the a.m.  
 
We will work to get a weekly report out before we leave tomorrow and will hopefully have more details by then.

-----Original Message-----
From: Donna Ross [mailto:ross@floridaattractions.org]
Sent: Wednesday, December 19, 2001 5:10 PM
To: ross@floridaattractions.org
Subject: Attraction Business Status Report #8


Florida Attractions Association 
Business Status Report #7 

The Florida Attractions Association is a trade association, founded in 1949,  representing more than 80 family-oriented attractions including astronaut, historical, cultural, military and scientific museums; castles; collections of the unique and different; dinner entertainments; dolphin and marine parks; exhibitions of alligators, lions, monkeys, parrots, butterflies and manatees; gardens; Indian villages; sightseeing trains, cruises, airboat and trolley tours; theme parks; water parks; and zoological parks. 
  


ATTRACTION BUSINESS INDICATORS  
(Based on  25 Benchmark Attractions) 


Attendance % Change 2001 vs 2000 


Week of 


12/5-12/11 
-15  Statewide 
+05   North 
-25  Central/Central East 
-15  Central West 
-10  Southwest 
-05  Southeast 
-05 The Keys 


Notes: 
> December 2000 weather was cold and rainy in the North 
>High hopes for the Christmas holiday, especially between the 25th and 31st 


11/28-12/4 
-20  Statewide 
 00   North 
 -25  Central/Central East 
-15  Central West 
-20  Southwest 
-15  Southeast 
-10 The Keys 


Notes: 
>  Dip in numbers following Thanksgiving week was expected 
>  Free days help attendance but not bottom line 
> Nothing to shout about. 
> Selling memberships and annual passes  as Christmas presents help revenue numbers 
>  Some have hired new part time staff and seasonal workers 
>  We appear to have made up some ground.  Although our numbers are in the red, the degree which they were below last year's numbers was an improvement. 
  


When asked about the remainder of 2001: 
> This is a dismal time of year for us anyway.  Charitable toy drive has helped business some. We plan to heavily discount admission.  More people does not mean more money.  Not planning to have an outstanding January and February, but the buzz is that North Florida will have an record-breaking Spring Break and summer. (North Florida) 
> Florida will survive - not as strong as previous years but survival is promising 
> Expect the rest of December to be the same as last year attendance wise but have noticed the amount spent per visitor on purchases has dropped.  What hurts the most now (besides economy and outside factors) is the weather. (North Florida) 
> We are not expecting any improvement until later in 2002. (Central East Florida) 
> This is traditionally the slowest time for attractions so we are optimistic for 2002.  (Southwest Florida) 
>  One attraction has reported that school group business has doubled since 9/11; others worry that education budget cuts will affect Spring 2002 school group business. 
> Our season started a little slow, but we expect the holiday to be about the same as last year.  January and February are looking stronger than last year.  (Southwest Florida) 
> We expect to be down 10-15 percent over the holidays...feel like we are still waiting for the other shoe to drop.  (Southeast Florida) 
>  The cruise ship industry is critical to our success in the year 2002.  We need to do everything in our power to increase port calls.  (The Keys/Key West) 
> Who knows?  (Central West)

Regions by Counties: 
North - Alachua, Bay, Baker, Bradford, Calhoun, Clay, Columbia, Dixie, Duval, Escambia, Flagler, Franklin, Gadsden, Gilchrist, Gulf, Hamilton, Holmes, Jackson, Jefferson, Lafayette, Leon, Levy, Liberty, Madison, Nassau, Okaloosa, Putnam, Santa Rosa, St. Johns, Suwannee, Taylor, Union, Wakulla, Walton, Washington 
Central/Central East - Brevard, Hardee, Highlands, Indian River, Lake, Marion, Okeechobee, Orange, Osceola, Polk, Seminole, St. Lucie, Sumter, Volusia 
Central West - Citrus, Hernando, Hillsboro, Pasco, Pinellas 
Southwest - Charlotte, Collier, DeSoto, Glades, Hendry, Lee, Manatee, Sarasota 
Southeast - Broward, Dade, Martin, Palm Beach 
The Keys - Monroe 


   Florida Attractions Association, Inc., 2001

From:	May, Warren C. <Warren.May@awi.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 19, 2001 3:52 PM
To:	Jeb Bush; 'jesse.manzano@myflorida.com'; Pam Dana (E-mail)
Cc:	McGurk, Thomas D.; Austin, Curtis
Subject:	Bullets for tomorrow

Governor Bush, tomorrow we are releasing the monthly Employment/Unemployment Report for the State of Florida.  The report shows:

*	Florida's unemployment rate for November stands at 5.0%, down slightly from October's revised rate of 5.1% (October was revised upward from 4.9%). 

 

*	Although Floridas job market is experiencing the effects of a national recession, the November jobless rate of 5.0% can still be described as moderately low based on historical trends. It compares very favorably with the national rate which rose by .03% in November to 5.7%.

 

*	Of the six largest Metropolitan Statistical Areas (MSAs) in Florida, Tampa-St. Petersburg-Clearwater continued to experience the fastest growth rate and created the most new jobs over the year (+40,300 jobs, +3.3 percent). The Tampa-St. Petersburg-Clearwater area also leads the nation in job growth, with three other Florida MSAs making the top ten job growth list West Palm Beach-Boca Raton (3), Orlando (4), and Jacksonville (10).

 

Warren May 
Communications Director 
Agency for Workforce Innovation 
Warren.May@awi.state.fl.us 
(850) 488-7228 ext 1312

From: David Colburn [mailto:Colburn@aa.ufl.edu]

This article from The Chronicle of Higher Education 
(http://chronicle.com) was forwarded to you from: jglover@aa.ufl.edu



  Wednesday, December 19, 2001



  Critics of Affirmative Action Try to Head Off Texas A&M's New
  Admissions Policy

  By JEFFREY SELINGO
  
  
  
  Several leading opponents of affirmative action, including
  Ward Connerly and Linda Chavez, urged officials in Texas and
  at the U.S. Department of Education on Tuesday to derail a
  plan by Texas A&M University to automatically admit the top 20
  percent of students from 250 low-performing high schools in
  the state.
  
  Their request, which was made in two separate letters, will
  probably heighten interest in a policy passed in relative
  obscurity by the Texas A&M system's Board of Regents this
  month. Mr. Connerly is a University of California regent who
  successfully led campaigns in California and Washington state
  to ban affirmative action. Ms. Chavez, who withdrew under fire
  as President Bush's nominee to be labor secretary this year,
  is president of the Center for Equal Opportunity, an advocacy
  group that opposes the use of racial preferences.
  
  In one letter, the Center for Equal Opportunity and the
  American Civil Rights Institute, which Mr. Connerly leads,
  asked the Education Department's Office for Civil Rights to
  investigate whether the policy is unconstitutional and
  violates a federal-court decision banning affirmative action
  in admissions in Texas.
  
  In the other letter -- signed by Mr. Connerly, Ms. Chavez, and
  five others -- the group urged the attorney general of Texas,
  John Cornyn, to declare the policy illegal. Mr. Cornyn is
  reviewing the policy, at the request of Texas A&M.
  
  "The intent of the regents is clear," Mr. Connerly and others
  wrote in their letter to the attorney general. "In order to
  increase the number of freshmen to A&M belonging to some
  racial and ethnic minorities, the admission criteria will be
  different for those races and ethnicities."
  
  The group wrote that the policy's real purpose was to
  "circumvent" a 1996 federal-court decision known as Hopwood v.
  Texas, a case in which the state finally abandoned its appeals
  of this year. If the attorney general approved the policy, it
  would surely be challenged in court, the group wrote. "The
  state -- and your office in particular -- now has the chance
  to redeem itself after its shameful defense of racial and
  ethnic discrimination, or it can compound the error and its
  moral and economic costs."
  
  Texas already guarantees spots to the top 10 percent of
  graduates from the state's high schools under a 1997 law
  enacted to increase the number of minority students in the
  wake of Hopwood. The law was crafted to take advantage of some
  high schools' being predominantly black or Hispanic, but the
  law also benefits students at high schools where most students
  are white. The Texas A&M plan would extend that offer to the
  top 20 percent of the selected 250 high schools, as long as
  those students meet the university's minimum admissions
  standards for courses and test scores. Students automatically
  admitted in the top 10 percent don't have to meet those
  standards.
  
  Texas A&M officials refused to comment on the two letters on
  Tuesday. They have maintained that their 20-percent plan is an
  effort to increase the number of applicants from high schools
  that typically send few students to the institution, not to
  increase the number of minority students. They have yet to
  release a list of the high schools selected for the program,
  but said that the schools were identified without taking race
  into account, using instead factors such as high dropout rates
  and limited English proficiency.
  
  But Roger Clegg, general counsel at the Center for Equal
  Opportunity, said on Tuesday that a low-performing school was
  nothing more than another name for a predominantly minority
  high school. If Texas A&M was truly interested in admitting
  the most academically talented students, he said, it would not
  be focusing on high schools with low passage rates on
  statewide achievement tests.
  
  "What schools should be doing is figuring out what admissions
  criteria would best select the most academically qualified
  students and then let the chips fall where they may," Mr.
  Clegg said. "They should not be choosing admissions criteria
  because they would favor or disfavor a particular group."
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  The Honorable John Cornyn
  Attorney General, State of Texas
  Office of the Attorney General
  Capitol Station
  Post Office Box 12548
  Austin, Texas, 78711-2548
  
  
  
  Dear General Cornyn:
  
  
  
  We write to express our grave concerns about a new admissions
  proposalthat was recently approved by the regents of Texas A &
  M University. Asyou may know, the regents have conditionally
  approved, pending anopinion from your office, a plan to target
  the graduates ofapproximately 250 low-performing Texas high
  schools for preferentialadmissions to their undergraduate
  program. Instead of just admitting thetop 10 percent of high
  school graduates from all schools throughout thestate, the
  regents propose to admit the top 20 percent from
  selectedschools.
  
  
  
  Based upon the comments of the A & M regents, the minutes of
  theirmeetings, and other evidence, it is our opinion that this
  is an effortto circumvent Hopwood v. Texas, 78 F.3d 932, cert.
  denied, 518 U.S. 1033 (1996).  That is, the high schools are
  being chosen because of theirracial and ethnic make-up, in an
  effort to favor some groups anddisfavor others in the
  admissions process at Texas A & M. Further, theoutcome of the
  implementation of this proposal will be to
  purposefullydiscriminate against individuals because of their
  race and ethnicity.This violates Titles VI of the Civil Rights
  Act of 1964, 42 U.S.C.2000d, and of the course the Equal
  Protection Clause of the FourteenthAmendment to the U.S.
  Constitution.
  
  
  
  We strongly urge you to deny the regents the ability to
  discriminateagainst individuals because of their race or
  ethnicity.
  
  
  
  
  
  If the tables were turned, and a Texas university were
  deliberatelytargeting high schools for recruitment that did
  not have very many blackor Latino students in order to limit
  their numbers, I doubt that therewould be much question about
  the practice's illegality. For example, ifthe regents of the
  University of Houston wanted to increase the numberof white
  students on their campus, would they be allowed to
  targetwealthy suburban high schools and offer admission to the
  top 20 percentof their graduates? The answer, of course, is
  that they would not.
  
  
  
  The intent of the regents is clear: in order to increase the
  number offreshmen to A & M belonging to some racial and ethnic
  minorities, theadmission criteria will be different for those
  races and ethnicities.
  
  
  
  This discrimination will surely be challenged in the courts
  next year ifit is allowed to proceed. The costs will be borne
  by the citizens whohave already paid millions for the Hopwood
  case.  The state -- and youroffice in particular -- now has a
  chance to redeem itself after itsshameful defense of racial
  and ethnic discrimination, or it can compoundthe error and its
  moral and economic costs.
  
  
  
  We encourage you to tell Texas A & M that its proposed new
  policy isillegal.
  
  
  
  Sincerely yours,
  
  
  
  Clint Bolick,  Institute for Justice
  Linda Chavez,  Center for Equal Opportunity
  Ward Connerly,  American Civil Rights Institute
  Tom Jipping,	Free Congress Foundation
  David Keene,	American Conservative Union
  Abigail Thernstrom,  U.S. Commission on Civil Rights
  Paul Weyrich,  Coalitions for America
  
  
  
  
  
  cc  Wendy Gramm, Texas A & M University Board of Regents.
    Todd Jones, Acting Asst. Secretary for Civil Rights, U.S.
  Dep't ofEducation.
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  Mr. Todd Jones
  Acting Asst. Secretary for Civil Rights
  Office for Civil Rights
  Department of Education
  400 Maryland Ave. SW
  Washington, DC  20202
  
  
  
    Dec. 18, 2001
  
  
  
  
  
  Dear Mr. Jones:
  
  
  
  We are writing to apprise you of a looming civil rights
  violation atTexas A & M University and to ask you to
  investigate.
  
  
  
  The board of regents at A & M has recently approved a new
  admissionsplan that we believe is designed to discriminate
  against students basedupon their race and ethnicity. The new
  plan will grant a preference tostudents from predominately
  minority high schools over all otherstudents by granting
  automatic admission to students from the top 20percent of the
  graduating classes from those schools. Other studentsfrom
  primarily non-minority schools will automatically be admitted
  to A& M only if they graduate in the top 10 percent of their
  class.
  
  
  
  Based upon the general comments of the A & M regents and
  members of theadministration, the minutes of their meetings,
  and other evidence, it isour opinion that this is an effort to
  circumvent Hopwood v. Texas, 78F.3d 932, cert. denied, 518
  U.S. 1033 (1996).  That is, the high schoolsare being chosen
  because of their racial and ethnic make-up, in aneffort to
  favor some groups and disfavor others in the admissionsprocess
  at Texas A & M. The outcome of the implementation of
  thisproposal will be to purposefully discriminate against
  individualsbecause of their race and ethnicity. This violates
  Titles VI of theCivil Rights Act of 1964, 42 U.S.C. 2000d, and
  of the course the EqualProtection Clause of the Fourteenth
  Amendment to the U.S. Constitution.
  
  
  
  It is apparent to us that if the tables were turned, and a
  Texasuniversity was deliberately targeting high schools for
  recruitment thatdid not have very many black or Latino
  students in order to limit theirnumbers, there would be little
  question about the practice's illegality.For example, if the
  regents of the University of Houston wanted toincrease the
  number of white students to their campus, would they beallowed
  to target wealthy suburban high schools and offer admission
  tothe top 20 percent of their graduates? The answer, of
  course, is thatthey would not.
  
  
  
  The circumstances of the adoption of this policy raise a
  stronginference that its aim is to favor certain students from
  specific racialand ethnic groups and disfavor others.  And, in
  light of the Hopwooddecision, which is the controlling
  precedent in Texas, there is no doubtthat such discrimination
  violates Title VI and the Equal ProtectionClause. We formally
  ask that you investigate this new policy.
  
  
  
  
  
  Very sincerely yours,
  
  
  
  Roger Clegg 
  General Counsel  
  Center for Equal Opportunity	 
  
  
  
  Edward Blum
  Director of Legal Affairs
  American Civil Rights Institute

From: Ward, Kevin D [mailto:kevin.ward@qwest.com]
Sent: Monday, October 01, 2001 2:12 PM
To: 'jeb@jeb.org'
Subject: Is Florida too dependent on Tourism?


Governor Bush -

The predominant question today is: are we too dependent on Tourism as a
state?

I think that I have a great opportunity for you to start proving or further
prove this assumption wrong.  I'd like to invite you to utilize our new 96K
S.F., 150+ million dollar CyberCenter as a "media/photo-op" back-drop to
directly discuss Florida's ever-diversifying economy.

Please consider the following as a sample press release... we'd love to take
you and the media on a guided-tour of our new and still expanding
ultra-high-tech facility.  Outside of NASA, the CyberCenter is the #1
facility in the state in terms of "cutting edge" technology, and it
dramatically offers a preview into what will undoubtedly emerge as the
driving market segment of Florida's 21st century economy - the Internet and
Data Services.  With data services access speeds of up to OC-192, the
CyberCenter is literally leading the way for Florida's growth at "light
speed"...

Take a look at the political angle I have tried to craft for The Governor's
Office benefit in the below sample.  If interested, we'd love to work with
your staff to make such a speech/tour/media event available to your
schedule.  It seems to me that the timing would be perfect given the growing
concerns about the travel industry slump.  And I'd like to think that it
would be a help to your reelection efforts as well...

Take care - Kevin

The Qwest CyberCenter - Tampa, Florida

Florida's 21st century economy is far more diverse than most outsiders might
consider.  Tourism will always play a key role in Florida's future, but
Florida's business infrastructure is already one of the most diverse and
far-reaching economic models to be found anywhere - globally.  At the
"cutting edge" of this business expansion, Florida's cyber-economy has leapt
forward at a tremendous pace.

Whether you are a dot-com company looking to quickly build an online
business or an established enterprise interested in building or expanding an
Internet presence, Florida has already undergone the necessary conversions
to rank it as one of the leading Internet Backbone and Web Hosting locations
worldwide.  The new Qwest CyberCenter in Tampa, Florida stands as the
perfect example of this leading edge diversification of Florida's economy.
This new and still expanding state-of-the-art facility is Florida's largest
and most advanced Dedicated Hosting Center and one of only 16 such Qwest
CyberCenters nationwide.  This 96,000 square foot, 150-plus million dollar
facility is poised and ready to keep Florida among the top hosting locations
worldwide.

The Tampa Qwest CyberCenter provides a full range of hosting services and a
robust Information Technology environment, which will enable the full
spectrum of Florida businesses to outsource their Internet infrastructure.
The CyberCenter is a single-source Internet solutions provider, offering the
most comprehensive array of hosting services available in the industry.   It
features monitoring and management of web servers and mission-critical
applications 24/7.  The CyberCenter is rated to withstand a Class 5
hurricane and is equipped with redundant HVAC, fire detection and
suppression systems, power and LAN architecture.

Whether running multimedia, corporate intranet/extranet or e-commerce
applications, the Tampa Qwest CyberCenter provides a secure, reliable and
scalable foundation for the success of Florida businesses. Specifically
designed to provide state-of-the-art hosting for mission-critical Web sites
and enterprise applications, the Qwest CyberCenter provides a compelling
alternative to developing, deploying and staffing your own Internet data
center.

Qwest CyberCenters are staffed 24/7 and like Florida itself, we are always
open to new business.  From the history and charm of St. Augustine to the
futuristic advancements evidenced by the new Qwest CyberCenter in Tampa, the
state of Florida is uniquely positioned to span the centuries of American
history... past, present and yet to come.  The Qwest CyberCenter is a
shining example of the new Florida - a Florida poised and ready to champion
the economic growth of America's new millennium.  We welcome the opportunity
to share this new technology with the Governor of Florida via a personal
tour.  We welcome this opportunity to help the Governor's Office taut the
work of its ITFlorida Task Force.

Qwest strongly believes that the new Tampa CyberCenter represents the best
example of Florida's emergence as a worldwide center for high technology and
e-commerce.  Florida has already emerged as a crossroads for global commerce
and as a business development magnet for America's economic growth.  Qwest
is proud to support the Governor's initiatives in the areas of Information
Services and Technological Development.  Florida will continue to lead in
the area of Information Technology.  The Qwest CyberCenter is just one
example of the growth and expansion of this key sector of Florida's economy.

-----Original Message-----
From: Karen Kellams [mailto:KellamsK@dor.state.fl.us]
Sent: Wednesday, December 19, 2001 9:11 AM

Governor Bush,
I just sent Ms. Adkins an email asking her to call me or to send me her
phone number.  This is one of those private cases that the Department of
Revenue doesn't administer.  I'll call the Florida Association of Court

Subject: Problems collecting child support...help!


I have been without a child support payment since Sept 1 for my 3
children.  I waited the required 30 days before contacting my attorney
to get an income deduction order to have the child support payments
taken straight out of my former husbands salary.  It took another 6
weeks to get the order signed by a judge.  On November 30, 2001, I was
told by my former husband's employer that a check would be maild out
that day and be sent to the state depository.  That was 16 days ago
and
when I call the hotline number to check on the status of the payments,
they tell me that it has not been received or posted.  I now have to
wait another 7 business days so they can run a trace on the check to
see
where it went. 
This is RIDICULOUS!  I have 3 children that depend on the child
support
payments to eat, have clothing, shelter, school, and then some.  I was
wary about going through the state for collection of the child support
because this has happened to so many of my divorced friends.  As it
stands now, they will have no Christmas!  I have exhausted my savings
to
support them the last few months.  And to make matters worse, I have
to
go back to my attorney to get the back child support caught up along
with collecting the back medical bills I am owed for the last year!
That will cost me another $725.00 that I do not have! 
Any help in expediting my payment through the system will be greatly
appreciated.  My kids might be able to have a merry Christmas.

lost due to the first 2 delays in the building code. The amount of money I
will lose because of the next delay that you allowed has my company in a
position that I am simply not sure I will recover from. Because of the
delay, customers of mine will not come to market in January and the expected
revenues I anticipated are gone. Investors will not even talk to me anymore
because they, like I, have no faith anymore in our legislative system to do
what's good for the people that got them elected over special interest, and
believe that you will continue to allow special interest to have their way
with the code and continue to push it back or make changes.

difficult due to these delays in the code. Lack of revenues has caused my
personal credit and company credit to be effected negatively, and find it
impossible to get any sort of traditional lending from banks. Now that you
allowed the code to be delayed again, investors are scared and traditional
lending is difficult, what do you suggest I do to stay in business????

Dear Governor Bush:

I am not sure if you recieved this email, since you responded to the
first
one I sent both times. I send it again only for the very strong points
our
team has brought up on special session.

I know you must be extremely busy and I appreciate your timely response
to
my email. I also appreciate the attention you are paying to this very
important bill.

Our team has been reviewing the actions in Tallahassee with our legal
team
and other very interested parties around the country and would like to
ask
the following questions about the actions from earlier this week.

1: Due to the fact that the issue of the Florida Building Code was
outside
the purview of the call, doesn't the fact that President McKay allowed
this
bill to be heard during special session allude to special interest
activity
not in the best interest of the citizens of the state of Florida. As you
are
well aware this process started in 1996 with the building code study
commission. In 1998 the commission issued the single statewide building
code
and was agreed upon as being in the best interest of the state of
Florida.
It is now approaching 2002 and there are several states that have
adopted
building codes that incorporate hurricane protection, while our
legislature
has continuously delayed this very important code.

2: Many are questioning the legality of the actions taken during the
session
of the House pertaining to the delay of the Florida Building Code. Many
wonder if this was constitutionally correct.

3: Another point that has been brought to my attention is the language
in
the amendment to the Senate Bill 52C. The amendment states "design
professional who have been preparing construction documents in
anticipation
of the current Florida Law stipulating the implementation day for
January 1,
2002, may have their projects governed by the Florida Building Code that
would have been in effect". How can allowing this particular industry to
not
be financially affected by the delay, and other industries allowed to be
financially effected by the delay, not be a very harmful form of
discrimination.

As we are all aware right now more than ever, the safety and security of
our
families and children are of the utmost importance. The stringent
requirements of the new code, does nothing but enhance the safety and
security of our great state of Florida.

As I eluded to in my previous email, I ask once again for the
opportunity to
meet with you or speak to via telephone on this very important issue for
all
parties involved before you make judgment on this bill. There is a
solution
that everyone can be happy with.

Respectfully,

Peter Merhige
Protective Glass Industries
2546 Fowler Street
Ft Myers, FL 33901
941-936-4227

www.trishield.net

-----Original Message-----
From: Peter Merhige [mailto:peter@trishield.net]
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 5:26 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Florida Building Code


Dear Governor Bush,

I am writing to express my disappointment and disbelief that The Senate
and
House has once again voted to delay the Florida Building Code. I wrote
to
you last week expressing my feelings and giving you an understanding of
what
the severity of this action means to our company, but I feel I must do
it
again, since you are the last possible chance I have to save my
business.

My name is Peter Merhige and my company is Protective Glass Industries,
located in Ft Myers, Florida. My company was formed over 2 years ago for
the
purpose of developing and bringing to market a new product for the
hurricane
protection markets. The reason for forming the company and products was
for
the potential in the hurricane markets mainly due to the
development of the new Florida building code (THE CODE IN WHICH YOU
AGREED
WAS GOOD FOR FLORIDA) that contains hurricane protection. We have
designed
and have patents pending on the finest impact glass product in the
industry.
Not only does it protect from hurricane damage but also due to it's
insulating properties, reduces the cost of energy. We have spent well
over
$1,000,000 on the development and commercialization of our products and
due
to several delays in the statewide building code; we have lost millions
of
dollars. Over the last 2 days, I have lost close to $1 MILLION in
investment
money because of the actions in Tallahassee. Not only has our company
spent
over $1,000,000 but also there has been millions and millions of dollars
already spent to develop this code, along with millions and millions of
dollars spent by companies to enhance their products to meet the new
codes.
There are hundreds of companies ready to provide product for these new
building codes and there has been more than ample time to prepare for
it.

I do not know how to make this any clearer than to tell you that all of
mine
and all of my loyal employees' hard work to develop our products and
bring
them to market over the last 2+ years is over unless you help. We had
the
potential to create over 100 jobs for the state of Florida with revenues
over $100 million dollars over the next 3 years, which would obviously
be
put back into the Florida economy while protecting your citizens. We
have
close to 20 companies that were getting set to come to market with our
glass
the first of the year because of your code, and due to the delay, they
will
not until March (if the code doesn't get eliminated all together). Due
to
this delay and the uncertainty of Tallahassee which makes my investors
uncomfortable enough to not invest, I will not be able to keep the doors
open. Your are really my last hope to see that Tallahassee actually
thinks
of it's citizens over their own personal agendas.

We worked very hard to present ideas that would make sense for everyone
and
had some really good suggestions, but because of obvious personal
agendas,
we were ignored. Presently Senators McKay, Clary and Constatine along
with
Representative Bennet, who have businesses in the construction industry,
stated that Florida's counties were not ready for the code. Ourselves,
The
Florida League of Cities, AIF and many more, have proof through the DCA
that
only 8% of Florida was not ready to enforce the code.

We suggested that all counties not ready be given a 60 day delay to get
prepared and the other 92% who have worked extremely hard to do what you
wanted, enforce the code as scheduled. I cannot, even in my worst
nightmares, imagine how this would not satisfy everyone if that was
their
true objections. Obviously it was not and Politics once again was
Politics.

As I stated, you are our last chance. We are not alone. There are many
companies that will be put out of business because of this action. I do
know
you have the power to make this right. I am begging you for the
opportunity
to meet with you to politely express the feelings and concerns of our
company and our industry before you sign the bill to put us out of
business.
I don't think this is an unfair request since Tallahassee has
potentially
stripped my life from me.

I hope to hear from you or your office soon.

Respectfully,

Peter Merhige
Protective Glass Industries
2546 Fowler Street
Ft Myers, FL 33901
941-936-4227
941-936-2237 fax
www.trishield.net

-----Original Message-----
From: Kathy Shoaf [mailto:kcshoaf@yahoo.com]
Sent: Tuesday, December 18, 2001 10:24 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Thank you for the opportunity to be part of your team


Dear Governor:

A little over three years ago, you hired me to be part
of your team.  It has been, without a doubt, the
biggest honor of my life and also the most humbling.
You know how much I love you and that I would do
anything to help your continued success.

The past year has been a time of transition for me
with a new Chief of Staff.  It has been an honor to
work with Kathleen and help her get situated in
Tallahassee. I admire her talents and repect her
abilities tremendously.  However, over the last few
months, Kathleen and I both have come to realize that
she needs someone else with skills more suitable to
her management style.  

Over the last seven weeks, Kathleen and I have
discussed my performance, or lack there of, on a
couple of occasions.  I have not been able to provide
her with the consistent performance that she requires
and this has been a great source of frustration to her
and to me, as well.  She has made it abudantly clear
to me on numerous occasions, that she is exceedingly
frustrated with me.  At one point, I told her that
maybe she needed someone else in my job who could
better serve her needs. After a discussion, a weekend
of thought, we agreed that I would continue in my job,
sharing some of the resonsibilites - and that if
either one of us felt a change was needed, we would
say so. I am sorry to say, I was not successful in my
attempts to provide her with the performance she needs
from me.  On December 11, before the memorial ceremony
in the courtyard, she told me, "This is not working
out - you are not handling things the way I want them.
 I want Betty Jordan to sit at your desk and to manage
the office."  I told her I understood and that it
would happen.  After Kathleen left for the ceremony, I
told Betty Jordan what Kathleen said and that we
needed to implement her wishes ASAP so that we could
focus on getting the work done for her.  Betty Jordan
approached Kathleen after the ceremony and shortly
thereafter, Kathleen told me she should not have said
what she did regarding moving Betty to my position. 
She instructed me to work on a list on how best to
distribute some of my duties. I began working on the
list.  On Friday morning, 12/14, Betty Jordan told me
that Kathleen had told her the night before that she
wanted her (Betty) to sit at my desk and manage the
office.  At that point, Betty J. and I agreed that we
were both getting the same message from Kathleen and,
since last Friday, the two of us have tried to
accommodate Kathleen's request - by working together
to make the change happen.  On Friday, 12/14, Betty J.
talked with Brian and Frank and told them of
Kathleen's request, and I met with them also. I told
them that it was very clear to me that this situation
needed to be resolved ASAP and that it was becoming a
huge distraction - Kathleen needed the person that
could best work with her management style. 

Sir, your time is so valuable and I have over extended
what was to be a simple, thoughtful message to you.  I
wanted to let you know that in the best interest of
the office, and in helping Kathleen have the kind of
administrative support she needs, it is time for me to
leave my position with the COS and find another
opportunity within your administration to serve you,
if you still feel that I can be an effective memeber
of your team.  I have asked Brian and Frank to please
consider me for a transfer as soon as possible to
accommodate Kathleen's request.


Thank you for your time and for letting me be part of
your administration.  I will carry this great honor
with me always.   I cherish the opportunity you have
given me.  Thank you for your time and for your
thoughtful consideration.

Sincerely,
Kathy

From:	dona hannagan <highlandsfrs@go.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 18, 2001 10:07 PM
To:	thomas.irvin@edu.gov
Cc:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	IDEA Call In

Mr Irvin:

First I want to thank you for the opportunity to call in today. I was concerned when I realized there were only 2 of us calling in.

It was difficult to hear but I feel I was able to understand MOST of what was said.

When I shared my story and attempted to share why we are concerned I don't feel I was listened to . I feel the forum just kept saying ours is an isolated istance. What I shared several times is that ours is NOT isolated.

As a result of our struggles, I am now a trainer for our PTI and a Family Resource Specialist for our part C program. I am active in STAND our statewide advocacy network.I am out there being a part of the solution. I have personally stopped over 40 Due Processes from happening by helping parents address the school.

This has not prevented our school from destroying our family. 

When IDEA is reauthorized there must be a way for parents to be protected from schools who have VERY deep pockets. 

As I have shared we prevailed in Due Process but because the school refused to accept it we are still in litigation. She is in 3rd grade. This all began in K. The school refuses to count her in FTE so there is no protection under IDEA. Because we are in litigation OCR, OSEP and EEOC will not do anything to protect her. They are continually causing us to spend money we don't have because we can't stop or we won't get our attorney fees. We owe thosands of dollars to an attorney who is making nothing practically because he knows we can't pay him what we should.

The system as it is presently keeps parents from pushing for Due Process and Attorneys from taking cases.

This allows the schools to run rampant over the parents and childrens rights.

During the forum I heard ESE Directors saying that giving out proceedural safeguards causes parents to distrust the school and is an expensive part of the system. 

Oh my goodness! Please don't allow them to be able to stop explaining the parents rights. Maybe we can say after the first set is given the parents can say No thank you I don't need another copy but please make it be required that it is offered. 

Most of us could wallpaper our home with the paperwork we get at each meeting. IDEA did not accomplish the paperwork reduction anticiapted.

My solution was and continues to be- There has to be a watchdog that is NOT hired or paid for by the district in each area that monitors compliance. This person could be part of the PTI or a totally seperate agency. It can't be connected with the school in anyway.

The local districts around here have parents hired by the district or the FDLRS. Both of these situations are not really ones that will guarentee the persons job will be protected if they find a problem.

I have friends who work in these situations and they say If I say that I will be fired you go say it for me.

We have to find a way to stop the wasted money on Due Process and Appeals forced to happen by districts that refuse to do what is right. Parents and Childrens rights are not protected.

Please find a way to protect parents from these districts that refuse to do what is right.

My husband developed a program that he used for his EdD. He reduced discipline by 50% when he was a principal. 

His whole class scores were raised at the .10 significance level. They were all ESE or Title One students. 

While listening to the forum we kept hearing it will take time. It doesn't have to take years. The above scores happened in less than 1 school year.

Why did this happen? 

For one he incorporated Charecter Education into the currculum rather than just an add on program that was jammed in someplace. 

He helped the kids see that there was value in "doing right because its right to do right" not just so you get paid or rewarded.

He taught team effort to help EVERYONE be successful.

But most importantly he cared.

It didn't take any new materials it just took effort. 

We need to allow our teachers time be good teachers. Maybe then we will eliminate some of the problems we have right now.

If we allow them to be good teachers and hold them truly accountable for doing a good job,the they will strive to be better. Right now, we just beat them up if they are wrong and ignore what is good.

We also need to eliminate the bad. If a district is found to be purposefully ignoring parental and student rights people in TOP postions should be fired. Don't blame the teacher who does what they do just to keep their job.

When litigation is in place, the parents need a place to go that will protect them. They should not have to pay to be protected.

If the school does not prevail in DUE PROCESS the attorney fees should be given right there. It shouldn't have to wait until the school appeals and gets continuances and.....

It is expensive to have a child with a disability. We pay for Therapy because the school won't do a good job, we pay for medical bills and we pay for activities that we want to have our child in so they can "be Normal". We can't pay so the school can keep us in court.

They also said we can't solve it for just one child it has to be for the group. Don't you realize that each small victory makes it easier for the next one? Look at Rosa Parks, Martin Luther and his one man rebellion aginst the churh, look at Mother Teresa - The list could go on and on. 

As the saying goes I am only one I can't do evrything but I can do something.

Thank You for "listening". I will once again offer my services t be a part of teh solution. If I can ever do ANYTHING to solve this please let me know!

Sincerely,
DonaKay Hannagan

From:	Jeb Bush
Sent:	Tuesday, December 18, 2001 10:01 PM

-----Original Message-----
From: Langston, Don [mailto:Don.Langston@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US]
Sent: Tuesday, December 18, 2001 9:38 AM
To: Jeb Bush; Brogan, Frank; Shanahan, Kathleen; Yablonski, Brian; Jimenez, Frank; Baur, Katie; Arduin, Donna; Turbeville, Greg
Subject: Business Groups--Economic Survey Results



This is a report on the results of the ninth week of economic surveys conducted by the Florida Retail Federation, National Federation of Independent Business, Associated Industries of Florida, the Florida Chamber of Commerce, and the Florida Hotel and Motel Association.  The surveys will continue through the end of December.

For the for the week ending December 3, the survey results across all industry groups show stability in sales and employment (compared to the same period last year).  As expressed in the previous report conditions do not seem to be getting noticeably worse or better right now. For sales compared to the same week last year, 43% of respondents indicated that they had lower sales, the same as reported last week.  The negative responses for employment (22% of respondents) are the same as the 22% recorded last week.  

Responses regarding the economic outlook are unchanged since last week. 

The occupancy survey results below show there have been sporadic signs of improvement in occupancy rates and average daily room rates in different regions of the state, but generally these measures are still significantly below last year's levels.  

Don: 
Our cumulative results, including this week's survey ending Dec. 9 are as follows: 
1) Sales indicators: 
NORTH FLORIDA: 
Week ending Sept. 16 - Occupancy down 26% and average daily rate (ADR) unchanged. 
Week ending Sept. 23 - Occupancy down 15% and ADR down 5%. 
Week ending Sept. 30 - Occupancy down 12% and ADR down 4%. 
Week ending Oct. 7 - Occupancy down 17% and ADR down 9% 
Week ending Oct. 14 - Occupancy down 21% and ADR down 8% 
Week ending Oct. 21 - Occupancy down 27% and ADR down 8% 
Week ending Oct. 28 - Occupancy down 18% and ADR up 2% 
Week ending Nov. 4 - Occupancy down 12% and ADR down 18% 
Week ending Nov.11 - Occupancy down 7% and ADR down 8% 
Week ending Nov. 18 - Occupancy down 17% and ADR down 7% 
Week ending Nov. 25 - Occupancy down 16% and ADR down 3% 
Week ending Dec. 2 - Occupancy up 7% and ADR down 6% 
Week ending Dec. 9 - Occupancy down 14% and ADR down 4%

Week ending Sept. 16 - Occupancy down 35% and ADR down 18% 
Week ending Sept. 23 - Occupancy down 48% and ADR down 30% 
Week ending Sept. 30 - Occupancy down 40% and ADR down 22% 
Week ending Oct. 7 - Occupancy down 32% and ADR down 17% 
Week ending Oct. 14 - Occupancy down 23% and ADR down 19% 
Week ending Oct. 21 - Occupancy down 22% and ADR down 12% 
Week ending Oct. 28 - Occupancy down 20% and ADR down 11% 
Week ending Nov. 4 - Occupancy down 22% and ADR down 8% 
Week ending Nov.11 - Occupancy down 20% and ADR down 15% 
Week ending Nov. 18 - Occupancy down 15% and ADR down 14% 
Week ending Nov. 25 - Occupancy down 12% and ADR down 9% 
Week ending Dec. 2 - Occupancy down 19% and ADR down 6% 
Week ending Dec. 9 - Occupancy down 21% and ADR down 14%

2) Statewide, payrolls REMAIN LOWER, and have now been reduced an estimated 22% statewide. 
3) Advance bookings for the next 90 days remain LOWER by about 9% statewide. 
4) The outlook for the next 6 months to a year remains WORSE (estimated down by 4%).

----- Forwarded by Tom Barry/CO/FDOT on 12/18/2001 07:18 AM -----
                                                                                            
                    Dick Kane                                                               
                                         To:     Tom Barry/CO/FDOT@FDOT, Ken                
                    12/17/2001            Morefield/CO/FDOT@FDOT, Cris Speer/CO/FDOT@FDOT,  
                    05:50 PM              DISTSEC, Freddie L Simmons/CO/FDOT@FDOT, Ed       
                                          Rice/CO/FDOT@FDOT, DIST-PIO                       
                                         cc:     katie.baur@myflorida.com,                  
                                          Elizabeth.Hirst@MyFlorida.com                     
                                         Subject:     TRIP Urban Safety Study               
                                                                                            



Good afternoon, here's an overview of my interview with USA Today reporter
Blake Morrison re DOT's reaction to The Road Information Program's (TRIP)
Urban Safety Study which will be released tomorrow:

   Safety remains our priority - although we are doing more than ever
   before, we continue to ask ourselves, "What else do we need to do to
   address this problem?"

   The Governor, the Florida Legislature, and Secretary Barry - along with
   our transportation partners - have lead the effort to dramatically
   increase transportation funding in the state over the past two years
   (Mobility 2000 & recent economic stimulus package) - this effort will
   save lives.

   I did not criticize TRIP's numbers or recommendations - in fact - other
   than keeping roads deiced during inclement weather, Florida is already
   taking all the steps to improve motorists, pedestrians, and bicyclists
   safety that TRIP recommends in its study.

   Even though the pure number of fatalities in Florida is going up, our
   fatality rate is going down.  Commercial Motor Vehicle (CMV) fatalities
   were down 11 percent in 2000.

   On the engineering side, we are spending $40 million to improve
   lighting, turn lanes, remove obstacles, etc.

   On the education and enforcement sides, we are spending $18 million on
   behavior issues like, alcohol countermeasures, occupant protection,
   bicycle/pedestrian safety, speed control, police traffic services, etc.

   The FSU/FAMU College of Engineering is doing a $450,000 study for DOT
   that will analyze all 1,802 fatalities on the state highway system in
   2000 to try to find out what could have prevented them.

   DOT's upper management is doing more through the Sterling process to
   improve transportation system safety.  We are addressing safety issues
   in each district by defining the problems & countermeasures.

   Morrison says the story should run in tomorrow's USA Today in Section A
   - probably page 3.

   I expect we'll get a few phone calls.  Ed Rice & I can handle the big
   picture up here.  Feel free to talk about your local issues.  Thanks,
   Dick Kane








(See attached file: Urban Safety 2001.doc)(See attached file: FLURBSAFETY
FTBA.doc)

-----Original Message-----
From: Edrank70@cs.com [mailto:Edrank70@cs.com]
Sent: Tuesday, December 18, 2001 8:41 PM
To: Hedgcock@aol.com
Cc: Jeb Bush
Subject: Hospital closure


12/15/01 
Official: GPW closure not trouble-free 

7 jailed, 3 dead, 1 missing, official confirms 


The state's plan to shift G. Pierce Wood patients into community-based 
programs has gone very well, according to Celeste Putnam, director of 
mental health programs for the Florida Department of Children and 
Families. 

However, that doesn't mean the transition from the DeSoto County mental 
hospital has been trouble-free, she confirmed this week. 

Putnam, in a phone interview, responded to confirm that, of 215 patients 
discharged since January, seven have been jailed, three died and one was 
missing. 

Also, three of 22 Florida Assertive Community Treatment teams, which 
were 
launched in the past two years to provide supervision for discharged 
patients in their home communities, have run amok with problems. 

One of those teams, the Ruth Cooper Center's team in Fort Myers, 
disbanded 
and dropped its state contract. Putnam said DCF is working to hire 
another 
team "with a proven track record" to take over the Fort Myers clients. 

Another team, the Bolley Center's team in St. Petersburg, was barred for 
weeks from taking on new patients. But problems have since been 
corrected 
and the moratorium lifted. 

Another team also came under scrutiny elsewhere in the state until 
problems 
were corrected, Putnam said. 

But, she pointed out, the 22 teams now have 862 patients statewide, an 
average of 39 each. The teams will eventually supervise 100 each, or 
2,200 
patients statewide. 

"We're working with them very closely," Putnam said. "Overall, given 
that 
we have 22 teams, we think they are doing very well. 

"In fact, the Legislature in the last session asked us to start up three 
more FACT teams in the non-GPW areas," Putnam noted. 

Some 38 percent of GPW's discharged patients are now living 
independently 
under the supervision of the FACT teams, according to a report of a Nov. 
27 
GPW staff meeting. 

Only 6 percent -- 13 out of 215 -- were discharged to nursing homes, 
according to another DCF report. 

"Clients in independent living are maintaining," the GPW staff report 
said. 
"Most are taking (their) meds and keeping appointments." 

The closure plan calls for a GPW discharge outreach team to take a 
patient 
to the new community residence -- where a FACT team member was supposed 
to 
be waiting to meet the new client. 

Putnam confirmed reports, however, that on "a couple of occasions very 
early on in our discharge process" there was no FACT team member present 
to 
receive the patient. That problem was corrected, however, she said. 

"There were no serious incidents that resulted (from the failure to meet 
the patient)," Putnam said. 

Putnam confirmed, however, that a number of nursing homes and assisted 
living facilities turned away mental patients because they were too 
difficult to supervise. 

"The ALFs just could not meet their needs," Putnam said. 

However, she said, the candor of the ALFs allowed GPW staffers to find 
more 
suitable arrangements for the patients elsewhere. 

Since July, some 27 patients have been discharged to other state 
hospitals 
because they were too ill to be shifted into community programs. 

Since January, only two discharged GPW patients were involuntarily 
committed back into a state hospital, under the Baker Act. 

"We've reduced hospitalizations -- compared to 1999 -- by 77 percent," 
she 
said. 

At least nine patients left the state, and three left the country. 

Putnam said seven discharged patients wound up in jail. However, five 
have 
since been released, she said. 

None of the incarcerations were for "serious incidents, that I'm aware 
of," 
Putnam said. 

Three discharged patients have died. Putnam said she knows of no death 
due 
to neglect. The causes included heart attack, stroke and "progressive 
decline in a nursing home," Putnam said. 

The patient who apparently died of a heart attack, John Hicks, 56, stirs 
further questions, however. He died in the loft of his group home in 
East 
Fort Myers, according to a Lee County Sheriff's report. One of the 
paramedics who responded called an abuse hotline after noting the room 
was 
unsanitary. 

Putnam also said one patient disappeared from a Manatee County FACT team 
and hasn't been seen since. He left his apartment to visit his parents 
for 
Thanksgiving and never arrived. Police have been notified. 

"We are concerned about the fact he's missing but I don't think it's 
because of the FACT team," Putnam said. 

As of early December, the hospital had just 88 patients remaining. Of 
those, 38 were to be discharged into community programs and 50 to other 
state hospitals. 

There were 450 employees, with about 240 who have yet to line up new 
jobs, 
according to GPW newsletter.

-----Original Message-----
From: Jeeeperzz@aol.com [mailto:Jeeeperzz@aol.com]
Sent: Monday, December 17, 2001 11:07 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Problems collecting child support...help!


I have been without a child support payment since Sept 1 for my 3 children.  I waited the required 30 days before contacting my attorney to get an income deduction order to have the child support payments taken straight out of my former husbands salary.  It took another 6 weeks to get the order signed by a judge.  On November 30, 2001, I was told by my former husband's employer that a check would be maild out that day and be sent to the state depository.  That was 16 days ago and when I call the hotline number to check on the status of the payments, they tell me that it has not been received or posted.  I now have to wait another 7 business days so they can run a trace on the check to see where it went. 
This is RIDICULOUS!  I have 3 children that depend on the child support payments to eat, have clothing, shelter, school, and then some.  I was wary about going through the state for collection of the child support because this has happened to so many of my divorced friends.  As it stands now, they will have no Christmas!  I have exhausted my savings to support them the last few months.  And to make matters worse, I have to go back to my attorney to get the back child support caught up along with collecting the back medical bills I am owed for the last year!  That will cost me another $725.00 that I do not have! 
Any help in expediting my payment through the system will be greatly appreciated.  My kids might be able to have a merry Christmas. 

Sincerely, 

Sonya C. Adkins 
8241 Glasgow Court 
Jacksonville, FL  32244 

Case # 98-0001910

-----Original Message-----
From: Scott Jackson [mailto:scott@info-strategies.com]
Sent: Tuesday, December 18, 2001 4:12 PM
To: Pamella Dana
Cc: David Bishop; Chris Lewis; Marla Gillman
Subject: Military.com Article on Gov Bush


In talking with Chris at the DC office the timing of the article has been moved to the first week of January to get the most eyeballs.
 
Typically web site traffic experiences a precipitous drop at the holiday stretch (underway).  Moreover, tidbits germane to the interview might surface in the interim and enrich the product.
 
On a different subject, the change of command for the Air Force Special Operations Command at Hurlburt will be Jan 16th which I am sure is known there.  However, the new commander, Lt Gen Paul Hester (an old squadron buddy from years ago) has a career lineage that you might want to make note of.  From 1986 to 1989, he was the Chief, U.S. House of Representatives liaison, Office of the Secretary of the Air Force for Legislative Liaison.  From 1997 to 1999 he was the Director, Legislative Liaison, Office of the Secretary of the Air Force at the Pentagon.
 
Scott

-----Original Message-----
From: sgriffith@mcguirewoods.com [mailto:sgriffith@mcguirewoods.com]
Sent: Tuesday, December 18, 2001 12:36 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: sbpres@sg.ufl.edu; das@whopper.com; cja@alfonsoarchitects.com; manny.fernandez@gartner.com; lulufarm@aol.com; wamcgriff@aol.com; joelenkm@aol.com; danirola@aol.com; MorganDianna@aol.com; coconnell@webershandwick.com; athweatt43@aol.com; alfredwar@aol.com; ceyoung@ufl.edu; colburn@nervm.nerdc.ufl.edu; rbryan9786@aol.com; pbernard@ufl.edu; fphandyman@aol.com
Subject: Message from Marshall Criser below.



Dear Governor:



You are on a roll. All reports are that your attendance and your message were extremely well received by all in attendance at UF Commencement on Saturday. We need to be reminded what an important event the earning of a college degree continues to be to the recipient and to his or her family and friends. That is why UF has maintained the tradition that each graduate be individually recognized (and on Saturday congratulated by his or her Governor). 



This new governance system will work if it is implemented as it was proposed and designed. That includes removal of "state agency" status and devolvement of management and accountability to the Boards of Trustees.  It is crucial that this be completed at the Regular Session.



In order to achieve credibility, responsible restraint must be imposed on legislative leadership who in recent years have conferred "most favored nation" status on selected programs at certain state universities that are extremely expensive and clearly parochial. While this gains favor of the few it demonstrates that parity or even equity is not being considered by the imposers. The system is therefore criticized and rebuked. A governatorial veto is a remedy if prior restraint is not accomplished.



When a completed and credible governance system is in place (as opposed to being intended) UF and other state universities will be well positioned to conduct successful searches at all administrative levels.


Marshall M. Criser
McGuireWoods LLP
Bank of America Tower
50 North Laura Street, Suite 3300
Jacksonville, Florida 32202
904.798.2682 (Direct Line)
904.798.3207 (Direct FAX)
sgriffith@mcguirewoods.com

This e-mail may contain confidential or privileged information. If you are not the intended recipient, please advise by return e-mail and delete immediately without reading or forwarding to others.

information on him and his situation.  Mr. Smith does not have an eviction
notice yet.  The social worker will be talking to the landlord today. (Also,
the social worker is going to help him get toys for his 6 year old son who
is living with him.)

From:	Langston, Don <Don.Langston@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 18, 2001 9:38 AM
To:	Jeb Bush; Brogan, Frank; Shanahan, Kathleen; Yablonski, Brian; Jimenez, Frank; Baur, Katie; Arduin, Donna; Turbeville, Greg
Subject:	Business Groups--Economic Survey Results

This is a report on the results of the ninth week of economic surveys conducted by the Florida Retail Federation, National Federation of Independent Business, Associated Industries of Florida, the Florida Chamber of Commerce, and the Florida Hotel and Motel Association.  The surveys will continue through the end of December.

For the for the week ending December 3, the survey results across all industry groups show stability in sales and employment (compared to the same period last year).  As expressed in the previous report conditions do not seem to be getting noticeably worse or better right now. For sales compared to the same week last year, 43% of respondents indicated that they had lower sales, the same as reported last week.  The negative responses for employment (22% of respondents) are the same as the 22% recorded last week.  

Responses regarding the economic outlook are unchanged since last week. 

The occupancy survey results below show there have been sporadic signs of improvement in occupancy rates and average daily room rates in different regions of the state, but generally these measures are still significantly below last year's levels.  

Don: 
Our cumulative results, including this week's survey ending Dec. 9 are as follows: 
1) Sales indicators: 
NORTH FLORIDA: 
Week ending Sept. 16 - Occupancy down 26% and average daily rate (ADR) unchanged. 
Week ending Sept. 23 - Occupancy down 15% and ADR down 5%. 
Week ending Sept. 30 - Occupancy down 12% and ADR down 4%. 
Week ending Oct. 7 - Occupancy down 17% and ADR down 9% 
Week ending Oct. 14 - Occupancy down 21% and ADR down 8% 
Week ending Oct. 21 - Occupancy down 27% and ADR down 8% 
Week ending Oct. 28 - Occupancy down 18% and ADR up 2% 
Week ending Nov. 4 - Occupancy down 12% and ADR down 18% 
Week ending Nov.11 - Occupancy down 7% and ADR down 8% 
Week ending Nov. 18 - Occupancy down 17% and ADR down 7% 
Week ending Nov. 25 - Occupancy down 16% and ADR down 3% 
Week ending Dec. 2 - Occupancy up 7% and ADR down 6% 
Week ending Dec. 9 - Occupancy down 14% and ADR down 4% 
CENTRAL FLORIDA: 
Week ending Sept. 16 - Occupancy down 35% and ADR down 18% 
Week ending Sept. 23 - Occupancy down 48% and ADR down 30% 
Week ending Sept. 30 - Occupancy down 40% and ADR down 22% 
Week ending Oct. 7 - Occupancy down 32% and ADR down 17% 
Week ending Oct. 14 - Occupancy down 23% and ADR down 19% 
Week ending Oct. 21 - Occupancy down 22% and ADR down 12% 
Week ending Oct. 28 - Occupancy down 20% and ADR down 11% 
Week ending Nov. 4 - Occupancy down 22% and ADR down 8% 
Week ending Nov.11 - Occupancy down 20% and ADR down 15% 
Week ending Nov. 18 - Occupancy down 15% and ADR down 14% 
Week ending Nov. 25 - Occupancy down 12% and ADR down 9% 
Week ending Dec. 2 - Occupancy down 19% and ADR down 6% 
Week ending Dec. 9 - Occupancy down 21% and ADR down 14% 
WEST FLORIDA: 
Week ending Sept. 16 - Occupancy down 42% and ADR down 8% 
Week ending Sept. 23 - Occupancy down 39% and ADR down 15% 
Week ending Sept. 30 - Occupancy down 29% and ADR down 10% 
Week Ending Oct. 7 - Occupancy down 19% and ADR down 5% 
Week ending Oct. 14 - Occupancy down 17% and ADR down 3% 
Week ending Oct. 21 - Occupancy down 19% and ADR down 4% 
Week ending Oct. 28 - Occupancy down 23% and ADR down 4% 
Week ending Nov. 4 - Occupancy down 21% and ADR up 5% 
Week ending Nov.11 - Occupancy down 18% and ADR down 3% 
Week ending Nov. 18 - Occupancy down 17% and ADR down 7% 
Week ending Nov. 25 - Occupancy down 18% and ADR down 2% 
Week ending Dec. 2 - Occupancy down 13% and ADR down 3% 
Week ending Dec. 9 - Occupancy down 14% and ADR down 4% 
SOUTH FLORIDA: 
Week ending Sept. 16 - Occupancy down 38% and ADR down 7% 
Week ending Sept. 23 - Occupancy down 52% and ADR down 11% 
Week ending Sept. 30 - Occupancy down 42% and ADR down 15% 
Week ending Oct. 7 - Occupancy down 29% and ADR down 9% 
Week ending Oct. 14 - Occupancy down 22% and ADR down 7% 
Week ending Oct. 21 - Occupancy down 20% and ADR down 10% 
Week ending Oct. 28 - Occupancy down 21% and ADR down 3% 
Week ending Nov. 4 - Occupancy down 26% and ADR down 11% 
Week ending Nov.11 - Occupancy down 18% and ADR down 4% 
Week ending Nov. 18 - Occupancy down 28% and ADR down 15% 
Week ending Nov. 25 - Occupancy down 22% and ADR down 16% 
Week ending Dec. 2 - Occupancy down 12% and ADR down 8% 
Week ending Dec. 9 - Occupancy down 18% and ADR down 9% 
2) Statewide, payrolls REMAIN LOWER, and have now been reduced an estimated 22% statewide. 
3) Advance bookings for the next 90 days remain LOWER by about 9% statewide. 
4) The outlook for the next 6 months to a year remains WORSE (estimated down by 4%). 
Gary Smith 
Executive Vice President 
Florida Hotel & Motel Association

From:	Harold O'Neal <diaspora8@lycos.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 18, 2001 7:56 AM
To:	tdedit@taldem.com
Cc:	stevelauraj@aol.com; Jeb Bush
Subject:	Bright Futures

Editors:

We have further proof that the so - called civil rights lobby is nothing but a bunch of self interested partisan Democrats. The Center for Fair and Open Testing's targeting Florida's Bright Futures program for criticism by suggesting that it is unfair to minorities is an obvious political hit; a clear attempt to antagonize Florida's black voters to turn out to defeat Jeb Bush in 2002 by making it appear as if the Bush administration is using Bright Futures to limit black access to college.

The Center for Fair and Open Testing in their zeal to criticize Bush administration did not mention that the Bright Futures Program was created years ago by a Florida Democrats. They also did not explain why only now, years after the program has been in place and in the midst of a Republican governor's re - election campaign do they raise these issues. And why hasn't the Center for Fair and Open Testing yet gone after Georgia's Hope Scholarship program, which was the model for Bright Futures, is being copied by many other states, and has existed for over ten years? (Hint: The governor of Georgia is a Democrat.) 

The debate over the fairness of standardized testing and access to quality education for minorities is one that needs to take place. However it is becoming clear that self interested leftist groups are the wrong people to represent blacks in this debate. For this situation the media must share blame. For instance, this newspaper should have asked tougher questions of the Center on why they were only targeting Florida's program and why now. This paper also should have mentioned the very large number of bright needy black college students in Florida that receive Bright Futures, and how it is in effect a legal nondiscriminatory replacement for race based scholarships. This newspaper did not, which I suppose is why you are called the Democrat. Thank you.

Harold O'Neal
2323 Stucky Street
Tallahassee, Florida 32310
850-662-4491

-----Original Message-----
From: Smith Family [mailto:zozer@mediaone.net]
Sent: Monday, December 17, 2001 10:19 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Electric Utility Deregulation


Dear Governor, To voice our opinions, my husband and I are not in favor of
the electrical companies deregulation in our state. We are quite happy with
FPL. Their rates are reasonable, service is dependable and after Hurricane
Andrew, they put back the power in an amazingly short time. With
deregulation, you actually let in other power companies who will be using
FPL lines who will have to pay for that use, thus creating a middle man and
higher prices. From the article in the Miami Herald,12/2/01, Katie Baur said
that most Floridians are for this. We are not. The real problem with
utilities in this state is the amount of taxes tacked on to utility bills:
my FPL bill was $143.75 and the taxes were $21.32, 14.8% in taxes. My cell
phone has 21% in taxes. These are unfair and obviously too high. Do
something about the taxes and forget about deregulation. The money that both
sides are spending in lobbying,could be used for people's benefits instead.
Nancy and Brett Smith of Coral Gables,Fl.

From: Laura A Wilson [mailto:law01@juno.com]
