Subject: RE: Questions about my son's death


Dear Governor Bush,

Thank you for acting on my request for answers in the manner in which
the
FHP handled the investigation of my son, Richard McKeefery's death by a
traffic incident that occurred on 04/24/01 in Tampa.

Unfortunately, Colonel Knight continues to direct my inquiries to
Captain
Tharpe of the Tampa patrol division who does not return my phone
messages.  He has never contacted me and I continue to get his answering
device.

I'd also like the DMV to explain why Martin's license was not suspended
on 04/02/01 since he had accumulated 14 pts in an eight month period by
that date.

If you read my list of questions in it's entirety, you're aware that
several of Florida's agencies has a lot to answer for in the manner in
which my son and our family has been treated.

I understand that Cynthia Holden handed you a letter and the list of
questions personally, she's been a God send and I'm proud to have a
person of her moral strength and character helping us in this fight for
justice.

It's really difficult when state legislatures claim that the law is
unimportant, that it wouldn't have mattered if Martin's license would
have been suspended because people still drive on suspended licenses. 
What they seem to fail to recognize is that because he had a pending DUI
from another crash he caused on 03/02/01 and had caused another crash on
04/13/01, less than two weeks before killing my son that more would have
been done to get him off the road.  They knew how dangerous this man's
driving was and continue to deny responsibility in their role by
allowing
him to keep a legal license.

Even if he'd still been on the road, he'd automatically be serving time
for the death of my son now instead of receiving a careless driving
ticket for something which is obviously manslaughter and he has shown
absolutely no remorse to our family for his actions.

I believe anyone who has a conscience cannot turn away from this
occurrence and will do what they can to see that the current laws are
followed and to provide legislation that will require blood testing for
drugs/alcohol in the case of severe injury/fatality in a traffic
incident.  Victims have no choice in this during the autopsy, where are
their rights?  When people are given drug tests by employers to simply
stock shelves don't the victim/victim's familiy have a right to know if
drugs/alcohol played a role in their loved one's death or injury? 
Shouldn't the culprit get more than a simple fine, less than a speeding
ticket for killing someone negligently?

Thank you for your time and effort in this matter.

Sincerely,
Laura A. Wilson
5115 N. Lister Ave.
Kansas City, MO  64119

(816) 413 - 9797

-----Original Message-----
From: JR Harding [mailto:jharding@garnet.acns.fsu.edu]
Sent: Monday, December 17, 2001 4:19 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: Regina Lopez-Loucel
Subject: Fw: What happened to Hilda


 Governor,
You should know, that one of our colleagues/your appointee to ADAWG passed
away.  Below is the husbands narrative regarding the particulars.
JR
> Subject: What happened to Hilda
>
>
> Normally my wife, Hilda and I travel to work together.  I take her to her
> job at Miami International Airport and drop her off, go about my business
> and then pick her up in the afternoon.  This gave us about an hour and a
> half in the morning and about an hour in the evening of rush hour traffic
to
> be alone together and talk about the world in general or catch up on
events
> of the day.  On Fridays, I have a standing weekly conference call along
with
> my coworkers at my work.  Because of this, on Fridays I take Hilda a few
> blocks away to one of our friend's (and coworker of Hilda's) house and she
> rides to work with her.  <?xml:namespace prefix = o ns =
> "urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office" />
>
> Last Friday, I dropped Hilda off at Aida's, gave her the normal "peck on
the
> cheek" kiss goodbye and went back to my house to proceeded with the
> conference call.  While on the call I got a page on my beeper with a
> telephone number I didn't recognize and "911" written after it.  I called
> the message and was told that my wife had fainted on her way to work and
the
> paramedics were taking her to the hospital.  Luckily Carey Ann and Richard
> were home from school as they both finished their finals earlier this
week.
> Carey went with me and Richard stayed at the house to field telephone
calls.
> The initial call said they were taking Hilda to Baptist Hospital but later
I
> got another call on the cellular phone saying they were taking her to
> Kendall Regional Hospital.  Five years ago Hilda had a tough bout with
> congestive heart failure caused by a virus she had pick up somewhere.
> Because of this and the fact that the paramedics changed locations, I
> realized the seriousness of the situation and called Hilda's brother,
Ruben,
> who picked up Hilda's parents and headed to the hospital.  The paramedics
> who responded to the call knew Hilda from Richard and Carey Ann's six year
> involvement with the Miami-Dade Fire Rescue Explorers Program.  One of the
> paramedics, Lt Eddie Ballester has been one of Richard's primary mentor
for
> much of this time and they've become much more than good friends.  Eddie
> called Richard and told him it could be serious that we needed to get
right
> to the hospital.  Richard called his sister and me, I updated Hilda's
> brother and we all met at the hospital.
>
> When we arrived we found out that two rescue units had responded, One with
> Lt Ballester in charge and the other with Lt Jose Nochea in charge,
another
> Firefighter Richard and Carey had worked with.  The told us Hilda was
"flat
> lined" when they got to her (Nochea's unit responded in less that three
> minutes and Ballester's was less than three minutes behind him).  They had
> shocked her to revived her, gave her a very strong medication, transported
> her to the hospital and she was being worked on inside.  All of this
> transpired from 7:55 to until we got to the hospital at 8:50 because of
rush
> hour traffic.  The doctor came out and told us here heart was beating on
> it's own, her sugar count was somewhat high, she was only faintly
breathing
> on her own so they had put her on a respirator. The were going to do a
> series of test excluding a cat scan and we'd hear something within two to
> three hours.
>
> Later a neurologist came to us to say Hilda was "brain dead" and we would
> have to make a decision as to weather to disconnect the life support
> equipment.  Dr. Lou Romeg, Director of Emergency Services and also a
mentor
> to Richard was with us.  Dr. Romeg reminded the neurologist that there was
a
> protocol they needed to do that would take about 4 to 6 hours.  The whole
> family packed into cars and drove to church where we stayed for about
three
> hours.  We went back to the hospital, took turns going in and saying good
> bye and at about 7:45 Hilda passed on.
>
> HILDA BERTRAN OLEXA
>
> A FINAL VIEWING FOR HILDA WILL BE HELD ON SUNDAY, DECEMBER 16TH
> FROM 3:00 PM TO 10:00 PM.
>
> CABALLERO RIVERO WOODLAWN FUNERAL HOME
> 8200 BIRD ROAD (SW 40TH ST AND 82 AVE)
> MIAMI, FLORIDA 33155
> 305 237-3344
>
>
> THERE WILL BE A FUNERAL MASS AT 12:00 PM MONDAY, DECEMBER 17TH
>
> ST LOUIS CATHOLIC CHURCH
> 7270 SW 120 STREET
> PINECREST, FLORIDA 33156
> 305 238-7562
>
> HILDA WILL BE LAID TO REST IMMEDIATELY FOLLOWING THE MASS
>
> MIAMI MEMORIAL PARK
> 6200 SW 77 AVENUE
> MIAMI, FLORIDA  33143
>
> There are those of you who may not know what a close knit family Hilda
> worked so hard to surround herself with.  Both of Hilda's Parents, Hilda's
> Brother, Sister-in-law and Neice have always been very close to us and our
> immediate family.  On behalf of that part of the family, along with Carey
> Ann, Richard and I, we would like to thank everyone for your kinds words,
> your prayers, and your expressions of caring and love.  Please keep in
> touch.

LETTER OF ENDORSEMENT TO GOVERNOR JEB BUSH




Dear Governor Bush:

       We the undersigned Hispanic leaders of Palm Beach County and representatives of the numerous Hispanic groups in Palm Beach County individually support and recommend Ed Gonzalez for gubernatorial appointment to the vacancy on the Palm Beach County School Board District 3.

       Ed Gonzalez has been a resident of Palm Beach County for almost four decades.  It is imperative that whomever you appoint has a long and profound understanding of our community needs and problems.

       Ed Gonzalez is eminently qualified to serve on the School Board.  He is an attorney and has served on several school board related committees and city boards.  He deeply cares about our community and has given unselfishly of his time to assist those less fortunate.

       For these reasons, we strongly support and recommend the gubernatorial appointment of Ed Gonzalez for the vacancy on the Palm Beach County School Board District 3.


Helman Ruiz                                                                        Jose Cerrato
Columbia                                                                             Honduras

From:	Baur, Katie <katie.baur@myflorida.com>

Subject:	December 17 Press Calls

EOG WRAP-UP

complaints of strings will you get rid of permanently? we'll find out next
session, we are going to push hard for...believe there is momentum...push
down authority...should push power to teachers, educators...FACT rule
change...have system of accountability...local school districts won't have
excuses...

Miami-Dade? point abdicate concern Miami Dade has...travel, land
purchases...always need for some financial accountability state will never
abdicate all its responsibilities at any point in k-20 system...real focus
on dealing with those issues

McKay proposal? holiday reading...looked at advanced copy...lot areas worthy
of debate answers to unintended consequences...wanted to get debate
started...don't know what end result will be...admire him for thinking big

sharing ballot with tax reform proposal? not concerned

politics with McKay's plan Feeney's congressional seat? add intensity fun if
your watching challenging if your in it...I like it others may not if they
have other parts of the agenda.

EOG PRESS CALLS

ch 51-maimi, hearld--miami iversight board---rumors of dissolving oversight
board--will await their mtg this week and any appropriate gov action

wfts tampa-wants copy of ex ordreed investrigation by state attorney
wolfinger ref. eisenberg investigation..gov office has not received report
yet

ch 7-panama city-bay point cabinet issue---staff recommendation to ask doa
to review matter of intervention to determine facts and right of association

bay news 9-school grading issue---to be discussed/action at cabinet mtg
tuesday

naples daily news-building codes--braod support to delay/counties ability to
set the wind lines and gives homebuilders several months to comply.

DCA PRESS CALLS

1. (Rcvd. call late on 12/14/01) Paige St. John, Gannett News Service.
Requested information regarding the building codes bill. She asked about
DCA's ability/responsibility to set the wind zone lines for local
jurisdictions that didn't already have theirs completed -  if the Governor
vetoes the delay of the Florida Building Code. 

Towson Fraser assured her we would be able to assist any jurisdiction, and
that it wouldn't be a problem .... We also had Rick Dixon from DCA speak to
the issue and advise her that again, we will work with local jurisdictions
to help them in their efforts to set the wind zones for their areas if
needed.

ACHA PRESS CALLS

Amanda Riddle AP - Medicaid vision screening questions.
Following reporters had questions regarding hospital certificate of need
(CON) decisions:

DOH PRESS CALLS

Mark Johnson, Daytona Beach News-Journal, about the blood lead testing of
the six children in the Royal Oaks Subdivision. He wanted to know when the
testing was done, why we did the testing and the results of the testing. He
also asked about the recent water testing and the lead we found in the city
water.
I told Mr. Johnson this sample was taken from an outside faucet and the
County Health Department is resampling the tap water to confirm the lead
results.
Later this morning, after I finished speaking with the reporter, the FDOH
Lab in Jacksonville called to tell me the blood lead test results of the
children. All of the results are within the normal range. I immediately
called each parent to let them know the results and will mail them a copy of
the results today. I will call Mark Johnson this afternoon to let him know
the results. 
Carol Marbin, Miami Herald, Ft. Lauderdale, Public Record request for the
2000 Child Death Review Report 
Wall Street Journal, information about completed anthrax investigation in
Palm Beach. 
DOC PRESS CALLS
Mary Maraghy called from the Florida Times Union for statistics on female
offenders for upcoming story on transition program for female offenders in
Jacksonville.  

Milissa Yablon of the Montel Williams show called about an inmate interview.
They already have consent from the inmate for the interview.  Told her to
fax copy of their request, their personnel and equipment list, and
timetable.

Florida production company wanting information on the inmate interview
process.  Provided information.

Cory, American Justice inquiring about inmate interview process.  Provided
information.

Rich Tucker, Florida Times-Union requested number of incidents of chemical
agents usage at Union Correctional Institution.  Provided information.

Dave Twiddy, Tallahassee Democrat, requesting records about the removal of
typewriters from Florida prisons.  Advised him to send us a specific 119
request for documents and we would provide the records.

Paige St. John, Gannett News Service, requesting records about the removal
of typewriters from Florida prisons.  Advised her to send us a specific 119
request for documents and we would provide the records.

DJJ PRESS CALLS

Stephanie Tasker, Madison County Record, (850) 973-4141, wanted to confirm
whether or not Madison County was losing its one juvenile probation officer,
Harvey Alston Kelly because of cuts (I told her yes and provided additional
information she wanted, which included that now Madison County will share a
probation officer with Lafayette County because in rural Circuit 3 - based
on population - these counties are the most sparsely populated. Also Madison
County will lose its DJJ office because of belt-tightening, however we will
be looking for shared space at the courthouse, in a school or in a law
enforcement agency. In response to her inquiry on how we would supervise
kids, I said we would do our best to manage our resources and we would look
to the community as a positive resource to help watch over youth.) story to
run tomorrow in this weekly paper
Rick Cundiff, Ocala Star-Banner, (352) 867-4130, wanted to know result of
alleged beating of juvenile at Marion Youth Development Center (waiting for
him to call back to tell him IG is investigating).
Shana Gruskin, Sun-Sentinel, (561) 243-6537, wanted actual JPO numbers who
lost jobs in Miami-Dade, Broward and Palm Beach counties for story on how FL
Department of Children and Families locally is interested in hiring JPOs who
were laid off, particularly as child abuse investigators. (Gave her the
three-county numbers; David Kerr, circuit manager in PBC, is going to talk
to her about his work with local DCF administrator on this issue) story not
due to run tomorrow.
Jim Ash, Palm Beach Post, (850) 566-6274, continued questions regarding
Edwin Iacobucci, recently hired staff in Prevention (had provided the public
records requested last week -- application, resume, job description. Wanting
to know if he had any connections to the Governor or Secretary (Governor --
no, Secretary has known Mr. Iacobucci over the years -- however, not close
personal friends), was someone fired to create the position (no position was
vacant), why he was hired when so many were being laid-off (hired before
lay-offs were known because of the level of expertise he brings to the
Department and to the job-- instrumental in helping Jacksonville secure a
Sterling Award, grant management, etc.). Ash requested to speak to Secretary
or person who made the hiring decision. Assistant Sec. Rod Love will discuss
the hiring issues with the reporter.
DCF PRESS CALLS
1. Shana Gruskin - Reporter - Ft. Lauderdale Sun-Sentinel - Contact:  Owen
Roach
Question:  reference her request of last week to speak with someone from
the department regarding the nationwide "lawyers for kids" debate/issue and
the pilot project for same in Palm Beach County.
Response:  facilitated telephone interview between Gruskin and Peggy
Sanford, department assistant legal counsel.  Gist of the interview dealt
with the issue; is it a viable alternative, will it move children through
the dependency system quicker, is it fundable and is the pilot project
working?  Interview went well.

2. Jill Barton - Reporter - Bradenton Herald - Contact:  Tim Bottcher
Question:  Seeking the number of FACT (Florida Assertive Community
Treatment) teams in the state and the number of clients they serve (this is
the community-based alternative to mental institutionalization for patients
who qualify).
Response:  22 teams are currently operational with another six expected to
be by spring '02; number of clients served is 861 as of Oct. 31, '01.

ALSO:

entirety. The text is included below.

-----Original Message-----
From: Laura A Wilson [mailto:law01@juno.com] 
Sent: Sunday, December 16, 2001 6:34 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: RE: Questions about my son's death


Dear Governor Bush,

Thank you for acting on my request for answers in the manner in which
the
FHP handled the investigation of my son, Richard McKeefery's death by a
traffic incident that occurred on 04/24/01 in Tampa.

Unfortunately, Colonel Knight continues to direct my inquiries to
Captain
Tharpe of the Tampa patrol division who does not return my phone
messages.  He has never contacted me and I continue to get his answering
device.

I'd also like the DMV to explain why Martin's license was not suspended
on 04/02/01 since he had accumulated 14 pts in an eight month period by
that date.

If you read my list of questions in it's entirety, you're aware that
several of Florida's agencies has a lot to answer for in the manner in
which my son and our family has been treated.

I understand that Cynthia Holden handed you a letter and the list of
questions personally, she's been a God send and I'm proud to have a
person of her moral strength and character helping us in this fight for
justice.

It's really difficult when state legislatures claim that the law is
unimportant, that it wouldn't have mattered if Martin's license would
have been suspended because people still drive on suspended licenses. 
What they seem to fail to recognize is that because he had a pending DUI
from another crash he caused on 03/02/01 and had caused another crash on
04/13/01, less than two weeks before killing my son that more would have
been done to get him off the road.  They knew how dangerous this man's
driving was and continue to deny responsibility in their role by
allowing
him to keep a legal license.

Even if he'd still been on the road, he'd automatically be serving time
for the death of my son now instead of receiving a careless driving
ticket for something which is obviously manslaughter and he has shown
absolutely no remorse to our family for his actions.

I believe anyone who has a conscience cannot turn away from this
occurrence and will do what they can to see that the current laws are
followed and to provide legislation that will require blood testing for
drugs/alcohol in the case of severe injury/fatality in a traffic
incident.  Victims have no choice in this during the autopsy, where are
their rights?  When people are given drug tests by employers to simply
stock shelves don't the victim/victim's familiy have a right to know if
drugs/alcohol played a role in their loved one's death or injury? 
Shouldn't the culprit get more than a simple fine, less than a speeding
ticket for killing someone negligently?

Thank you for your time and effort in this matter.

Sincerely,
Laura A. Wilson
5115 N. Lister Ave.
Kansas City, MO  64119

(816) 413 - 9797

From:	Langston, Don <Don.Langston@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US>
Sent:	Monday, December 17, 2001 2:29 PM
To:	Jeb Bush; Shanahan, Kathleen; Yablonski, Brian; Jimenez, Frank; Baur, Katie; Hirst, Elizabeth; Arduin, Donna; Turbeville, Greg; Brogan, Frank; Dempsey, Hayden
Cc:	OPB Finance and Economic Analysis
Subject:	McKay Tax Plan Press Conference Report
Attachments:	McKay Const Amend Summary.doc

Sen. McKay held a press conference this morning to officially unveil his "tax reform" plan. Standing beside Sen. McKay were senators Lee, Latvala, King, Pruitt, and Silver.  McKay also indicated that Sen. Webster would have been there if not for a scheduling conflict.

There was not much in the way of new information revealed.  The rationale for the effort is that the tax system is antiquated, there is an overdependence on tourism, there is a looming $4 billion revenue crisis because of repeal of the estate tax and loss of revenues to internet sales, the system is not fair to Florida families (it is regressive).

Sen. McKay outlined the specifics of the proposed constitutional amendment (see attached for details).  He (and Sen. King) emphasized that this effort is not like what happened in the late 1980's.  That was a tax increase, McKay's plan is not because it is revenue neutral.  Whether or not the plan would be revenue neutral beyond the first year was not discussed, nor did the press ask the question.  Hank Fishkind, in answering a press question said, "Are we going to keep increasing the tax rate? or broaden the base?"

Also emphasized several times, was that the plan is flexible in that the Legislature will be able to retain about $7.5 billion in exemptions beyond the necessities specified by Sen. McKay in order to assure that concerns about economic competitiveness are addressed.  This will probably be a standard response to questions about specific exemptions that will invariably arise.  Hank Fishkind said that this will not be a big issue for businesses and that businesses pass through all taxes to their customers.

Figures were cited that the plan will save Florida households a total of $750 million annually, averaging $133 per household.  Hank Fishkind indicated that these numbers are based on assumptions about how much of the current tax and proposed tax is payed by households and businesses.  Since there is no specific list of exemptions to be repealed, the assumptions are basically arbitrary.  Based on my experience, these estimates are probably fairly simplistic SWAGS.

Noteably absent from the discussion was any substantiation of the stability argument.  Improvements in tax base stability will very much depend on which exemptions are ultimately repealed.  Again, as long as there is no specific list of exemptions to be repealed, the stability effects of the proposal can not be evaluated.

<<McKay Const Amend Summary.doc>>

-----Original Message-----
From: EarthWS@aol.com [mailto:EarthWS@aol.com]

yjackson@becker-poliakoff.com; federation@maxxconnect.net;
CULLENRX@aol.com; WGazette@bellsouth.net
Subject: Clarification from audrey peterman



Can we find common ground?
By Audrey Peterman

The headline "Have they no shame?" appearing over my letter in last week's 
Broward Times, casts my comments in an entirely different light than 
intended. It is not my purpose to demean anyone. I'm trying, instead, to 
remind us that "community" implies "working together for the common good."

For the past five years I have written copiously about the Earth and our 
environment. My goal has been to remind everyone, and African Americans in 
particular, that as the child in the womb depends on the mother, so we
depend 
upon the planet. Respect for Mother Earth should be the most natural force
in 
man. If bad decisions continue to be made that trash our planet, it doesn't 
matter that we didn't make them. We will be the first affected. Therefore, 
for our own protection and survival, we have to become a force for good in 
America's dealings with our Earth.

The Wingate Superfund site in Fort Lauderdale, literally in our own 
backyards, is the perfect example of how this principle works. When we 
learned:

 that every piece of waste and garbage produced in Palm Beach, Broward and 
Dade from 1954 to 1978 had either been incinerated or buried in that 
landfill;
  that the records of everything trucked to the site had mysteriously
burned 
up in a fire at the City of Fort Lauderdale; 
 that the African American community in a one-mile radius surrounding the 
site had HIGHER RATES OF FIVE DIFFERENT KINDS OF CANCERS than all other 
neighborhoods in the state;
 that the whole mess sits on top of the Biscayne acquifer, from which South

Floridians get our drinking water;

We assumed that 
 the state, federal and local Department of Environmental Protection, and 
the City of Fort Lauderdale that operated the site, would immediately put 
their best minds to work on how to fix the problem.
 These agencies would work with members of the Environmental Justice 
community, and the mainstream environmental community, locally and across
the 
country, to get the site cleaned up with the best technology available, 
emphasis on protecting human health and the environment. The Fortune 500s
and 
other corporations that dumped at the site, would pay the cost of cleaning
it 
up.
 Social justice organizations, especially the NAACP, would work to educate 
the local community about the issues, and champion the needs of the affected

neighborhoods;
 Medical testing, studies and assistance would be provided free to these 
people. 

Instead, the exact opposite has happened. Elgin Jones' story in The Times, 
Dec. 7 illustrates how this result came about. My letter was meant to remind

the community that it doesn't have to be this way, that our actions, or 
inactions, help determine the kind of leadership we have, and ultimately,
the 
kind of community that we build, together.

A congressional aide told me earlier this year: "One letter to your 
Congressperson (City, County, School Board etc.) gets a letter in response;
5 
letters get attention, 10 letters get ACTION!" 

So, you get the picture! Organize! Write letters to the Editor, to the City 
and County Commission (and not just to the person who represents you, but to

ALL members), outlining the needs of your community. Participate. Make the 
system work FOR you, taxpaying citizens!

-----Original Message-----
From: Jerina Copsey [mailto:jcopsey@gumdropbooks.com]
Sent: Friday, December 14, 2001 6:54 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Florida approved book vendor list; 1% surchage issue



Dear Governor: 

Thank you for returning Harold Fitzgerald's telephone call so promptly.  It was a pleasure to speak with you and briefly acquaint you with two issues that are vitally important to Gumdrop Books.  

Issue One:  Being placed on the Florida approved book vendor list.  

Due to the fact that Florida changed its method of bid notifications from a packet to a postcard, several book vendors, including Gumdrop, did not receive the postcard inviting us to bid for a place on the approved vendor list.  When we realized that the normal deadline to apply was close, we contacted the Florida Department of Education and were told that the deadline had passed.  They said they were sorry that we had not received the postcard but that we would be able to apply in the autumn to get on the list along with other vendors who also did not received the postcard.  This we did in early September but we were told that a decision would not be made until early December.  With follow-up calls, we found that Genny Boynton with the State Purchasing Department (tel: 850-488-7996) was handling our application.  However, she had been out of the office for several weeks and our application sat on her desk.  

Last week we finally spoke with Ms. Boynton only to learn that she had misplaced our bid.  We immediately faxed her a copy and followed up with her the next day by which time she had found the original bid.  When we asked what the next step should be, she informed us that after our bid left her desk in about two weeks, it would go to someone else for approval.  This could take four to six weeks before we could be on the list.

We explained the urgency in getting on the list as we are unable to sell books to our Florida librarian customers who are growing impatient while waiting.  Naturally, impatience will become lost sales unless we can get this resolved immediately.  Ms. Boynton called our office on Monday, Dec. 10th to let us know that Gumdrop Books was not registered in Florida, which we immediately rectified.

Waiting another six weeks to get on the list will substantially add to the loss of business we have already incurred in your state.

Issue Two:  1% vendor surcharge fee on contractors' sales.  

This year the Florida Department of Management Services added this surcharge which must be paid 15 days after the end of each contract quarter.  Failure to comply with this new requirement will result in the supplier being removed from the state contract.  To the best of our knowledge, Florida is the only state that requires a quarterly payment in order to do business within its borders.  This surcharge will not help generate sales and in fact will increase our prices when the funds allocated to purchase our books are, in fact, normally state funds.

Again, thank you for your willingness to hear our concerns on both of these issues.  We are hopeful that with your assistance, some resolution to these issues may be found in a very timely fashion.

Our toll free number is 1-800-821-7199.  Vice President Jeff Fitzgerald's personal email is jeff@gumdropbooks.com.  He is looking forward to hearing from you.  Thank you again for taking time to consider these issues..



Have a good day! 
Jerina Copsey, Human Resources Manager 
jcopsey@gumdropbooks.com 
Gumdrop Books 
a division of Central Programs, Inc. 
100 N. 16th Street 
PO Box 505 
Bethany, MO 64424-0505 

Telephone:  (660) 425-7777 
Fax:  (660) 425-3929 
Email:  wecare@gumdropbooks.com

Cc:	Brian Yablonski (EOG) (E-mail); Pam Dana (E-mail)
Subject:	RE: Florida approved book vendor list; 1% surchage issue

My staff indicates that Gumdrop will be on the vendor list that is released by DMS at the first of the year.  Once they are added by DMS we will give notice to all the libraries and school districts that the list has been updated.  Cynthia, if there is anything else that we can do to assist, please let me know.

From: Jerina Copsey [mailto:jcopsey@gumdropbooks.com]

Subject: Florida approved book vendor list; 1% surchage issue



Dear Governor: 

Thank you for returning Harold Fitzgerald's telephone call so promptly.  It was a pleasure to speak with you and briefly acquaint you with two issues that are vitally important to Gumdrop Books.  

Issue One:  Being placed on the Florida approved book vendor list.  

Due to the fact that Florida changed its method of bid notifications from a packet to a postcard, several book vendors, including Gumdrop, did not receive the postcard inviting us to bid for a place on the approved vendor list.  When we realized that the normal deadline to apply was close, we contacted the Florida Department of Education and were told that the deadline had passed.  They said they were sorry that we had not received the postcard but that we would be able to apply in the autumn to get on the list along with other vendors who also did not received the postcard.  This we did in early September but we were told that a decision would not be made until early December.  With follow-up calls, we found that Genny Boynton with the State Purchasing Department (tel: 850-488-7996) was handling our application.  However, she had been out of the office for several weeks and our application sat on her desk.  

Last week we finally spoke with Ms. Boynton only to learn that she had misplaced our bid.  We immediately faxed her a copy and followed up with her the next day by which time she had found the original bid.  When we asked what the next step should be, she informed us that after our bid left her desk in about two weeks, it would go to someone else for approval.  This could take four to six weeks before we could be on the list.

We explained the urgency in getting on the list as we are unable to sell books to our Florida librarian customers who are growing impatient while waiting.  Naturally, impatience will become lost sales unless we can get this resolved immediately.  Ms. Boynton called our office on Monday, Dec. 10th to let us know that Gumdrop Books was not registered in Florida, which we immediately rectified.

Waiting another six weeks to get on the list will substantially add to the loss of business we have already incurred in your state.

Issue Two:  1% vendor surcharge fee on contractors' sales.  

This year the Florida Department of Management Services added this surcharge which must be paid 15 days after the end of each contract quarter.  Failure to comply with this new requirement will result in the supplier being removed from the state contract.  To the best of our knowledge, Florida is the only state that requires a quarterly payment in order to do business within its borders.  This surcharge will not help generate sales and in fact will increase our prices when the funds allocated to purchase our books are, in fact, normally state funds.

Again, thank you for your willingness to hear our concerns on both of these issues.  We are hopeful that with your assistance, some resolution to these issues may be found in a very timely fashion.

Our toll free number is 1-800-821-7199.  Vice President Jeff Fitzgerald's personal email is jeff@gumdropbooks.com.  He is looking forward to hearing from you.  Thank you again for taking time to consider these issues..



Have a good day! 
Jerina Copsey, Human Resources Manager 
jcopsey@gumdropbooks.com 
Gumdrop Books 
a division of Central Programs, Inc. 
100 N. 16th Street 
PO Box 505 
Bethany, MO 64424-0505 

Telephone:  (660) 425-7777 
Fax:  (660) 425-3929 
Email:  wecare@gumdropbooks.com

He is not scheduled for release until 2014

There is no DC medical record indicating liver or any other cancer.

When he left for Escambia county he was showing no distress of any kind

From: BillLongLFD@aol.com [mailto:BillLongLFD@aol.com]
Sent: Wednesday, December 05, 2001 12:03 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Governor


Dear Governor Bush:

       With all that is going on in the Great State of Florida, the Nation, and the World I will try to keep this e-mail brief.  In your speech to the Florida League of Cities Downtown Redevelopment Seminar held in Miami you stated that your e-mail is one of the best ways to get in touch with you.
       As an elected official I know first hand how hard it is to keep track of everything that is going on.  However, when I feel someone is treated improperly I work hard to rectify the situation.  
       You can imagine how hard it is to survive as a small business man these days.  As if the economy were not bad enough, one of your agencies is causing me unnecessary problems.  I submitted an application to the Department of Business and Professional Regulation, Board of Funeral Directors and Embalmers to open a new cinerator (crematory) facility.  In my twenty-one years in this profession I have received one minor complaint which currently pending against me.  The Departments Legal Advisor (Charles Tunnicliff) has specifically stated to my attorney that the staff of the Department is improperly using a statute to deny my final inspection.  I invested $100,000.00 in the construction and equipment for the cinerator facility.  I hired two additional staff members to operate the facility.  When I made application to the Department in May/2001 I was told my inspection would take place in 30 days.  Well, its now December and I have been forced to sell the crematory at a loss, I have suffered tens of thousands of dollars in lost income, and I am being forced to terminate the two employee's.  As if that were not enough, the Department is denying my request to have my $400.00+ application fee refunded.  They have taken no action on my application.  I should at least be entitled to a refund of my application fee.  
       Again, (in summary) I lose a new business venture, I lose tens of thousands of dollars in income, I am adding two more people to the unemployment lines, and I can't even get my lousy 400+ dollars back.  Needless, to say I am appalled at the Departments handling of this matter.
       Governor Bush, I believe you are a sincere, honest man, who cares a lot about all of us.  I support you and all that you have tried to do to downsize and limit government spending.  I have been one of your most outspoken supporters in local and statewide political circles.  Of course having the former Chairwoman of the Brevard Republican Executive Committee as a mother; in her eyes Republicans can do no wrong (especially a Bush)!  Please take this matter under consideration.  I want to continue to be in your corner as we go into this election year.  I need your help!  Persons working for you should promote commerce and the economy not help tear it down.

"God Bless America"

Sincerely,
William Long

City Councilman
Member, IFDF - Political Action Committee
Board Member, Volusia League of Cities

substantiating research. But the "Big" news is that we are in negotiations
with The Walt Disney Company to co-produce a product for early intervention
of children ages 6 months to 14 years old who are deaf or hard of hearing or
have various communications and learning disabilities. It is an exciting
time here in Sarasota at ISI. Thank you for taking the time to ask how we

for your constituents.

-----Original Message-----
From: Nina Strickland/Greg K. Sloan, M.D. [mailto:fca@digitalexp.com]
Sent: Friday, December 07, 2001 2:16 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: Representative Donald Brown; Senator Durell Peaden
Subject: The "Newer Kinder" Medicare (CMS)


Dear Governor Bush,
 
I am writing this letter to comment on the "newer, kinder" Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.  I certainly have not found them to be any less frustrating than usual.
 
Have you looked at the Provider Application process lately?  We I have!  I am in process of completing an application for a physician who will be joining our group soon.  When I signed onto the CMA website to print the application, I was overwhelmed, to say the least, to find that one section of the application was 57 pages long, one section was 67 pages long, one section was 31 pages long and just the reassignment of benefits form was 9 pages long.  Maybe you would not be intimated by the sheer volume of these applications but a simple working person out here in the trenches is.  It was my understanding that the new applications, effective November, 2001, were simpler, clearer and easier. But looking at these I sure don't feel that they are simpler, clearer and easier.  
 
I did receive The Florida Medicare B Update on Saturday, December 1 which included information regarding a "FREE" Provider Enrollment Workshop to be held in Jacksonville, FL on December 13 or 14th.  It stated that we should "Register Early, because "Seating is limited."  However, there was no phone number, fax number etc to facilitate that happening.  When I finally did get a phone number for Provider Education (not an 800# by the way) 904-791-6422 and I began calling on Monday, Dec. 3 to register I was instructed to leave a detailed message.  I did this including my phone number, fax number, and e-mail address where I could be reached.  I noted that I needed confirmation that I would be able to attend so that I could make travel and motel arrangements as I am approx 6-7 hours away.  I have now made 26 long distance phone calls as well as spending my time which is very valuable to me. By the time I incur travel/hotel costs along with the time and phone calls, this certainly will not have been "FREE" to me.  By Monday, if I were to get a response by then, I will have only 2 days left to make arrangements to attend. 
 
Let me stress, it is very important to me to attend this workshop!!   Having been through the application process several times previously with disastrous results I was so excited to think that I might get my "questions answered directly by a Medicare Expert" who will give me "on-the-spot" assistance in completing and submitting my enrollment applications.  
 
I have always supported you and felt that you were supportive of the people in this state and the medical community.  I will certainly appreciate it if you can offer any assistance to a small rural town physician's office in your state.
 
Nina Strickland, CPC CMA
Practice Administrator
Family Care Associates of NW Florida
925 Carlisle Road
Chipley, FL   32428
(850) 638-1634
Fax (850) 638-3720
fca@digitalexp.com

that date.

If you read my list of questions in it's entirety, you're aware that
several of Florida's agencies has a lot to answer for in the manner in
which my son and our family has been treated.

I understand that Cynthia Holden handed you a letter and the list of
questions personally, she's been a God send and I'm proud to have a
person of her moral strength and character helping us in this fight for
justice.

It's really difficult when state legislatures claim that the law is
unimportant, that it wouldn't have mattered if Martin's license would
have been suspended because people still drive on suspended licenses. 
What they seem to fail to recognize is that because he had a pending DUI
from another crash he caused on 03/02/01 and had caused another crash on
04/13/01, less than two weeks before killing my son that more would have
been done to get him off the road.  They knew how dangerous this man's
driving was and continue to deny responsibility in their role by allowing
him to keep a legal license.

Even if he'd still been on the road, he'd automatically be serving time
for the death of my son now instead of receiving a careless driving
ticket for something which is obviously manslaughter and he has shown
absolutely no remorse to our family for his actions.

I believe anyone who has a conscience cannot turn away from this
occurrence and will do what they can to see that the current laws are
followed and to provide legislation that will require blood testing for
drugs/alcohol in the case of severe injury/fatality in a traffic
incident.  Victims have no choice in this during the autopsy, where are
their rights?  When people are given drug tests by employers to simply
stock shelves don't the victim/victim's familiy have a right to know if
drugs/alcohol played a role in their loved one's death or injury? 
Shouldn't the culprit get more than a simple fine, less than a speeding
ticket for killing someone negligently?

Thank you for your time and effort in this matter.

Sincerely,
Laura A. Wilson
5115 N. Lister Ave.
Kansas City, MO  64119

(816) 413 - 9797

-----Original Message-----
From: Jerina Copsey [mailto:jcopsey@gumdropbooks.com]
Sent: Friday, December 14, 2001 6:54 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Florida approved book vendor list; 1% surchage issue



Dear Governor: 

Thank you for returning Harold Fitzgerald's telephone call so promptly.  It was a pleasure to speak with you and briefly acquaint you with two issues that are vitally important to Gumdrop Books.  

Issue One:  Being placed on the Florida approved book vendor list.  

Due to the fact that Florida changed its method of bid notifications from a packet to a postcard, several book vendors, including Gumdrop, did not receive the postcard inviting us to bid for a place on the approved vendor list.  When we realized that the normal deadline to apply was close, we contacted the Florida Department of Education and were told that the deadline had passed.  They said they were sorry that we had not received the postcard but that we would be able to apply in the autumn to get on the list along with other vendors who also did not received the postcard.  This we did in early September but we were told that a decision would not be made until early December.  With follow-up calls, we found that Genny Boynton with the State Purchasing Department (tel: 850-488-7996) was handling our application.  However, she had been out of the office for several weeks and our application sat on her desk.  

Last week we finally spoke with Ms. Boynton only to learn that she had misplaced our bid.  We immediately faxed her a copy and followed up with her the next day by which time she had found the original bid.  When we asked what the next step should be, she informed us that after our bid left her desk in about two weeks, it would go to someone else for approval.  This could take four to six weeks before we could be on the list.

We explained the urgency in getting on the list as we are unable to sell books to our Florida librarian customers who are growing impatient while waiting.  Naturally, impatience will become lost sales unless we can get this resolved immediately.  Ms. Boynton called our office on Monday, Dec. 10th to let us know that Gumdrop Books was not registered in Florida, which we immediately rectified.

Waiting another six weeks to get on the list will substantially add to the loss of business we have already incurred in your state.

Issue Two:  1% vendor surcharge fee on contractors' sales.  

This year the Florida Department of Management Services added this surcharge which must be paid 15 days after the end of each contract quarter.  Failure to comply with this new requirement will result in the supplier being removed from the state contract.  To the best of our knowledge, Florida is the only state that requires a quarterly payment in order to do business within its borders.  This surcharge will not help generate sales and in fact will increase our prices when the funds allocated to purchase our books are, in fact, normally state funds.

Again, thank you for your willingness to hear our concerns on both of these issues.  We are hopeful that with your assistance, some resolution to these issues may be found in a very timely fashion.

Our toll free number is 1-800-821-7199.  Vice President Jeff Fitzgerald's personal email is jeff@gumdropbooks.com.  He is looking forward to hearing from you.  Thank you again for taking time to consider these issues..



Have a good day! 
Jerina Copsey, Human Resources Manager 
jcopsey@gumdropbooks.com 
Gumdrop Books 
a division of Central Programs, Inc. 
100 N. 16th Street 
PO Box 505 
Bethany, MO 64424-0505 

Telephone:  (660) 425-7777 
Fax:  (660) 425-3929 
Email:  wecare@gumdropbooks.com

From:	Dana, Pamella <pamella.dana@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Sunday, December 16, 2001 1:38 PM
To:	Moore, Michael
Cc:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	FW: Avon Park

Secretary Moore: 

I need to bring to your attention an escalating issue between the Dept of
Corrections and the Air Force's Avon Park Bombing Range.  Avon Park provided
land to the state which is now used by DOC for prison.  In the deed, the
state is responsible for upkeep of utilities (e.g., electical, sewage,
water).  The water and sewage system in desparate need of repair--with its
current condition of mal-repair detrimentally affecting Avon Park
operations.  This issue is currently bogged down in your legal shop (Obed is
handling).  

Avon Park is getting very frustrated with DOC as non-action to needed
repairs is affecting their installation.  

We are involved because we work extensively w/ the military bases in the
state and Avon Park officials have come to us to assist in resolution.  Can
you help? 


Avon Park Bombing Range Fact Sheet

	*	Quitclaim deed between the AF and the state in 1971 called
for joint use of utility lines and facilities, with the state agreeing to
maintain all the utilities (deed was to the Board of Trustees of the
Internal Improvement trust Fund)

	*	Corrections(DOC)  was designated as the lead agency, the
land transferred houses a prison

	*	The AF contacted DOC regarding electrical utility repairs
needed at the range and encountered difficulty from the DOC in agreeing that
the state was truly responsible for the costs of maintenance.  

	*	At one point, DOC referred the matter to DEP stating it was
DEP's concern because it was regarding a state lands issue and they are the
appropriate agency to handle the matters

	*	DEP determined that the state was responsible for the costs
and facilitated an agreement with the Peace River Electric Co-op (the local
electric utility company) to assume responsiblity for the repair and
maintenance.  The electrical systems are no longer an issue. 

	*	Problems with the water and sewage systems have arisen
recently--including some sewage spillages--which the AF has done emergency
repairs on the system to prevent environmental disasters.  DEP issued a
letter to DOC that it was responsible for finding an entity to maintain the
water and sewage systems. 

	*	DOC has now reverted to the original position that it is
unclear whether the state is responsible for the utility systems, reversing
an earlier affirmative determination.
>  
>

-----Original Message-----
From: Howard Smith [mailto:hsmith@yahoo-inc.com]
Sent: Wednesday, October 17, 2001 5:08 PM
To: pamella.dana@myflorida.com
Subject: RE: MyFlorida.com


Dear Ms. Dana:

Terry Semel, our CEO, suggested that I update you on an improvement we
are
making to our proposal to rebuild the State of Florida's portal.  Yahoo!
is
responding to Governor Bush's email asking for help getting tourist's
back
to Florida.  While this was not something that was a part of the
original
scope of the relationship, we believe it is a perfect way to showcase
what
we can do together.

As part of our proposal, at no additional cost to the state, Yahoo! will
include targeted advertising promoting Florida tourism on the number one
travel site on the Internet, Yahoo! Travel.  Yahoo! Travel and Yahoo!
Lodging are the leading online portal travel sites, offering Yahoo's
200+
million users, the web's best resource to research, shop and buy travel
online. Reservation services are offered for air, car, hotel, vacations
and
cruises. Yahoo! Travel allows our partners, such as the State of
Florida, to
reach an attractive demographic, such as those engaged in research,
planning
and purchasing travel to Florida.

I hope you find this solution attractive.  We at Yahoo! want to
demonstrate
our commitment to not only delivering a great portal solution, but
leveraging the entire Yahoo! global network to solve real problems
facing
Florida today.

Please feel free to forward this to any members of your team who could
benefit from this information.  I would like to speak with you at your

introduced here as well as get your ideas for additional programs we
could

Dear Ms. Dana:

Terry Semel, our CEO, suggested that I update you on an improvement we are
making to our proposal to rebuild the State of Florida's portal.  Yahoo! is
responding to Governor Bush's email asking for help getting tourist's back
to Florida.  While this was not something that was a part of the original
scope of the relationship, we believe it is a perfect way to showcase what
we can do together.

As part of our proposal, at no additional cost to the state, Yahoo! will
include targeted advertising promoting Florida tourism on the number one
travel site on the Internet, Yahoo! Travel.  Yahoo! Travel and Yahoo!
Lodging are the leading online portal travel sites, offering Yahoo's 200+
million users, the web's best resource to research, shop and buy travel
online. Reservation services are offered for air, car, hotel, vacations and
cruises. Yahoo! Travel allows our partners, such as the State of Florida, to
reach an attractive demographic, such as those engaged in research, planning
and purchasing travel to Florida.

I hope you find this solution attractive.  We at Yahoo! want to demonstrate
our commitment to not only delivering a great portal solution, but
leveraging the entire Yahoo! global network to solve real problems facing
Florida today.

Please feel free to forward this to any members of your team who could
benefit from this information.  I would like to speak with you at your
earliest convenience to describe in more detail the program I have
introduced here as well as get your ideas for additional programs we could
work on together.  Please call me or email me with any questions.

-----Original Message-----
From: Levywolf@aol.com [mailto:Levywolf@aol.com]
Sent: Sunday, December 16, 2001 8:31 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: (no subject)


Jeb - Thanks for hosting Barbara Lumpkin and I are the Mansion for the 
holiday function - it meant a great deal to us to be there.

Governor, I'm sure you're aware the Executive Director of the Florida 
Commission on the Status of Women has been terminated - I believe unjustly 
but that's another issue for another day - and the Commission itself is in 
utter turmoil.

It's lost it's direction and purpose and almost every former chair is calling 
for it's demise before it begins to actually do damage.

It's about a quarter of a million dollars in the budget and at this point the 
only thing the Commission does of any value if the Women's Hall of Fame.

I discussed an idea with Barbara Lumpkin and she suggested I relay it to you 
for possible action.

I suggest we do away with the Commission (which there is a plan to transfer 
to your jurisdiction this budget year).  I think you can administer the 
Women's Hall of Fame in much the way the Secretary of State administers the 
Artist Recognition Program and the Art's Recognition Program - and save the 
$250,000 a year.

I think you can solicit nominations for the Hall in much the same fashion as 
the Commission - I'd then suggest involving the statewide commissions on the 
status of women and ask them to review the nominees and each of them nominate 
one and you choose your three inductees from among those nominees.

It gets the local commissions more involved and gives them a sense of purpose 
and importance.  It gives you wider discretion in who you choose or any 
governor chooses to induct.

And it continues the good tradition of the Hall of Fame, while saving Florida 
$250,000 which is sorely needed currently and is being misused by this 
Commission.

If OPAGA looked at the Commission and if the Commission were subject to the 
input and output that every other branch of your government has been - I'd 
suggest it couldn't meet the test.

Thanks Governor - I hope you'll take action before the Commission goes any 
further down the slippery slope on which it's currently headed.


Bob Levy

-----Original Message-----
From: Wm. D. Walker [mailto:redhawk103@home.com]
Sent: Thursday, December 13, 2001 12:48 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Fw: **TALLAHASSEE UPDATE**


Sir please read this carefully, though I am sure you are aware of most of
it.  The part about Delmarva and Maximus is true to my belief sir.  Why
can't the districts and Support Coordinators be more responsible instead of
repeating their effort with Delmarva and Maximus.  Here in District 1 we
have started a report card system on coordinators and provider agencies
through the Family Care Council,  and the district has assured me that
individuals and agencies that are not doing their jobs correctly or
negligently will be decertified and will not be able to provide services.
To me this will be a more cost effective and cost saving way of doing thing
on a state level.  If you contact the legal department of the State of
Connecticut you will see they went to a managed care system for their
developmentally delayed children and adults and the incidence of fatalities
increased to four times the previous amount due to lack of care received
because it was deemed as not medically necessary.  Thank you again for
listening. Your friend Darrell Walker

From: "Hawke" <wilburhawke@sprintmail.com>

Subject: Fw: **TALLAHASSEE UPDATE**


>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Denise Karp" <denisek1@ispchannel.com>
> To: <deniseslist@yahoogroups.com>;
<AUTISMRECOVERYNETWORK@YAHOOGROUPS.COM>;
> <WILBURHAWKE@SPRINTMAIL.COM>
> Sent: Thursday, December 13, 2001 10:53 AM
> Subject: **TALLAHASSEE UPDATE**

>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Susan Goldstein [mailto:skgoldstein@hotmail.com]
> KEEP INFORMED.
> TALLAHASSEE UPDATE
>
> By:  Susan Goldstein
>
> Last week the special Legislative Session addressing the state budget
> deficit came to a close with the House and Senate reaching an agreement in
a
> much more collegial fashion than the first. Cutting over $1.1 billion is
no
> picnic.  Believe it or not, there was some good news.  The good news is
that
> some programs will remain whole; the bad news is that we don't know how
much
> longer it will be before more cuts will take place.  The next regular
> session will begin in January 2002.  Since some cuts were salvaged by
> nonrecurring trust fund dollars, the legislature must find these dollars
> again.  Senate President McKay will review the sales tax exemptions to
find
> more sources of revenue, however it is a difficult task in a shaken
economy.
> The intangibles tax repeal was delayed which contributed about $130
million,
> however the state reserve fund for budget stabilization was not utilized.
> There is almost $1 billion in that reserve but legislators fear that if
the
> State economy does not improve there may be more potential shortfalls,
> possibly in the $2 to $3 billion range.
>
> Although your calls, letters and faxes were very effective, the cuts were
> inevitable. The largest came from the Department of Education.  Autism
CARD
> programs were cut by  $320,440 and overall FEFP was cut $250,264,821.
> Another disappointing hit was $99,960 for the Centers for Independent
> Living.  In Health and Human Services, MediPass Services were cut
> $3,798,399, which is an option that many of our families utilize.  Also
hit
> was Community Mental Health Services by $215,567.
>
> A huge debt of gratitude is owed to Senate Health and Human Services
> Appropriations Chair, Senator Ron Silver! The Senate position was much
more
> palatable in terms of minimizing cuts to direct services for persons with
> developmental disabilities. Senator Sanderson was also a very key
legislator
> contributing her support to $2.2 million in direct intervention funding.
> Initially the House position was to cap waiver services.  If it cost more
> than $77,000 annually for care, that individual would be directed to an
ICF.
> Senator Silver was crucial in removing that cap on cost plans and our
> friends at Florida ARF, Chairman, Dennis Haas and lobbyist Max Bosman,
> worked tirelessly to eliminate it.
>
> Other cuts came for the implementation of the Personal Planning Guide,
which
> had no significant impact and the Choice and Control Pilot Project that is
> funded out of general revenue.  The approximately 150 people on the plan
> will not be affected to a great degree as they will now be served in the
> Waiver, and no federal match is lost.  However, the Individual and Family
> Support Program suffered a cut so services will be lost as will federal
> dollars.
>
> The Therapeutic Intervention Program remained intact, as did the
Therapeutic
> Residential Autism Care program, thanks to the efforts of our friend and
> lobbyist Ron Book and his staff.  Unfortunately, the Inclusive Child Care
> Project lost it's funding of $100,000 which was only half of last year's
> amount.  This is an issue we must let the legislature know is an important
> one.  Without quality childcare, we cannot earn a living.
> Page 2
> As many of you have been advised directly by Delmarva Foundation, they and
a
> company named Maximus have signed extended contracts with the Department
of
> Children and Families.   Delmarva was hired for quality control and
> assurance and Maximus for rate utilization review and delivery
consistency.
> They offer, in my opinion, redundant services that the department does and
> should be responsible to provide. Each contract is valued at approximately
> $4 million over the term. These are dollars that should not be tapped from
> direct services and duplicate the function of the support coordinators,
> which are now costing $56.4 million annually.  Waiver support coordination
> helps consumers make informed choices about services and assure they are
> cost effective.  They also monitor the programs and certify that services
> have been received prior to payment to the provider. Each support
> coordinator must not service a caseload of more than 36 individuals.  In
> addition, each district reviews and approves all cost and support plans.
> They also monitor the support coordinators for performance outcomes.  In
> addition, because of the budget crisis, many districts are reviewing each
> support plan for cost efficiency.  This seems to be quite sufficient as
far
> as a 'checks and balances' system is concerned.
>
> Delmarva held several public meetings across the state, however many got
the
> notice after meetings had occurred, or with only one days notice.  One
> parent, Holly Borfield, who did attend in Orlando, was very upset that
these
> companies would have access to our children's medical records and may
> override intervention prescribed by their regular physician.  Delmarva's
> doctors may do this without ever having seen the child. Such statements
> along with the fear of cuts in program dollars created serious concern
over
> these contracts statewide. The concern of a 'managed care' effect seems to
> be lurking in the shadows.
>
> It appears to me that this is just another way to get around the 'medical
> necessity' or 'meaningful day activity' that is required by law.  The
> problem is that these interpretations are currently in litigation and
still
> undecided.  It is my experience with the health care industry that their
> definition of "medical necessity" means: Is it a matter of life or death?
> This is the same argument the industry uses in committee when they try to
> gut our insurance bill every year. If you are ever the victim of this
> circumstance or experience a disregarding of vital services, remember that
> you have the right to a hearing and due process. We will need all our
> parents who are attorneys to step up to the plate and form a committee to
> address what could potentially become a significant and frequent issue.
>
> These and other funding concerns prompted a teleconference call, which
took
> place last Thursday that included a group of parents and providers, with
> Carl Littlefield, who is in charge of the DC&F, Mike Hanson from the
> Governor's office, Shelly Brantly the Medicaid Bureau Chief and Susan
> Dickerson, Medicaid Budget Supervisor.  Carl Littlefield stated that the
> contracts were designated language by the legislature and specific proviso
> in SB 2000, special appropriation 377, Home and Community Based Waiver,
> referring to quality assurance. Their function, as he explained, is a
> 'checks and balances' system. Delmarva comes in up front and Maximus
follows
> as a backup.   He also stated that it was a 25/75 match meaning that 75%
of
> the dollars were federal, however, this was inconsistent with earlier
> reports I received. Susan Dickerson stated that quality assurance is
> required by ACHA contracts and it is 'Medicaid protocol' when federal
> dollars are drawn.
> Page 3
> Suggestions given in the conference call were to bring stakeholders to the
> table before decisions are made that affect the lives of our children.
When
> budget cuts are eminent, preferably administrative redundancy is
considered
> for a cut before the direct services to our precious children.  A better
> dissemination of information was also suggested and requested.  Mr.
> Littlefield said that a $90,000 grant from the Development Disabilities
> Council is in the works to fund an information liaison. I'd like to know
how
> to apply for that job! Better yet, lets spend the $90,000 on those that
need
> it and try e-mail or a web page.   This situation is far from being over;
we
> will work hard to prevent additional cuts in services.  Remember, when an
> alert is sent, please respond promptly, it can make a big difference in
the
> life of your children.  Happy Holidays and a better New Year!
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
> THE AUTISM INSURANCE BILL STILL ALIVE AND KICKING
> And will never go away!
> By: Susan Goldstein
>
> The status of the Autism Insurance Bill is an important issue this session
> as many who are wait- listed for the waiver will not be receiving the
> services that Mr. Littlefield promised would come in March.
Representative
> Crow and Senator Geller have already filed and we must not give up this
> fight for insurance coverage.  Please write you legislators and ask them
to
> sign on as sponsors.  Now more than ever the State must require the
> insurance industry to accept some of the financial burden they have
> abandoned and written off for so long.  Premium-paying policyholders with
> autistic children are discriminated against and we must not let it
continue.
>   Insurance is a mutually beneficial concept.  Our premiums pay for
> treatments of other children, as theirs should pay for treatment of
autism.
> Call you House member and Senator.  Go to your delegation and sign up to
> speak at the public hearings.  Take your child to their district offices
and
> let them meet in person.   Tell them we must pass the insurance bill!
Let's
> do it this year!
>

From:	DARRYL MADISON <dmadison@providertech.com>
Sent:	Saturday, December 15, 2001 11:57 AM
To:	Jeb Bush; Mr. Oscar Alberto Martinez; Terry Haynes; Stacey McMillion; Randy Arruda; Ralph Smith; Peter Harris; Martin Traber; Lionel Shipman; Kyle Kennedy; Kay Kammel; Colleen Castille; Barry Shevlin; Barrow, Joe; Windell Paige; Wendy Grant; Vivian Booth; Veatrice Holifield-Farrell; Smooth1J@worldnet.att.net; Sharon Ofuani; Ron Cook; Romeo Nelson; Robert Little; Rob G Little; Randy Wadle; Matthew Carter; Mark Wofford; lunelle@alliancefinancialcap.com; jimc@lionsharegroup.com; Jim Cheatham; James Browning; George Farrell; Flo Thomas; Eric B. Brown; Derrick Woodard; Curt Long; Cory Tellbuescher; Chris Tellbuescher; cathy hannah; Cape, Parker; Brian Cain; Bill Seavey; Audrey Jones; Antoinette Rodriguez; Ailneal Morris
Subject:	MINORITY-OWNED BUSINESS AWARDS NOMINATIONS 

 
Dear Friends,

 

Provider Technologies has worked very hard in Tallahassee for the past two years trying to get contracts for minority business in the Technology Field.  This week our company hosted the State Technology Office Chief of Staff "Mr. Romeo Nelson" in Tampa Bay to highlight some of Tampa Bay's premiere tech firms.  We have seen a positive change in how minorities firms participate in State contracts.  The process has reformed procurement to encourage the pursuit of diversity.  Cut the red tape in the certification process and enhanced minority business development. Doing business with the State is better than ever before and the rewards can be great.  We believe in the Governors One Florida Initiative and have supported the program throughout Tampa Bay and Florida in general.  Diversity is the way to go and "One Florida Initiative" is about Diversity.

 

Executive Order Number [EO 99-281] With my One Florida Initiative, we can increase opportunity and diversity in the states  contracting without using polices that discriminate or that pit one racial group against another.  Behind a common vision that unites us, we can ensure that the promise of Floridas future will be shared by all of Floridas residents, regardless of race, ethnicity, neighborhood, or background. Governor Jeb Bush

 

I would like all our business partners and friends to support us in the Minority-Owned Business Awards.  We are pushing for the One Florida Initiative because we know it's the right way to do business, not only in Tampa Bay but also in the whole USA. By supporting us we can continue to speak to the masses about our products and the One Florida Initiative.

 

Below is the URL to get to the nomination sheet. The dead line is December 28, 2001.   Please support us, because we support you.

 

Thank you in advance.

 

 

http://tampabay.bcentral.com/tampabay/contactus/nominations/369
===========================
Darryl J. Madison, President
Provider Technologies, Inc.
Ph:   (813) 350-7868
Fax: (813) 350-7801
===========================

-----Original Message-----
From: Yablonski, Brian [mailto:brian.yablonski@myflorida.com]

Subject: Nursing Announcement


I've been told today that Hospital Corporation of America is having a press
conference on Monday with Elaine Chao to announce a forgiveable scholarship
program to address shortage of nurses.  

HCA would donate $5 million nationwide -- no gov money involved
Of this, HCA would dedicate $1.2 million to Florida for two areas --
Tampa/St. Pete area and South Florida
Money would be used to fund 120 scholarships for RN, LPN, Surgical and
Radiology Technicians -- AWI thinks with money they could get 	more
scholarships than 120
Scholarships are to go for displace workers as a result of Sept. 11
AWI would assist HCA with candidate screening

Tara Dudley is HCA's lobbyist and we spoke this evening -- she could not
confirm timing of announcement but was generally aware of program -- will
redouble this weekend with her client.  I told her we would be willing to do
a press release to bring some attention to this in Florida and potentially
have HCA ceo (Sen. Frist's brother) down here with you to do some kind of
media event to announce Florida scholarships over the next few weeks.

awi
Florida News Channel, Keisha Hayes. Update on unemployment numbers.
Palm Beach Post, Amy Martinez.  Update on unemployment numbers.
WCTV, Tallahassee and WTXL Tallahassee - Called both stations to get
coverage of the Agency's "Adopt A Family" program delivering Christmas
presents to 12 families we adopted at Nims Middle School. AWI associates
purchased or donated gifts to each family ranging from beds to bicycles. In
addition, our FLUID re-engineering team, who won $600 in a Davis
Productivity award, donated the entire amount to the Christmas Connection.
We also donated 27 blankets to the Christmas Connection

dbpr:
-- Lawan Williams of channel 9 in Orlando asked about Arvida Realty and real
estate licensee Dale Parker. Arvida had some minor complaints and Dale
Parker had none. Lawan also asked about Jerry Johns and two companies,
Jerry's Marine Construction and Jerry's Sea Walls. None of these are
licensed and no complaints were found under these names. 
-- Joe Clements of Banker and Tradesman Newspaper asked if we were
investigating Bay Communities and William Lilly and Valerie Kaan. Bay
Communities is licensed and there are no public complaints. William Lilly
and Valerie Kaan are not licensed by our department. We understand they are
being investigated by the US Attorney's Office. 
-- Susie Falero of channel 7 in Miami has requested a ride-along for an
underage alcoholic beverage controlled buy operation and interview the minor
and their parents afterward. 
-- Lisa Gugernick of the Wall Street Journal requested the number of
restaurants in Orange County now vs. 1997. Figures show an increase in the
number of accounts over that time period. 
-- Evan Cutler of the Daily Show in New York requested a copy of the statute
that prohibits dwarf tossing.  (The Daily Show with John Stewart is a
national run cable comedy show.)
-- Mike Wright of the Citrus County Chronicle asked for information on
complaints against Artistic Home Builders. No complaints are public record
at this time. 
-- Jennifer Sorentrue of the Port St. Lucie News asked if the city could
hold a liquor license. 
Proactive Report:
We sent out a press release on the gambling stings in Palm Beach County. 
We are sending out a press release regarding CPAs nationally standardizing
computer-based testing- Florida and DBPR's role.

DOEA
1.	Mark Cross, Ft. Myers News-Press called regarding Imperial Harbor
Estates in Bonita Springs wanting to become an official retirement
community. Referred to Elder Ready Communities and Web site address.Talked
about philosophy of intergenerational interaction to foster aging with
purpose and reduce disengagement

2.	Sandy Shelfer, Public Radio in Fort Myers, wanted a phone interview
with someone about flu shots for elders. Referred to DOH.

3.	Kim McCoy, South Florida Sun-Sentinel wanted to know if ADCs
extending hours during week and on weekend is a trend. Referred to Florida
ADC Association.

4.	Diane Lade, Sun-Sentinel writing a story on Gary Barg of Today's
Caregiver and Caregiver.com wanted to know why we selected him as a keynote
speaker for our Caregiver Forum and what effect we are seeing in the
increases of web sites for caregivers. Barg is respected resource on
caregiver issues, able to articulate in a way appropriate to that audience
and has personal experience as a caregiver.

5.	Alisa LaPolt, Gannett News Service, asked about the push to get
better continuum of services for elders in Long-Term Care. 

6.	Jack Leavitt, The Great Age Radio Show, airs on WHNZ in Tampa and
WDDV in Sarasota, to interview Joan Spainhower and Gail LaRosa of our agency
on elder care issues. 

We are establishing better communication channels with our AAAs, lead
agencies and our Advisory Council and planning five "Listening Sessions" in
specific parts of Florida. 

2002 is the 10th anniversary for our agency and we are planning different
types of celebrations and special ways to commemorate the anniversary. A
special event is being planned for Elder Day at the Capitol on March 7,
2002. 

doc
Release use of chemical agents report from Santa Rosa and Washington
Correctional Institutions to Rich Tucker of the Florida Times Union.

WCTV CBS, Tallahassee, and Capital News Service, interviewed Sterling Ivey
and Richard Dugger about toys made by inmates that will be distributed to
local needy children.  The toys were on display at DOC.

Erin Black, Gabriel Media, requesting to do an in-depth story on women in
prison.  Asked her to fax a proposal to the Public Affairs Office for
review.

 dep:
1. Gary Appleson, Carribean Conservation, 352-373-6441; re: left name and
number on voicemail, no message. Have been unable to reach him all day.

2. Jane Mienhardt, Tampa Bay Business,  727-507-0000, re: underground
storage
tanks. re: need stats from Marshall Mott-smith. Need general info about
closures and regs, storage tank stats.

3. Palmer Hastings, Washington County News, re: Reference to discharges and
confirmation that Holmes Creek was a Class III water body.
question:

What are the classifications of water bodies?
What classifcation water body is Holmes Creek?
What is required for a water body to be designated an Outstanding FL Water?
What about the discharges from Graceville, Vernon, and Chipley WWTP's?

summary:

Reporter was referred to our surface water website which delineates the
classifications and defines Outstanding Florida Water Bodies.
Told reporter I thought that Holmes Creek was a Class III water body but
would seek confirmation. I verbally went over the classification information
and designation definition for OFW's.
I would have someone call him concerning the discharges.

4. Amanda Brandon, NW FL Daily News, re: redtide background information

5. Tom Palmer, Lakeland Ledger, 863-802-7535; re: parks press release
reservation system.

dcf:
1. Shana Gruskin - Reporter - Sun-Sentinel - Contact:  Owen Roach
Query:  working on a story about the debate over lawyers for children,
particularly those in the dependency system.  She cited SB 686 and wants to
speak with someone from the department on the issue and the bill.
Response:  once an appropriate spokesperson is identified, will facilitate
a telephone interview. Notifying legislative affairs at the department, as
well.

2. Art Levine - Reporter - City Link - Contact:  Tim Bottcher
Query:  Seeking information for mental health story.
Response:  Based on his previous mental health story, which contained
over-generalizations and innuendoes, we decline to comment. This is not a
major news outlet in the state; the reporter was not professional at all.

Yesterday I wrote you about a pressing need for Chrismass gifts at Fort
Campbell.

Today the 101st Airborne Division Chaplin wrote me and told me there was no
such need.

I should have written the chaplin before I wrote to you.

Your Mrs. Doreen Rutledge demonstrated her deep and true concern for all

(supposedly) in trouble.

Thank you and I am very sorry for the confusion.

john p mckenzie

> 	 -----Original Message-----
> 	From: 	Woodring, Daniel  
> 	Sent:	Friday, December 14, 2001 3:34 PM
> 	To:	Canady, Charles T.
> 	Subject:	draft of letter to agency heads
> 
> 		This year, December 24th, Christmas Eve, falls on a Monday.
> Recognizing the desire of many to spend this joyous time of the year with
> family and friends, I ask that my agencies allow any employees who are not
> required on December 24th for the provision of critical services, and who
> desire to take that day off to avail themselves of  available paid or
> unpaid leave. Provision should still be made to allow any non-critical
> employees who desire to work December 24th the ability to work. If certain
> state offices will be entirely closed as a result of employees
> leave-taking, agencies should notify the public of any accompanying
> closures or changes in hours 
> 		I would encourage the agency heads for all other state
> agencies to also consider allowing many of their non-critical employees to
> spend December 24th with family and friends.   
> 
> 	Merry Christmas,

From:	Dana, Pamella <pamella.dana@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Friday, December 14, 2001 2:39 PM

Subject:	RE: Florida's Trade with Andean Community
