-----Original Message-----
From: Manny Mencia [mailto:MMencia@floridabusiness.com]
Sent: Thursday, December 13, 2001 5:44 PM
To: 'danap@itflorida.com'; 'freedman@sso.org'
Cc: John Anderson
Subject: FW: Florida's Trade with Andean Community
Importance: High


Pam
 
Per your request for information for Florida House.
 
The Andean region includes some of Florida's top export markets around the world.  Last year despite recessionary conditions  throughout most of the region, they still bought about 5.7 billion dollars in Florida products and probably as much as 3 billion in Florida services. Many of the products we sell them are high technology Florida origin products( see attachment # 2).  About  50% of everything Colombia buys from the US passes through Florida.
 
The Andean Trade Preference Act gives duty free entry to the US to Andean region produced products (see attachment # 1). Last year  approximately 3.3 billion dollar in Andean products passed through Florida. Thousands of Floridians are employed by the companies that import these products. For example the Colombian flower industry here employs over 10,000.
 
Repeal of the  ATPA would:
 
1- Impact heavily the already weakened economies of the region as it will affect about 35 % of the total products they export to the US. This in turn would deny them the reserves needed to buy US products affecting an already sluggish Florida export and services export.
 
2- It will damage further Florida logistic and transportation services sector that supports our two way trade not to mention the workforce that works for the importers
 
3- It will further fuel the economic pressures that are responsible for an unprecedented migration of Andean citizens to Florida, many of them undocumented.Further affecting our economy, quality of life, services, etc.
 
4- The ATPA also serves as an incentive for these nations to promote alternatives to cultivation of Coca and marijuana and to combat drug trafficking. Should the act be eliminated so will one of our key carrots to combat the drug trade.
 
I hope this helps.
 
 
Manny
 
 
 
 
 
-----Original Message-----

Cc: Helen.Walker@mail.house.gov; Kris.Tande@mail.house.gov;
Lois.Hoyt@mail.house.gov; brett.verzwyvelt@eglin.af.mil; Jeb Bush
Subject: Eglin AFB AOC Event


The Association of Old Crows is an international group of individuals
and companies involved in the electronics and defense industries. The
Eglin AFB Chapter of the AOC will host its Eleventh Annual Technical
Symposium and Exhibits at the NCO Club at Eglin AFB on February 12-13,
2002. The government sponsor of the event is the 53rd Wing at Eglin AFB.
The Symposium "Test & Evaluation in the Information  and Electronic
Domains" will be attended by military personnel and defense contractors
from organizations throughout the USA. Many of the organizations would
be potential customers and users of the facilities at Eglin AFB, which
are vital to the economy of Northwest Florida. Details concerning the
agenda can be viewed at the Eglin AOC website, www.eglinaoc.org.

The Eglin Chapter invites the Governor and Congressman to attend the
Symposium and visit the exhibits with an opportunity to officially
welcome Symposium attendees to the State and its First Congressional
District.

Please contact me for additional information.

Steven J. Czonstka
Past President, Eglin Chapter AOC
4554 Redbud Trail
Niceville, FL 32578-8768

-----Original Message-----
From: Nina Oviedo [mailto:oviedon@sso.org]
Sent: Thursday, December 13, 2001 7:50 PM
To: Jeb Bush; Brian Yablonski; Frank R. Jimenez; Kathleen Shanahan

Subject: Election reform passes the House
Team, see summary below re election reform.
 
-----Original Message-----
From: Freedman, Melissa [mailto:freedmm@SSONet.sso.org]
Sent: Thursday, December 13, 2001 10:41 AM
To: Oviedo, Nina
Subject: Election reform passes the House
 
Nina, 
The House approved election reform legislation last night by a vote of 362-63. The Help America Vote Act of 2001 (H.R. 3295) authorizes funding to states and counties to replace and update voting systems, and establishes mandatory election standards for states.
Federal standards under the bill would require that states do the following: 
o        Implement a statewide voter registration system linked to local jurisdictions; 
o        Permit provisional voting, or an alternative that achieves the same objective, in all precincts; 
o        Maintain and update voter registration records; 
o        Adopt uniform vote tabulation standards; 
o        Tabulate all military and overseas ballots; and 
o        Provide new voting systems for voters with disabilities. 
These standards are not optional and would apply whether or not a state received federal funding. 
Funds authorized under the bill include a one-time payment or reimbursement to states and counties of approximately $400 million to replace existing punch card voting equipment and a $2.25 billion "Election Fund" to provide payments to states over three years. States would be required to provide a 25 percent matching payment before receiving monies from the fund. The Election Fund would be administered by a bipartisan "Election Assistance Commission" comprised of state and local election officials, election experts, and other interested parties.
The Senate has not yet approved election reform legislation and is continuing with internal negotiations to develop a compromise, bipartisan reform package.
Melissa Freedman 
Florida-Washington Office 
(202) 624-5885

Subject:    Southcom

Got a call from Ana Carbonell at Lincoln Diaz Balart's  Miami office
regarding
the Southcom visit on Wed. Jan 2, 2002.  Her office has outlined the
following
plan for the joint visit of Diaz Balart and Sen. Graham, and they have asked
Assistant Sec'y of Defense, Roger Pablo-Maurer to join the visit.
1)   Meet with community leaders who have been active over the years in
getting
and trying to keep Southcom in Miami.  i.e.  Lettie Bien, attny and
reservist
with Army; Donald Sleznick, formerly active with Miami Chamber of Commerce
and
currently Mayor of Coral Gables.
2) Joint site visit to Southcom.
3)  Press event.
4)  Meeting with Herald editorial board to dispel notion of the paper that
not
enough is being done to counter efforts to move Southcom.
If there is more info about this than mentioned, please let me know.  Time
of
meeting is not known yet, and the first meeting would be held close to the
Southcom location.           FYI

-----Original Message----- 
From: LAUREEN GIORGIO [ mailto:laureengiorgio@msn.com] 
Sent: Tuesday, December 11, 2001 2:11 PM 
To: Jeb Bush 
Subject: Children's Medical Services Mistreatment of Stormy Burn 


December 11, 2001 
  
  
Re:  Children's Medical Service 
        Client:    Stormy Burn 
        Mother:  Katie Burn 
                      25231 Mathew Street Christmas, Florida 
                      Home Phone 407 568 5463 
                      Florida Hospital East 407 303 8110 
                      Room 124 
  
Dear Governor; 
  
I know how busy you are in these difficult times, and I apologize, in 
advance, for disturbing you.  But I know you have said many times how 
concerned you are about kids, especially seriously ill kids. 
  
Stormy Burn is a 13 year old wheelchair bound quadriplegic.  He is now 
bedridden and in severe pain at Florida Hospital East in Orlando.  You met 
Stormy last year concerning the Medically Essential Utility Law.  He was in 
Tallahassee with the other families. 
  
Stormy's mother, Katie, pleaded with the Children's Medical Service to put a 
feeding tube in Stormy because he was not getting enough nourishment by 
mouth and he was losing weight.  Stormy was down to 61 pounds and his mother 
was afraid that his bones were going to become brittle, as they often do, 
with these children.  It took a year, and her having to sit on the floor in 
the emergency room of the hospital and threaten not to leave until they put 
the feeding tube in him.  The doctors at C.M.S. finally decided to do so. 
By this time, the child's bones have gotten so brittle, that every time they 
move him they are afraid of breaking his bones.  Are they not suppose to be 
helping these families? 
  
Stormy started to feel pain in his body and a fracture showed up on a scan 
that was done by an emergency room doctor. A cast was put on, and the doctor 
told the mother it would have to stay on for about 4 weeks.  When Mrs. Burn 
went to the Children's Medical Services Doctors at Nemourse Clinic at Arnold 
Palmer, 
she was told he did not need to keep the cast on and they removed it.  They 
strongly refused to replace the cast.  Dr. Phillips and his associate, Dr. 
Burnbaum, twisted the childs foot and leg in so many directions that they 
made him cry and yell.  Stormy has not been the same.  He was sent home in 
constant pain and was told by Bernice, the Orthopedic Nurse, that they do 
not address pain management and not to bring him in for pain. He was 
bedridden and without any medication to help relieve his pain.  His mother 
and older brother could not turn him or touch him without him crying in 
pain. They have given him an appointment in January to see an Orthopedic 
doctor.  This is ridiculous.  Stormy is presently at Florida Hospital East 
and is on heavy pain medication.  He may have a bone infection, and they 
have found a fracture in his right ankle.  He may be sent home again without 
pain medication by Dr. Goetz, another C.M.S practitioner.  Animals are 
treated better! 
  
Stormy's mother and brother have dedicated their lives to Stormy.  Their 
lives are centered upon him and his needs.  It is very frustrating to them 
and frightening not to be able to trust the doctors they need to help 
Stormy. 
  
I have had many experiences with the Children's Medical Services  over my 18 
years helping these families, and I can tell you these families are not 
treated justly.  The level of care is substandard, to say the least, with 
personnel who are nasty and vindictive and doctors who haven't a clue to a 
child's needs. 
  
Stormy needs help and he needs it now.  I know they think his mom is a big 
mouth.  But when you see your child not getting the treatment needed, and 
you have to wait a year for treatment, my patience would run out too.  More 
parents have to speak up and not be afraid of retribution.  
  
I am asking, before something else goes wrong with Stormy Burn, for your 
assistance in getting this child and other children like him assistance 
before it is too late.  This child will die if he does not get the proper 
attention. 
  
The Children's Medical Service is another example of a good idea gone bad. 
It is a waste of money and energy.  Bernice, the Orthopedic Nurse, needs to 
find another profession and so do some of the doctors Mrs. Burn has had to 
deal with. 
  
Respectfully, 
  
Tony Giorgio, President 
Compassion Children's Foundation

-----Original Message-----
From: Nina Oviedo [mailto:oviedon@sso.org]
Sent: Thursday, December 13, 2001 7:50 PM
To: Jeb Bush; Brian Yablonski; Frank R. Jimenez; Kathleen Shanahan
Cc: Melissa Freedman
Subject: Election reform passes the House
Team, see summary below re election reform.
 
-----Original Message-----
From: Freedman, Melissa [mailto:freedmm@SSONet.sso.org]
Sent: Thursday, December 13, 2001 10:41 AM
To: Oviedo, Nina
Subject: Election reform passes the House
 
Nina, 
The House approved election reform legislation last night by a vote of 362-63. The Help America Vote Act of 2001 (H.R. 3295) authorizes funding to states and counties to replace and update voting systems, and establishes mandatory election standards for states.
Federal standards under the bill would require that states do the following: 
o        Implement a statewide voter registration system linked to local jurisdictions; 
o        Permit provisional voting, or an alternative that achieves the same objective, in all precincts; 
o        Maintain and update voter registration records; 
o        Adopt uniform vote tabulation standards; 
o        Tabulate all military and overseas ballots; and 
o        Provide new voting systems for voters with disabilities. 
These standards are not optional and would apply whether or not a state received federal funding. 
Funds authorized under the bill include a one-time payment or reimbursement to states and counties of approximately $400 million to replace existing punch card voting equipment and a $2.25 billion "Election Fund" to provide payments to states over three years. States would be required to provide a 25 percent matching payment before receiving monies from the fund. The Election Fund would be administered by a bipartisan "Election Assistance Commission" comprised of state and local election officials, election experts, and other interested parties.
The Senate has not yet approved election reform legislation and is continuing with internal negotiations to develop a compromise, bipartisan reform package.
Melissa Freedman 
Florida-Washington Office 
(202) 624-5885

doing the same thing. Just thought you'd like to know.

From:	Jeb Bush
Sent:	Thursday, December 13, 2001 8:09 PM

Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law.
Most written communications to or from state officials
regarding state business are public records available to the
public and media upon request.   Your e-mail communications
may therefore be subject to public disclosure. 
-----Original Message-----
From: Nina Oviedo [mailto:oviedon@sso.org]
Sent: Thursday, December 13, 2001 7:50 PM
To: Jeb Bush; Brian Yablonski; Frank R. Jimenez; Kathleen Shanahan
Cc: Melissa Freedman
Subject: Election reform passes the House


Team, see summary below re election reform.
 
-----Original Message-----
From: Freedman, Melissa [mailto:freedmm@SSONet.sso.org]
Sent: Thursday, December 13, 2001 10:41 AM
To: Oviedo, Nina
Subject: Election reform passes the House
 
Nina, 
The House approved election reform legislation last night by a vote of 362-63. The Help America Vote Act of 2001 (H.R. 3295) authorizes funding to states and counties to replace and update voting systems, and establishes mandatory election standards for states.
Federal standards under the bill would require that states do the following: 
*	Implement a statewide voter registration system linked to local jurisdictions; 

*	Permit provisional voting, or an alternative that achieves the same objective, in all precincts; 

*	Maintain and update voter registration records; 

*	Adopt uniform vote tabulation standards; 

*	Tabulate all military and overseas ballots; and 

*	Provide new voting systems for voters with disabilities. 
These standards are not optional and would apply whether or not a state received federal funding. 
Funds authorized under the bill include a one-time payment or reimbursement to states and counties of approximately $400 million to replace existing punch card voting equipment and a $2.25 billion "Election Fund" to provide payments to states over three years. States would be required to provide a 25 percent matching payment before receiving monies from the fund. The Election Fund would be administered by a bipartisan "Election Assistance Commission" comprised of state and local election officials, election experts, and other interested parties.
The Senate has not yet approved election reform legislation and is continuing with internal negotiations to develop a compromise, bipartisan reform package.
Melissa Freedman 
Florida-Washington Office 
(202) 624-5885 
From:	Nina Oviedo <oviedon@sso.org>

To:	Jeb Bush; Brian Yablonski; Frank R. Jimenez; Kathleen Shanahan
Cc:	Melissa Freedman

-----Original Message-----
From: Freedman, Melissa [mailto:freedmm@SSONet.sso.org]
Sent: Thursday, December 13, 2001 10:41 AM
To: Oviedo, Nina
Subject: Election reform passes the House
 
Nina, 
The House approved election reform legislation last night by a vote of 362-63. The Help America Vote Act of 2001 (H.R. 3295) authorizes funding to states and counties to replace and update voting systems, and establishes mandatory election standards for states.
Federal standards under the bill would require that states do the following: 
*	Implement a statewide voter registration system linked to local jurisdictions; 
*	Permit provisional voting, or an alternative that achieves the same objective, in all precincts; 
*	Maintain and update voter registration records; 
*	Adopt uniform vote tabulation standards; 
*	Tabulate all military and overseas ballots; and 
*	Provide new voting systems for voters with disabilities.
These standards are not optional and would apply whether or not a state received federal funding. 
Funds authorized under the bill include a one-time payment or reimbursement to states and counties of approximately $400 million to replace existing punch card voting equipment and a $2.25 billion "Election Fund" to provide payments to states over three years. States would be required to provide a 25 percent matching payment before receiving monies from the fund. The Election Fund would be administered by a bipartisan "Election Assistance Commission" comprised of state and local election officials, election experts, and other interested parties.
The Senate has not yet approved election reform legislation and is continuing with internal negotiations to develop a compromise, bipartisan reform package.
Melissa Freedman 
Florida-Washington Office 
(202) 624-5885

-----Original Message-----
From: Shanahan, Kathleen 
Sent: Thursday, December 13, 2001 2:02 PM
To: 'Jeb Bush'; Oviedo, Nina; Branker, Laura; Yablonski, Brian; Jimenez, Frank; Shanahan, Kathleen
Cc: Hampton, Betty; Arduin, Donna
Subject: RE: NEXT 48 HOURS/VERY IMPORTANT
Importance: High


current update:
We have called/spoken with 
Mark Weinberger - lead negotiator with  Treasury and WH on this stimulus pkg
Mark Summerlin - lead tax/stimulus contact in WH/Larry Lindsey's shop
Karl Rove
 
Bottom line: 
1) 30% depreciation as part of corporate tax package is pretty set/wh priority - will not move at this point in time
 
2) karl met w/ 5 govs last night - said wh would quietly agree to including fmap w/a 1.5% increase for 1 year to this fed medicaid assistance - IF that is included fla could get a $162mil/GR
 
3) guidance given to govs was to get to dem govs to get daschle to bring up stimulus package for vote, if fmap in wh would sign, as long as core wh package is in it: depreciation, amt, rebates, rates (not clear on what is exactly in each of those items)>
 
4) mark summerlin - wh tax guy, said they had recently included in a redrafted admin proposal this week some type of fed unemployment insurance to offset impact of  depreciation - I specifically asked him to call me back with number WH had found out fla would get, also from what i am told NOT GR $$.
 
Nina recommends in your call to THomas you take the following approach:
 
1) CONGRATS on TANF - your hard work paid off, hope my note to fla delegation pushed some towards you....ie cliff stearns...was happy to be helpful
 
2) Need some help on Tanf sub ($60mil to fla) - should be an easy lift for him to support, we need this this year before TANF renewal debate begins next year....so we not start next year with a $60mill shortfall
 
3) move then to current debate on economic stimulus, as house ways and means chair, he is KEY player...just want him to be cognizant of impact on states/fla - is real,
        depreciation hit at 30% to fla will be approx $200m, real GR money
        just finished 2nd special session, where we cut $1.2billion
        financial hit in states is real - remember 36 govs up next year, 20 GOP govs - ....
        UPL hit to fla, and others is real - wish we could get longer transition....know your leadership got calif their 8 year transition last year.....
        ask that you NOT OPPOSE FMAP, if included in final stimulus package to offset hit we will take on depreciation item
 
    thank you for your leadership and your help - let me knw if there are others calls i can make
 
 
2nd CALL - BILL YOUNG
        He is having a celebration TONIGHT in TAMPA for his bday. - you could say happy bday!
        Ask for TANF supplemental support
        UPL - does he see this moving on either Labor H Appropriation or DOD Approps or stimulus pkg
        THANK HIM FOR HIS LEADERSHIP 
        WHAT ELSE CAN YOU DO TO HELP HIM
 
Let's discuss
Timing of calls VERY VERY IMPORTANT

Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law.
Most written communications to or from state officials

-----Original Message-----
From: Nina Oviedo [mailto:oviedon@sso.org]
Sent: Wednesday, December 12, 2001 7:53 PM
To: Laura Branker; Brian Yablonski; Frank R. Jimenez; Kathleen Shanahan
Cc: Jeb Bush
Subject: NEXT 48 HOURS/VERY IMPORTANT
Importance: High


Team, 
 
We need to fish or cut bait.  All signs are that Congress will work up to Friday, cut whatever deals they can between now and the weekend and return one day next week to pass that which is agreed to.
 
There are a few open issueswe need guidance from you on priorities and we likely need one phone call from the Governor to Chairman Young------ its now or wait till next year.
 
Today, the NGA Executive Committee met with Governors Whitman, Ridge, Secretary Thompson and Director Brown (Allbaughs Deputy).  11 Governors attended:  Minner (D-ME), Sundquist (R-TN), Musgrove (D-MS), Leavitt (R-UT), Engler (R-MI), Patton (D-KY), Huckabee (R-AR), Vilsack (D-IA), Kempthorne (R-ID), Glendenning (D-MD), OBannon (D-IN).  Some of their comments are reflected below. 
 
UPL---- According to our hospital contacts 18 of our FL House Members and both Senators have co-sponsored legislation delaying UPL rule for 1 year.  Im thinking I need to go to Mr. Bilirakis and ask him how to bring this to a close.  Overall, the bill has 60 co-sponsors.  This issue needs a bit of a push.  If I go see Mr. B, it will be read as a message from the Gov.  We have been holding off on flying above radar because we have not received approval on our last plan amendment.  If were too vocal, were concerned that the Administration will not grant or delay granting our plan amendment.  This issue is $185M to the pocketbook.
 
Economic Stimulus----according to NGA, the Senate has now moved to the House column on depreciation allowance.   That means that both House and Senate agreed to a 30% depreciation allowance; this means a revenue loss to Florida of $200 million.  The NGA including Governors Engler, Pataki, and Sundquist were on the Hill yesterday and today pushing FMAP.  NGAs Democrat Govs met with 14 Senate Democrats (including Daschle) and assured NGA that the Senate Democrats are committed to FMAP.  The question was raised as to how we approach the WH (Engler looked at my direction, I stared at the floor).  All Govs acknowledged that the WH was the stumbling block.  FMAP could mean $162M to $324M to FL.
 
TANF Supplemental Grants----on a scale of 1 to 10(passage); we feel this is at 8.  We need to push Chairman Thomas.  At todays NGA Executive Committee meeting, Governor Sundquist announced that he has again called Chairman Thomas.  Doesnt know whether it was effective.  The Senate passed a stand alone bill which the House could consider under suspension (stand alone, without Committee action).  Were hoping but not convinced.  This issue means $60M to FL. 
 
Seaport Security----we have conveyed to Chairman Young a short list of earmarks for Defense Approps.  I received assurances from Youngs COS that if they cant specifically earmark out of the Supplemental bill they would try to include in separate categories within DOD approps.  Commissioner Moore insists that this issue is Govs number 1.  He would like the Gov to call Chairman Young and make this happen.  At the NGA meeting, Governor Ridge expressed his views on the supplementalhe essentially said its out of his hands, and anyone elses.  He suggested to the Governors that they focus their attention on the Presidents 03 Budget.  I conveyed Governor Ridges remarks to Com Moore and it was not to his satisfaction.  He has asked me whether he should come up to see Chairman Young (even if the Governor should call the Chairman).  This earmark is for $30M.
 
CONCLUSION: We need to determine our priorities.  At the end of this game, there may well be only one pot of money, one vehicle.  This requires us to be very focused on any message to the Hill.  We have one shot at the pot and every hour that goes by means less opportunity.  Can we conference in the morning?  We need to know whether I pay a few visits to the Hill and whether the Governor makes a call to Chairman Young.
 
Thank, Nina.    
 
 
 
 
 
From:	Gates, Lisa <lisa.gates@myflorida.com>

-----Original Message-----
From: STRANGE.CAROLE [mailto:STRANGE.CAROLE@leg.state.fl.us]
Sent: Thursday, December 13, 2001 3:46 PM
Subject: PRESS CONFERENCE


President McKay's "Tax Reform" Press Conference is scheduled for Monday, December 17, 2001 at 11:00 a.m.  It will be held in Room 409 - SENATE OFFICE BUILDING.
 
 
From:	Yablonski, Brian <brian.yablonski@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Thursday, December 13, 2001 3:42 PM
To:	Shanahan, Kathleen; Jeb Bush; Oviedo, Nina; Branker, Laura; Jimenez, Frank
Cc:	Hampton, Betty; Arduin, Donna
Subject:	RE: NEXT 48 HOURS/VERY IMPORTANT

Spoke to Marc Summerlin -- the redrafted proposal would provide Florida with $237 million from Reed Act funds.  This is money that would go primarily (90%) into our UC Trust Fund for benefits, etc. NONE OF THIS COULD BE USED TO OFFSET GR LOSSES ON OTHER SIDE OF THE LEDGER.  Some states have general revenue supplements or payments into their UC funds -- if that was the case we could of used this new revenue to offset.  Unfortunately, Florida is one of the few states that has zero gr supplements or payments into its UC fund.
 
Still, this money could be used for Operation Paycheck activities and other reemployment services -- it just doesnt help our immediate budget problem.
-----Original Message-----

From:	McPherson, Scott <scott.mcpherson@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Thursday, December 13, 2001 2:32 PM
To:	'Thompson, Kevin'; Saliba, Lisa
Cc:	Snow, Chris; Bahrami, Kimberly
Subject:	Budget Issues:  Security and legislative intent

Importance:	High

Just to let everyone know that the legislature, despite all the funding cuts
and such, actually gave the STO's Office of Information Security an
additional $500,000 to expand the information security audits of State
agencies.  the sponsor was Sen. Ginny Brown-Waite, the chair of the Senate
Security Committee.  This action tells me the legislature wants information
security to continue and if we move forward to make this a continuation
issue, we will receive favorable consideration from the legislature.

-----Original Message-----
From: Nina Oviedo [mailto:oviedon@sso.org]
Sent: Wednesday, December 12, 2001 7:53 PM
To: Laura Branker; Brian Yablonski; Frank R. Jimenez; Kathleen Shanahan
Cc: Jeb Bush
Subject: NEXT 48 HOURS/VERY IMPORTANT
Importance: High


Team,

We need to fish or cut bait.  All signs are that Congress will work up to
Friday, cut whatever deals they can between now and the weekend and return
one day next week to pass that which is agreed to.

There are a few open issues...we need guidance from you on priorities and we
likely need one phone call from the Governor to Chairman Young------ it's
now or wait till next year.

Today, the NGA Executive Committee met with Governors Whitman, Ridge,
Secretary Thompson and Director Brown (Allbaugh's Deputy).  11 Governors
attended:  Minner (D-ME), Sundquist (R-TN), Musgrove (D-MS), Leavitt (R-UT),
Engler (R-MI), Patton (D-KY), Huckabee (R-AR), Vilsack (D-IA), Kempthorne
(R-ID), Glendenning (D-MD), O'Bannon (D-IN).  Some of their comments are
reflected below.

UPL---- According to our hospital contacts 18 of our FL House Members and
both Senators have co-sponsored legislation delaying UPL rule for 1 year.
I'm thinking I need to go to Mr. Bilirakis and ask him how to bring this to
a close.  Overall, the bill has 60 co-sponsors.  This issue needs a bit of a
push.  If I go see Mr. B, it will be read as a message from the Gov.  We
have been holding off on flying above radar because we have not received
approval on our last plan amendment.  If we're too vocal, we're concerned
that the Administration will not grant or delay granting our plan amendment.
This issue is $185M to the pocketbook.

Economic Stimulus----according to NGA, the Senate has now moved to the House
column on depreciation allowance.   That means that both House and Senate
agreed to a 30% depreciation allowance; this means a revenue loss to Florida
of $200 million.  The NGA including Governors Engler, Pataki, and Sundquist
were on the Hill yesterday and today pushing FMAP.  NGA's Democrat Govs met
with 14 Senate Democrats (including Daschle) and assured NGA that the Senate
Democrats are committed to FMAP.  The question was raised as to how we
approach the WH (Engler looked at my direction, I stared at the floor).  All
Gov's acknowledged that the WH was the stumbling block.  FMAP could mean
$162M to $324M to FL.

TANF Supplemental Grants----on a scale of 1 to 10(passage); we feel this is
at 8.  We need to push Chairman Thomas.  At today's NGA Executive Committee
meeting, Governor Sundquist announced that he has again called Chairman
Thomas.  Doesn't know whether it was effective.  The Senate passed a stand
alone bill which the House could consider under suspension (stand alone,
without Committee action).  We're hoping but not convinced.  This issue
means $60M to FL.

Seaport Security----we have conveyed to Chairman Young a short list of
earmarks for Defense Approps.  I received assurances from Young's COS that
if they can't specifically earmark out of the Supplemental bill they would
try to include in separate categories within DOD approps.  Commissioner
Moore insists that this issue is Gov's number 1.  He would like the Gov to
call Chairman Young and make this happen.  At the NGA meeting, Governor
Ridge expressed his views on the supplemental...he essentially said it's out
of his hands, and anyone else's.  He suggested to the Governors that they
focus their attention on the President's '03 Budget.  I conveyed Governor
Ridge's remarks to Com Moore and it was not to his satisfaction.  He has
asked me whether he should come up to see Chairman Young (even if the
Governor should call the Chairman).  This earmark is for $30M.

CONCLUSION: We need to determine our priorities.  At the end of this game,
there may well be only one pot of money, one vehicle.  This requires us to
be very focused on any message to the Hill.  We have one shot at the pot and
every hour that goes by means less opportunity.  Can we conference in the
morning?  We need to know whether I pay a few visits to the Hill and whether
the Governor makes a call to Chairman Young.

Thank, Nina.

Mark Summerlin - lead tax/stimulus contact in WH/Larry Lindsey's shop
Karl Rove
 
Bottom line: 
1) 30% depreciation as part of corporate tax package is pretty set/wh priority - will not move at this point in time
 
2) karl met w/ 5 govs last night - said wh would quietly agree to including fmap w/a 1.5% increase for 1 year to this fed medicaid assistance - IF that is included fla could get a $162mil/GR
 
3) guidance given to govs was to get to dem govs to get daschle to bring up stimulus package for vote, if fmap in wh would sign, as long as core wh package is in it: depreciation, amt, rebates, rates (not clear on what is exactly in each of those items)>
 
4) mark summerlin - wh tax guy, said they had recently included in a redrafted admin proposal this week some type of fed unemployment insurance to offset impact of  depreciation - I specifically asked him to call me back with number WH had found out fla would get, also from what i am told NOT GR $$.
 
Nina recommends in your call to THomas you take the following approach:
 
1) CONGRATS on TANF - your hard work paid off, hope my note to fla delegation pushed some towards you....ie cliff stearns...was happy to be helpful
 
2) Need some help on Tanf sub ($60mil to fla) - should be an easy lift for him to support, we need this this year before TANF renewal debate begins next year....so we not start next year with a $60mill shortfall
 
3) move then to current debate on economic stimulus, as house ways and means chair, he is KEY player...just want him to be cognizant of impact on states/fla - is real,
        depreciation hit at 30% to fla will be approx $200m, real GR money
        just finished 2nd special session, where we cut $1.2billion
        financial hit in states is real - remember 36 govs up next year, 20 GOP govs - ....
        UPL hit to fla, and others is real - wish we could get longer transition....know your leadership got calif their 8 year transition last year.....
        ask that you NOT OPPOSE FMAP, if included in final stimulus package to offset hit we will take on depreciation item
 
    thank you for your leadership and your help - let me knw if there are others calls i can make

        He is having a celebration TONIGHT in TAMPA for his bday. - you could say happy bday!
        Ask for TANF supplemental support
        UPL - does he see this moving on either Labor H Appropriation or DOD Approps or stimulus pkg
        THANK HIM FOR HIS LEADERSHIP

Let's discuss

-----Original Message-----
From: Nina Oviedo [mailto:oviedon@sso.org]
Sent: Wednesday, December 12, 2001 7:53 PM
To: Laura Branker; Brian Yablonski; Frank R. Jimenez; Kathleen Shanahan
Cc: Jeb Bush
Subject: NEXT 48 HOURS/VERY IMPORTANT
Importance: High


Team, 
 
We need to fish or cut bait.  All signs are that Congress will work up to Friday, cut whatever deals they can between now and the weekend and return one day next week to pass that which is agreed to.
 
There are a few open issueswe need guidance from you on priorities and we likely need one phone call from the Governor to Chairman Young------ its now or wait till next year.
 
Today, the NGA Executive Committee met with Governors Whitman, Ridge, Secretary Thompson and Director Brown (Allbaughs Deputy).  11 Governors attended:  Minner (D-ME), Sundquist (R-TN), Musgrove (D-MS), Leavitt (R-UT), Engler (R-MI), Patton (D-KY), Huckabee (R-AR), Vilsack (D-IA), Kempthorne (R-ID), Glendenning (D-MD), OBannon (D-IN).  Some of their comments are reflected below. 
 
UPL---- According to our hospital contacts 18 of our FL House Members and both Senators have co-sponsored legislation delaying UPL rule for 1 year.  Im thinking I need to go to Mr. Bilirakis and ask him how to bring this to a close.  Overall, the bill has 60 co-sponsors.  This issue needs a bit of a push.  If I go see Mr. B, it will be read as a message from the Gov.  We have been holding off on flying above radar because we have not received approval on our last plan amendment.  If were too vocal, were concerned that the Administration will not grant or delay granting our plan amendment.  This issue is $185M to the pocketbook.
 
Economic Stimulus----according to NGA, the Senate has now moved to the House column on depreciation allowance.   That means that both House and Senate agreed to a 30% depreciation allowance; this means a revenue loss to Florida of $200 million.  The NGA including Governors Engler, Pataki, and Sundquist were on the Hill yesterday and today pushing FMAP.  NGAs Democrat Govs met with 14 Senate Democrats (including Daschle) and assured NGA that the Senate Democrats are committed to FMAP.  The question was raised as to how we approach the WH (Engler looked at my direction, I stared at the floor).  All Govs acknowledged that the WH was the stumbling block.  FMAP could mean $162M to $324M to FL.
 
TANF Supplemental Grants----on a scale of 1 to 10(passage); we feel this is at 8.  We need to push Chairman Thomas.  At todays NGA Executive Committee meeting, Governor Sundquist announced that he has again called Chairman Thomas.  Doesnt know whether it was effective.  The Senate passed a stand alone bill which the House could consider under suspension (stand alone, without Committee action).  Were hoping but not convinced.  This issue means $60M to FL. 
 
Seaport Security----we have conveyed to Chairman Young a short list of earmarks for Defense Approps.  I received assurances from Youngs COS that if they cant specifically earmark out of the Supplemental bill they would try to include in separate categories within DOD approps.  Commissioner Moore insists that this issue is Govs number 1.  He would like the Gov to call Chairman Young and make this happen.  At the NGA meeting, Governor Ridge expressed his views on the supplementalhe essentially said its out of his hands, and anyone elses.  He suggested to the Governors that they focus their attention on the Presidents 03 Budget.  I conveyed Governor Ridges remarks to Com Moore and it was not to his satisfaction.  He has asked me whether he should come up to see Chairman Young (even if the Governor should call the Chairman).  This earmark is for $30M.
 
CONCLUSION: We need to determine our priorities.  At the end of this game, there may well be only one pot of money, one vehicle.  This requires us to be very focused on any message to the Hill.  We have one shot at the pot and every hour that goes by means less opportunity.  Can we conference in the morning?  We need to know whether I pay a few visits to the Hill and whether the Governor makes a call to Chairman Young.
 
Thank, Nina.

-----Original Message-----
From: Freedman, Melissa [mailto:freedmm@SSONet.sso.org]
Sent: Thursday, December 13, 2001 10:42 AM
To: Brewser Brown; Donna Arduin; Greg Turbeville
Cc: Oviedo, Nina
Subject: ESEA Title I Grant Money to FL
 
Hello, 
A quick update on ESEA, and dollars to Florida: 
The ESEA Re-authorization Conference Report is scheduled to go to the floor of the House for a final vote on Thursday, and is yet unscheduled in the Senate. 
According to the Congressional Research Service a dollar estimate for ESEA Title I, Part A "Grants to States" for Florida is approximately $510 million.
As soon as the ESEA Conference Report is passed by the House and Senate, the Labor/HHS/Education Appropriation bill should begin to move in chambers, which will give us a more exact number.
Melissa Freedman 
Florida-Washington Office 
(202) 624-5885

From:	McPherson, Scott <scott.mcpherson@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Thursday, December 13, 2001 10:20 AM
To:	'Thompson, Kevin'; Saliba, Lisa
Cc:	McPherson, Scott; Snow, Chris; Bahrami, Kimberly
Subject:	RE: Budget Issues:  Security Reductions

Kevin, it was good talking with you yesterday.  I ahve been out for 2 days,
trying to get over this damn bronchitis! And this fog has been REAL
helpful...

Your response to Lisa's requests is correct.  There is ZERO duplication in
funds vis a vis FDLE.  They received no cyberterrorism funding; in fact,
they are counting on STO to push that initiative.  The training dollars in
the FIPC proposal are for local governments, and members of the critical
infrastructure, to learn about the alert software.

Everything we have presented has been vetted by FDLE and fits into their
grand scheme of things.  They just don't have funds, and neither does the
Federal Government.  I asked the President's cyber guy, Richard Clarke, that
very questions and got the "no, there's no cash" response.  In fact, Clarke
asked Bob Breeden and I to write the state government component of what he
wants to do!
If we are serious about combatting all forms of terrorism -- including
cyberterrorism -- then these initiatives will find their way into the
Governor's recs.  I will close with the observation from the recent NASCIO
meeting Kim and I attended that no other state in the Union is moving
forward with such detailed plans.  Kansas, Virginia and Arizona are trying
to implement, but Florida is far ahead of the other states in both critical
infrastrcture defense plans, and in cyberterrorism defense.

If anyone needs me, I am at 488-7241 and ready to help anyway I can.

-----Original Message-----
From: Thompson, Kevin [mailto:kevin.thompson@myflorida.com]
Sent: Tuesday, December 11, 2001 3:58 PM
To: Saliba, Lisa
Cc: McPherson, Scott (DC); Snow, Chris; Bahrami, Kimberly
Subject: RE: Budget Issues: Security Reductions


Lisa - I am trying to get in touch w/Scott to verify, but here are the
answers based on my understanding at this time:

1.  To continue the True Secure Audits, $1,250,000 is needed.  This would
provide for expansion of the security audits to non-Governor agencies.

2.  A)  Per discussion w/Bob Breeden, Special Agent at FDLE (Ph. 410.7057)
who has worked closely w/Scott on security issues, none of the amounts
requested in the Office of Info. Security Issue or the FIPC Issue are
duplicative of what was funded in FDLE during special session.  B)  Funding
received by FDLE during special session was not related to computer forensic
assistance.

3.  The $1.25 million provides for expansion of the security audits to
non-Governor agencies.  These audits involve the following:

	Attempt to penetrate core systems, data centers, and networks
	Scan all ports for potential security breaches
	Map existing data networks to determine points of weakness
	Place all CIOs and InfoSec officers on their exclusive TruSecure
alert system
	Generate detailed reports for the agency to examine and evaluate
	Work with the agency to remediate and close loopholes in their
computer security
	Retest the entity to determine the quality of their remediation
effort
	Certify the entity once the remediation has been proven successful

4.  The $961,300 is broken down as follows:

- $386,300 for software.  The specific software to be used in the FIPC Issue
has not yet been identified.  The desired software would provide for mass
notification of attacks on Florida's infrastructure (i.e., telephone, gas,
banks, etc.) through e-mail mesaages, beeper alerts, etc.  Software to
perform these functions is available and would be acquired through a
competitive procurement process.  

- $575,000 for a contract with TrueSecure.  This would provide Florida with
access to what TrueSecure calls "The Brain".  The Brain is essentially a
massive intelligence tool.  Florida would also get access to TrueSecure
resources such as one of their groups that infiltrates hackers and warns
companies like McAfee and Norton of new viruses.  

5.  That would be another option.  Your call given the fiscal situation.

6.  Per discussion w/Bob Breeden, Special Agent at FDLE (Ph. 410.7057), FDLE
did not receive an additional appropriation for cyber terrorism.

7.  See attachments for additional info. Last page has some spending plan
info., but it is not much more detailed.  The narrative may be helpful.



-----Original Message-----
From: Saliba, Lisa [mailto:Lisa.Saliba@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US]
Sent: Tuesday, December 11, 2001 2:05 PM
To: 'kevin.thompson@myflorida.com'
Cc: Snow, Chris; 'kim.bahrami@myflorida.com'
Subject: FW: Budget Issues: Security Reductions


Kevin,

First, I apologize for not reading the issue narrative ahead of time.
Second, there is not enough detail to ascertain whether this issues are
absolutely essential.  The bar has been raised very high on new issues given
the current fiscal situation. Here are some questions I have:

1.  What level of funding is needed to continue the True Secure contract?
2.  Is any of this issue duplicative with what was funded in FDLE during
special session?  Specifically, why does FDLE need computer forensic
assistance if their issue was just fund?
3.  What exactly do you get for $1.25 million security audits and alerts?
4.  What software?  What do you get for the $?  What are the licenses?  So
you are buying a data base for $961,300?
5.  Shouldn't training for agency staff be requested by the agency where a
multitude of other funds could be used?
6.  Did FDLE receive additional appropriation for cyber terrorism?
7.  Do you have a more detailed spending plan?

Sorry for the delay.  Any information you get us will be a tremendous help.

-----Original Message-----
From: Thompson, Kevin [mailto:kevin.thompson@myflorida.com]
Sent: Tuesday, December 11, 2001 10:22 AM
To: McPherson, Scott (DC)
Cc: 'russell.rhonda@mail.dc.state.fl.us'
Subject: Budget Issues: Security Reductions


Scott - The Governor has not yet made a decision on whether to include the
two security issues (i.e., Office of Info. Security and FIPC) in the Gov.
Rec's.  That decision may be made today.  As I mentioned to you yesterday at
lunch, OPB has requested that the funding requests for the two issues be
reduced.  At this time, the following reductions have been made:

Deletions in Office of Information Security Issue

Training						   75,000
Public Awareness Campaign (State Component) 275,500

Deletions in FIPC Issue

FIPC Seminars and Training			  284,905

Additional reductions are currently be considered.  This is your opportunity
to provide input prior to any unilateral decisions.  Please advise as to
additional cuts.  I do not want the issues to get cut to the point that you
can not do anything, but I need your help in defending the issues.  What is
the bare minimum needed?

He suggested to the Governors that they focus their attention on the Presidents 03 Budget.  I conveyed Governor Ridges remarks to Com Moore and it was not to his satisfaction.  He has asked me whether he should come up to see Chairman Young (even if the Governor should call the Chairman).  This earmark is for $30M.
 
CONCLUSION: We need to determine our priorities.  At the end of this game, there may well be only one pot of money, one vehicle.  This requires us to be very focused on any message to the Hill.  We have one shot at the pot and every hour that goes by means less opportunity.  Can we conference in the morning?  We need to know whether I pay a few visits to the Hill and whether the Governor makes a call to Chairman Young.
 
Thank, Nina.

-----Original Message-----
From: Springbookhaus@aol.com [mailto:Springbookhaus@aol.com]
Sent: Monday, December 10, 2001 3:52 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: BEACH EROSION


Hi Jeb...We voted for YOU!


Subject:  Brevard County Shore Protection Project Funding: Phase II, South Reach

Dear Senator:

I request your leadership in obtaining federal funds for Brevard County's beaches in the 2001 Conference Energy and Water Bill.  The House bill included $8.5 million for Brevard County's Shore Protection Project, but the Senate and Administration's budgets included only $200,000.  The federal cost-share for Phase II, as authorized by Congress in 1996, is $12 million.  Brevard County needs this $12 million appropriated in the FY 2001-2002 Conference Bill.  Brevard County is relying on you to take the lead in appropriating these dollars.

A few special interest groups have attempted to label beach nourishment as pork, primarily benefiting wealthy oceanfront property owners.  This is untrue!  As the photos above indicate, the majority of those who benefit are the millions of people who relax and play on our public beaches each year.  Private property rights in America give oceanfront property owners the right to protect their investments or to be compensated by the government for lost property.  When faced with erosion, these property owners erect seawalls.  Seawalls displace public recreation, increase the pace of erosion, and destroy marine turtle nesting habitat.  Along highly developed shorelines like Brevard's, the government simply cannot afford to outlaw seawalls and fund a retreat policy.  In contrast, beach nourishment restores the beaches to a healthy width, thereby averting the demand for seawalls while simultaneously creating huge recreational and environmental benefits.  Beach nourishment saves America's beaches from seawalls.

Thank you in advance for your support.  With a $12 million appropriation in the Conference Bill, we can build back Brevard's beaches. 

Sincerely, Philip D. Snyder & Dorothy J. Snyder
Printed Name

877 N. Highway A1A, Unit 1108
Street Address

Indialantic, Florida  32903-3028
Sign Here City, State, Zip Code

From:	Nina Oviedo <oviedon@sso.org>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 12, 2001 7:53 PM
To:	Laura Branker; Brian Yablonski; Frank R. Jimenez; Kathleen Shanahan
Cc:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	NEXT 48 HOURS/VERY IMPORTANT

Importance:	High

Team, 
 
We need to fish or cut bait.  All signs are that Congress will work up to Friday, cut whatever deals they can between now and the weekend and return one day next week to pass that which is agreed to.
 
There are a few open issueswe need guidance from you on priorities and we likely need one phone call from the Governor to Chairman Young------ its now or wait till next year.
 
Today, the NGA Executive Committee met with Governors Whitman, Ridge, Secretary Thompson and Director Brown (Allbaughs Deputy).  11 Governors attended:  Minner (D-ME), Sundquist (R-TN), Musgrove (D-MS), Leavitt (R-UT), Engler (R-MI), Patton (D-KY), Huckabee (R-AR), Vilsack (D-IA), Kempthorne (R-ID), Glendenning (D-MD), OBannon (D-IN).  Some of their comments are reflected below. 
 
UPL---- According to our hospital contacts 18 of our FL House Members and both Senators have co-sponsored legislation delaying UPL rule for 1 year.  Im thinking I need to go to Mr. Bilirakis and ask him how to bring this to a close.  Overall, the bill has 60 co-sponsors.  This issue needs a bit of a push.  If I go see Mr. B, it will be read as a message from the Gov.  We have been holding off on flying above radar because we have not received approval on our last plan amendment.  If were too vocal, were concerned that the Administration will not grant or delay granting our plan amendment.  This issue is $185M to the pocketbook.
 
Economic Stimulus----according to NGA, the Senate has now moved to the House column on depreciation allowance.   That means that both House and Senate agreed to a 30% depreciation allowance; this means a revenue loss to Florida of $200 million.  The NGA including Governors Engler, Pataki, and Sundquist were on the Hill yesterday and today pushing FMAP.  NGAs Democrat Govs met with 14 Senate Democrats (including Daschle) and assured NGA that the Senate Democrats are committed to FMAP.  The question was raised as to how we approach the WH (Engler looked at my direction, I stared at the floor).  All Govs acknowledged that the WH was the stumbling block.  FMAP could mean $162M to $324M to FL.
 
TANF Supplemental Grants----on a scale of 1 to 10(passage); we feel this is at 8.  We need to push Chairman Thomas.  At todays NGA Executive Committee meeting, Governor Sundquist announced that he has again called Chairman Thomas.  Doesnt know whether it was effective.  The Senate passed a stand alone bill which the House could consider under suspension (stand alone, without Committee action).  Were hoping but not convinced.  This issue means $60M to FL. 
 
Seaport Security----we have conveyed to Chairman Young a short list of earmarks for Defense Approps.  I received assurances from Youngs COS that if they cant specifically earmark out of the Supplemental bill they would try to include in separate categories within DOD approps.  Commissioner Moore insists that this issue is Govs number 1.  He would like the Gov to call Chairman Young and make this happen.  At the NGA meeting, Governor Ridge expressed his views on the supplementalhe essentially said its out of his hands, and anyone elses.  He suggested to the Governors that they focus their attention on the Presidents 03 Budget.  I conveyed Governor Ridges remarks to Com Moore and it was not to his satisfaction.  He has asked me whether he should come up to see Chairman Young (even if the Governor should call the Chairman).  This earmark is for $30M.
 
CONCLUSION: We need to determine our priorities.  At the end of this game, there may well be only one pot of money, one vehicle.  This requires us to be very focused on any message to the Hill.  We have one shot at the pot and every hour that goes by means less opportunity.  Can we conference in the morning?  We need to know whether I pay a few visits to the Hill and whether the Governor makes a call to Chairman Young.
 
Thank, Nina.

From:	Jimenez, Frank <frank.jimenez@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 12, 2001 6:40 PM
To:	Snow, Chris
Cc:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	FW: October Minority Vendor reports
Attachments:	frank.xls; worksheet.xls; goal worksheet.xls

Good work, Chris.  I actually like the second chart.  According to it, we're
ahead of where we were this time last year, right?  Also, may I send this
e-mail out to the agency heads?

>  -----Original Message-----
> From: 	Snow, Chris [mailto:Chris.Snow@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US] 
> Sent:	Monday, December 10, 2001 10:15 AM
> To:	Jimenez, Frank; Grant, Wendy
> Cc:	Flack, Christopher; Saliba, Lisa; Sauls, Cynthia; Pfeifer, Pam;
> Turbeville, Greg; Arduin, Donna; Matt Carter (E-mail); Windell Paige
> (E-mail)
> Subject:	October Minority Vendor reports
> 
> The first spreadsheet, "frank.xls", is the traditional report we've been
> doing.  It shows the current year status of spending with minority vendors
> as compared to the total spending for FY 2000-01.  We are one third of the
> way through the year and therefore a simple analysis would say we should
> be at 33% of prior year spending to be keeping pace.  We are only at
> 30.82% for Gov's agencies.  DOT, DEP and AWI are ahead of pace, with all
> other Gov's agencies behind last year's pace.  There are some cyclical
> effects as well as the economic slowdown to consider.
> 
> The spreadsheet, "worksheet.xls", is a rough comparison of the months of
> July through October for the last 4 years.  It only includes one of the
> three components of our total minority vendor calculation and thus does
> not tie back to the frank.xls report.  It's importance is to show the
> cyclical spending and that historically the early months in the fiscal
> year are lower spending months in general and for minority vendors.  I
> think this report is more confusing than helpful and will not send it out
> anymore unless someone requests it.
> 
> The spreadsheet, "goal worksheet.xls", is a new format I worked on to make
> it simple to communicate with agency heads what there goals should be for
> the balance of the year.  The first two columns are from the "frank.xls"
> report and show total MBE spending for 2000-01 and current spending so far
> in 2001-02.  The third and fourth columns show the goal for each agency,
> in total and monthly, for the remainder of the year to equal FY 2000-01
> MBE spending.  Columns six and seven do the same for a 10% increase over
> 2000-01. Column five shows the agency 10% increase total annualized.
> 
> If you have any comments or question please call me at 922-4982.  Thanks!
> 
> 
> 
>  <<frank.xls>>  <<worksheet.xls>>  <<goal worksheet.xls>> 
> 
> Frank,  I'm still working on the discretionary spending report by agency.
> We are pretty loaded up in OPB now with the Special Session budget and the
> Gov's Recs budget for 2002-03.  Call me if you want to discuss.  Thanks!

DCF:
*Greg Martin - Reporter - Charlotte Sun Herald - Contacts:  Tim Bottcher &
Debbie Webb
Query:  Numerous questions on the closing of G. Pierce Wood state mental
hospital.
Response:  Arranged conference call with head of DCF mental health office.

James Abraham - Editor - Sarasota Herald-Tribune - Contact:  Tim Bottcher
Query:  How many GPW residents have been discharged into Group Homes.
Response:  One, as of 11.30.01

Nancy Lauer - Reporter - Tallahassee Democrat - Contact:  Tim Bottcher
Query:  Seeking update on welfare and welfare reform.
Response:  Program officials not available today, will contact them
Thursday about speaking with the reporter.

*Suzzane Boyd -reporter- NewsChannel 12 - West Palm Beach-   Contact: Bob
Lloyd
Query:  Can  DCF-licensed  Alcohol and Drug Abuse rehabilitation facilities
operate
group homes?
Response:   Arranged for Phil Emenheiser of the Substance Abuse Program
Office
to call the reporter.  He explained that under F.S. Chapter 397, DCF
licenses, through its District Offices, substance abuse rehabilitation
facilities and residential treatment facilities.
Facilities without treatment, sometimes generically referred to as "group
homes", are licensed by the Agency for Health Care Administration.
Ms. Boyd asked if Behavioral Health of the Palm Beaches, Inc., North Palm
Beach, is
DCF licensed.   Emenheiser responded that  this facility, according to
industry directories,
is DCF licensed for a full range of services.  He cautioned her to check
with the District
Office in Palm Beach County for the latest update on the license.

OTHER ISSUES
* Got approval from Liz for the op ed on Bonnie L. Sending to the Miami
Herald tonight. They are expecting it.
Note: There is a good chance that it will run on Sunday.
* Working on a communications plan for Developmental Services. Will focus
on cost containment and choice.
* Working on communications plan for budget cuts.

From:	DiBenigno, Arlene <arlene.dibenigno@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 12, 2001 6:01 PM
To:	Shanahan, Kathleen; Brown, Brewser; Kammel, Kay; Hirst, Elizabeth; Gates, Lisa; Busse, Mark; Cliett, Cheryl; Wainwright, Tara; Turbeville, Greg; McDougal, Kim

-----Original Message-----
From: tomdandrea06@home.com [mailto:tomdandrea06@home.com]
Sent: Wednesday, December 12, 2001 8:45 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Sun Herald Story







12/12/01


Area has stake in board vacancy 



Drought and concerns about phosphate mining place added significance on the task of filling a vacant seat on the Peace River Basin Board. 


Punta Gorda resident Tom D'Andrea unexpectedly resigned his position on the board recently and care must be taken to appoint someone who not only has knowledge of Southwest Florida's water resources but someone who can commit to standing up for our best interests. 


D'Andrea's resignation came shortly after Don Ross -- Charlotte County's second, and only other, delegate -- moved from the county and was forced to step down. Ross was replaced by former Punta Gorda Mayor Rufus Lazell. 


The board plays an important role in shaping water-related policy in Southwest Florida. The six-pers! on board is charged with investigating issues regarding water in the five-county basin and recommending solutions and policy to the Southwest Florida Water Management District, also known as SWIFTMUD. 


In recent months, sentiments on the board have swung from one extreme to the next as representatives from inland counties sought to protect their water resources from being diverted to fast-growing coastal counties. Board members from Polk and DeSoto counties have also voiced support for phosphate mining -- an industry they are relying on for economic development. 


Charlotte County has sometimes stood alone in its battle to force more extensive studies of the effects of phosphate mining on the Peace River, which provides drinking water to Charlotte County, North Port and eventually Sarasota County. 


The fact Charlotte County is the lone government with two representatives speaks of its size and the underdog role its board members embrace. Their greatest chal! lenge is to convince representatives of smaller, inland counties to be more proactive in protecting the few water resources we have while planning for alternative sources. 


D'Andrea was an outspoken proponent of protecting the Peace River and Horse Creek. His voice on the board will be missed. 


The process of nominating a replacement is a wide-open affair. While no names have surfaced publicly, it would benefit all coastal communities if local politicos and Charlotte County officials work together to support a qualified, dedicated nominee. 


Even though all Peace River Basin recommendations must be approved by SWIFTMUD, the importance of coming up with fact-based, responsible policies cannot be stressed enough. Charlotte County's next representative will shoulder an important responsibility We must seek out a quality nominee. 







 <http://www!.sun-herald.com/mailnews.htm?date=121201&filename=op1.htm> Email this story to a friend or relative

	

This story appeared in either the Sun Herald, the Venice Gondolier, Waterline or the Weekly Record - all publications of the Sun Coast Media Group.

FBI: Uncorroborated threat received against Texas schools 

12/12/2001 

By CONNIE MABIN / The Associated Press 

AUSTIN - FBI agents have alerted schools throughout Texas that a vague threat has been received suggesting two people may retaliate against unknown Texas schools for the U.S. bombing in Afghanistan.

"Basically, as vague as I gave it, is as vague as we have it," Houston FBI Special Agent Bob Doguim said Wednesday. "This is coming to us from a foreign government. We are working with them to try and determine the reliability of it."

From:	Flack, Christopher <Christopher.Flack@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 12, 2001 3:31 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	Yablonski, Brian; Arduin, Donna; Saliba, Lisa
Subject:	Farm Share

Governor I have spoken with Patricia Robbins of Farm Share and with Joan Glickman in Senator Jones' office regarding the Farm Share funding.  Both were comfortable with the fact that the $900,000 would be non-recurring and that they would be at square one during the next legislative session.  According to Patricia Robbins, they were already going to ask for additional money next year, over the $400,000 recurring, and expected to be funded out of non-recurring anyway.  Senator Jones is preparing the paperwork now for next years request.  The additional money they will receive this year will enable them to distribute an additional 15 million pounds of food from USDA giving them a total distribution of 31.2 million pounds of food this year.  So it would be my recommendation to leave the funding in the special session alone and let them come back to the legislature for funding next year.

From:	Hirst, Elizabeth <Elizabeth.Hirst@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 12, 2001 3:19 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	erosion letter


December 11, 2001



VIA FAX:  321/255-9550
Letters to the Editor
Florida Today
P.O. Box 419000
Melbourne, FL 32941-9000

Your November 29 article, "Gov. Bush denies Brevard and Indian River
counties money to renourish beaches," misconstrued the process for
requesting federal disaster assistance and failed to mention any of the
measures we are taking to protect these vital Florida assets.

Simply put, it was not my decision to deny funding.  I was unable to request
a federal disaster declaration because one can only be issued within certain
strict guidelines.  One of these is that the impact of every storm must be
individually assessed by teams of local and state officials to determine if
the damages rise to the level of a federal disaster. In the case of
Hurricane Michelle, what damage could be documented did not reach this
level.

Your paper performed a disservice by not making these guidelines clear.  In
Florida, our focus has been, and will continue to be, on protecting and
strengthening our beaches so that beach erosion-whether gradual or
catastrophic-can be prevented.

To that end, we have brought together a team of the Federal Emergency
Management Agency, Federal Highway Administration, U.S. Army Corps of
Engineers and our Congressional delegation to find both short- and long-term
solutions to fix our beaches and to minimize further erosion.

I have full confidence in the team we have assembled to protect Florida's
beaches in their pristine beauty.



Sincerely,



Jeb Bush

Elizabeth E. Hirst
Press Secretary
Office of Governor Jeb Bush

From:	Doster, Brett <brett.doster@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 12, 2001 2:47 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	Dana, Pamella; Shanahan, Kathleen
Subject:	Biotechnology Initiative

Chief,

Just to bring you up to speed on what we are doing to further your interest
in developing a tool to expand the state's biotechnology sector, I have put
together a basic outline of our OTTED strategy.

Bio-Tech Initiative:

I.  Identify key members of the state's existing bio-tech infrastructure.
	(Because it is impossible for me or other state government types to
know the finer points related to biotechnology or the 	economic strategies
that may be in place in other states to help develop the industry, I have
chosen some of Florida's leaders 	in the field to make up an informal
panel for reviewing and suggesting ideas and strategies.)

	The selected members are the following (This list will continue to
be expanded over the next few days to include medical
device manufacturers):

	a.  Scott Adams, Cenetec
	b.  David Day, University of Florida
	c.  John Fraser, Florida State University
	d.  Weaver Gaines, Ixion Biotechnology and Chair of Bio-Florida
	e.  David Gury, Nabi
	f.   Gary Hennen, Oglesby-Plants International
	g.  Albert Kern, Entomos
	h.  Jeff Kline, Accris
	i.   Win Philips, University of Florida
	j.   John Rogers, AquaGene
	k.  Bob Zahradinik, OraGen

II.  Provide a set of principles to help in analyzing possible state
strategies.
	(I will provide each of the informal panelists a list of seven
principles to assist them in "grading" programs that other states 	may
have in place and may be replicated here in Florida.)

III.  Provide a list of programs that have been effective in other states
that have a current biotechnology strategy.
	(That list is made up from a couple of comparative studies that I
have found which outlines what each state is doing as it 	relates to
the field of biotechnology.)

IV. Get feedback in the form of grading sheets on the programs being
utilized in other states.

V.  Group and segregate suggestions that are original ideas and unrelated to
other states' programs.

VI.  Formulate a final strategy for presentation to the Governor with fiscal
impact analysis from OPB.


Chief, this is the outline of the plan that we are pursuing.  Our panel will
all have seen the material that I am mailing to them by Friday of this week.
I have a couple of other ideas.  We have received initial agreement through
David Day at UF to have former Governor Jim Hunt of North Carolina come down
here and have a discussion with us and possibly even you to explain the
steps that they took in North Carolina to make that state a leader in
biotechnology.  That could possibly be a public event.  Also, ITFlorida.Com
and the Florida Research Consortium will be doing the first ever legislative
"Tech Days" in Tallahassee on the tentative dates of January 29th and 30th.
It may very well be a great forum after working through this exercise to
target one of those days to publicly unveil a Bio-Tech Initiative along with
those respective boards.


Brett

A grades

Poverty Rates

0  - 24%		=24%

Sorting by Minority first
Minority Rates
75 and Above	=12%
50 - 74%		=53%
25 - 49		=40%
0 -  24%		=33%

From:	Busse, Mark <mark.busse@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 12, 2001 11:53 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	Shanahan, Kathleen; Jimenez, Frank; Yablonski, Brian; Hirst, Elizabeth; Grant, Wendy; McFadden, Liza
Subject:	RE: And black history's impact on Jeb

Governor --

As you can see from this thread, we are already considering this.  Here's my
idea:

1)  We immediately draft a response to the News-Journal saying we'll do it,
and remind them that this is a *continuation* of our tradition of
celebrating Black History Month.
2)  (Optional)  Send out a press release now, clarifying that we are taking
up the challenge of the News-Journal, not our idea.
3)  Submit the essay to the News-Journal (and statewide) after the New Year
TBA.  (When the kids submit 1/8, when the winners are announced 2/4, maybe
late January to not step on the 2/4 announcement?)

Liz's concerns are as follows (she's not necessarily against it)::
1)  Even though they challenged us, it could still look political.
2)  The Governor gets challenged to do things all the time (FCAT, etc).  Is
this really a precedent we want to set?

It's really your call, Governor.  Kathleen's in favor and Brian has some
ideas (in a different thread) to help me draft the actual essay.  I think
think could be fun and cool.

What do you think?

-- Mark

-----Original Message-----
From: Valerie Adams [mailto:valadams@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Friday, November 30, 2001 10:23 AM
To: Martha Pratt; Martha Pratt
Subject: Gov. Bush denies Brevard & Indian River counties money to
renourish beaches. Fl.Today 11/30/01


2001.11.29 23:20:32

Gov. Bush denies Brevard and Indian River counties money to renourish
beaches

By Linda Jump
FLORIDA TODAY

WABASSO -- Cheryl Gerstner has watched the beach in front of her
Surfside
Terrace home erode 20 feet, threatening to send her home into the
Atlantic
Ocean if more sand is lost. She's hoping Tropical Storm Olga won't take
any
more.

Brevard and Indian River counties officials are watching carefully too,
after learning that any immediate repairs to erosion will be paid either
by
them or private homeowners.

Gov. Jeb Bush determined this week that the $8 to $10 million worth of
damage reported by several East Coast counties after Hurricane Michelle
early this month didn't rise to the level needed to qualify for state or
federal emergency aid.

Indian River County had asked for $1 million in erosion control measures
to
help rebuild its beaches from the hurricane, which never hit land but
whipped up the surf, said Jonathan Gorham, county environmental
engineer.
Brevard asked for even less since previous work to save its shoreline
prevented major damage.

But Gorham said without a disaster declaration, both counties are left
without a lot of options. "It's the individual homeowner's
responsibility to
protect their property," Gorham said.

The state Office of Beaches and Shores on Thursday approved permits for
four
Dubloon Drive families north of the Wabasso Causeway to build sea walls,
and
issued a temporary permit for Surfside Terrace for sandbags and sand
until
more permanent measures can be taken.

Gerstner said that won't solve the problem. She has personally
purchased,
filled, tied and piled more than 1,000 sandbags "only to have them roll
on
the beach like they were styrofoam."

"We just want to solve our own problems with our own money to protect
our
property," Gerstner said.

Gorham said many think only hurricanes cause beach erosion, but often,
the
fall and winter northeasters cause as much, if not more, damage. "So
far, we
really haven't seen any affects from Tropical Storm Olga because the
waves
are nowhere as large as predicted," he said.

Nathan B. McCollum, emergency management coordinator, said Olga isn't
expected to hit land in Indian River County. Nor will it hit Brevard .
But
the swelled waves and eastern winds from the storm still could gouge
dunes,
he said.

Hurricane Michelle, on the other hand, took five to six feet of dune
daily
in some areas of the Indian River County after Nov. 6, Gorham said.





From:	Robert Janauskas <wishfer@worldnet.att.net>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 12, 2001 1:18 PM
To:	Steven A. Geller ; My Florida; Eleanor Sobel 
Cc:	Will S. Kendrick ; Walter G. "Skip" Campbell, Jr.; Ronald A. Silver ; Renier Diaz de la Portilla ; Cliff Stearns; Bob Graham; Karen Thurman; Senator Rod Smith; Senator Richard Mitchell; Senator Anna P. Cowin; Senator James E. "Jim" King, Jr., Majority Leader; Rep. Edward L. "Ed" Jennings; Rep. Carey Baker; Rep. Joe H. Pickens; Rep. Perry C. McGriff; Rep. Hugh H. Gibson; Rep. Dennis K. Baxley; Rep. Nancy Argenziano; Lois J. Frankel ; Locke Burt; Lieutenant Governor Frank Brogan; Kendrick B. Meek; Ken Pruitt ; Jim Sebesta ; Jack Latvala; J. Dudley Goodlette ; Gordon Johnston; Doug Wiles ; Debbie Wasserman Schultz; Buddy Dyer; Daryl L. Jones; City Of Ocala; Larry Cretul; Andy Kesselring; Parnell Townley; Randy Harris; Steve Henning
Subject:	Fw: CS/SB 148: Relating to HOA's/U.S. Flag

Cyber Citizens For Justice Dispatch - Distribute Widely -
http://www.ccfj.net/ 
 
Our Members and Friends attest to the facts: 
 
Dear Senator Steven Geller, Representative Eleanor Sobel, et al.,
 
The Staff Analysis of CS/SB 148: Relating to HOA's/U.S. Flag, indicates, as we've concluded; the primary reason for enacting meaningful reform is precipitated by HOA lawsuits against residents of deed restricted communities for erecting a FLAGPOLE or bracket (in the case of a CONDO unit owner) to display the U.S. Flag. 
 
We don't understand why current bills don't recognize; owners must be permitted to install a portable, removable or telescoping FLAGPOLE, a maximum height which could be twenty (20') feet, in the front, side or rear yard of their property. 
 
Likewise, CONDO unit owners must be permitted to install a bracket to the front of their unit to display the U.S. Flag. 
 
The issue of frivolous lawsuits is not about a '...portable, removable U.S. Flag...' because flags are; portable and removable. The flagpole is the heart and soul of this issue. 
 
In addition, U.S. Code Title 36 Chapter 10 provides the parameters for respectful display of the U.S. Flag and does not include the perogative for display using a pole or bracket. This may change as we continue to advocate for an amendment to the code at the Federal level?
 
In the meantime, the state of Florida can set the trend in the nation to  protect the rights of residents of deed restricted communities by including the provisions requested in any bill enacted during the 2002 Legislative session. 
 
In that vain, here's what others have to say about this issue. 
 
* SEE BELOW * 
 
Thank you for your consideration. We look forward to your reply. 
Sincerely, 
Robert Janauskas 
5395 SW 81st Street
Ocala, FL 34476
Public Relations - CCFJ, Inc., 
http://www.ccfj.net/     
------------------------------------- * SEE BELOW * --------------------------------
From our friend, Stephen: 
 
The good news is that some judge will have to figure out what this bill changes from existing law.
 
Maybe the deletion of the language relating to size, placement, etc. will help and if (the) Senate analysis can be used as evidence, the mention of the Andres case might help.  
 
It could be better. It could be much better. 
 
If people are fighting over flagpoles mention flagpoles and brackets and end the issue.
 
I did like the Constitutional analysis as representing a fair reading of case law. At least they didn't simply conclude it was unconstitutional 
 
....and once enacted, there is a presumption that the legislature only enacts Constitutional laws.  
 
It doesn't mean they are always upheld as Constitutional but one gets a home court advantage once the law is passed.
Stephen

From our member, Willow Vance:
 
Dear Bob:
 
When Uncle Sam asks its citizens to give up their family, career and safety to be shot at or diseased for their fellow country men, everyone shouts about the glory of the flag. 
 
Why has the flag pole that flies it become so unwanted by those who are safe because others like my family and yours were willing to give their life.
 
My husband was buried early in March (at an) AFB Cemetery because of an illness contracted in the South Pacific untreated after World Wat Two...
 
My dearest brother-in-law lies buried in Arlington National Cemetery after 25 years of horror stories on the high seas in the Coast Guard and my sweetest Uncle was blown apart on D Day after he saved several shipmates in the Seabees with a total of 20 more who gave all.
 
I fly every flag from the Union Jack, Don't Tread on Me to Betsy Ross and I dare anyone get between me and my flag collection with all the scars and memories of the price we paid so dear.
 
The style setting empty soul jerks should move on an island where they have to defend themselves from headhunters without our help because they represent everything bad our ancestors ran away from to give birth to America. 
 
God save the USA and God forgive these tyrants! Such selfish ignorance. 
 
Willow Wootten Vance, widow of M/Sgt Rudy L. Vance, USAF, mother of Sgt Rudy L. Vance 11, 101st Airborne, Vietnam and daughter of, US Army Poster Girl, Diane Vance Morrison, who saw duty in coldwar Germany ...on the Russian border and has the arthritis to prove it, no compensation.
 
....covers her medical, teaching (in) the new age war zone schools.
 
We need a new flag for the unAmerican Americans so we know who to pray for...Born in America a long time ago and proud of it!

From:	Stephen Windhaus <steve@windhaus.com>

Subject:	An Afterthought on Education budget

I recently heard a radio report that indicated the revised education budget
still allows pay raises for school principals and assistant principals.
Frankly, if that is true, I am saddened and angry that such a caveat was
allowed. Good, dedicated teachers are just as valuable, if not moreso.
Without teachers there is no need for principals and assistant principals.
Furthermore, I find it repulsive that "all" employees are not included in
these budget cuts.

If the report is true, who was responsible for pushing that particular
clause?

On another note...I continue to be impressed with your brother's agenda with
the terrorists. Undoubtedly, you and your father must be proud. Likewise,
Laura Bush has done an excellent job as First Lady. She exudes an
appropriateness this "old fashioned" voter truly admires. When I look at
your brother's eyes as they gaze on her there is no doubt in my mind she
stayed the course and pulled him back in line when it was necessary. We all
have to grow up at one time or another. My wife can attest to that. I can
see strong similarities between Laura Bush and my wife when it comes to
being a strong woman in the house:)

Steve Windhaus
