-----Original Message-----
From: Jim Williams [mailto:jimwill@bellsouth.net]
Sent: Monday, December 10, 2001 5:24 AM
To: dcifers@floridamagazine.com; jeb@jeb.org; pam.dana@myflorida.com;
Brett.Doster@myflorida.com
Subject: Thank you for trying.........


Thanks to each of you who receive and read this.  We gave it all we had,
but looks like the 9-11 perpetrators have won another one.  I wrote this
letter to George Lane (my friend and mentor in legislative procedure)
this morning and thought each of you had in one way or another been involved
and I wanted you to know what is happening.

Governor Bush, you have a great young bunch of folks around you there
in Tallahassee and they did all they could to help in this trying time.
 Those folks that make up the Federal agencies just don't know or care
what is happening and I hope when you and your staff move to Washington
in 7 more years you will do what you can to unseat all those whose jobs
were protected, but who didn't feel the need to make sure others receive
adequate help.  Never did we ask for handouts; only long term loans to
help stay in business during the recovery.  They mouth good words, just
short on carry through.  Brett Doster sat with some of us from the Orlando
area and listen to people 'mouth' platitudes.  I only hope at least some
of those that attended got more attention and help than our little school.

Thanks again...........

Jim Williams
Captain, Delta Air Lines (Ret.)
Chairman, Airline Training Academy

Addressees:  Gov Bush, Pam Dana, Brett Doster, Doug Cifers

============================================================================
===
=================================

George,

I'm back from the West Coast and am happy to say things went well out
there.  Now it's time to see what I can do about the problems back here.

While I was gone the SBA has for all practical purposes turned down the
loan application (long term/low interest) for the money to replace business
lost as a result of 9-11.  They didn't exactly turn it down but said if
we wanted the paperwork to go any farther in the consideration process,
each of my sons and myself must put our homes up as collateral.  We can't
do that.  If they want personal guarantees that would be different.  You
often have to give those for a loan, but never your house.  We tried to
tell them, 'what would happen if another plane flew into the Sears Tower
in Chicago, and no airline could or would be able to hire new pilots for
several years?'  All of us would not only lose the business, but our homes
as well and that is unsatisfactory.


They say that is the chance you must take if you want the loan.  So, no
loan!  We are willing to put our personal guarantee up but not our homes.

If I had to make a guess, we will now lose the Academy, and as you know
have already lost (through selling to a new owner) Discover Air.  In order
to just meet fixed and certain variable expenses, the academy has to bring
in 20 new students each month.   Thirteen have been enrolled for the
December
class and the rest (29) withdrew before they even arrived (we now have
over a million dollars in revenue withdrawls since 9-11), so that
accelerates
the end of something really quite good.  There will come a time when the
pilot shortage hits that those folks in Federal programs administration
and those folks we elect to public office will regret that they have allowed
a whole industry to flounder.  They think that by throwing a 'little'
money at the major airlines who could afford expensive lobbyists, that
they have done something heroic.  I have one trump card to play and that's
getting airlines that are going to need our services to step up to the
plate and tell the next generation of pilots that there is a future for
them in the airline business.  It may really be too late for Airline
Training
Academy, but maybe some others can get through this period intact.

George, if you have any plans for further involvement with the Academy,
do yourself and us a favor and terminate any time commitment.  There is
not money enough to pay our bills, such as gas, that allow us to continue
to instruct, let alone your invoice which you would have earned by the
end of December.  We have paid you for October and November but will not
be able to pay anything more.  There is not money for salaries for my
sons and so personal savings will get tapped just to make mortgage payments
from here on out.  I don't regret paying you the $5,000 in fees for
services,
I just wish that we had known you at a better time when we would have
benefited more from your association.

George, even though we won't be able to have a professional association,
we are still 'brothers in Christ'.  I wish you and Libby a Holy holiday
season and the very best possible in 2002 as things get better, we hope.
 God bless you and your entire family.

Jim

Brett

=================================

George,

I'm back from the West Coast and am happy to say things went well out
there.  Now it's time to see what I can do about the problems back here.

While I was gone the SBA has for all practical purposes turned down the
loan application (long term/low interest) for the money to replace business
lost as a result of 9-11.  They didn't exactly turn it down but said if
we wanted the paperwork to go any farther in the consideration process,
each of my sons and myself must put our homes up as collateral.  We can't
do that.  If they want personal guarantees that would be different.  You
often have to give those for a loan, but never your house.  We tried to
tell them, 'what would happen if another plane flew into the Sears Tower
in Chicago, and no airline could or would be able to hire new pilots for
several years?'  All of us would not only lose the business, but our homes
as well and that is unsatisfactory.


They say that is the chance you must take if you want the loan.  So, no
loan!  We are willing to put our personal guarantee up but not our homes.

If I had to make a guess, we will now lose the Academy, and as you know
have already lost (through selling to a new owner) Discover Air.  In order
to just meet fixed and certain variable expenses, the academy has to bring
in 20 new students each month.   Thirteen have been enrolled for the
December
class and the rest (29) withdrew before they even arrived (we now have
over a million dollars in revenue withdrawls since 9-11), so that
accelerates
the end of something really quite good.  There will come a time when the
pilot shortage hits that those folks in Federal programs administration
and those folks we elect to public office will regret that they have allowed
a whole industry to flounder.  They think that by throwing a 'little'
money at the major airlines who could afford expensive lobbyists, that
they have done something heroic.  I have one trump card to play and that's
getting airlines that are going to need our services to step up to the
plate and tell the next generation of pilots that there is a future for
them in the airline business.  It may really be too late for Airline
Training
Academy, but maybe some others can get through this period intact.

George, if you have any plans for further involvement with the Academy,
do yourself and us a favor and terminate any time commitment.  There is
not money enough to pay our bills, such as gas, that allow us to continue
to instruct, let alone your invoice which you would have earned by the
end of December.  We have paid you for October and November but will not
be able to pay anything more.  There is not money for salaries for my
sons and so personal savings will get tapped just to make mortgage payments
from here on out.  I don't regret paying you the $5,000 in fees for
services,
I just wish that we had known you at a better time when we would have
benefited more from your association.

George, even though we won't be able to have a professional association,
we are still 'brothers in Christ'.  I wish you and Libby a Holy holiday
season and the very best possible in 2002 as things get better, we hope.
 God bless you and your entire family.

Jim

-----Original Message-----
From: Thomas, Brad [mailto:Brad.Thomas@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US]
Sent: Tuesday, December 11, 2001 3:51 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: County opt-in under Fla. Constitution, Article 8, Section 5 re: gun sales



Governor, 

As you noted, Article 8, Section 5, passed in 1998, allows any county to require a 3-5 day waiting period, and background check, for the sale of any firearm on property with public access, including gun shows.  [Other Florida law under Section 790.065, requires all licensed dealers to utilize background checks throughout the state. 790.0655 requires a 3-day waiting period between the purchase and the delivery at retail of any handgun.] 


We have learned that Broward, Volusia, Orange, Dade [informed by contact person,] Sarasota [informed by contact person,] Palm Beach, and Hillsborough  have opted in under the 1998 amendment that allows requiring waiting periods for gun sales, regardless of the nature or location of the sale. Each county may differ regarding whether they use the 1998 amendment to regulate all firearms or just handguns, whether they require a 3 or 5 day waiting period, etc. Orange and  Volusia limit their ordinances to handguns, even though they could cover all guns.  We are checking on other counties and have an information request into the Association of Counties. 

I don't believe there are lot more than these. One source said there are about seven counties that have opted in.

GOV--below is general outline for pbs program ref rebecca mattingly...with
suggested points from her office. this segement will be taped following your
FACE TO FACE interview on  12-13-01

----------------------------------------------------------------------------
----------------------------------------------------------
The Women in Your Life program, in short...premise is about Women of
influence in our State influencing and mentoring younger up and coming
females. The program series will premiere in November of this year with the
first person being Betty Jane France of NASCAR and The segment on Rebecca is
to air in the second program.

GENERAL QUESTIONS (not exact but these shared) :

Q-why was Rebecca your first choice for Florida's Film Commissioner?

A-RDM had the field experience, a great deal of industry knowledge,
enthusiasm, and the right attitude Florida needed to grow the economic
potetial that this clean industry represents to the State.

Q-what have been the biggest challenges Rebecca was able to overcome?

A- 1) To be seen as a leader and to gain the respect of the stateweide
industry and Florida's 49 film offices.
 
   2) To pull together a badly fragmented industry into a team that works
together to promote the film & entertainment 	   industry in Florida to
the nation & the world with a unified voice. 

   3) To overcome the negative perceptions left over from the misadventures
of the previous film office disbanded by Gov.         	   Chiles.

Q-how has she changed Florida's film industry?

A- Rebecca has channelled her energy, and within a short time ( less than
two years ) Rebecca and her office have pulled together Florida's film &
entertainment industry. The Office of Film & Entertainment is now seen as
the driving force behind Florida's production industry. Passed significant
legislation that now provides an up-front sales tax exemption on production
related expenses (a new incentive for productions to be filmed in Florida
rather than other competing locations), and has represented my office well.
 
Q-What personal and professional characteristics allow her to be such a
strong role model?

A-She has a positive attitude on life and shares this with those she
mentors. She is a leader and takes the time to help others.

Q- General feelings about Rebecca as an individual?

A-I enjoy having her work on my team and she is a brite and capable
employee.

Q- How do you feel about mentoring in general?

A-I believe the Gov. is more than adequate on this subject!  


Robert Grimm



Elizabeth E. Hirst
Press Secretary
Office of Governor Jeb Bush

From:	Bryan Siddell <bfsid@ithink.net>

Subject:	WoW! They printed my letter!

Letters to the Editor 


Wednesday, December 12, 2001 





Be Prepared: Supply And Demand Also Affects Taxes 


I have been reading a lot of comments from citizens of Florida who are disgusted with the cuts in the state budget. The legislation from the second emergency session has produced a bill that slashes another $1.3 billion from the state's budget. These deep throat cuts are aimed at the most needed services in Florida. The elderly, Medicaid and Medicare, child-abuse prevention and family services, safety, and all educational institutions are affected by these cuts. 


When I see these headlines of articles and letters to the editor like "Don't Sacrifice Children, Elders To Balance Budget," I start thinking back to last year's attempts by the Legislature to pass SB 310 and 380. This was a growth management bill coupled with the educational needs of districts in the state, giving taxation abilities to school boards and county commissions instead of voters. By a majority vote of these boards, they would have been able to increase local sales-tax amounts. Also included in the language were ways the school districts could raise local millage rates above the state's maximum allowable rate for capital expenditures. 


But this bill died because of the haggling back and forth over specific language that I can only guess was for more special interests. As I stated last year when SB 310 and 380 weren't passed, the timing wasn't quite right to receive the support of the citizens of Florida for tax increases. But I also said it would be back in the next regular session of the Legislature, and that it would pass with their full support. Now that all these deep throat cuts to the most vital needs in the state have been made, the citizens of Florida will now be more receptive to a tax increase. Just like everything else in the economy . . . to be able to raise the price (taxes), there has to be both a demand and a shortage. We now have both, so be prepared! 


BRYAN SIDDELL
Lakeland

-----Original Message-----
From: Valerie Adams [mailto:valadams@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Friday, November 30, 2001 10:23 AM
To: Martha Pratt; Martha Pratt
Subject: Gov. Bush denies Brevard & Indian River counties money to
renourish beaches. Fl.Today 11/30/01


2001.11.29 23:20:32

Gov. Bush denies Brevard and Indian River counties money to renourish
beaches

By Linda Jump
FLORIDA TODAY

WABASSO -- Cheryl Gerstner has watched the beach in front of her
Surfside
Terrace home erode 20 feet, threatening to send her home into the
Atlantic
Ocean if more sand is lost. She's hoping Tropical Storm Olga won't take
any
more.

Brevard and Indian River counties officials are watching carefully too,
after learning that any immediate repairs to erosion will be paid either
by
them or private homeowners.

Gov. Jeb Bush determined this week that the $8 to $10 million worth of
damage reported by several East Coast counties after Hurricane Michelle
early this month didn't rise to the level needed to qualify for state or
federal emergency aid.

Indian River County had asked for $1 million in erosion control measures
to
help rebuild its beaches from the hurricane, which never hit land but
whipped up the surf, said Jonathan Gorham, county environmental
engineer.
Brevard asked for even less since previous work to save its shoreline
prevented major damage.

But Gorham said without a disaster declaration, both counties are left
without a lot of options. "It's the individual homeowner's
responsibility to
protect their property," Gorham said.

The state Office of Beaches and Shores on Thursday approved permits for
four
Dubloon Drive families north of the Wabasso Causeway to build sea walls,
and
issued a temporary permit for Surfside Terrace for sandbags and sand
until
more permanent measures can be taken.

Gerstner said that won't solve the problem. She has personally
purchased,
filled, tied and piled more than 1,000 sandbags "only to have them roll
on
the beach like they were styrofoam."

"We just want to solve our own problems with our own money to protect
our
property," Gerstner said.

Gorham said many think only hurricanes cause beach erosion, but often,
the
fall and winter northeasters cause as much, if not more, damage. "So
far, we
really haven't seen any affects from Tropical Storm Olga because the
waves
are nowhere as large as predicted," he said.

Nathan B. McCollum, emergency management coordinator, said Olga isn't
expected to hit land in Indian River County. Nor will it hit Brevard .
But
the swelled waves and eastern winds from the storm still could gouge
dunes,
he said.

Hurricane Michelle, on the other hand, took five to six feet of dune
daily
in some areas of the Indian River County after Nov. 6, Gorham said.





From:	tomdandrea06@home.com
Sent:	Wednesday, December 12, 2001 8:45 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Sun Herald Story



12/12/01


Area has stake in board vacancy



Drought and concerns about phosphate mining place added significance on the task of filling a vacant seat on the Peace River Basin Board.


Punta Gorda resident Tom D'Andrea unexpectedly resigned his position on the board recently and care must be taken to appoint someone who not only has knowledge of Southwest Florida's water resources but someone who can commit to standing up for our best interests.


D'Andrea's resignation came shortly after Don Ross -- Charlotte County's second, and only other, delegate -- moved from the county and was forced to step down. Ross was replaced by former Punta Gorda Mayor Rufus Lazell.


The board plays an important role in shaping water-related policy in Southwest Florida. The six-pers! on board is charged with investigating issues regarding water in the five-county basin and recommending solutions and policy to the Southwest Florida Water Management District, also known as SWIFTMUD.


In recent months, sentiments on the board have swung from one extreme to the next as representatives from inland counties sought to protect their water resources from being diverted to fast-growing coastal counties. Board members from Polk and DeSoto counties have also voiced support for phosphate mining -- an industry they are relying on for economic development.


Charlotte County has sometimes stood alone in its battle to force more extensive studies of the effects of phosphate mining on the Peace River, which provides drinking water to Charlotte County, North Port and eventually Sarasota County.


The fact Charlotte County is the lone government with two representatives speaks of its size and the underdog role its board members embrace. Their greatest chal! lenge is to convince representatives of smaller, inland counties to be more proactive in protecting the few water resources we have while planning for alternative sources.


D'Andrea was an outspoken proponent of protecting the Peace River and Horse Creek. His voice on the board will be missed.


The process of nominating a replacement is a wide-open affair. While no names have surfaced publicly, it would benefit all coastal communities if local politicos and Charlotte County officials work together to support a qualified, dedicated nominee.


Even though all Peace River Basin recommendations must be approved by SWIFTMUD, the importance of coming up with fact-based, responsible policies cannot be stressed enough. Charlotte County's next representative will shoulder an important responsibility We must seek out a quality nominee.







 <http://www! .sun-herald.com/mailnews.htm?date=121201&filename=op1.htm> Email this story to a friend or relative

This story appeared in either the Sun Herald, the Venice Gondolier, Waterline or the Weekly Record - all publications of the Sun Coast Media Group.

-----Original Message-----
From: Valerie Adams [mailto:valadams@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Friday, November 30, 2001 10:23 AM
To: Martha Pratt; Martha Pratt
Subject: Gov. Bush denies Brevard & Indian River counties money to
renourish beaches. Fl.Today 11/30/01


2001.11.29 23:20:32

Gov. Bush denies Brevard and Indian River counties money to renourish
beaches

By Linda Jump
FLORIDA TODAY

WABASSO -- Cheryl Gerstner has watched the beach in front of her
Surfside
Terrace home erode 20 feet, threatening to send her home into the
Atlantic
Ocean if more sand is lost. She's hoping Tropical Storm Olga won't take
any
more.

Brevard and Indian River counties officials are watching carefully too,
after learning that any immediate repairs to erosion will be paid either
by
them or private homeowners.

Gov. Jeb Bush determined this week that the $8 to $10 million worth of
damage reported by several East Coast counties after Hurricane Michelle
early this month didn't rise to the level needed to qualify for state or
federal emergency aid.

Indian River County had asked for $1 million in erosion control measures
to
help rebuild its beaches from the hurricane, which never hit land but
whipped up the surf, said Jonathan Gorham, county environmental
engineer.
Brevard asked for even less since previous work to save its shoreline
prevented major damage.

But Gorham said without a disaster declaration, both counties are left
without a lot of options. "It's the individual homeowner's
responsibility to
protect their property," Gorham said.

The state Office of Beaches and Shores on Thursday approved permits for
four
Dubloon Drive families north of the Wabasso Causeway to build sea walls,
and
issued a temporary permit for Surfside Terrace for sandbags and sand
until
more permanent measures can be taken.

Gerstner said that won't solve the problem. She has personally
purchased,
filled, tied and piled more than 1,000 sandbags "only to have them roll
on
the beach like they were styrofoam."

"We just want to solve our own problems with our own money to protect
our
property," Gerstner said.

Gorham said many think only hurricanes cause beach erosion, but often,
the
fall and winter northeasters cause as much, if not more, damage. "So
far, we
really haven't seen any affects from Tropical Storm Olga because the
waves
are nowhere as large as predicted," he said.

Nathan B. McCollum, emergency management coordinator, said Olga isn't
expected to hit land in Indian River County. Nor will it hit Brevard .
But
the swelled waves and eastern winds from the storm still could gouge
dunes,
he said.

Hurricane Michelle, on the other hand, took five to six feet of dune
daily
in some areas of the Indian River County after Nov. 6, Gorham said.

-----Original Message-----
From: Valerie Adams [mailto:valadams@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Friday, November 30, 2001 10:23 AM
To: Martha Pratt; Martha Pratt
Subject: Gov. Bush denies Brevard & Indian River counties money to
renourish beaches. Fl.Today 11/30/01


2001.11.29 23:20:32

Gov. Bush denies Brevard and Indian River counties money to renourish
beaches

By Linda Jump
FLORIDA TODAY

WABASSO -- Cheryl Gerstner has watched the beach in front of her
Surfside
Terrace home erode 20 feet, threatening to send her home into the
Atlantic
Ocean if more sand is lost. She's hoping Tropical Storm Olga won't take
any
more.

Brevard and Indian River counties officials are watching carefully too,
after learning that any immediate repairs to erosion will be paid either
by
them or private homeowners.

Gov. Jeb Bush determined this week that the $8 to $10 million worth of
damage reported by several East Coast counties after Hurricane Michelle
early this month didn't rise to the level needed to qualify for state or
federal emergency aid.

Indian River County had asked for $1 million in erosion control measures
to
help rebuild its beaches from the hurricane, which never hit land but
whipped up the surf, said Jonathan Gorham, county environmental
engineer.
Brevard asked for even less since previous work to save its shoreline
prevented major damage.

But Gorham said without a disaster declaration, both counties are left
without a lot of options. "It's the individual homeowner's
responsibility to
protect their property," Gorham said.

The state Office of Beaches and Shores on Thursday approved permits for
four
Dubloon Drive families north of the Wabasso Causeway to build sea walls,
and
issued a temporary permit for Surfside Terrace for sandbags and sand
until
more permanent measures can be taken.

Gerstner said that won't solve the problem. She has personally
purchased,
filled, tied and piled more than 1,000 sandbags "only to have them roll
on
the beach like they were styrofoam."

"We just want to solve our own problems with our own money to protect
our
property," Gerstner said.

Gorham said many think only hurricanes cause beach erosion, but often,
the
fall and winter northeasters cause as much, if not more, damage. "So
far, we
really haven't seen any affects from Tropical Storm Olga because the
waves
are nowhere as large as predicted," he said.

Nathan B. McCollum, emergency management coordinator, said Olga isn't
expected to hit land in Indian River County. Nor will it hit Brevard .
But
the swelled waves and eastern winds from the storm still could gouge
dunes,
he said.

Hurricane Michelle, on the other hand, took five to six feet of dune
daily
in some areas of the Indian River County after Nov. 6, Gorham said.

-----Original Message-----
From: Thomas, Brad [mailto:Brad.Thomas@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US]
Sent: Tuesday, December 11, 2001 3:51 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: County opt-in under Fla. Constitution, Article 8, Section 5 re: gun sales



Governor, 

As you noted, Article 8, Section 5, passed in 1998, allows any county to require a 3-5 day waiting period, and background check, for the sale of any firearm on property with public access, including gun shows.  [Other Florida law under Section 790.065, requires all licensed dealers to utilize background checks throughout the state. 790.0655 requires a 3-day waiting period between the purchase and the delivery at retail of any handgun.] 


We have learned that Broward, Volusia, Orange, Dade [informed by contact person,] Sarasota [informed by contact person,] Palm Beach, and Hillsborough  have opted in under the 1998 amendment that allows requiring waiting periods for gun sales, regardless of the nature or location of the sale. Each county may differ regarding whether they use the 1998 amendment to regulate all firearms or just handguns, whether they require a 3 or 5 day waiting period, etc. Orange and  Volusia limit their ordinances to handguns, even though they could cover all guns.  We are checking on other counties and have an information request into the Association of Counties. 

I don't believe there are lot more than these. One source said there are about seven counties that have opted in.

-----Original Message-----
From: Tom Jarlock [mailto:Tom@nafi.coxatwork.com]
Sent: Tuesday, December 11, 2001 10:04 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: an e-mail to your real address


I sent this a few weeks ago in response to your announcement about state employees getting an increase.  It was to the "myflorida address" so I don't think you read it.  Here is the text of the message:
 
Dear Governor,

I am in the private sector, providing rehabilitative services for juvenile
offenders.  While I am happy that DJJ workers are getting another COLA
increase I felt that you should know that providers have not had their
per-diem rates adjusted since 1990.  How long can a business maintain
quality service when the revenue streams remain static?

The company I work for operates two programs at the lowest DJJ per diem
available, $75 per day.  Recent studies put the cost of similar providers in
other states much higher.  Juvenile crime is down, recidivism rates are
down, the private providers in our state have served you well.  What will it
take for you to recognize our work and see to it that we can afford quality
staff to do a most difficult task?  Will recidivism have to climb?  Will
juvenile crime have to increase before you spend some time evaluating
revenue streams that are over a decade old?  Sometimes we feel that we are
simply training people in the industry for the Department of Juvenile
Justice because as soon as they have training and some experience, they can
go to DJJ and work for thousands of dollars more.

I don't want to damper your enthusiasm for your state worker's pay increase,
just wanted to let you know that Christmas for the private providers comes
with little consideration from your office or the office of the department.

Sincerely,

Tom Jarlock
Regional Director
North American Family Institute
www.nafi.com

percent,

> increase passed by the Legislature in May for those earning more modest
> salaries.
>
> However, special appreciation must be extended to those forgoing their
> annual pay raise to help balance our state budget.  As you know, a decline
> in state revenues due in large part to the terrorist attacks of September
11
> and the drop in airline travel has necessitated cuts in the current year's
> budget.
>
> Those who join me in making this sacrifice are helping us preserve
essential
> services to our people, while funding our new initiatives in domestic
> security and economic stimulus.  Floridians will be safer, and the coming
> economic recovery will be accelerated for all our people, in part because
of
> this sacrifice.

> following the terrorist attacks of September 11.  It is a great privilege
to

-----Original Message-----
From: Martha Pratt 
Sent: Tuesday, December 11, 2001 9:03 AM
Subject: FW: Caught between the political fires: kids who can't read.
Orlando Sen. 12/11/01




-----Original Message-----
From: Valerie Adams [mailto:valadams@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Monday, December 10, 2001 10:00 PM
To: Martha Pratt; Martha Pratt
Subject: Caught between the political fires: kids who can't read.
Orlando Sen. 12/11/01


Orlando Sentinel
Myriam Marquez

Caught between the political fires: Kids who can't read
Published December 11, 2001

We're going about this the wrong way. Educators pounce on politicians for
sticking their noses into schoolhouse business, promising quick fixes on the
cheap that cost more later. Old GOP hands blast liberal-leaning teacher
unions and stagnant academic bureaucracies for shutting out reform.

Caught between the political fire are thousands of Florida children who keep
flunking reading but get promoted to the next grade anyway. This abomination
has to stop.

Gov. Jeb Bush and the Legislature thought it had. Social promotion surely
leads to dropouts. But school districts use a loophole in the law to keep
passing ill-prepared students so as not to hurt the kiddies' feelings. Or
maybe to not burden already cramped Trailer Towns called schools.

Let's backtrack here. Fourth grade is way too late to correct a situation
that usually starts before kindergarten. Well-to-do parents know this. For
years the upwardly mobile have sought to have their kids outperform others.
They see no shame in holding back their preschooler if he or she isn't quite
ready for kindergarten. That extra year opens up the world to a more mature
and inquisitive child.

The challenge for Florida lawmakers is to fix the law so that
inquisitiveness is not solely a middle-class outcome. Last year three in 10
fourth-graders in public schools failed the Florida Comprehensive Assessment
Test. One in 100 was held back. Same old. Bush calls it a "quiet scandal."
Prefacing: "Sadly, many districts are lacking the courage to hold back
students and remediate."

Bush wants children who have trouble reading to get tutored, attend summer
school. You go, Jeb! But it must begin in pre-kindergarten. Yes, pre-K. That
can't be an afterthought. Yet in tight budget scrapes, school districts
slash summer school first. Pre-K? Not on Jeb's radar in his K-20 reform that
set up a superboard to oversee public schools and universities.

The governor supports school readiness -- it's just not fully funded. Never
has been, even when the Democrats ran things. Yet if we would focus on
preparing each and every child for basic skills in pre-K, taxpayers' money
would be spent more efficiently than having to pay millions more later on
remediation. It's smart business, smart politics. Predictably, the
Legislature's Republican majority resists making pre-K mandatory. Oh, they
throw a little money at the problem, but not enough to help all the ones who
would benefit most.

Overlay the demographics of poverty and single parents' lack of education,
and you'll find the place where many children struggling to read in fourth
grade languish today. Too many live in homes where books are the exception
and television rules.

It's parents' responsibility to prepare their children, but what if mama or
papa won't? Kids don't get to choose their parents. Should the schools, with
society's nod, just pass along the "problem," year after year, point to the
parents and smugly doom those kids to mediocrity?

A democratic society that values equal opportunity must demand that all
children get a good start. It's critical for Orlando to attract high-tech
jobs, too.

Fiscal conservatives must see the economic-development benefits of offering
pre-K to all children. Not just for those kids whose parents can afford
private preschool. But instead of expanding the pre-K program, which serves
a fraction of the kids who need it, Bush & Co. moved that program out of the
public schools. Now day-care centers or others will get some state money for
pre-K, but that "bargain" still leaves most poor kids waiting to get in.

The governor protected education from deeper budget cuts during the latest
belt-tightening. Overall, he has increased education spending during his
term and demanded more accountability. That's to his credit, but unless he
moves decisively on pre-K reform, Jeb's well-meaning Reading by Nine push
won't amount to more than a slogan that pulls at the heart with near-empty
purse strings.

Reach Myriam Marquez at mmarquez@orlandosentinel.com or 407-420-5399.
Copyright  2001, Orlando Sentinel

-----Original Message-----
From: LAUREEN GIORGIO [mailto:laureengiorgio@msn.com]
Sent: Tuesday, December 11, 2001 2:11 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Children's Medical Services Mistreatment of Stormy Burn


December 11, 2001
 
 
Re:  Children's Medical Service
        Client:    Stormy Burn
        Mother:  Katie Burn
                      25231 Mathew Street Christmas, Florida
                      Home Phone 407 568 5463
                      Florida Hospital East 407 303 8110 
                      Room 124
 
Dear Governor;
 
I know how busy you are in these difficult times, and I apologize, in advance, for disturbing you.  But I know you have said many times how concerned you are about kids, especially seriously ill kids. 
 
Stormy Burn is a 13 year old wheelchair bound quadriplegic.  He is now bedridden and in severe pain at Florida Hospital East in Orlando.  You met Stormy last year concerning the Medically Essential Utility Law.  He was in Tallahassee with the other families.
 
Stormy's mother, Katie, pleaded with the Children's Medical Service to put a feeding tube in Stormy because he was not getting enough nourishment by mouth and he was losing weight.  Stormy was down to 61 pounds and his mother was afraid that his bones were going to become brittle, as they often do, with these children.  It took a year, and her having to sit on the floor in the emergency room of the hospital and threaten not to leave until they put the feeding tube in him.  The doctors at C.M.S. finally decided to do so.  By this time, the child's bones have gotten so brittle, that every time they move him they are afraid of breaking his bones.  Are they not suppose to be helping these families?
 
Stormy started to feel pain in his body and a fracture showed up on a scan that was done by an emergency room doctor. A cast was put on, and the doctor told the mother it would have to stay on for about 4 weeks.  When Mrs. Burn went to the Children's Medical Services Doctors at Nemourse Clinic at Arnold Palmer,
she was told he did not need to keep the cast on and they removed it.  They strongly refused to replace the cast.  Dr. Phillips and his associate, Dr. Burnbaum, twisted the childs foot and leg in so many directions that they made him cry and yell.  Stormy has not been the same.  He was sent home in constant pain and was told by Bernice, the Orthopedic Nurse, that they do not address pain management and not to bring him in for pain. He was bedridden and without any medication to help relieve his pain.  His mother and older brother could not turn him or touch him without him crying in pain. They have given him an appointment in January to see an Orthopedic doctor.  This is ridiculous.  Stormy is presently at Florida Hospital East and is on heavy pain medication.  He may have a bone infection, and they have found a fracture in his right ankle.  He may be sent home again without pain medication by Dr. Goetz, another C.M.S practitioner.  Animals are treated better!
 
Stormy's mother and brother have dedicated their lives to Stormy.  Their lives are centered upon him and his needs.  It is very frustrating to them and frightening not to be able to trust the doctors they need to help Stormy.
 
I have had many experiences with the Children's Medical Services  over my 18 years helping these families, and I can tell you these families are not treated justly.  The level of care is substandard, to say the least, with personnel who are nasty and vindictive and doctors who haven't a clue to a child's needs.
 
Stormy needs help and he needs it now.  I know they think his mom is a big mouth.  But when you see your child not getting the treatment needed, and you have to wait a year for treatment, my patience would run out too.  More parents have to speak up and not be afraid of retribution.  
 
I am asking, before something else goes wrong with Stormy Burn, for your assistance in getting this child and other children like him assistance before it is too late.  This child will die if he does not get the proper attention.
 
The Children's Medical Service is another example of a good idea gone bad.  It is a waste of money and energy.  Bernice, the Orthopedic Nurse, needs to find another profession and so do some of the doctors Mrs. Burn has had to deal with.
 
Respectfully,
 
Tony Giorgio, President
Compassion Children's Foundation
 

From:	Jeb Bush
Sent:	Tuesday, December 11, 2001 8:47 PM
To:	'jtdickson@agere.com'
Subject:	FW: Governor Bush letter to Dickson01

 
 
Mr. John Dickson
Chairman & CEO
Agere Systems, Inc.
555 Union Blvd.
Allentown, PA  18109
 
Dear John:
 
It was a pleasure speaking with you regarding Agere Systems and the valued relationship your company maintains with the State of Florida.  The investments Agere has made in business expansions and job creation in Florida has contributed to greatly to our economy.  Equally important has been your companys role as a partner in economic development programsfrom participation in the Florida High Tech Corridor to providing chairs at the University of Central Florida and the University of South Florida.
 
Fully recognizing the difficult times facing your industry, I want to emphasize that Floridas commitment to fostering the growth of technology-based industry clusters remains steadfast.  Florida has partnered with your company in the past, and we are ready to do so again to ensure your continued successparticularly in research and development realms.
 
With a focus on the optoelectronics and photonics, there are particularly unique opportunities for Agere to excel in Florida.  As you may be aware, the University of Central Florida (UCF) is recognized as among the top three schools in the nation (if not world) for optical science and engineering, and its Center for Research and Education in Optics and Lasers (CREOL  www.creol.ucf.edu <http://www.creol.ucf.edu/> ) is in class amongst itself.   Beyond espousing incredible research, UCF and CREOL are producing optoelectronics graduates highly sought in the private sectormany of whom have assumed employment at Agere.  With an obvious shared vision, it would seem very advantageous for UCF to work closely with Agere Sytems to build upon research and development programs that will lead to model innovations.  
 
I have asked John Hitt, UCF President to contact your office to strategize on how UCF and CREOL can best incorporate Agere into its varied research and development programs.   Perhaps this could include relocation of some of Ageres optoelectronics programs presently based in New Jersey.  From both a vantage of academic excellence and financial feasibility, I am confident that Florida could greatly benefit Agere Systems in its continued growth plans.
 
Until then, I wish you all the best and welcome you to contact me whenever I might be of assistance.
 
Sincerely,
 
 
Jeb Bush

You really should pay more attention to these new revenue sources. 

I would be more than happy to speak with you but not your subordinates directly on this. Or perhaps  send you some additional information on the idea of using the Fla sunshine to produce alternative. fuels and electrical power for growth and production of drinking water.

-----Original Message-----
From: Maryann [mailto:mburnham@wackenhut.com]
Sent: Tuesday, December 11, 2001 4:22 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Recommended Veto Items


Dear Governor,

You will recall that I sent an E-mail to you last week urging you to veto
line items 570 and 189B of the Legislative Appropriation Act that resulted
from the most recent Special Legislative Session.  I understand that a
substitute amendment was offered late in the legislative process that may
make the veto of line item 570 no longer necessary.

However, Governor, I would still urge you to veto line item 189B.  I have
enumerated the following points to assist you in your decision making
process:

    The language in the implementing Act, 4C, Section 5 cancels the
existing
procurement for the development and operation of a 600 bed facility for the
treatment of sexually violent predators

    This cancellation limits the ability of your office and the state to
secure the best, most cost effective solution to the housing and treatment
of this growing, dangerous population.

    The issues regarding the procurement or the best approach to dealing
with
the housing and treatment of the population were never debated in
legislative Committee nor were they discussed in Conference.

    The process whereby this occurred does not suggest government in the
sunshine and sends a devastating signal to the Florida business Community
who currently are, or who seek to do business with the State of Florida

    This language effectively makes a decision which does not comport with
the
recommendations of your own Task Force which convened approximately one
year
ago to address the needs of the State in dealing with this dangerous
population.

    In a recent Ft. Lauderdale Sun Sentinel Article it was noted that the
courts have recently released some of these dangerous criminals to the
community because funding was running out and evaluations, therefore, were
not able to be completed in a timely legal manner.  Yet, line item 189B
cuts
$300,000 from the remainder of this years budget.

    This language is totally unnecessary for the Correctional
Privatization
Commission and the Department of Children and Families to proceed to
determine the most cost effective way to deal with this population: In
fact,
it limits those options.

Governor, as the successful bidder on this project, we stand ready to
assist
both agencies in arriving at the most cost effective solution.  We
respectfully request that opportunity and again urge you to veto line items
189B, thus, nullifying its corresponding language in the implementing bill.

Thank you!
George Zoley
Wackenhut Corrections Corporation

According to Dave Pridgeon, Deputy Director for Institutions at DC, the following is the status on Mr. Hathaway. This conflicts with the information below:

*	This individual is in the custody of Escambia county jail as he is a state witness in a criminal case. He has been "out to court" since 12-05-01. It could be he is exchanging testimony for some change in sentence but this is unknown. 

*	He is not scheduled for release until 2014 

*	There have been no reports of use of force on this inmate. 

*	There is no DC medical record indicating liver or any other cancer. 

*	On 5-14-01 a lesion was biopsied from his lip and the reports were clear. 

*	He was scheduled for some follow up medical tests on 11-20-01 but did not fast for them as instructed, so they were not conducted. 

*	When he left for Escambia county he was showing no distress of any kind 

*	It is noted that Mr. Hathaway has a very extensive record including 2 prior prison terms and multiple community supervision sentences. He is 30 years old and has been involved in the adult criminal justice system since 1990. 


As you know, the state would be responsible to treat him for any illness, including cancer. There were no budget cuts to the agency's health care budget. It is unclear whether Mr. Hathaway's fianc, Starla, is inferring that DC officers beat him, other inmates or jail personnel. According to Mr. Pridgeon, there is nothing on the DC record to indicate anything of this nature. With more information we may be able to ask DC to initiate an investigation if warranted. I will gladly speak with Starla to try to get some clarity regarding her concerns if I could receive some way to speak with her. 

Please let me know if I can provide further information or assist in any way. 

JoAnne

Here is another special operations project and request for assistance. (You
met with them.  This is complementary to the Panama City--Center for Coastal
and Maritime Security effort.  Tim Moore, Steve Lauer, and DEP joined me in
a meeting last week w/ group to vett and ensure coordination.  Steve
recommended a meeting with SOCOM Deputy CINC which is scheduled for January.
STRICOM is working closely w/ effort--both developing simulations and
vouching for project on behalf of the Army. STRICOM sent a rep to our
meeting.  The company reps are requesting our support through a letter to
Young and Boyd.

All this special ops training stuff is a bit much to stay on top of...but,
we have a window of opportunity to own the effort.  Good news is that all
the projects and efforts are in sync and working together.  General
Kostelnik would be perfect to pull together all of these efforts on behalf
of the Panhandle.  I have presented the idea to him and asked what it would
take to have him take on.  He could also pursue his dream of bringing R&D
and manufacture of unmanned vehicles (to include subs being developed at NAS
Coastal Systems) in Panhandle.

From: Bruce McCormack [mailto:bruce.mccormack@eer-specialops.com]
Sent: Tuesday, December 11, 2001 9:54 AM
To: marla.gillman@myflorida.com
Cc: 'Brett.Doster@myflorida.com'
Subject: Gulf Maritime Assistance Center(G-MAC)


Marla,
I want to thank Dr, Dana You and Brett for arranging our meeting on this
very important matter.

The total investment expenditure on infrastructure and improvements for
G-MAC not including the Integrated Range Facility is $1.3M.The building on
the Apalachicola Airport is part of the lease arrangement and funding for
the building is arranged by Franklin County. US Special Operations Command
who we are negotiating with will be the ultimate source of funding. There
will be no improvements to the landing strips at Apalachicola Airport they
are in excellent shape. The $4.4M is used for operations and maintenance.
EER Systems will  provide housing and feeding of personnel when deployed to
either Blue or Gold  Forward Operating Base. EER will also provide all
transportation, integrated logistics and security support. The training plan
for G-MAC excluding the Integrated Range Facility is 150 personnel per day.
75 personnel  training in the Apalachicola area and 75 personnel training in
the Liberty County and Calhoun County area. Training will be conducted from
the 3rd Friday in February till Thanksgiving weekend or 40 weeks of training
per year. The down time in  training allows G-MAC  maintenance time and not
interfere with hunting season.

Time line for construction, as soon as we receive a commitment from USSOCOM,
be operational in 5 months. The Environmental Assessment has been completed
and turned into the State of Florida DEP. We are now working with Connie
Krystoff, Environmental Administrator for submerged lands and environmental
resources programs Northwest District. Mrs. Krystoff has asked us for an
environmental management plan that covers the areas that we will be working
in. This plan has been written but not turned into the District for
approval, we are waiting for further commitments from USSOCOM.

EER Systems agreement with USSOCOM is for EER  to lease the properties for a
minimum 20 years the government has no problems with this leasing
arrangement.

Briefings planned for continued support. We would like the State of Florida
to fully endorse the Gulf Maritime Assistance Center in letter  to US
Congressman Bill Young, US Congressman Allen Boyd, State Representative Bev
Kilmer. We will arrange a meeting with SOCOM in January 2002 to help bring
this project to closure.

Enclosed is a presentation we made to the  Apalachee Regional Planning
Council in July.

Marla thank you for your time, and again I want to thank Dr. Dana and Brett
for there time.

Very Respectfully,

Bruce McCormack
EER Systems Special Programs
2111 Suite 11
Thomas Drive, Panama City Beach,Fl. 32407
Ph. (850) 233-8883
bruce.mccormack@eer-specialops.com








Bruce McCormack
EER Systems, Special OPS
850-233-8883 PH
850-233-8813 FX
Special Programs

*	There have been no reports of use of force on this inmate.
*	There is no DC medical record indicating liver or any other cancer.
*	On 5-14-01 a lesion was biopsied from his lip and the reports were clear.
*	He was scheduled for some follow up medical tests on 11-20-01 but did not fast for them as instructed, so they were not conducted.
*	When he left for Escambia county he was showing no distress of any kind
*	It is noted that Mr. Hathaway has a very extensive record including 2 prior prison terms and multiple community supervision sentences. He is 30 years old and has been involved in the adult criminal justice system since 1990.

Presidential Declaration. As discussed in the conference call today,
Linda Heiberger of DCA had previously contacted Andy Gill of USDOL
regarding Disaster Unemployment Assistance (DUA).  

In my  conversation with Andy on today, he could not recall an instance
where DUA had been approved in the past in response to  Red Tide. Andy
specifically mentioned that he worked with North Carolina officials for
over a two-year period with Red Tide and their request was never
approved.  However,  Andy did imply that the situation maybe somewhat
different here in Florida and encouraged us to continue with submitting
the request.  At this point, my assessment is that we will need the
support of your office and the Florida Congressional Delegation to
obtain federal approval for DUA.  We are virgously gathering information
to support the declaration request. However,  I wanted to share the
results of my conversation with Andy prior to the Thursday Town Hall
meeting.

From:	Center for Education Reform <CER@lb.bcentral.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 11, 2001 7:59 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Education Reform Newswire

The latest news in education from The Center for Education Reform, http://www.edreform.com.

CER NEWSWIRE
Vol. 3, No. 48
December 11, 2001
_______________________________________

* SCHOOL CHOICE: Let the debate begin! The U.S. Supreme Court has scheduled oral arguments for February 20, 2002, at 10:00 a.m., to hear Zelman v. Simmons-Harris, also known as the Cleveland school choice case.  The high Court will determine whether the program, currently helping roughly 4,000 Cleveland children escape chronically failing schools through scholarships at participating private schools, can continue.  CER was joined in filing an amicus, or "friend of the Court," brief by 27 other groups, organizations and individuals, representing tens of thousands of interested parents and civic, community and elected leaders.  The brief urges the Court to consider the context in which the program was enacted  25 years of failed education reform and only one of multiple educational options created by the state of Ohio  in determining whether lawmakers acted constitutionally to fulfill their mandate of providing a fair and equitable education to all children.  At least 20 other groups representing a bipartisan convergence of governors, mayors, attorneys general, legislators, scholars and civil liberties groups filed separate briefs in support of the program, as did the U.S. Solicitor General.

To view CER's brief, go to http://www.edreform.com/press/2001/amicus2001.pdf 

* HELPING HANDS: Valley Academy in Phoenix, AZ is a K-12 college-prep charter school in its fifth year of successful operation, with consistent test score increases from year to year.  It is one of the top performing public schools in the state.  Seventh-grader Adam Shali has been nominated for the second time as a "People to People" student ambassador for Summer 2002.  The program, founded in 1963 by Dwight Eisenhower, teaches young people leadership skills, goal setting, planning, teamwork and more.  Adam couldn't afford to attend with his delegation to the U.K. last year.  This year, the Australia trip is also out of reach.  Why is this a reform issue?  Well, in most traditional public schools and districts, money is allocated to assist participation in these programs.  But charter schools are traditionally on tight, if not sub-par, budgets.  If anyone wants to help Adam, email us at cer@edreform.com.

* CHARTERS:  Charter schools in Florida are embracing new accountability that will require schools in operation for at least one year and serving not less than 30 students to be graded based on their FCAT scores.  The move is a result of the path-breaking A+ Plan which since 1999 has been grading schools based on state test scores and allowing children in persistently failing schools to go to a school of their choice.  Charter operators welcomed the move.  Said one colleague, :If I walk into a legislator's office, drop on the desk a list of charter schools and how they are performing compared to other schools, the legislator will be more receptive than if I say, "Trust me.'"  Last year, the Pembroke Pines elementary and middle charter schools were rewarded for their "A" performance with bonuses of nearly $100,000.  They were two of seven charter schools in the state to receive money for high achievement and this was the first year that any charter school has been recognized.  Not only will charters have to test now, but the public will be able to make meaningful judgements about their performance as well.

* URBAN TROUBLES: California officials poised to allow Compton, CA to run its own school affairs again may want to think twice before allowing the district to discover good education on its own.  While the eight-year long state takeover forced debt to be eliminated, the schools are still among the worst in the state.  The benefit of takeovers normally is that the bureaucracy and corruption that pervades many cities is uncovered and at least partially eliminated to allow for the resolution of things like bad plumbing and inadequate textbook supplies.  Unfortunately, such state intervention rarely, if ever, results in educational improvement.  California leaders may want to consider the more dramatic moves being pushed in Philly, or even nearby Chester, PA where the state's intervention resulted in new schools being set up and much-needed choices among at least a small number of children.  Or they could consider the lessons of Florida or Milwaukee, where varied school choice programs rippled throughout the otherwise complacent system and forced a response that while slow, was steady. 

For more, go to: http://www.edreform.com/school_choice/compete.htm

     * UNIONS:  Many local unions are fighting over power and money while all around them, educational problems persist. 

     *In Clark County, NV, the Teamsters and the Nevada State Education Association, an NEA affiliate, are battling it out over who will represent support workers. 

     *Teachers in Middletown, NJ last week went on strike and the Superior Court Judge ordered them back to work.  When they didn't go back, he called each teacher, in alphabetical order, before the bench and told them to go back to work.  If they refused, they were to be sent to jail.  By Thursday night, 228 teachers were jailedabout a quarter of the staff.  The New York Times reported that, "Many of the teachers made impassioned speeches about willingness to suffer the consequences of their defiance, their love of the job and their contempt for Board of Education leaders."  Three teachers resigned or retired in the courtroom rather than face jail time.  The strike ended Friday afternoon, and the two sides are currently entering into negotiations.

     *Worth Repeating: New York Mayor Rudoph Giuliani accused the teachers union of risking grave damage to the city by seeking a 22 percent wage hikedespite the city's budget deficit following the September 11 tragedy.  Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers, responded that the union was making the same demands as before the terrorist attack, and accused Mr. Giuliani of exploiting the tragedy to avoid paying teachers. 

FEDERAL POLICY:  After months of bickering, robust debate and negotiation, a House-Senate conference committee working on the education bill is completing work on an agreement that institutes yearly testing  though what and how is left to the states  some additional flexibility for states (though not as much as many would have liked), and flexibility for teacher quality programs.  Timing for final passage in both the House and the Senate is still being worked out.  

For the latest, go to http://www.edreform.com  

------------
The CER Newswire may be redistributed in its entirety with proper attribution. If you have been forwarded this message from a friend and would like to subscribe to receive future Newswires, you can join at http://www.edreform.com/newswire.htm.

The CER Newswire is published by The Center for Education Reform, the nation's leading authority on school reform. CER is dedicated to making schools better for America's children by improving educational access and excellence for all. CER works with parents, teachers and policymakers to advance meaningful education improvement initiatives.  For more information on CER and education reform, visit our website at http://www.edreform.com.

Kathy, note where they are putting this -- Mike
 

 SEOS Limited has recently won a $1.5m contract with the US Navy to supply
them with an 11     
 foot radius PANORAMA display, for their reconfigurable simulator program at
the Naval Air     
 Warfare Centre, Patuxent River, Maryland. The project will prove to be a
challenge as the     
 simulator is to be installed on the second floor of the building in a room
only slightly      
 larger than the display, and will accommodate six interchangeable cockpits
ranging from       
 helicopter to fast jet.

Delta is considering offer to leave Dade and relocate in Broward (big local
incentives in mix).  Under law, the State can not support such a move
utilizing our incentives.  However, individual county can use their own $$$
to entice.  If Broward is successful, I would think this would cause extreme
inter-county clashes, well beyond the Delta "deal".

As noted, I will talk to both counties tomorrow to see if we can get
resolution.

Hi Pam: 

Just to follow up on some matters and/or issues that we discussed during our meeting: 

1. Both Don and I agree with you that the Southcom issue needs to be a State Issue, not a local issue.  Since we do not have the contacts with these legislators in north Florida, we were hoping that you are making initial contact with them regarding the Resolution as well as the overall Southcom issue. 

2. You were going to get back with us about the Governor's intent for the telephone conference scheduled for Monday at 0930.  We want to be sure to be fully prepared with whatever he wants, needs, expects, etc. 

3.  Stanley Tate met with Karl Rove over the weekend and when Stanley brought the Southcom issue up to him (according to Stanley) Rove knew nothing about the matter. That is somewhat distressing to us. Stanley provided him with the limited information that he had and tried to give him the thumbnail sketch of the issues. 

4. In case you have not seen it, I am faxing to you the Dec 17th Newsweek article and an article from "Inside the Pentagon." It gets real interesting at the bottom of page 3. 

Respectfully, 
Lettie Bien

attack on Judge Moreno's character.

and radio shows to talk about Judge Moreno's ruling. These appearances will
dot the state.

editorial about "contracts." We will have a copy of the oped before it goes

-----Original Message-----
From: Dana, Pamella

-----Original Message-----
From: Mark Kaplan [mailto:Mark.Kaplan@floridahousing.org]
Sent: Tuesday, December 11, 2001 5:40 PM
To: frank.jimenez@myflorida.com; pamella.dana@myflorida.com
Subject: RE: Follow up to Aug. 27th Base Commanders Meeting


Yeah, we've been working on it.

Virginia is the model that was used at the Base Commanders Meeting.  We were
able to get the details of their program.  Unfortunately, the Virginia plan
isn't viable here.  There are too many structural differences in our
organizations and balance sheets to make it work.  (For example, they have
the resources to do a full faith and credit general obligation bond issue.
We don't.)

We're exploring other structural options.  Part of the problem is today's
interest rate environment.  The conventional market is offering very low
mortgage rates right now, and we can't do much better.  Also, the yield
curve is incredibly steep.  That means that we are likely to incur
considerable negative arbitrage expenses on any money that we push out.
This wasn't a problem 18 months ago but is huge right now.

I'm sorry that we don't have any more specifics yet, but this is a hard math
problem.

We're still trying to find the answer.

- Mark

From:	Dana, Pamella <pamella.dana@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 11, 2001 5:59 PM
To:	Oviedo, Nina
Cc:	Kopelousos, Stephanie; Buckey, William; Jeb Bush; Castille, Colleen; Doster, Brett; Moore, James (Tim); Yablonski, Brian; Jimenez, Frank; Shanahan, Kathleen
Subject:	RE: TIME SENSITIVE: Larry Mixon/Center for Coastal and maritime Security

Nina, this is what Colleen and I have been talking about for awhile.  The effort is being headed up by folks at NAS Coastal Systems to utilize unused capacity on base--to include mock-up ships.  Coast Guard (Adm Thad Allen) and Navy leadership both agree Center is best suited in Florida as proposed. However, there is apparently a Virginia legislator who also wants the Center designation and funding.  Some have also mentioned that perhaps a Mississippi Legislator does too.   There is no place in the nation that has the stronghold on this industry.  WE COULD OWN IT!!!  I have a vision.  (Governor/Kathleen, this is effort Gen Kostelnik can lead!)
 
On background, the Center is part of the Panhandle's effort to become Center of Excellence for training Counter-Terrorism/Security/Special Ops.  It is a realistic and very appropriate industry niche for the region.  We should and do want to support.  Aside from companies located in the Panhandle specifically working in this arena--e.g., Intelligence gathering, IT innovations, developing simulations for training, R&D on unmanned vehicles/submarines, there are varied programs either being proposed or already in place to support special ops, counter-terrorism, security training.  Following are a few:
 
Center for Coastal and Maritime Security--being proposed for NAS Coastal Systems in Panama City (In cooperation w/ private sector, Navy would run coastal/maritime counter-terrorism & related security program--for both local and federal law enforcement, coast guard, military, etc.--to train in real-life situations utilizing unused capacity on base (to include resident ships).  They are complimentary to other related training proposed or existing in the Panhandle--and are in discussion w/ them on how to coordinate efforts.  They are complimentary to other related training proposed or existing in the Panhandle.
 
Gulf Assistance Maritime Assistance Center (G-MAC)--Blountstown--Negotiations in final stages-- (Private sector training for special ops--SOCOM, Seals, etc.)  The company is in negotiations with the Dep CINC at SOCOM to bring special operations training to Blountstown Center.  They already have been training BLM law enforcement.  They have acquired a vacant facility--in tact with "kill rooms" and airline storage--for training.  Gov met with team that wants to do.  I brought Commissioner Moore, Steve Lauer, DEP, and others together last week to discuss with the company their plans.   STRICOM has developed significant simulation programs for them and sees this as a big-time
 
Eglin Air Force Base Special Ops Training--Currently Fully Operational--Trains Special Ops in swamps of Eglin.  Army Ranger Training there.
 
Hurlburt AFB--Ft Walton Beach--Air Force Special Operations Headquarters
 
NAS Pensacola--Spacial Orientation Training (underwater special operations training).
 
Sincerely,
 
General Dana

From:	Hirst, Elizabeth <Elizabeth.Hirst@MyFlorida.com>

Mark Hollis, Sun-Sentinel
Governor's remarks to ERC mtg.? Expressed support for the setting of the
phosphorous standard at 10 parts per billion / said the goal is to seek a
consensus among all interested parties as to how progress will be measured /
reiterated his administration's strong support for Everglades restoration,
which it has fully funded...ERC will decide how progress will be measured

Sharon, Daily Business Review
Senator McKay's tax reform proposal? Atthis point the Senator hasn't
released specifics, but the Governro has said that the proposal deserves to
be fairly heardin hte legislative process and should be fully vetted in the
public policy arena

Mark Stricker, Education Week
The Governor has been a strong advocate for charter schools and charter
districts...schools are freed from bureaucratic regulations which allows for
innovated ideas while still holding districts and schools accountable.  The
charter school law was passed prior to the Governor taking office (1995 or
1996).  He did advocate and lobby for its passage as chariman of the
Foundation for Florida's Future.  The charter districts law was passed in
1999 and the Governor was a catalyst

did quick interview with AP radio
reflect on what happened on 9/11...redouble efforts to be kinder...and show
resolve to protect freedoms whether we have family members overseas...or
here at home many things people are doing...important to reflect on what we
are doing 
seen brother grow even more was doing wonderful job as President but seen
grow in my eyes into a giant hard to describe the sense of pride I have as
he has taken on challenge...concerned with what happened to our
country...going to Camp David for holiday joyous time also time for
reflection
proud of state and country coming together showing generosity

how has changed since 9/11? talking to pastor...more generous
unified...rancor of politics hasn't gone away that would be a little bit
dangerous but the personalization of things seems to have subsided...people
are unified and supportive of war effort...difficult times economy in
recession anger and grief...lots of good things going on as well

teachers pension/retirement fund lost money? rebound since 9/11...look at on
long term basis investment strategy is conservative...significant surplus
and will be for years to come...well managed over time...no cause for
concern for 750,000 people in the system

Enron? loss there...Herndon will make recommendation at next SBA mtg. on
what recourse we have...possible we'll sue possible may not...recommendation
on the best recourse...we're waiting on his opinion we'll base that on the
best legal he gets...

Baseball wants to quash the subpoenas? in periled due to baseball
economics...teams are well managed fan support could be improved...state
stands ready to help local communities...legal maneuverings won't change
that fact...need to get act together...other options other than contraction

Enron contribution effect your decision to sue? no we have fiduciary
responsibility...SBA if there was any wrong doing and we have recourse to
get money back we should do it.

resume campaign fundraising? yes...we haven't had since 9/11 only two so
far...we're starting up again...

why now? special and the very special session are over...the other guys
hadn't stopped...if I'm going to run a campaign I need to raise money

doc
Rich Tucker, Florida Times Union, calling to check on the status of his
public records request concerning the use of chemical agents at Santa Rosa
and Washington Correctional Institutions.  Advised him that it should be
ready by the end of the week.

Christine, WINK Ft. Myers, inquired about the Secretary's visit to Hendry
Correctional Institution next week.  Advised her that a definite time has
not been determined and that she will be notified when it has.

Mary Kelly Bridges, Naples Daily News, wanted to know if DOC has sent out
any pink slips or laid off any employees yet.  Advised her the department
has done neither.

Denise Low, crimelibrary.com, a subsidiary of Court TV, called regarding the
1998 death on inmate Robert Lee Bennett Jr. (DC# 522768) at North Florida
Reception Center. We show his death as natural.  Told her for more details
she should contact the medical examiner in Columbia county.  She also asked
about his disciplinary history.  Advised her that it did not appear he was a
disciplinary problem to DOC as he only had 1 disciplinary report on his
record.

Rich Tucker, Florida Times-Union wanting information on new inmate George
Michael Durrance for an interview.  Stated we received him today and he
would not be eligible for an interview until the first of the year.

Dave Carp, St Petersburg Times following up on his request to interview
death row inmate Ruldoph Holton.  Holton had originally denied his interview
request.  Reporter going back and talking to inmate's attorney.

Jim Gilmore, Frontline Productions wanting information on inmate Francisco
Escalona. Advised him to fax a public records request with specific
information for us to review and assemble for him.

WFTV Orlando picked up on the police scanners the arrest of offender Richard
Mitchell at a local Orlando probation office.  They filmed local law
enforcement arresting him.  Note:  Offender was arrested for attempted
murder.  His community supervision did not begin until September. They did
not talk to any probation staff.

Kathleen Hennessey, Mother Jones Investigative Reporting, requesting
information about the chemicals used in lethal injection.  Advised her it is
not public record but the information she is requesting is available from
the Florida Supreme Court.

Deborah Buckholder, Jackson County Newspaper, requesting information about
the possible closing of the Marianna Service Center.  Advised her that we
are working on a plan to transition out of the building in accordance with
budget reductions.

WTVT Orlando, called requesting information on pending DOC budget cuts.
Provided information.

> FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE:	December 11, 2001 	CONTACT:   JoAnn
> Carrin or Adam Shores

> (850) 488-9968

> 
> MICROSOFT SETTLEMENT COULD HELP OFFSET BUDGET REDUCTIONS
> 
> TALLAHASSEE -- As a result of the announcement of impending hearings by
> the U.S. Senate Judiciary Committee regarding the Microsoft antitrust
> lawsuit, Florida Education Commissioner Charlie Crist has recently
> expressed his support for the software company's plan to provide more than
> $1 billion in cash and software to schools. In Florida, 628 schools would
> benefit from the arrangements of the settlement with an estimated 415,517
> students and 24,516 teachers receiving these resources.
> "These resources will be critical for our students, especially when you
> consider the recent budget reductions in education," said Crist. "We fully
> support the Microsoft settlement."
> According to the Associated Press, Microsoft also enjoys the support of
> the National Education Association and the United Negro College Fund. 
> As part of the Department of Justice settlement, Microsoft has developed a
> five-year education program for economically disadvantaged students that
> will provide more than 12,500 schools nationwide with money, computer
> hardware, software, technical assistance and teacher training for over
> 400,000 American teachers.
> 
> - 30 -
>

Subject: Family Cafe

At the past Cafe I heard you speak on the Choice and Control pilot project.  My son Kent Pearson is a participate in this program and I was on the committee to set up the pilot for our District in the Tallahassee area.  I understand this project is to be cut either part or whole in the budget the legislators have given to you for signing.  I urge you to line item veto this.  The nursing agency can not staff our case full time, my wife had to quit work to fill the gaps.  This project has been able to help make up some of this lost income.  We are a family of four living on just 24,000.00 a year.  As a state worker even that is in question.  With the project we have been able to get items my son has needed for years to help him live at home with the family.  I could go on, but I know time is as important to you as it to me. From:	LISA KORIN <liko8@msn.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 11, 2001 5:17 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Haulover Park

Honorable Jeb Bush

Governor, State of Florida

Executive Office of the Governor

The Capitol

Tallahassee, Florida 32399

 

Dear Governor Bush,

 

Recently, the Department of Environmental Protection of the State of Florida denied a permit for the Parks Department to run the Ella Star Casino gambling boat out of Haulover Park.

 

Public records indicate that the County obtained the submerged land by misleading the State about the use of the land, which was not intended for public purposes.

 

With the DEPs recent order, its possible that the County may face legal action from Alpha Hospitality, the company operating the Ella Star for breach of contract.  According to Alphas quarterly reports, the Ella Star has not been profitable since it began operating out of the park, even before the September 11 disaster.  In response to decreased tourist traffic, the Ella Star ceased operations in mid-November.  They may now have a perfect exit strategy, however, evidence exists that they were working in direct cooperation with the Parks Department to deceive the public. Through their mismanagement, the Parks Department and the County have placed an unfair burden on the public with their ridiculous Redevelopment Plan by executing a lease that was illegal.

  

I believe it is in the best interests of the public that further permits for this Redevelopment be suspended or revoked until a full inquiry can be made.  It is becoming increasingly evident that the Parks Department at this point cannot be trusted to pursue what is in the publics best interest.  Your offices continued vigilance and intervention is greatly appreciated.

Sincerely,

 

Jason Kumlien

9064 Collins Avenue

Miami, FL  33154
