From:	Frark@aol.com
Sent:	Tuesday, December 11, 2001 4:57 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	From Frank Messersmith

Dear Gvernor Bush:

As legislator, a taxpayer, and a concerned citizen, I have always done my 
best to support good education and to help as best I can, efforts to improve 
our childrens future through education.

Suffice to say, many children are dropping-out of the public education 
system and complicating their individual lives and the collective lives of 
our society as a whole.

What to do about it?  Well, thousands of our citizens and corporations have 
joined together in the operation of Community in Schools (CIS), one of the 
most successful dropout prevention and mentoring programs in the entire 
country. 

CIS is a program with documented success in keeping kids in school, bettering 
their grades, and providing avenues for good outcomes in young lives. I have 
been constructively critical of our public school system for many years, yet, 
in that same time frame, I have dedicated much time and effort to the 
implementation and expansion of CIS throughout Florida because of the 
positive results and because something has to be done to provide a helping 
hand to many of our young people who dont fit the square pegs and round 
holes of the education system. 

I have been on the Board of Directors of CIS for over 16 years, beginning 
when I was a member of the Legislature, and later serving two terms as the 
State Chairman. I know CIS and I know how it performs. I know the community 
and the business world responds to CIS and its efforts. And I know that 
without CIS we are going to lose a lot of young people.

Last year the State of Florida cut the CIS budget by $2 million, leaving its 
many programs around the state floundering and trying to survive.  The 
Special Session cut an additional $500,000 for the CIS budget item. There is 
no way this incredibly successful program can survive this cut.

Please consider a veto of item 4B in the Special Session budget and at least 
give CIS a chance to hold itself together until efforts can be made to 
restore the needed financial support.

Sincerely,

Frank S. Messersmith
205-9000

From:	George Zoley <gzoley@wackenhut.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 11, 2001 4:46 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Recommended Veto Items

Dear Governor,

You will recall that I sent an E-mail to you last week urging you to veto
line items 570 and 189B of the Legislative Appropriation Act that resulted
from the most recent Special Legislative Session.  I understand that a
substitute amendment was offered late in the legislative process that may
make the veto of line item 570 no longer necessary.

However, Governor, I would still urge you to veto line item 189B.  I have
enumerated the following points to assist you in your decision making
process:

    The language in the implementing Act, 4C, Section 5 cancels the
existing
procurement for the development and operation of a 600 bed facility for the
treatment of sexually violent predators

    This cancellation limits the ability of your office and the state to
secure the best, most cost effective solution to the housing and treatment
of this growing, dangerous population.

    The issues regarding the procurement or the best approach to dealing
with
the housing and treatment of the population were never debated in
legislative Committee nor were they discussed in Conference.

    The process whereby this occurred does not suggest government in the
sunshine and sends a devastating signal to the Florida business Community
who currently are, or who seek to do business with the State of Florida

    This language effectively makes a decision which does not comport with
the
recommendations of your own Task Force which convened approximately one
year
ago to address the needs of the State in dealing with this dangerous
population.

    In a recent Ft. Lauderdale Sun Sentinel Article it was noted that the
courts have recently released some of these dangerous criminals to the
community because funding was running out and evaluations, therefore, were
not able to be completed in a timely legal manner.  Yet, line item 189B
cuts
$300,000 from the remainder of this years budget.

    This language is totally unnecessary for the Correctional
Privatization
Commission and the Department of Children and Families to proceed to
determine the most cost effective way to deal with this population: In
fact,
it limits those options.

Governor, as the successful bidder on this project, we stand ready to
assist
both agencies in arriving at the most cost effective solution.  We
respectfully request that opportunity and again urge you to veto line items
189B, thus, nullifying its corresponding language in the implementing bill.

Thank you!
George Zoley
Wackenhut Corrections Corporation

From:	Thomas, Brad <Brad.Thomas@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 11, 2001 3:51 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	County opt-in under Fla. Constitution, Article 8, Section 5 re: gun sales

Governor, 

As you noted, Article 8, Section 5, passed in 1998, allows any county to require a 3-5 day waiting period, and background check, for the sale of any firearm on property with public access, including gun shows.  [Other Florida law under Section 790.065, requires all licensed dealers to utilize background checks throughout the state. 790.0655 requires a 3-day waiting period between the purchase and the delivery at retail of any handgun.] 


We have learned that Broward, Volusia, Orange, Dade [informed by contact person,] Sarasota [informed by contact person,] Palm Beach, and Hillsborough  have opted in under the 1998 amendment that allows requiring waiting periods for gun sales, regardless of the nature or location of the sale. Each county may differ regarding whether they use the 1998 amendment to regulate all firearms or just handguns, whether they require a 3 or 5 day waiting period, etc. Orange and  Volusia limit their ordinances to handguns, even though they could cover all guns.  We are checking on other counties and have an information request into the Association of Counties. 

I don't believe there are lot more than these. One source said there are about seven counties that have opted in.

My Dear Jeb , 

As the polls show, your economic recovery efforts are falling behind the curve and you have yet to deal with the 2.1 Billion more in cuts that you will be addressing in the next regular legislative session. 

May I suggest that you consider going with the ADM and Democrats plans for Ethanol as a viable economic solution to diversity in the Fla revenue market? 

I previously sent to you and your staff the synfuel developments of an out of state corportation using garbage and plasma conversion to produce syn fuels and destroy toxic waste. 

You really should pay more attention to these new revenue sources. 

I would be more than happy to speak with you but not your subordinates directly on this. Or perhaps  send you some additional information on the idea of using the Fla sunshine to produce alternative. fuels and electrical power for growth and production of drinking water. 

Or you can work on a plan to explain to Fla voters why Fla prisions are being emptied of violent criminals, medicade is being cut back, mentally ill are roaming the streets and the overcrowded and unsafe fire trap state schools rank 50 out of 50 in state funding behind all other states. 

Don't forget the promised statewide water shortages and the high levels of  unemployment and school/ university over crowding current and projected. 

Have a Merry Christmas Jeb

-----Original Message-----
From: BillLongLFD@aol.com [mailto:BillLongLFD@aol.com]
Sent: Wednesday, December 05, 2001 12:03 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Governor


Dear Governor Bush:

       With all that is going on in the Great State of Florida, the Nation, and the World I will try to keep this e-mail brief.  In your speech to the Florida League of Cities Downtown Redevelopment Seminar held in Miami you stated that your e-mail is one of the best ways to get in touch with you.
       As an elected official I know first hand how hard it is to keep track of everything that is going on.  However, when I feel someone is treated improperly I work hard to rectify the situation.  
       You can imagine how hard it is to survive as a small business man these days.  As if the economy were not bad enough, one of your agencies is causing me unnecessary problems.  I submitted an application to the Department of Business and Professional Regulation, Board of Funeral Directors and Embalmers to open a new cinerator (crematory) facility.  In my twenty-one years in this profession I have received one minor complaint which currently pending against me.  The Departments Legal Advisor (Charles Tunnicliff) has specifically stated to my attorney that the staff of the Department is improperly using a statute to deny my final inspection.  I invested $100,000.00 in the construction and equipment for the cinerator facility.  I hired two additional staff members to operate the facility.  When I made application to the Department in May/2001 I was told my inspection would take place in 30 days.  Well, its now December and I have been forced to sell the crematory at a loss, I have suffered tens of thousands of dollars in lost income, and I am being forced to terminate the two employee's.  As if that were not enough, the Department is denying my request to have my $400.00+ application fee refunded.  They have taken no action on my application.  I should at least be entitled to a refund of my application fee.  
       Again, (in summary) I lose a new business venture, I lose tens of thousands of dollars in income, I am adding two more people to the unemployment lines, and I can't even get my lousy 400+ dollars back.  Needless, to say I am appalled at the Departments handling of this matter.
       Governor Bush, I believe you are a sincere, honest man, who cares a lot about all of us.  I support you and all that you have tried to do to downsize and limit government spending.  I have been one of your most outspoken supporters in local and statewide political circles.  Of course having the former Chairwoman of the Brevard Republican Executive Committee as a mother; in her eyes Republicans can do no wrong (especially a Bush)!  Please take this matter under consideration.  I want to continue to be in your corner as we go into this election year.  I need your help!  Persons working for you should promote commerce and the economy not help tear it down.

"God Bless America"

Sincerely,
William Long

City Councilman
Member, IFDF - Political Action Committee
Board Member, Volusia League of Cities




From:	Busse, Mark <mark.busse@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 11, 2001 2:32 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	Shanahan, Kathleen; Hirst, Elizabeth; Manzano, Jesse
Subject:	UF Commencement thoughts

Governor --

Here's an update.

I.  Things I already know about the address:
-- 10-12 minutes
-- President Charles Young will intro you
-- there will be six students (student leader of the year) etc on the dias
with you
-- about 1500 students total will be in attendance

II.  Things I'm getting info on:
-- the breakdown of the 1500 and what schools (Arts & Sciences, Accounting,
etc.) they're getting their degrees from
-- what these six students did to merit recognition (their personal stories)
-- also other grads with personal stories we can use to illustrate our
points

III.  Themes for you to consider (Governor -- please reply so I know which
of these if any I should be developing)

Option A:  September 11th as a catalyst for a renewed sense of purpose
-- for our nation
-- for each of you graduates
-- education expands your abilities, but it cannot give you purpose
-- purpose comes from realizing that you are special, that you have energy
and talent (refined by education) to contribute, that the world can and must
be changed
-- theme to the grads:  you have the potential to be the next Greatest
Generation.  And we need one.

Option B:  Your Personal Vision on a Key Issue
-- this would be a more personal look at one key issue you've addressed
since you took office
-- less why it is important for Florida, and more why it is important to you
-- perhaps how your ideas have changed on it as it's been implemented
-- the theme being for the grads that you have to stick to your vision, be
able to take criticism while also being flexible and taking advantage of new
opportunities
-- policy areas you could address here:  One Florida (I know at UF would be
controversial, all the more reason to do ir), Developmentally Disabled, the
Everglades, A+ Plan

Option C:  Enjoy what you do
-- tell a bunch of stories that illustrate how much fun it is to be
Govenror, to be you
-- to poke fun at yourself and politics in general
-- not an irreverent speech at all but something a little more lighthearted
-- the theme for the graduates would be relish what you do, laugh at
yourself, it can actually help you be more productive by not taking yourself
so seriously
-- if you choose this option, I'll talk to Slater and Chris Clarke and have
them give me the Top Five Funny Governor stories
-- also your thoughts on the more light-hearted moments you've enjoyed as
Governor
-- one story I know about is the story of Shakespeare the bird from last
year's SOS (died recently, did you see the letter), how it caught your eye
on the video and you wanted to find out more about the bird and the couple
(Jerry and Jeanne Price)

Governor, those are three broad themes.  Please let me know which one you'd
like me to pursue or if I should start from scratch with a few more options.

-- Mark

P.S.  Kathleen, any thoughts?
  

Mark Busse
Chief Speechwriter
Office of Governor Jeb Bush

Thank you for this information.
 
Sincerely,
Vincent Collogan
Dunedin, FL
From:	LAUREEN GIORGIO <laureengiorgio@msn.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 11, 2001 2:11 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Children's Medical Services Mistreatment of Stormy Burn

December 11, 2001
 
 
Re:  Children's Medical Service
        Client:    Stormy Burn
        Mother:  Katie Burn
                      25231 Mathew Street Christmas, Florida
                      Home Phone 407 568 5463
                      Florida Hospital East 407 303 8110 
                      Room 124
 
Dear Governor;
 
I know how busy you are in these difficult times, and I apologize, in advance, for disturbing you.  But I know you have said many times how concerned you are about kids, especially seriously ill kids. 
 
Stormy Burn is a 13 year old wheelchair bound quadriplegic.  He is now bedridden and in severe pain at Florida Hospital East in Orlando.  You met Stormy last year concerning the Medically Essential Utility Law.  He was in Tallahassee with the other families.
 
Stormy's mother, Katie, pleaded with the Children's Medical Service to put a feeding tube in Stormy because he was not getting enough nourishment by mouth and he was losing weight.  Stormy was down to 61 pounds and his mother was afraid that his bones were going to become brittle, as they often do, with these children.  It took a year, and her having to sit on the floor in the emergency room of the hospital and threaten not to leave until they put the feeding tube in him.  The doctors at C.M.S. finally decided to do so.  By this time, the child's bones have gotten so brittle, that every time they move him they are afraid of breaking his bones.  Are they not suppose to be helping these families?
 
Stormy started to feel pain in his body and a fracture showed up on a scan that was done by an emergency room doctor. A cast was put on, and the doctor told the mother it would have to stay on for about 4 weeks.  When Mrs. Burn went to the Children's Medical Services Doctors at Nemourse Clinic at Arnold Palmer,
she was told he did not need to keep the cast on and they removed it.  They strongly refused to replace the cast.  Dr. Phillips and his associate, Dr. Burnbaum, twisted the childs foot and leg in so many directions that they made him cry and yell.  Stormy has not been the same.  He was sent home in constant pain and was told by Bernice, the Orthopedic Nurse, that they do not address pain management and not to bring him in for pain. He was bedridden and without any medication to help relieve his pain.  His mother and older brother could not turn him or touch him without him crying in pain. They have given him an appointment in January to see an Orthopedic doctor.  This is ridiculous.  Stormy is presently at Florida Hospital East and is on heavy pain medication.  He may have a bone infection, and they have found a fracture in his right ankle.  He may be sent home again without pain medication by Dr. Goetz, another C.M.S practitioner.  Animals are treated better!
 
Stormy's mother and brother have dedicated their lives to Stormy.  Their lives are centered upon him and his needs.  It is very frustrating to them and frightening not to be able to trust the doctors they need to help Stormy.
 
I have had many experiences with the Children's Medical Services  over my 18 years helping these families, and I can tell you these families are not treated justly.  The level of care is substandard, to say the least, with personnel who are nasty and vindictive and doctors who haven't a clue to a child's needs.
 
Stormy needs help and he needs it now.  I know they think his mom is a big mouth.  But when you see your child not getting the treatment needed, and you have to wait a year for treatment, my patience would run out too.  More parents have to speak up and not be afraid of retribution.  
 
I am asking, before something else goes wrong with Stormy Burn, for your assistance in getting this child and other children like him assistance before it is too late.  This child will die if he does not get the proper attention.
 
The Children's Medical Service is another example of a good idea gone bad.  It is a waste of money and energy.  Bernice, the Orthopedic Nurse, needs to find another profession and so do some of the doctors Mrs. Burn has had to deal with.
 
Respectfully,
 
Tony Giorgio, President
Compassion Children's Foundation

TANF SUPPLEMENTAL GRANTS
 
*         Mr. Chairman, [small talk about just completing FL special session].  I wanted to touch base with you on a couple of issues critical to Florida. 
*         Everyday Florida has new TANF applicants due to our economic slowdown----putting new strains on our programs.
*         We are hopeful, now that the Senate has passed a free standing, one-year extension, that the House will take up the bill under suspension of the rules.
*         Your leadership is critical on this issue.

*         I know that the California Delegation is very interested in this issue as we are.
*         Our UPL dollars are directed to hospitals serving low-income and uninsured populations---safety net hospitals.
*         In this soft economy, I would appreciate any thing you can do to help with a UPL soft landing until January of 2003.

From:	Dana, Pamella <pamella.dana@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 11, 2001 1:15 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	Doster, Brett
Subject:	RE: Thank you for trying.........

Relatively good news on the Jim Williams front.  First, on the SBA loan, he
wasn't exactly denied SBA loan--but he refused to  put up home or business
property as collateral (as required by SBA).  SBA would give him loan IF he
put up property (however, his family opted against). 

Second, Jim is selling Discover Air to Chalks Airline (owned by Onyx
insurance).  Chalks Airline provides amphibious flights to the Keys and
Bahamas and they are purchasing Discover Air so that they can fly regular
flights and land on air strips (rather than land just on water).  Jim and
his sons are swapping Discover Air for a third of the Chalks Airline stock.
And with that stock, Jim will have the opportunity to be the COO and
President of the newly formed company.

-----Original Message-----
From: Jim Williams [mailto:jimwill@bellsouth.net]
Sent: Monday, December 10, 2001 5:24 AM
To: dcifers@floridamagazine.com; Jeb Bush; pam.dana@myflorida.com;
Brett.Doster@myflorida.com
Subject: Thank you for trying.........


Thanks to each of you who receive and read this.  We gave it all we had,
but looks like the 9-11 perpetrators have won another one.  I wrote this
letter to George Lane (my friend and mentor in legislative procedure)
this morning and thought each of you had in one way or another been
involved
and I wanted you to know what is happening.

Governor Bush, you have a great young bunch of folks around you there
in Tallahassee and they did all they could to help in this trying time.
 Those folks that make up the Federal agencies just don't know or care
what is happening and I hope when you and your staff move to Washington
in 7 more years you will do what you can to unseat all those whose jobs
were protected, but who didn't feel the need to make sure others receive
adequate help.  Never did we ask for handouts; only long term loans to
help stay in business during the recovery.  They mouth good words, just
short on carry through.  Brett Doster sat with some of us from the
Orlando
area and listen to people 'mouth' platitudes.  I only hope at least some
of those that attended got more attention and help than our little
school.

Thanks again...........

Jim Williams
Captain, Delta Air Lines (Ret.)
Chairman, Airline Training Academy

Addressees:  Gov Bush, Pam Dana, Brett Doster, Doug Cifers

========================================================================
=======
=================================

George,

I'm back from the West Coast and am happy to say things went well out
there.  Now it's time to see what I can do about the problems back here.

While I was gone the SBA has for all practical purposes turned down the
loan application (long term/low interest) for the money to replace
business
lost as a result of 9-11.  They didn't exactly turn it down but said if
we wanted the paperwork to go any farther in the consideration process,
each of my sons and myself must put our homes up as collateral.  We
can't
do that.  If they want personal guarantees that would be different.  You
often have to give those for a loan, but never your house.  We tried to
tell them, 'what would happen if another plane flew into the Sears Tower
in Chicago, and no airline could or would be able to hire new pilots for
several years?'  All of us would not only lose the business, but our
homes
as well and that is unsatisfactory.


They say that is the chance you must take if you want the loan.  So, no
loan!  We are willing to put our personal guarantee up but not our
homes.

If I had to make a guess, we will now lose the Academy, and as you know
have already lost (through selling to a new owner) Discover Air.  In
order
to just meet fixed and certain variable expenses, the academy has to
bring
in 20 new students each month.   Thirteen have been enrolled for the
December
class and the rest (29) withdrew before they even arrived (we now have
over a million dollars in revenue withdrawls since 9-11), so that
accelerates
the end of something really quite good.  There will come a time when the
pilot shortage hits that those folks in Federal programs administration
and those folks we elect to public office will regret that they have
allowed
a whole industry to flounder.  They think that by throwing a 'little'
money at the major airlines who could afford expensive lobbyists, that
they have done something heroic.  I have one trump card to play and
that's
getting airlines that are going to need our services to step up to the
plate and tell the next generation of pilots that there is a future for
them in the airline business.  It may really be too late for Airline
Training
Academy, but maybe some others can get through this period intact.

George, if you have any plans for further involvement with the Academy,
do yourself and us a favor and terminate any time commitment.  There is
not money enough to pay our bills, such as gas, that allow us to
continue
to instruct, let alone your invoice which you would have earned by the
end of December.  We have paid you for October and November but will not
be able to pay anything more.  There is not money for salaries for my
sons and so personal savings will get tapped just to make mortgage
payments
from here on out.  I don't regret paying you the $5,000 in fees for
services,
I just wish that we had known you at a better time when we would have
benefited more from your association.

George, even though we won't be able to have a professional association,
we are still 'brothers in Christ'.  I wish you and Libby a Holy holiday
season and the very best possible in 2002 as things get better, we hope.
 God bless you and your entire family.

Jim

 -----Original Message-----
From: Dana, Pamella 
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 1:12 PM
To: Hampton, Betty
Subject: Governor Bush letter to Dickson01


Mr. John Dickson
Chairman & CEO
Agere Systems, Inc.
555 Union Blvd.
Allentown, PA  18109
 
Dear John:
 
It was a pleasure speaking with you regarding Agere Systems and the valued relationship your company maintains with the State of Florida.  The investments Agere has made in business expansions and job creation in Florida has contributed to greatly to our economy.  Equally important has been your companys role as a partner in economic development programsfrom participation in the Florida High Tech Corridor to providing chairs at the University of Central Florida and the University of South Florida.
 
Fully recognizing the difficult times facing your industry, I want to emphasize that Floridas commitment to fostering the growth of technology-based industry clusters remains steadfast.  Florida has partnered with your company in the past, and we are ready to do so again to ensure your continued successparticularly in research and development realms.
 
With a focus on the optoelectronics and photonics, there are particularly unique opportunities for Agere to excel in Florida.  As you may be aware, the University of Central Florida (UCF) is recognized as among the top three schools in the nation (if not world) for optical science and engineering, and its Center for Research and Education in Optics and Lasers (CREOL  www.creol.ucf.edu <http://www.creol.ucf.edu/> ) is in class amongst itself.   Beyond espousing incredible research, UCF and CREOL are producing optoelectronics graduates highly sought in the private sectormany of whom have assumed employment at Agere.  With an obvious shared vision, it would seem very advantageous for UCF to work closely with Agere Sytems to build upon research and development programs that will lead to model innovations.  
 
I have asked John Hitt, UCF President to contact your office to strategize on how UCF and CREOL can best incorporate Agere into its varied research and development programs.   Perhaps this could include relocation of some of Ageres optoelectronics programs presently based in New Jersey.  From both a vantage of academic excellence and financial feasibility, I am confident that Florida could greatly benefit Agere Systems in its continued growth plans.
 
Until then, I wish you all the best and welcome you to contact me whenever I might be of assistance.
 
Sincerely,
 
 
Jeb Bush
 
From:	GANOR@aol.com
Sent:	Tuesday, December 11, 2001 12:14 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Budget Cuts

Dear Governor Bush, 

The Special Session Budget being presented to you includeds Senate and House recommendations to reduce Communities In Schools (CIS) funding by another 50% of the promised allocation for this year.  This is  disproportionate cut for CIS.  We lost 2/3 of our funding this year and while most child services organizations received cuts that were significantly less than ours-many cuts came from increases granted in last year's session.  Programs in Miami are in jeopardy.  Our students are greatly in need of psychological services that, at best, are difficult to secure.  If we should lose the people who seek services for students they will suffer great emotional harm.  Our students are already hurting emotionally from home problems they cannot overcome by themselves.  If you could only see the look of relief on students faces after they receive professional counseling at school or hear comments from students who have the chance to be heard by a trained Listener you would understand the need for services provided by CIS.  As we try to prepare students for the "real world" of work and challenges of overcoming daily obstacles we cannot overlook the fact that they need social and emotional help to keep them in school.  One of our students lost her mother last week and is taking care of her blind father.  Another student lost both parents last year when his father killed his mother and then himself.  Another student has been abandoned by his parents, his guardian lives in Georgia, and he is living with a cousin in south Miami-Dade County.These students need the small class size, caring individuals in their lives, emotional support, counseling, focus on careers, mentoring and tutoring that CIS offers.  We are the family our students don't have.  Please veto budget line item 4. 

Sincerely, 

Gail Gelvan 
Resource Coordinator 
Communities In Schools of Miami, Inc.

Subject:	CS/SB 148: Relating to HOA's/U.S. Flag

Cyber Citizens For Justice Dispatch - Distribute Widely -
http://www.ccfj.net/ 
 
Dear members and friends, 
 
A markedly different bill filed by Senator Steven Geller has emerged from committee hearings in Tallahassee and appears headed for enactment once the companion bill Hb 177 filed by Rep. Sobel is considered prior to and/or during the upcoming 2002 Legislative session. 
 
* SEE BELOW * 
 
Regardless, the amended bill seems to casts doubt on the ability of residents of deed restricted communities to install a FLAGPOLE in their front, side or rear yard or a bracket on the front of their condominium without a fight from the community HOA. 
 
Neither of these perogatives were included when the bill was heard and approved unanimously in committee. Possibly, it isn't necessary? Review and decide for yourselves. 
 
NOTE: While the bill can be retrieved in .html or .pdf format, Adobe Acrobat software is required to read the analysis. In time, both will be available for review at our Web site. 
 
Your comments and suggestions are appreciated. Thank you.  
 
The best to you and yours, 
Robert Janauskas 
5395 SW 81st Street
Ocala, FL 
Public Relations - CCFJ, Inc., 
http://www.ccfj.net/ 
----------------------------------- * SEE BELOW * ------------------------------

-----Original Message-----
From: Van Deman, Scott 
Sent: Friday, December 07, 2001 3:29 PM
To: Griffin, David
Cc: Adams, Ruth
Subject: Hot Vacation Deals/flalottery.com link exchange
 
Secretary Griffin,
 
Good morning.  I have great news about the Florida Hot Vacation Deals/flalottery.com link exchange program I want to share with you.
 
Just as a reminder, from 11/1/01, the first day of our link exchange program, through 11/8/01, flalottery.com sent an average of 155 visitors a day to the Hot Vacation Deals web site, for a total of approximately 1,240 visitors during that time period.
 
This morning, Chris Gasparro, of Miles Media, provided me with some updated figures on how much traffic flalottery.com has referred to the Hot Vacation Deals web site.  The news is very good!
 
Here are the details:
 
*	From 11/9/01 through 12/6/01, flalottery.com has sent a total of 4,162 visitors to the Hot Vacation Deals web site.
*	From 11/9/01 through 12/6/01, flalottery.com is sending a daily average of 148 visitors to the Hot Vacation Deals web site.
*	Our highest daily total referrals occurred 11/25/01, when flalottery.com sent Hot Vacation Deals 243 visitors
*	Our lowest daily total referrals occurred on 11/27/01 (the Tuesday after Thanksgiving), when flalottery.com sent Hot Vacation Deals 94 visitors.  This low figure seems to be an anomaly.  I can provide you with detailed daily figures if it would be helpful.
*	So far during December (12/1/01  12/6/01), flalottery.com is sending a daily average of 153 visitors to the Hot Vacation Deals web site.  Please note that this average is remaining relatively constant more than a full month into the link exchange program.
*	As of 8:30 a.m. this morning, 12/7/01, we have sent 15 visitors to the Hot Vacation Deals web site.
 
Other items of interest:  Since we have activated the short button banner on the main page, and added the FLA-USA links to all of our pages, the FLA-USA web site has leapfrogged flalottery.com in the Google search engine rankings for the general search term: florida.  Currently FLA-USA ranks fourth and flalottery.com ranks sixth (before the link exchange, it was the other way around).  Since the Google ranking algorithm considers links to a web site to be a major factor in relevancy, our numerous links to FLA-USA could be a major factor in their improved ranking.
 
In addition, I believe it is significant that the traffic we are sending to the Hot Vacation Deals web site is targeted traffic.  In other words, people arent just surfing on in, but rather are clicking the Hot Vacation Deals link specifically because they are interested in visiting Florida.
 
Please let me know if you have any questions or if I can provide further information or assistance.
 
Scott

Subject: September 11th Remembrance Ceremony
Importance: High


On December 11th  the three-month anniversary of the September 11th attacks  President George W. Bush is asking states to hold remembrance events and to play the national anthem at the exact moment the first airplane struck the World Trade Center in New York (8:46 a.m. EST).
 
Lt. Governor Brogan and I welcome you to come down to the Capitol Courtyard tomorrow, December 11th, at 8:30 a.m. to participate in Floridas remembrance ceremony.  Supervisors should make every effort to accommodate their employees' desire to attend this service.
 
God Bless America.
 
Jeb Bush
 
 
From:	Tom Jarlock <Tom@nafi.coxatwork.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 11, 2001 10:04 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	an e-mail to your real address

I sent this a few weeks ago in response to your announcement about state employees getting an increase.  It was to the "myflorida address" so I don't think you read it.  Here is the text of the message:
 
Dear Governor,

I am in the private sector, providing rehabilitative services for juvenile
offenders.  While I am happy that DJJ workers are getting another COLA
increase I felt that you should know that providers have not had their
per-diem rates adjusted since 1990.  How long can a business maintain
quality service when the revenue streams remain static?

The company I work for operates two programs at the lowest DJJ per diem
available, $75 per day.  Recent studies put the cost of similar providers in
other states much higher.  Juvenile crime is down, recidivism rates are
down, the private providers in our state have served you well.  What will it
take for you to recognize our work and see to it that we can afford quality
staff to do a most difficult task?  Will recidivism have to climb?  Will
juvenile crime have to increase before you spend some time evaluating
revenue streams that are over a decade old?  Sometimes we feel that we are
simply training people in the industry for the Department of Juvenile
Justice because as soon as they have training and some experience, they can
go to DJJ and work for thousands of dollars more.

I don't want to damper your enthusiasm for your state worker's pay increase,
just wanted to let you know that Christmas for the private providers comes
with little consideration from your office or the office of the department.

Sincerely,

Tom Jarlock
Regional Director
North American Family Institute
www.nafi.com
----- Original Message -----
From: <Jeb.Bush@myflorida.com>
Sent: Friday, November 30, 2001 9:09 AM
Subject: Pay Increase


> November 30, 2001
>
> To All State Employees:
>
> I am pleased to report that all eligible non-temporary state employees
> earning $90,000 a year or less have received a pay increase of 2.5
percent,
> effective November 1, 2001.  I believe it's important to preserve the pay
> increase passed by the Legislature in May for those earning more modest
> salaries.
>
> However, special appreciation must be extended to those forgoing their
> annual pay raise to help balance our state budget.  As you know, a decline
> in state revenues due in large part to the terrorist attacks of September
11
> and the drop in airline travel has necessitated cuts in the current year's
> budget.
>
> Those who join me in making this sacrifice are helping us preserve
essential
> services to our people, while funding our new initiatives in domestic
> security and economic stimulus.  Floridians will be safer, and the coming
> economic recovery will be accelerated for all our people, in part because
of
> this sacrifice.
>
> I hope every state employee shares with me a renewed sense of purpose
> following the terrorist attacks of September 11.  It is a great privilege
to
> serve the people of the Sunshine State, and an even greater privilege to
> serve during times that challenge us.  Your hard work and dedication is
> valued.
>
> Sincerely,
> Jeb Bush
>

-----Original Message-----
From: Valerie Adams [mailto:valadams@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Tuesday, December 11, 2001 8:48 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Fast-track teacher training gets new looks. (Georgia)


Tuesday, December 11, 2001
Fast-track teacher training gets new look

By Doug Gross
Times-Union staff writer

ATLANTA-- Georgia's education colleges are giving folks who have lost
their
jobs in the post-Sept. 11 economic slump a chance to rebound -- in the
state's classrooms.

Fifteen Georgia universities announced yesterday a fast-track teacher
training program that will begin this summer and let graduates start
work in
short-handed classrooms across the state in the fall.

Georgia Responds, a revamped version of the state's current alternative
teacher program, is geared to attract college-educated professionals who
may
have been laid off or unable to find other work as the national economy
slides.

"The philosophy is, if you've ever wanted to get into teaching, and fate
has
dealt you a curveball, take another look at it," said Drew Albritton,
executive director of the Georgia Association of Educators, which
opposed
the state's earlier fast-track plan but favors this one.

Paul Beare, dean of the college of education at Armstrong Atlantic State
University in Savannah, said ideas for the statewide plan were developed
during a meeting when university leaders were looking for ways to
respond to
September's terrorist attacks and their aftermath.

"[Now] we're kind of downplaying Sept. 11 because [university officials]
didn't want to make it look like we were piggybacking on that," Beare
said.
"But it was so heartwarming to be able to do something for some of these
people who have lost their jobs."

The program is set to start in June at 15 campuses. Enrollees will get
teacher training throughout the summer.

Albritton's group, which represents nearly 40,000 teachers throughout
the
state, loudly opposed Georgia's current Teacher Alternative Preparation
Program (TAPP), which puts teachers through an intensive course that
lasts
roughly four weeks. A spokesman called teachers churned out by the
program
"four-week wonders," saying the program doesn't prepare them for the
realities of the classroom.

But Albritton said the Georgia Responds program will include more
training
on teaching techniques and other classroom skills, and provide full-time
mentors to help the new teachers adjust.

"The sad part is we could have done it right the first time," he said.
"Since we didn't, I'm glad the deans have taken the initiative."

Beare said he expects his school's version of the program to be almost
twice
as popular as TAPP. Armstrong Atlantic graduated 82 students from the
program this year and expects to enroll about 150 for Georgia Responds.

Statewide, more than 4,000 people applied for TAPP, which began in the
summer. About 750 of them were in classrooms at the beginning of this
school
year.

The Georgia Department of Education estimates there were 900 teaching
jobs
vacant when school started in the fall.
Georgia Responds
Here are the colleges of education that plan to take part in the teacher
training program called Georgia Responds.

Albany State University

Armstrong Atlantic State University

Augusta State University

Clayton College & State University

Columbus State University

Fort Valley State University

Georgia College & State University

Georgia Southern University

Georgia Southwestern State University

Georgia State University

Kennesaw State University

North Georgia College & State University

State University of West Georgia

University of Georgia

Valdosta State University

group on this if one has not yet been formed.  

John

From:	Cisputnam@aol.com
Sent:	Tuesday, December 11, 2001 9:32 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Communities In Schools

This e-mail is to ask you to veto budget line item 4 which reflects a reduction in Communities In Schools' budget to $500,000.  As you know Communities In Schools (CIS)  is a stay in school program which provides the five basics a child needs to grow up to be a productive citizen:  a one-on-one relationships with a caring adult, a safe place to learn and grow, a healthy start, a marketable skill upon graduation, and a chance to give back to peers and community.  In many instances, CIS provides one or more of these basics which would otherwise not be available to the child.  In a small rural community like Putnam County, CIS is critical to insure that our children grow up to be educated, healthy adults.  In this county alone, CIS  has the Americorps PutnamWRITES! and PutnamREADS! program which places 36 Members in the elementary schools to provide one on one tutorial assistance to at risk children.  Without funding, these 36 members could disappear - resulting in additional hardship to an already "stressed" school district.    Also, CIS has several mentoring initatives:  A Boy's to Men Connection which pairs young middle school  males with positive male role models as their mentors, an EnvironMentor program which partners science and environmental professionals with students in grades 5-8 to explore career opportunities and Florida's environment, and several other mentoring programs that are in the develpmental stages.  CIS of Putnam believes "a one on one relationship with a caring adult" is fundamental to the success of young people.  Our board is committed to establishing a wide variety of mentoring programs which address the community's resources and the needs of our children.  If CIS is not funded, these programs will likely end.  So much progress is being made to stop now.   

Please consider a veto of this item.  Spending dollars "up front" in our youth will certainly save dollars down the road. 

Sandra Hartley 
Executive Director 
CIS of Putnam County, Inc. 
From:	Pat Maier <mvtinc@gtcom.net>

Subject:	Carrabelle Consumers

I haven't "bothered" you much lately because I know that you and your
brother have been extremely busy. However, the fire that leveled the IGA in
Carrabelle has caused a difficulty I never expected. The prices at the
convenience stores/gas stations for bread, milk, etc. rose on the very SAME
day of the fire. (Two of these stations were fined after Sept. 11 for
raising gas prices also!) I don't mind...we can drive elsewhere, but there
are a lot of older people in town who don't have that option and could only
get to the IGA by using a golf cart or walking. Is there someone from your
consumer affairs dept. that could look into this for those poor souls?

Thanks, Pat

From:	Flack, Christopher <Christopher.Flack@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 11, 2001 9:12 AM
To:	Jeb Bush; Arduin, Donna
Cc:	Saliba, Lisa; Sauls, Cynthia



Governor, Donna asked that I follow up from Saturday's morning briefing regarding vetoes for the special session.  Our unit raised a question over the increase in funding for Farm Share.  Farm Share is separate from the individual food banks which we have not funded.  Farm Share had been receiving $400,000 in recurring GR for the last few years, during the special session, this money was cut and was replaced with $900,000 non-recurring GR.  It is my understanding that Senator Jones pushed for the increased appropriation.  The reason we raised the question is that we believe there may not be the need for this increase.  During last session it was brought to our attention that Farm Share and Patricia Robbins (Executive Director) had been contracting with her son ($100,000 annually) to provide computer assistance to the administration of the program.  After this was discovered I had several conversations with Terry Rhodes and the Dept. of Agriculture and they have since put language into the contract with Farm Share that all monies from the state must be used for the delivery of food.  In addition, it was reported over the summer by the Miami Herald that Farm Share was making a bid to purchase a 1/2 acre lot in Miami for $1 million to establish an Agricultural Museum.  According to DACS there is no need for an Ag Museum and they have a hard enough time keeping open the one Ag Museum currently in existence.  According to my information this is possible because of the sponsors and supporters of Farm Share as well as the investment practices of the non-profit company.  Currently Farm Share has received money from the state as well as 2 full time positions funded by the Dept. of Agriculture for the administration of the program.  In addition DACS provides them space to operate.

Taking all of this into consideration, it was questioned whether or not they needed additional funding.  There would really be 3 options for this issue:

1.  Let the funding go, since it is not recurring, they would be back at the table next session fighting for funding with everyone else.  This would put them on the same level as federal programs (Women, Infant and Children (WIC), Farmer's Market Nutrition Program) which Ag has to come to the table for every year for matching funding.

2.  Veto the funding which would allow them to keep the $400,000 in recurring GR. 
3.  Let the funding go and in the Executive Budget, and eliminate the positions funded by DACS that support the program if they are going to continue to receive such a large appropriation.

-----Original Message-----
From: Valerie Adams [mailto:valadams@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Tuesday, December 11, 2001 8:48 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Fast-track teacher training gets new looks. (Georgia)


Tuesday, December 11, 2001
Fast-track teacher training gets new look

By Doug Gross
Times-Union staff writer

ATLANTA-- Georgia's education colleges are giving folks who have lost
their
jobs in the post-Sept. 11 economic slump a chance to rebound -- in the
state's classrooms.

Fifteen Georgia universities announced yesterday a fast-track teacher
training program that will begin this summer and let graduates start
work in
short-handed classrooms across the state in the fall.

Georgia Responds, a revamped version of the state's current alternative
teacher program, is geared to attract college-educated professionals who
may
have been laid off or unable to find other work as the national economy
slides.

"The philosophy is, if you've ever wanted to get into teaching, and fate
has
dealt you a curveball, take another look at it," said Drew Albritton,
executive director of the Georgia Association of Educators, which
opposed
the state's earlier fast-track plan but favors this one.

Paul Beare, dean of the college of education at Armstrong Atlantic State
University in Savannah, said ideas for the statewide plan were developed
during a meeting when university leaders were looking for ways to
respond to
September's terrorist attacks and their aftermath.

"[Now] we're kind of downplaying Sept. 11 because [university officials]
didn't want to make it look like we were piggybacking on that," Beare
said.
"But it was so heartwarming to be able to do something for some of these
people who have lost their jobs."

The program is set to start in June at 15 campuses. Enrollees will get
teacher training throughout the summer.

Albritton's group, which represents nearly 40,000 teachers throughout
the
state, loudly opposed Georgia's current Teacher Alternative Preparation
Program (TAPP), which puts teachers through an intensive course that
lasts
roughly four weeks. A spokesman called teachers churned out by the
program
"four-week wonders," saying the program doesn't prepare them for the
realities of the classroom.

But Albritton said the Georgia Responds program will include more
training
on teaching techniques and other classroom skills, and provide full-time
mentors to help the new teachers adjust.

"The sad part is we could have done it right the first time," he said.
"Since we didn't, I'm glad the deans have taken the initiative."

Beare said he expects his school's version of the program to be almost
twice
as popular as TAPP. Armstrong Atlantic graduated 82 students from the
program this year and expects to enroll about 150 for Georgia Responds.

Statewide, more than 4,000 people applied for TAPP, which began in the
summer. About 750 of them were in classrooms at the beginning of this
school
year.

The Georgia Department of Education estimates there were 900 teaching
jobs
vacant when school started in the fall.
Georgia Responds
Here are the colleges of education that plan to take part in the teacher
training program called Georgia Responds.

Albany State University

Armstrong Atlantic State University

Augusta State University

Clayton College & State University

Columbus State University

Fort Valley State University

Georgia College & State University

Georgia Southern University

Georgia Southwestern State University

Georgia State University

Kennesaw State University

North Georgia College & State University

State University of West Georgia

University of Georgia

Valdosta State University



From:	BertrandRand@aol.com
Sent:	Tuesday, December 11, 2001 8:33 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Concerns regarding Treatment for Florida

Dear Sir:

We have spent many years in the State of Florida trying to build programming
to a level that inmates are able to be rehabilitated, and this hard work by
the State and providers has begun to pay off as proven by the decrease in
crime and drug use.  This is part of your legislative agenda, to reduce drug
use by 50% in the State of Florida.  

How can the State of Florida have money set aside for Faith Based programming
when you are cutting the current programs provided for Department of
Corrections Institutions?  Faith Based programming is a good concept without
the legalities worked out.  Any treatment programming must be licensed by
Department of Children and Families.  This licensing requires qualified
and/or certified professionals.  Most Chaplins do not have these kind of
credentials.  It doesn't make good business to not find the matching funds
necessary to continue your grant funded programming.  Finding $500,000 to
save $2.5m should be a priority of the State.

Please try to identify the funds necessary to continue needed services in our
prison system.  It is in the State's best interest to move the $5m set-aside
for faith based programming to existing programs.  Many families are
dependent upon employment in this field.  Don't cut jobs that are already in
place.

Sincerely,

Bertrand Randolph
Associate Director
The Unlimited Path of Central Florida
P.O. Box 206
Panama City, FL 32402

From: Wm. D. Walker [mailto:redhawk103@home.com]
Sent: Monday, December 10, 2001 11:46 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Matter of Choice Pilot Project


Good Morning Gov. Bush,
 
 Sir I have heard that you are suppose to make a decision today on whether or not to cut the 3 pilot projects because of the budget crunch.  Sir I implore you to please consider letting these projects finish running their course through June as originally planned.  Stopping them now would from all indications cost the state more in State Funding than it would if they where left in place.  I Say this from experience with the programs.  The people on these programs are saving the State of Florida thousands if not millions in state revenue.  They are making purchases at a much lower cost than the state can at this time for their consumable medical products and durable goods.  They are getting much more for the money that the state provides them than the state can.  They are paying lower rate for repite, companion and personal care because they can hire non-certified family members or friends for these services than having to riley on companies the state hires at a much higher rate.  
  Please consider very carefully because there are some clients on the pilot project that will not be eligible to go back on the Med - Waiver program and will be left eith no support at all except to be place into a state institution which will cost the state three times as much in support.  Thank you again for listening to me, an if I can help you in any way please feel free to let me know.  Your friend always Darrell Walker.

-----Original Message-----
From: Yablonski, Brian [mailto:brian.yablonski@myflorida.com]

-----Original Message-----
From: Matt Conroy [mailto:Matt@cfl.rr.com]
Sent: Tuesday, December 11, 2001 6:32 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: No easy answers


Jeb

An Orlando station interviewed an Orange County High School principal
(didn't catch the school) on budget cuts, I guess yesterday--I just
caught
it on the 5:30 am news.  His comments brought to light the entire issue
of
accountability.  He stated that his school will be looking at the
unpopular
weak programs to cut and keep the more popular stronger programs.  The
verbiage--popular used synonymously with weak, is of concern.  It is
about
accountability and what constitutes a strong or a weak program.  To me,
at
least, it is disturbing that schools gauge program success on
popularity--which is about what feels good or may be just an easy A with
a
teacher who lets kids sleep in class and does not correlate the skills
they
attain with their grade.  More often than not--that would fit this
principals definition, as well as many others, of a strong program while
another academically rigorous course may be unpopular and classified as
weak. Of course students will shun away from ineffective teachers--but
that
is the exception rather than the rule--most of them in my experience
give
easy grades to keep everyone happy and 25 years later still teach the
same
class.

This underscores the need for accountability and for some concrete
definitions to be put into place on what constitutes a weak program and
a
strong program - especially when we are cutting "weak" programs due to
budget issues. Perhaps a note for schools and districts to be careful
how
they determine what they will cut and what they will not?  Florida
students
could have viable courses cut and consequently are the losers here if
such a
liberal rule is applied to measure program success based on student
popularity of a course.  Using that scale we will wind up keeping the
ceramics class and cut introduction to word processing, electronics or
chemistry III.    This also highlights the need for re-engineering
guidance
department methodologies and technologies on how courses are selected in
the
first place and the level of parental involvement--but that's an
entirely
other issue--although related.


Thanks for letting me share these concerns with you, and thank you for
listening.  There are no easy answers.

Matt Conroy

You have been sent this message from kgreen@surfbest.net as a courtesy of the Washington Post (http://www.washingtonpost.com).

Dear Governor:  I have sent you many e-mails & articles on this pill that should have been distributed to all close to Nuclear Power Plants. But for Florida Power's influence it should have been a done deal. Mass. has done it! I hope you would revisit this situation . The Federal Govt. will make these available @ no cost to the State. What will it hurt & if there is a leak or a Terrorist attack. Then it will be to late!! These are only effective ASAP after the event. And no one will stay in the comtaminated area because they took these pills. That is the stupidest logic F>P> ever came up with. Lame or nothing I guess. Thanks , Keith A. Green,11745 SW 230th av.RD.  Dunnellon,Fl 34431

To view the entire article, go to http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A22582-2001Dec10.html

FDA Urges Pill to Combat Radiation

By Justin Gillis


Spurred by fears of nuclear terrorism, the Food and Drug Administration yesterday called for widespread use of a cheap, readily available pill soon after an attack to protect people against thyroid cancer.

The FDA issued new guidelines for the use of a drug called potassium iodide. They break relatively little medical ground. But by emphasizing the proven usefulness of the drug in countering radioactive fallout, the FDA's action is likely to feed a growing discussion in the country about how broadly the drug should be stockpiled.

Authorities have known for decades that taking potassium iodide before or right after exposure to radioactive fallout can prevent some ill effects, especially in young children, who are most vulnerable to thyroid cancer. 

The revised FDA guidelines use studies done after the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear plant disaster to recommend new dosage levels for various groups, replacing guidelines based on studies of the atomic bombings in Japan in 1945.

Only a handful of states maintain stockpiles of the drug. The Department of Health and Human Services is studying whether to add potassium iodide to a national stockpile it maintains of drugs and supplies to counter large-scale terror strikes.

Some groups, noting that the drug costs as little as 10 cents a dose in bulk, have called for even broader stockpiling -- for instance, in all schools and homes that could be affected by the bombing of a nuclear plant.

"All the studies I've seen have shown that it does provide protection, particularly for young children," said David Lochbaum, a nuclear expert at the Union of Concerned Scientists, a watchdog group. "Considering its price, it just seems like a no-brainer. We should have been doing this a long time ago."

He cautioned, however, that potassium iodide protects against only one type of radiation exposure and is no substitute for preventing attacks or for evacuating people after an attack. 

Some state officials are skeptical of stockpiling the drug for the same reason, saying their main focus would be on moving people out of the path of a fallout plume and preventing contamination of the food supply. Alabama, Arizona, Maine and Tennessee are the only states with large stockpiles of potassium iodide.

A handful of states maintain smaller stockpiles, and many others have begun discussing the issue since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, realizing that nuclear plants could be prime targets. The FDA emphasized yesterday that potassium iodide should be taken within hours of a radiation release and this "requires a ready supply" of the drug.

The biology works this way: The one organ in the body that uses a lot of iodine is the thyroid gland, which produces substances that help regulate metabolism. Iodine is such an important nutrient that a form of it is routinely added to salt to help prevent deficiencies.

Iodine is not normally radioactive. However, one of the prime consequences of nuclear attack or accident would be the release of radioactive forms of the element into the air and possibly the food supply. The radioactive iodine could concentrate in the thyroid glands of exposed people, particularly fast-growing children, elevating their risk of thyroid cancer.

The absorption of radioactive iodine can be slowed, however, if exposed people quickly take a large dose of nonradioactive iodine -- "flooding" the thyroid gland with the safe form of the element. Potassium iodide pills are the preferred way to do this. The pills would ideally be taken by anyone who could be exposed to fallout within a few hours of a nuclear-plant bombing or other release of radioactivity.

The FDA emphasized yesterday that the benefits of potassium iodide in the midst of a radiation disaster are clear, and the risks minimal even if people overdose on the drug. Potassium iodide is not a prescription drug, and anybody who wants to can buy it, though most pharmacies don't stock the drug.

The new guidelines call for daily doses of potassium iodide at the following levels for those likely to be exposed to radioactive fallout:

 Infants less than 1 month old: 16 milligrams.

 Children aged 1 month to 3 years: 32 milligrams.

 Children 3 to 18 years old: 65 milligrams.

 Adults, including pregnant and lactating women, and adolescents over 150 pounds: 130 milligrams.

From:	Genevieve Jones <ghugginsjones@hotmail.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 11, 2001 7:05 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Response

This is my response letter sent to Wendy Berger after her last contact, just for your informational purposes.

  

To Whom It May Concern:

 

          I fully understand that things do not just happen overnight.  I am a teacher with a masters degree and I have done my homework on our justice system and rehabilitation centers.  I do know however that my family and I are not asking you to let my nephew just walk out the door.  We are asking for an extensive, residential drug rehabilitation program.  While you are going through all of the research that it takes for commutation of sentence, he could be getting rehabilitation.  I have spent countless hours researching rehabilitation programs and as I have stated in previous letters, Dunklin Memorial is the rehabilitation center of choice.  It seems to have the best success rate of any that I have found and he could be there as part of the sentence.  

          I have taught many students through the years about justice, the Preamble, the Constitution, Congress, the pledge to our flag, etc.  I believed in all that it stood for but the older I get the more I realize that the justice that everyone speaks of is not necessarily equal.   It seems that in our country, if you have a well-known name or have enough money for an excellent attorney, things go easier on you to begin with and you get the opportunity of rehabilitation after numerous slaps on the hand.  For those people the expression has been stated many times, They dont need prison, they have an illness and an illness needs to be treated as such.  My nephew definitely has that same illness and everything he was charged with was done under the influence of drugs and yet he has not been given that privilege as part of the justice.

          I apologize in advance for what seems like a rotten attitude, but I am truly tired of watching the news and reading the paper and hearing that one more prominent person or celebrity has been given rehabilitation and yet my nephew sits in prison for the same type of crime wasting away and nothing to say for making a more productive citizen when he does get out.  Just because we dont have a prominent name and we arent celebrities doesnt mean that our lives and those that are dear to us arent worthy of the same justice.

 

                                                          Sad and disillusioned,

                                                          Genevieve Jones


  _____  

Get more from the Web. FREE MSN Explorer download : http://explorer.msn.com


From:	Matt Conroy <Matt@cfl.rr.com>

Subject:	No easy answers

Jeb

An Orlando station interviewed an Orange County High School principal
(didn't catch the school) on budget cuts, I guess yesterday--I just caught
it on the 5:30 am news.  His comments brought to light the entire issue of
accountability.  He stated that his school will be looking at the unpopular
weak programs to cut and keep the more popular stronger programs.  The
verbiage--popular used synonymously with weak, is of concern.  It is about
accountability and what constitutes a strong or a weak program.  To me, at
least, it is disturbing that schools gauge program success on
popularity--which is about what feels good or may be just an easy A with a
teacher who lets kids sleep in class and does not correlate the skills they
attain with their grade.  More often than not--that would fit this
principals definition, as well as many others, of a strong program while
another academically rigorous course may be unpopular and classified as
weak. Of course students will shun away from ineffective teachers--but that
is the exception rather than the rule--most of them in my experience give
easy grades to keep everyone happy and 25 years later still teach the same
class.

This underscores the need for accountability and for some concrete
definitions to be put into place on what constitutes a weak program and a
strong program - especially when we are cutting "weak" programs due to
budget issues. Perhaps a note for schools and districts to be careful how
they determine what they will cut and what they will not?  Florida students
could have viable courses cut and consequently are the losers here if such a
liberal rule is applied to measure program success based on student
popularity of a course.  Using that scale we will wind up keeping the
ceramics class and cut introduction to word processing, electronics or
chemistry III.    This also highlights the need for re-engineering guidance
department methodologies and technologies on how courses are selected in the
first place and the level of parental involvement--but that's an entirely
other issue--although related.


Thanks for letting me share these concerns with you, and thank you for
listening.  There are no easy answers.

Matt Conroy

To view the entire article, go to http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A22582-2001Dec10.html

FDA Urges Pill to Combat Radiation

By Justin Gillis


Spurred by fears of nuclear terrorism, the Food and Drug Administration yesterday called for widespread use of a cheap, readily available pill soon after an attack to protect people against thyroid cancer.

The FDA issued new guidelines for the use of a drug called potassium iodide. They break relatively little medical ground. But by emphasizing the proven usefulness of the drug in countering radioactive fallout, the FDA's action is likely to feed a growing discussion in the country about how broadly the drug should be stockpiled.

Authorities have known for decades that taking potassium iodide before or right after exposure to radioactive fallout can prevent some ill effects, especially in young children, who are most vulnerable to thyroid cancer. 

The revised FDA guidelines use studies done after the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear plant disaster to recommend new dosage levels for various groups, replacing guidelines based on studies of the atomic bombings in Japan in 1945.

Only a handful of states maintain stockpiles of the drug. The Department of Health and Human Services is studying whether to add potassium iodide to a national stockpile it maintains of drugs and supplies to counter large-scale terror strikes.

Some groups, noting that the drug costs as little as 10 cents a dose in bulk, have called for even broader stockpiling -- for instance, in all schools and homes that could be affected by the bombing of a nuclear plant.

"All the studies I've seen have shown that it does provide protection, particularly for young children," said David Lochbaum, a nuclear expert at the Union of Concerned Scientists, a watchdog group. "Considering its price, it just seems like a no-brainer. We should have been doing this a long time ago."

He cautioned, however, that potassium iodide protects against only one type of radiation exposure and is no substitute for preventing attacks or for evacuating people after an attack. 

Some state officials are skeptical of stockpiling the drug for the same reason, saying their main focus would be on moving people out of the path of a fallout plume and preventing contamination of the food supply. Alabama, Arizona, Maine and Tennessee are the only states with large stockpiles of potassium iodide.

A handful of states maintain smaller stockpiles, and many others have begun discussing the issue since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, realizing that nuclear plants could be prime targets. The FDA emphasized yesterday that potassium iodide should be taken within hours of a radiation release and this "requires a ready supply" of the drug.

The biology works this way: The one organ in the body that uses a lot of iodine is the thyroid gland, which produces substances that help regulate metabolism. Iodine is such an important nutrient that a form of it is routinely added to salt to help prevent deficiencies.

Iodine is not normally radioactive. However, one of the prime consequences of nuclear attack or accident would be the release of radioactive forms of the element into the air and possibly the food supply. The radioactive iodine could concentrate in the thyroid glands of exposed people, particularly fast-growing children, elevating their risk of thyroid cancer.

The absorption of radioactive iodine can be slowed, however, if exposed people quickly take a large dose of nonradioactive iodine -- "flooding" the thyroid gland with the safe form of the element. Potassium iodide pills are the preferred way to do this. The pills would ideally be taken by anyone who could be exposed to fallout within a few hours of a nuclear-plant bombing or other release of radioactivity.

The FDA emphasized yesterday that the benefits of potassium iodide in the midst of a radiation disaster are clear, and the risks minimal even if people overdose on the drug. Potassium iodide is not a prescription drug, and anybody who wants to can buy it, though most pharmacies don't stock the drug.

The new guidelines call for daily doses of potassium iodide at the following levels for those likely to be exposed to radioactive fallout:

 Infants less than 1 month old: 16 milligrams.

 Children aged 1 month to 3 years: 32 milligrams.

 Children 3 to 18 years old: 65 milligrams.

 Adults, including pregnant and lactating women, and adolescents over 150 pounds: 130 milligrams.

Good Morning Gov. Bush,
 
 Sir I have heard that you are suppose to make a decision today on whether or not to cut the 3 pilot projects because of the budget crunch.  Sir I implore you to please consider letting these projects finish running their course through June as originally planned.  Stopping them now would from all indications cost the state more in State Funding than it would if they where left in place.  I Say this from experience with the programs.  The people on these programs are saving the State of Florida thousands if not millions in state revenue.  They are making purchases at a much lower cost than the state can at this time for their consumable medical products and durable goods.  They are getting much more for the money that the state provides them than the state can.  They are paying lower rate for repite, companion and personal care because they can hire non-certified family members or friends for these services than having to riley on companies the state hires at a much higher rate.

From: Laurie McLamore [mailto:lbmac@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Monday, December 10, 2001 5:30 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Communities In Schools Funding


Dear Governor Bush ,
 
I am a very proud member of the Board of Directors of Communities In Schools (CIS) of Florida and Communities In Schools of Hillsborough. I am writing to plead with you to exercise your Governors veto of budget line item 4.  Communities In School is an exceptionally well managed non-profit that is succeeding at achieving its very worthy mission of keeping at risk kids in school. Funding from the State of Florida has already been cut by two-thirds for this year.  Please do not allow it to be cut in half again by the special session.  Please veto line item 4.
 
In this time of budget limitations, we realize that there are many vying for taxpayer dollars. Please keep in mind that CIS matches each state dollar with eight dollars raised from individuals, corporations or grants. This powerful combination allows CIS to go into schools and give hope to struggling students and their parents and relief to classroom teachers already stretched to the limit. Our programs include reading tutoring for our youngest students so they have the basic skills for life long learning, self-esteem building through a caring adult mentor and high tech computer networking skills for future studies and employment.  
 
This organization has a strong infrastructure. It was started over 20 years ago and has been in the State of Florida for more than 10 years. This organization has gained the support and trust of the community and its constituents. This additional cut will eliminate the infrastructure necessary to continue to leverage additional dollars, to continue to collaborate with Take Stock In Children and Florida READS and possibly to continue to operate our programs.
 
I have donated many hours of my time for the past ten years because I have seen first hand the successes of these Communities In Schools programs.  As a former Burger King franchisee we received a Governors Community Investment Award in 2000 for our program at Monroe Middle School.  We are making a positive impact on the lives of our young citizens that live under the most difficult circumstances. 
 
Every dollar spent on our youth today saves money on expensive intervention in the future.  Another cut to the CIS budget puts the future of the organization at risk.  These students need our support.  Please veto line item 4.  
 
Thank you for your time and support.
 
 
 
Sincerely,
Lauren B. McLamore

From:	Castille, Colleen <colleen.castille@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Monday, December 10, 2001 7:16 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	stiltsville

	Florida Audubon's position on it. 

ANOTHER WRONG-HEADED TRY FOR STILTSVILLE

Once again, U.S. Rep. Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, R.-Miami, is trying to preserve
Stiltsville for the pleasure of a few at the expense of the many. Now Ms.
Ros-Lehtinen is pushing to keep the Biscayne National Park shacks in private
ownership to Florida's governor and Cabinet. This argument failed where it
really counted, in Washington, D.C. It deserves the same fate in
Tallahassee.
Stiltsville is now part of the national park, but the state gave 25-year
leases on individual structures perched in the shallows -- with the
understanding that when the leases expired they would revert to the park.
This arrangement often is used when national parks expand. But the
Stiltsville folks weren't satisfied with 25 years. The leases have been
extended annually three times since 1999.

Ms. Ros-Lehtinen is promoting a swap wherein 74 acres of mostly lifeless bay
bottom owned by the state would be exchanged for the lush bottomland under
Stiltsville. The Cabinet would have to OK this swap, but it would still need
federal approval, too.

It's time that Stiltsville become part of the public domain. To abrogate the
original intent just to suit property owners who agreed to the original
lease terms would set a terrible precedent that could do harm in other
national parks. Ms. Ros-Lehtinen's constituents surely have more pressing
needs that she could be fighting to obtain than this Quixotic pursuit.

Sent:	Monday, December 10, 2001 7:13 PM

From:	mike.jennings@prudential.com

Subject:	Communities in Schools of Florida, Inc.


----- Forwarded by Michael A Jennings/LAW/Pru on 12/10/2001 06:17 PM -----
                                                                                         
                                                                                         
                                                  To:                                    
                                                  cc:                                    
                                                  Subject:                               
                                                                                         
                                                                                         






Good afternoon, Governor. I correspond today with my hat on as Chairman of
Communities in Schools of Florida, Inc. I think you know the value this
stay in school program brings to Florida's education system, through its
own programs and by providing a platform for the delivery of other
programs, like the mentoring program of Take Stock in Children.

We began the year with a $3 million investment from the state. During the
regular session of the legislature our appropriation was reduced by $2
million. In the latest special session our appropriation was reduced
another fifty per cent to $500,000. While we understand and accept the need
to tighten our belts in the economic times we face, I respectfully submit
that we seem to be bearing a disproportionate cut in funding when compared
to most child services organizations, where cuts in appropriations have
taken away only the increase they received during the regular legislative
session. I can assure you our board is doing everything possible to secure
additional monies in the private sector. These efforts, unfortunately, will
not offset the significant loss in state funding we are facing this year.
Some of our local programs were already at risk with the initial funding
loss. We now find ourselves in a survival mode and are taking all
appropriate actions to properly manage our assets in an effort to maintain
this important program.

I respectfully request your favorable consideration in vetoing budget line
itme 4 of the budget  presented to you at the conclusion of last week's
second special legislative session. Although we would still face a 2/3 cut
in appropriations from 2000 we could keep our doors open.

Thank you for your consideration.
Sincerely,

Mike Jennings
