DEP	
1. Bruce Ritchie, Tallahassee Democrat, re: wants a copy of the Secretary's
schedule. Wants the photog to get some candid photos of him "at work" to go
with the profile piece he's writing this week. 
2. Charles Haddad, Atlanta Business Week, 404-240-7390  re: drilling. State
and Gov position now.

3. Palmer Hastings (Washington County) called and was wondering about (needs
ASAP):
A.  Does the fact that a discharge enters a creek affect its designation?
B.  Some people want the state to designate the Holmes Creek as an
outstanding Florida waterbody --- what would keep it from happening?
C.  What would be the process for redesignating a surface water body?
D.  What are the discharges into Holmes Creek and their status?
	Graceville WWTP?
	Chipley WWTP?
	Vernon WWTP? 
	Others?
1. A discharge into a water body does NOT change its designation.  The
"Class" is what is looked at and the "Designation" as OFW means that the
discharge is given closer review.  Also, new discharges must meet
antidegradation review and address NPDES criteria as a new surface water
discharge.  Normally, if a waterbody changes designation, an area around the
discharge point is preserved as not being OFW to allow the discharge to
remain.

2.  They would have to petition the State for the designation as it will
place restrictions on the County, Cities and State as a whole on use of the
waters.  With TMDLs, there could be an impact on agricultural use of the
land
due to current runoff practices.

3.  Contact Janet Klemm, DEP Tallahassee, at SunCom 291-9928 as she is
already working some redesignations and looking to she how they impact
current utilities.  If the boundaries are made with not grandfathering, some
cities would be severly economically impacted in upgrade expenditures to
their facilities.

4.  I maintain that we need another WW and PW map of our district and have
not been able to get one since Eric Ericson left.  Greg can give you
violation status of each place.  Chipley discharges into a creek that runs
into a stream that runs into Holmes Creek.  The creek would not necessarily
be "OFW" and travel time of effluent would come into play.

Most of this was given to the reported a couple of months ago when he called
asking the identical questions.  

3. Prakash Ghandi, Florida Specifier, 407-852-6420; re: 
budget isses. may need to speak w/ the Secretary for this story.

4. Sid Dosh, Editor of the Advocate paper in Dixie County.  His # is (352)
498-3312; re: tire recycling $2.00 environmental recovery fee.

5. Neil Santaniello, 561-243-6625; Is the Sec. doing an update on phosphorus
limits tomorrow?

6. Debbie Salamone, Orlando Sentinel, 407-420-5456; re: Blue SpringsAHCA

-----Original Message-----
From: Valerie Adams [mailto:valadams@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Friday, November 30, 2001 10:23 AM
To: Martha Pratt; Martha Pratt
Subject: Gov. Bush denies Brevard & Indian River counties money to

2001.11.29 23:20:32

Gov. Bush denies Brevard and Indian River counties money to renourish
beaches

By Linda Jump
FLORIDA TODAY

WABASSO -- Cheryl Gerstner has watched the beach in front of her
Surfside
Terrace home erode 20 feet, threatening to send her home into the
Atlantic
Ocean if more sand is lost. She's hoping Tropical Storm Olga won't take
any
more.

Brevard and Indian River counties officials are watching carefully too,
after learning that any immediate repairs to erosion will be paid either
by
them or private homeowners.

Gov. Jeb Bush determined this week that the $8 to $10 million worth of
damage reported by several East Coast counties after Hurricane Michelle
early this month didn't rise to the level needed to qualify for state or
federal emergency aid.

Indian River County had asked for $1 million in erosion control measures
to
help rebuild its beaches from the hurricane, which never hit land but
whipped up the surf, said Jonathan Gorham, county environmental
engineer.
Brevard asked for even less since previous work to save its shoreline
prevented major damage.

But Gorham said without a disaster declaration, both counties are left
without a lot of options. "It's the individual homeowner's
responsibility to
protect their property," Gorham said.

The state Office of Beaches and Shores on Thursday approved permits for
four
Dubloon Drive families north of the Wabasso Causeway to build sea walls,
and
issued a temporary permit for Surfside Terrace for sandbags and sand
until
more permanent measures can be taken.

Gerstner said that won't solve the problem. She has personally
purchased,
filled, tied and piled more than 1,000 sandbags "only to have them roll
on
the beach like they were styrofoam."

"We just want to solve our own problems with our own money to protect
our
property," Gerstner said.

Gorham said many think only hurricanes cause beach erosion, but often,
the
fall and winter northeasters cause as much, if not more, damage. "So
far, we
really haven't seen any affects from Tropical Storm Olga because the
waves
are nowhere as large as predicted," he said.

Nathan B. McCollum, emergency management coordinator, said Olga isn't
expected to hit land in Indian River County. Nor will it hit Brevard .
But
the swelled waves and eastern winds from the storm still could gouge
dunes,
he said.

Hurricane Michelle, on the other hand, took five to six feet of dune
daily
in some areas of the Indian River County after Nov. 6, Gorham said.

-----Original Message-----
From: Melody Petersen [mailto:melody@nytimes.com]
Sent: Monday, December 10, 2001 4:02 PM
To: Hirst, Elizabeth
Subject: questions


Elizabeth,

    Thanks so much for sending the release. I'm writing a story about 
electronic prescription tracking systems like the one that Governor Bush

hopes to create in Florida. There is a growing effort to create these 
systems because of the problems associated with OxyContin.

I was hoping to talk to the Governor for five minutes. I have the
following 
questions:

* Why does Florida need a electronic system that tracks prescriptions? 
Could it have helped identify the abuse of OxyContin before it reached 
almost epidemic levels in Florida and other states? Could this help 
officials identify the next prescription drug that addicts turn to?
Could 
this help stop people from dying unnecessarily from abuse of OxyContin
and 
other prescription drugs?

* In many states, doctors, drug companies and pharmacies have lobbied 
against attempts to create these programs. The most often used argument 
against these systems is that they violate the privacy of patients.
Would 
Florida's system have benefits that would outweigh any loss of privacy?

* Last week, at a press conference, the Governor mentioned that he had
once 
taken OxyContin after he crushed a finger. What did he learn from that 
experience?

Thanks so very much.

My direct line is 212-556-5121. I'll be here until about 7 p.m. tonight
and 
back at 10 a.m. tomorrow.

Melody Petersen
The New York Times


From:	Hooks, Mary B <Mary_B._Hooks@fdles.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Monday, December 10, 2001 5:39 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Governor's Exercise on Small Pox - Table Top Games



Dear Governor: 

Again, thank you for the opportunity allowing me to serve our citizens in the great state of Florida.  I felt inspired to send this note to you.   

It is my belief that by divine design Florida has been at the helm in developing a response to the potential use of biological agents as a model for other sates to follow; largely in part, due to our experience in the handling of natural disasters or in this case, chemical/biological/man-made disasters.  It shows our willingness to be proactive and at the forefront of ensuring the well being of our community, state and nation.  Of course, having somewhat of a blueprint from the past weeks of the Anthrax scenario, affecting and originating in our state, has been helpful towards perfecting such a plan of action.  Timely and adequate responses of leadership certainly lessens tensions and fears of the people who look to their leaders for the comfort of security they have always been accustomed to. 

I've always remembered your campaign promise of past, "We Can Do Better."  We have and shall continue that mantra. I have confidence that our citizens will be the primary beneficiaries of this exercise for enhancing their safety and protection.

  
With that said, this exercise has been and immense benefit to me and hopefully, to everyone else who was in attendance today.  I believe wholeheartedly that vigilance and preparedness is an insurance policy for our security.  


Sincerely, 

Mary Hooks   

From:	Laurie McLamore <lbmac@tampabay.rr.com>
Sent:	Monday, December 10, 2001 5:30 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Communities In Schools Funding

Dear Governor Bush ,
 
I am a very proud member of the Board of Directors of Communities In Schools (CIS) of Florida and Communities In Schools of Hillsborough. I am writing to plead with you to exercise your Governors veto of budget line item 4.  Communities In School is an exceptionally well managed non-profit that is succeeding at achieving its very worthy mission of keeping at risk kids in school. Funding from the State of Florida has already been cut by two-thirds for this year.  Please do not allow it to be cut in half again by the special session.  Please veto line item 4.
 
In this time of budget limitations, we realize that there are many vying for taxpayer dollars. Please keep in mind that CIS matches each state dollar with eight dollars raised from individuals, corporations or grants. This powerful combination allows CIS to go into schools and give hope to struggling students and their parents and relief to classroom teachers already stretched to the limit. Our programs include reading tutoring for our youngest students so they have the basic skills for life long learning, self-esteem building through a caring adult mentor and high tech computer networking skills for future studies and employment.  
 
This organization has a strong infrastructure. It was started over 20 years ago and has been in the State of Florida for more than 10 years. This organization has gained the support and trust of the community and its constituents. This additional cut will eliminate the infrastructure necessary to continue to leverage additional dollars, to continue to collaborate with Take Stock In Children and Florida READS and possibly to continue to operate our programs.
 
I have donated many hours of my time for the past ten years because I have seen first hand the successes of these Communities In Schools programs.  As a former Burger King franchisee we received a Governors Community Investment Award in 2000 for our program at Monroe Middle School.  We are making a positive impact on the lives of our young citizens that live under the most difficult circumstances. 
 
Every dollar spent on our youth today saves money on expensive intervention in the future.  Another cut to the CIS budget puts the future of the organization at risk.  These students need our support.  Please veto line item 4.  
 
Thank you for your time and support.
 
 
 
Sincerely,
Lauren B. McLamore
 
From:	Doreen Rutledge <Doreen_Rutledge@dcf.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Monday, December 10, 2001 5:33 PM

Subject:	The Ty donation

I just spoke to the Ty corporation in Illinois. The value of their product
donation is $200,000.00  They do not want any press at all. The prefer to
be magnanimous? That's what they said. They would like me to send them some
pictures of the children receiving their gifts and their delight but
nothing else.
They have put us on their list of continued recipients so they will
continue to ship to us.
Thank you all for your support in this and I will update you as the other
shipments start to arrive!
Doreen

     Jeb,

     light? The
     area of concern is the N. Monroe / Universal Rd. (between Tallahassee
     mall
     and Hooters) This unique portion of N. Monroe is home for 12
     restaurants.
     Turning left to access any of these establishments has resulted in
     many
     wrecks and close calls. A few of which I've personally witnessed while

     dining. Entering and leaving these restaurants during peek periods
     also
     results in delays and drive-thru backups. For example; the delay in
     leaving
     the Chic-Fil-A in the morning is 7 minutes waiting for the light at
     John knox
     to turn.


     I'm no traffic engineer but I believe the time duration of the light
     would be
     quick since Universal doesn't cross N. Monroe. So rather than a 4 way
     it
     would only be a 3 way light signal. Its location is precisely halfway
     between
     Northwood shopping center and John Knox Road. With 12 restaurants now
     on that
     stretch, a left hand turn during breakfast, lunch or dinner has become
     a life
     threatening task. Even if this light could be activated during those
     times
     and remain a flashing yellow the rest of the day would be an
     improvement.


     Eating establishments are: EL Chico, Arby's, Chic-fil-A, Roadhouse,
     Boston
     market, DQ, Miami subs, 4TH Quarter, Woody's BBQ, Rallys, Silver
     Slipper,
     Lindy's.

-----Original Message-----
From: Valerie Adams [mailto:valadams@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Friday, November 30, 2001 10:23 AM
To: Martha Pratt; Martha Pratt
Subject: Gov. Bush denies Brevard & Indian River counties money to
renourish beaches. Fl.Today 11/30/01


2001.11.29 23:20:32

Gov. Bush denies Brevard and Indian River counties money to renourish
beaches

By Linda Jump
FLORIDA TODAY

WABASSO -- Cheryl Gerstner has watched the beach in front of her
Surfside
Terrace home erode 20 feet, threatening to send her home into the
Atlantic
Ocean if more sand is lost. She's hoping Tropical Storm Olga won't take
any
more.

Brevard and Indian River counties officials are watching carefully too,
after learning that any immediate repairs to erosion will be paid either
by
them or private homeowners.

Gov. Jeb Bush determined this week that the $8 to $10 million worth of
damage reported by several East Coast counties after Hurricane Michelle
early this month didn't rise to the level needed to qualify for state or
federal emergency aid.

Indian River County had asked for $1 million in erosion control measures
to
help rebuild its beaches from the hurricane, which never hit land but
whipped up the surf, said Jonathan Gorham, county environmental
engineer.
Brevard asked for even less since previous work to save its shoreline
prevented major damage.

But Gorham said without a disaster declaration, both counties are left
without a lot of options. "It's the individual homeowner's
responsibility to
protect their property," Gorham said.

The state Office of Beaches and Shores on Thursday approved permits for
four
Dubloon Drive families north of the Wabasso Causeway to build sea walls,
and
issued a temporary permit for Surfside Terrace for sandbags and sand
until
more permanent measures can be taken.

Gerstner said that won't solve the problem. She has personally
purchased,
filled, tied and piled more than 1,000 sandbags "only to have them roll
on
the beach like they were styrofoam."

"We just want to solve our own problems with our own money to protect
our
property," Gerstner said.

Gorham said many think only hurricanes cause beach erosion, but often,
the
fall and winter northeasters cause as much, if not more, damage. "So
far, we
really haven't seen any affects from Tropical Storm Olga because the
waves
are nowhere as large as predicted," he said.

Nathan B. McCollum, emergency management coordinator, said Olga isn't
expected to hit land in Indian River County. Nor will it hit Brevard .
But
the swelled waves and eastern winds from the storm still could gouge
dunes,
he said.

Hurricane Michelle, on the other hand, took five to six feet of dune
daily
in some areas of the Indian River County after Nov. 6, Gorham said.

From:	Kathy Adams <kathya@mediareachpr.com>
Sent:	Monday, December 10, 2001 4:55 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Urgent - Communities in Schools

Governor,
Communities in Schools is in a crisis situation now. I have supported this organization for 17 years, and this is the first time our State program is in great peril. Our budget was cut from 3 million dollars last year to 1 million dollars this year. Although cuts were necessary a 2/3 cut caused us to reconfigure all our services. It appears that the new budget is going to cut an additional 500 thousand dollars.
These cuts are disproportionate to other organizations' cuts whose monies were primarily cut from increases in this years funding.Operating on a 500 thousand dollar budget from 3 millon dollars will also jeopardize a 2 million dollar grant we received from federal dollars (a loss of an additional 2 million dollars to our state's education system.
I truly hope you will Veto our line item (4) and enable us to continue to address the needs of the at risk students in our state. It costs us less to support them now, then in our Juvenile Justice System.
Thank you for your consideration, and I look forward to seeing you Saturday evening at your Christmas party.
 
Respectfully,
Kathy Adams
Board Member and Past Chairman
Communities in Schools of Florida
From:	Kathy Rafanan <katmraf@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Monday, December 10, 2001 4:43 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	feeney.tom@leg.state.fl.us; baker.carey@leg.state.fl.us; mckay.john.web@leg.state.us
Subject:	Budget cuts

Dear Gov. Bush, 

Thank you for having Paul Strickland respond to my
email. I appreciate your interest in what voters like
myself think. 

I also appreciate that corporations benefit from tax
exemptions and this can in turn help stimulate the
economy. I do not agree though that tax exemptions for
organizations such as golf courses are necessary for
economic stimulus.

As for the developmentally disabled community, I do
not see how it can be stated that their needs are
being met when over 6700 individuals from the July
1999 wait list were suppose to begin to receive
services in March of 2002 are now not going to receive
services this fiscal year. Currently there is no plan
to provide services for these individuals because
there are insufficient funds in the budget to provide
for all of those with Developmental Disabilities.
Also, this figure does not include some 4000
additional individuals who have applied for services
since July 1999. 

I fail to understand the logic of placing individuals
with disabilities in nursing homes. For example, a 35
year old with Cerebral Palsy who has some medical
involvement; if I understand your response correctly;
would have to live in a nursing home if this was the
most cost effective arrangement. What about this
individuals friends, family, and interests? What about
thier quality of life? 

Individuals with disabilities should have the same
opportunities for living situations as everyone else
whether it is in the family home, an apartment or home
of their own, or other community living arrangement.
They should not be forced into group homes, nursing
homes, or institutions. 

I was glad to hear that the $77,000 CAP will not be
implemented. Thank you for any assistance you offered
in keeping this from happening. Also, thank you for
keeping some of the needed funding in General Revenue.


I sincerely hope more consideration will be given to
eliminating many of the current tax exemptions on the
books. It is imperative that Florida build a recurring
tax base that does rely so heavily on tourism dollars.
This is one way to do that. 

Thank you for listening and for all that you have
already done for those with disabilities and their
families.

Sincerely,
Kathy Rafanan
katmraf@yahoo.com

-----Original Message-----
From: Melody Petersen [mailto:melody@nytimes.com]
Sent: Monday, December 10, 2001 4:02 PM
To: Hirst, Elizabeth
Subject: questions


Elizabeth,

    Thanks so much for sending the release. I'm writing a story about 
electronic prescription tracking systems like the one that Governor Bush 
hopes to create in Florida. There is a growing effort to create these 
systems because of the problems associated with OxyContin.

I was hoping to talk to the Governor for five minutes. I have the following 
questions:

* Why does Florida need a electronic system that tracks prescriptions? 
Could it have helped identify the abuse of OxyContin before it reached 
almost epidemic levels in Florida and other states? Could this help 
officials identify the next prescription drug that addicts turn to? Could 
this help stop people from dying unnecessarily from abuse of OxyContin and 
other prescription drugs?

* In many states, doctors, drug companies and pharmacies have lobbied 
against attempts to create these programs. The most often used argument 
against these systems is that they violate the privacy of patients. Would 
Florida's system have benefits that would outweigh any loss of privacy?

* Last week, at a press conference, the Governor mentioned that he had once 
taken OxyContin after he crushed a finger. What did he learn from that 
experience?

Thanks so very much.

My direct line is 212-556-5121. I'll be here until about 7 p.m. tonight and 
back at 10 a.m. tomorrow.

Melody Petersen
The New York Times

From:	Springbookhaus@aol.com
Sent:	Monday, December 10, 2001 3:52 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	BEACH EROSION

Hi Jeb...We voted for YOU!


Subject:  Brevard County Shore Protection Project Funding: Phase II, South Reach

Dear Senator:

I request your leadership in obtaining federal funds for Brevard County's beaches in the 2001 Conference Energy and Water Bill.  The House bill included $8.5 million for Brevard County's Shore Protection Project, but the Senate and Administration's budgets included only $200,000.  The federal cost-share for Phase II, as authorized by Congress in 1996, is $12 million.  Brevard County needs this $12 million appropriated in the FY 2001-2002 Conference Bill.  Brevard County is relying on you to take the lead in appropriating these dollars.

A few special interest groups have attempted to label beach nourishment as pork, primarily benefiting wealthy oceanfront property owners.  This is untrue!  As the photos above indicate, the majority of those who benefit are the millions of people who relax and play on our public beaches each year.  Private property rights in America give oceanfront property owners the right to protect their investments or to be compensated by the government for lost property.  When faced with erosion, these property owners erect seawalls.  Seawalls displace public recreation, increase the pace of erosion, and destroy marine turtle nesting habitat.  Along highly developed shorelines like Brevard's, the government simply cannot afford to outlaw seawalls and fund a retreat policy.  In contrast, beach nourishment restores the beaches to a healthy width, thereby averting the demand for seawalls while simultaneously creating huge recreational and environmental benefits.  Beach nourishment saves America's beaches from seawalls.

Thank you in advance for your support.  With a $12 million appropriation in the Conference Bill, we can build back Brevard's beaches. 

Sincerely, Philip D. Snyder & Dorothy J. Snyder
Printed Name

877 N. Highway A1A, Unit 1108
Street Address

Indialantic, Florida  32903-3028
Sign Here City, State, Zip Code

From:	Nina Oviedo <oviedon@sso.org>
Sent:	Monday, December 10, 2001 3:01 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	Donna Arduin; Greg Turbeville; Don Langston; Brian Yablonski; Frank R. Jimenez; Kathleen Shanahan
Subject:	Gov Huckabee creates "Tax Me More Fund"

I thought you might like this  Nina.
 
 
'TAX ME MORE FUND' CREATES A STIR
 
Donald Lambro
THE WASHINGTON TIMES
 
-----------------------------------------------------------
 
They're chuckling, cheering and chafing in Arkansas these
days over Gov. Mike Huckabee's novel idea for raising more
taxes: He's inviting taxpayers who want to pay more to do
so. 
 
The Republican governor, who appears to be a shoo-in for a
second term next year, has set up the "Tax Me More Fund" to
give voters who think they are not taxed enough the chance
to send more money to the state.
 
Mr. Huckabee's opponents in the news media and in the state
legislature were nearly apoplectic when he announced the
creation of the fund, but the governor says he is not fazed.
"I'm having way too much fun," he says.
 
"The press is mad at me and some of the liberals in the
legislature are furious and have resorted to name-calling,
but the people understand it. They get the whole deal," the
governor said in a telephone interview.
 
"I have not had one person come up to me and say 'I haven't
been paying enough in taxes and my wife and I feel guilty we
aren't paying enough,' " he said with a chuckle.
 
Since the fund was announced, he says the Department of
Finance and Administration has collected "a whopping $260."
And that's the point that Mr. Huckabee says his
tongue-in-cheek idea makes loud and clear: Most people do
not want their taxes raised.
 
"What it does is expose the hypocrisy of the liberals
because they want to raise taxes as long as someone else has
to pay for them. Our state law does not prohibit someone
from paying more. So if they believe it would make them feel
better to contribute more, then I want them to write as
generous a check as they can to make themselves feel good,"
Mr. Huckabee said.
 
"I have a pocketful of pre-addressed envelopes for them to
mail in their checks. If someone in the legislature comes up
to me and talks about a tax increase, I pull out an envelope
and say mail it in. They just shake their head," he said.
 
Like most states during the current economic slump, Arkansas
has seen its tax revenues fall, resulting in a $142 million
deficit this year, equaling about 4 percent of the state's
budget. But Mr. Huckabee has resisted calls for a special
session of the legislature to consider new taxes.
 
"My feeling is everyone in Arkansas is having to adjust to
the downturn in the economy and every business is doing the
same. Asking Arkansas to cough up more money during a
recession is like asking a bleeding hemophiliac to donate a
pint of blood to the Red Cross," he said.
 
The governor's political opponents have attacked him with a
vengeance. Sen. John Riggs, a Little Rock Democrat, has
called Mr. Huckabee "a clown," and former Democratic Govs.
Dale Bumpers and David Pryor say that the fund is not a
serious solution to the state's budget shortfall.
 
But Mr. Huckabee, whose job approval ratings are running
over 70 percent, has been cheered on the campaign trail
whenever he raises the tax issue and pulls out his
pre-address envelopes to the Tax Me More Fund.
 
"The point that the people of Arkansas get clearly right now
is they are struggling to hold their jobs, pay their rent,
make a car payment and put a piece of baloney between two
slices of bread for lunch," he said.
 
Mr. Huckabee's political success with his tax fund has not
gone unnoticed among campaign strategists elsewhere, some of
whom think it could be used in other gubernatorial
campaigns.
 
"I think he has come up with a kind of clever ploy that has
the liberals sputtering," said Stephen Moore, president of
the Club for Growth, which supports candidates who favor tax
cuts.
 
"There is going to be increasing muttering about raising
taxes in next year's campaigns, and this type of approach by
Huckabee might be a good way to stop the liberals in their
tracks," Mr. Moore said.

-----Original Message-----
From: Valerie Adams [mailto:valadams@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Friday, November 30, 2001 10:23 AM
To: Martha Pratt; Martha Pratt
Subject: Gov. Bush denies Brevard & Indian River counties money to
renourish beaches. Fl.Today 11/30/01


2001.11.29 23:20:32

Gov. Bush denies Brevard and Indian River counties money to renourish
beaches

By Linda Jump
FLORIDA TODAY

WABASSO -- Cheryl Gerstner has watched the beach in front of her
Surfside
Terrace home erode 20 feet, threatening to send her home into the
Atlantic
Ocean if more sand is lost. She's hoping Tropical Storm Olga won't take
any
more.

Brevard and Indian River counties officials are watching carefully too,
after learning that any immediate repairs to erosion will be paid either
by
them or private homeowners.

Gov. Jeb Bush determined this week that the $8 to $10 million worth of
damage reported by several East Coast counties after Hurricane Michelle
early this month didn't rise to the level needed to qualify for state or
federal emergency aid.

Indian River County had asked for $1 million in erosion control measures
to
help rebuild its beaches from the hurricane, which never hit land but
whipped up the surf, said Jonathan Gorham, county environmental
engineer.
Brevard asked for even less since previous work to save its shoreline
prevented major damage.

But Gorham said without a disaster declaration, both counties are left
without a lot of options. "It's the individual homeowner's
responsibility to
protect their property," Gorham said.

The state Office of Beaches and Shores on Thursday approved permits for
four
Dubloon Drive families north of the Wabasso Causeway to build sea walls,
and
issued a temporary permit for Surfside Terrace for sandbags and sand
until
more permanent measures can be taken.

Gerstner said that won't solve the problem. She has personally
purchased,
filled, tied and piled more than 1,000 sandbags "only to have them roll
on
the beach like they were styrofoam."

"We just want to solve our own problems with our own money to protect
our
property," Gerstner said.

Gorham said many think only hurricanes cause beach erosion, but often,
the
fall and winter northeasters cause as much, if not more, damage. "So
far, we
really haven't seen any affects from Tropical Storm Olga because the
waves
are nowhere as large as predicted," he said.

Nathan B. McCollum, emergency management coordinator, said Olga isn't
expected to hit land in Indian River County. Nor will it hit Brevard .
But
the swelled waves and eastern winds from the storm still could gouge
dunes,
he said.

Hurricane Michelle, on the other hand, took five to six feet of dune
daily
in some areas of the Indian River County after Nov. 6, Gorham said.

From: kay <mailto:b10g7@mediaone.net>  
To: Undisclosed-Recipient:@chmls06.mediaone.net; 
Sent: Monday, December 10, 2001 9:52 AM
Subject: [lyme-information] Action for IGENEX

December 3, 2001

Re:  Pending HCGA/ CLIA ACTION AGAINST  IGENEX

Dear Clients, Friends and Fellow Lyme Advocates and Providers

It is with deep regret and a sense of urgency that I write to you to advise
of a critical situation - the - impending shutdown of IgeneX by the
government.

To give a brief history, as many of you know, IGX has been under
investigation by HCGA/CLIA for 2  years.   We have been guilty of nothing
more than acting and speaking loudly and fearlessly on behalf of the Lyme
community.  Our tests have been state-of-the-art and we
have devoted 1/3 of our budget to research of new cutting edge tests.  We
have found positive results where others have not.  We have passed every
standard graded proficiency, and passed every inspection "with flying
colors" until July, 1999, when it appears that the CDC, HCFA/CLIA and the CA
Dept. of Field Serviced decided to make things difficult for IGX.
Coincidentally, some of the finest Lyme physicians were also targeted at the
same time.

We have provided documentation requested by these agencies, but they have
been deliberately vague in their requests, and they told us that our
documentation was never enough and never in the form that they liked,
although they never told us exactly what they did want.  We
have been found guilty until proven innocent in a no-win situation.  We have
hired lawyers and consultants at a tremendous cost to IGX, and they have
been successful in helping us until now.  The outcome was apparently
mandated and predetermined.

I will expand upon the details at the later date, but at this time I must
advise you that HCFA/CLIA HAS IMPOSED SANCTIONS ON IGX, WHICH INCLUDED THE
SHUT DOWN OF THE LAB THIS FRIDAY DECEMBER 7TH.   We learned Monday afternoon
through our attorney that the December 7th shutdown has been put on
TEMPORARY HOLD.  However, the situation is
far from resolved-it is merely a "stay."  We are doing everything in our
power to fight this, including submitting additional documents today.   We
are not shut down and we certainly hope we will not be shut down, but we can
use your help.  Some of you have already asked
how you can assist.  Here are some ideas:


SAMPLE LETTER

ANOTHER SAMPLE LETTER


1. Fax or write letters to the people listed below.  We understand that, as
physicians, you may not wish to sign your name for fear of retaliation.  But
you may wish to write anonymously and tell them why.
2. Fax or write to your local and state representatives.  Many of them are
already aware of the situation and are attempting to intercede.
3. Encourage and advise any patients who have been helped in part by our
tests to also fax letters describing their positive experiences.
4. If you have other ideas to assist us, please do not hesitate to call me
personally at 800-832-3200

We will advise you as soon as we know the outcome.  Meanwhile, IGX will be
open to process specimens and take your phone calls.  Please remember that
IGeneX is and always has been a fine, honest and dedicated lab.

With heartfelt appreciation and gratitude,
Nick S. Harris, Ph.D
President of IgeneX

Faxed letters may be directed to:
Karen Fuller, Acting Director - CLIA Operations -  CMS-San Francisco

Services

engine)

Barry Straube, MD
Medical Director, HCFA/CMS
75 Hawthorne St.
San Francisco CA 94105-3903
(415) 744-3503 (office)
BStraube@cms.hhs.gov

Subject: September 11th Remembrance Ceremony
Importance: High


On December 11th  the three-month anniversary of the September 11th attacks  President George W. Bush is asking states to hold remembrance events and to play the national anthem at the exact moment the first airplane struck the World Trade Center in New York (8:46 a.m. EST).
 
Lt. Governor Brogan and I welcome you to come down to the Capitol Courtyard tomorrow, December 11th, at 8:30 a.m. to participate in Floridas remembrance ceremony.  Supervisors should make every effort to accommodate their employees' desire to attend this service.
 
God Bless America.
 
Jeb Bush

From: Busse, Mark [mailto:mark.busse@myflorida.com]
Sent: Tuesday, December 04, 2001 12:34 PM
To: Struhs, David
Cc: 'bob.sparks@dep.fl.state.us'; Gaither, Kathalyn; Hirst, Elizabeth;
Gates, Lisa
Subject: FW: Gov. Bush denies Brevard & Indian River counties money to

-----Original Message-----
From: Valerie Adams [mailto:valadams@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Friday, November 30, 2001 10:23 AM
To: Martha Pratt; Martha Pratt
Subject: Gov. Bush denies Brevard & Indian River counties money to
renourish beaches. Fl.Today 11/30/01


2001.11.29 23:20:32

Gov. Bush denies Brevard and Indian River counties money to renourish
beaches

By Linda Jump
FLORIDA TODAY

WABASSO -- Cheryl Gerstner has watched the beach in front of her
Surfside
Terrace home erode 20 feet, threatening to send her home into the
Atlantic
Ocean if more sand is lost. She's hoping Tropical Storm Olga won't take
any
more.

Brevard and Indian River counties officials are watching carefully too,
after learning that any immediate repairs to erosion will be paid either
by
them or private homeowners.

Gov. Jeb Bush determined this week that the $8 to $10 million worth of
damage reported by several East Coast counties after Hurricane Michelle
early this month didn't rise to the level needed to qualify for state or
federal emergency aid.

Indian River County had asked for $1 million in erosion control measures
to
help rebuild its beaches from the hurricane, which never hit land but
whipped up the surf, said Jonathan Gorham, county environmental
engineer.
Brevard asked for even less since previous work to save its shoreline
prevented major damage.

But Gorham said without a disaster declaration, both counties are left
without a lot of options. "It's the individual homeowner's
responsibility to
protect their property," Gorham said.

The state Office of Beaches and Shores on Thursday approved permits for
four
Dubloon Drive families north of the Wabasso Causeway to build sea walls,
and
issued a temporary permit for Surfside Terrace for sandbags and sand
until
more permanent measures can be taken.

Gerstner said that won't solve the problem. She has personally
purchased,
filled, tied and piled more than 1,000 sandbags "only to have them roll
on
the beach like they were styrofoam."

"We just want to solve our own problems with our own money to protect
our
property," Gerstner said.

Gorham said many think only hurricanes cause beach erosion, but often,
the
fall and winter northeasters cause as much, if not more, damage. "So
far, we
really haven't seen any affects from Tropical Storm Olga because the
waves
are nowhere as large as predicted," he said.

Nathan B. McCollum, emergency management coordinator, said Olga isn't
expected to hit land in Indian River County. Nor will it hit Brevard .
But
the swelled waves and eastern winds from the storm still could gouge
dunes,
he said.

Hurricane Michelle, on the other hand, took five to six feet of dune
daily
in some areas of the Indian River County after Nov. 6, Gorham said.




From:	Sparks, Bob <Bob.Sparks@dep.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Monday, December 10, 2001 12:42 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	FL_DEP; Stutler, Denver
Subject:	FW: Gov. Bush denies Brevard & Indian River counties money to renourish beaches. Fl.Today 11/30/01

Governor:

David asked me to advise you that we have worked with DCA to respond to the
Daytona Beach News Journal story below.  We have provided DCA with the
positive news of the state's extraordinary efforts toward beach
renourishment.  DCA took the lead in responding to the question of funding
based upon their role as coordinator with FEMA on these matters.  It was
determined that there was insufficient "eligible" damages to justify a
disaster request to FEMA.  Bottom line: we are responding while remaining on
offense.  Best regards.

Bob Sparks

Gov. Bush denies Brevard and Indian River counties money to renourish
beaches

By Linda Jump
FLORIDA TODAY

WABASSO -- Cheryl Gerstner has watched the beach in front of her
Surfside
Terrace home erode 20 feet, threatening to send her home into the
Atlantic
Ocean if more sand is lost. She's hoping Tropical Storm Olga won't take
any
more.

Brevard and Indian River counties officials are watching carefully too,
after learning that any immediate repairs to erosion will be paid either
by
them or private homeowners.

Gov. Jeb Bush determined this week that the $8 to $10 million worth of
damage reported by several East Coast counties after Hurricane Michelle
early this month didn't rise to the level needed to qualify for state or
federal emergency aid.

Indian River County had asked for $1 million in erosion control measures
to
help rebuild its beaches from the hurricane, which never hit land but
whipped up the surf, said Jonathan Gorham, county environmental
engineer.
Brevard asked for even less since previous work to save its shoreline
prevented major damage.

But Gorham said without a disaster declaration, both counties are left
without a lot of options. "It's the individual homeowner's
responsibility to
protect their property," Gorham said.

The state Office of Beaches and Shores on Thursday approved permits for
four
Dubloon Drive families north of the Wabasso Causeway to build sea walls,
and
issued a temporary permit for Surfside Terrace for sandbags and sand
until
more permanent measures can be taken.

Gerstner said that won't solve the problem. She has personally
purchased,
filled, tied and piled more than 1,000 sandbags "only to have them roll
on
the beach like they were styrofoam."

"We just want to solve our own problems with our own money to protect
our
property," Gerstner said.

Gorham said many think only hurricanes cause beach erosion, but often,
the
fall and winter northeasters cause as much, if not more, damage. "So
far, we
really haven't seen any affects from Tropical Storm Olga because the
waves
are nowhere as large as predicted," he said.

Nathan B. McCollum, emergency management coordinator, said Olga isn't
expected to hit land in Indian River County. Nor will it hit Brevard .
But
the swelled waves and eastern winds from the storm still could gouge
dunes,
he said.

Hurricane Michelle, on the other hand, took five to six feet of dune
daily
in some areas of the Indian River County after Nov. 6, Gorham said.

-----Original Message-----
From: Jim Williams [mailto:jimwill@bellsouth.net]
Sent: Monday, December 10, 2001 5:24 AM
To: dcifers@floridamagazine.com; Jeb Bush; pam.dana@myflorida.com;
Brett.Doster@myflorida.com
Subject: Thank you for trying.........


Thanks to each of you who receive and read this.  We gave it all we had,
but looks like the 9-11 perpetrators have won another one.  I wrote this
letter to George Lane (my friend and mentor in legislative procedure)
this morning and thought each of you had in one way or another been involved
and I wanted you to know what is happening.

Governor Bush, you have a great young bunch of folks around you there
in Tallahassee and they did all they could to help in this trying time.
 Those folks that make up the Federal agencies just don't know or care
what is happening and I hope when you and your staff move to Washington
in 7 more years you will do what you can to unseat all those whose jobs
were protected, but who didn't feel the need to make sure others receive
adequate help.  Never did we ask for handouts; only long term loans to
help stay in business during the recovery.  They mouth good words, just
short on carry through.  Brett Doster sat with some of us from the Orlando
area and listen to people 'mouth' platitudes.  I only hope at least some
of those that attended got more attention and help than our little school.

Thanks again...........

Jim Williams
Captain, Delta Air Lines (Ret.)
Chairman, Airline Training Academy

Addressees:  Gov Bush, Pam Dana, Brett Doster, Doug Cifers

===============================================================================
=================================

George,

I'm back from the West Coast and am happy to say things went well out
there.  Now it's time to see what I can do about the problems back here.

While I was gone the SBA has for all practical purposes turned down the
loan application (long term/low interest) for the money to replace business
lost as a result of 9-11.  They didn't exactly turn it down but said if
we wanted the paperwork to go any farther in the consideration process,
each of my sons and myself must put our homes up as collateral.  We can't
do that.  If they want personal guarantees that would be different.  You
often have to give those for a loan, but never your house.  We tried to
tell them, 'what would happen if another plane flew into the Sears Tower
in Chicago, and no airline could or would be able to hire new pilots for
several years?'  All of us would not only lose the business, but our homes
as well and that is unsatisfactory.


They say that is the chance you must take if you want the loan.  So, no
loan!  We are willing to put our personal guarantee up but not our homes.

If I had to make a guess, we will now lose the Academy, and as you know
have already lost (through selling to a new owner) Discover Air.  In order
to just meet fixed and certain variable expenses, the academy has to bring
in 20 new students each month.   Thirteen have been enrolled for the December
class and the rest (29) withdrew before they even arrived (we now have
over a million dollars in revenue withdrawls since 9-11), so that accelerates
the end of something really quite good.  There will come a time when the
pilot shortage hits that those folks in Federal programs administration
and those folks we elect to public office will regret that they have allowed
a whole industry to flounder.  They think that by throwing a 'little'
money at the major airlines who could afford expensive lobbyists, that
they have done something heroic.  I have one trump card to play and that's
getting airlines that are going to need our services to step up to the
plate and tell the next generation of pilots that there is a future for
them in the airline business.  It may really be too late for Airline Training
Academy, but maybe some others can get through this period intact.

George, if you have any plans for further involvement with the Academy,
do yourself and us a favor and terminate any time commitment.  There is
not money enough to pay our bills, such as gas, that allow us to continue
to instruct, let alone your invoice which you would have earned by the
end of December.  We have paid you for October and November but will not
be able to pay anything more.  There is not money for salaries for my
sons and so personal savings will get tapped just to make mortgage payments
from here on out.  I don't regret paying you the $5,000 in fees for services,
I just wish that we had known you at a better time when we would have
benefited more from your association.

George, even though we won't be able to have a professional association,
we are still 'brothers in Christ'.  I wish you and Libby a Holy holiday
season and the very best possible in 2002 as things get better, we hope.
 God bless you and your entire family.

Jim

The people on these programs are saving the State of Florida thousands if not millions in state revenue.  They are making purchases at a much lower cost than the state can at this time for their consumable medical products and durable goods.  They are getting much more for the money that the state provides them than the state can.  They are paying lower rate for repite, companion and personal care because they can hire non-certified family members or friends for these services than having to riley on companies the state hires at a much higher rate.

Governor, 
You may recall suspending Mr. Brown after he was charged with sexual battery 
and aggravated battery (both felonies) for attacking his girlfriend in 
January.  He was the man that shoved dirt down the victim's throat and 
digitally penetrated the victim's vagina.  The State Attorney's Office 
accepted a plea to a misdemeanor battery charge in July, but you agreed to 
leave the suspension order in effect based on our belief that Mr. Brown had, 
in fact, committed a felony.  (As you know, you can suspend county officers 
if they commit a felony but not if they commit a misdemeanor.)  Wendy and I 
were prepared for a trial on Monday, held before the Senate's special 
master,  to prove the felony charges and get Mr. Brown permanently removed 
from office.  

Today, Mr. Brown resigned his position.  He recently got a copy of all the 
evidence that Wendy and I planned to present, and many people (including the 
victim) received subpoenas this week for the trial.  I believe he finally 
realized the strength of our case and decided not to have all the dirty 
laundry aired at a public trial.  On your behalf, we filed an Executive 
Order today officially declaring his seat vacant. 

The State Attorney's Office has asked local law enforcement to make extra 
patrols by the residence of Mr. Brown and the victim to respond to any 
domestic violence that might arise from the resignation.  One of the reasons 
the victim did not want to cooperate was because of Mr. Brown's position as 
a County Commissioner.  If there is more violence, perhaps she will be more 
likely to cooperate since he is no longer a County Commissioner. 

From:	Herbert, Adam <aherbert@unf.edu>
Sent:	Monday, December 10, 2001 10:50 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Admissions Policy Court Hearing

Jeb,

You might be interested in the attached article.  The Michigan case will be
the one which goes to the Supreme Court to define acceptable admissions
practices.

I hope you and the family have a wonderful holiday season.

Adam
-----------------------------------------------------------------
College affirmative action on trial
-----------------------------------------------------------------
(12/7/01 Chicago Tribune)
-----------------------------------------------------------------
CINCINNATI -- The University of Michigan held aloft the tattered flag of
affirmative action Thursday, defending its admissions policies before
federal judges who raised thorny questions about whether the school uses an
unconstitutional race-based quota system.

The hearing and its outcome could have far-reaching implications affecting
the racial makeup of the nation's top educational institutions.

The nine-judge 6thCircuit Court of Appeals heard arguments in two cases that
could significantly alter admissions policies at such schools as the
University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, the University of Chicago and
Northwestern.

The cases involve admissions policies at the undergraduate college at the
University of Michigan's flagship campus in Ann Arbor and the Michigan law
school. They are virtually the only such cases still pending and are
expected to end up in the U.S. Supreme Court.

The judges asked whether an attempt to achieve racial diversity on campus
might become something like an unconstitutional quota system. The questions
went to the heart of the university's position, which is that the goal of
diversity is a compelling governmental interest that allows them to take
race into account in admissions.

Judge Danny Boggs, the most persistent questioner, said he was sympathetic
to the educational value of diversity but expressed concern that the
university's methods were just "a way of getting numbers."

At one point Boggs said a quota system restricting Jews to 15 percent of the
Harvard student body in the 1930s had been defended at the time as ensuring
that too many Jews didn't endanger Harvard's diversity.

John Payton, the lead counsel for the university, said Michigan's policies
are a way of getting a "critical mass" of qualified minority students so
they weren't isolated or defined by others as stereotypes.

In sparring that prompted courtroom laughter, Boggs asked whether Michigan
might logically award favorable admissions treatment to Southern Baptists if
it deemed they were underrepresented.

But Miranda Massie, an attorney representing students supporting the
university, responded that Southern Baptists might indeed warrant special
consideration if their lack of access to top quality education was a "major
impediment to social progress in our nation."

Hundreds of high school and college students, many of whom had come in
busses from Michigan, held a rain-soaked rally about affirmative action
about a block from the courthouse before the session began.

Affirmative action in higher education has been in retreat over the last
decade as courts have struck down school policies and states have pulled
back from previous programs.

California, Texas and Florida have replaced such policies with controversial
systems allowing a percentage of top high school students into the best
state schools.

But at many schools diversity remains a key goal and admissions offices use
race-based policies to achieve it.

"This is not just about the University of Michigan and this is not just
about public institutions, but all of higher education because every
institution takes race into account," said University of Michigan President
Lee Bollinger before the hearing.

Michigan officials argue that if they lose, recruiting programs targeting
minorities or "bridge" programs that help minorities become eligible for
admission, like one that exists at the University of Illinois, could be
ruled unconstitutional.

The two cases, both filed in 1997, were brought by Jennifer Gratz, a young
white woman denied admission as an undergraduate at Ann Arbor, and Barbara
Grutter, a white woman in her 40s who was rejected by the law school.

Different federal district judges ruled on them about a year ago. The Gratz
case judge upheld the university policy and the Grutter case judge ruled
against it.

Both cases depend heavily on interpretations of the 1978 Bakke decision of
the Supreme Court.

That ruling threw out quota systems for admitting minorities but has been
widely interpreted to mean that diversity is a compelling governmental
interest and schools can use race in admission decisions to further that
interest.

The Center for Individual Rights has challenged the methodology schools have
used to factor in race and the constitutionality of any use of race in
admissions, including for the purpose of fostering diversity.

The appeals court is expected to rule in months and the cases are being
closely watched in Illinois. "We make a major effort on the recruiting and
enrolling side to get as many students of color as possible," said Michael
Behnke, dean of college enrollment at the U. of C.

"The fear on our part would be a decision to ban the use of race in the
admissions process in any way."
	


Adam W. Herbert
Regents Professor and Executive Director
The Florida Center for Public Policy and Leadership
University of North Florida
12000 Alumni Way
Jacksonville, Florida   32224
Phone:  904-620-4400
Fax:      904-620-4405
email:  aherbert@unf.edu
http://thefloridacenter.unf.edu

> Medows speeds toward confirmation 
> Rhonda Medows, a former physician at Mayo Clinic and medical director for
> Blue Cross Blue Shield of Florida, appears to be speeding toward easy
> confirmation by the Florida Senate. 
> Gov. Jeb Bush tapped Medows in July to head up the Agency for Health Care
> Administration, the state agency responsible for regulating hospitals,
> health maintenance organizations and nursing homes and for running
> Florida's $8 billion-plus Medicaid program. 
> Last week the Senate Health, Aging and Long-Term Care Committee
> unanimously approved the choice of Medows. A final vote by the Senate is
> expected during the 2002 session. 
> Medows told senators she felt privileged to head up AHCA since she grew up
> in a poor family in New York and her family was forced to rely on Medicaid
> for medical assistance. 
> "As a past recipient of Medicaid services as a child ... I have a better
> understanding of what recipients need," said Medows, who specialized in
> family medicine while practicing at Mayo Clinic from 1993 to 2000. 
> She worked for Blue Cross Blue Shield from 2000 until earlier this year. 
> "I am here to fulfill a debt. I have a debt to pay to take care of those
> people who took care of me when my family could not afford to do so." 
> Medows was asked a handful of questions by senators, including whether she
> favors wholesale changes to the certificate-of-need process for hospitals
> and clinics. 
> Medows was worried about delays in approving new facilities, but that she
> has not decided whether to press for sweeping changes during the 2002
> session. 
> Medows also touted "Health Flex" plans as a way to improve access to
> health insurance. 
> The measure, which already is moving through the House, would allow
> insurers to offer stripped-down policies to companies as a pilot program
> in the three areas of the state with the highest number of uninsureds.

From:	Yablonski, Brian <brian.yablonski@myflorida.com>

-----Original Message-----
From: JLRttag@cs.com [mailto:JLRttag@cs.com]
Sent: Saturday, December 08, 2001 12:01 PM
To: brian.yablonski@myflorida.com
Subject: Ag issues-draft


TO: Brian Yablonski, Office of the Governor 
FROM: J. Luis Rodriguez 
DATE: December 8, 2001 
RE: Critical issues for Florida Agriculture 

Thank you for the opportunity to provide an outline of critical issues facing Florida agriculture. I look forward to meeting with you Monday to discuss these matters. 


Country of Origin legislation. This consumer right-to-know issue is included in the House passed farm bill and in the farm bill presently being considered by the Senate. Representative Mary Bono and Senator Bob Graham are providing leadership with a broad base of support in each chamber. Consumers want to know where their food is grown for reasons of food safety and quality because of the wide variance in the environmental, pesticide and farm labor regulation in various countries. The legislation is patterned after the 1979 Florida Produce Labeling act. Opposition comes from food chains who profit from low cost imported fruits and vegetables. Cost of enforcement is minimal although opponents claim that enforcement would cost $60 million per year. This is a much exaggerated figure, but even if true, this would amount to 1 cent per consumer per week. This issue is extremely important to our winter vegetable growers 

Citrus canker. Adequate funding of USDA canker efforts and establishment of a policy for compensating losses from citrus canker based on a "grove acres" basis, not on a "net tree acres" basis, to include the additional acreage required by governmental regulation of land and water resources for operation of a commercial citrus business. Citrus canker is primarily a Florida problem. Also USDA/APHIS could send additional inspectors to Florida's ports of entry. 
Tomato Suspension Agreement. In 1996 the Florida tomato industry filed an antidumping suit against Mexican producers alleging dumping of tomatoes in the U.S. Market. The Department of Commerce found preliminary dumping margins. The Mexican Tomato industry and DOC reached an agreement under a suspension agreement. The suspension agreement is on its 5th year of enforcement. It is presently under sunset review by DOC. Almost since the beginning there have been enforcement problems with the agreement and Florida growers believe that the agreement has no teeth. A meeting of Secretary Don Evans with growers would go a long way toward resolving the differences that exist. 

Farmworker housing. Through the Governor's Farm Worker Housing Initiative, a $10 million federal grant was obtained from USDA from funds appropriated by Congress in response to the request of Governor Bush. Three projects are underway in areas of great need in Hillsborough and Lee County. The Florida Housing Finance Corporation has augmented this statewide effort to deliver affordable rural housing through community-based nonprofit developers. This significant federal/state initiative needs to be continued and expanded to benefit farmworkers and rural Florida. USDA could add $10 million additional to the regular yearly allocation for Florida to be leveraged by FHFC resources. 

Immigration reform. Support for compromise and passage of H-2A Reform and Agricultural Worker Adjustment Act, as proposed by Sen.Gordon Smith and Sen. Bob Graham. 
. 
Conservation. Increased funding of the conservation title of the farm bill, as an aspect of federal farm policy particular important to Florida and other Southern states. This includes the Wetlands Reserve Program (WRP) which assists willing landowners to restore wetlands that have been damaged by agricultural production, thus maximizing wildlife values. 
<>

From:	Moore, Tim <TimMoore@fdle.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Monday, December 10, 2001 7:56 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	OSI
Subject:	FW: "Goner" virus writers

Interesting!
 
tim
 
 
Israelis Confess to Internet Attack


	
Updated: Sat, Dec 08 4:58 PM EST	

	
By LAURIE COPANS, Associated Press Writer 

JERUSALEM (AP) - Four Israeli youths in police custody have admitted to
creating and spreading the computer worm "Goner" by e-mail to attack
hundreds of users around the world, police said Saturday. 


Police arrested the high school students, ages 15 and 16, from the northern
city of Nahariya on Friday, said Meir Zohar, the head of the police computer
crime squad. 


The Internet worm first spread early this month to computers in Europe,
especially in France and Germany. American anti-virus companies have
reported more than 400 cases of Goner attacks worldwide. An Internet worm
can spread to other computers on its own. 



The Goner worm appears as an apparently harmless e-mail, with a subject line
of "Hi" and a note asking the recipient to open an attached screen saver,
which affects the computer if downloaded. The worm then spreads to all
addresses in the computer's e-mail system and through the instant messaging
program ICQ and Internet chat tools. 


Israeli police had been investigating the case for about a week, Zohar said.
One of the youths had admitted creating the worm and the other three
confessed to spreading it, he said. 


Under Israeli law, the suspects could face between three and five years in
jail if convicted, Zohar said.

-----Original Message-----
From: Bahrami, Kimberly [mailto:Kim.Bahrami@MyFlorida.com]
Sent: Friday, December 07, 2001 2:01 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: RE: STO and Bobby 


Governor,
 
The TimeDirect system was originally developed in 1999 and the program
has been significantly enhanced since that time to respond to needs and
comments of our customers.  These enhancements include increased
accessibility for the system.  Some previous accessiblity issues with
the system were quickly resolved with an upgrade to the user's
accessibility tool.  The STO works closely with Julie Shaw and the ADA
Working Group to solve issues such as these, and, in checking with Julie
on this issue, she is not aware of any unresolved accessibility issues
with TimeDirect.  The email does not specifically mention any
accessibility problem but rather stresses the importance of testing the
system with the Bobby Program.  I will check on whether a new issue has
arisen.  However, the STO does not set its accessibility standard
relative to results from the Bobby Program.  The Bobby Program is not a
true measure of accessibility and is generally seen as an introduction
to the issue.  Many Web sites may pass a Bobby review and yet remain
inaccessible.   Again, we work closely with Julie and others on this
issue, and they do not recommend the Bobby approach.  For Web site
accessibility, our standard is Section 508 of the Rehabilitation Act -
the current and significantly more comprehensive federal standard.
 
I understand the Department of Health issue has been ongoing since
November 2000.  Julie Shaw was made aware of the situation in October of
this year and brought it to the attention of the STO last month.  I
understand a work analysis evaluation has been performed by the Division
of Blind Services, the solution is now a top priority within DOH, and
the problem will be fixed in two to three months.  I am also working
with the CIOs to insert a "web accessibility" component into our
statewide applications procurement and development processes.  I will
continue to monitor this issue. 
 
If you would like to discuss further, please let me know.
 
Kim

Dear Governor Bush: 

Thank you for forwarding my e-mail to the appropriate persons who handle

Times Direct system.  I have spoken with Donna Livingston at DMS about
the 
issue and hopefully they will test the system with the Bobby program to
make 
it more accessible.  It may not cost a lot of money either since many of
the 
changes that the Bobby Program includes are simple.  I strongly
encouraged 
her to work on this problem since the state does not want to be put in a

position of looking as though it does not care if it complies with
federal 
laws.  The ADA is not a voluntary law.  I don't think the state can
argue 
hardship either because it knew before the system was purchased that the

Bobby program should be included and used to make it accessible. I don't

know why the STO did not check this before they bought the program.  

I have a friend who works for the Department of Health and she is having
the 
same problem with their statewide program used for case management.  The

department of Health was told before they ever purchased this case 
management program that it was not accessible to the disabled however,
they 
purchased it anyway. Since that department receives federal money they
are 
in an awkward position because they could be sued under several
different 
laws including the OFCCP and probably the DOJ. Ninety per cent of her
job is 
computer work and since they have installed this new program she is
unable 
to do her job because the entire program is icon based and totally 
inaccessible to blind persons who use speech programs.  It also uses a
blue 
screen which makes Braille displays unusable and prevents her from using
an 
Optacon which is an old device that people used to use to read displays 
before speech programs were created.  This lady, Ms. Elizabeth Bowden,
has 
worked with the Vocational Rehabilitation program for ten years and now 
because of this badly designed Department of Health Case Management
system, 
she will probably have to be moved to another position through no fault
of 
her own and will have to move from the job that she does very well.  She
is 
a VR Technician and has handled the job well until now. By the way, the 
Comptroller's office program for Employee Earnings Statement review
works 
very well and is totally accessible.   

I am letting you know these things, because  the STO is falling down on
the 
job in making the state's computer systems more efficient and user
friendly. 
Some of the staff  also have the attitude that its just not important
and 
we've never had a blind employee before so we just didn't know.   I
think it 
is very important especially when the state may be subject to being sued

when that is not necessary if precautions  are taken. Also,not having
had to 
deal with disabled employees before is not an excuse especially when
there 
are programs like Bobby available to assist in making programs
compliant. 

Sincerely, 

Linda Mathis

-----Original Message-----
From: Nina Strickland/Greg K. Sloan, M.D. [mailto:fca@digitalexp.com]
Sent: Friday, December 07, 2001 2:16 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: Representative Donald Brown; Senator Durell Peaden
Subject: The "Newer Kinder" Medicare (CMS)


Dear Governor Bush,
 
I am writing this letter to comment on the "newer, kinder" Centers for
Medicare and Medicaid Services.  I certainly have not found them to be
any less frustrating than usual.
 
Have you looked at the Provider Application process lately?  We I have!
I am in process of completing an application for a physician who will be
joining our group soon.  When I signed onto the CMA website to print the
application, I was overwhelmed, to say the least, to find that one
section of the application was 57 pages long, one section was 67 pages
long, one section was 31 pages long and just the reassignment of
benefits form was 9 pages long.  Maybe you would not be intimated by the
sheer volume of these applications but a simple working person out here
in the trenches is.  It was my understanding that the new applications,
effective November, 2001, were simpler, clearer and easier. But looking
at these I sure don't feel that they are simpler, clearer and easier.  
 
I did receive The Florida Medicare B Update on Saturday, December 1
which included information regarding a "FREE" Provider Enrollment
Workshop to be held in Jacksonville, FL on December 13 or 14th.  It
stated that we should "Register Early, because "Seating is limited."
However, there was no phone number, fax number etc to facilitate that
happening.  When I finally did get a phone number for Provider Education
(not an 800# by the way) 904-791-6422 and I began calling on Monday,
Dec. 3 to register I was instructed to leave a detailed message.  I did
this including my phone number, fax number, and e-mail address where I
could be reached.  I noted that I needed confirmation that I would be
able to attend so that I could make travel and motel arrangements as I
am approx 6-7 hours away.  I have now made 26 long distance phone calls
as well as spending my time which is very valuable to me. By the time I
incur travel/hotel costs along with the time and phone calls, this
certainly will not have been "FREE" to me.  By Monday, if I were to get
a response by then, I will have only 2 days left to make arrangements to
attend. 
 
Let me stress, it is very important to me to attend this workshop!!
Having been through the application process several times previously
with disastrous results I was so excited to think that I might get my
"questions answered directly by a Medicare Expert" who will give me
"on-the-spot" assistance in completing and submitting my enrollment
applications.  
 
I have always supported you and felt that you were supportive of the
people in this state and the medical community.  I will certainly
appreciate it if you can offer any assistance to a small rural town
physician's office in your state.
 
Nina Strickland, CPC CMA
Practice Administrator
Family Care Associates of NW Florida
925 Carlisle Road
Chipley, FL   32428
(850) 638-1634
Fax (850) 638-3720
fca@digitalexp.com

-----Original Message-----
From: WashEcon@aol.com [mailto:WashEcon@aol.com]
Sent: Sunday, December 09, 2001 6:59 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Re: Northwest Florida Daily News Article / Fishkind.


Governor, good evening!  Yes, I was surprised also that Senator Mackay stated that it was Hank and his firm that did the plan for him. At our very first Council of Economic Advisors meeting, there was consensus that the current tax system of our state did not need major reform. This was based on a study that Council member Randy Holcombe of FSU completed. Randy has testified several times about his perspectives to the Tax Reform Commission. So Hank is on his owm on this one. You know my views a-) Current tax system has served the State well as tax receipts pretty much track the growth of the economy.  In the future we do need to continue lowering taxes on saving and inputs of production--the last thing we want to do is broaden the base as per Mackay's proposal.b) Discussing the Senator's proposal in this session only adds further uncertainty to an already uncertain economic outllook. c) The proposed reform sounds "good" from a revenue technical perspective only  (I can get you revenue neutrality anytime in a comparative static setting by broadening the base enough and lowering the rate). The problem are the adverse dynamic impacts on investment and economic growth that are not considered in this proposal.
I am sure Council can discuss at next meeting, Randy, Steve Morrell and I among others would be glad to testify in strong  opposition to the proposal. 
On a lighter note, How about my LSU tigers!!!! We avenged the Florida loss! Excuse the green tint in screen but I am in TJ's computer. Un abrazo, Tony Villamil.

-----Original Message-----
From: Charles Lee [mailto:chlee2@earthlink.net]
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 11:38 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Everglades Water Quality Standard



I spent much of yesterday in a briefing by DEP General Counsel Teri
Donaldson, Ernie Barnett, and Frank Nearhoof on what they represented to
me to be DEP's position regarding the Everglades phosphorus standard. 

Based on their briefing, I remain gravely concerned that what is about
to be proposed will have the following effects: 

* Initiate 3 years or more of gratuitous litigation. Instead of the
"best and brightest" at DEP and SFWMD being able to focus on how to
ATTAIN the standard already in the law (10ppb) their time and energies
will be dissipated by having to defend a rule to before an
administrative law judge. Since the 10ppb standard is ALREADY in the
law, there is NO value added here, only RISK. 

* Subject the formulation of a "compliance methodology" to the more
difficult standards of rulemaking rather than keeping it within the more
manageable confines of the permit process. The Everglades Forever Act
has NO directive to DEP that authorizes a rule on compliance
methodology. Compliance methodology is discussed in a SEPARATE
subsection of the Everglades Forever Act with NO authority to adopt a
rule attached to it (the Legislature easily COULD have granted DEP
rulemaking authority associated with the compliance methodology, but
chose not to). 

DEP has attempted to adopt rules under similar circumstances recently,
and has LOST rule challenges on similar points. See:

 State of Florida, Board of Trustees of the Internal Improvement Trust
Fund v. Day Cruise Association, 1st District Court of Appeal, September
13, 2001

I have not yet seen the draft rule language. In the briefing yesterday,
the DEP staff only showed me "bullet points"of what the rule would
contain on the points of the criterion (10ppb), compliance methodology,
and "net improvement" of impacted areas. 

Many of the "bullet points" sounded pretty good as to what the rule
would contain, but I can't assess them with certainty until I see the
actual rule language. 

However, no matter how good the draft rule appears on first blush, its
benefits will be illusory if they create an unnecessary new round of
litigation that the state is at risk of losing, or at best dissipating
its energies and public funds in over the next several years.

Far better course of action: 

*  Announce a decision to rely on 10ppb default standard in the law
because rulemaking to put the same number in a rule is redundant, and
exposes the state to unnecessary litigation.

* Deal with "compliance methodology" in long term permits as originally
envisioned by the Everglades Forever Act, which must be considered by
DEP in 2003.

Charles

-----Original Message-----
From: Tinker Cooper [mailto:tinkerfad@cfl.rr.com]
Sent: Sunday, December 09, 2001 12:28 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Bright Futures Scholarships


Hi Jeb,
Below is a concern I've heard from many parents about these scholarships
from parents whose kids are blowing college and using this money for drugs.
They are very concerned that the checks go to the student.  Is there a
better way of handling these scholarships?

Dear Tinker
At the last FAD meeting you asked me to e-mail you this concern.  I thought
you might have the opportunity to point this out to the governor.
The easiest way to explain this is just to use my son as an example.
Andrew received a Bright Futures Scholarship and whatever is not used each
semester will be sent to him in the form of a check.  He has figured out he
will receive $1200 in Feb.  This is because we have the Florida Prepaid.  To
me it would be better if the money could only be used for college expenses
and the college would draw it out of an account with the student's name on
it.  It could be used for fees, books, or help with dorm expenses.  Whatever
isn't used goes back to the state of Florida and not to the student. Andrew
informed me the state is stopping the Bright Futures Scholarship, but  I
think this happens with all state scholarships.  My daughter received the
Gold Seal scholarship. She got a check each semester and blew it all which
in  total was $6000-$7000.  I believe many of these kids that receive this
money use it for drugs.  I will hope and pray when Andrew gets his, he uses
it in a responsible manner.   He says it will go in his savings for a car,
but who knows.
 Thanks for all you do,
 Carolyn Clarke

-----Original Message-----
From: Peter Merhige [mailto:peter@trishield.net]
Sent: Sunday, December 09, 2001 1:42 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: RE: Florida Building Code


Dear Governor Bush:

I am not sure if you recieved this email, since you responded to the
first
one I sent both times. I send it again only for the very strong points
our
team has brought up on special session.

I know you must be extremely busy and I appreciate your timely response
to
my email. I also appreciate the attention you are paying to this very
important bill.

Our team has been reviewing the actions in Tallahassee with our legal
team
and other very interested parties around the country and would like to
ask
the following questions about the actions from earlier this week.

1: Due to the fact that the issue of the Florida Building Code was
outside
the purview of the call, doesn't the fact that President McKay allowed
this
bill to be heard during special session allude to special interest
activity
not in the best interest of the citizens of the state of Florida. As you
are
well aware this process started in 1996 with the building code study
commission. In 1998 the commission issued the single statewide building
code
and was agreed upon as being in the best interest of the state of
Florida.
It is now approaching 2002 and there are several states that have
adopted
building codes that incorporate hurricane protection, while our
legislature
has continuously delayed this very important code.

2: Many are questioning the legality of the actions taken during the
session
of the House pertaining to the delay of the Florida Building Code. Many
wonder if this was constitutionally correct.

3: Another point that has been brought to my attention is the language
in
the amendment to the Senate Bill 52C. The amendment states "design
professional who have been preparing construction documents in
anticipation
of the current Florida Law stipulating the implementation day for
January 1,
2002, may have their projects governed by the Florida Building Code that
would have been in effect". How can allowing this particular industry to
not
be financially affected by the delay, and other industries allowed to be
financially effected by the delay, not be a very harmful form of
discrimination.

As we are all aware right now more than ever, the safety and security of
our
families and children are of the utmost importance. The stringent
requirements of the new code, does nothing but enhance the safety and
security of our great state of Florida.

As I eluded to in my previous email, I ask once again for the
opportunity to
meet with you or speak to via telephone on this very important issue for
all
parties involved before you make judgment on this bill. There is a
solution
that everyone can be happy with.

Respectfully,

Peter Merhige
Protective Glass Industries
2546 Fowler Street
Ft Myers, FL 33901
941-936-4227
941-936-2237 fax
www.trishield.net
