From: Peter Merhige [mailto:peter@trishield.net]
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 5:26 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Florida Building Code


Dear Governor Bush,

I am writing to express my disappointment and disbelief that The Senate
and
House has once again voted to delay the Florida Building Code. I wrote
to
you last week expressing my feelings and giving you an understanding of
what
the severity of this action means to our company, but I feel I must do
it
again, since you are the last possible chance I have to save my
business.

My name is Peter Merhige and my company is Protective Glass Industries,
located in Ft Myers, Florida. My company was formed over 2 years ago for
the
purpose of developing and bringing to market a new product for the
hurricane
protection markets. The reason for forming the company and products was
for
the potential in the hurricane markets mainly due to the
development of the new Florida building code (THE CODE IN WHICH YOU
AGREED
WAS GOOD FOR FLORIDA) that contains hurricane protection. We have
designed
and have patents pending on the finest impact glass product in the
industry.
Not only does it protect from hurricane damage but also due to it's
insulating properties, reduces the cost of energy. We have spent well
over
$1,000,000 on the development and commercialization of our products and
due
to several delays in the statewide building code; we have lost millions
of
dollars. Over the last 2 days, I have lost close to $1 MILLION in
investment
money because of the actions in Tallahassee. Not only has our company
spent
over $1,000,000 but also there has been millions and millions of dollars
already spent to develop this code, along with millions and millions of
dollars spent by companies to enhance their products to meet the new
codes.
There are hundreds of companies ready to provide product for these new
building codes and there has been more than ample time to prepare for
it.

I do not know how to make this any clearer than to tell you that all of
mine
and all of my loyal employees' hard work to develop our products and
bring
them to market over the last 2+ years is over unless you help. We had
the
potential to create over 100 jobs for the state of Florida with revenues
over $100 million dollars over the next 3 years, which would obviously
be
put back into the Florida economy while protecting your citizens. We
have
close to 20 companies that were getting set to come to market with our
glass
the first of the year because of your code, and due to the delay, they
will
not until March (if the code doesn't get eliminated all together). Due
to
this delay and the uncertainty of Tallahassee which makes my investors
uncomfortable enough to not invest, I will not be able to keep the doors
open. Your are really my last hope to see that Tallahassee actually
thinks
of it's citizens over their own personal agendas.

We worked very hard to present ideas that would make sense for everyone
and
had some really good suggestions, but because of obvious personal
agendas,
we were ignored. Presently Senators McKay, Clary and Constatine along
with
Representative Bennet, who have businesses in the construction industry,
stated that Florida's counties were not ready for the code. Ourselves,
The
Florida League of Cities, AIF and many more, have proof through the DCA
that
only 8% of Florida was not ready to enforce the code.

We suggested that all counties not ready be given a 60 day delay to get
prepared and the other 92% who have worked extremely hard to do what you
wanted, enforce the code as scheduled. I cannot, even in my worst
nightmares, imagine how this would not satisfy everyone if that was
their
true objections. Obviously it was not and Politics once again was
Politics.

As I stated, you are our last chance. We are not alone. There are many
companies that will be put out of business because of this action. I do
know
you have the power to make this right. I am begging you for the
opportunity
to meet with you to politely express the feelings and concerns of our
company and our industry before you sign the bill to put us out of
business.
I don't think this is an unfair request since Tallahassee has
potentially
stripped my life from me.

I hope to hear from you or your office soon.

Respectfully,

Peter Merhige
Protective Glass Industries
2546 Fowler Street
Ft Myers, FL 33901
941-936-4227
941-936-2237 fax
www.trishield.net

-----Original Message-----
From: Peter Merhige [mailto:peter@trishield.net]
Sent: Sunday, December 09, 2001 1:42 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: RE: Florida Building Code


Dear Governor Bush:

I am not sure if you recieved this email, since you responded to the first
one I sent both times. I send it again only for the very strong points our
team has brought up on special session.

I know you must be extremely busy and I appreciate your timely response to
my email. I also appreciate the attention you are paying to this very
important bill.

Our team has been reviewing the actions in Tallahassee with our legal team
and other very interested parties around the country and would like to ask
the following questions about the actions from earlier this week.

1: Due to the fact that the issue of the Florida Building Code was outside
the purview of the call, doesn't the fact that President McKay allowed this
bill to be heard during special session allude to special interest activity
not in the best interest of the citizens of the state of Florida. As you are
well aware this process started in 1996 with the building code study
commission. In 1998 the commission issued the single statewide building code
and was agreed upon as being in the best interest of the state of Florida.
It is now approaching 2002 and there are several states that have adopted
building codes that incorporate hurricane protection, while our legislature
has continuously delayed this very important code.

2: Many are questioning the legality of the actions taken during the session
of the House pertaining to the delay of the Florida Building Code. Many
wonder if this was constitutionally correct.

3: Another point that has been brought to my attention is the language in
the amendment to the Senate Bill 52C. The amendment states "design
professional who have been preparing construction documents in anticipation
of the current Florida Law stipulating the implementation day for January 1,
2002, may have their projects governed by the Florida Building Code that
would have been in effect". How can allowing this particular industry to not
be financially affected by the delay, and other industries allowed to be
financially effected by the delay, not be a very harmful form of
discrimination.

As we are all aware right now more than ever, the safety and security of our
families and children are of the utmost importance. The stringent
requirements of the new code, does nothing but enhance the safety and
security of our great state of Florida.

As I eluded to in my previous email, I ask once again for the opportunity to
meet with you or speak to via telephone on this very important issue for all
parties involved before you make judgment on this bill. There is a solution
that everyone can be happy with.

Respectfully,

Peter Merhige
Protective Glass Industries
2546 Fowler Street
Ft Myers, FL 33901
941-936-4227
941-936-2237 fax
www.trishield.net

From: Peter Merhige [mailto:peter@trishield.net]
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 5:26 PM

Subject: Florida Building Code


Dear Governor Bush,

I am writing to express my disappointment and disbelief that The Senate
and
House has once again voted to delay the Florida Building Code. I wrote
to
you last week expressing my feelings and giving you an understanding of
what
the severity of this action means to our company, but I feel I must do
it
again, since you are the last possible chance I have to save my
business.

My name is Peter Merhige and my company is Protective Glass Industries,
located in Ft Myers, Florida. My company was formed over 2 years ago for
the
purpose of developing and bringing to market a new product for the
hurricane
protection markets. The reason for forming the company and products was
for
the potential in the hurricane markets mainly due to the
development of the new Florida building code (THE CODE IN WHICH YOU
AGREED
WAS GOOD FOR FLORIDA) that contains hurricane protection. We have
designed
and have patents pending on the finest impact glass product in the
industry.
Not only does it protect from hurricane damage but also due to it's
insulating properties, reduces the cost of energy. We have spent well
over
$1,000,000 on the development and commercialization of our products and
due
to several delays in the statewide building code; we have lost millions
of
dollars. Over the last 2 days, I have lost close to $1 MILLION in
investment
money because of the actions in Tallahassee. Not only has our company
spent
over $1,000,000 but also there has been millions and millions of dollars
already spent to develop this code, along with millions and millions of
dollars spent by companies to enhance their products to meet the new
codes.
There are hundreds of companies ready to provide product for these new
building codes and there has been more than ample time to prepare for
it.

I do not know how to make this any clearer than to tell you that all of
mine
and all of my loyal employees' hard work to develop our products and
bring
them to market over the last 2+ years is over unless you help. We had
the
potential to create over 100 jobs for the state of Florida with revenues
over $100 million dollars over the next 3 years, which would obviously
be
put back into the Florida economy while protecting your citizens. We
have
close to 20 companies that were getting set to come to market with our

thinks
of it's citizens over their own personal agendas.

and

agendas,

with

stated that Florida's counties were not ready for the code. Ourselves,

Florida League of Cities, AIF and many more, have proof through the DCA
that

Subject: RE: Gerstner Seawall: Indian River County



Dear Gov. Bush: I have not heard from Mr. Stutler.  I realize other agencies have review authority regarding the HCP & the Section 10 permit.  I have been advised that your influence is what is needed to allow me to finish my seawall.  For two years I have been asking to do just that.  The alleged "take" created by my seawall is mitigated by the Section 10/Interim Agreement.  In my meeting with David Struhs and Mr. Stutler and their staff 4/30/01, Chairman Ginn & I were assured that there was no movement afoot to make approval of the Section 10 contingent on removing our project from coverage under the permit.  Chairman Ginn still has her doubts regarding that issue, but we have been further assured that eventually the Habitat Conservation Plan with the Section 10 will be approved & implemented.  With that assurance in mind, may I finish my wall?  The cost of completing the wall is one-half the cost of moving it a few feet.  I am asking you to intervene on our behalf.   This is complicated only if it is made so.  Thanks Again, Cheryl Gerstner

-----Original Message-----
From: Cheryl Gerstner [mailto:cigerstner@yahoo.com]
Sent: Friday, November 30, 2001 5:50 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Gerstner Seawall: Indian River County


Dear Gov. Bush: Since January of 1997, I have been trying to complete my
seawall needed to protect what is left of my oceanfront property & my home
in Indian River Bounty. I have been in communication with you on this
matter since February 2000. As you may recall, this 5 year controversy is
over the position of the DEP that the wall is 15 feet too far seaward, and
therfore represents a "take" of turtle habitat. We have through your
efforts, those of local officials, and our own been given a permit to move
the wall as few as 8 feet. We continue to request that we be allowed to
complete the wall in its as-built location for several reasons. The primary
reason is the expense. At $850 a foot, it would cost $78,200 to move this
wall even 1 foot. Some quotes are as high as $1000.00 a foot. We have also
resisted moving the wall for reasons of value to our primary asset, because
we have documented the inconsistencies regarding the placement of permitted
wals elsewhere, and because we know that moving our wall is not going to
make a significant difference. The scuttlebut is that the unwillingness of
the decision makers to reach the obvious conclusion regarding the "Gerstner
Wall" is their fear of setting a precendent. It is not this decision that
willset a precendent; the inconsistent application of the rules and regs has
already established that "opening". What hasn't yet happened is a court
case to expose those Inconsistencies. Noone wants to be the one to take on
that task, and is it really necessary? Chairwoman Ginn if in Tallahassee
today and may contact you to make this same appeal. I know there are
agencies that could not tolerate a $100,000 budget cut. Please consider
what it represents to me and my family and weigh that cost against the gain.
You are acutely aware of the critical condition of our beaches. Seawalls
are only temporary structures that buy time until the conditions dictating
their need can be cured. We need sand by-pass srojects at inlets &
nourishing programs. I would not contact you again if I did not think it
was going to take your influence to get this done. Thank you, Cheryl
Gerstner

-----Original Message----- 
From: Bush-Brogan 2002 [  < mailto:bushbrogan@jeb.org
<mailto:bushbrogan@jeb.org> > 
mailto:bushbrogan@jeb.org <mailto:bushbrogan@jeb.org> ] 
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 6:48 PM 
To: Bush-Brogan 2002 
Subject: GOVERNOR AND REPUBLICAN LEGISLATORS SHOW LEADERSHIP; FINISH 
SUCCESSFUL LEGISLATIVE SESSION 


FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE 
CONTACT: KAREN UNGER 
THURSDAY, DECEMBER 6, 2001 
850/224-4JEB 

TALLAHASSEE- During challenging times for our nation and state, Governor 
Jeb Bush and the Republican-led Legislature should be commended for 
their leadership and a successful special session. With the passage of a 
revised wartime budget, Governor Bush and the Republican-led Legislature 
have worked together to ensure that Florida's highest priorities are 
funded: 

 Education funding remains at historic levels - funding for K-12 
education has been increased during Governor Bush's tenure in office 
over $2 billion from where it was in 1998. 

 Health and human services funding, including child welfare and 
services to those in need, has increased by 31% percent since 1998. 

 Economic stimulus efforts will create 33,000 new jobs and boost 
Florida's tourism industry, still struggling as a result of the attacks 
on our nation, with $20 million for marketing campaigns. 

 $19 million in spending for various anti-terrorism and domestic 
security measures will equip our state's law and health officials with 
the tools they need to ensure that Floridians are safe. 

Even with wartime necessitated budget reductions, the state budget is 
still 20% greater than in 1998, with spending increases focused on our 
state's priorities - education, health and human services, public safety 
and the environment. Showing tremendous leadership in tough times, 
Governor Bush and the Republican-led Legislature joined together to 
overcome numerous challenges and get a difficult job done. 

The Democrat leadership and their candidates for governor, on the other 
hand, have served as mere spectators in the process. Their criticism of 
the budget and blaming of Governor Bush for the budget shortfall is 
ironic and hypocritical at best, given the facts: 

 The previous Democrat Administration left the state with a mere $1.3 
billion in reserves. Under Governor Bush's leadership, the reserves have 
been built to a record $2.9 billion - an increase of 120 percent. 
Anticipating harder times, the Governor vetoed $916 million in special 
projects to minimize Florida's spending obligations. Thanks to this 
incredible foresight and willingness to make the tough decisions, our 
state is in a position of greater financial strength. 

 Democrats in the Florida Legislature voted in favor of the last three 
budgets by 98% (1999), 100% (2000), and 89% (2001) - the same budgets 
they are now criticizing. 

 Over 90% of Democrats in the Florida Legislature voted in favor of the 
Intangibles Tax Cut in 1998, 1999, and 2000. 

"Being a leader takes more than criticizing from the sidelines. Being a 
leader means having the strength to offer realistic solutions and make 
the tough decisions," said Karen Unger, campaign manager for the 
Bush/Brogan 2002 campaign. "Governor Bush has lead. The Democrats have 
not."

From:	Peter Merhige <peter@trishield.net>
Sent:	Sunday, December 9, 2001 2:22 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: Florida Building Code

I cannot speak for the builders, nor will I say I understand their true
motivations behind their interest in delaying and eliminating the new
building code, but I do know, that they were part of the group that insisted
on 1 unified building code for the state.

My instincts tell me along with conversations I have had with many builders
in my area, that they will not build to the new standards unless made to or
asked to by the home owner.

As far as it being only a short delay, this will be the 3rd so called delay.
Another delay will only give the individuals in the Senate and House another
opportunity in January and February to push it back again, if not eliminate
it totally. I do not think we are truly speaking about delays, the
individuals will keep delaying and delaying this code until you say enough
is enough.

I mean this with absolutely no disrespect and hope you do not take it as
disrespect, but try to look at this from another angle. We work with window
companies all around the country who have spent millions and millions of
dollars in testing and product to make sure their products were able to be
sold in Florida per new code specifications. These companies have had it
with the indecision of our legislation and are growing more and more
frustrated with our process. Believe me when I say the companies we are
working with are the biggest and most powerful in our industry and for the
lack of kinder words, they are pissed about another delay because of the
money they have spent because our government said if they want to due
business in Florida, they have to make stronger products, and they have. How
much more of this will it take before Florida is in the National spotlight
again because 1 of these companies wants Florida to take responsibility for
the money they did not want to spend, but Florida said they had to.

How silly will Florida's political process look if we get hit with a storm
and as much as 1 home gets destroyed when our legislators have been pushing
their personal agendas over what I know you feel is in the best interest of
the safety and well being of all Floridians. You must VETO this bill because
the new building code is good.

I'm no politician but I think national headlines saying that Florida adopts
tougher statewide building code for hurricane and security reasons, could be
exactly what Florida needs to bring positive attention to the state and
bring people back vacationing.

-----Original Message-----
From: Peter Merhige [mailto:peter@trishield.net]
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 5:26 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Florida Building Code


Dear Governor Bush,

I am writing to express my disappointment and disbelief that The Senate
and
House has once again voted to delay the Florida Building Code. I wrote
to
you last week expressing my feelings and giving you an understanding of
what
the severity of this action means to our company, but I feel I must do
it
again, since you are the last possible chance I have to save my
business.

My name is Peter Merhige and my company is Protective Glass Industries,
located in Ft Myers, Florida. My company was formed over 2 years ago for
the
purpose of developing and bringing to market a new product for the
hurricane
protection markets. The reason for forming the company and products was
for
the potential in the hurricane markets mainly due to the
development of the new Florida building code (THE CODE IN WHICH YOU
AGREED
WAS GOOD FOR FLORIDA) that contains hurricane protection. We have
designed
and have patents pending on the finest impact glass product in the
industry.
Not only does it protect from hurricane damage but also due to it's
insulating properties, reduces the cost of energy. We have spent well
over
$1,000,000 on the development and commercialization of our products and
due
to several delays in the statewide building code; we have lost millions
of
dollars. Over the last 2 days, I have lost close to $1 MILLION in
investment
money because of the actions in Tallahassee. Not only has our company
spent
over $1,000,000 but also there has been millions and millions of dollars
already spent to develop this code, along with millions and millions of
dollars spent by companies to enhance their products to meet the new
codes.
There are hundreds of companies ready to provide product for these new
building codes and there has been more than ample time to prepare for
it.

I do not know how to make this any clearer than to tell you that all of
mine
and all of my loyal employees' hard work to develop our products and
bring
them to market over the last 2+ years is over unless you help. We had
the
potential to create over 100 jobs for the state of Florida with revenues
over $100 million dollars over the next 3 years, which would obviously
be
put back into the Florida economy while protecting your citizens. We
have
close to 20 companies that were getting set to come to market with our
glass
the first of the year because of your code, and due to the delay, they
will
not until March (if the code doesn't get eliminated all together). Due
to
this delay and the uncertainty of Tallahassee which makes my investors
uncomfortable enough to not invest, I will not be able to keep the doors
open. Your are really my last hope to see that Tallahassee actually
thinks
of it's citizens over their own personal agendas.

We worked very hard to present ideas that would make sense for everyone
and
had some really good suggestions, but because of obvious personal
agendas,
we were ignored. Presently Senators McKay, Clary and Constatine along
with
Representative Bennet, who have businesses in the construction industry,
stated that Florida's counties were not ready for the code. Ourselves,
The
Florida League of Cities, AIF and many more, have proof through the DCA
that
only 8% of Florida was not ready to enforce the code.

We suggested that all counties not ready be given a 60 day delay to get
prepared and the other 92% who have worked extremely hard to do what you
wanted, enforce the code as scheduled. I cannot, even in my worst
nightmares, imagine how this would not satisfy everyone if that was
their
true objections. Obviously it was not and Politics once again was
Politics.

As I stated, you are our last chance. We are not alone. There are many
companies that will be put out of business because of this action. I do
know
you have the power to make this right. I am begging you for the
opportunity
to meet with you to politely express the feelings and concerns of our
company and our industry before you sign the bill to put us out of
business.
I don't think this is an unfair request since Tallahassee has
potentially
stripped my life from me.

I hope to hear from you or your office soon.

Respectfully,

Peter Merhige
Protective Glass Industries
2546 Fowler Street
Ft Myers, FL 33901
941-936-4227
941-936-2237 fax
www.trishield.net



From:	Turbeville, Greg <Greg.Turbeville@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US>

From:	Peter Merhige <peter@trishield.net>
Sent:	Sunday, December 9, 2001 1:42 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: Florida Building Code

Dear Governor Bush:

I am not sure if you recieved this email, since you responded to the first
one I sent both times. I send it again only for the very strong points our
team has brought up on special session.

I know you must be extremely busy and I appreciate your timely response to
my email. I also appreciate the attention you are paying to this very
important bill.

Our team has been reviewing the actions in Tallahassee with our legal team
and other very interested parties around the country and would like to ask
the following questions about the actions from earlier this week.

1: Due to the fact that the issue of the Florida Building Code was outside
the purview of the call, doesn't the fact that President McKay allowed this
bill to be heard during special session allude to special interest activity
not in the best interest of the citizens of the state of Florida. As you are
well aware this process started in 1996 with the building code study
commission. In 1998 the commission issued the single statewide building code
and was agreed upon as being in the best interest of the state of Florida.
It is now approaching 2002 and there are several states that have adopted
building codes that incorporate hurricane protection, while our legislature
has continuously delayed this very important code.

2: Many are questioning the legality of the actions taken during the session
of the House pertaining to the delay of the Florida Building Code. Many
wonder if this was constitutionally correct.

3: Another point that has been brought to my attention is the language in
the amendment to the Senate Bill 52C. The amendment states "design
professional who have been preparing construction documents in anticipation
of the current Florida Law stipulating the implementation day for January 1,
2002, may have their projects governed by the Florida Building Code that
would have been in effect". How can allowing this particular industry to not
be financially affected by the delay, and other industries allowed to be
financially effected by the delay, not be a very harmful form of
discrimination.

As we are all aware right now more than ever, the safety and security of our
families and children are of the utmost importance. The stringent
requirements of the new code, does nothing but enhance the safety and
security of our great state of Florida.

As I eluded to in my previous email, I ask once again for the opportunity to
meet with you or speak to via telephone on this very important issue for all
parties involved before you make judgment on this bill. There is a solution
that everyone can be happy with.

Respectfully,

Peter Merhige
Protective Glass Industries
2546 Fowler Street
Ft Myers, FL 33901
941-936-4227
941-936-2237 fax
www.trishield.net

Subject:	RE: Gerstner Seawall: Indian River County

Dear Gov. Bush: I have not heard from Mr. Stutler.  I realize other agencies have review authority regarding the HCP & the Section 10 permit.  I have been advised that your influence is what is needed to allow me to finish my seawall.  For two years I have been asking to do just that.  The alleged "take" created by my seawall is mitigated by the Section 10/Interim Agreement.  In my meeting with David Struhs and Mr. Stutler and their staff 4/30/01, Chairman Ginn & I were assured that there was no movement afoot to make approval of the Section 10 contingent on removing our project from coverage under the permit.  Chairman Ginn still has her doubts regarding that issue, but we have been further assured that eventually the Habitat Conservation Plan with the Section 10 will be approved & implemented.  With that assurance in mind, may I finish my wall?  The cost of completing the wall is one-half the cost of moving it a few feet.  I am asking you to intervene on our behalf.   This is complicated only if it is made so.  Thanks Again, Cheryl Gerstner

-----Original Message-----
From: Cheryl Gerstner [mailto:cigerstner@yahoo.com]
Sent: Friday, November 30, 2001 5:50 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Gerstner Seawall: Indian River County


Dear Gov. Bush: Since January of 1997, I have been trying to complete my
seawall needed to protect what is left of my oceanfront property & my home
in Indian River Bounty. I have been in communication with you on this
matter since February 2000. As you may recall, this 5 year controversy is
over the position of the DEP that the wall is 15 feet too far seaward, and
therfore represents a "take" of turtle habitat. We have through your
efforts, those of local officials, and our own been given a permit to move
the wall as few as 8 feet. We continue to request that we be allowed to
complete the wall in its as-built location for several reasons. The primary
reason is the expense. At $850 a foot, it would cost $78,200 to move this
wall even 1 foot. Some quotes are as high as $1000.00 a foot. We have also
resisted moving the wall for reasons of value to our primary asset, because
we have documented the inconsistencies regarding the placement of permitted
wals elsewhere, and because we know that moving our wall is not going to
make a significant difference. The scuttlebut is that the unwillingness of
the decision makers to reach the obvious conclusion regarding the "Gerstner
Wall" is their fear of setting a precendent. It is not this decision that
willset a precendent; the inconsistent application of the rules and regs has
already established that "opening". What hasn't yet happened is a court
case to expose those Inconsistencies. Noone wants to be the one to take on
that task, and is it really necessary? Chairwoman Ginn if in Tallahassee
today and may contact you to make this same appeal. I know there are
agencies that could not tolerate a $100,000 budget cut. Please consider
what it represents to me and my family and weigh that cost against the gain.
You are acutely aware of the critical condition of our beaches. Seawalls
are only temporary structures that buy time until the conditions dictating
their need can be cured. We need sand by-pass srojects at inlets &
nourishing programs. I would not contact you again if I did not think it
was going to take your influence to get this done. Thank you, Cheryl
Gerstner

-----Original Message-----
From: Van Deman, Scott 
Sent: Friday, December 07, 2001 3:30 PM
To: King,Waymond
Subject: Hot Vacation Deals/flalottery.com link exchange

 
 
Secretary Griffin,
 
Good morning.  I have great news about the Florida Hot Vacation Deals/flalottery.com link exchange program I want to share with you.
 
Just as a reminder, from 11/1/01, the first day of our link exchange program, through 11/8/01, flalottery.com sent an average of 155 visitors a day to the Hot Vacation Deals web site, for a total of approximately 1,240 visitors during that time period.
 
This morning, Chris Gasparro, of Miles Media, provided me with some updated figures on how much traffic flalottery.com has referred to the Hot Vacation Deals web site.  The news is very good!
 
Here are the details:
 
*	From 11/9/01 through 12/6/01, flalottery.com has sent a total of 4,162 visitors to the Hot Vacation Deals web site. 

*	From 11/9/01 through 12/6/01, flalottery.com is sending a daily average of 148 visitors to the Hot Vacation Deals web site. 

*	Our highest daily total referrals occurred 11/25/01, when flalottery.com sent Hot Vacation Deals 243 visitors 

*	Our lowest daily total referrals occurred on 11/27/01 (the Tuesday after Thanksgiving), when flalottery.com sent Hot Vacation Deals 94 visitors.  This low figure seems to be an anomaly.  I can provide you with detailed daily figures if it would be helpful. 

*	So far during December (12/1/01 - 12/6/01), flalottery.com is sending a daily average of 153 visitors to the Hot Vacation Deals web site.  Please note that this average is remaining relatively constant more than a full month into the link exchange program. 

*	As of 8:30 a.m. this morning, 12/7/01, we have sent 15 visitors to the Hot Vacation Deals web site. 
 
Other items of interest:  Since we have activated the short button banner on the main page, and added the FLA-USA links to all of our pages, the FLA-USA web site has leapfrogged flalottery.com in the Google search engine rankings for the general search term: florida.  Currently FLA-USA ranks fourth and flalottery.com ranks sixth (before the link exchange, it was the other way around).  Since the Google ranking algorithm considers links to a web site to be a major factor in relevancy, our numerous links to FLA-USA could be a major factor in their improved ranking.
 
In addition, I believe it is significant that the traffic we are sending to the Hot Vacation Deals web site is "targeted traffic."  In other words, people aren't just "surfing on in," but rather are clicking the Hot Vacation Deals link specifically because they are interested in visiting Florida.
 
Please let me know if you have any questions or if I can provide further information or assistance.
 
Scott

Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law.


Most written communications to or from state officials
regarding state business are public records available to the
public and media upon request.   Your e-mail communications
may therefore be subject to public disclosure. 


-----Original Message-----
From: Charles Lee [mailto:chlee2@earthlink.net]
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 11:38 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Everglades Water Quality Standard


I spent much of yesterday in a briefing by DEP General Counsel Teri Donaldson, Ernie Barnett, and Frank Nearhoof on what they represented to me to be DEP's position regarding the Everglades phosphorus standard. 

Based on their briefing, I remain gravely concerned that what is about to be proposed will have the following effects: 

* Initiate 3 years or more of gratuitous litigation. Instead of the "best and brightest" at DEP and SFWMD being able to focus on how to ATTAIN the standard already in the law (10ppb) their time and energies will be dissipated by having to defend a rule to before an administrative law judge. Since the 10ppb standard is ALREADY in the law, there is NO value added here, only RISK. 

* Subject the formulation of a "compliance methodology" to the more difficult standards of rulemaking rather than keeping it within the more manageable confines of the permit process. The Everglades Forever Act has NO directive to DEP that authorizes a rule on compliance methodology. Compliance methodology is discussed in a SEPARATE subsection of the Everglades Forever Act with NO authority to adopt a rule attached to it (the Legislature easily COULD have granted DEP rulemaking authority associated with the compliance methodology, but chose not to). 

DEP has attempted to adopt rules under similar circumstances recently, and has LOST rule challenges on similar points. See: 

 State of Florida, Board of Trustees of the Internal Improvement Trust Fund v. Day Cruise Association, 1st District Court of Appeal, September 13, 2001 

I have not yet seen the draft rule language. In the briefing yesterday, the DEP staff only showed me "bullet points"of what the rule would contain on the points of the criterion (10ppb), compliance methodology, and "net improvement" of impacted areas. 

Many of the "bullet points" sounded pretty good as to what the rule would contain, but I can't assess them with certainty until I see the actual rule language. 

However, no matter how good the draft rule appears on first blush, its benefits will be illusory if they create an unnecessary new round of litigation that the state is at risk of losing, or at best dissipating its energies and public funds in over the next several years. 

Far better course of action: 

*  Announce a decision to rely on 10ppb default standard in the law because rulemaking to put the same number in a rule is redundant, and exposes the state to unnecessary litigation. 

* Deal with "compliance methodology" in long term permits as originally envisioned by the Everglades Forever Act, which must be considered by DEP in 2003. 

Charles

-----Original Message-----
From: John Hornbuckle [mailto:John.Hornbuckle@taylor.k12.fl.us]
Sent: Friday, December 07, 2001 7:59 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Thank You


Governor Bush,
   I wanted to take a moment to thank you for your efforts to increase
tourism to Florida in general and Walt Disney World in particular. I'm a
Disney stockholder and fan, so I benefit doubly when the company
thrives! I've also appreciated President Bush's comments encouraging
people to come visit. I believe Michael Eisner was down here in the same
timeframe as your visit, so you undoubtedly had the chance to speak with
him. Attendance in Disney's theme parks have been steadily picking up,
according to some friends I have who work there. I'm told that over the
Thanksgiving weekend, attendance at most of the parks was on par with
(or at least close to) last year's levels. The biggest problem is that
the occupancy rates at Disney's resorts--and the others in Orlando--are
so low. Still, at least we can see a light at the end of the tunnel.
   I also wanted to thank you for your leadership in helping us clear up
our concerns with the State Technology Office. While the issues haven't
yet been completely resolved (although I'm afraid STO may think they
have), the lines of communication have at least been opened. Dialog an
self-evaluation seem to be taking place, and that's a good thing. I'm
optimistic that the problems will be resolved once FIRN and STO can talk
a bit more.
   You might also be interested to know that I signed up through your
Web site to help the reelection campaign. I'm a long-time Republican; in
fact, I was the Treasurer of the Taylor County Young Republicans for
some time and have worked with Daryll Gunther quite a bit.
   Which leads me to my last point. THANK YOU for appointing Daryll as a
County Commissioner following the untimely death of Bea Foskey. I don't
know if Daryll has shared with you the sheer idiocy that tends to
surround our Commissioners and their actions. It's like a T.V. sitcom,
and would be comical if these goons weren't actually affecting the lives
of real people. Daryll is a breath of fresh air, and a voice of reason
on a ship of fools. He's not afraid to call a spade a spade, and I
appreciate it. He was an excellent choice, and has done an outstanding
job.


________________
John Hornbuckle
MIS Department
Taylor County School District
318 North Clark Street
Perry, FL 32347

-----Original Message-----
From: robert gaye [mailto:roberttgaye@hotmail.com]
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 10:17 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: SBA Loan Request



Hon. Governor Jeb Bush: 

Thanks for your support.  I was overwhelmed by the support shown for 
Transtar by the President, HUD Secretary Martinez, Mayor Hood, and you at 
the recent Town Hall Meeting.  However, the feedback from Thomas Butler of 
the SBA is that Transtar exceeds the size standards for small businesses.  
Therefore, the loan application that would provide the assistance necessary 
for Transtar to resume doing business at Orlando International Airport has 
been declined. 

I find myself asking for your urgent help in this matter.  Transtar was very 
important to this community, as it employed over 250 people.  The shutting 
down of Transtar had a direct impact on nearly 1000 individuals, not to 
mention Transtar's local suppliers and their employees. 

Transtar was dealt a deathblow by the events of September 11.  As you can 
imagine, time is of the essence.  Transtar faces several major challenges in 
the next few days.  Cancellation of the OIA contract is pending if no help 
is forthcoming. If the OIA contract is cancelled and the bond is called, it 
is not likely that Transtar or myself will ever be able to do business again 
with the Greater Orlando Aviation Authority.  Even with financial help to 
resume operations, Transtar faces additional challenges in structuring an 
ongoing relationship with GOAA. 

Over the past 16 years, I have more than demonstrated my ability to survive 
in a very difficult and competitive environment.  Before September 11, I 
built the business with personal resources and private sector financing.  I 
have never applied for government-backed assistance.  However, September 11 
created special needs, which require special solutions. 

Perhaps I can appeal for a special waiver in view of the employment 
represented by Transtar and its DBE status.  Perhaps there are other forms 
of state or federal aid that can mitigate this hardship.  There are many 
compelling reasons to support efforts to get Transtar back in business.  At 
this time I really need your guidance in dealing with this matter.  Governor 
Bush, I know that you are extremely busy, and your immediate attention of 
this matter would be greatly appreciated.  Thanks again for your support and 
guidance. 

Respectfully Yours, 
Robert T. Gaye 
Transtar Transportation, Inc. 

_________________________________________________________________

Take Care,  Terry

From:	Tinker Cooper <tinkerfad@cfl.rr.com>
Sent:	Sunday, December 9, 2001 12:28 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Bright Futures Scholarships

Hi Jeb,
Below is a concern I've heard from many parents about these scholarships
from parents whose kids are blowing college and using this money for drugs.
They are very concerned that the checks go to the student.  Is there a
better way of handling these scholarships?

Dear Tinker
At the last FAD meeting you asked me to e-mail you this concern.  I thought
you might have the opportunity to point this out to the governor.
The easiest way to explain this is just to use my son as an example.
Andrew received a Bright Futures Scholarship and whatever is not used each
semester will be sent to him in the form of a check.  He has figured out he
will receive $1200 in Feb.  This is because we have the Florida Prepaid.  To
me it would be better if the money could only be used for college expenses
and the college would draw it out of an account with the student's name on
it.  It could be used for fees, books, or help with dorm expenses.  Whatever
isn't used goes back to the state of Florida and not to the student. Andrew
informed me the state is stopping the Bright Futures Scholarship, but  I
think this happens with all state scholarships.  My daughter received the
Gold Seal scholarship. She got a check each semester and blew it all which
in  total was $6000-$7000.  I believe many of these kids that receive this
money use it for drugs.  I will hope and pray when Andrew gets his, he uses
it in a responsible manner.   He says it will go in his savings for a car,
but who knows.
 Thanks for all you do,
 Carolyn Clarke

Sunday, December  9 
Accent  <http://www.gopbi.com/partners/pbpost/epaper/editions/today/accent.html> | Business  <http://www.gopbi.com/partners/pbpost/epaper/editions/today/business.html> | Local News  <http://www.gopbi.com/partners/pbpost/epaper/editions/today/local_news.html> | Martin/St.Lucie  <http://www.gopbi.com/partners/pbpost/epaper/editions/today/martin_stlucie.html> | News  <http://www.gopbi.com/partners/pbpost/epaper/editions/today/news.html> | Opinion  <http://www.gopbi.com/partners/pbpost/epaper/editions/today/opinion.html> | South PB County  <http://www.gopbi.com/partners/pbpost/epaper/editions/today/south_county.html> | Sports  <http://www.gopbi.com/partners/pbpost/epaper/editions/today/sports.html> 

Editorial: To cleanse Everglades, make standards tough 



The Palm Beach Post
Sunday, December 9, 2001



On Tuesday, the Florida Department of Environmental Protection will announce a number that should be no more than 10, as in 10 parts per billion. That figure should be the maximum amount of phosphorus -- found in runoff from cities and farms -- the state will allow in water that flows into the Everglades. 


In 1994, to settle the federal lawsuit over pollution entering Everglades National Park, the Legislature passed the Everglades Forever Act, a plan for restoring water quality to Florida's "river of grass." The first phase, designed to lower discharges to 50 parts per billion, has exceeded expectations. The second phase will set a permanent limit. 


The 10 parts per billion standard was set in the Everglades Forever Act. The Environmental Protection Agency approved the same limit 2 1/2 years ago for the portion of the Everglades that the Miccosukee Indians control. If the state recommends 10 parts per billion, as DEP Secretary David Struhs suggested in an interview Friday that it will, Gov. Bush's administration will agree with what most scientists have recommended for years. 


If the number seems certain, however, enforcement is not. Details of the proposal and of complex monitoring plans were not final as of Friday. DEP will deliver them Tuesday to the state Environmental Regulation Commission, which must make a final decision on pollution limits by the end of 2003. The EPA also will review the state's decision. 


Audubon of Florida had urged Mr. Struhs to do nothing before Dec. 31, non-action that under the Everglades Forever Act would have made 10 parts per billion the standard by default and made the legal challenge Mr. Struhs expects not a matter of administrative law. Opponents now can claim that the state is writing an improper rule to implement the Everglades Forever Act. In essence, the burden of proof shifts to the state. 


Among those Mr. Struhs expects to sue immediately over the tighter standards are farms and public utilities that discharge polluted water into the Everglades. Sugar farms and western areas such as Wellington and Weston routinely discharge water with phosphorus levels higher than 100 parts per billion. As recently as October, sugar growers suggested a standard of 20 to 30 parts per billion. 


Mr. Struhs defends DEP's decision by saying it is important for the state to go on the record. He is confident that his agency will win the lawsuit because, he says, the science is sound. Floridians will be able to share his confidence about the Everglades' future if the plan for enforcing the limits is strong and DEP leans on the South Florida Water Management District and its hundreds of permit-holders to comply.

Most written communications to or from state officials
regarding state business are public records available to the
public and media upon request.   Your e-mail communications
may therefore be subject to public disclosure. 



-----Original Message-----
From: Nelson E.Miner [mailto:miner@usa.net]
Sent: Friday, December 07, 2001 1:01 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Florida Building Code


&#65279;                        Nelson E. Miner
                      806 Pinecrest Avenue
                    Panama City, Fl   32401
                              USA
 
Telephone:
850-872-1607       miner@usa.net            FAX 850-872-1645

                                                               
                                                7 December 2001

	Subject:  New Building Codes 


Dear Mr. Governor;

	I have had the opportunity to be involved in many Hurricane
recoveries and
cleanup from Camille 1969-70 to Georges 1998-1999. As a practicing
Engineer in
public service for more than 35 years, I ask that you do what is
required to
NOT delay the implementations of the Florida Unified Building Code. The
people
of Florida should not be ask to adsorb the cost replacing the large
number of
building being built that will not survive the storms that visit us our
state.

	Delaying the new code is akin to not adding oil to your car when
the low oil
indicator is showing. The cost of the probable damage will far out weigh
cost
of a quart of oil. 

	The citizens of Florida need you to stand tall and firm in their
corner as a
voice of reason as others over react to events of the last few months.


	Thank you for your time and attention.

-----Original Message-----
From: Truly Burton [mailto:trulyburton@basfonline.org]
Sent: Friday, December 07, 2001 3:15 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: Lani Kahn-Drody (E-mail)
Subject: Be our Highlight Speaker @ the Builders Association in 2002 



Hey, Jeb. It's Truly Burton. I see you are hanging in there with budget
cuts, economic issues, and the like. We are doing the same down here. 

This coming year, BASF's 2002 Program Committee is planning to invite
some dynamic, unique speakers for the Association's General Membership
meetings. We are planning on five major meetings this year with a
variety of highlight speakers. We would very much like for you to be a
featured "highlight" speaker. Since we are planning our calendar now, I
was hoping we could get you to come speak to us, perhaps in either May
or September. We had asked your Scheduler once before (about 12-18
months ago) if you could come talk with us, but that did not work out. 

As we look toward the campaign season, would a debate format/candidates
forum be equally interesting to you? We'd work with your campaign staff
for the right location, moderator(s), questions prepared in advance,
etc.  

Please let us know either way, as the Committee wants to finalize the
2002 calendar and we want to save you the best spot - you are our Number
1 pick! Best of the holiday season to you and your family. Best, Truly.


Ms. Truly Burton
Government Affairs Director - Miami Dade County
Builders Association of South Florida
trulyburton@basfonline.org
305-556-6300 x 209

-----Original Message-----
From: Matt Conroy [mailto:Matt@cfl.rr.com]
Sent: Friday, December 07, 2001 6:21 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: from the cheap seats


Jeb,

I watched you an hour or so ago, I believe Channel 6 Orlando, being ask
about the budget cuts.  You didn't seem as confident this evening as you
usually are when  reporters ask questions.  I realize live one on one
interviews are hard--I wouldn't even be able to talk--however you
typically
exhibit a stronger presence.

I also received the budget fact e-mail from Karen Unger this
afternoon--which is extremely important info to get out as I have seen
similar teacher union "fact" (har har) sheets this week already too.
Your
teams fact sheet begins with:
 Budget Fact Sheet

 Even with wartime necessitated budget reductions,.......

as simply an observation from someone who certainly isn't aware of all
facts
by any means, but do recall that before Sept. 11, Fl. was looking at
500-600
million in deficit shortfalls.  If I may suggest--don't let your team
get
carried away with casting our current shortfall too heavily on 9-11.
It's
just my opinion--but that would be a dangerous place to go.  Of course
it
has had a serious impact--but that wasn't our only problem that led to
it.
Your fact sheet on the democratic votes on the intangible tax and others
were very enlightening to me and I know will be to others as well--so I
suppose my point is--you have a great deal of good hard important work
you
have done to substantiate your positions and you don't need even the
appearances of throwing too much of the budget problem on wartime
downturns.
It will only fuel unnecessitated attacks from the left.  Just an opinion
from the cheap seats!

Take care and enjoy the weekend

Matt

-----Original Message-----
From: Mike Chap [mailto:chapsieml@hotmail.com]
Sent: Sunday, December 09, 2001 6:23 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: A time to save


We know that during times of national emergency the President of these United States and the Governors of all the states in the US have unusual power. We could shut down all state and federal government for Christmas week. Giving all workers the week off (LWOP) to spend time with their families etc. This cost saving /Job saving measure would keep people employed and prevent the need to increase taxes. The cities and counties in the US should allow their people off, or participate as well. All retailers should be encouraged to let their workers take one the following weeks off after Christmas week.

During this past week off we have worked on my mothers house, my friend's house, have done a little at my home, and have built up three computers for Project Hope to give away. We have spent between $500.00-$1000.00 dollars this week, all money going into the economy. Getting needed projects done, and at the same time helping others to keep their job by buying in the local stores. 

We still have to do a lot of shopping for Christmas presents. More people would shop and do home projects if they had the time off. "A million people @ one dollar per day, is one million dollars spent per day."

We cannot lay people off and cut spending in hope of bringing prosperity back. The economy is based on cash flow. An unemployed person does not have cash flow. My Father always said, "keep things simple".

When we leave the tax base as is-to keep from having to raise taxes later. And things improve, keep excess revenue for future down turn spending. "Save during the good times to spend during the bad times."

God Bless and have a Happy Christmas!

Mike

Sent:	Sunday, December 9, 2001 7:11 AM

Jeb Bush

-----Original Message-----
From: jjmozz@juno.com [mailto:jjmozz@juno.com]
Sent: Saturday, December 08, 2001 11:47 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: ltr of 12-1-01


Dear Gov. Bush:

Thank you for your kind  note of  December 1, 2001.  I am glad you
received the newspaper article, that was run in the Plant City newspaper,
that sent you regarding the tutoring program at The West Side Boys and
Girls Club.  The program is going well and I am hoping after the lst of
the year to attract more volunteers so that we can expand it to include
more children.

I also want to thank you for the heartfelt letter of sympathy that you
sent to Margie Kincaid, that was read at the memorial service for Bill
Kincaid this past Thursday.  Your personal reference to the fact that
Bill Kincaid liked to play the piano and that Bill's one regret was that
he wasn't able to play the piano at the White House.  You also mentioned
that when you heard the piano playing in the White House you would think
of Bill Kincaid was very special.

My husband and I feel very fortunate to live in Florida where we have a
great Governor but also a Governor, who is thoughtful and compassionate
and listens to the "little people."

Our best wishes go out to you and your family this Holiday Season.

Sincerely,
Joyce Mozzicato
Plant City, Fl.

would take President Bush's council of being vigilant if our own FBI won't

the United States!? .

concerning my knowledge and experience with terrorists in this hemisphere.

-----Original Message-----
From: robert gaye [mailto:roberttgaye@hotmail.com]
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 10:17 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: SBA Loan Request



Hon. Governor Jeb Bush: 

Thanks for your support.  I was overwhelmed by the support shown for 
Transtar by the President, HUD Secretary Martinez, Mayor Hood, and you at 
the recent Town Hall Meeting.  However, the feedback from Thomas Butler of 
the SBA is that Transtar exceeds the size standards for small businesses.  
Therefore, the loan application that would provide the assistance necessary 
for Transtar to resume doing business at Orlando International Airport has 
been declined. 

I find myself asking for your urgent help in this matter.  Transtar was very 
important to this community, as it employed over 250 people.  The shutting 
down of Transtar had a direct impact on nearly 1000 individuals, not to 
mention Transtar's local suppliers and their employees. 

Transtar was dealt a deathblow by the events of September 11.  As you can 
imagine, time is of the essence.  Transtar faces several major challenges in 
the next few days.  Cancellation of the OIA contract is pending if no help 
is forthcoming. If the OIA contract is cancelled and the bond is called, it 
is not likely that Transtar or myself will ever be able to do business again 
with the Greater Orlando Aviation Authority.  Even with financial help to 
resume operations, Transtar faces additional challenges in structuring an 
ongoing relationship with GOAA. 

Over the past 16 years, I have more than demonstrated my ability to survive 
in a very difficult and competitive environment.  Before September 11, I 
built the business with personal resources and private sector financing.  I 
have never applied for government-backed assistance.  However, September 11 
created special needs, which require special solutions. 

Perhaps I can appeal for a special waiver in view of the employment 
represented by Transtar and its DBE status.  Perhaps there are other forms 
of state or federal aid that can mitigate this hardship.  There are many 
compelling reasons to support efforts to get Transtar back in business.  At 
this time I really need your guidance in dealing with this matter.  Governor 
Bush, I know that you are extremely busy, and your immediate attention of 
this matter would be greatly appreciated.  Thanks again for your support and 
guidance. 

Respectfully Yours, 
Robert T. Gaye 
Transtar Transportation, Inc.

-----Original Message-----
From: fasano.mike@leg.state.fl.us [mailto:fasano.mike@leg.state.fl.us]
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 5:43 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Bush's tax cut wins delay despite several GOP nays
This St. Petersburg Times (http://www.sptimes.com) story has been sent to you from fasano.mike@leg.state.fl.us 
You did not lose any votes... 
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 
http://www.sptimes.com/News/120601/State/Bush_s_tax_cut_wins_d.shtml 
Bush's tax cut wins delay despite several GOP nays 
By ALISA ULFERTS 
 St. Petersburg Times, published December 6, 2001 
 
   TALLAHASSEE -- Lawmakers handed Gov. Jeb Bush the delay he sought in a controversial tax cut Wednesday, but it came without the support of some of the House's most conservative members.   TALLAHASSEE -- Lawmakers handed Gov. Jeb Bush the delay he sought in a controversial tax cut Wednesday, but it came without the support of some of the House's most conservative members.
   Repeatedly, Bush has been asked whether he had the 61 Republican House votes he wanted to delay a cut in the state's intangibles tax. Repeatedly, he has answered "Absolutely" or "We have the votes."
   In the end, Bush got 60 Republicans to vote for the delay. Seventeen other GOP lawmakers defected. Had all 43 Democrats joined the 17 Republican defectors in opposing the bill, it would have failed. Now, it will go to Bush for his signature.
   Bush insisted he could have delivered more Republicans, if he needed them. 
   "We were up to about 68 votes -- 60 very solid and eight who would have joined us" had it not become clear that the Democrats were going to support the delay, Bush said.
   "We had a lot of 61st votes," Bush said. 
   The House's 102-17 vote marks the first time Bush has lost more than a handful of Republican votes on any issue he wanted. The Senate earlier had approved Bush's bill 36-2.
   Rep. Connie Mack was among the young conservatives, informally dubbed the Freedom Caucus, who opposed Bush's plan. 
   "There were some of us that had a philosophical belief that this was not the right thing to do or the right time to do it," said Mack, R-Fort Lauderdale. He doesn't think Bush's failure to get 61 Republican votes reflects on the governor's standing within his own party.
   "He's been a leader on tax cuts. This shouldn't be made into "The governor's changed on the position of taxes,' " Mack said.
   Democrats supported the tax delay, but not before rubbing Republicans' noses in that fact. Delaying the cut will free up $128-million so budget cuts in the special session won't be so deep.
   House Democratic Leader Lois Frankel said the Democrats had considered voting against the tax delay as a strategy to pressure the Republicans who run the House to back off the budget cuts further. But the Democrats decided that wouldn't work.
   "We thought all that would happen is one of the 17 (nay votes) would have the noose around his neck" by voting for the delay, Frankel said.
   Bush stepped in to help broker a budget deal after the first special session he called to fix the budget collapsed when Senate President John McKay and Speaker of the House Tom Feeney failed to agree on the intangibles tax. Part of that agreement -- to be finalized today -- was to delay the latest round of the intangibles tax cut for 18 months to give the economy time to recover.
   McKay had wanted to repeal the tax cut entirely, and Feeney wouldn't even consider a delay. 
   Feeney joined 16 other Republicans in voting against the compromise. But he asked his lieutenants to help round up votes for Bush's compromise plan.
   "I candidly never knew whether we had 61 votes or not, but I worked closely with some of the Democratic members," Feeney said.
   Rep. Mike Fasano, who has popularized the phrase "seniors and savers" during his speeches opposing the intangibles tax on stocks and bonds, said he was impressed by Bush's abilities to garner 102 votes, even though his wasn't among those.
   "I'm convinced that if 61 Republican votes were needed on the floor, there would have been 61 votes. But it probably would not have been mine," said Fasano, R-New Port Richey.
   It's a point Bush agrees with. 
   "We probably had six people who, if they were needed, would have helped, maybe more," Bush said. "It shows we can forge a consensus and deal with problems. It was a good day for Republican leadership ... and tomorrow will be an even better day."
   - Times staff writers Lucy Morgan and Steve Bousquet contributed to this report.

-----Original Message-----
From: RDuKate@aol.com [mailto:RDuKate@aol.com]
Sent: Friday, December 07, 2001 2:50 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Consumer contract scams


Dear Gov. Bush, 

I have become the victim of a scam involving a home alarm service which has an automatic annual renewal clause in the contract.  As a result of this event, it has made me aware that there are probably thousands of Florida residents who have also become victims of similar consumer contracts, so I would like to make a recommendation to provide a remedy to this situation. 

Specifically, I would like to recommend legislation which would require all "automatically" annual renewal invoices to be mailed to consumers BEFORE the renewal date with bold print stating that this contract is the result of an automatic renewal provision in your contract and the consumer has 30 days to notify the business provider if they wish to discontinue the contract. 

In my situation I had signed a contract for 3 years of alarm monitoring service for my residence.  At the end of the 1st and 2nd years I noticed that I received the renewal invoices about 30-60 days after the annual renewal date, but assumed this was an accounting or technology problem with the business, Alarm Depot of Miami, Florida.  After the 3rd yr. of service I again received the invoice about 45 days after the renewal date, so I telephoned the company and instructed them to discontinue the service (the sales rep. had initially told me that a telephone call would be all that was required to cancel the contract even though it states in the contract that this must be done in writing).   

Approximately a month later I received a call from the company in which they told me that I was past due on the invoice so I told them that I had already called and canceled the service.  At this time, I was told by the company rep. that this had to be done in writing and since it wasn't done in writing they could not cancel the service.  On Dec. 6th I received a call from a collection agency in which a very nice lady informed me that I was delinquent and threatened to ruin my credit if I did not pay.  I explained to her that I had canceled, so contacted the company to ask them and called me back to inform me that I had not canceled so they were threatening to sue me as well as place negative remarks on my credit reports. 

I called the company and spoke with Paul who he said I spoke with previously.  He told me that since I had not canceled the contract in writing PRIOR to the renewal date that the full contract amount was due and that he could not accept my cancellation verbally, as I had done attempted to do twice before when speaking with the company.  While he claimed that they have a responsibility to not take verbal cancellations due to someone mistakenly not having security service due to unauthorized cancellation, I counted that argument that this did not make sense due to the fact that the alarm company has passwords which could have been used to verify the authority of the person in which they were speaking. 

After spending a consider amount of time and aggravation on the phone with the company's representatives, I realized that this entire process is a scam to keep people in contracts for longer than they desire.  As a matter of fact, the renewal notice I received this year was also received the same day that I received a delinquency notice for this same invoice.  Furthermore, nowhere on the renewal invoice is there any text notifying customers that this is an "automatically" renewal of the contract, nor any disclosure that cancellation is required in writing BEFORE the renewal date.  Of course it will be impossible to a customer to cancel when renewal invoice is received since the renewal date has already passed. 

In my opinion, what should concern the lawmakers is the fact that this is a relatively small amount of money, i.e., $300, so I am sure that 99% of the customers who are pressed for collection just mail them a check to get collection agents and the company off their backs.  While my situation involves an alarm company, but I suspect that there are other service contracts used in this state that have similar terms which are designed to extract money from customers without their approval.  Hence, my recommendation that this legislation be applied to all consumer contracts in the state, especially for amounts under $500. 

For your investigation the name of this company is Alarm Depot and they are located at 9960 NW 116th Way, Suite 7, Medley, FL 33178 and their telephone number is 305-471-7950. 

Please keep me informed of any investigation results and any proposed legislative changes brought about as a result of this correspondence. 
Sincerely, 
Robert DuKate 
5351 NW 3rd Terrace 
Boca Raton, FL 33487 
tel.-561-994-2498

-----Original Message-----
From: McDonough, Jim [mailto:jim.mcdonough@myflorida.com]
Sent: Friday, December 07, 2001 4:35 PM
To: Jeb Bush; Marstiller, Simone
Cc: McDonough, Jim
Subject: RE: Drug Treatment Initiative Oral Argument on 12/10/01



 Governor, 

I recommend all the amicus briefs yield the oral argument to the Save Our Society brief.  The fact that you have filed an amicus brief is apparant (and weighty).  Only 20 minutes are given to each sides argument, no matter how many amicus briefs.  They have put up a former Supreme Court Justice; Save our Society has put up a former Solicitor General.  Let the legal mavens argue it out.

We (all of the amicus briefs on our side) have coordinated the arguments, and feel that one spokesperson can make the best case.

I believe we have the stronger hand.  And I believe by yielding the time to one speaker strengthens the substantive case even more, through the consistency of the interrelated points of law coming from one voice.

I also believe we are going to win this case.  Every professional organization involved in drug aspects of the criminal justice system and/or treatment are aligned against the proposition, with the exception of public defenders, and they are not aligned for it.  The backers of the amendment have not been able to break out a single treatment center to speak for it, and they have tried mightily.

Jim McDonough

From: Marstiller, Simone [ mailto:simone.marstiller@myflorida.com] 
Sent: Tuesday, December 04, 2001 4:28 PM 
To: Jeb Bush 
Cc: McDonough, Jim 
Subject: Drug Treatment Initiative Oral Argument on 12/10/01 



Governor: 

As you know, we filed a brief in the Fla. Supreme Court on your behalf 
opposing the drug treatment initiative.  Oral argument is scheduled for 
Monday, Dec. 10 at 9:00 a.m.  We requested oral argument when the brief 
was 
filed in order to preserve the opportunity.  However, four of the five 
parties opposing the initiative -- including the EOG -- are scheduled to 

argue and have been alotted 5 minutes each.  The other parties' briefs 
-- 
especially that of Save Our Society from Drugs -- largely cover the same 

territory covered in our brief, although they make additional arguments, 
as 
well.  Because of the overlap, and because FDLE and the Prosecuting 
Attorneys Assn can adequately advance the concerns of the executive 
branch, 
we propose waiving or yielding our time to the other parties to best 
utilize 
the time given to the initiative's opponents collectively. 

Please let me know whether you agree or disagree.  Thank you. 

Simone Marstiller 
Legal Affairs 

From:	Jeb Bush

-----Original Message-----
From: Nina Strickland/Greg K. Sloan, M.D. [mailto:fca@digitalexp.com]
Sent: Friday, December 07, 2001 2:16 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: Representative Donald Brown; Senator Durell Peaden
Subject: The "Newer Kinder" Medicare (CMS)


Dear Governor Bush,
 
I am writing this letter to comment on the "newer, kinder" Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.  I certainly have not found them to be any less frustrating than usual.
 
Have you looked at the Provider Application process lately?  We I have!  I am in process of completing an application for a physician who will be joining our group soon.  When I signed onto the CMA website to print the application, I was overwhelmed, to say the least, to find that one section of the application was 57 pages long, one section was 67 pages long, one section was 31 pages long and just the reassignment of benefits form was 9 pages long.  Maybe you would not be intimated by the sheer volume of these applications but a simple working person out here in the trenches is.  It was my understanding that the new applications, effective November, 2001, were simpler, clearer and easier. But looking at these I sure don't feel that they are simpler, clearer and easier.  
 
I did receive The Florida Medicare B Update on Saturday, December 1 which included information regarding a "FREE" Provider Enrollment Workshop to be held in Jacksonville, FL on December 13 or 14th.  It stated that we should "Register Early, because "Seating is limited."  However, there was no phone number, fax number etc to facilitate that happening.  When I finally did get a phone number for Provider Education (not an 800# by the way) 904-791-6422 and I began calling on Monday, Dec. 3 to register I was instructed to leave a detailed message.  I did this including my phone number, fax number, and e-mail address where I could be reached.  I noted that I needed confirmation that I would be able to attend so that I could make travel and motel arrangements as I am approx 6-7 hours away.  I have now made 26 long distance phone calls as well as spending my time which is very valuable to me. By the time I incur travel/hotel costs along with the time and phone calls, this certainly will not have been "FREE" to me.  By Monday, if I were to get a response by then, I will have only 2 days left to make arrangements to attend. 
 
Let me stress, it is very important to me to attend this workshop!!   Having been through the application process several times previously with disastrous results I was so excited to think that I might get my "questions answered directly by a Medicare Expert" who will give me "on-the-spot" assistance in completing and submitting my enrollment applications.  
 
I have always supported you and felt that you were supportive of the people in this state and the medical community.  I will certainly appreciate it if you can offer any assistance to a small rural town physician's office in your state.
 
Nina Strickland, CPC CMA
Practice Administrator
Family Care Associates of NW Florida
925 Carlisle Road
Chipley, FL   32428
(850) 638-1634
Fax (850) 638-3720
fca@digitalexp.com

Dear Governor Bush,
 
I am writing this letter to comment on the "newer, kinder" Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.  I certainly have not found them to be any less frustrating than usual.
 
Have you looked at the Provider Application process lately?  We I have!  I am in process of completing an application for a physician who will be joining our group soon.  When I signed onto the CMA website to print the application, I was overwhelmed, to say the least, to find that one section of the application was 57 pages long, one section was 67 pages long, one section was 31 pages long and just the reassignment of benefits form was 9 pages long.  Maybe you would not be intimated by the sheer volume of these applications but a simple working person out here in the trenches is.  It was my understanding that the new applications, effective November, 2001, were simpler, clearer and easier. But looking at these I sure don't feel that they are simpler, clearer and easier.  
 
I did receive The Florida Medicare B Update on Saturday, December 1 which included information regarding a "FREE" Provider Enrollment Workshop to be held in Jacksonville, FL on December 13 or 14th.  It stated that we should "Register Early, because "Seating is limited."  However, there was no phone number, fax number etc to facilitate that happening.  When I finally did get a phone number for Provider Education (not an 800# by the way) 904-791-6422 and I began calling on Monday, Dec. 3 to register I was instructed to leave a detailed message.  I did this including my phone number, fax number, and e-mail address where I could be reached.  I noted that I needed confirmation that I would be able to attend so that I could make travel and motel arrangements as I am approx 6-7 hours away.  I have now made 26 long distance phone calls as well as spending my time which is very valuable to me. Subject: AIG Meeting Request


Governor Bush: 
At your suggestion during our initial meeting I am contacting you  regarding an insurance industry group interested in meeting with you again. To refresh your memory, an AIG directed group met in your office over a year ago to discuss opportunities with the state utilizing an Owner Controlled Insurance Program related to statewide increased minority contracting and surety support. 

Our success with this model compels us to again seek an audience with you and several senior executive representatives from AIG's New York office along with representatives from the national Insurance Brokerage firm of Willis from Florida wish to discuss new opportunities. We are prepared to brief you on new Insurance programs as they relate to public project construction funding and minority contractor utilization. Our schedules are open the first two weeks of January. 

I am a new resident of South Florida and have become more aware of the importance of this issue in Florida. This initiative may help you in providing resources for educational facilities and other public projects without the investment of state capital. We believe it is timely for a private-public collaboration on this issue. I look forward to discussing this opportunity with you soon. You may reach me via this e-mail,  or my office number is (954) 577-1082, or you may also reach me at my cell phone number: (954)-895-1488.

From: Nelson E.Miner [mailto:miner@usa.net]

Subject: Florida Building Code


&#65279;                        Nelson E. Miner
                      806 Pinecrest Avenue
                    Panama City, Fl   32401
                              USA
                                                                 Telephone:
850-872-1607       miner@usa.net            FAX 850-872-1645

                                                               
                                                7 December 2001

	Subject:  New Building Codes 


Dear Mr. Governor;

	I have had the opportunity to be involved in many Hurricane recoveries and
cleanup from Camille 1969-70 to Georges 1998-1999. As a practicing Engineer in
public service for more than 35 years, I ask that you do what is required to
NOT delay the implementations of the Florida Unified Building Code. The people
of Florida should not be ask to adsorb the cost replacing the large number of
building being built that will not survive the storms that visit us our
state.

	Delaying the new code is akin to not adding oil to your car when the low oil
indicator is showing. The cost of the probable damage will far out weigh cost
of a quart of oil. 

	The citizens of Florida need you to stand tall and firm in their corner as a
voice of reason as others over react to events of the last few months.


	Thank you for your time and attention.

Good morning Governor Bush,

Well we were told by the District 1 Developmental Disabilities office that all the special projects for districts 1,2,and 4 will cease as of Dec. 10th this year.  This is a sad, sad time for the Great State of Florida, and for families with handicapped children and adult children.  I am afraid that our state institutions for the handicapped will soon be crowded beyond belief because some parents will have no choice with their supports removed but to remand their handicapped children over to DCF facilities.  We were also told that all cost plans for individuals will be cut by $150.00.  for some individuals that is their whole cost plan, and that cuts in cost plans will be even higher is some other districts.  That all personal care attendants will be cut, another reason DCF's will become crowded.
I know these are hard times, and everyone need to bite the bullet so to say but to ruin the lives of individuals with handicaps and their families, it's just a very hard pill to swallow.
Sir is there anything I can do to help as an individual and in my capacity as chairman of the Family Care Council in District 1?
