-----Original Message-----
From: James Murfee [mailto:jmurfpat@bellsouth.net]
Sent: Friday, December 07, 2001 9:54 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Choice and Control


Dear Governor Bush:

My son participates in subject pilot and has received speech and
physical therapy for the first time in his 36 years because of it.  This
has not cost much. We have worked within or near his original budget by
dropping his assigned coordinator and providing most of his
transportation ourselves. We have also supplemented state funding with
our own funds and insurance for therapy.  This pilot has made our family
take on the rightful responsibility for our son's development instead of
leaving it to the State.  I had no idea how much I could help Drew
myself until he entered the program.

I appreciate all the hard work of so many people which has made this
pilot possible and urge you to veto any unwise attempts to reduce
funding for it in this time of fiscal hardship.  I believe this will be
a money saving program in the long run.

Jim Murfee
850-265-6218
15139 Highway 77
Southport, FL
32409-2659

Sent: Friday, December 07, 2001 9:43 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Naples Botanical Gardens Event




Dear Jeb, 

        We spoke last April about the possibility of your attending the inaugural opening of the Naples Botanical Gardens on Saturday evening, February 13, 2002 in Naples. Since it was far too early for you to commit, you asked me to contact you as we got closer to the event. I spoke to Mr. Jimison today, and he is going to put the date in the computer, but he explained to me that your schedule really remains open and flexible until six weeks prior.

        He also suggested that I e-mail you to remind you about the event, so you could contact him about scheduling it into your calendar if you are interested. Naples and the surrounding area is a very affluent region. The property for the Botanical Gardens (150 acres worth $5 million) was donated by a single Naples resident. The additional money (millions of dollars) has also been donated by the residents of Naples.

        Mr. Jimison suggested that a fundraiser held by the Party, scheduled during that time frame, might make your stop in Naples more persuasive. I have therefore contacted Mike Hanna, and am faxing a copy of this e-mail. As further incentive, my husband and I would be honored to have you stay with us in our Naples home. We live on the golf course, so perhaps you could relax for a few hours, get in a round of golf on a beautiful course and/or do a little fishing. Our next-door neighbor is the president of the Gardens, so you would also have the opportunity to meet her.

        Jeb, your appearance at the event would mean so much to the Gardens and to the people of Naples -- and, of course, I always enjoy speaking with you. Please try to come.

        I look forward to hearing from you. 

                                                                        Sincerely,

-----Original Message-----
From: STRAHL, Stuart [mailto:sstrahl@Audubon.org]
Sent: Friday, December 07, 2001 6:38 AM

-----Original Message----- 
From: Bush-Brogan 2002 [  < mailto:bushbrogan@jeb.org> 
mailto:bushbrogan@jeb.org] 
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 6:48 PM 
To: Bush-Brogan 2002 
Subject: GOVERNOR AND REPUBLICAN LEGISLATORS SHOW LEADERSHIP; FINISH 
SUCCESSFUL LEGISLATIVE SESSION 


FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE 
CONTACT: KAREN UNGER 
THURSDAY, DECEMBER 6, 2001 
850/224-4JEB 

TALLAHASSEE- During challenging times for our nation and state, Governor 
Jeb Bush and the Republican-led Legislature should be commended for 
their leadership and a successful special session. With the passage of a 
revised wartime budget, Governor Bush and the Republican-led Legislature 
have worked together to ensure that Florida's highest priorities are 
funded: 

 Education funding remains at historic levels - funding for K-12 
education has been increased during Governor Bush's tenure in office 
over $2 billion from where it was in 1998. 

 Health and human services funding, including child welfare and 
services to those in need, has increased by 31% percent since 1998. 

 Economic stimulus efforts will create 33,000 new jobs and boost 
Florida's tourism industry, still struggling as a result of the attacks 
on our nation, with $20 million for marketing campaigns. 

 $19 million in spending for various anti-terrorism and domestic 
security measures will equip our state's law and health officials with 
the tools they need to ensure that Floridians are safe. 

Even with wartime necessitated budget reductions, the state budget is 
still 20% greater than in 1998, with spending increases focused on our 
state's priorities - education, health and human services, public safety 
and the environment. Showing tremendous leadership in tough times, 
Governor Bush and the Republican-led Legislature joined together to 
overcome numerous challenges and get a difficult job done. 

The Democrat leadership and their candidates for governor, on the other 
hand, have served as mere spectators in the process. Their criticism of 
the budget and blaming of Governor Bush for the budget shortfall is 
ironic and hypocritical at best, given the facts: 

 The previous Democrat Administration left the state with a mere $1.3 
billion in reserves. Under Governor Bush's leadership, the reserves have 
been built to a record $2.9 billion - an increase of 120 percent. 
Anticipating harder times, the Governor vetoed $916 million in special 
projects to minimize Florida's spending obligations. Thanks to this 
incredible foresight and willingness to make the tough decisions, our 
state is in a position of greater financial strength. 

 Democrats in the Florida Legislature voted in favor of the last three 
budgets by 98% (1999), 100% (2000), and 89% (2001) - the same budgets 
they are now criticizing. 

 Over 90% of Democrats in the Florida Legislature voted in favor of the 
Intangibles Tax Cut in 1998, 1999, and 2000. 

"Being a leader takes more than criticizing from the sidelines. Being a 
leader means having the strength to offer realistic solutions and make 
the tough decisions," said Karen Unger, campaign manager for the 
Bush/Brogan 2002 campaign. "Governor Bush has lead. The Democrats have 
not."

From: redmon [mailto:redmon@nettally.com]
Sent: Friday, December 07, 2001 5:39 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Family Cafe and Disabilities



Dear Governor Bush, 
I've heard you speak at the Family Cafe and I know your passion to 
support persons with disabilities.  Noah, our 23 year son, has severe 
disabilities and is medically unstable.  At the past Cafe I heard you 
speak on the Choice and Control pilot project.  Noah participates in 
this 
program and I was on the committee to set up the pilot for our District 
in the Tallahassee area.  I understand this project is facing severe or 
total cuts in the budget the legislators have given to you for signing. 
Our family urges you to line item veto this.  The Project gives us the 
first opportunity in many years to provide Noah with the goods and 
services he requires.  That means he can continue to live at home with 
his family.  If he had to live in a state funded facility it would cost 
over $100,000 a year--more than 5 times what the state is currently 
spending on the Choice and Control Pilot Project for him.  Please help 
us keep our family together.  Please e-mail me if you require more 
information. 
Thanks for your consideration, Susan, Fred and Noah Redmon 

From:	Jeb Bush
Sent:	Friday, December 7, 2001 9:07 PM
To:	'MMarquez@OrlandoSentinel.com'
Subject:	RE: thanks for your response.

You are right to focus on readiness and the state is doing some good things in this regard. We spend $700 + million on the subject, are building an assessment tool and I am urging further private sector investment since I know there is real interest there. 
 
I applaud the Sentinel's interest in this subject. I hope the paper keeps the heat up and gets many more citizens involved as well. 
 
However, the social promotion acceptance is pathetic. 
 
Para terminar, me siento herido por tus palabras sobre me accento! :) Colu sigue siendo una maestra excelente!
 

Jeb Bush 

***********************************************************
Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law.
Most written communications to or from state officials
regarding state business are public records available to the
public and media upon request.   Your e-mail communications
may therefore be subject to public disclosure. 

-----Original Message-----
From: MMarquez@OrlandoSentinel.com [mailto:MMarquez@OrlandoSentinel.com]
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 10:38 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: RE: thanks for your response.


Thanks for taking the time out of your very busy day to respond. I hope to use some of what you've written in a column, though I'm going a different route in my assessment of what's wrong in the system. I believe you're right on target about ending social promotion, and the districts not doing what they should. But I think true reform would start all kids in pre-K because the earlier the better, particularly for disadvantaged kids who don't get reading at home, etc. It's become fashionable for middle-class and upper-middle class parents to "hold back" Johnny in pre-K for a year to get him really prepared and "mature" for kindergarten, and private schools retain kids all the time in pre-K and kindergarten. I've seen it over the years at St. James. I know your K-20 plan doesn't cover pre-K and that program, which never has received adequate funding, now falls to day care groups. I talked to Phil Handy about it when he came to speak to the ed board about the new education structure, but he said it's something that's on the table and open for discussion. 
 
Well, the dinner turned out lovely. I noticed that the group's awards to public officials all went to Republicans. Sheriff Beary was there and Rep. Ric Keller sent his Hispanic outreach guy, Joe Mantilla.(Keller also sent a video and blamed you for his rotten Spanish -- teehee). Crotty sent a video, too. The GOP is working harder than the Dems around here... but you may have heard that already. I did notice that your accent on the tape was more noticeable. Que pasa .. no estas practicando con Columba?
 
One last note re Reading by 9. The paper really is committed, and I think part of that is that you have an editor and a managing editor at this paper now who both have young children attending public schools. (And I've got one in public high school) That says something about their commitment and the stake they have in Florida's public education system. By the way, I have volunteered along with about a dozen others at the paper to be a tutor for the Reading by 9 program at a nearby school for at least nine weeks. I look forward to it.
 
Hope to catch you next time your in Orlando.

-----Original Message-----
From: Jeb Bush [mailto:jeb@jeb.org]
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 8:29 PM
To: Marquez, Myriam
Subject: RE: Hello


Miriam, I am obviously not at the dinner and committed to be there. 
 
On social promotion, the FCAT is but one criteria. Sadly, many districts are lacking the courage to hold back students and remediate. It is a shame and a quiet scandal. However, our proposed enhancements of the grading system will help focus the districts on the kids left behind. If approved in the next weeks, if schools ignore the kids that are struggling, they will be penalized. 
 
In addition, based on the districts' non compliance with the intent of the A plus plan, there is the strong possibility of legislative reforms to tighten the requirements regarding social promotion. I would support reasonable reforms in this regard. 
 
I really appreciate the efforts of the Orlando Sentinel in advancing the cause of reading and student achievement. It is and will continue to make a difference. No other paper is focused on this and your involvement will have a statewide impact. 
 
 

Jeb Bush 

 
PS I did not proof since i am tired.

-----Original Message-----
From: robert gaye [mailto:roberttgaye@hotmail.com]
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 10:17 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: SBA Loan Request



Hon. Governor Jeb Bush: 

Thanks for your support.  I was overwhelmed by the support shown for 
Transtar by the President, HUD Secretary Martinez, Mayor Hood, and you at 
the recent Town Hall Meeting.  However, the feedback from Thomas Butler of 
the SBA is that Transtar exceeds the size standards for small businesses.  
Therefore, the loan application that would provide the assistance necessary 
for Transtar to resume doing business at Orlando International Airport has 
been declined. 

I find myself asking for your urgent help in this matter.  Transtar was very 
important to this community, as it employed over 250 people.  The shutting 
down of Transtar had a direct impact on nearly 1000 individuals, not to 
mention Transtar's local suppliers and their employees. 

Transtar was dealt a deathblow by the events of September 11.  As you can 
imagine, time is of the essence.  Transtar faces several major challenges in 
the next few days.  Cancellation of the OIA contract is pending if no help 
is forthcoming. If the OIA contract is cancelled and the bond is called, it 
is not likely that Transtar or myself will ever be able to do business again 
with the Greater Orlando Aviation Authority.  Even with financial help to 
resume operations, Transtar faces additional challenges in structuring an 
ongoing relationship with GOAA. 

Over the past 16 years, I have more than demonstrated my ability to survive 
in a very difficult and competitive environment.  Before September 11, I 
built the business with personal resources and private sector financing.  I 
have never applied for government-backed assistance.  However, September 11 
created special needs, which require special solutions. 

Perhaps I can appeal for a special waiver in view of the employment 
represented by Transtar and its DBE status.  Perhaps there are other forms 
of state or federal aid that can mitigate this hardship.  There are many 
compelling reasons to support efforts to get Transtar back in business.  At 
this time I really need your guidance in dealing with this matter.  Governor 
Bush, I know that you are extremely busy, and your immediate attention of 
this matter would be greatly appreciated.  Thanks again for your support and 
guidance. 

Respectfully Yours, 
Robert T. Gaye 
Transtar Transportation, Inc.

-----Original Message-----
From: Peter Merhige [mailto:peter@trishield.net]
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 5:26 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Florida Building Code


Dear Governor Bush,

I am writing to express my disappointment and disbelief that The Senate and
House has once again voted to delay the Florida Building Code. I wrote to
you last week expressing my feelings and giving you an understanding of what
the severity of this action means to our company, but I feel I must do it
again, since you are the last possible chance I have to save my business.

My name is Peter Merhige and my company is Protective Glass Industries,
located in Ft Myers, Florida. My company was formed over 2 years ago for the
purpose of developing and bringing to market a new product for the hurricane
protection markets. The reason for forming the company and products was for
the potential in the hurricane markets mainly due to the
development of the new Florida building code (THE CODE IN WHICH YOU AGREED
WAS GOOD FOR FLORIDA) that contains hurricane protection. We have designed
and have patents pending on the finest impact glass product in the industry.
Not only does it protect from hurricane damage but also due to it's
insulating properties, reduces the cost of energy. We have spent well over
$1,000,000 on the development and commercialization of our products and due
to several delays in the statewide building code; we have lost millions of
dollars. Over the last 2 days, I have lost close to $1 MILLION in investment
money because of the actions in Tallahassee. Not only has our company spent
over $1,000,000 but also there has been millions and millions of dollars
already spent to develop this code, along with millions and millions of
dollars spent by companies to enhance their products to meet the new codes.
There are hundreds of companies ready to provide product for these new
building codes and there has been more than ample time to prepare for it.

I do not know how to make this any clearer than to tell you that all of mine
and all of my loyal employees' hard work to develop our products and bring
them to market over the last 2+ years is over unless you help. We had the
potential to create over 100 jobs for the state of Florida with revenues
over $100 million dollars over the next 3 years, which would obviously be
put back into the Florida economy while protecting your citizens. We have
close to 20 companies that were getting set to come to market with our glass
the first of the year because of your code, and due to the delay, they will
not until March (if the code doesn't get eliminated all together). Due to
this delay and the uncertainty of Tallahassee which makes my investors
uncomfortable enough to not invest, I will not be able to keep the doors
open. Your are really my last hope to see that Tallahassee actually thinks
of it's citizens over their own personal agendas.

We worked very hard to present ideas that would make sense for everyone and
had some really good suggestions, but because of obvious personal agendas,
we were ignored. Presently Senators McKay, Clary and Constatine along with
Representative Bennet, who have businesses in the construction industry,
stated that Florida's counties were not ready for the code. Ourselves, The
Florida League of Cities, AIF and many more, have proof through the DCA that
only 8% of Florida was not ready to enforce the code.

We suggested that all counties not ready be given a 60 day delay to get
prepared and the other 92% who have worked extremely hard to do what you
wanted, enforce the code as scheduled. I cannot, even in my worst
nightmares, imagine how this would not satisfy everyone if that was their
true objections. Obviously it was not and Politics once again was Politics.

As I stated, you are our last chance. We are not alone. There are many
companies that will be put out of business because of this action. I do know
you have the power to make this right. I am begging you for the opportunity
to meet with you to politely express the feelings and concerns of our
company and our industry before you sign the bill to put us out of business.
I don't think this is an unfair request since Tallahassee has potentially
stripped my life from me.

I hope to hear from you or your office soon.

Respectfully,

Peter Merhige
Protective Glass Industries
2546 Fowler Street
Ft Myers, FL 33901
941-936-4227
941-936-2237 fax
www.trishield.net

From:	Deborah_A._Spagnoli@who.eop.gov

Subject:	Economic Stimulus
Attachments:	pic14303.pcx

Per the conference call earlier today, the attached graphic shows:

1)  The Reed Act distribution number in the House bill ($9 billion);   (We
believe that states with legislative action can essentially spend this money
however they want);

- Two columns on Medicaid:

2)  A column estimating the increased state costs associated with a significant
increase in unemployment (4.5% to 6.5% nationally, spread proportionally across
states) for a year;

3)  A column showing the benefit of the FMAP increase proposal in the Senate
Finance bill;

4)  A Column on NEG grant distributions to states (assumes that state grants go
out in proportion to unemployment rise);

5) The final column adds together NEG + the $9B Reed Act distribution;


If you have any questions or comments, please give me a call or send me an
e-mail.

-----Original Message-----
From: McIntyre, Larry [mailto:Larry.McIntyre@awi.state.fl.us]
Sent: Tuesday, November 27, 2001 5:53 PM
To: 'maryhelen.blakeslee@myflorida.com'
Cc: Hadi, Lucy D.; Scott, Lois; Clendenning, Tom; Switzer, Mike;
'linda.heiberger@dca.state.fl.us'
Subject: Disaster Unemployment Assistance-Red Tide Situation in
Apalachico la Bay



As you know, REACT was asked to assist in gathering information on the
impact of Red Tide on oyster harvesters in the Apalachicola Bay area.
This information would then be used to help substantiate a request for a
Presidential Declaration. As discussed in the conference call today,
Linda Heiberger of DCA had previously contacted Andy Gill of USDOL
regarding Disaster Unemployment Assistance (DUA).  

In my  conversation with Andy on today, he could not recall an instance
where DUA had been approved in the past in response to  Red Tide. Andy
specifically mentioned that he worked with North Carolina officials for
over a two-year period with Red Tide and their request was never
approved.  However,  Andy did imply that the situation maybe somewhat
different here in Florida and encouraged us to continue with submitting
the request.  At this point, my assessment is that we will need the
support of your office and the Florida Congressional Delegation to
obtain federal approval for DUA.  We are virgously gathering information
to support the declaration request. However,  I wanted to share the
results of my conversation with Andy prior to the Thursday Town Hall
meeting.

Thanks. 

ljm 

From:	Dana, Pamella <pamella.dana@myflorida.com>

Per my instructions, EFI was engaged with AMI early on (Sept & Oct) to assist where/if possible for site relocation assistance (both temporary and permanent).  I personally spoke with Mr. Pecker to ensure the team had been working with him and he was delighted with the attention he had received from Steve Mayberry and EFI team.   However, at that time, he was unsure of where he wanted to be and we didn't have the type of grants he was looking for to assist. From: Steve Mayberry [mailto:SMayberry@floridabusiness.com]

 -----Original Message-----
From: Larry Pelton [mailto:lpelton@bdb.org]
Sent: Friday, December 07, 2001 2:44 PM
To: membership@bdb.org
Subject: AMI Resolution


URGENT
 
To:       All BDB Members
From:   Ed Sabin, Chair
Date:    12/07/01
RE:       AMI Resolution
 
The Board of Directors of the Business Development Board unanimously approved the following Resolution supporting AMI and encouraging the company to remain in Palm Beach County.  The resolution is intended to convey to the company the business community's support and to counter any misconceptions arising from negative comments appearing in recent media articles.
 
We are asking each member to review the recitals and the resolution carefully, and send an email of support to Mr. David Pecker, CEO of AMI today.  His address is dpecker@AMILINK.com.
 
We feel this company has experienced substantial harm from a tragedy that affected all Americans.  A decision to move this company to another location because of a belief they are not supported by our "business community" would deal a serious blow to our economy.  Most importantly, we need to convey the message that an individual does not represent the feelings of our community and the act of lending support to employees and management in difficult times is our sincere objective. 
 
 Thank you in advance for a favorable action of this request
 
 
 
 
RESOLUTION OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS OF THE
BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT BOARD OF PALM BEACH COUNTY
 
 
This Resolution is adopted this 7th day of December, 2001, by the members of the Board of Directors of the Business Development Board of Palm Beach County, Inc.

R E C I T A L S

WHEREAS, AMI is a business domiciled in Palm Beach County, Florida, employing three hundred ninety (390) employees with an average salary of $65,000.00; and
WHEREAS, AMI has been subjected to an extraordinary tragedy of financial and personal impact; and
WHEREAS, an offer of financial assistance by the Board of County Commissioners of Palm Beach County was a gesture of support by the County - not a request by AMI for funds;  and AMI never threatened to move if Palm Beach County did not offer grants; and
`WHEREAS, AMI expressed appreciation of the offer of assistance, and AMI agreed to repay any Palm Beach County funds if insurance reimbursement or federal assistance was received by AMI; and 
WHEREAS, recent articles in the Palm Beach Post have suggested that one individual believes that the business community should not be supporting AMI; and
WHEREAS, the members of the Board of Directors of the Business Development Board care for and support the individuals, officers and directors of AMI and the business of AMI, and support the long term location of AMI within Palm Beach County, Florida.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED:
1.         That the Business Development Board of Palm Beach County expresses its regret and condolences for the tragic circumstances which have affected the individuals, business and operations of AMI.
 
2.                  That the Business Development Board of Palm Beach County recognizes the positive economic contribution to our county and the state of Florida of AMI's operations and business.
3.                  That the Business Development Board of Palm Beach County supports and strongly encourages that the business operations of AMI remain within Palm Beach County, Florida.
 Adopted by affirmative vote of the Board of Directors of the Business Development of Palm Beach County, Florida, on this 7th day of December, 2001.
 
______________________________
Edward G. Sabin, Chairman

From:	Bernd Wollschlaeger <info@miamihealth.com>
Sent:	Friday, December 7, 2001 9:20 PM
To:	Moore, Tim; Domestic Security Advisory Panel; Domestic Security Co-Chairs; Domestic Security Oversight Board
Cc:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	AMA meeting



Dear Tim:
Thanks for the e-mail and I am very sorry not to be able to attend the
Monday meeting but I have to teach docs about emergency preparedness in
Jupiter on Monday.
I serve as an Alternate AMA delegate for the FMA and was surprised to
witness the AMA efforts to educate physicians (see attached press release).
The members of our delegation were convinced that the AMA models its
approach according to Florida's experience.
Nearly a dozen speakers presented topics including biological and chemical
terrorism, disaster preparedness and the management of posttraumatic stress
disorder resulting from the events of 911.
Most speakers emphasized that disaster preparedness is a local problem and
need to be dealt with accordingly.
Hospitals, physicians and the local community need to coordinate their
readiness planning and training exercises.
It is crucial that we closely direct and supervise:
1) development and implementation  of emergency readiness plans at each
healthcare facility (doctors offices)
2) guide local hospitals in emergency readiness planning and to provide
templates.
3) coordinate training exercises at local hospitals and other community
based sites (shopping malls, movie theatre etc.) involving local healthcare
professionals.
4) local public education and awareness campaign utilizing community
newspapers and local radio and TV stations.

The FMA delegation also introduced a resolution calling for a national
smallpox vaccination initiative and a modified resolution passed the House
of Delegates.
============================================================================
==============================================
AMA Press release:

AMA Interim Meeting features major educational effort on bioterrorism;
public service announcement aimed at millions
Fulfilling its vital role in educating physicians on recognizing and
responding to biological attacks, the AMA is devoting a major portion of its
Interim Meeting in San Francisco this week to discussions related to
bioterrorism. Included in the mix: more than seven hours of educational
sessions  some offered for continuing medical education credit -- intended
to deepen physicians clinical and professional skills on the subject. The
AMA plans to make the information available via the Internet to all
physicians in the nation following its meeting.

Bioterrorism is one of the most important issues facing Americas patients
and physicians right now, said AMA President Richard Corlin, MD. With our
Interim Meeting bringing together physicians from across the country and
across the medical spectrum, there is no more appropriate forum to tackle
this issue and forge the medical response strategies and solutions that can
protect Americas patients against this threat.

As part of the effort, the AMA this week is releasing a national television
public service announcement (PSA) directing the public to their family
physician and the AMA Web site for up-to-date information on biological and
chemical terrorism.

The PSA is part of a comprehensive AMA program to educate patients and
physicians on how to respond to biological and chemical attacks. The best
antidote to public anxiety is full, accurate information, said Dr. Corlin.
Our job is to deliver that information so patients and doctors can respond
to rapidly changing circumstances.

In the national TV spot, Dr. Corlin tells viewers, In a world where
biological terrorism has become a reality, many Americans are confused. For
timely information, go where doctors go, the AMA Web site. Learn why not to
stockpile medicines, especially antibiotics, and why a flu shot is just for
the flu, and nothing else. And remember, for sound medical advice, trust
your family physician. Good medical information can protect your family 
and protect our way of life.

The broadcast announcement will be distributed this week by satellite to
television news and public affairs directors. In addition, all AMA
physicians will soon receive a CD-ROM with clinical information on
biowarfare threats such as anthrax and smallpox, plus details on hospital
preparedness and the medical management of biological and chemical
casualties.

The bioterrorism agenda at the Interim meeting included a videotaped speech
by Health and Human Services Secretary Tommy Thompson and an address from
Surgeon General David Satcher, MD, who thanked the AMA and the House for the
work theyve done to address bioterrorism education. The satellite
conferences that we [the CDC] have cosponsored with the AMA have reached
more than a half million physicians in the country -- and without your
leadership, that would not have been possible, he said. Clearly it is the
kind of interaction that needs to be ongoing as we work together to
strengthen the public health infrastructure.

Jeb,

I watched you an hour or so ago, I believe Channel 6 Orlando, being ask
about the budget cuts.  You didn't seem as confident this evening as you
usually are when  reporters ask questions.  I realize live one on one
interviews are hard--I wouldn't even be able to talk--however you typically
exhibit a stronger presence.

I also received the budget fact e-mail from Karen Unger this
afternoon--which is extremely important info to get out as I have seen
similar teacher union "fact" (har har) sheets this week already too.  Your
teams fact sheet begins with:
 Budget Fact Sheet

 Even with wartime necessitated budget reductions,.......

as simply an observation from someone who certainly isn't aware of all facts
by any means, but do recall that before Sept. 11, Fl. was looking at 500-600
million in deficit shortfalls.  If I may suggest--don't let your team get
carried away with casting our current shortfall too heavily on 9-11.  It's
just my opinion--but that would be a dangerous place to go.  Of course it
has had a serious impact--but that wasn't our only problem that led to it.
Your fact sheet on the democratic votes on the intangible tax and others
were very enlightening to me and I know will be to others as well--so I
suppose my point is--you have a great deal of good hard important work you
have done to substantiate your positions and you don't need even the
appearances of throwing too much of the budget problem on wartime downturns.
It will only fuel unnecessitated attacks from the left.  Just an opinion
from the cheap seats!

Take care and enjoy the weekend

Matt

>   2001-2002 Budget = $48.4 billion

> Total Increase = $3 billion
>

> 
> Spending reductions - $722 million (53%)
> Cash from working capitol - $104 million (8%)
> Trust fund reserves - $383 million (29%)
> Intangibles tax cut delay - $128 million (10%)
> 
> Total = $1.34 billion
> 
>  Current budget reserves = $2.862 billion (compared to $1.328 
> billion
> in 1998)  The previous Democrat Administration left the state with 
> a
> mere $1.3 billion in reserves. Under Governor Bush's leadership, 
> the
> reserves have been built to a record $2.9 billion - an increase of
> 115 percent.

> special
> projects over the last three years to minimize Florida's spending
> obligations.
>

> three
> budgets by 98% (1999), 100% (2000), and 89% (2001) - the same 
> budgets
> they are now criticizing.

> the

-----Original Message-----
From: L. C. Alexander [mailto:l1alex@infi.net]
Sent: Tuesday, December 04, 2001 10:04 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: A editorial copy and a query.


Another Whats going on in Lake Panasoffkee, Governor Bush? 
Some time ago the Blade asked this same question. Its appearance on the web aroused the ire of some individuals, so in the thinking of this editor it was believed some education benefits toward what public disclosures can provide was accomplished. Due to a number of recent questions being raised by some Lake P citizens, however, maybe the belief was similar to the old adage of yelling against the wind? 
To recap, the state legislature some two years ago said in passing a Bill that was to provide about $26 million dollars over five years (paraphrased here) that the Lake was a state treasure owned by all its citizens, and the sad, man mangled mess needed restoration before it was totally lost. A lake restoration committee set-up began, that to shorten a long involved session of political finagling, ended up as being less in number of members as originally planned by governor appointment, all placed in office by the local county commission. Not unexpected, some well-known local power players, according to citizen activists, ended up in a majority of those seats that has guided matters ever since. 
Their first project decided upon was to restore sections on the lakes east side around Colemans Landing, an uninhabited shore a far piece for any boat trailering, that had public access right of way and was at one time a prime fishery area. Unfortunately, due to contentions that native aquatic plants must be allowed to repopulate the dredged areas, public access there is still a figment for future decision. Waterfront dwellers on the west shore where a major Sumter County population resides are mad. Especially canal property owners who cant get anything done, once privy to clean, clear runs to open water but now landlocked by excess weeds and muck buildup, are not happy to know that as a practical matter, only fish camp owners and their customers for the most part are reaping any benefits from this cost-overrun, millions of dollars operation. Some fish camp owners they point out who set on the restorations committee. 
Recently the chorus of questioners has widened and deepened apparently. It now is being noised about that as dredging activity has been transferred to the west side of the lake, clearing of the channel from one of said fish camps to open water, and a open lakefront restoration along another committee members property ongoing, is stirring real heat to an already hot mix. A mix that embroils state and county money, hard to track according to these activists with agencies like Swiftmud and the Fish and Game Department trying to roil the pot on the side. 
Yep, Governor! If any parts of the above are true, Id say you and some others got a big problem. Come to think of it, even the perception evidently affecting a bunch of folks, smells pretty bad in these volatile times. What do you say? LCA[] 

Governor Bush: A letter advising the Attorney Generals office of criminal actions in the above program from a Mr. Knute Dobson of Lake Panasoffkee has been copied to me as the Citrus-Sumter Blade editor. Complaint is made this notification is being ignored by the AG. Could your office look into these matters? L. C. Alexander[]

Subject:	CIS Funding Cuts



The Honorable Governor Jeb Bush, PL 05
The Capitol
400 South Monroe Street
Tallahassee, Florida  32399-0001

Dear Governor Bush:

Please allow me to introduce myself.  My name is Randy James and I am 
Chairperson of the Communities and Schools program in Hillsborough County.
I am writing you because I was distressed to hear that the CIS State 
allocation in the last special session has a proposed 50% reduction from 1 
Million Dollars to $500,000.  

As CIS of Florida's Budget was already cut by 2/3rds from $3 million to $1 
million in this year's regular session, I feel that we are shouldering more 
than our share of cuts.  I appreciate the difficult situation that you and 
the legislature are in and we are prepared to accept our share of cuts.  
However, I do not understand why we are being asked to take a considerably 
larger cut than most other programs that I have reviewed.  

I respectfully request that you reconsider allowing such a large cut to 
become law.  CIS of HIllsborough alone serves some 5,000 at risk students and 
these continuing cuts are putting an incredible strain on our ability to 
continue to serve this important class of students.

Thank you for taking the time to review my concerns and please let me know if 
there are any questions that I can answer about this issue.

Sincerely:

Randal James, President
James Group International
4230 S. MacDill Ave.  Suite K
Tampa, Florida  33611
Ph:   813-831-5688
Fax:  813-831-8182

From:	Yablonski, Brian <brian.yablonski@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Friday, December 7, 2001 5:25 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	Kathleen Shanahan
Subject:	casa blanca

If you engage in any conversations with casa blanca over the weekend, might
want to relay issue on economic stimulus package.

everyone knows package is in trouble

based on calls that nina and i have been on, biggest sticking point with
governors -- today raised by gov. taft and hull on conference call with paul
o'neil -- is the accelerated depreciation component.  the administration is
calling for a 30% depreciation up front.  it impacts states b/c this is a
change to the federal corporate income tax calculation -- states'
calculations are tied to the federal calculation (sort of like estate tax).
Our guys are projecting a $200 million hit annually for 3 years to the state
budget if this goes through.

bottom line is, many states are having to go through special session like we
have had to and are worried about the additional hit to the state budget.

it is an issue that is keeping governors from endorsing the presidents plan
or advocating for it -- it has been the subject of every economic stimulus
conference call i have been on with the white house, and i heard the
governors at the RGA meeting a couple weeks ago all were up in arms about
it.

on all conference calls with white house on the issue and most recently
today's call with Paul O'Neil, the response from the administration has been
weak -- non responsive or philosophical in nature.

suggestions: 	make it a federal tax credit -- that wont impact state
calculations -- white house will say economic stimulus will not be as
great doing it this way
		lower depreciation component -- even lowering it to 10%
would cost florida $70 million.

-----Original Message-----
From: Dana, Pamella 
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 1:12 PM
To: Hampton, Betty
Subject: Governor Bush letter to Dickson01


Mr. John Dickson
Chairman & CEO
Agere Systems, Inc.
555 Union Blvd.
Allentown, PA  18109
 
Dear John:
 
It was a pleasure speaking with you regarding Agere Systems and the valued relationship your company maintains with the State of Florida.  The investments Agere has made in business expansions and job creation in Florida has contributed to greatly to our economy.  Equally important has been your company's role as a partner in economic development programs-from participation in the Florida High Tech Corridor to providing chairs at the University of Central Florida and the University of South Florida.
 
Fully recognizing the difficult times facing your industry, I want to emphasize that Florida's commitment to fostering the growth of technology-based industry clusters remains steadfast.  Florida has partnered with your company in the past, and we are ready to do so again to ensure your continued success-particularly in research and development realms.
 
With a focus on the optoelectronics and photonics, there are particularly unique opportunities for Agere to excel in Florida.  As you may be aware, the University of Central Florida (UCF) is recognized as among the top three schools in the nation (if not world) for optical science and engineering, and it's Center for Research and Education in Optics and Lasers (CREOL - www.creol.ucf.edu <http://www.creol.ucf.edu/> ) is in class amongst itself.   Beyond espousing incredible research, UCF and CREOL are producing optoelectronics graduates highly sought in the private sector-many of whom have assumed employment at Agere.  With an obvious shared vision, it would seem very advantageous for UCF to work closely with Agere Sytems to build upon research and development programs that will lead to model innovations.  
 
I have asked John Hitt, UCF President to contact your office to strategize on how UCF and CREOL can best incorporate Agere into its varied research and development programs.   Perhaps this could include relocation of some of Agere's optoelectronics programs presently based in New Jersey.  From both a vantage of academic excellence and financial feasibility, I am confident that Florida could greatly benefit Agere Systems in its continued growth plans.
 
Until then, I wish you all the best and welcome you to contact me whenever I might be of assistance.
 
Sincerely,
 
 
Jeb Bush

-----Original Message-----
From: Mary O'Meara [mailto:msosparc@ucnsb.net]
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 8:47 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Possible Scam relating to our disabled population



Dear Governor Bush,
 
I would not normally contact you with the details of the goings on in our community, but I think that I am a target for a Scientology scam.
 
My name is Mary O'Meara and I am the president of S.P.A.R.C. of Volusia, Inc. (Special Population Activities & Recreation Council). We are a 501 (c) 3 Florida non-profit, and our organization provides recreational, athletic, social and educational activities for mentally challenged people in Volusia County. I live in New Smyrna Beach, and our group has been experiencing the growth and wonder of the success of reaching anyone and everyone who can benefit from our activities. We are hoping that in the future we can establish a community center to serve a lot of needs. I was planning to start writing grants for funding in 2002. We have over 150 "participants", whose age range is 3-65 who represent a myriad of disabilities.
 
My concern is that we saw an e-mail for seed money to open an "ABLE Center" and I jumped at the opportunity to learn more about it. ...Long story short, I have arranged for a meeting with Lori Bennett, "Ambassador of Hope" as she regards herself, to speak to the parents and care-givers of my group. I have recently been made aware that she may represent the Church of Scientology. Although asked many direct questions about religion and funding, Lori has never given me a direct answer. She has claimed that the seed money does not come from Federal or State funding, that it does not come from any form of grant, and that she will only disclose where the funds come from at our meeting. This meeting is scheduled for December 12th at Coronado Community United Methodist Church's "Beach Club" at 7pm. You are invited if you'd like to attend!
 
I have spent the better part of the day speaking with my attorney, surfing the internet looking for any information I can get. I was hoping to find a direct tie between the A.B.L.E. Foundation and Scientology, but I cannot find one. I have, however, received e-mails stating that some people KNOW the tie to be there. As a result I have e-mailed my mailing list and will follow up with a post card tomorrow telling ALL that I am only hosting, not backing, this organization. I have urged my families NOT to sign anything. I am a recognized and trusted entity in my county and want to keep on doing what I'm doing - it's needed and I truly enjoy it. Here's the thing: I am afraid that she will bully my desperate parents into something, or that she will make my life difficult if I don't comply with her... The information I digested regarding Scientology is horrifying, and I am actually personally afraid at this point. 
 
I am hoping for some input, advice or reassurance - who knows what - mostly because I feel that all of my work can be ruined in one fell swoop. Do you have any information on this church in Florida? Lori Bennett is the CEO of "The A.B.L.E. (Achieving Beyond Limited Expectations) Foundation, Inc,  - as it's worded in the Division of Corporations website - and her family members are the other directors. She lives in Williston, Florida. There is some connection with Illinois, as our meeting invitations came from zip code 60499 in South Suburban Illinois - although when I asked her about the postmark she did not answer my question satisfactorily. I am hoping that we can stop this before other counties are possibly taken advantage of also. I have included the ABLE website and hope that perhaps your office can look it over thoroughly... it seems to say a lot while saying very little, and yet I felt obliged to investigate it as something of a possibility for our county. http://www.ablefoundation.org
 
My contact information is as follows: I live at 321 Roslyn Avenue, New Smyrna Beach, FL 32168 - 
My phone number is 386-409-9292, and my e-mail is msosparc@ucnsb.net. 
 
I thank you in advance for any input you can provide.
 
Sincerely,
 
Mary S. O'Meara
 
 
 

From:	Manny Mencia <MMencia@floridabusiness.com>
Sent:	Friday, December 7, 2001 4:43 PM
To:	Jeb Bush; Dana, Pamella
Cc:	Kathleen Shanahan
Subject:	RE: Dominican Republic

Importance:	High

Dear Governor
 
Sorry,  I didn't mean to lose you the big bet. You are correct in terms of exports alone.  The  Dominican Republic is our # 3 export  destination after Brazil and Venezuela if measured by the conventional merchandise trade method, which is based on what goes out of our ports and airports.  If we focus on origin exports, which are export transactions that originate in-state, Dominican Republic would be # 4 after Brazil, Canada and Mexico.
 
However as a trading partner meaning two way trade, Dominican Republic would be second only  to Brazil, which I guess makes Pam $5 - richer.
 
Best regards,
 
Manny

From:	McDonough, Jim <jim.mcdonough@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Friday, December 7, 2001 4:35 PM
To:	Jeb Bush; Marstiller, Simone
Cc:	McDonough, Jim
Subject:	RE: Drug Treatment Initiative Oral Argument on 12/10/01

 Governor, 

I recommend all the amicus briefs yield the oral argument to the Save Our Society brief.  The fact that you have filed an amicus brief is apparant (and weighty).  Only 20 minutes are given to each sides argument, no matter how many amicus briefs.  They have put up a former Supreme Court Justice; Save our Society has put up a former Solicitor General.  Let the legal mavens argue it out.

We (all of the amicus briefs on our side) have coordinated the arguments, and feel that one spokesperson can make the best case.

I believe we have the stronger hand.  And I believe by yielding the time to one speaker strengthens the substantive case even more, through the consistency of the interrelated points of law coming from one voice.

I also believe we are going to win this case.  Every professional organization involved in drug aspects of the criminal justice system and/or treatment are aligned against the proposition, with the exception of public defenders, and they are not aligned for it.  The backers of the amendment have not been able to break out a single treatment center to speak for it, and they have tried mightily.

Jim McDonough

From: Marstiller, Simone [mailto:simone.marstiller@myflorida.com] 
Sent: Tuesday, December 04, 2001 4:28 PM 
To: Jeb Bush 
Cc: McDonough, Jim 
Subject: Drug Treatment Initiative Oral Argument on 12/10/01 



Governor: 

As you know, we filed a brief in the Fla. Supreme Court on your behalf 
opposing the drug treatment initiative.  Oral argument is scheduled for 
Monday, Dec. 10 at 9:00 a.m.  We requested oral argument when the brief 
was 
filed in order to preserve the opportunity.  However, four of the five 
parties opposing the initiative -- including the EOG -- are scheduled to 

argue and have been alotted 5 minutes each.  The other parties' briefs 
-- 
especially that of Save Our Society from Drugs -- largely cover the same 

territory covered in our brief, although they make additional arguments, 
as 
well.  Because of the overlap, and because FDLE and the Prosecuting 
Attorneys Assn can adequately advance the concerns of the executive 
branch, 
we propose waiving or yielding our time to the other parties to best 
utilize 
the time given to the initiative's opponents collectively. 

Please let me know whether you agree or disagree.  Thank you. 

Simone Marstiller 
Legal Affairs

-----Original Message-----
From: Maidique [mailto:maidique@fiu.edu]
Sent: Friday, December 07, 2001 12:46 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Dec. 17 meeting


Governor,

I regret I won't be able to join the other university presidents when
they meet with you on the 17th.  That's graduation day for us, and I
will be hosting Secretary of Energy Spencer Abraham, who will be our
commencement speaker.  Chairman Codina will be hosting the Secretary for
dinner at his home that evening.  It's part of our strategy to lay the
groundwork for the major new federal energy center at FIU I discussed
personally with you when we met in Miami.

For your information, I have attached the first two paragraphs of the
proposal's executive summary.

Best regards,

Mitch



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The events of September 11th and subsequent military action bring the
issue of the Nation's energy security into sharp focus once again.  This
proposal suggests a way to enhance U.S. energy security by building on
the United States' longstanding historical, commercial, social, and
geopolitical ties with Latin America.  Florida International University
(FIU) proposes to create a new kind of academic research, policy
analysis, technology development, and student training institution to
help increase the development of energy supplies and improve energy
efficiency throughout Latin America.

An additional benefit from implementing this proposal would be the
promotion of economic development and political stability throughout the
Western Hemisphere by encouraging clean and affordable development of
indigenous energy resources through investment and technology policya
clear win-win proposition for both the United States and Latin America.

From:	George Wedgworth <ghwedgworth@msn.com>
Sent:	Friday, December 7, 2001 3:15 PM
To:	Jeb Bush

Dear Governor Bush:

On your watch, the Florida Department of Environmental Protection is now 
proposing a phosphorus rule for the Everglades that will be the gretest 
public policy disaster Florida has faced in 30 years. DEP intends to propose 
a phosphorus standard of 10 ppb based on what it believes would cause no 
changes in the unimpacted (pristine) areas which are 94% of the remaining 
Everglades. The rule would then propose to apply this standard across the 
board to the impacted areas (the remaining 6%) of the Everglades, even 
though neither Florida nor Federal law requires this. While on the surface 
one might read the political tea leaves as indicating public support for 
this stringent Everglades regulation, the misguided DEP proposal promises to 
waste $2-4 billion dollars of taxpayers' money that would likely require tax 
increases during your second administration, potentially devastate an 
important agricultural contributor to Florida's economy and at the same time 
increase mercury contamination in Everglades fish and wildlife to levels 
that further endanger their continued existence. Rumor has it that you have 
reviewed this proposal with DEP and concur with it. We can only assume that 
you have not been fully or fairly briefed on the scientific and economic 
reasons against this proposal. We implore you to give us the opportunity to 
brief you on the economic and environmental consequences of the proposal 
before DEP makes it public at next Tuesday's meeting of the Environmental 
Regulation Commission. I can be reached at (863) 467-9822 over the weekend 
and at my office (561) 996-4701 on Monday.

Respectfully,

George H. Wedgworth
President and CEO of
Sugar Cane Growers Cooperative of Florida

>  <<Gov Brief 120601.doc>> 
From:	RDuKate@aol.com
Sent:	Friday, December 7, 2001 2:50 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Consumer contract scams

Dear Gov. Bush, 

I have become the victim of a scam involving a home alarm service which has an automatic annual renewal clause in the contract.  As a result of this event, it has made me aware that there are probably thousands of Florida residents who have also become victims of similar consumer contracts, so I would like to make a recommendation to provide a remedy to this situation. 

Specifically, I would like to recommend legislation which would require all "automatically" annual renewal invoices to be mailed to consumers BEFORE the renewal date with bold print stating that this contract is the result of an automatic renewal provision in your contract and the consumer has 30 days to notify the business provider if they wish to discontinue the contract. 

In my situation I had signed a contract for 3 years of alarm monitoring service for my residence.  At the end of the 1st and 2nd years I noticed that I received the renewal invoices about 30-60 days after the annual renewal date, but assumed this was an accounting or technology problem with the business, Alarm Depot of Miami, Florida.  After the 3rd yr. of service I again received the invoice about 45 days after the renewal date, so I telephoned the company and instructed them to discontinue the service (the sales rep. had initially told me that a telephone call would be all that was required to cancel the contract even though it states in the contract that this must be done in writing).   

Approximately a month later I received a call from the company in which they told me that I was past due on the invoice so I told them that I had already called and canceled the service.  At this time, I was told by the company rep. that this had to be done in writing and since it wasn't done in writing they could not cancel the service.  On Dec. 6th I received a call from a collection agency in which a very nice lady informed me that I was delinquent and threatened to ruin my credit if I did not pay.  I explained to her that I had canceled, so contacted the company to ask them and called me back to inform me that I had not canceled so they were threatening to sue me as well as place negative remarks on my credit reports. 

I called the company and spoke with Paul who he said I spoke with previously.  He told me that since I had not canceled the contract in writing PRIOR to the renewal date that the full contract amount was due and that he could not accept my cancellation verbally, as I had done attempted to do twice before when speaking with the company.  While he claimed that they have a responsibility to not take verbal cancellations due to someone mistakenly not having security service due to unauthorized cancellation, I counted that argument that this did not make sense due to the fact that the alarm company has passwords which could have been used to verify the authority of the person in which they were speaking. 

After spending a consider amount of time and aggravation on the phone with the company's representatives, I realized that this entire process is a scam to keep people in contracts for longer than they desire.  As a matter of fact, the renewal notice I received this year was also received the same day that I received a delinquency notice for this same invoice.  Furthermore, nowhere on the renewal invoice is there any text notifying customers that this is an "automatically" renewal of the contract, nor any disclosure that cancellation is required in writing BEFORE the renewal date.  Of course it will be impossible to a customer to cancel when renewal invoice is received since the renewal date has already passed. 

In my opinion, what should concern the lawmakers is the fact that this is a relatively small amount of money, i.e., $300, so I am sure that 99% of the customers who are pressed for collection just mail them a check to get collection agents and the company off their backs.  While my situation involves an alarm company, but I suspect that there are other service contracts used in this state that have similar terms which are designed to extract money from customers without their approval.  Hence, my recommendation that this legislation be applied to all consumer contracts in the state, especially for amounts under $500. 

For your investigation the name of this company is Alarm Depot and they are located at 9960 NW 116th Way, Suite 7, Medley, FL 33178 and their telephone number is 305-471-7950. 

Please keep me informed of any investigation results and any proposed legislative changes brought about as a result of this correspondence. 
Sincerely, 
Robert DuKate 
5351 NW 3rd Terrace 
Boca Raton, FL 33487 
tel.-561-994-2498

-----Original Message-----
From: Lynch, Tom [mailto:lyncht@infinity-software.com]
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 1:54 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: RE: Blackberry/Outlook Solution


Governor,
 
Our tests yesterday were successful.  We are implementing the solution this afternoon.  We will continue to monitor the system through this afternoon and expect a final assessment no later than tomorrow morning.  FWIW,  Bruce has been a big help and a joy to work with.  We would have been unsuccessful without his assistance.  

 
I'll keep you posted on our progress.
 
Tom Lynch

Infinity Software Development, Inc.
 
------------
 
P.S.  a more detailed/technical assessment of the situation follows: 
 

Statement of the Problem:

The client was experiencing a problem getting their Blackberry wireless email device to synchronize with Outlook. A generic method (POP3) was used to download email messages from an Exchange server to a laptop. The Blackberry was also used to receive email via wireless. When the Blackberry was placed in the cradle attached to a laptop it would not "synchronize" with Exchange or Outlook on the laptop. In other words, messages that were received, read, deleted, or replied to with the Blackberry were updated on neither the Exchange Server nor Outlook. 

The Analysis:

The Blackberry device will not work with the generic method (POP3) of handling emails. Blackberry requires that its cradle and attached computer have a direct connection to the Exchange Server.  Blackberry synchronizes with the Exchange Server, not Outlook. 

The Solution:

We configured the laptop with an Outlook profile to connect directly to the Exchange Server.  The Blackberry device now works. When the device is put in the cradle it automatically updates the Exchange Server and, by extension, Outlook. We further modified Outlook to use "offline" folders. This provides two major advantages. First, it allows Outlook to be used without an Internet connection. Emails may be managed normally. The next time Outlook is connected to Exchange, it again synchronizes (e.g. sending or deleting emails). The second advantage to this solution is that it requires the least direct communication with Exchange. This is a benefit when operating on a dial-up or low bandwidth line. Using Outlook with offline folders will not significantly degrade performance compared to using Outlook with a POP3 connection. 

In summary, we recommend to Bruce to discontinue using POP3.  Instead, use a direct connection to Exchange with Outlooks offline folders enabled. He is going to implement the solution this afternoon. Their ISP will reconfigure their firewall to enable communication this afternoon. Bruce will also reconfigure their Exchange 2000 Server. Infinity has created a modification for the Exchange Server for Bruce to use.  Infinity will meet with Bruce at 1pm today to assist in the process.

From:	Nina Oviedo <oviedon@sso.org>
Sent:	Friday, December 7, 2001 2:35 PM

Cc:	Kathy Shoaf; Betty Hampton; Laura Branker; Karen Hogan; Jill Randolph; Brian Yablonski; Frank R. Jimenez; Kathleen Shanahan
Subject:	Call to Senator Lott

BETTY/KATHY, PLS PRINT FOR GOVERNOR AND KATHLEEN.
 
Governor, below is a brief description/update on TANF Supplemental grants and UPL, and suggested talking points for your call to Senator Lott.  Given the latest stand-off on an economic stimulus bill (there are serious concerns that we wont see a bill before Christmas), it really may be more important to call Chairman Young.  Without an economic stimulus package, both UPL and TANF Grants can be added to the Labor-H appropriations bill. 
 
Senator Lott may be reached at 202/224-3135; Chairman Young may be reached at 225-5961.  
 
Background---TANF Supplemental Grants:
 
Senate Finance Committee passed a one year extension of the TANF Supplemental Grants two weeks ago, and have been trying to get it on the Senate calendar.  Republican Leader Trent Lott is the latest Senator to place a hold on the legislation.  He is concerned that the offset is not valid.  We are also working to pass this bill in some form in either the stimulus package, or one of the last appropriations bills before Congress adjourns.  Senator Lott's support (or at the least, no objection) would be important in whatever package may become available.  This one-year extension of TANF supplemental grants will provide an additional $60 million to Florida.
 
Background---Medicaid Upper Payment Limit (UPL):
 
Governor, while you have Senator Lott on the phone, you may also want to raise the Medicaid Upper Payment Limit.  With the recent rule from HHS/CMS reducing the UPL from 150% to 100% sometime in the spring, Florida's $185 million program may be at risk.  There are bills in both the House and Senate that would create a one-year moratorium on HHS/CMS in going forward with the rule until January 2003. 
 
Suggested Talking Points:
*	Mr. Leader, [make small talk about watching proceedingsdifficultjust finished our own session.]  
*	TANF supplemental grants are very important to Florida---and all southern states.
*	These supplemental grants are intended to provide equity for states with historically low welfare payments and high growth. 
*	TANF reserves from prior years have been depleted in Florida, and in other sunbelt states. 
*	Everyday Florida has new TANF applicants due to our economic slowdown----putting new strains on our programs. 
*	Without these grants, Florida's ability to provide critical TANF work supports will suffer.
*	These are not welfare payments.  The grants serve to help with transportation and child care services, so that citizens can go to work.
UPL
*	We also need help with Florida's UPL plan.
*	These dollars are directed to hospitals serving low-income and uninsured populations 
*	The program was designed to provide financial stability to our safety-net hospitals 
*	CONCLUSION:  In this soft economy, I would appreciate any thing you can do to help with a UPL soft landing until January of 2003, and I would appreciate your help in getting a one-year extension of TANF supplemental grants passed before Congress recesses.

-----Original Message-----
From: William Buckey [mailto:buckeyw@sso.org]
Sent: Friday, December 07, 2001 2:19 PM
To: Pamella Dana; Nina Oviedo; Marla Gillman; Kellie Jo Kilberg; Kathy Ward; Kathleen Shanahan; Frank Brogan; Diana Gonzalez; Brewser Brown; Bob Black; Anderson, John
Subject: 



Inside the Pentagon reported that an announcement on the creation of a Homeland Defense Command is imminent in the "next few weeks." Many in the Army reportedly favor identifying Joint Forces Command as the homeland security lead, whereas the other Services on the whole prefer the creation of an entirely new command organization to handle that mission.

The Joint Staff's Directorate for Strategic Plans and Policy (J-5) has led a working group of O-6 level officers for several weeks to flesh out options for tasking the homeland security mission.

If a new organization is created, other elements of the unified combatant command structure may be cut, according to Inside the Pentagon, and one potential candidate for trimming or elimination is said to be Southern Command.

Source: Inside the Pentagon, December 6, 2001

From:	Nina Strickland/Greg K. Sloan, M.D. <fca@digitalexp.com>
Sent:	Friday, December 7, 2001 2:16 PM
To:	Jeb Bush

Subject:	The "Newer Kinder" Medicare (CMS)

Dear Governor Bush,
 
I am writing this letter to comment on the "newer, kinder" Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.  I certainly have not found them to be any less frustrating than usual.
 
Have you looked at the Provider Application process lately?  We I have!  I am in process of completing an application for a physician who will be joining our group soon.  When I signed onto the CMA website to print the application, I was overwhelmed, to say the least, to find that one section of the application was 57 pages long, one section was 67 pages long, one section was 31 pages long and just the reassignment of benefits form was 9 pages long.  Maybe you would not be intimated by the sheer volume of these applications but a simple working person out here in the trenches is.  It was my understanding that the new applications, effective November, 2001, were simpler, clearer and easier. But looking at these I sure don't feel that they are simpler, clearer and easier.  
 
I did receive The Florida Medicare B Update on Saturday, December 1 which included information regarding a "FREE" Provider Enrollment Workshop to be held in Jacksonville, FL on December 13 or 14th.  It stated that we should "Register Early, because "Seating is limited."  However, there was no phone number, fax number etc to facilitate that happening.  When I finally did get a phone number for Provider Education (not an 800# by the way) 904-791-6422 and I began calling on Monday, Dec. 3 to register I was instructed to leave a detailed message.  I did this including my phone number, fax number, and e-mail address where I could be reached.  I noted that I needed confirmation that I would be able to attend so that I could make travel and motel arrangements as I am approx 6-7 hours away.  I have now made 26 long distance phone calls as well as spending my time which is very valuable to me. By the time I incur travel/hotel costs along with the time and phone calls, this certainly will not have been "FREE" to me.  By Monday, if I were to get a response by then, I will have only 2 days left to make arrangements to attend. 
 
Let me stress, it is very important to me to attend this workshop!!   Having been through the application process several times previously with disastrous results I was so excited to think that I might get my "questions answered directly by a Medicare Expert" who will give me "on-the-spot" assistance in completing and submitting my enrollment applications.  
 
I have always supported you and felt that you were supportive of the people in this state and the medical community.  I will certainly appreciate it if you can offer any assistance to a small rural town physician's office in your state.
 
Nina Strickland, CPC CMA
Practice Administrator
Family Care Associates of NW Florida
925 Carlisle Road
Chipley, FL   32428
(850) 638-1634
Fax (850) 638-3720
fca@digitalexp.com

From:	Bahrami, Kimberly <Kim.Bahrami@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Friday, December 7, 2001 2:01 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: STO and Bobby 

Governor,
 
The TimeDirect system was originally developed in 1999 and the program has been significantly enhanced since that time to respond to needs and comments of our customers.  These enhancements include increased accessibility for the system.  Some previous accessiblity issues with the system were quickly resolved with an upgrade to the user's accessibility tool.  The STO works closely with Julie Shaw and the ADA Working Group to solve issues such as these, and, in checking with Julie on this issue, she is not aware of any unresolved accessibility issues with TimeDirect.  The email does not specifically mention any accessibility problem but rather stresses the importance of testing the system with the Bobby Program.  I will check on whether a new issue has arisen.  However, the STO does not set its accessibility standard relative to results from the Bobby Program.  The Bobby Program is not a true measure of accessibility and is generally seen as an introduction to the issue.  Many Web sites may pass a Bobby review and yet remain inaccessible.   Again, we work closely with Julie and others on this issue, and they do not recommend the Bobby approach.  For Web site accessibility, our standard is Section 508 of the Rehabilitation Act -  the current and significantly more comprehensive federal standard.
 
I understand the Department of Health issue has been ongoing since November 2000.  Julie Shaw was made aware of the situation in October of this year and brought it to the attention of the STO last month.  I understand a work analysis evaluation has been performed by the Division of Blind Services, the solution is now a top priority within DOH, and the problem will be fixed in two to three months.  I am also working with the CIOs to insert a "web accessibility" component into our statewide applications procurement and development processes.  I will continue to monitor this issue. 
 
If you would like to discuss further, please let me know.
 
Kim

-----Original Message-----
From: Mathis, Linda [mailto:MathisL@dms.state.fl.us]
Sent: Wednesday, November 28, 2001 8:36 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: STO and Bobby 



Dear Governor Bush: 

Thank you for forwarding my e-mail to the appropriate persons who handle the 
Times Direct system.  I have spoken with Donna Livingston at DMS about the 
issue and hopefully they will test the system with the Bobby program to make 
it more accessible.  It may not cost a lot of money either since many of the 
changes that the Bobby Program includes are simple.  I strongly encouraged 
her to work on this problem since the state does not want to be put in a 
position of looking as though it does not care if it complies with federal 
laws.  The ADA is not a voluntary law.  I don't think the state can argue 
hardship either because it knew before the system was purchased that the 
Bobby program should be included and used to make it accessible. I don't 
know why the STO did not check this before they bought the program.  

I have a friend who works for the Department of Health and she is having the 
same problem with their statewide program used for case management.  The 
department of Health was told before they ever purchased this case 
management program that it was not accessible to the disabled however, they 
purchased it anyway. Since that department receives federal money they are 
in an awkward position because they could be sued under several different 
laws including the OFCCP and probably the DOJ. Ninety per cent of her job is 
computer work and since they have installed this new program she is unable 
to do her job because the entire program is icon based and totally 
inaccessible to blind persons who use speech programs.  It also uses a blue 
screen which makes Braille displays unusable and prevents her from using an 
Optacon which is an old device that people used to use to read displays 
before speech programs were created.  This lady, Ms. Elizabeth Bowden,  has 
worked with the Vocational Rehabilitation program for ten years and now 
because of this badly designed Department of Health Case Management system, 
she will probably have to be moved to another position through no fault of 
her own and will have to move from the job that she does very well.  She is 
a VR Technician and has handled the job well until now. By the way, the 
Comptroller's office program for Employee Earnings Statement review works 
very well and is totally accessible.   

I am letting you know these things, because  the STO is falling down on the 
job in making the state's computer systems more efficient and user friendly. 
Some of the staff  also have the attitude that its just not important and 
we've never had a blind employee before so we just didn't know.   I think it 
is very important especially when the state may be subject to being sued 
when that is not necessary if precautions  are taken. Also,not having had to 
deal with disabled employees before is not an excuse especially when there 
are programs like Bobby available to assist in making programs compliant. 

Sincerely, 

Linda Mathis
