December 5, 2001

MEMORANDUM

To:		Chief Stephen Lauer
From:		General Counsel Michael Ramage
Subject:	Terrorism Proposals Enacted By Special Session
	


As you know, this morning the Florida House Of Representatives passed
several terrorism-related bills.   The proposals have now passed the
Legislature (having passed the Senate on Monday) and move to Governor Bush
for signing.  He will sign them promptly, and we expect there will be formal
bill-signing event since these proposals are of major significance.  The
proposals become effective "upon becoming law" when Governor Bush signs
them. 

Here is a brief summary of each bill that passed.  Included is a link to the
Legislature's web site where the bill as passed can be reviewed.  Each bill,
including legislative staff analyses and vote histories, as well as the
"enrolled" (final, as will go into law books) version, can be located at the
Legislature's web site: www.leg.state.fl.us under "Senate" chamber and the
2001-C Session.  (Note:  When accessing the site, it defaults to the 2002
Session.  You have to manually change to the 2001-C Session.  Make sure the
"Senate" is selected as the chamber.)  If there is any question about the
impact or purpose of any proposal noted below, feel free to call me at (850)
410-7676 or email me at: michaelramage@fdle.state.fl.us

----------------------------------------------------------------------------
-----------------------------------------------------------

Bills Establishing Domestic Security Task Forces and Database:

S 24-C  Domestic Security/Counter-terrorism; requires FDLE to coordinate &
  direct response to acts of terrorism; provides legislative intent re
  counter-terrorism efforts & initial responses to acts of terrorism
  within or affecting this state; requires FDLE to establish regional
  domestic security task force in each of FDLE's operational regions;
  requires regional task forces to provide for investigating & responding
  to certain hate crimes, etc. Amends Ch. 943; creates 775.30.  
EFFECTIVE DATE: Upon becoming law.
(Passed Senate 37-0; House 119-0)
http://www.leg.state.fl.us/data/session/2001C/Senate/bills/billtext/pdf/s002
4Ce1.pdf

S 26-C  Domestic Security/Counter-terrorism; creates Fla. Domestic Security
&
  Counter-Terrorism Intelligence Center within FDLE; creates Fla. Domestic
  Security & Counter-Terrorism Database within intelligence center;
  provides functions of intelligence center re gathering & analyzing
  active criminal intelligence information & criminal investigative
  information; requires intelligence center to maintain & operate
  database, etc. Creates 775.30, 943.0321.  
EFFECTIVE DATE: Upon becoming law.
(Passed Senate 38-0; House 115-1)
http://www.leg.state.fl.us/data/session/2001C/Senate/bills/billtext/pdf/s002
6C.pdf

 
Bills Defining "Terrorism" and Setting Enhanced Sentencing For
"Terrorism-Related" Crimes:

SB 6-C	Definition of "Terrorism."  Creating s.
775.30, F.S.; defining "terrorism" for purposes of the Florida Criminal
Code; amending s.
907.041, F.S.; providing for pretrial detention of persons charged with an
act of terrorism.
EFFECTIVE DATE: Upon becoming law.
(Passed Senate 37-0; House 118-0)
http://www.leg.state.fl.us/data/session/2001C/Senate/bills/billtext/pdf/s000
6Ce1.pdf

SB 8-C	Sentencing/Act of Terrorism; provides for reclassification of
offenses
  commission of which facilitated or furthered any act of terrorism;
  defines term "terrorism"; includes any felony that is act of terrorism
  or is in furtherance of act of terrorism as qualifying offense under
  felony murder provisions; creates crime of felony murder involving any
  felony that is act of terrorism or is in furtherance of act of
  terrorism; defines term "terrorism". Creates 775.31; amends 782.04.
  EFFECTIVE DATE: Upon becoming law. 
(Passed Senate 38-0; House 119-0)
http://www.leg.state.fl.us/data/session/2001C/Senate/bills/billtext/pdf/s000
8C.pdf

Bills Expanding Public Record or Sunshine Law Exemptions:

SB 16-C	Public Records/Security-system Plan; provides exemption from
  public-records requirements for security-system plan or portion thereof;
  provides exemption from public-meeting requirements for those portions
  of any meeting which would reveal security-system plan or portion
  thereof which is confidential & exempt under this act; provides for
  future review & repeal; provides statement of public necessity. 
Creates 119.071, 286.0113.  
EFFECTIVE DATE: Upon becoming law.
(Passed Senate 38-0; House 115-3)
http://www.leg.state.fl.us/data/session/2001C/Senate/bills/billtext/pdf/s001
6Ce1.pdf

SB 22-C	Law Enforcement Public Records Requests; creates exemption from
public-records
  requirements; provides that request by law enforcement agency from
  another agency for information from public entity is exempt; provides
  that response of public entity to law enforcement agency for information
  is exempt; provides for future repeal & review; provides statement of
  public necessity. Amends 119.07.  
EFFECTIVE DATE: Upon becoming law.
(Passed Senate 37-1; House 117-2)
http://www.leg.state.fl.us/data/session/2001C/Senate/bills/billtext/pdf/s002
2Cc1.pdf

Terrorism-Related Changes To Chapter 934 Related To Interceptions Of
Communications:

SB 12-C	Communications Interception; adds aircraft piracy to list of crimes
for
  which interception of communications may be authorized; adds
  solicitation to commit certain offenses to list of crimes for which
  interception of communications may be authorized; allows judge, in
  investigations of acts of terrorism, to authorize continued interception
  anywhere within state of wire, oral, or electronic communications under
  specified conditions, etc. Amends Ch. 934.  
EFFECTIVE DATE: Upon becoming law except as otherwise provided.
(Passed Senate 37-0; House 117-1)
http://www.leg.state.fl.us/data/session/2001C/Senate/bills/billtext/pdf/s001
2C.pdf
 
Public Records & Sunshine Law Exemptions Related To Hospitals and
Pharmaceuticals:

SB 18-C	Public Records/Emergency-management; provides exemption from
  public-records requirements for those portions of comprehensive
  emergency-management plan which addresses response of public or private
  hospital to act of terrorism; creates exemption for those portions of
  said plan which address response of public hospital to said act;
  provides exemption from public-meeting requirements for any portion of
  public meeting which would reveal information contained in said plan, etc.
Creates 395.1056.  
EFFECTIVE DATE: Effective upon SB 6-C becoming law.
(Passed Senate 38-0; House 116-2)
http://www.leg.state.fl.us/data/session/2001C/Senate/bills/billtext/pdf/s001
8Ce1.pdf

SB 20-C	Public Records/Pharmaceutical; provides that any information
identifying
  or describing name, location, pharmaceutical cache, contents, capacity,
  equipment, physical features, or capabilities of individual medical
  facilities, storage facilities, or laboratories established, maintained,
  or regulated by Health Dept. in response to act of terrorism are exempt
  from public-records requirements; provides for future review & repeal;
  provides statement of public necessity.  
EFFECTIVE DATE: Effective upon SB 6-C becoming law.
(Passed Senate 38-1; House 116-2)
http://www.leg.state.fl.us/data/session/2001C/Senate/bills/billtext/pdf/s002
0Ce1.pdf

State Agriculture's Terrorism-Related Initiatives:

SB 10-C	Poisoning; prohibits introduction or addition of any poison, or
  introduction, addition, or mingling of any bacterium, radioactive
  material, virus, chemical compound, or specified products into food,
  drink, medicine, or water systems under certain circumstances; provides
  penalties; amends provision to conform to changes made by act. 
Amends 859.01, 921.0022.  
EFFECTIVE DATE: Upon becoming law.
(Passed Senate 38-0; House 119-0)	
http://www.leg.state.fl.us/data/session/2001C/Senate/bills/billtext/pdf/s001
0Cc1.pdf

SB 14-C	Agric. & Consumer Services Dept.; authorizes department to adopt
rules
  establishing requirements governing aircraft used for aerial application
  of pesticides & requirements governing storage of pesticides &
  fertilizers; authorizes department to adopt rules establishing
  requirements governing aircraft used for aerial application of seed;
  requires that dept. report to Legislature on implementation of any rule
  adopted as authorized by act, etc. 
Amends 487.051, 570.07, 576.181,578.11.  
EFFECTIVE DATE: Upon becoming law.
(Passed Senate 37-1; House 119-0)
http://www.leg.state.fl.us/data/session/2001C/Senate/bills/billtext/pdf/s001
4Ce1.pdf


Proposals That Did NOT Pass Because Of Significant Opposition:

SB 28-C	Would have authorized delay in inspection or copying of public
record when disclosure would jeopardize safety or impede investigation.
SB 78-B (Considered in Special Session B) Would have authorized circuit
judges to order detention of certain material witnesses for prescribed
period of time under specified circumstances when probable cause to arrest
did not exist.
SB 64-B and 66-B  (Considered in Special Session B) Would have exempted law
officers' cell phone and pager bills and numbers from public records review.

Dear Mr. Bush, 

   I remember coming to you with a plea for help.  I remember how stern and 
serious you took the meeting.  I remember you assigning someone to take care 
of the matter.  Well, here we are, nothing's changed other than DCF trying 
to cover its ass.  Let me give you a quick idea as to what I've lost during 
this ordeal: my truck, my job, my dignity, and my freedom.  I can't do this 
anymore.  Your agencies have blantently and provably broken the law, 
violated my rights & civil liberties, harbored an abusive individual and 
lied to cover it up in a swamp of paper work, broken promises and mis 
represented statements.  When the inspector general showed up at my house, 
his only concern was finding a fall guy in the matter; Delisa Mathews will 
be the target I'm sure.  When they dealt with Nancy and Al, it was purely a 
"prove DCF didn't relatiate" routine.  Now, when I talk to Sue Grey & 
BaryBeth on the matter, it's "we don't know anything" or "we can't tell you 
anything".  Well, tell me this Jeb, how is it that I've commited NO CRIME, 
I've done EVERYTHING that DCF has told me and I'm STILL paying for this??? 
No more.  I've waited long enough and sacrificed everything I can.  Is this 
the type of organization that runs the state I live in?  Well, it seems that 
my hands were bound 8 years ago when I was raped & they're still bound 
today.  I'm turning Charlie over to DCF as it's clear that I have no help in 
this matter and DCF has a state budget.  Personally, I hope you feel a 
little better knowing that an 8 year child can't be protected in your state 
because you don't have a clue as to what goes on behind your back.  As for 
me, I'll spend the next 5 or so years trying to recover what has taken me a 
lifetime to aquire and as for Charlie, all I can do is hope he makes it. 

Thanks for your help, 
John Greiner 

If you can't/won't help me, at least prevent this from happening to other 
innocent people. 

From:	Dana, Pamella <pamella.dana@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Friday, December 7, 2001 1:33 PM
To:	Shanahan, Kathleen; Jeb Bush
Cc:	DiBenigno, Arlene
Subject:	RE: NSC Steve Hadley

SOUTHCOM
We are producing a letter now for Gov to send to Rumsfeld.  In my discussion with Asst Sec of Defense, Ray Dubois this morning, he noted that he had not seen (nor heard) about letter sent by Gov to Wolfowitz.   He wanted a faxed copy if possible.   He did say though that Barry McCaffrey has been vocal and adament about keeping SOUTHCOM in Miami.  Dubois said McCaffrey has very compelling arguments.  Congressman Hobson is adamently against it being in Miami (biggest hurdle politically).  FYI, McCaffrey was a former commander of SOUTHCOM.  Also, Chuck Ohlinger was the commander at MacDill when deliberations and decisions were made to put SOUTHCOM, Central Command (CENTCOM), and Special Ops Command (SOCOM) all in Florida.  Charlie said he would be more than willing to help in providing rationale as to why SOUTHCOM needs to remain here.
 
I spoke to Mike Rhodes, SOUTHCOM, today who said that Secretary Rumsfeld has apparently called for a list of potential names of folks to command SOUTHCOM.  Depending how you read it, this may signify that the Secretary is considering keeping SOUTHCOM mission as a regional command (and not subordinating it under homeland defense).
 
HOMESTEAD
The Secretary of Air Force, James Roche is sending a letter out (today?) to advise that the investigation is completed and there are "no deviations" so they are not going to overturn the supplmental ROD.  Also, yesterday, Miami-Dade voted 8 -5 in favor of eco-tourism use. 
 
KEY WEST
Dubois wanted to make sure we were aware and okay with Navy decision to not move forward with transfer of land from Navy to the City due to post 9/11 land needs.  I told him we were aware, and that I had been engaged with local and state leadership to ensure minimal feathers ruffled.
 
VISIT TO TAMPA
Ray Dubois also wanted us to know that he will be in Tampa on Sunday and Monday to speak before a global Special Ops Medical conference.  On Monday, he will also meet with General Tommy Franks and General Holland (SOCOM/CENTCOM).

	Subject:  New Building Codes 


Dear Mr. Governor;

	I have had the opportunity to be involved in many Hurricane recoveries and
cleanup from Camille 1969-70 to Georges 1998-1999. As a practicing Engineer in
public service for more than 35 years, I ask that you do what is required to
NOT delay the implementations of the Florida Unified Building Code. The people
of Florida should not be ask to adsorb the cost replacing the large number of
building being built that will not survive the storms that visit us our
state.

	Delaying the new code is akin to not adding oil to your car when the low oil
indicator is showing. The cost of the probable damage will far out weigh cost
of a quart of oil. 

	The citizens of Florida need you to stand tall and firm in their corner as a
voice of reason as others over react to events of the last few months.


	Thank you for your time and attention.

From:	Maidique <maidique@fiu.edu>
Sent:	Friday, December 7, 2001 12:46 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Dec. 17 meeting

Governor,

I regret I won't be able to join the other university presidents when
they meet with you on the 17th.  That's graduation day for us, and I
will be hosting Secretary of Energy Spencer Abraham, who will be our
commencement speaker.  Chairman Codina will be hosting the Secretary for
dinner at his home that evening.  It's part of our strategy to lay the
groundwork for the major new federal energy center at FIU I discussed
personally with you when we met in Miami.

For your information, I have attached the first two paragraphs of the
proposal's executive summary.

Best regards,

Mitch



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The events of September 11th and subsequent military action bring the
issue of the Nation's energy security into sharp focus once again.  This
proposal suggests a way to enhance U.S. energy security by building on
the United States' longstanding historical, commercial, social, and
geopolitical ties with Latin America.  Florida International University
(FIU) proposes to create a new kind of academic research, policy
analysis, technology development, and student training institution to
help increase the development of energy supplies and improve energy
efficiency throughout Latin America.

An additional benefit from implementing this proposal would be the
promotion of economic development and political stability throughout the
Western Hemisphere by encouraging clean and affordable development of
indigenous energy resources through investment and technology policya
clear win-win proposition for both the United States and Latin America.
From:	Gleason, Patrick <GleasonPJ@cdm.com>
Sent:	Friday, December 7, 2001 12:42 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	'David Struhs'; 'Denver Stutler'
Subject:	Everglades Phosphorus Rule

Dear Governor Bush:  I am one of your governing board appointees to the
South Florida Water Management District.  I would like to provide you with
some throughts for the Everglades Phosphorus Rule that will be forthcoming
soon.  Earlier this week, Henry Dean and I met with four representatives of
the sugar industry regarding this issue.  Their concerns are very much along
the same lines as mine.  First, I believe that the phosphorus standard is 10
parts per billion phosphorus.  Research strongly supports this.  This in
itself is not an issue.   Second, where the standard is met is an issue.
Meeting it at the end of pipe will be an impossibility.  There is no
technology that we can use today that will get us there except for chemical
treatment no one wants to use it because of possible marsh effects and
disposal problems with the waste stream.  The STAs can get us to the range
of 20-30 ppb.  To set a standard of 10 ppb at end of pipe will automatically
put us in violation of the rule. A possible solution is to meet the standard
in the marsh.  Or possibly to give us more time perhaps another five years
to attempt to find a cost effective means of reaching the standard.   Third,
if there was an application of a technology such as chemical treatment that
could get us to 10 ppb phosphorus, it would probably cost about $1billion to
$2 billion to achieve it.  Inasmuch as we are having funding problems
everywhere (Everglades, Lake Okeechobee, alternative water supplies, land
acquisition, etc) this is too great a burden.  

I would like to ask for your consideration in asking the Department of
Environmental Protection to not come up with a phosphorus rule that will
automatically put us in default of the rule and in severe debt and without a
technology that is acceptable.  

Thank you governor for your consideration of these ideas. 

Pat 

Patrick J. Gleason
Patrick J. Gleason, Ph.D., P.G.
Governing Board
South Florida Water Management District
561-386-0278 (cell phone)
561-689-3336 (office phone) 
gleasonpj@cdm.com

From:	Laura Udell <ludell305@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Friday, December 7, 2001 12:42 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Haulover Park

December 7, 2001


Honorable Jeb Bush
Governor, State of Florida
Executive Office of the Governor
The Capitol
Tallahassee, Florida 32399

RE:	Haulover Park, Northern Miami-Dade County

Dear Governor,

   I applaud the Department of Environmental
protections recent order denying a permit for a
Gambling Boat to be located at Haulover Park, a public
park located in northern Miami-Dade County. 

   It has become increasingly evident that the Parks
Department, along with lobbyists and some publicly
elected officials intend to use the Park to line their
pockets rather than provide quality recreational
entertainment for the public.  In addition to failing
to follow their mandate to protect rather than harm
the natural environment, the Parks Departments
redevelopment plan uses tax dollars to pay for
improvements that will benefit commercial enterprises
rather than the public at large.

   I participated in a Labor Day Awareness Session at
Haulover.  I spoke with hundreds of people that day
who were there to enjoy the park.  Overwhelmingly,
these people were frustrated that a gambling boat was
running out of the park and taking up parking spaces
for families.  They disliked the fact that parking for
the gambling boat was free, while the amount of 
parking for park users was reduced and cost $4.00. 
More importantly, people were upset that this was how
the Parks department was using its time and energy. 
They expressed a desire for more trees (shade) in the
park, and more playgrounds for their children.  Many
families are moving into areas that were previously
largely retirement communities near the Park.  They
would like a place to take their children to play, not
a place to go gambling.  The park stands greatly
neglected, yet the slated improvements do not include
refurbishing public benches and restrooms for years. 
Instead, the Parks department is paving the way for
commercial enterprises to operate out of the park.  I
will send you some of the comment cards people filled
out on Labor Day under separate cover so you can see
for yourself that the Parks Department plans do not
reflect the will of park users.

   I appreciate your Departments decision to block
gambling in this beautiful park near my home, and hope
that you will continue with your good work to ensure
this public treasure will be enjoyed by generations to
come for what it was intended to be: a public park.

Sincerely,

LaRein Udell
9180 Byron Avenue
Surfside, FL  33154
Tel. 305-861-2167

From:	Herbert, Adam <aherbert@unf.edu>
Sent:	Friday, December 7, 2001 12:05 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Presidential salaries

You have probably seen the attached article, but I want to flag it for you
because it has VERY significant negative implications.  Before I left the
Chancellor's office we hired a consultant who specializes in reviewing
presidential salaries.  The current salary structure for presidents reflects
the results of that survey.  You should know that there are no states in
America in which the president of a second level research institution earns
a higher salary than those in the major research institutions.  In this
case, Mitch will not only make more than the presidents of UF, FSU and USF,
but more than that of many of the presidents of most of the American
Association of Universities presidents (the major research institutions in
America).  In addition to the $285,000 salary, he also will receive another
12% of that amount from the foundation. This brings the total cash
compensation package to:  $319,200, along with a car and free housing.  

This action will put pressure on all the other Boards of Trustees to
increase salaries of their presidents so that the current salary balance
related to mission is returned.  When the faculty around the state hear
about this over the next few days, it will cause those with salaries above
$90,000 to  ignore your request to reject salary increases.  The argument
will be that if the Boards of Trustees can ignore your request in
establishing presidential salaries, why should they comply with your
request.  This action could not have come at a worse time for the
universities.  It sends a message that is totally inconsistent with your
expressed desires for sacrifice.  Moreover, any responsible consultant
analyzing presidential salaries could not have made such a recommendation
based on all the data I saw over the last four years as Chancellor.  

A critical policy question here is whether local boards sould have the final
decision authority on compensation issues without review and approval either
by the Secretary of Education or the State Board.  As these decisions have
such significant implications for the entire university system, such a
review is essential if you want to maintain a rational presidential salary
strucuture for the state.

If you would like any other observations or information, please let me know.

Adam



Adam W. Herbert
Regents Professor and Executive Director
The Florida Center for Public Policy and Leadership
University of North Florida
12000 Alumni Way
Jacksonville, Florida   32224
Phone:  904-620-4400

From:	Sharon Bourassa <SBourassa@LegalAid.org>
Sent:	Friday, December 7, 2001 11:56 AM

-----Original Message-----
From: Corie Shomper [mailto:CShomper@BPINEWS.COM]
Sent: Friday, December 07, 2001 11:17 AM
To: 'sbourassa@legalaid.org'
Subject: Wingate story 


Here is the story that ran on the Wingate Landfill. Sorry it took me so long to get it to you I have been in and out of the office this week. It ran in the 12/3 issue. Thanks for all your help.
Corie Shomper 
 
Taxpayers Foot Bill on Wingate Landfill
But Cleanup Still Lags, Activist Says
 
       Residents have paid for cleanup of the Wingate Road Municipal Incinerator and Landfill Superfund Site for more than 20 years but have seen no results, according to one citizen.
 
       Denise Cobb, president of Second Chance Inc., a nonprofit organization that follows federal funding for the Fort Lauderdale community, said she found out that the Fort Lauderdale government has billed the community for cleanup of the landfill. People are getting angry and want the city to use that money to clean the landfill, she told HWSW. 
 
       The remedy for the landfill is a cap, according to government officials. When the city says cap it is misleading because it sounds secure, but what the city is doing is putting a plastic and soil layer over the landfill, she said.
 
Find Alternatives, Citizens Say
 
       The community wants the landfill remediated using other alternatives besides the cap, Legal Aid of Broward County Inc. lawyer Sharon Bourassa said. But the state wants to keep the plastic liner, "the horse and buggy of our time," instead of using newer technology, she told HWSW. Bourassa represents a group of mostly black residents of public housing projects adjacent to the dump in an environmental justice case. She recently filed appellant briefs on behalf of the residents. The court will review the case Dec. 20, she said.
 
       Citing higher-than-expected levels of pollutants, the residents said they want to move. The case was dismissed by a federal judge in August (HWSW, Sept. 10, p. 355) and now is being appealed to the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals. 
 
       "Our argument is that it is fine and dandy to restrict potentially responsible parties from litigating during remediation activities, but you cannot restrict citizens from doing so," Bourassa said. 
 
       In addition, not allowing the citizens' concerns to be heard discriminates against minorities because they are usually the ones living around these contaminated sites, Bourassa said. 
 
       "What is driving this whole thing is money and politics, and it's an absolute shame," Cobb said.
 
       The residents also are worried, that, with the war going on, if an explosive was dropped on Wingate the contamination would go everywhere, Bourassa said.
 
       The city plans to build a nine-hole golf course at the site once the cap is finished. When people start trampling and walking on the contamination the movement is going to push the contamination into the ground water, Cobb told HWSW. 
       
       Children will be playing on the golf course and they should not, Bourassa said. The liner may leak. Contacts: Sharon Bourassa, Legal Aid, (954) 765-8950; Denise Cobb, Second Chance Inc., pager: (954) 705-0454.

From: Lynch, Tom [mailto:lyncht@infinity-software.com]

Subject: RE: Blackberry/Outlook Solution


Governor,

We will continue to monitor the system through this afternoon and expect a final assessment no later than tomorrow morning.  FWIW,  Bruce has been a big help and a joy to work with.  We would have been unsuccessful without his assistance.

------------
 
P.S.  a more detailed/technical assessment of the situation follows: 
 

Statement of the Problem:

The client was experiencing a problem getting their Blackberry wireless email device to synchronize with Outlook. A generic method (POP3) was used to download email messages from an Exchange server to a laptop. The Blackberry was also used to receive email via wireless. When the Blackberry was placed in the cradle attached to a laptop it would not "synchronize" with Exchange or Outlook on the laptop. In other words, messages that were received, read, deleted, or replied to with the Blackberry were updated on neither the Exchange Server nor Outlook. 

The Analysis:

The Blackberry device will not work with the generic method (POP3) of handling emails. Blackberry requires that its cradle and attached computer have a direct connection to the Exchange Server.  Blackberry synchronizes with the Exchange Server, not Outlook. 

The Solution:

We configured the laptop with an Outlook profile to connect directly to the Exchange Server.  The Blackberry device now works. When the device is put in the cradle it automatically updates the Exchange Server and, by extension, Outlook. We further modified Outlook to use "offline" folders. This provides two major advantages. First, it allows Outlook to be used without an Internet connection. Emails may be managed normally. The next time Outlook is connected to Exchange, it again synchronizes (e.g. sending or deleting emails). The second advantage to this solution is that it requires the least direct communication with Exchange. This is a benefit when operating on a dial-up or low bandwidth line. Using Outlook with offline folders will not significantly degrade performance compared to using Outlook with a POP3 connection. 

In summary, we recommend to Bruce to discontinue using POP3.  Instead, use a direct connection to Exchange with Outlooks offline folders enabled. He is going to implement the solution this afternoon. Their ISP will reconfigure their firewall to enable communication this afternoon. Bruce will also reconfigure their Exchange 2000 Server. Infinity has created a modification for the Exchange Server for Bruce to use.  Infinity will meet with Bruce at 1pm today to assist in the process.

-----Original Message-----
From: WALTER J. CAMPBELL, JR. [mailto:wcampbell@krupnicklaw.com]
Sent: Monday, September 24, 2001 4:08 PM
To: 'Jeb Bush'
Subject: FW: News article




> Dear Jeb;
>
> 	First let me start by saying that  I am truly impressed by the fact
> that you stayed up late at night  to send me an e-mail.   By way, after I
> read the article I can see where you might be confused about my
> quotations.
>
> 	Whenever words that are printed seem to have no logical meaning, I
> am frequently  led to the conclusion that the words have no meaning.  As
> you know, quotations in the print media are as reliable as to where the
> author wishes to place them in an article.  It should also be pointed out
> that criticism is a staple of most newspapers and anybody who read the
> article in the Miami Herald that you question must have questions in their
> own minds as to the placement of the quotations in this article.  The
> interview that I gave dealt with my thoughts as to whether a democrat
> could win the next gubernatorial election in light of the catostrophic
> events of September 11, 2001.
>
> 	The subject matter of the economy was merely an aside.  The reporter
> representated to me that you and members of your staff were quoted as
> saying that there was no budgetary crisis in the state of Florida prior to
> the unspeakable events of September 11, 2001.  It was further
> representated to me that you and members of your staff were blaming the
> democrats in the legislature, which would include me, for trying to create
> a budgetary crisis in the state by suggesting that the state was
> experiencing financial problems prior to the bombings at the World Trade
> Center.  It is interesting to note that I have never demanded nor
> suggested that the state has a financial crisis which required a special
> session of legislature.  Certainly, like most cycles, the economy is at a
> down cycle which needs response by government to help it go into an up
> cycle.  My response to the hypothetical presented to me was that if
> individuals were blaming the democrats for trying to create a financial
> crisis that suggestion would represent politics at it's worst and was
> inappropriate at such a time of tragedy.  My response was not antagonistic
> nor provocative.  It was meant to say that we as a nation must ban
> together and stand strong as one.  We should be neither democrats nor
> republicans but, Americans first and Floridians second.  We all have the
> responsibility to fix this economic problem and not to affix the blame for
> its cause.  The economy had problems prior to the bombing and to try
> politicize at this time in this fashion would be wrong for either party.
>
> 	By the way, the important part of what I said to the reporter was
> not included in my quotation.  I informed the reporter that I couldn't
> believe that either you or your staff would say the things that were
> presented to me.  My grandfather once told me that if I ever got involved
> in politics that I should never take credit for the rain because in times
> of drought I would be blamed for it.  I can assure you that you do not
> have to worry about me because I do believe that you are trying to do the
> best for the state of Florida.  I believe you are a truly honest and
> diligent servant of the people of Florida.  You are my governor and at
> this time of conflict you can be assured that I will assist you in every
> effort to make sure that we Floridians and Americans survive this tragedy.
>
> 							Sincerely,
>
>
>
> 							Walter "Skip"
> Campbell
>
> P.S.  The President should be congratulated for a job well done.  Tell him
> to keep up the good work.




From:	Nina Oviedo <oviedon@sso.org>
Sent:	Friday, December 7, 2001 10:18 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	Betty Hampton; Brian Yablonski; Frank R. Jimenez; Kathleen Shanahan
Subject:	Congresswoman Meek in hospital

See news report below.  I spoke with Meeks COS.  Apparently its shingles.  Shes still in the hospital but may be out by noon today. A call would be nice----Hospital:  301/295-9302;  home, 202/544-3190.
 
WASHINGTON  Florida Rep. Carrie Meek was hospitalized Thursday after experiencing severe abdominal pains. 
Meek, a five-term Democrat who represents the Miami area, was admitted to Bethesda Naval Hospital, said deputy chief of staff John Shelby. 
Shelby said Meek, 75, began experiencing pain the day before. 
"She went and saw the doctor a couple of times. They were not able to diagnose what was wrong and they were not able to alleviate the pain," Shelby said. "They will be doing tests to find out what's wrong with her." 
Meek was unable to be present for Thursday's vote on whether to grant the president the authority to negotiate trade deals. That measure passed by only one vote. 
Meek's son, Florida state Sen. Kendrick B. Meek, was en route to Washington to be with his mother, Shelby said.

-----Original Message-----
From: Kimberley Fritts [mailto:fritts@podestamattoon.com]
Sent: Wednesday, December 05, 2001 7:08 PM
To: 'kathleen@jeb.org'
Cc: 'jeb@jeb.org'
Subject: Foley Bill


Hi - Hope you guys are well.  As much as I hate to bother you with my
mundane client business, one of our clients has asked me to seek your
assistance on something that could actually benefit Florida.

Don't know whether or not this might have come up yesterday but Mark Foley
has introduced a bill (attached) that will provide relief to states whose
tourism revenue has suffered due to 9/11.  Specifically, this bill would
direct the Secretary of Commerce to provide grants to state agencies for
advertising to promote travel and tourism. Vivendi/Universal thinks this is
a good idea and would love for the Governor to do a letter in support of the
bill to the Congressional leadership in the House and Senate.  We would be
happy to draft a letter for your review.

Thanks in advance for your consideration.

Regards,
Kimberley

 <<Foley Bill.doc>>

-----Original Message-----
From: Lois Adams [mailto:ladams@hhcs.com]
Sent: Monday, December 03, 2001 3:08 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: yopfell@juno.com
Subject: MAIL ORDER PILOT PROGRAM FOR DIABETES


Dear Jeb.....
It is my understanding that the mail order pilot program for diabetes for patients along the I-4 corridor (Central Florida) requires that patients receive their diabetic medications and supplies through an out of state provider Health Alliance.  Not only is that an outrage for businesses within this state but that it makes no sense at all medically.- it is dangerous to the patient.  Our pharmacy presently provides medication management for the Senior Resource Alliance which includes 5 counties in Central Florida.  We monitor not only their diabetes but also the diseases which are a direct result on non-compliance,  inappropriate use of medication, failure to properly educate, etc.  And- it is at no charge to anyone including the Medicaid program. There is no way to control the health of these people with the therapy bifurcated and with incomplete patient history at our pharmacy.   It is inconceivable that you would allow this to go to a company which up to this point has not performed in a satisfactory matter when you have a woman owned business in this state (and a staunch Republican member of the Republican Congressional Committee Business Advisory Council) right here in Central Florida (Orlando).  I understand that you will be in Orlando tomorrow and I would hope that you would have a few moments to speak with me as I have been invited by Rich Crotty to attend-as a member of OCREC.  Please e-mail me concerning this.  Thank you.
N. Lois Adams

-----Original Message-----
From: David Bundy [mailto:David.Bundy@chsfl.org]
Sent: Wednesday, December 05, 2001 5:23 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: 



Dear Governor Bush: 


We are writing to you in keeping with a discussion that we had in your 
office last year.  We had met with you regarding the process of implementing 
community-based care, and you had requested at that time that we let you 
know of issues that needed to be addressed to keep the implementation on 
track. 

An extremely important issue has come to our attention as we move forward 
with implementing comunity-based care projects in additional communities 
(Daytona Beach, Tampa, Pensacola and Palm Beach).  Private providers are 
currently being required to secure a performance bond equal to 25% of the 
community-based care contracts.  There are a number of detrimental impacts 
of this requrement.  They include: 

        1.  The costs of securing the bond.   The lead agencies are being 
asked to secure and pay for the bonds.  The cost of the bonds is 
approximately $15 per $1,000 of coverage, which would create $1.5 million of 
costs being diverted from service provision (based on $400 million) of CBC 
contracts. 

        2.  Many CBC systems are being developed using separately 
incorporated entities.  They are unable to secure the performance bonds and 
the bonds are only attainable when a third party provides a guarantee for 
the bond.  The bonding companies are requiring guarantees from 
community-based agencies against their limited assets. 

        3.  With agency assets pledged against the bonds we are concerned 
about the mpact on our ability to continue to raise funds privately if a 
donor feels that their contribution could be lost. 

While we understand the state's need for some form of protection against the 
default of the CBC initiative, the current requirements will dramatically 
limit the ability of community-based agencies to assume the lead agency 
role.  Strong participation of experienced community-based agencies is 
essential to successfully complete the vision of community-based care. 

We would be happy to meet with you or a member of your staff to discuss this 
issue further. 

Thank you very much for your attention to this matter. 



David A. Bundy 
President/CEO 
Children's Home Society of Florida 
1485 S. Semoran Blvd., Suite 1448 
Winter Park, FL  32792 


Howard Olshansky 
CEO 
Children's Place at Homesafe 
2309 Ponce de Leon Avenue 
West Palm Beach, FL  33407 


Gary Bembry 
Chief Financial Officer 
Lakeview Mental Health 
1221 W. Lakeview Avenue 
Pensacola, FL  32501

From:	Wm. D. Walker <redhawk103@home.com>
Sent:	Friday, December 7, 2001 8:54 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Good morning

Good morning Governor Bush,
  Hope everything is fine for you today.  Well we were told by the District 1 Developmental Disabilities office that all the special projects for districts 1,2,and 4 will cease as of Dec. 10th this year.  This is a sad, sad time for the Great State of Florida, and for families with handicapped children and adult children.  I am afraid that our state institutions for the handicapped will soon be crowded beyond belief because some parents will have no choice with their supports removed but to remand their handicapped children over to DCF facilities.  We were also told that all cost plans for individuals will be cut by $150.00.  for some individuals that is their whole cost plan, and that cuts in cost plans will be even higher is some other districts.  That all personal care attendants will be cut, another reason DCF's will become crowded.
I know these are hard times, and everyone need to bite the bullet so to say but to ruin the lives of individuals with handicaps and their families, it's just a very hard pill to swallow.
Sir is there anything I can do to help as an individual and in my capacity as chairman of the Family Care Council in District 1?
I would be more than willing to help any anyway. I have been ask to speak at the CAFE this year that is if we have one, and was wondering what would be a good subject to speak on that can be encouraging to our families during this time.  Thanks for listening to me again sir and please have a nice day.  Your friend, Darrell Walker

From:	Hirst, Elizabeth <Elizabeth.Hirst@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Friday, December 7, 2001 8:48 AM
To:	Jeb Bush; Shanahan, Kathleen; Brogan, Frank
Cc:	PRESS OFFICE
Subject:	miami herald 



Published Friday, December 7, 2001 


Exerting no influence
Peter Wallsten's Dec. 2 column, Senate soap opera: Lust for power suggests
that I am influencing the race for the next president of the Florida Senate.
This is false, irresponsible and unfair -- not only to me but to each of the
candidates currently vying for the post.
Far from directing my supposed ``emissaries'' to make ``suggestions'' to
unnamed parties, I publicly have refused to endorse any candidate and have
remained true to that position in private. It is outrageous to suggest that
I am offering the quid pro quo of job opportunities for supporting one
candidate over others.

Lt. Gov. Frank Brogan told Senate President John McKay last week on the
Senate floor that neither he nor I wish to influence the internal
deliberations of that chamber regarding its future leadership. I remain
ready and willing to work with any senator designated to lead colleagues in
the future. Any suggestion to the contrary is false.


JEB BUSH
Governor of Florida
Tallahassee

Elizabeth E. Hirst
Press Secretary
Office of Governor Jeb Bush

From:	John Hornbuckle <John.Hornbuckle@taylor.k12.fl.us>
Sent:	Friday, December 7, 2001 7:59 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Thank You

Governor Bush,
   I wanted to take a moment to thank you for your efforts to increase
tourism to Florida in general and Walt Disney World in particular. I'm a
Disney stockholder and fan, so I benefit doubly when the company
thrives! I've also appreciated President Bush's comments encouraging
people to come visit. I believe Michael Eisner was down here in the same
timeframe as your visit, so you undoubtedly had the chance to speak with
him. Attendance in Disney's theme parks have been steadily picking up,
according to some friends I have who work there. I'm told that over the
Thanksgiving weekend, attendance at most of the parks was on par with
(or at least close to) last year's levels. The biggest problem is that
the occupancy rates at Disney's resorts--and the others in Orlando--are
so low. Still, at least we can see a light at the end of the tunnel.
   I also wanted to thank you for your leadership in helping us clear up
our concerns with the State Technology Office. While the issues haven't
yet been completely resolved (although I'm afraid STO may think they
have), the lines of communication have at least been opened. Dialog an
self-evaluation seem to be taking place, and that's a good thing. I'm
optimistic that the problems will be resolved once FIRN and STO can talk
a bit more.
   You might also be interested to know that I signed up through your
Web site to help the reelection campaign. I'm a long-time Republican; in
fact, I was the Treasurer of the Taylor County Young Republicans for
some time and have worked with Daryll Gunther quite a bit.
   Which leads me to my last point. THANK YOU for appointing Daryll as a
County Commissioner following the untimely death of Bea Foskey. I don't
know if Daryll has shared with you the sheer idiocy that tends to
surround our Commissioners and their actions. It's like a T.V. sitcom,
and would be comical if these goons weren't actually affecting the lives
of real people. Daryll is a breath of fresh air, and a voice of reason
on a ship of fools. He's not afraid to call a spade a spade, and I
appreciate it. He was an excellent choice, and has done an outstanding
job.


________________
John Hornbuckle
MIS Department
Taylor County School District
318 North Clark Street
Perry, FL 32347

Dear Governor Bush, 

I cannot truly express how much I appreciate your continued support of our 
Nurse Practitioner Prescribing Bill. I'm sure you know by now that we were 
smashed in the House Regulation Committee on Tuesday morning.  We  do not 
consider this as defeat but rather as another hurdle that will be overcome 
while you are still our Governor. The nurses, supportive physicians, and 
Representative Green thank you for having Mike Hansen appear before the 
committee to express your support. We really felt that we would have a 
closer vote but the opposition mounted over the weekend and on Monday was 
widespread and impressive if not always completely accurate. However we are 
hearing from legislators who watched to meeting in their offices that at 
least some are beginning to see that the negative debate at times is a 
message that conveys a lack of respect for the professionalism and ethics of 
registered nurses. 

I did speak with Greg Turberville yesterday and he tells me that he has 
mentioned to FMA that they must meet with our Association to discuss how our 
two professions can improve the practice environment for all levels of 
nurses in Florida's hospitals, nursing homes, and other health care 
facilities. As you know we are always willing to participate in discussion 
designed address the nursing shortage and/or to improve the quality and 
accessibility to coast effective health care services provided in a variety 
of settings for the citizens of our state and nation. 

On a personal note I really appreciate so much your offer for the 
opportunity to meet the President when he was here in Orlando on Tuesday. 
That you would even consider giving me that honor in humbling and deeply 
appreciated. 

With heartfelt sincerity,

Subject:	TPA

Thanks for all your help getting TPA passed in the House!!   The President is 
extremely grateful.  See his Press Release below, and the press releases from 
Secretary Evans and USTR  Zoellick.  On to the Senate... 




          THE WHITE HOUSE 

                         Office of the Press Secretary 


For Immediate Release                         December 6, 2001 

                           STATEMENT BY THE PRESIDENT 


     I commend the House of Representatives for passing legislation that will 
restore our nation 
's authority to negotiate trade agreements.  Trade Promotion 
Authority will give me the flexibility I need to secure the greatest possible 
trade opportunities for America's farmers, workers, families, and consumers. 

     Trade Promotion Authority is a key part of our trade agenda.  It will help 
us pursue and complete trade agreements, including the global trade negotiations 
launched last month in Doha, Qatar.  By promoting open trade, we expand export 
markets and create high-paying jobs for Americans, while providing opportunities 
for other nations as a result of free trade. 

     Now that the House has acted, I urge the Senate to move quickly to send me 
a Trade Promotion Authority bill I can sign. 

                                     # # # 



FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE               CONTACT:       Jim Dyke 
Thursday, December 6, 2001                              Trevor Francis 
                                                              202-482-4883 


               Statement by Secretary of Commerce Don Evans 
                on the Passage of Trade Promotion Authority 


I commend the House leadership for bringing Trade Promotion Authority up 
for a vote and I congratulate both the Republicans and the Democrats who 
stood strong and voted for its passage. Today's vote was a win for 
expanding trade; a win for American leadership around the world; a win for 
the American worker, entrepreneur, businessman, and farmer;  and a win for 
the economic security of America. 

President Bush is committed to free trade because it is an engine of 
economic growth and security, job creation and innovation. Opening markets 
for American products and crops will result in more and better paying jobs 
for Americans and lower prices for American consumers. 

The benefits of today's vote will be felt in every home, on every factory 
floor, on every farm and up and down every Main Street in America. 

### 


For Immediate Release: 
December 6, 2001 

Contact:  Richard Mills 
202-395-3230 

Statement by USTR Robert B. Zoellick on Results 
of House Trade Promotion Authority Vote 

WASHINGTON - "Today's vote in the House of Representatives to renew Trade 
Promotion Authority is a vote for American leadership, American workers, and 
American families. It is an important step in the process of helping to 
stimulate our economic recovery, to regain momentum on trade, and to return the 
United States to its rightful place as a leader in global trade liberalization. 

"The House vote is only the first step, of course. We will now work closely with 
the Senate Finance Committee to bring Trade Promotion Authority to the Senate 
floor. 

"Today's vote will help increase momentum for our trade agenda. We are moving 
forward with the global trade negotiations launched in Doha last month, because 
we believe it is in America's strong interest to seize the opportunity to 
further open the world's markets for American farm products, goods, and 
services. We will press ahead on the practical work to achieve our vision for a 
Free Trade Area of the Americas. We expect to finalize free trade agreements 
with Chile and Singapore next year. And we will continue to press globally, 
regionally, and with other nations to open additional markets for America. 

"With passage of the Jordan and Vietnam agreements earlier this year, the 
completion of the accession of China and Taiwan into the WTO, and the recent 
launch of the global trade negotiations, the Bush Administration has 
demonstrated a commitment to restoring U.S. leadership in trade liberalization. 
We will continue to do our best to strike the strongest deal possible for 
America's workers, families, farmers, and businesses. 

"I want to thank Chairman Thomas, in particular, for his tireless efforts. We 
would not have achieved this victory without him. Chairman Dreier and his trade 
whip team have also been of great assistance to me and my associates at USTR, 
and the House Republican leadership went to great lengths to build support for 
this measure, both inside the House and outside.  I also appreciate the efforts 
of a number of pro-trade Democrats, including John Tanner, William Jefferson, 
Cal Dooley, and Jim Moran.  I appreciate their willingness to stand by the 
courage of their convictions." 

### 


From:	STRAHL, Stuart <sstrahl@Audubon.org>

-----Original Message----- 
From: Bush-Brogan 2002 [  < mailto:bushbrogan@jeb.org> 
mailto:bushbrogan@jeb.org] 
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 6:48 PM 
To: Bush-Brogan 2002 
Subject: GOVERNOR AND REPUBLICAN LEGISLATORS SHOW LEADERSHIP; FINISH 
SUCCESSFUL LEGISLATIVE SESSION 


FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE 
CONTACT: KAREN UNGER 
THURSDAY, DECEMBER 6, 2001 
850/224-4JEB 

TALLAHASSEE- During challenging times for our nation and state, Governor 
Jeb Bush and the Republican-led Legislature should be commended for 
their leadership and a successful special session. With the passage of a 
revised wartime budget, Governor Bush and the Republican-led Legislature 
have worked together to ensure that Florida's highest priorities are 
funded: 

 Education funding remains at historic levels - funding for K-12 
education has been increased during Governor Bush's tenure in office 
over $2 billion from where it was in 1998. 

 Health and human services funding, including child welfare and 
services to those in need, has increased by 31% percent since 1998. 

 Economic stimulus efforts will create 33,000 new jobs and boost 
Florida's tourism industry, still struggling as a result of the attacks 
on our nation, with $20 million for marketing campaigns. 

 $19 million in spending for various anti-terrorism and domestic 
security measures will equip our state's law and health officials with 
the tools they need to ensure that Floridians are safe. 

Even with wartime necessitated budget reductions, the state budget is 
still 20% greater than in 1998, with spending increases focused on our 
state's priorities - education, health and human services, public safety 
and the environment. Showing tremendous leadership in tough times, 
Governor Bush and the Republican-led Legislature joined together to 
overcome numerous challenges and get a difficult job done. 

The Democrat leadership and their candidates for governor, on the other 
hand, have served as mere spectators in the process. Their criticism of 
the budget and blaming of Governor Bush for the budget shortfall is 
ironic and hypocritical at best, given the facts: 

 The previous Democrat Administration left the state with a mere $1.3 
billion in reserves. Under Governor Bush's leadership, the reserves have 
been built to a record $2.9 billion - an increase of 120 percent. 
Anticipating harder times, the Governor vetoed $916 million in special 
projects to minimize Florida's spending obligations. Thanks to this 
incredible foresight and willingness to make the tough decisions, our 
state is in a position of greater financial strength. 

 Democrats in the Florida Legislature voted in favor of the last three 
budgets by 98% (1999), 100% (2000), and 89% (2001) - the same budgets 
they are now criticizing. 

 Over 90% of Democrats in the Florida Legislature voted in favor of the 
Intangibles Tax Cut in 1998, 1999, and 2000. 

"Being a leader takes more than criticizing from the sidelines. Being a 
leader means having the strength to offer realistic solutions and make 
the tough decisions," said Karen Unger, campaign manager for the 
Bush/Brogan 2002 campaign. "Governor Bush has lead. The Democrats have 
not."

Dear Governor Bush, 
I've heard you speak at the Family Cafe and I know your passion to 
support persons with disabilities.  Noah, our 23 year son, has severe 
disabilities and is medically unstable.  At the past Cafe I heard you 
speak on the Choice and Control pilot project.  Noah participates in 
this 
program and I was on the committee to set up the pilot for our District 
in the Tallahassee area.  I understand this project is facing severe or 
total cuts in the budget the legislators have given to you for signing. 
Our family urges you to line item veto this.  The Project gives us the 
first opportunity in many years to provide Noah with the goods and 
services he requires.  That means he can continue to live at home with 
his family.  If he had to live in a state funded facility it would cost 
over $100,000 a year--more than 5 times what the state is currently 
spending on the Choice and Control Pilot Project for him.  Please help 
us keep our family together.  Please e-mail me if you require more 
information.

From:	VSequenzia@aol.com
Sent:	Thursday, December 6, 2001 11:19 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	FYI - Gov. Branstad comments

Dear Governor Bush: 

I thought you would be interested in reading the following comments. I have 
also attached my response. 

Ven 

Quote from Chair of President Bush's Commission on Special 
Education 

Gov. Branstad (former governor of Iowa) has been appointed to serve as 
chair of the Administration's new special education commission. 
  
Following is a quote from Gov Branstad (Iowa) from an interview 
transcript. The entire transcript is available at: 
  
http://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/education/schools_1-16.html 
  
GOV. TERRY BRANSTAD: In our state nearly 60 percent of the budget goes 
for education. And what we find is people are willing to invest in 
quality education, but they are also fiscally conservative. They want to 
see results. They want to see achievement for the dollars that they put 
in. I think that the federal government in its mandates in the area of 
special ed has driven up costs needlessly. I think that needs to be 
reviewed. 
  
I want to see every child have an opportunity to learn. All special 
ed children do have a right to an education, but to spend tens 
oft thousands of dollars on kids that really are not going to be able to 
support themselves or be able to really learn a great deal at the 
expense of the general education of the rest of the students is not 
fair. 

And so that has to be addressed. A lot of people are afraid of it, 
of being, you know, accused of being insensitive or whatever. I was 
in Sioux City, Iowa, yesterday, and I heard from a Teacher of the Year, 
Nancy Mounts, who had been Teacher of the Year, and the 
superintendent there about how their school is being squeezed 
because of the federal mandates in the area of special ed and 
how there needs to be more flexibility and latitude given to local 
school districts in that area. 

Dear President Bush: 

I am the father of an 18 year old daughter with Autism and Epilepsy. I just 
read Governor Branstad's (chair of Commission on Special Education) statement 
about spending money on Special Education students at the expense of Regular 
Education students. I think the Governor needs to visit some classrooms and 
avoid making blanket statements that are unsupported. 

Many years ago we use to just take our disabled students and leave them home 
or institutionalize them. Society was afraid to look at them and afraid to 
deal with them. It is now 2001 and the governor's statements sound fearfully 
like those of the past. How do we decide who is worthy of an education and 
who is not? Do we cut education off to those who only have an IQ of 80, 70, 
60 or 50?  Who is to say a child with an IQ of 50 with intense therapy and 
specialized education cannot become a productive member of society?  Studies 
show $1 dollar spent early on a special needs child, can save $7 dollars when 
the child becomes an adult. 

I think the Governor needs to be aware of the strides made by children and 
adults with disabilities. I understand the concerns of increasing costs in 
education and not getting a return for your money, but to put that on the 
backs of the least fortunate in our society is a crime. The disability 
community is one of the largest minorities in this country and it continues 
to the most discriminated against. Governor Branstad could not make the 
statement he made if he were talking about African Americans or any other 
minority group. So why is it okay to say it about the disabled?  True, there 
are many people with disabilities who cannot vote, but their families do.  

A personal friend of mine was told "put your child in an institution and have 
more children" when his son was 3 years old. Today he is 33 years old and 
holds a job with the Florida Diagnostic Learning Resource System (FDLRS). His 
IQ was below 50 when he was 3 years old. 

In closing, I hope you look carefully at who is representing you on this 
commission. There are over 60 million people with disabilities in this 
country and I can assure you that education is one of the most important 
things to our families who have children with disabilities. The laws (94-152, 
504, ADA, IDEA) were created to protect our rights and we will fight to keep 
them in place and make sure our children become productive members of 
society.  

Sincerely, 

Ven Sequenzia 
President 
The Autism Society of Florida 
Co-chair 
State Advisory Committee on 
Exceptional Student Education (Florida) 

From:	MMarquez@OrlandoSentinel.com
Sent:	Thursday, December 6, 2001 10:38 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: thanks for your response.

Thanks for taking the time out of your very busy day to respond. I hope to use some of what you've written in a column, though I'm going a different route in my assessment of what's wrong in the system. I believe you're right on target about ending social promotion, and the districts not doing what they should. But I think true reform would start all kids in pre-K because the earlier the better, particularly for disadvantaged kids who don't get reading at home, etc. It's become fashionable for middle-class and upper-middle class parents to "hold back" Johnny in pre-K for a year to get him really prepared and "mature" for kindergarten, and private schools retain kids all the time in pre-K and kindergarten. I've seen it over the years at St. James. I know your K-20 plan doesn't cover pre-K and that program, which never has received adequate funding, now falls to day care groups. I talked to Phil Handy about it when he came to speak to the ed board about the new education structure, but he said it's something that's on the table and open for discussion. 
 
Well, the dinner turned out lovely. I noticed that the group's awards to public officials all went to Republicans. Sheriff Beary was there and Rep. Ric Keller sent his Hispanic outreach guy, Joe Mantilla.(Keller also sent a video and blamed you for his rotten Spanish -- teehee). Crotty sent a video, too. The GOP is working harder than the Dems around here... but you may have heard that already. I did notice that your accent on the tape was more noticeable. Que pasa .. no estas practicando con Columba?
 
One last note re Reading by 9. The paper really is committed, and I think part of that is that you have an editor and a managing editor at this paper now who both have young children attending public schools. (And I've got one in public high school) That says something about their commitment and the stake they have in Florida's public education system. By the way, I have volunteered along with about a dozen others at the paper to be a tutor for the Reading by 9 program at a nearby school for at least nine weeks. I look forward to it.
 
Hope to catch you next time your in Orlando.

-----Original Message-----
From: Jeb Bush [mailto:jeb@jeb.org]
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 8:29 PM
To: Marquez, Myriam
Subject: RE: Hello


Miriam, I am obviously not at the dinner and committed to be there. 
 
On social promotion, the FCAT is but one criteria. Sadly, many districts are lacking the courage to hold back students and remediate. It is a shame and a quiet scandal. However, our proposed enhancements of the grading system will help focus the districts on the kids left behind. If approved in the next weeks, if schools ignore the kids that are struggling, they will be penalized. 
 
In addition, based on the districts' non compliance with the intent of the A plus plan, there is the strong possibility of legislative reforms to tighten the requirements regarding social promotion. I would support reasonable reforms in this regard. 
 
I really appreciate the efforts of the Orlando Sentinel in advancing the cause of reading and student achievement. It is and will continue to make a difference. No other paper is focused on this and your involvement will have a statewide impact. 
 
 

Jeb Bush 

 
PS I did not proof since i am tired.

From:	robert gaye <roberttgaye@hotmail.com>
Sent:	Thursday, December 6, 2001 10:17 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	SBA Loan Request

Hon. Governor Jeb Bush: 

Thanks for your support.  I was overwhelmed by the support shown for 
Transtar by the President, HUD Secretary Martinez, Mayor Hood, and you at 
the recent Town Hall Meeting.  However, the feedback from Thomas Butler of 
the SBA is that Transtar exceeds the size standards for small businesses.  
Therefore, the loan application that would provide the assistance necessary 
for Transtar to resume doing business at Orlando International Airport has 
been declined. 

I find myself asking for your urgent help in this matter.  Transtar was very 
important to this community, as it employed over 250 people.  The shutting 
down of Transtar had a direct impact on nearly 1000 individuals, not to 
mention Transtar's local suppliers and their employees. 

Transtar was dealt a deathblow by the events of September 11.  As you can 
imagine, time is of the essence.  Transtar faces several major challenges in 
the next few days.  Cancellation of the OIA contract is pending if no help 
is forthcoming. If the OIA contract is cancelled and the bond is called, it 
is not likely that Transtar or myself will ever be able to do business again 
with the Greater Orlando Aviation Authority.  Even with financial help to 
resume operations, Transtar faces additional challenges in structuring an 
ongoing relationship with GOAA. 

Over the past 16 years, I have more than demonstrated my ability to survive 
in a very difficult and competitive environment.  Before September 11, I 
built the business with personal resources and private sector financing.  I 
have never applied for government-backed assistance.  However, September 11 
created special needs, which require special solutions. 

Perhaps I can appeal for a special waiver in view of the employment 
represented by Transtar and its DBE status.  Perhaps there are other forms 
of state or federal aid that can mitigate this hardship.  There are many 
compelling reasons to support efforts to get Transtar back in business.  At 
this time I really need your guidance in dealing with this matter.  Governor 
Bush, I know that you are extremely busy, and your immediate attention of 
this matter would be greatly appreciated.  Thanks again for your support and 
guidance. 

Respectfully Yours, 
Robert T. Gaye 
Transtar Transportation, Inc.

From:	Mary O'Meara <msosparc@ucnsb.net>
Sent:	Thursday, December 6, 2001 9:33 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	A.B.L.E. Foundation information

Dear Jeb,
 
I wrote to you yesterday regarding the A.B.L.E. Foundation, and since then have decided to cancel the meeting I had scheduled in New Smyrna. I felt too uncomfortable to proceed. Following are my most recent dealings with Lori Bennett from the A.B.L.E. Foundation, and her response to my cancellation has me scared. I understand that I do not have the right to make any slanderous or false statements about the organization, and I most certainly do not intend to, but I thought I had the right to make statements, derogatory or not, based on my opinion, as per the 1st amendment... At any rate. This is not my purpose. I clearly explained to her (as you can see) why I am not comfortable and her response almost dismisses every point I made. I am not sure what you may do with this information, but I have several e-mails that I have exchanged with her and none of them are as incendiary as this one. I am willing to share any information I have at your request. Thank you for your time.
 
Sincerely,
 
Mary O'Meara, President
S.P.A.R.C. of Volusia, Inc. (Special Population Activities & Recreation Council)
386-409-9292
msosparc@ucnsb.net

This came to me at 5:09pm 12/06/01 with the heading: You are hereby advised, from the A.B.L.E. Foundation
 
 
Praise God!
 
Thank you Mary -
 
Your obvious misinterpretations, gross misunderstanding, and personal agenda are not qualifications of a leader for an A.B.L.E. Center.  Either someone has seriously misled you, or you have a personal problem that has led to your confusion as to the truth and the way.  
 
We have discussed your emails with our legal counsel and have forwarded them to their firm.  An investigator has been assigned to this matter.
 
You are hereby advised that you will be held liable for any derogatory, slanderous, or false comments from you or anyone else stemming from your opinions, personal bias, or prejudice regarding our organization.
 
We wish you well and pray for the Volusia community.  
 
Sincerely,
 
The A.B.L.E. (Achieving Beyond Limited Expectations) Foundation, Inc.
 
----- Original Message ----- 
From: Mary O'Meara <mailto:msosparc@ucnsb.net>  
To: The A.B.L.E. Foundation, Inc. <mailto:webmaster@ablefoundation.org>  
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 2:37 PM
Subject: Re: December 12 meeting

Lori,
 
I have been getting lots of questions about A.B.L.E. from my membership. As I find myself telling them over and over that I'd like to answer them, and that although I have asked many direct questions I still do not have direct answers, it gives me great pause. The last question relating to compensation was not answered directly - and although I accepted your unwillingness to share where the money comes from one month ago, I realize that most of my direct questions have not been answered. I'm sure you can understand that when you propose to people that there will be enough money to cover any need without using government support and grants they do have a right to understand where the money is coming from. Your are proposing something unconventional, and yet are expecting loving and caring parents to go on faith alone... that is what they have spent many years doing and they cannot. In other words, my organization WILL NOT accept money unless we know who the source is, and by the same token, I as a responsible parent will not let my kids participate in anything that I am not fully clear about. To that end, SPARC cannot stand behind A.B.L.E. in that our attempts to understand by asking questions have failed. We are a humble group of parents who have never thought of stealing an idea from someone, as you have insinuated we may do if we learned your source before the meeting. I guess it shows your lack of trust in us. You also asked me to think of leadership in my community... and yet have given me no tools with which to explain to them what exactly this is. 
 
I apologize for waiting this long to share my feelings with you. I have been having "red flags" for a while. A big one occurred in our phone conversation when you said, " Some people actually have the nerve to ask if we're a religious organization". I told you that I was one who asked the question because it's important for me to allow personal relationships with God to be separate from SPARC. And yet it seemed to me that you were unnerved by the question, not even realizing that when something so unusual is proposed, people have a dire need to understand its origins. 
 
I have tried to go on faith alone, but it is irresponsible for me to continue this way. Therefore, I am canceling the meeting for the 12th and do not wish to pursue the A.B.L.E. Center. I will send a mailer to my membership, and I will also post the cancellation on the e-mail exchange. 
 
 
Sincerely,
 
Mary O'Meara

-----Original Message-----
From: Mary O'Meara [mailto:msosparc@ucnsb.net]
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 8:47 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Possible Scam relating to our disabled population



Dear Governor Bush,
 
I would not normally contact you with the details of the goings on in our community, but I think that I am a target for a Scientology scam.
 
My name is Mary O'Meara and I am the president of S.P.A.R.C. of Volusia, Inc. (Special Population Activities & Recreation Council). We are a 501 (c) 3 Florida non-profit, and our organization provides recreational, athletic, social and educational activities for mentally challenged people in Volusia County. I live in New Smyrna Beach, and our group has been experiencing the growth and wonder of the success of reaching anyone and everyone who can benefit from our activities. We are hoping that in the future we can establish a community center to serve a lot of needs. I was planning to start writing grants for funding in 2002. We have over 150 "participants", whose age range is 3-65 who represent a myriad of disabilities.
 
My concern is that we saw an e-mail for seed money to open an "ABLE Center" and I jumped at the opportunity to learn more about it. ...Long story short, I have arranged for a meeting with Lori Bennett, "Ambassador of Hope" as she regards herself, to speak to the parents and care-givers of my group. I have recently been made aware that she may represent the Church of Scientology. Although asked many direct questions about religion and funding, Lori has never given me a direct answer. She has claimed that the seed money does not come from Federal or State funding, that it does not come from any form of grant, and that she will only disclose where the funds come from at our meeting. This meeting is scheduled for December 12th at Coronado Community United Methodist Church's "Beach Club" at 7pm. You are invited if you'd like to attend!
 
I have spent the better part of the day speaking with my attorney, surfing the internet looking for any information I can get. I was hoping to find a direct tie between the A.B.L.E. Foundation and Scientology, but I cannot find one. I have, however, received e-mails stating that some people KNOW the tie to be there. As a result I have e-mailed my mailing list and will follow up with a post card tomorrow telling ALL that I am only hosting, not backing, this organization. I have urged my families NOT to sign anything. I am a recognized and trusted entity in my county and want to keep on doing what I'm doing - it's needed and I truly enjoy it. Here's the thing: I am afraid that she will bully my desperate parents into something, or that she will make my life difficult if I don't comply with her... The information I digested regarding Scientology is horrifying, and I am actually personally afraid at this point. 
 
I am hoping for some input, advice or reassurance - who knows what - mostly because I feel that all of my work can be ruined in one fell swoop. Do you have any information on this church in Florida? Lori Bennett is the CEO of "The A.B.L.E. (Achieving Beyond Limited Expectations) Foundation, Inc,  - as it's worded in the Division of Corporations website - and her family members are the other directors. She lives in Williston, Florida. There is some connection with Illinois, as our meeting invitations came from zip code 60499 in South Suburban Illinois - although when I asked her about the postmark she did not answer my question satisfactorily. I am hoping that we can stop this before other counties are possibly taken advantage of also. I have included the ABLE website and hope that perhaps your office can look it over thoroughly... it seems to say a lot while saying very little, and yet I felt obliged to investigate it as something of a possibility for our county. http://www.ablefoundation.org
 
My contact information is as follows: I live at 321 Roslyn Avenue, New Smyrna Beach, FL 32168 - 
My phone number is 386-409-9292, and my e-mail is msosparc@ucnsb.net. 
 
I thank you in advance for any input you can provide.
 
Sincerely,
 
Mary S. O'Meara

-----Original Message-----
From: Buddysjoy@aol.com [mailto:Buddysjoy@aol.com]
Sent: Wednesday, December 05, 2001 11:13 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: (no subject)


Dear Governor Bush, 

We have just been made aware of some disturbing news...My son is one of the people who are on the Matter of Choice Project.  We entered into the Matter Of Choice Project in "Good Faith" that the program would be a testing program for Developmental Disabilities.  We risked losing our services in order to help Developmental Disabilities make their system more cost effective.  Now, we are being told that Developmental Disabilities has overspent more than $80 million (or some unGodly amount like that!).  It seems to me, you are asking our children to pay for something that obviously didn't have the proper  Checks and Balances System! 

We were originally told the project would be coming to an end as of June 2002.  Then, we were told the project would be coming to an end as of March 2002.  Last weekend, I attended a Family Care Council Chairperson's Meeting in Orlando and Mr. Carl Littlefield informed us the project would be ending in January 2002.  This evening, I just received a phone call from our FCC Chairperson informing us The Matter of Choice Program will be ending this Monday, Dec. 10th!!!  Which one is it?  How can we plan for our children's daily care if we can't even count on what we are told?  We can't help but feel as though we are being manipulated!!! 

We can't begin to plan for our children's daily care!!!  The dates keep changing...there is no time to look for any other sources, support coordinators, support services, transportation to jobs, day programs, etc.!!   

How can you take our services away when we haven't even been officially notified?  When were we going to be told?  We are lucky, we are informed because we are a part of the Family Care Council and so we know people who called us when this came down today, Wednesday!  What about the people who don't have the connections like us?  When would they find out?  Monday...when there would be no services?  No one would come for respite, daily care, transportation, job coaching...? 

Our children depend on these services for their daily living...to live in our communities as independent adults.  They want to be independent and lead productive lives just like any other person their age...these services allow that to happen!!  And now, they are being taken away without proper notice and without any explanations of other options! 

This is totally unfair and not being done in "Good Faith"!!!  We are very disappointed!!! 

Please show us and our children respect and give them their dignity!!  If the project must come to an end, give us proper notice and time to make the necessary adjustments!!  We need to be allowed back into the system in a timely manner in order to not disrupt our children's lives!!! 

I look forward to hearing from you on this matter! 

Sincerely, 

Joy Frazier, Parent 
Lyall L. Frazier III, Matter Of Choice Client
