From:	Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>
Sent:	Thursday, December 6, 2001 8:29 PM
To:	MMarquez@OrlandoSentinel.com
Subject:	RE: Hello

Miriam, I am obviously not at the dinner and committed to be there. 
 
On social promotion, the FCAT is but one criteria. Sadly, many districts are lacking the courage to hold back students and remediate. It is a shame and a quiet scandal. However, our proposed enhancements of the grading system will help focus the districts on the kids left behind. If approved in the next weeks, if schools ignore the kids that are struggling, they will be penalized. 
 
In addition, based on the districts' non compliance with the intent of the A plus plan, there is the strong possibility of legislative reforms to tighten the requirements regarding social promotion. I would support reasonable reforms in this regard. 
 
I really appreciate the efforts of the Orlando Sentinel in advancing the cause of reading and student achievement. It is and will continue to make a difference. No other paper is focused on this and your involvement will have a statewide impact. 
 
 

Jeb Bush

From: scarlett [mailto:miscarlett@gtcom.net]

-----Original Message-----
From: Lynch, Tom [mailto:lyncht@infinity-software.com]
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 1:54 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: RE: Blackberry/Outlook Solution


Governor,
 
Our tests yesterday were successful.  We are implementing the solution this afternoon.  We will continue to monitor the system through this afternoon and expect a final assessment no later than tomorrow morning.  FWIW,  Bruce has been a big help and a joy to work with.  We would have been unsuccessful without his assistance.  

 
I'll keep you posted on our progress.
 
Tom Lynch
President
Infinity Software Development, Inc.
 
------------
 
P.S.  a more detailed/technical assessment of the situation follows: 
 

Statement of the Problem:

The client was experiencing a problem getting their Blackberry wireless email device to synchronize with Outlook. A generic method (POP3) was used to download email messages from an Exchange server to a laptop. The Blackberry was also used to receive email via wireless. When the Blackberry was placed in the cradle attached to a laptop it would not "synchronize" with Exchange or Outlook on the laptop. In other words, messages that were received, read, deleted, or replied to with the Blackberry were updated on neither the Exchange Server nor Outlook. 

The Analysis:

The Blackberry device will not work with the generic method (POP3) of handling emails. Blackberry requires that its cradle and attached computer have a direct connection to the Exchange Server.  Blackberry synchronizes with the Exchange Server, not Outlook. 

The Solution:

We configured the laptop with an Outlook profile to connect directly to the Exchange Server.  The Blackberry device now works. When the device is put in the cradle it automatically updates the Exchange Server and, by extension, Outlook. We further modified Outlook to use "offline" folders. This provides two major advantages. First, it allows Outlook to be used without an Internet connection. Emails may be managed normally. The next time Outlook is connected to Exchange, it again synchronizes (e.g. sending or deleting emails). The second advantage to this solution is that it requires the least direct communication with Exchange. This is a benefit when operating on a dial-up or low bandwidth line. Using Outlook with offline folders will not significantly degrade performance compared to using Outlook with a POP3 connection. 

In summary, we recommend to Bruce to discontinue using POP3.  Instead, use a direct connection to Exchange with Outlooks offline folders enabled. He is going to implement the solution this afternoon. Their ISP will reconfigure their firewall to enable communication this afternoon. Bruce will also reconfigure their Exchange 2000 Server. Infinity has created a modification for the Exchange Server for Bruce to use.  Infinity will meet with Bruce at 1pm today to assist in the process.

From: frenc71@dellepro.com [mailto:frenc71@dellepro.com]
Sent: Wednesday, December 05, 2001 3:23 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: frenc71@dellepro.com
Subject: Past criminal from 20 years ago


Dear Gov. Bush (Jeb) ,
 
My name is Ed French (Edwin C. French III) ,
I am writing as per several sources state that you are probably the only person that can help and might consider helping me with this problem . I am originally a born-and-raised Floridian who now resides in the State of Arizona . Nearly all of my childhood family ties remain in Orlando and surrounding areas .
 
In 1981 , I was sentenced after submitting a guilty plea for a white-collar non-violent crime for which I served time on in the Deland facility for Volusia County . The Honorable McFerrin Smith was acting Judge in this case during Sept. of 1981 . Four months after I was introduced to facility my case was reviewed , between going from Maximum security at time of intake to Trustee in three months , my 1 year sentence was commuted to probation and I was released the morning before Christmas .
 
Jeb , since that time ( 20 years ago ) , I have been a productive taxpayer , model employee , devoted husband and most recently an exuberant and loving father to my 9 year old daughter Meaghan who I adore . Other than an occasional traffic citation in the first 10 years , I have not had to visit a courtroom except to seek visitation for my wife Krista's Grandaughter .
 
Now that I have given you some background on myself  we come to the issue at hand . I am a mature and responsible parent , husband and citizen . I have never had a violent background or tendency . My last 3 employers cover over 11 yrs in customer service : Tucson Medical Center - 6yrs        American Airlines- 2+ years     Spherion (corporate travel agency for Amex) 3 yrs .
 
For the vast majority of these past 20 years I have had all of my Civil Liberties restored except for the Right to Bear Arms .
I live in a fairly remote area just southwest of Tucson Az. and between our location gradually becoming more urban , the state of our World today and an overwhelming desire to be able to feel safe in our home , I am asking for your help in the only way I know how . I am hoping that somewhere deep down you can relate to what I am talking about at some level .
 
Several years ago I had inquired as to the steps neccessary to re-obtain the last liberty I was still missing and was referred to ATF for more info . They stated at that time that the only way to do this was to be granted Clemency or a Pardon from the State in which the crime was committed . I left Florida in 1985 and have been an Arizona resident since 1986 . In all this time I have been back to visit my folks on a fairly regular basis and have always respected the laws and citizens of Florida .
 
I am not exactly sure what measure you would need to use to accomplish my request should you choose to help me , but any help and/or advise is welcome . Just on a side - note , Jeb , if this is something you can't do or aren't comfortable with , I'll understand . I am just a good man that made a huge mistake early in life and have paid for it ever since .
 
Thanks for taking the time .
Respectfully ,
                                                                                            Ed French
                                                                                            3402 S. Bradford Drive
                                                                                            Tucson , Az. 85735
                                                                                             1-520-908-9662 - home
                                                                                             1-520-331-2720 - cell             frenc71@dellepro.com  or   frenc71@hotmail.com

-----Original Message-----
From: Simnszz@aol.com [mailto:Simnszz@aol.com]
Sent: Monday, December 03, 2001 12:28 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Please Help Romanian-Amerocan Teen volunteer
Dear Governor Bush, 
Nick's story has gone to over 100,00 thousand websites.  We have heard from Uganda, Australia, Arizona, Russia, Romania, and Brazil.  The only ones we haven not heard from yet are influential people who can help us transport the backpacks safely to Romania.  We just sent the following letter to Bart Conners and Nadia Comaneci.  Hopefully they will respond.  Several other celebrities who are humanitarians have also been contacted.  We hope you or one of these other contacts will help us.  It would be good publicity for Florida since a young Florida teen volunteer is making such an incredible difference in this world.  His volunteerism can change the world for millions of orphans worldwide. 

We know that you are extremely busy.  We just need to know if you can help us.  If you can, please let us know as soon as possible.  We want to deliver supplies to Romania by Christmas. Thank you for listening and may you and your family have blessed Christmas. 

Peace and blessings, 
Connie Simon 


Dear Mr. Conners and Ms. Comaneci, 

We know that you rarely respond to private email.  However, this is an urgent matter and we hope you will make an exception. Our son, Anton Nicolai (Nick) Simon, was adopted from a Romanian orphanage in 1990. He spent his first 5 1/2 years in one of Romania's poorest orphanages. Last summer, he heard about the children who weren't adopted.  They are kids our son's age who are being released to the streets without any family, skills or education. Many live in sewers beneath Bucharest and beg for food to survive.  This upset our son, Nick, tremendously. 

He decided to do something to help them.  He started a program called Backpack Carepak to collect new and nearly new backpacks, scarves, gloves, sweatshirts, combs, caps, and socks to help them endure the harsh winter months ahead.   

Nick's story has inspired many people to better appreciate how wonderful it is to have the gift of a family.  Hundreds of young people in our local schools have donated winterwear and backpacks.  Now our greatest obstacle is finding transportation.  We were going to have a concert to raise money for transportation costs, but the anthrax threat and high cost of insurance and security put that idea on hold indefinitely. 

Please read Nick's story located at the following web site.  It will take just a couple of minutes and we hope that you think it is worthwhile. 
http://joanbramsch.com/helpothers/backpack.shtml 

After reading it, if you want to help us, our greatest need is transportation.  If you know anyone with airline connections to Bucharest or a large plane that will transport supplies from Florida to Romania, would you please make the contacts to help us? We would deeply appreciate any help you can give Nick's project.   

Many people have been helping to make this project a success.  Kids at one school raised 500 dollars in pennies to buy backpacks.  An elderly lady knitted 100 hats for street kids.  A woman from Minnesota has made over 300 polar fleece scarves. Groups of all ages want to help these kids because Nick has inspired them to care about others who have so little. 

Nick is an outstanding young man who has overcome incredible challenges.  We are very proud of him.  We think he was the only one to get out of Orphanage #4 because he was meant to be a spokesperson for those who have no voice.  Nick wants to make a difference in this world.  Will you help him if you can?   

Nick wants to help the orphans in Romania first and then expand humanitarian aid in the future to orphans in China, Brazil, Afghanistan, Russia, and Africa.  There are millions of abandoned children worldwide in desperate need of help.  Not one major advocacy program exists today to advocate solely for orphans or abandoned children.  Nick wants to start one and will call it O.W.L.S. for Orphans Without Love or Shelter.   

Over the years, advocates have helped many worthy causes such as whales, turtles, trees, owls.  They have saved many species from harm or extinction.  We think even more people care about orphans.  We want to join together to advocate for children worldwide who need protection and shelter. Incredibly, a former orphan from Romania is leading the way. 

Thank you for reading this email and if you can help us locate a plane to deliver Backpack Carepaks to Romania before Christmas, we would be so grateful.  Any help or direction you can give this project will be deeply appreciated.  God bless you and your family. 

Most sincerely, 
The Simon Family 
Connie, Paul, Nick, and Liana 
3165 Hanging Moss Circle 
Kissimmee, FL 34747 
(407) 518-1801

Gay Adoptions
*  Ron Hayes - Reporter - Palm Beach Post - Contact:  Owen Roach
Query:  doing a story on adoptions in general with mention of homosexual
adoptions.  Wanted a copy of page 4 of the department's adoptive parent
application form which asks the "are you a homosexual" question.
Response:  faxed the requested information to Hayes.
* Jane Adams -- Reporter -- Rosie (O'Donnell) Magazine       Contact:
LaNedra Carroll
Question: Ms. Adams has been calling for several days to get a response
about the Lofton/Croteau (gay adoption) case.
Response: Told her that AFSA, the federal law, made permanency a goal for
kids who are in foster care. Told her that we can't talk about specific
cases, despite the fact that this case has been widely reported. She asked
about the number of kids in care (more than 10,000 as of October), the
number of kids who have been in long-term foster care for eight years or
more (don't know; will see if we can come up with the number); the number
of kids who have been TPR'd (about 3,500) and how many adoptive parents
there are (don't know).
Her story is probably going to run in the February issue.

District 10 Contracts
*  Shana Gruskin - Reporter - Sun-Sentinel - Contact:  Owen Roach
Query:  working on a daily story about a contract debate/dispute in Broward
County between contracted foster care providers and the department.
Negotiation is taking place as the existing contracts expire 31 Dec 01 and
the providers are taking umbrage with the new contracts.  Has the formula
for the contract changed on a district basis or as a result of directions
from Tallahassee?
Response:  Yes, they've changed and the change is directed by central
office.  The department is implementing new contracts for group care
providers that address a number of issues, primarily the difference between
what we pay for and purchase and what the providers bill Medicaid for.
This will help to prevent double-dipping.  Secondly, the new version
requires quarterly financial reports from the providers to give us a
clearer picture of true costs.  This will allow us to better monitor the
contracts and to beef up and improve them.

Bonnie L/Judge Moreno
* Joe Oglesby -- Editorial Page Editor, Miami Herald         Contact:
LaNedra Carroll
Question: Wanted to talk about Judge Moreno's ruling in Bonnie L. He wanted
to ask about where the district goes from here, what the plan is for
keeping the children who are in the system safe, etc. Wanted an interview
with the secretary.
Response: Would try very hard to get them together. If not, he will be
talking to the district administrator, the family safety director and me
about improvements; that this is Judge M's second ruling in the
department's favor -- which in effect is a vote of confidence; HomeSafeNet;
how the department is strongly following the recommendations of the Palm
Beach Grand Jury, the District 7 Strike Force and making major efforts to
improve the quality of care for our children.


Other issues:
* About the "20/20 Give Me A Break" situation....
In Polk County Judge Prince dismissed on father's attorney's motion after
we finished with our witnesses.
Before the hearing, mom read a written statement to the media on her view,
which was positive toward the department.

20/20 had an affiliate station shooting for them.-
Regional PIO Shawnna Lee and Ann Hipson, from District 14, talked briefly
to the local print media to say: "We file petitions in good faith, give our
evidence and it's up to the Judge to decide." Our attorney was asked  if we
could appeal, and she simply explained the process. She said no decision
had been made about whether to appeal.

Finally, we faxed the response that was read to you this morning to
Producer Karen Saunders, basically saying that we can't comment on open
child-protection cases. We referred her to Online Sunshine for information
about our child protection system.

dca
1. Alan Harten, Sarasota Herald Tribune.  Requested information on why two
projects were approved for funding in Sarasota County through DCA's Florida
Community Trust this past Friday, Nov. 30.  Ann Rowe advised him it is not
uncommon for two projects to be approved in the same area/county/city as
long as they meet the criteria within the application process.  He also
requested a copy of the funded list, it is available at
http://www.dca.state.fl.us/ffct/

2. Randy Abraham, Plantation News.  Again, requested information regarding
the FCT award list from Nov. 30, specifically the project PLANTATION CENTRAL
OPEN SPACE.  Ann Rowe advised him the project is on the "contingent funded
list", meaning FCT anticipates that funding will come available and the City
of Plantation will be notified if/when.  He asked if most cities go ahead
with their plans/project anyway?  Yes, they normally do.

3. Page St. John, Gannett News Service.  Requested information regarding the
State Housing Trust Fund - what is the main funding source?  What are the
limitations - statutorily or constitutional?  Ann Rowe advised that the
Trust Fund is primarily funded through the Doc Stamp tax, and that the
limitations are statutorily.

labor
Dave Royce of the Associated Press called wanting to know if the Dept. would
know how many increased claims of WC have surfaced due to Anthrax medication
and Ms. Cape responded that that is between the employer/carrier and the
employee and we don't have those figures.


doc:
Boxing Magazine based out of New York City wanting to interview an inmate at
Walton Correctional Institution for possible article and book.  Stated
interview procedures and that we would need to see a copy of their work
before we would consider their request.

Received fax from Greta Van Susteren's show The Point concerning her
interview with death row inmate Aileen Wournos. Waiting on them to call back
to discuss the fax.

Paige St. John from Gannett News Service called regarding $4 million in the
appropriations bill for "salary incentives."  She wondered what they were,
and why we would be giving out "raises" in a time of cutbacks.  Explained
they are not salary incentives per se, but one time training incentive
payments for certified employee training as in hostage training.  All law
enforcement gets these training incentives If you divide the $4 million by
20,000 DOC certified employees it comes to out $200 one time only payment
per officer.



Elizabeth E. Hirst
Press Secretary
Office of Governor Jeb Bush 
From:	Miriam Sequeira <architecture@rodriguezquiroga.com>
Sent:	Thursday, December 6, 2001 6:01 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Senate Bill 52-C

Dear Governor:

Today the Legislature passed Senate Bill 52-C delaying the effective date of
the Florida Building Code from January 1, 2002 to March 1, 2002.

The Florida Building Commission, your body of technical advisors, voted
unanimously both at the October and November meetings to recommend to you
that the code go into effect on January 1, 2002.

Should you decide to veto this bill it would enormously strengthen the
ability of the Florida Building Commission to promote consensus within the
industry in the future.

Sincerely,



Raul

From:	Castille, Colleen <colleen.castille@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Thursday, December 6, 2001 5:33 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: under siege

Governor, 
 
In the 1980's the Trustees gave the land to Miami-Dade County with a reverter clause stating that if the county failed to use the property for public uses (i.e. commercial ventures) that the property automatically reverts to the Trustee's ownership.  
 
The County was seeking permits on the marina proposal when DEP found out that there was a casino gambling boat docked there.  We issued a legal notice that the gambling vessel constitutes a private venture and that they needed to remove the vessel or we would take positive action to evict the vessel.  Miami-Dade is challenging this action because they receive $900,000 annually from the boat. So everything else they are proposing is being held up on a determination of who owns the land.  We argue that the land has automatically reverted to us because they are using it for commercial purposes.  They argue that we have to take some action. 
 
The matter is likely to become a cabinet item in January 2002, if we cannot come to conclusion. 
 
ON the proposal for the marina, golf driving range, etc.   I am not sure how much of it is on land that we own vs. land that Miami-Dade owns.  That will be the key for what we have authority to negotiate. 
 
I will find out. 
 
Colleen

From: David Steinfeld [mailto:david@apimaging.com]
Sent: Tuesday, December 04, 2001 12:59 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: under siege



Honorable Governor Bush, 

Our County Park is under siege by the political games played in Dade County. 
The Parks Department along with the Honorable Gwen Margolis have 
orchestrated a plan to commercialize Haulover Park in Dade County. The park 
is bordered by the ocean and Intercoastal and provides access to many 
minority groups living west of Biscayne Boulevard. I solicited their 
comments through a public awareness campaign held on Labor Day. Their 
suggestions were that the county should concentrate their efforts on better 
bathrooms, sand boxes for the kids, picnic tables and more. They are not 
aware of the assault on their access through increased parking concessions, 
privatized dock space that will destroy the breathtaking views of the 
intercoastal, and an overall commercialization of the Park. 

The FDEP West Palm Beach, recently denied an application for an expansion of 
the dock facility that presently houses a GAMING vessel, which was in the 
park ILLEGALLY, and authorized by the county. 

I ask you to further review, contest, and revoke an existing permit that 
allows the county to expand the Marina additionally for private use with 
over 150 new slips for rent, a 350' intrusion into the intercoastal, 300 
yard driving range with a 60' net, and other commercial operations at the 
park. These proposed changes do not serve the PUBLIC interest and 
generations to come will suffer if their allowed to proceed unchecked. 

Please Help 

David Steinfeld 
9180 Byron Ave 
Surfside, FL. 33154

From:	Peter Merhige <peter@trishield.net>
Sent:	Thursday, December 6, 2001 5:26 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Florida Building Code

Dear Governor Bush,

I am writing to express my disappointment and disbelief that The Senate and
House has once again voted to delay the Florida Building Code. I wrote to
you last week expressing my feelings and giving you an understanding of what
the severity of this action means to our company, but I feel I must do it
again, since you are the last possible chance I have to save my business.

My name is Peter Merhige and my company is Protective Glass Industries,
located in Ft Myers, Florida. My company was formed over 2 years ago for the
purpose of developing and bringing to market a new product for the hurricane
protection markets. The reason for forming the company and products was for
the potential in the hurricane markets mainly due to the
development of the new Florida building code (THE CODE IN WHICH YOU AGREED
WAS GOOD FOR FLORIDA) that contains hurricane protection. We have designed
and have patents pending on the finest impact glass product in the industry.
Not only does it protect from hurricane damage but also due to it's
insulating properties, reduces the cost of energy. We have spent well over
$1,000,000 on the development and commercialization of our products and due
to several delays in the statewide building code; we have lost millions of
dollars. Over the last 2 days, I have lost close to $1 MILLION in investment
money because of the actions in Tallahassee. Not only has our company spent
over $1,000,000 but also there has been millions and millions of dollars
already spent to develop this code, along with millions and millions of
dollars spent by companies to enhance their products to meet the new codes.
There are hundreds of companies ready to provide product for these new
building codes and there has been more than ample time to prepare for it.

I do not know how to make this any clearer than to tell you that all of mine
and all of my loyal employees' hard work to develop our products and bring
them to market over the last 2+ years is over unless you help. We had the
potential to create over 100 jobs for the state of Florida with revenues
over $100 million dollars over the next 3 years, which would obviously be
put back into the Florida economy while protecting your citizens. We have
close to 20 companies that were getting set to come to market with our glass
the first of the year because of your code, and due to the delay, they will
not until March (if the code doesn't get eliminated all together). Due to
this delay and the uncertainty of Tallahassee which makes my investors
uncomfortable enough to not invest, I will not be able to keep the doors
open. Your are really my last hope to see that Tallahassee actually thinks
of it's citizens over their own personal agendas.

We worked very hard to present ideas that would make sense for everyone and
had some really good suggestions, but because of obvious personal agendas,
we were ignored. Presently Senators McKay, Clary and Constatine along with
Representative Bennet, who have businesses in the construction industry,
stated that Florida's counties were not ready for the code. Ourselves, The
Florida League of Cities, AIF and many more, have proof through the DCA that
only 8% of Florida was not ready to enforce the code.

We suggested that all counties not ready be given a 60 day delay to get
prepared and the other 92% who have worked extremely hard to do what you
wanted, enforce the code as scheduled. I cannot, even in my worst
nightmares, imagine how this would not satisfy everyone if that was their
true objections. Obviously it was not and Politics once again was Politics.

As I stated, you are our last chance. We are not alone. There are many
companies that will be put out of business because of this action. I do know
you have the power to make this right. I am begging you for the opportunity
to meet with you to politely express the feelings and concerns of our
company and our industry before you sign the bill to put us out of business.
I don't think this is an unfair request since Tallahassee has potentially
stripped my life from me.

I hope to hear from you or your office soon.

Respectfully,

Peter Merhige
Protective Glass Industries
2546 Fowler Street
Ft Myers, FL 33901
941-936-4227
941-936-2237 fax
www.trishield.net

From: Lois Adams [mailto:ladams@hhcs.com]
Sent: Monday, December 03, 2001 3:08 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: yopfell@juno.com
Subject: MAIL ORDER PILOT PROGRAM FOR DIABETES


Dear Jeb.....
It is my understanding that the mail order pilot program for diabetes for patients along the I-4 corridor (Central Florida) requires that patients receive their diabetic medications and supplies through an out of state provider Health Alliance.  Not only is that an outrage for businesses within this state but that it makes no sense at all medically.- it is dangerous to the patient.  Our pharmacy presently provides medication management for the Senior Resource Alliance which includes 5 counties in Central Florida.  We monitor not only their diabetes but also the diseases which are a direct result on non-compliance,  inappropriate use of medication, failure to properly educate, etc.  And- it is at no charge to anyone including the Medicaid program. There is no way to control the health of these people with the therapy bifurcated and with incomplete patient history at our pharmacy.   It is inconceivable that you would allow this to go to a company which up to this point has not performed in a satisfactory matter when you have a woman owned business in this state (and a staunch Republican member of the Republican Congressional Committee Business Advisory Council) right here in Central Florida (Orlando).  I understand that you will be in Orlando tomorrow and I would hope that you would have a few moments to speak with me as I have been invited by Rich Crotty to attend-as a member of OCREC.  Please e-mail me concerning this.  Thank you.
N. Lois Adams

-----Original Message-----
From: frenc71@dellepro.com [mailto:frenc71@dellepro.com]
Sent: Wednesday, December 05, 2001 3:23 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: frenc71@dellepro.com
Subject: Past criminal from 20 years ago


Dear Gov. Bush (Jeb) ,
 
My name is Ed French (Edwin C. French III) ,
I am writing as per several sources state that you are probably the only person that can help and might consider helping me with this problem . I am originally a born-and-raised Floridian who now resides in the State of Arizona . Nearly all of my childhood family ties remain in Orlando and surrounding areas .
 
In 1981 , I was sentenced after submitting a guilty plea for a white-collar non-violent crime for which I served time on in the Deland facility for Volusia County . The Honorable McFerrin Smith was acting Judge in this case during Sept. of 1981 . Four months after I was introduced to facility my case was reviewed , between going from Maximum security at time of intake to Trustee in three months , my 1 year sentence was commuted to probation and I was released the morning before Christmas .
 
Jeb , since that time ( 20 years ago ) , I have been a productive taxpayer , model employee , devoted husband and most recently an exuberant and loving father to my 9 year old daughter Meaghan who I adore . Other than an occasional traffic citation in the first 10 years , I have not had to visit a courtroom except to seek visitation for my wife Krista's Grandaughter .
 
Now that I have given you some background on myself  we come to the issue at hand . I am a mature and responsible parent , husband and citizen . I have never had a violent background or tendency . My last 3 employers cover over 11 yrs in customer service : Tucson Medical Center - 6yrs        American Airlines- 2+ years     Spherion (corporate travel agency for Amex) 3 yrs .
 
For the vast majority of these past 20 years I have had all of my Civil Liberties restored except for the Right to Bear Arms .
I live in a fairly remote area just southwest of Tucson Az. and between our location gradually becoming more urban , the state of our World today and an overwhelming desire to be able to feel safe in our home , I am asking for your help in the only way I know how . I am hoping that somewhere deep down you can relate to what I am talking about at some level .
 
Several years ago I had inquired as to the steps neccessary to re-obtain the last liberty I was still missing and was referred to ATF for more info . They stated at that time that the only way to do this was to be granted Clemency or a Pardon from the State in which the crime was committed . I left Florida in 1985 and have been an Arizona resident since 1986 . In all this time I have been back to visit my folks on a fairly regular basis and have always respected the laws and citizens of Florida .
 
I am not exactly sure what measure you would need to use to accomplish my request should you choose to help me , but any help and/or advise is welcome . Just on a side - note , Jeb , if this is something you can't do or aren't comfortable with , I'll understand . I am just a good man that made a huge mistake early in life and have paid for it ever since .
 
Thanks for taking the time .
Respectfully ,
                                                                                            Ed French
                                                                                            3402 S. Bradford Drive
                                                                                            Tucson , Az. 85735
                                                                                             1-520-908-9662 - home
                                                                                             1-520-331-2720 - cell             frenc71@dellepro.com  or   frenc71@hotmail.com
 
 
 
                                                                           

From:	Phil Myrick <pmyrick@pps.org>
Sent:	Thursday, December 6, 2001 4:12 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Haulover Park, Surfside, FL
Attachments:	Phil Myrick.vcf

December 6, 2001
 
Honorable Jeb Bush
Governor, State of Florida
Executive Office of the Governor
The Capitol
Tallahassee, Florida 32399
 
Dear Governor Bush,
 
I am writing to support a resolution by the Town of Surfside (#1623) that opposes the permitting and/or establishment of a commercial marina at Haulover Park.  As a national nonprofit that watches public space and urban park issues, we are very disturbed by Miami-Dade County's plans for developing this public waterfront park into a commercial zone that will deprive the majority of the public from free use of the waterfront. Furthermore, these plans have been put forth by the County without community consultation. 
 
Over the past 26 years, Project for Public Spaces has worked in over 1,000 communities and has become the leading national expert on how to create vibrant public spaces and revitalize the neighborhoods around them. In the process, we have worked with downtown development groups, neighborhood associations, foundations, government at the local, state and federal levels, merchants associations, corporations and private developers.  We have learned, through this experience, that decisions regarding public spaces need to be made in a full and open process that involves the public, and that planning efforts that eschew public participation invariably fail, either because of controversy or through lack of use by the public.  On the other hand, places that do use an inclusive visioning process can generate enormous positive spin-off effects extending far beyond the space itself and build a healthier relationship between public officials and their constituents . 
 
Furthermore, public assets need to remain public, and while private concessions may, at times, create a desirable source of revenue that contributes to better maintenance, such uses should always be complementary and supportive of the public nature of the space, rather than an intrusion on it.  It is our strong feeling that the commercial uses in Miami-Dade County's plans are entirely inappropriate for Haulover Park.
 
Thank you for your attention in these matters.
 
 
Philip  Myrick
Vice-President  
Project for Public Spaces
 <http://www.pps.org/> www.pps.org
 <mailto:pmyrick@pps.org> pmyrick@pps.org
212-620-5660  
 
CC: 
Melissa Meeker, Regional Director, Florida Department of Environmental Protection
Carolyn A. Dekle, Executive Director  <http://www.sfrpc.com/> South Florida Regional Planning Council

From:	Lynch, Tom <lyncht@infinity-software.com>
Sent:	Thursday, December 6, 2001 1:54 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: Blackberry/Outlook Solution

Governor,
 
Our tests yesterday were successful.  We are implementing the solution this afternoon.  We will continue to monitor the system through this afternoon and expect a final assessment no later than tomorrow morning.  FWIW,  Bruce has been a big help and a joy to work with.  We would have been unsuccessful without his assistance.  
 
I'll keep you posted on our progress.
 
Tom Lynch
President
Infinity Software Development, Inc.
 
------------
 
P.S.  a more detailed/technical assessment of the situation follows: 
 

Statement of the Problem:

The client was experiencing a problem getting their Blackberry wireless email device to synchronize with Outlook. A generic method (POP3) was used to download email messages from an Exchange server to a laptop. The Blackberry was also used to receive email via wireless. When the Blackberry was placed in the cradle attached to a laptop it would not "synchronize" with Exchange or Outlook on the laptop. In other words, messages that were received, read, deleted, or replied to with the Blackberry were updated on neither the Exchange Server nor Outlook. 

The Analysis:

The Blackberry device will not work with the generic method (POP3) of handling emails. Blackberry requires that its cradle and attached computer have a direct connection to the Exchange Server.  Blackberry synchronizes with the Exchange Server, not Outlook. 

The Solution:

We configured the laptop with an Outlook profile to connect directly to the Exchange Server.  The Blackberry device now works. When the device is put in the cradle it automatically updates the Exchange Server and, by extension, Outlook. We further modified Outlook to use "offline" folders. This provides two major advantages. First, it allows Outlook to be used without an Internet connection. Emails may be managed normally. The next time Outlook is connected to Exchange, it again synchronizes (e.g. sending or deleting emails). The second advantage to this solution is that it requires the least direct communication with Exchange. This is a benefit when operating on a dial-up or low bandwidth line. Using Outlook with offline folders will not significantly degrade performance compared to using Outlook with a POP3 connection. 

In summary, we recommend to Bruce to discontinue using POP3.  Instead, use a direct connection to Exchange with Outlooks offline folders enabled. He is going to implement the solution this afternoon. Their ISP will reconfigure their firewall to enable communication this afternoon. Bruce will also reconfigure their Exchange 2000 Server. Infinity has created a modification for the Exchange Server for Bruce to use.  Infinity will meet with Bruce at 1pm today to assist in the process.

-----Original Message-----
From: Martha Pratt [mailto:martha@jeb.org]
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 11:31 AM

-----Original Message-----
From: Valerie Adams [mailto:valadams@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 11:29 AM
To: Martha Pratt; Martha Pratt
Subject: Capitol recycling buried in inaction. St. Petersburg Times
12/6/01


Capitol recycling buried in inaction
State officials toss their trash, marking a retreat from a program
lawmakers
mandated in 1988.
By JULIE HAUSERMAN
 St. Petersburg Times,
published December 6, 2001
------------------------------------------------------------------------

TALLAHASSEE -- All over Florida, people are rinsing out bottles and cans
and
putting them into recycling bins. State law requires every county to
recycle.

But at the state Capitol, it's a different story. Most lawmakers,
lobbyists
and state staffers just throw bottles and cans into the trash. Even
though
the law requires it, there's no official aluminum recycling program at
the
Capitol. Informally, janitors and maids collect some aluminum cans and
turn
them in for money.

And what about paper recycling? A much-ballyhooed program to recycle the
mounds of office paper from state buildings has been mediocre at best, a
local official says.

Every week, giant loads of paper from state government offices go
straight
into the Leon County landfill. The 86 state office buildings in
Tallahassee
are recycling only 100 tons of paper a month -- about half as much as
they
could be, said Nancy Paul, the recycling coordinator for Leon County.

"There are forests that lay bare because of us," said state Rep. Lindsay
Harrington, a Punta Gorda Republican who heads the House Natural
Resources
and Environmental Protection Committee. "We are not abiding by the
laws."

The waning interest in recycling at the Capitol itself mirrors the
Legislature's gradual retreat from a recycling program that lawmakers
mandated with much fanfare in 1988.

In the years since, Florida communities have embraced recycling. But the
Legislature keeps cutting back the local grants to pay for it. Every
year,
lawmakers raid millions of dollars from recycling trust funds and use
the
money for other things.

This week, lawmakers proposed to cut recycling grants to counties
altogether
and set up a new small statewide fund of $3-million to $5-million.
Counties
would have to compete for the money. By comparison, when the Legislature
first started statewide recycling, it handed out $35-million in grants
to
counties. Each year, the pot got smaller and smaller. This year, the
state
had just $5.3-million available for county grants.

Lawmakers now want to take the millions that once paid for local
recycling
programs and use the money for other needs, such as restoring the
Everglades
and spraying pesticides to control the west Nile virus.

Even some leading Republicans are queasy about it.

"I'm really concerned that we're sending a message here," Republican
Sen.
Jim King of Jacksonville said at a committee meeting this week. "We were
so
proud in Jacksonville, we were one of the leading cities in the nation
in
terms of recycling. I'm concerned we're sending a message of "That was
then,
this is now.' I'm concerned you'll end up with piles of bottles and cans
and
plastics, and they'll end up in the same place they were before -- in
the
landfill."

Proponents of the cuts say that local community recycling programs are
thriving, and it's time for the state to pull back.

In big counties such as Hillsborough and Pinellas, the impact won't be
that
great, local officials say, because county commissions have taken on
more of
the burden when state money started to dwindle several years ago.

Small counties, though, could be hurt.

"It's a very sad situation to see Florida walk away from its commitment.
Small counties just don't have the resources," said former Republican
State
Sen. George Kirkpatrick of Gainesville, who was one of the chief
architects
of Florida's 1988 Solid Waste Management Act. "Legislators today have no
idea why we started these programs. These people are going to wake up
one
day and there's going to be trash on the roads and along the rivers, and
they are going to say: What happened?"

In 1988, Florida was the second state in the country to set a recycling
goal
for itself: 30 percent of all solid waste was supposed to be recycled by
1994.

Florida has come close to the goal but hasn't met it. The statewide
recycling rate in 1998, the last year the state totaled the figures,
stands
at about 28 percent, according to a recent Department of Environmental
Protection review of the state's recycling programs.

The state set goals for individual counties as well. Florida's 35
biggest
counties were supposed to be recycling 30 percent of their waste by
1994.
But that goal hasn't been met, either. In 1998, only nine out of those
35
counties had met the goal, the DEP report says. (In the Tampa Bay area,
only
one county, Citrus, met the 30 percent goal.)

"The fact that many counties did not achieve the goals does not mean the
effort was futile," the DEP report says, noting that Florida has more
curbside recycling programs than ever before -- 299 statewide.

Overall, Floridians are recycling about 21/2 times more garbage then
they
were a decade ago.

From a political standpoint, recycling seems more important than ever.
Not a
single new landfill has been built in Florida since 1994 because of
neighborhood opposition, the DEP report says.

Most important, recycling offers Floridians a chance to help the state's
environment hands-on.

"The people who are the biggest advocates for recycling are the citizens
of
Florida -- the kids and moms and dads," said John Schert, executive
director
of the Center for Solid and Hazardous Waste at the University of
Florida.
"They want to feel like they aren't just throwing things in a landfill,
that
someone is going to make a new product out of it."

State Sen. Ken Pruitt, R-Port St. Lucie, is leading the effort to do
away
with most county recycling grants. He says the state needed to help
counties
when programs were new, but that counties should take more
responsibility
now. He says the state has met its recycling goals "in spirit."

"We have done what the Legislature intended," Pruitt said. "Sometimes,
you
don't meet the exact percentage of the goal."

On Wednesday, the Department of Management Services, the state agency
that's
supposed to coordinate recycling at state buildings, acknowledged that
recycling at the Capitol and other state buildings isn't what it should
be.
DMS Deputy Secretary Mallory Harrell pledged to beef up the program.

"If we can provide better quality and better quantity of materials,
we'll
have better recycling," Harrell said. "We're looking at how we can do
that."

She said DMS wants to increase its paper recycling and start a viable
aluminum recycling program at the Capitol.

There are plenty of aluminum cans to recycle there. Every year, soft
drink
lobbyists haul in crates of free soda to the Capitol and hand them out
to
the masses gathered for the legislative session.

Tampa Bay recycling
Here's a look at the recycling rates that local counties reported to the
state Department of Environmental Protection in 1998.

Hillsborough -- 28 percent

Pinellas -- 24 percent

Hernando -- 27 percent

Citrus -- 31 percent

Pasco -- 13 percent

Source: DEP

From:	Charles Lee <chlee2@earthlink.net>
Sent:	Thursday, December 6, 2001 11:38 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Everglades Water Quality Standard

I spent much of yesterday in a briefing by DEP General Counsel Teri Donaldson, Ernie Barnett, and Frank Nearhoof on what they represented to me to be DEP's position regarding the Everglades phosphorus standard. 

Based on their briefing, I remain gravely concerned that what is about to be proposed will have the following effects: 

* Initiate 3 years or more of gratuitous litigation. Instead of the "best and brightest" at DEP and SFWMD being able to focus on how to ATTAIN the standard already in the law (10ppb) their time and energies will be dissipated by having to defend a rule to before an administrative law judge. Since the 10ppb standard is ALREADY in the law, there is NO value added here, only RISK. 

* Subject the formulation of a "compliance methodology" to the more difficult standards of rulemaking rather than keeping it within the more manageable confines of the permit process. The Everglades Forever Act has NO directive to DEP that authorizes a rule on compliance methodology. Compliance methodology is discussed in a SEPARATE subsection of the Everglades Forever Act with NO authority to adopt a rule attached to it (the Legislature easily COULD have granted DEP rulemaking authority associated with the compliance methodology, but chose not to). 

DEP has attempted to adopt rules under similar circumstances recently, and has LOST rule challenges on similar points. See:

 State of Florida, Board of Trustees of the Internal Improvement Trust Fund v. Day Cruise Association, 1st District Court of Appeal, September 13, 2001

I have not yet seen the draft rule language. In the briefing yesterday, the DEP staff only showed me "bullet points"of what the rule would contain on the points of the criterion (10ppb), compliance methodology, and "net improvement" of impacted areas. 

Many of the "bullet points" sounded pretty good as to what the rule would contain, but I can't assess them with certainty until I see the actual rule language. 

However, no matter how good the draft rule appears on first blush, its benefits will be illusory if they create an unnecessary new round of litigation that the state is at risk of losing, or at best dissipating its energies and public funds in over the next several years.

Far better course of action: 

*  Announce a decision to rely on 10ppb default standard in the law because rulemaking to put the same number in a rule is redundant, and exposes the state to unnecessary litigation.

* Deal with "compliance methodology" in long term permits as originally envisioned by the Everglades Forever Act, which must be considered by DEP in 2003.

Charles 

From:	Barbara Lumpkin <blumpkin@floridanurse.org>
Sent:	Thursday, December 6, 2001 11:25 AM
To:	Jeb Bush

Dear Governor Bush, 

I cannot truly express how much I appreciate your continued support of our 
Nurse Practitioner Prescribing Bill. I'm sure you know by now that we were 
smashed in the House Regulation Committee on Tuesday morning.  We  do not 
consider this as defeat but rather as another hurdle that will be overcome 
while you are still our Governor. The nurses, supportive physicians, and 
Representative Green thank you for having Mike Hansen appear before the 
committee to express your support. We really felt that we would have a 
closer vote but the opposition mounted over the weekend and on Monday was 
widespread and impressive if not always completely accurate. However we are 
hearing from legislators who watched to meeting in their offices that at 
least some are beginning to see that the negative debate at times is a 
message that conveys a lack of respect for the professionalism and ethics of 
registered nurses. 

I did speak with Greg Turberville yesterday and he tells me that he has 
mentioned to FMA that they must meet with our Association to discuss how our 
two professions can improve the practice environment for all levels of 
nurses in Florida's hospitals, nursing homes, and other health care 
facilities. As you know we are always willing to participate in discussion 
designed address the nursing shortage and/or to improve the quality and 
accessibility to coast effective health care services provided in a variety 
of settings for the citizens of our state and nation. 

On a personal note I really appreciate so much your offer for the 
opportunity to meet the President when he was here in Orlando on Tuesday. 
That you would even consider giving me that honor in humbling and deeply 
appreciated. 

With heartfelt sincerity, 

Barbara Lumpkin, RN

Florida Nurses Association

says ... no matter how foolish or damaging ...
rationalizing F&W opinions/recommendations seems to be the norm. F&W
incessantly asks for more than is reasonable, and the Corps gives it. Thus,
Miami-Dade citizens will be in jeopardy of exacerbated flooding for at least
2 more years if the current IOP preferred alternative is chosen ... even
though this was unanimously opposed by the Miami-Dade County Flood Mgt
Task Force ... and, even more, I am quite confident it will be considerably
longer as, in my judgment, there are simply too many tough issues to 
overcome to ensure a Dec 2003 completion as required in the Biological 
Opinion ... hate for a boss to micro-manage but it's needed on this one if the 
date is going to be met. My prediction is that, with the best of intentions but 
a lack of the  requisite attention, Col May will stand by the Dec 2003
completion, leave in summer of 2003, the new guy will say "it wasn't my
fault" that Mod Waters didn't get done as I just got here, and he'll be
given his 3-year tenure to get it done ... that's the way it seems to
be headed ... unfortunately it will be the citizens of M-D county, the
Indians, and others who will continue to suffer ... all for the most incredible
foolishness I have ever witnessed ... the use of the Cape Sable Seaside
Sparrow to control water. 
 
Keep this note and we'll evaluate my prognosis
on Jan 1, 2004 ... if the Corps gets it done ... operational Mod Water that
is ... I'll have the party and buy the beer for Greg and all who made it
possible ... and eat crow ... you and other friends certainly will be invited. 
I sure hope my prediction is wrong so we can celebrate ... even on me! 
Anything for a party.
 
Anyway, we just need some courageous public servants who
understand what's right and do it ... we do have some now and hopefully
they will step forward as they have already done on other issues ... both
stand-up to the Sparrow chicanery and get Mod Waters done ASAP.

Terry

Subject: IOP Comments



I presented the IPO letter to Col. May at the SERGE meeting today.  I
read the cover letter into the record during the public comment session
and provided copies to SFWMD, SFERTF (Rock), DOE (Everglades National
Park -- Maureen), the State (Rick Smith), USDA - Ron Smola, the County
(to go to Roman Gastesi) and the District's Water Resources Advisory
Council (Julio Fanjul).
I faxed a copy to Dexter last night.

The letter and my comments got a much more lively and lengthy reception
than I anticipated.  Col May -- who was acting as the Chairman --
immediately launched into a very articulate, but largely defensive
rebuttal.  Rick Smith really perked up when he heard that Cindy Lerner
and the Mayors endorsed our position and that you provided the technical
expertise -- seemed very concerned that the state may come out opposing
the Corp's recommendation.  Neal McAlliley opined we are "crying wolf"
again".  The US Fish and Wildlife rep -- a new guy named Jay -- tried to
assure me that the feds were working it all out and we will be OK.  But,
I got to intervene as it went along to clarify issues -- as best I could
-- and to challenge comments I thought inappropriate or inaccurate.

 Same old story -- we'll be OK once Mod Waters and C-111 are completed,
but only vague ideas of how we get through the interim period without
increasing flooding probabilities.  However, out of all the discussion,
Col. May invited you and I to sit down with him and his hydrologists to
discuss the differences in our respective opinions.  I concurred, but
asked that we be able to bring Roman along to represent the County's
perspective.

Let me know what you think we need to do next.

From: Audubon of Florida [mailto:advocacy@audubonofflorida.org]
Sent: Wednesday, December 05, 2001 4:18 PM

Subject: Audubon of Florida On-line Advocacy Center Launched!



Hi Jeb, 

Audubon of Florida On-line Advocacy Center Launched! 
http://ga1.org/natureadvocate/home.html 

I am pleased to announce the launch of our new on-line Advocacy Center. As a friend, supporter, and/or advocate in either the Florida Conservation or Everglades Conservation Network, you have been automatically added as a participant in our new on-line Advocacy Center. Your participation preferences have not changed and you can continue to choose to participate in either citizen advocacy network or both. 

We have upgraded our communication abilities and you will find this new web based advocacy technology easy to use and effective for communicating with decision-makers and keeping track of what, when, and to whom communications are sent.  As part of our Advocacy Center you have your own "Activist" web page to keep track of the following:

1. Your contact information- email/address changes, how you like to receive electronic mail [html (like a web page) or text]

2. What Audubon campaigns you have participated in 
3. When you participated in each campaign 
4. Learn what the result of your participation was, track how a campaign is going 
5. Look up your elected officials 
6. Additional advocacy resources for each campaign issue 

To take advantage of this effective advocacy tool, log-in to the site below and access the Advocacy Center. Initially, you will need to obtain a password to take full advantage of your Advocacy Center's features: 

SINCE YOU HAVE ALREADY BEEN AUTOMATICALLY SIGNED UP FOR THE NEW ADVOCACY CENTER CLICK ON "FORGOT YOUR PASSWORD?" TO GET STARTED. 

http://ga1.org/natureadvocate/home.html 

Thanks for participating! 

Shannon Mayorga 
Conservation Associate 
Audubon of Florida

http://www.audubonofflorida.org

-----Original Message-----
From: Secretary Moore [mailto:secretary@mail.dc.state.fl.us]
Sent: Thursday, December 06, 2001 9:26 AM
To: Jimenez, Frank
Cc: Ball, Peggy; Prudom, Richard; Agwunobi, John; Zingale, James; Kathleen Shanahan (E-mail); Jeb Bush
Subject: FW: Minority Business Spending



Frank, the difficulty for us in reaching last years expenditures is the 
reductions in current year FCO (6 million) and the decision by ARAMARK to 
cancel the PRIDE food commodities contract.  I have discussed with ARAMARK 
the importance of MBE subcontracting.  I asked ARAMARK to attend the DMS 
conference and to contact Windell Paige for ideas and vendors.  This is a 
potential 10 million dollar impact on our numbers. 

Our goal is four million less than last year.  Our budget is approximately 
40 million less as a result of this special session, including substance 
abuse contract reduction in the community and in prisons, which will affect 
some MBE providers.  

It will be a struggle to meet last year's spending.  We will strive to 
increase our spending in appropriate areas.  We are currently exploring 
medical contracts to see if there are new or additional MBE providers to 
utilize in the clinical areas. 

I will be happy to stay after the meeting to discuss further ideas.

abuse contract reduction in the community and in prisons, which will affect 
some MBE providers.  

It will be a struggle to meet last year's spending.  We will strive to 
increase our spending in appropriate areas.  We are currently exploring 
medical contracts to see if there are new or additional MBE providers to 
utilize in the clinical areas. 

I will be happy to stay after the meeting to discuss further ideas.

To the Big 6 Minority Business Spending Agencies: 

So far, we are ahead in minority business spending from this time last year, 

although DOT has taken the lion's share of the increase.  Two questions:  

1.  Do any of you anticipate major difficulties in exceeding last year's 
spending? 
2.  Windell Paige will give us a One Florida update at the agency heads 
meeting December 18.  Can you all stay for 10 minutes afterward to discuss 
your agency's spending?  Jim Zingale has offered to help us in coming up 
with strategies to overcome any obstacles this year's tighter budget 
situation may present us. 

Thanks.

and, on behalf of Governor Bush, i want say a special thanks to all of you

the fact that Florida is without peer in terms of our Statewide Strategy and 
our collective will to execute the Strategy to strengthen our domestic 
security.  This is  a complement to each of you!

From:	Jamie Sene <jsene@smartcertify.com>

Subject:	Special Education

Importance:	High

Dear Mr. President: 

First I want to acknowledge you and your Administration for the great job you are doing in leading our nation during these troubled times.

There is an issue that is not getting a lot of press but that is vital to this nation and all it's people.  Too many young children are being put into Special Education and labeled with "learning disorders" simply because they haven't been taught to read or have been "left behind" because they lack fundamental educational tools. This problem will not be fixed by labeling them and then drugging them.  I urge you not to allocate any more funding for Special Education until it has been reformed!

Thank You and Best Regards, 

Jamie Sene 
764 Forest Glen Road 
Clearwater, FL 33765

From:	Mary O'Meara <msosparc@ucnsb.net>
Sent:	Thursday, December 6, 2001 8:47 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Possible Scam relating to our disabled population

Dear Governor Bush,
 
I would not normally contact you with the details of the goings on in our community, but I think that I am a target for a Scientology scam.
 
My name is Mary O'Meara and I am the president of S.P.A.R.C. of Volusia, Inc. (Special Population Activities & Recreation Council). We are a 501 (c) 3 Florida non-profit, and our organization provides recreational, athletic, social and educational activities for mentally challenged people in Volusia County. I live in New Smyrna Beach, and our group has been experiencing the growth and wonder of the success of reaching anyone and everyone who can benefit from our activities. We are hoping that in the future we can establish a community center to serve a lot of needs. I was planning to start writing grants for funding in 2002. We have over 150 "participants", whose age range is 3-65 who represent a myriad of disabilities.
 
My concern is that we saw an e-mail for seed money to open an "ABLE Center" and I jumped at the opportunity to learn more about it. ...Long story short, I have arranged for a meeting with Lori Bennett, "Ambassador of Hope" as she regards herself, to speak to the parents and care-givers of my group. I have recently been made aware that she may represent the Church of Scientology. Although asked many direct questions about religion and funding, Lori has never given me a direct answer. She has claimed that the seed money does not come from Federal or State funding, that it does not come from any form of grant, and that she will only disclose where the funds come from at our meeting. This meeting is scheduled for December 12th at Coronado Community United Methodist Church's "Beach Club" at 7pm. You are invited if you'd like to attend!
 
I have spent the better part of the day speaking with my attorney, surfing the internet looking for any information I can get. I was hoping to find a direct tie between the A.B.L.E. Foundation and Scientology, but I cannot find one. I have, however, received e-mails stating that some people KNOW the tie to be there. As a result I have e-mailed my mailing list and will follow up with a post card tomorrow telling ALL that I am only hosting, not backing, this organization. I have urged my families NOT to sign anything. I am a recognized and trusted entity in my county and want to keep on doing what I'm doing - it's needed and I truly enjoy it. Here's the thing: I am afraid that she will bully my desperate parents into something, or that she will make my life difficult if I don't comply with her... The information I digested regarding Scientology is horrifying, and I am actually personally afraid at this point. 
 
I am hoping for some input, advice or reassurance - who knows what - mostly because I feel that all of my work can be ruined in one fell swoop. Do you have any information on this church in Florida? Lori Bennett is the CEO of "The A.B.L.E. (Achieving Beyond Limited Expectations) Foundation, Inc,  - as it's worded in the Division of Corporations website - and her family members are the other directors. She lives in Williston, Florida. There is some connection with Illinois, as our meeting invitations came from zip code 60499 in South Suburban Illinois - although when I asked her about the postmark she did not answer my question satisfactorily. I am hoping that we can stop this before other counties are possibly taken advantage of also. I have included the ABLE website and hope that perhaps your office can look it over thoroughly... it seems to say a lot while saying very little, and yet I felt obliged to investigate it as something of a possibility for our county. http://www.ablefoundation.org
 
My contact information is as follows: I live at 321 Roslyn Avenue, New Smyrna Beach, FL 32168 - 
My phone number is 386-409-9292, and my e-mail is msosparc@ucnsb.net. 
 
I thank you in advance for any input you can provide.
 
Sincerely,
 
Mary S. O'Meara

Governor Bush,

backed you and you sent it back to me, with your signature and a thank you.

tho I knew I would loose my job, I supported you.  On Friday November 30, I 
issued the last State Building Permit, So now I have to try and find myself 
another job.  

Now that the position that I have done for the entire state has been done 
away with and a guy like myself will be required for each of the indivual 
counties and municipalities, I have found a job at Florida State University, 
where I will be able to continue to do what I have done, and bring with me 
what I have learned to a Dept. that does not have a clue as to the 
permitting and building inspection process.  I would like to ask if you 
would help me to obtain the position as building inspector for the States 
University Systems New Inspection and Permitting program.

New Building Code Administrator.  Mr. Deckerts Phone number is (850) 
644-7686, and his e-mail is: tdeckert@admin.fsu.edu.

doing so, then that is no problem also.

my vote.

From:	Shanahan, Kathleen <kathleen.shanahan@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Thursday, December 6, 2001 8:34 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	FW: response faxed ref oreilly factor

FYI 

-----Original Message----- 
From: Hirst, Elizabeth 
Sent: Wednesday, December 05, 2001 5:44 PM 
To: Shanahan, Kathleen 
Subject: response faxed ref oreilly factor 




MEMORANDUM 

DATE:   December 5, 2001 
TO:     Bill O'Reilly, O'Reilly Factor 
FROM:   Elizabeth Hirst,  Press Secretary for Governor Jeb Bush 
RE:     Previous Response to the O'Reilly Factor 


Please be advised that on October 16, 2001 the following information was 
provided to an associate producer in your office by the name of Andrea.  She 
called our press office to inquire about an interview with Governor Jeb Bush 
regarding the situation involving University of South Florida professor Sami 
Al-Arian.  The Governor was not available for an interview, however the 
following response was provided to Andrea. 

"No Governor in the state of Florida has ever had the authority to hire or 
fire university faculty, nor does the Governor have the authority to direct 
a university president to hire or fire any individual.  The university 
system in Florida is bound by a collective bargaining agreement.  In this 
case, Sami Al-Arian is a tenured professor. It is our understanding that 
under a legally binding contract, a person cannot be fired solely based on 
his/her beliefs or personal associations.  At this point, university 
officials are looking at all available options." 

The most appropriate contacts regarding this issue would be the President of 
the University of South Florida, Dr. Judy Genshaft, (813) 974-2791 SC 
574-2791 or the Secretary of the Florida Board of Education Jim Horne, 
850-201-7400. 


                                                        # # # 


Elizabeth E. Hirst 
Press Secretary 
Office of Governor Jeb Bush 

From:	Shanahan, Kathleen <kathleen.shanahan@myflorida.com>

-----Original Message----- 
From: Horne, Jim [ mailto:Jim.Horne@flboe.org] 
Sent: Wednesday, December 05, 2001 4:40 PM 
To: 'Eli.Ferrera@myflorida.com' 
Cc: 'justine.orlich@myflorida.com'; 'kathleen.shanahan@myflorida.com' 
Subject: Reappointment of Mary Jane Dillon to the Board for the Florida 
Sc hool for the Deaf and Blind 


Eli- 

Just a quick note to give my strong recommendation for the reappointment of 
Mary Jane Dillon to the Board for the Florida School for the Deaf and Blind. 

Mrs. Dillon has worked at Flagler College for the past four years, serving 
as Coordinator of Services for Students with Disabilities and as an 
Assistant to Dr. William Proctor, member of the Florida Board of Education. 
She comes highly recommended by Dr. Proctor as well.  In fact, he feels that 
she in an integral part of the Board and has made significant contributions 
to its success.  She comes with a wealth of knowledge. 

It is my understanding from Dr. Proctor that previous to her employment at 
the College, Mrs. Dillon worked at the Florida School for the Deaf and Blind 
for over 16 years, serving as a Guidance Counselor in the Department for the 
Blind for six years and as Public Information Officer for the School for 10 
years.  She has a deep regard for the School and has maintained many 
associations with staff, faculty and alumni. 

I am confident that Mrs. Dillon has all the necessary qualifications to 
serve as a member of the board. It is without reservation and with a great 
deal of pleasure that I offer this recommendation on her behalf. 

If you have any questions, please don't hesitate to contact me. 

Thank you for your kind consideration. 

Jim Horne 
Secretary 
Florida Board of Education

From:	fasano.mike@leg.state.fl.us
Sent:	Thursday, December 6, 2001 6:08 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	A vote for a new tax

This St. Petersburg Times ( http://www.sptimes.com) story has been sent to you from fasano.mike@leg.state.fl.us 



------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 

http://www.sptimes.com/News/120601/Opinion/A_vote_for_a_new_tax.shtml 

A vote for a new tax 

 St. Petersburg Times, published December 6, 2001 


   As promised, the Legislature has voted to delay the previously approved intangibles tax cut, thereby saving $128-million to apply to the budget deficit. The margins of 37-2 in the Senate and 102-17 in the House were impressive, considering that it could be called -- as some did -- a vote for a new tax.   As promised, the Legislature has voted to delay the previously approved intangibles tax cut, thereby saving $128-million to apply to the budget deficit. The margins of 37-2 in the Senate and 102-17 in the House were impressive, considering that it could be called -- as some did -- a vote for a new tax.

   Now, that wasn't so hard, was it? 

   In debate, House members had to endure yet another of Mike Fasano's tiresome laments about the poor "savers" who have to pay a tax on their "hard-earned money after it's been taxed."

   Two things need to be said about that. 

   The bill came to the floor under a rule that prevented any amendments, among them a Democratic proposal to exempt more than 500,000 of the smallest taxpayers, double the rate on the rest and close a much-abused trust loophole. This would have virtually erased the deficit without any need for the punishing cuts in education, health and crime prevention that will occur under the budget bill to be passed today. It's a pity that the leadership didn't allow members to vote.

   Most people's life savings are concentrated in the value of their homes rather than in stocks and bonds subject to the intangibles tax. Yet Floridians pay real estate taxes on those homes, at an average of nearly 21 times the rate on stocks on bonds, without any comparable protest from Fasano. Might the fact that he works for a stock brokerage firm have something to do with his fixation? 






From:	fasano.mike@leg.state.fl.us
Sent:	Thursday, December 6, 2001 5:43 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Bush's tax cut wins delay despite several GOP nays

This St. Petersburg Times ( http://www.sptimes.com) story has been sent to you from fasano.mike@leg.state.fl.us 

You did not lose any votes... 

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 

http://www.sptimes.com/News/120601/State/Bush_s_tax_cut_wins_d.shtml 

Bush's tax cut wins delay despite several GOP nays 
By ALISA ULFERTS 
 St. Petersburg Times, published December 6, 2001 


   TALLAHASSEE -- Lawmakers handed Gov. Jeb Bush the delay he sought in a controversial tax cut Wednesday, but it came without the support of some of the House's most conservative members.   TALLAHASSEE -- Lawmakers handed Gov. Jeb Bush the delay he sought in a controversial tax cut Wednesday, but it came without the support of some of the House's most conservative members.

   Repeatedly, Bush has been asked whether he had the 61 Republican House votes he wanted to delay a cut in the state's intangibles tax. Repeatedly, he has answered "Absolutely" or "We have the votes."

   In the end, Bush got 60 Republicans to vote for the delay. Seventeen other GOP lawmakers defected. Had all 43 Democrats joined the 17 Republican defectors in opposing the bill, it would have failed. Now, it will go to Bush for his signature.

   Bush insisted he could have delivered more Republicans, if he needed them. 

   "We were up to about 68 votes -- 60 very solid and eight who would have joined us" had it not become clear that the Democrats were going to support the delay, Bush said.

   "We had a lot of 61st votes," Bush said. 

   The House's 102-17 vote marks the first time Bush has lost more than a handful of Republican votes on any issue he wanted. The Senate earlier had approved Bush's bill 36-2.

   Rep. Connie Mack was among the young conservatives, informally dubbed the Freedom Caucus, who opposed Bush's plan. 

   "There were some of us that had a philosophical belief that this was not the right thing to do or the right time to do it," said Mack, R-Fort Lauderdale. He doesn't think Bush's failure to get 61 Republican votes reflects on the governor's standing within his own party.

   "He's been a leader on tax cuts. This shouldn't be made into "The governor's changed on the position of taxes,' " Mack said.

   Democrats supported the tax delay, but not before rubbing Republicans' noses in that fact. Delaying the cut will free up $128-million so budget cuts in the special session won't be so deep.

   House Democratic Leader Lois Frankel said the Democrats had considered voting against the tax delay as a strategy to pressure the Republicans who run the House to back off the budget cuts further. But the Democrats decided that wouldn't work.

   "We thought all that would happen is one of the 17 (nay votes) would have the noose around his neck" by voting for the delay, Frankel said.

   Bush stepped in to help broker a budget deal after the first special session he called to fix the budget collapsed when Senate President John McKay and Speaker of the House Tom Feeney failed to agree on the intangibles tax. Part of that agreement -- to be finalized today -- was to delay the latest round of the intangibles tax cut for 18 months to give the economy time to recover.

   McKay had wanted to repeal the tax cut entirely, and Feeney wouldn't even consider a delay. 

   Feeney joined 16 other Republicans in voting against the compromise. But he asked his lieutenants to help round up votes for Bush's compromise plan.

   "I candidly never knew whether we had 61 votes or not, but I worked closely with some of the Democratic members," Feeney said.

   Rep. Mike Fasano, who has popularized the phrase "seniors and savers" during his speeches opposing the intangibles tax on stocks and bonds, said he was impressed by Bush's abilities to garner 102 votes, even though his wasn't among those.

   "I'm convinced that if 61 Republican votes were needed on the floor, there would have been 61 votes. But it probably would not have been mine," said Fasano, R-New Port Richey.

   It's a point Bush agrees with. 

   "We probably had six people who, if they were needed, would have helped, maybe more," Bush said. "It shows we can forge a consensus and deal with problems. It was a good day for Republican leadership ... and tomorrow will be an even better day."

   - Times staff writers Lucy Morgan and Steve Bousquet contributed to this report.

From:	Buddysjoy@aol.com
Sent:	Wednesday, December 5, 2001 11:13 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	(no subject)

Dear Governor Bush, 

We have just been made aware of some disturbing news...My son is one of the people who are on the Matter of Choice Project.  We entered into the Matter Of Choice Project in "Good Faith" that the program would be a testing program for Developmental Disabilities.  We risked losing our services in order to help Developmental Disabilities make their system more cost effective.  Now, we are being told that Developmental Disabilities has overspent more than $80 million (or some unGodly amount like that!).  It seems to me, you are asking our children to pay for something that obviously didn't have the proper  Checks and Balances System! 

We were originally told the project would be coming to an end as of June 2002.  Then, we were told the project would be coming to an end as of March 2002.  Last weekend, I attended a Family Care Council Chairperson's Meeting in Orlando and Mr. Carl Littlefield informed us the project would be ending in January 2002.  This evening, I just received a phone call from our FCC Chairperson informing us The Matter of Choice Program will be ending this Monday, Dec. 10th!!!  Which one is it?  How can we plan for our children's daily care if we can't even count on what we are told?  We can't help but feel as though we are being manipulated!!! 

We can't begin to plan for our children's daily care!!!  The dates keep changing...there is no time to look for any other sources, support coordinators, support services, transportation to jobs, day programs, etc.!!   

How can you take our services away when we haven't even been officially notified?  When were we going to be told?  We are lucky, we are informed because we are a part of the Family Care Council and so we know people who called us when this came down today, Wednesday!  What about the people who don't have the connections like us?  When would they find out?  Monday...when there would be no services?  No one would come for respite, daily care, transportation, job coaching...? 

Our children depend on these services for their daily living...to live in our communities as independent adults.  They want to be independent and lead productive lives just like any other person their age...these services allow that to happen!!  And now, they are being taken away without proper notice and without any explanations of other options! 

This is totally unfair and not being done in "Good Faith"!!!  We are very disappointed!!! 

Please show us and our children respect and give them their dignity!!  If the project must come to an end, give us proper notice and time to make the necessary adjustments!!  We need to be allowed back into the system in a timely manner in order to not disrupt our children's lives!!! 

I look forward to hearing from you on this matter! 

Sincerely, 

Joy Frazier, Parent 
Lyall L. Frazier III, Matter Of Choice Client
