From:	Ward, Kevin D <kevin.ward@qwest.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 5, 2001 2:39 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Beware of that same old game... 

Governor - 

The same old semantical games have begun anew and will apparently be the 
focus of political and media attacks against you during your reelection bid. 
It's an old debating trick... rephrase and redefine - rephrase and redefine 
terminology and issues to place the argument into the best context from your 
point of view, regardless of accuracy. 

The results of the Special Session have yielded the first serious barrage of 
political and media bias in our newest political season.  And as the spin 
begins, the media either wittingly, or through sheer incompetence, is prone 
to further the arguments of the Democrats by repeating and echoing the false 
assertions... 

For example - a reduction in proposed budgetary growth is always cast by the 
Democrats and their media allies as a Spending Cut.  The implication is that 
key programs are being rolled-back, slashed, dismantled, etc.  The reality, 
as we both know, is that proposed increases in spending have been lowered - 
resulting in a lower level of new spending and growth, but still growth. 

This is not new and has been the hallmark of Democratic tactics for years. 
Reductions in taxation rates or taxation levels have always been 
characterized as Tax Cuts - even if the net result was an overall 
augmentation of tax revenue (as in the Reagan-Bush years).  They are more 
often clever ways to stimulate the economy and foster greater consumption 
and even greater government revenue.  But - the Democrats and the media are 
not going to redefine a tax-rate reduction as a tax revenue enhancer even if 
every living Nobel-winning Economist analyzed it that way on network TV. 

During the 2000 campaign, I tried to make this point again and again.  This 
is one big debate - and the Democrats and the media are jointly the 
opposition for the most part.  It is our role as Republicans to define, 
redefine and redefine again as necessary.  Our greatest challenge will 
always be "Rhetoric vs. Reality".  I've already heard Florida Republicans 
slip-up repeatedly over the last few weeks by agreeing to talk in 
"Demo-Speak", the language of our opposition.  If a Democrat labels a 
reduction in proposed spending increases as a Budget Cut - plain and simple, 
it is our responsibility to stop immediately and restate the obvious - 
redefining their rhetoric back into political reality.  If the media echoes 
Democratic remarks or frames questions in such terminology, we must likewise 
stop immediately and set the record straight.  Republicans far too often 
answer the question as is - even if it slanted or biased, even in its 
construction. 

It is a hard practice to master, and it requires extreme levels of self 
control and resolve... But it must be done.  "Right makes right" --- but it 
is far easier to be on the right side than it is to convince people of it. 
I have 20-30 personal examples of conversations where I have redefined media 
analysis of the results of the Special Session already.  And the results are 
always the same... "Oh, really? - well that makes since then."  But, if we 
don't explain it and redefine it as needed, we have already lost the battle 
of words. 

You can't be defeated in 2002 without political reality being spun into a 
"Demo-Speak" blur of contradictions and mis-information.  We already know 
that they are going to try... the only question is whether all Republicans 
are poised and ready to challenge them - with facts and truth and Republican 
realism. 

Good luck with all of this.  Your reelection is now my most pressing 
personal issue over the next 11 months.  If you or your team ever need any 
assistance, you only need ask... free-time, part-time or full-time... I'm 
ready to serve and assist as needed. 

Take care and God bless - Kevin Ward 

From:	Wm. D. Walker <redhawk103@home.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 5, 2001 10:55 PM
To:	president@whitehouse.gov
Cc:	Jeb Bush; Steven Houghland
Subject:	Fw: [Fwd: FW: Quote from Chair of President Bush's Commission onSpecial Education]

 
 








Sir I am forwarding a copy of this quote to you, from former Governor Branstand, your recent appointee as chairman of the your Administrations new Special Education Commission.  It is people like him who give a major setback to the very little we have been able to achieve for our physically and mentally handicapped children, a large majority of the special education schools in this country are sorely lacking in what these children and adults need in just learning life skills to try and fit into what we call the "normal" world.  
A young lady I use to volunteer with who fell into the catagory of being physically and mentally handicapped was telling me that she referred to "normal" people as T.A.B.'s (Temporarilly  Able Bodied)  Because she said everybody at one time in their life is going to depend on someone else for total and complete help for just everyday living and God forbid that it be permenant like mine.  So to her everybody else in the "normal" world are just T.A.B.'s and if everybody could just see it that way they wouldn't think there investment in their education a waste of money.  A perfect example of this unfortunately if our former President Ronald Reagan.  I think this last statement says it all sir.    Right now in Florida we are in for the struggle of our lives due the cowardly act of terrorism perpitrated on our country and it's effect on our state and all the other fortynine states economy it may be because I am prejudiced but it seems like it is going to effect our handicapped children the most. Thank You for your time.
 
                                      Yours Truely
                                      Wm. Darrell Walker
                                      Chairman
                                      Family Care Council
                                      District 1,  State of Florida
*************************************************

-----Original Message-----
From: jim harvey [mailto:jamesmharvey@earthlink.net]
Sent: Tuesday, December 04, 2001 9:28 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: p rule


 
governor bush
 
i want to bring to your attention to the direction (what i know is mostly rumor) that the p rule is heading.   dep had some meetings (operated by some consultants) with "interested parties" and many presentations were made and there was lots of discussion.  
 
we (wellington) had requested one more meeting for everyone to describe what technology (s) could bring us to standard,  but that did not happen.   
 
it seems that we are heading for a standard of 10 (wellington is not really interested in arguing this) and how the standard is measured (and wellington has no choice but to be interested in this aspect)  we made a presentation to the consultants and other parties and brought forward all the unresolved issues that have an impact on the urban areas (such things as by-pass water, where and how to measure, stuff like that) and what seems to be coming out is a system of "variances" which i believe will cause major heartburn.
 
i think dep as labored hard on this issue and doing everything i can do to make sure we do not embrace you or ourselves in the process............................   somehow i think this one ends up on your desk.
 
you know suzanne and i did not go to ireland this year (usually we are over there now) in fear that absence could be bad for my clients heath
 
keep up the great work and thanks for reading this 
 
    
jim harvey

From: Sir Bink [mailto:sirbink@hotmail.com]
Sent: Monday, December 03, 2001 9:16 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: What else can I do.



Dear Mr. Bush, 

   I remember coming to you with a plea for help.  I remember how stern and 
serious you took the meeting.  I remember you assigning someone to take care 
of the matter.  Well, here we are, nothing's changed other than DCF trying 
to cover its ass.  Let me give you a quick idea as to what I've lost during 
this ordeal: my truck, my job, my dignity, and my freedom.  I can't do this 
anymore.  Your agencies have blantently and provably broken the law, 
violated my rights & civil liberties, harbored an abusive individual and 
lied to cover it up in a swamp of paper work, broken promises and mis 
represented statements.  When the inspector general showed up at my house, 
his only concern was finding a fall guy in the matter; Delisa Mathews will 
be the target I'm sure.  When they dealt with Nancy and Al, it was purely a 
"prove DCF didn't relatiate" routine.  Now, when I talk to Sue Grey & 
BaryBeth on the matter, it's "we don't know anything" or "we can't tell you 
anything".  Well, tell me this Jeb, how is it that I've commited NO CRIME, 
I've done EVERYTHING that DCF has told me and I'm STILL paying for this??? 
No more.  I've waited long enough and sacrificed everything I can.  Is this 
the type of organization that runs the state I live in?  Well, it seems that 
my hands were bound 8 years ago when I was raped & they're still bound 
today.  I'm turning Charlie over to DCF as it's clear that I have no help in 
this matter and DCF has a state budget.  Personally, I hope you feel a 
little better knowing that an 8 year child can't be protected in your state 
because you don't have a clue as to what goes on behind your back.  As for 
me, I'll spend the next 5 or so years trying to recover what has taken me a 
lifetime to aquire and as for Charlie, all I can do is hope he makes it. 

Thanks for your help, 
John Greiner 

If you can't/won't help me, at least prevent this from happening to other 
innocent people.

-----Original Message-----
From: P1509@aol.com [mailto:P1509@aol.com]
Sent: Wednesday, December 05, 2001 9:01 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: THANK YOU FROM THE BOTTOM OF OUR HEARTS


Dear Governor Bush, 

Below is a copy of an email I am sending to our state legislators to thank them for protecting the funding for the developmentally disabled.  However,  we are all aware of the key role that you played in making sure that the proper action was taken to preserve the very livelihood of these special needs Floridians.   

The Family Care Council of District 7,  Orlando,  would just like to thank you again for your continued interest and support. 

Dean Parker, Co-Chair, 
Family Care Council,  District 7,  Orlando 

Dear Senator/Represetative, 

As advocates for the developmentally disabled, our most vulnerable Floridians,  our heartfelt thanks go out to you and your fellow legislators who took the time to take our phone calls,  read our emails, listen to us in face to face conversations, and then acted to preserve most of the funding that is so critical to this population.   

Responsible legislation of Florida's citizens tax contributions has moved our state to the forefront as a leader in caring for those who cannot care for themselves.  In one of the most trying budgeting sessions in memory,  you and your counterparts have withstood the pressures from many directions, and have determined those most needy and protected them.  For this we will forever be thankful.  As I am sure you understand,  we will continue to call on you as our elected officials to keep the developmentally disabled as a top priority when making funding decisions. 

Once again,  thanks so much for your support and you can depend on ours as we move into the future together. 

Respectfully, 


Dean Parker,  Co-Chair, 
Family Care Council,  District 7 
Orlando

-----Original Message-----
From: Lois Adams [mailto:ladams@hhcs.com]
Sent: Monday, December 03, 2001 3:08 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: yopfell@juno.com
Subject: MAIL ORDER PILOT PROGRAM FOR DIABETES


Dear Jeb.....
It is my understanding that the mail order pilot program for diabetes for patients along the I-4 corridor (Central Florida) requires that patients receive their diabetic medications and supplies through an out of state provider Health Alliance.  Not only is that an outrage for businesses within this state but that it makes no sense at all medically.- it is dangerous to the patient.  Our pharmacy presently provides medication management for the Senior Resource Alliance which includes 5 counties in Central Florida.  We monitor not only their diabetes but also the diseases which are a direct result on non-compliance,  inappropriate use of medication, failure to properly educate, etc.  And- it is at no charge to anyone including the Medicaid program. There is no way to control the health of these people with the therapy bifurcated and with incomplete patient history at our pharmacy.   It is inconceivable that you would allow this to go to a company which up to this point has not performed in a satisfactory matter when you have a woman owned business in this state (and a staunch Republican member of the Republican Congressional Committee Business Advisory Council) right here in Central Florida (Orlando).  I understand that you will be in Orlando tomorrow and I would hope that you would have a few moments to speak with me as I have been invited by Rich Crotty to attend-as a member of OCREC.  Please e-mail me concerning this.  Thank you.
N. Lois Adams

----- Original Message ----- 
From: Beatrice <mailto:beatrice@nivets.com>  
To: The A.B.L.E. Foundation, Inc. <mailto:webmaster@ablefoundation.org>  
Sent: Wednesday, December 05, 2001 9:15 AM
Subject: Re: Osceola County ABLE Center

Hello Lori,
 
Reading the first Email that was send to me. I saw that you were talking about oversees. Maybe you don't know but I am originally
from Europe. 
 

To briefly give a broad overview of the program:  The A.B.L.E. (Achieving Beyond Limited Expectations) Foundation, Inc. establishes, oversees, manages, and assists in the funding of each A.B.L.E. Center.  Strict quality control is essential to insure that our programs and services are provided in top-notch fashion.  The creation of each A.B.L.E. Center is simply a process of duplication.  The system has been developed and we are now ready to implement the creation of the Centers throughout the state in each community.  It is a very simple process to follow, but it does take commitment from the community and the families who will benefit from each Center.  So, if you are interested in helping to spear-head, so to speak, this project in YOUR community, please let us know as soon as possible.
 
so, I checkeed it up and found A.B.L.E International. that seems to be another wonderfull organization like yours.
that are helping people and I thought that you at least knew about it or maybe be part of A.B.L.E international.
You didn't tell me about NY and California I noticed. Could you please tell me?
 
God bless
 
Beatrice

----- Original Message ----- 
From: The A.B.L.E. Foundation,  <mailto:webmaster@ablefoundation.org> Inc. 
To: Beatrice <mailto:beatrice@nivets.com>  
Sent: Tuesday, December 04, 2001 6:45 PM
Subject: Re: Osceola County ABLE Center

Hi Beatrice -
 
From reading your email, I can see why so many people are emailing me with compliments about you and your commitment to help people with disabilities!  You are busy gathering information and the people who can help make this awesome A.B.L.E. Vision a reality in Osceola County!
 
Great news about the meeting room.  We'll provide the refreshments.
 
We need to reach out to parents and families with children of all ages with disabilities - adults especially, too.  Encourage people to reach out to other people they have never really stopped to talk to.  Asking people if they have heard about the A.B.L.E. Vision and how it can benefit the community is a great way to get a conversation started.  
 
To answer your questions from your other email I received today:
 
We have A.B.L.E. Centers in various stages of opening in Illinois, California, Alabama, Georgia, and New York, so far with plans to open in all 50 states and Canada.
 
As a foundation, we are automatically a not-for-profit organization.  We are fully funded.  We are a group of philanthropists who are providing the seed money and the funding for this project.
 
We have the funding and will purchase the land the Centers will be built upon.
 
We have the funding to open the centers.  We need to make sure that the communities we choose to open a center in are able to keep it open.  Our concept is unique and it is not comparable to any other program currently open anywhere in this country serving people with disabilities.
 
We are volunteers in that we are financially independent and are able to volunteer our time without worrying about compensation.  
 
We are a private board of directors.  We do not solicit board members.
 
The A.B.L.E. Vision is a gift from God.
 
Our son, Daniel, who is 23 years old, is the inspiration for the A.B.L.E. Concept.
 
Our system works because it has taken more than 10 years to research, develop, and fine tune.  It is based upon success principles that are proven to be true.  We are here to serve, we are not self-seeking, nor do we seek fame or fortune.  We have no personal agendas - this is truly a gift from God - we are simply the vessles He is using.
 
As far as the actual buildings for the A.B.L.E. Center, we have architectural drawings of the A.B.L.E. Vision.  Approdx. 10-25 acres are necessary depending upon the needs of the communities we will be serving and the extent of the programs and services we will provide.
 
It is refreshing to see that you have questions and that you are thinking about this project in depth.  Ask any question you would like - that's perfectly fine!
 
Beatrice - you are doing a great job so far gathering informatin and people together and coordinating the meeting room and date and for getting the word out.  I saw the message on the hawke list today.  
 
We are open to questions, comments, and suggestions.  We are here to serve the needs of the community.  We are NOT funded by the government or any other agency - private or public.  We are free to dream big and to make those dreams a reality - together!
 
Keep doing what you are doing.  With the news about the state funding cutbacks, people are really getting desperate for help and for programs and services.  A.B.L.E. is the answer.
 
We are NOT affiliated in any way with the ABLE trust.  That is a state agency/organization.  Our name is a acronym for Achieving Beyond Limited Expectations.  
 
We can't wait to meet you and the dynamic Osceola group!
 
Warm regards,
Lori Bennett
Ambassador of Hope

-----Original Message----- 
From: Frazer, Nat [ mailto:FrazerN@wec.ufl.edu] 
Sent: Tuesday, December 04, 2001 2:26 PM 
To: 'mvm@gnv.ifas.ufl.edu'; 'jcj@gnv.ifas.ufl.edu' 
Subject: McKay's "shotgun" comments 


FYI Several staff and faculty members in my department have stopped me in 
the hall today to express their outrage over Senator McKay's comments in the 
Gainesville Sun encouraging folks to take their shotguns into IFAS on a 
Friday after 4PM..  

1.  They resent the implication that IFAS folks do not work hard for their 
paychecks (and they are not aware that the Senator ever visited our building 
before making such a remark). 
2.  They feel that if any of them had made similar comments about the 
Florida Senate, that they would have been slammed into jail for threatening 
public officials carrying out their duties in a public building.  They want 
to know how anyone can get away with making such comments, especially in the 
wake of September 11th. 
3.  Several of the women who work on the first floor in my building  have 
said they now feel unsafe -- from crazies who might "take the hint" from 
McKay; I would not be surprized if some of my employees do take off this 
Friday and go home before 4PM. 

In the best of times, folks would be worried about losing their jobs; in 
these times of terrorism and other acts of public violence, this was an 
especially insensitive remark for a leading public official to make. 

Folks in my department have been pretty calm and fearless about all this 
budget-cut stuff -- they're pulling together, willing to endure the 
belt-tightening for the sake of the IFAS team, etc. (Several have inquired 
about the possibility of voluntary furloughs or going part time to prevent 
others from losing their jobs, etc.) But this latest cavalier comment from a 
key Florida legislator has REALLY ticked them off and contributed to a 
marked decline in morale. 

I know my staff and faculty are not alone in their feelings about this 
issue.  I assume other personnel in other departments are equally outraged. 

-- 
Nat B. Frazer, Professor and Chair 
Department of Wildlife Ecology and Conservation 
Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences 
University of Florida 
PO Box 110430 
Gainesville, FL 32611-0430 
(352) 846-0552 
FAX (352) 392-6984 
FrazerN@wec.ufl.edu

-----Original Message-----
From: SandyF5977@aol.com [mailto:SandyF5977@aol.com]
Sent: Wednesday, December 05, 2001 8:58 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Education -- State Diplomas


Dear Governor Bush: 

With more and more people choosing home school for their children, I would like to suggest a change in the Florida High School Diploma (GED) program.   Many of the home schoolers prescribe to a rigorous course of study yet they are only eligible for the GED Diploma, which to the best of my knowledge, can only be obtained by those under 18 by attending special GED classes.    The problem with this is twofold -- 1.) Many home schoolers curriculum is much more challenging than the GED classes and taking those are only a waste of time 2.) the General Studies Diploma only test for basic skills.   

My suggestion is that the state offer two different tests -- keep the General Education Diploma program with its study classes as is, and add a new test, for the more challenging curriculum and allow students 16 and older to take it so that they can continue their studies at colleges and universities when they are ready. 

Thank you for your consideration. 


Sandra M. Faulkner

may therefore be subject to public disclosure.

From: prochristi@juno.com [mailto:prochristi@juno.com]

Dear Governor Bush, 
Last May I spoke with William Large about the shocking murder of a 
preborn infant, Baby 
Baez, by the hands of Florida abortionist (and convicted felon) James 
Scott Pendergraft. 

I reported the infant's murder to the Tampa Police Department on May 11, 
2001 
 I supplied them with all of the information that I am sending to you, 
including the name and telephone 
number of eye witness John Ruiz. The police did not follow up on the 
crime. 

I am so troubled by the lack of concern and justice in this infant murder 
case. I believe that it is my duty to little Baby Baez to pursue exposing 
this kind of murder. Below you will find information regarding the murder 
of Baby Baez. I would so appreciate your help at this time. Would you 
please follow up and make efforts to see to it that this case is brought 
to the attention of those in command of the criminal justice system in 
the state of Florida? 

I would be so grateful if you would take the time to read the case as I 
have outlined below 
and get the right people involved in investigating the horrible murder of 
Baby Baez. 

Blessings, 
Patte Smith 
Orlando 
407.830.8274 
******************************** 
The Central Florida Murder of Baby Baez 

Abortionist James Scott Pendergraft instructed his Orlando staff to have 
Ms Baez meet him at his Tampa abortuary (Hyde Park Women's Center, 502 
South Magnolia) on Friday, May 11, 2001. 
In the early evening (approximately 7 pm) of May 11, abortionist 
Pendergraft inserted a needle through the abdomen of Ms Baez , who was 
between 5-6 months pregnant. The syringe contained digoxin. Using 
ultrasound, Pendergraft guided the needle into the heart of Ms Baez's 
preborn baby girl and injected digoxin. The baby's heart sped up, then 
began to slow down, and finally the infant's tiny heart stopped beating. 
Abortionist Pendergraft gave Ms Baez pills with instructions to take them 
at midnight and then again at 6 a.m. The pills would induce Ms Baez's 
body into premature labor and eventual delivery of her stillborn infant. 

Ms Baez left Hyde Park Women's Center and checked into Economy Express 
Inn, West Kennedy Blvd, Rm 108 in Tampa with her cousin John Ruiz and 
three children. As instructed by abortionist Pendergraft, Ms Baez took 
the pills she was given at midnight. 

At 5a.m. on Saturday Ms Baez began her labor in earnest. Amidst her 
screams Ms Baez's baby girl was delivered on the bathroom floor of hotel 
room 108 by her cousin John Ruiz at 6 a.m. on the morning of Saturday, 
May 12, 2001. A frightened and bewildered John Ruiz was shocked to 
discover that the baby was fully developed with a head of soft hair. Ms 
Baez saw her infant laying on her side and was faced with the perfection 
and beauty of her little daughter. John Ruiz called Hyde Park Women's 
Center and was instructed NOT to call 911 or the local hospital. 
Pendergraft employee Inga advised that she would be right over to the 
hotel. With trembling hands John wrapped his tiny niece up in towels. 
When abortion clinic worker Inga arrived she looked at the baby and said: 
"I was afraid something like this would happen. When I got the emergency 
call this morning I knew it was you. If this baby had been just 2 weeks 
older she would've been considered a preemie." 

John Ruiz strapped his two children and Ms Baez's little boy into his 
van. He placed the tiny baby girl (who was bundled in towels from Economy 
Express) onto the floor of his van. Hyde Park Women's Center employee 
Inga drove ahead to the clinic in her own vehicle. As John raced to the 
abortuary he realized that Baby Baez's body rolled from side to side on 
the floor of the van. John slowed down to prevent her body from 
continuing to roll. 

When John Ruiz, Ms Baez and the four children arrived at Hyde Park 
Women's Center, employee Inga advised John to place Baby Baez on the 
counter in the back of the abortuary. Pendergraft employee Inga proceeded 
to become physically ill, vomiting several times in an office of the 
abortuary. After Pendergraft employee Inga took some time to recover she 
proceeded to provide some kind of medical care to Ms Baez. 

John Ruiz took Ms Baez  and the three children back home to Orlando on 
the morning of May 12, 2001. 

Did Dr James Scott Pendergraft commit an illegal abortion in this case? 
What happened to the body of Baby Baez? 
Why didn't the Tampa Police investigate? 

This infanticide was reported as a murder to Tampa Police Department on 
the afternoon of May 12, 2001by Patte Smith of Orlando (407.830.8274). 
Baby Baez case number: 01-34976 
To my knowledge the body of Baby Baez was not seized by the TPD, nor was 
a 
thorough criminal investigation performed. 

John Ruiz is willing to cooperate fully in the 
investigation of this murder. 
To investigate this story please call John Ruiz: 407.238.9074 

FTI: The abortionist (and abortion clinic owner) who performed the murder 
of Baby Baez, James Scott Pendergraft, is presently serving a 46 month 
sentence in for unrelated charges (extortion). He began serving his 
sentence in August. He is in Federal Prison Camp in Atlanta. His 
registration # is 42979-018. The telephone number of the prison is 
407-635-5100.

participants overwhelmingly found each time, the status 
quo, unacceptable. We have strong beliefs that there is 
a more economical, effective way to clean up our lake, 
from this constant mess of weeds and muck. We don't like 
hearing "this new program (essentially the same process) 
will take 4-5 yrs to implement", or putting the blame on 
some other condition, while we feel they are just 
putting us of until they can retire. It is felt they are 
being well paid to do a job, that falls far from success 
in resolving our problem. We have some suggestions that 
deserve to be heard, and possibly tried, and are willing 
to bring our staff to the capital for a presentation, if 
necessary. But we certainly need a change of direction, 
that will yield RESULTS.I'm writing you this letter on 
behalf of our WHOA participants at our meeting this PM. 
Regards Stuart Barnette Director of WHOA

i want to bring to your attention to the direction (what i know is mostly rumor) that the p rule is heading.   dep had some meetings (operated by some consultants) with "interested parties" and many presentations were made and there was lots of discussion.

it seems that we are heading for a standard of 10 (wellington is not really interested in arguing this) and how the standard is measured (and wellington has no choice but to be interested in this aspect)  we made a presentation to the consultants and other parties and brought forward all the unresolved issues that have an impact on the urban areas (such things as by-pass water, where and how to measure, stuff like that) and what seems to be coming out is a system of "variances" which i believe will cause major heartburn.

From: Lois Adams [mailto:ladams@hhcs.com]
Sent: Monday, December 03, 2001 3:08 PM

Cc: yopfell@juno.com
Subject: MAIL ORDER PILOT PROGRAM FOR DIABETES


Dear Jeb.....
It is my understanding that the mail order pilot program for diabetes for patients along the I-4 corridor (Central Florida) requires that patients receive their diabetic medications and supplies through an out of state provider Health Alliance.  Not only is that an outrage for businesses within this state but that it makes no sense at all medically.- it is dangerous to the patient.  Our pharmacy presently provides medication management for the Senior Resource Alliance which includes 5 counties in Central Florida.  We monitor not only their diabetes but also the diseases which are a direct result on non-compliance,  inappropriate use of medication, failure to properly educate, etc.  And- it is at no charge to anyone including the Medicaid program. There is no way to control the health of these people with the therapy bifurcated and with incomplete patient history at our pharmacy.   It is inconceivable that you would allow this to go to a company which up to this point has not performed in a satisfactory matter when you have a woman owned business in this state (and a staunch Republican member of the Republican Congressional Committee Business Advisory Council) right here in Central Florida (Orlando).  I understand that you will be in Orlando tomorrow and I would hope that you would have a few moments to speak with me as I have been invited by Rich Crotty to attend-as a member of OCREC.  Please e-mail me concerning this.  Thank you.
N. Lois Adams

Governor - 

I think that you are right on target with your new tourism initiatives.  To

Our family in fact had two week-long vacations this year and both were 
within Florida.  I've now been to 33 different countries and over 40 states, 
but I find that Florida itself offers more than enough variety, 
entertainment and sheer vacation value.  It's like multiple states & nations 
all rolled into one. 

Except for the Inaugural Ball back in January, the next Bush Inaugural to 
come - and your two future Inaugurals... I can't think of a really good 
reason to travel beyond our borders.  *** I actually wouldn't mind making it

days of Jim Kelley), but tickets to that one aren't likely and Pasadena is 
just too far...

-----Original Message-----
From: Susan Goldstein [mailto:skgoldstein@hotmail.com]
Sent: Wednesday, December 05, 2001 10:06 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Thanks for budget crisis rescue



Dear Jeb, 
Hope all is well with you and your family.  Thank you for the consideration 
you have given to autism and the entire DD population in the special session 
and the budget crisis.  Your influence and leadership have not gone 
unnoticed. 

We have been trying to amass local dollars, both public and private, to fund 
programs for children that will suffer i.e. child care and summer programs, 
extended school year, etc.  Now is a perfect opportunity to encourage the 
local community leadership to fill in the gaps for those programs that have 
experienced cuts. 

The good new is property values are at an all time high in Broward and we 
have a new children's taxing district.   Bad news is the new council and the 
county commission feel that if they step up to the plate and fund lost 
dollars, the state will abandon their responsibility, when it is in a 
position to fund. 

Efforts have been initiated to bring their attention to these pressing 
concerns and hopefully we will be successful. The disabled population is not 
represented on the council and, as I predicted, have been left out of the 
mix. Our highly successful Inclusive Childcare Project is in trouble.  Since 
there is no special needs catagory, we structured a request around their 
guidlines in the abused and neglected category (which many become), they 
then informed us they would not accept lost dollar applications.  We have 
over 350 children in this program and a waiting list.  Your support for this 
effort with the Children's Services Council here in Broward would be greatly 
appreciated. 

Unfortunately, some have the feeling that dollars would be better spent on 
children that are not so "hopeless" and can transition into the community.  
Disabled children through no fault of their own are not being treated 
equitably in this process. 

Which brings me to this quote I wanted you to see that offended many parents 
who have fought so long in education and have the same hopes and dreams for 
their children as everyone else. 
********************************************************************** 
Quote from Chair of President Bush's Commission on Special 
Education 

Gov. Branstad (former governor of Iowa) has been appointed to serve as 
chair of the Administration's new special education commission. 

Following is a quote from Gov Branstad (Iowa) from an interview 
transcript. The entire transcript is available at: 

http://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/education/schools_1-16.html 

GOV. TERRY BRANSTAD: In our state nearly 60 percent of the budget goes 
for education. And what we find is people are willing to invest in 
quality education, but they are also fiscally conservative. They want to 
see results. They want to see achievement for the dollars that they put 
in. I think that the federal government in its mandates in the area of 
special ed has driven up costs needlessly. I think that needs to be 
reviewed. 

I want to see every child have an opportunity to learn. All special 
ed children do have a right to an education, but to spend tens 
oft thousands of dollars on kids that really are not going to be able to 
support themselves or be able to really learn a great deal at the 
expense of the general education of the rest of the students is not 
fair. 

And so that has to be addressed. A lot of people are afraid of it, 
of being, you know, accused of being insensitive or whatever. I was 
in Sioux City, Iowa, yesterday, and I heard from a Teacher of the Year, 
Nancy Mounts, who had been Teacher of the Year, and the 
superintendent there about how their school is being squeezed 
because of the federal mandates in the area of special ed and 
how there needs to be more flexibility and latitude given to local 
school districts in that area. 

******************************************************************** 


Jeb, if you ever cross paths with Governor Branstad, maybe you could mention

-----Original Message-----
From: Manzano, Jesse [mailto:jesse.manzano@myflorida.com]
Sent: Wednesday, December 05, 2001 4:20 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: Busse, Mark; Hirst, Elizabeth; Jimenez, Frank; Turbeville, Greg
Subject: New Ocala Star-Banner response



Gobernador, 

We have prepared the following extended outline for a new response to the 
Ocala Star-Banner Editorial. 


        These would be the themes for each paragraph: 

        a) Same intro: Your November 25 editorial, "On the backs of the 
vulnerable," does not paint n accurate picture of how we are striving to 
preserve essential services to our people despite the need to cut our budget 
for this fiscal year. 

        b) We are faced with tough choices, but by abiding by our 
principles, the legislators have done an outsanding job at protecting the 
budgets for our schools and for the services we provide to Florida's most 
vulnerable. Examples: our schools saw their budgets cut by only a fraction 
of the amount originally projected, from XX% to only XX% (other examples if 
available) 

        c)  However, It is important to remember that FL's budget is still 
growing and that even with the cuts made this session, we are still 
providing better services to more Floridians than at any other time in 
recent history. Economic development and tax cuts are more important today 
than ever before because they not only stimulate growth, but also help us 
fund Florida's priorities. 

        d) Thanks to the Legislature, Florida has today a balanced budget 
and enough money to stimulate its economy and protect its citizens. These 
are no small achievements, especially during a time when our nation is at 
war and we are experiencing an economic downturn.  

Please let us know if this a better approach, sir, so that we can beign to 
draft it. 

Thank you, 

Jesse MP 


  


Jesse Manzano 
Deputy Speechwriter 
Office of Governor Jeb Bush 

From:	P1509@aol.com
Sent:	Wednesday, December 5, 2001 9:01 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	THANK YOU FROM THE BOTTOM OF OUR HEARTS

Dear Governor Bush, 

Below is a copy of an email I am sending to our state legislators to thank them for protecting the funding for the developmentally disabled.  However,  we are all aware of the key role that you played in making sure that the proper action was taken to preserve the very livelihood of these special needs Floridians.   

The Family Care Council of District 7,  Orlando,  would just like to thank you again for your continued interest and support. 

Dean Parker, Co-Chair, 
Family Care Council,  District 7,  Orlando 

Dear Senator/Represetative, 

As advocates for the developmentally disabled, our most vulnerable Floridians,  our heartfelt thanks go out to you and your fellow legislators who took the time to take our phone calls,  read our emails, listen to us in face to face conversations, and then acted to preserve most of the funding that is so critical to this population.   

Responsible legislation of Florida's citizens tax contributions has moved our state to the forefront as a leader in caring for those who cannot care for themselves.  In one of the most trying budgeting sessions in memory,  you and your counterparts have withstood the pressures from many directions, and have determined those most needy and protected them.  For this we will forever be thankful.  As I am sure you understand,  we will continue to call on you as our elected officials to keep the developmentally disabled as a top priority when making funding decisions. 

Once again,  thanks so much for your support and you can depend on ours as we move into the future together. 

Respectfully, 


Dean Parker,  Co-Chair, 
Family Care Council,  District 7 
Orlando

From: Slusher, James Ed (Slushco) [mailto:slushej@dms.state.fl.us]
Sent: Wednesday, December 05, 2001 3:08 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Request



Governor Bush, 

I am the guy who back before you ran for office, sent you a letter, that I 
supported you, I believed in you and when the day came, I voted for you. 
Then later, when you went into office, you allowed me to bring my boy and 
wife over and have our picture taken.  When you implimented making 
modifications to the career service system, I sent you a letter that I 
backed you and you sent it back to me, with your signature and a thank you. 
And for the last 4 years, the department I work for, began to be sunset, and 
tho I knew I would loose my job, I supported you.  On Friday November 30, I 
issued the last State Building Permit, So now I have to try and find myself 
another job.  

Now that the position that I have done for the entire state has been done 
away with and a guy like myself will be required for each of the indivual 
counties and municipalities, I have found a job at Florida State University, 
where I will be able to continue to do what I have done, and bring with me 
what I have learned to a Dept. that does not have a clue as to the 
permitting and building inspection process.  I would like to ask if you 
would help me to obtain the position as building inspector for the States 
University Systems New Inspection and Permitting program.  

The person that is doing the hiring at FSU is Mr. Tom Deckert, who is FSU's 
New Building Code Administrator.  Mr. Deckerts Phone number is (850) 
644-7686, and his e-mail is: tdeckert@admin.fsu.edu. 

If it not to much, I would appreciate a vote of confidence from you to Mr. 
Deckert.  If I am out of line by asking this, and you would not feel right 
doing so, then that is no problem also.  

Reguardless of my future, be it with FSU or with another firm or agency, I 
assure you that I will continue to support you and back that promise up with 
my vote. 

May the Great God Bless you abundantly as he has myself. 

Sincerely, 
James Ed. Slusher 
State Building Inspector

-----Original Message-----
From: Munson, Greg [mailto:greg.munson@myflorida.com]
Sent: Wednesday, December 05, 2001 2:20 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: Berger, Wendy; Canady, Charles T.; Ferrera, Eli
Subject: Win of Removal Action against Avant Brown, Glades County Commissioner



Governor, 
You may recall suspending Mr. Brown after he was charged with sexual battery 
and aggravated battery (both felonies) for attacking his girlfriend in 
January.  He was the man that shoved dirt down the victim's throat and 
digitally penetrated the victim's vagina.  The State Attorney's Office 
accepted a plea to a misdemeanor battery charge in July, but you agreed to 
leave the suspension order in effect based on our belief that Mr. Brown had, 
in fact, committed a felony.  (As you know, you can suspend county officers 
if they commit a felony but not if they commit a misdemeanor.)  Wendy and I 
were prepared for a trial on Monday, held before the Senate's special 
master,  to prove the felony charges and get Mr. Brown permanently removed 
from office.  

Today, Mr. Brown resigned his position.  He recently got a copy of all the 
evidence that Wendy and I planned to present, and many people (including the 
victim) received subpoenas this week for the trial.  I believe he finally 
realized the strength of our case and decided not to have all the dirty 
laundry aired at a public trial.  On your behalf, we filed an Executive 
Order today officially declaring his seat vacant. 

The State Attorney's Office has asked local law enforcement to make extra 
patrols by the residence of Mr. Brown and the victim to respond to any 
domestic violence that might arise from the resignation.  One of the reasons 
the victim did not want to cooperate was because of Mr. Brown's position as 
a County Commissioner.  If there is more violence, perhaps she will be more 
likely to cooperate since he is no longer a County Commissioner.

Back in the beginning of the summer I asked you for some PR Quotes that we could use for Microsoft's, Cisco's, etc Press Releases on American Education Association and how it is a win win for Children, Parents, Teachers, Schools, and America. Colleen was enthusiastic and said that she would get some wordage from you, education, and several other people. That never happened. I spoke to her on the phone, I have had an ongoing email dialog with her (once every 6 weeks or so) including about 2 weeks ago.

When we last corresponded she was now negative and wasn't sure if she could do anything. I ask her if she would like a copy of the email that you sent to me and copied to John Winn and she said no.

I know this is long winded but could you please intervene with a quick note to someone. We are launching and will be heading for Florida in the first quarter of next year. 

As a reminder:



*	American Education Association (AmEdu) supplies money in the form of technology to schools at no cost. 

*	The trickle-down also supplies the poorest of the poor schools as well. 

*	The money it supplies to schools can be used for matching fund grants and e-rate equipment. 

*	As little as 500 interested parents in a school puts $90,000.00 into a school for technology immediately, and at no cost to the parents or the schools. (Patent pending) (500 parents is an example there is no minimum requirement. 50 parents would equal $9,000.00 (about 10 brand new PC's with software) 

*	On the National scope supplying schools with a billion dollars a year in technology within the next 2 or 3 years is obtainable (at about 8% of our market), with no additional cost to anyone.

DEP 
. Bruce Ritchie, Tallahassee Democrat, re: interviewing Sec. Struhs. Scaled 
back the time needed considerably -- approximately 1 hour -- but still wants 
that 1/2 day w/ the photographer. Claims he wants to do a profile story, but 
when I asked for specific questions he had none. He said topics of interest 
are: Increased enforcement activity (specifically St. Mark's refinery -- of 
which he was critical); ACF; DEPs enforcement record; Mary Jean Yon and 
problems in Escambia.  Told him that I would pass this information along and 
get back with him if scheduling an interview is possible. However, told him 
that IF we agreed to this interview at all, the MOST he would get is a half 
hour and it's no dice with the photog. 

2. Ron Matus, Gainesville Sun called water resources management directly, 
re: 
arsenic-contaminated drinking water wells.Why has DEP offered assistance to 
connect Wimberly Estates (Gainesville)residences to GRU public water system? 
How soon will the connections be made? 
summary: 
I explained that since EPA has decided to reduce the drinking water standard 
for arsenic from 50 ppb to 10 ppb, we decided to proceed with assisting the 
Wimberly Estates residents that have drinking water wells containing more 
than 10 ppb arsenic. I said that once the residents return our applications 
for assistance, the purchase order for the connections could be issued to 
GRU 
within a few days, but I was uncertain how long it would take for GRU to 
construct the water line extension and install the water meters. 

3. Debbie Salamone, Orlando Sentinel, 407-420-5456; re: called to talk to 
Karl Kurka about Blue Springs. 
Needs to discuss the whole MSL issue; may need to make a public records 
request on some documents. (note: e-mailed Karl to talk w/ me first as we 
may 
want to do a conference call with Debbie) 


LOTTERY 
Matt Boody, Augusta, Ga. Chronicle--wanted list of Florida Lottery 
retailers on the Georgia and Alabama border.  Mr. Boody plans on calling 
them as he researches a story on the new S. C. Lottery and comparing 
potential impact to Georgia lottery retailers similar to when Georgia 
started their lottery in 1995 had on the Florida Lottery. 

DOEA 
We were contacted by Tait Trussell of the Orlando Sentinel Lake County 
edition on info about our frailty levels, funding and services for Lake 
County. We are preparing a response. 

We received a request for a radio interview with Faye Leavitt of Tampa's The 
Great Age radio show. I am contact Faye and Jack Leavitt to see what type of 
interview they are interested in doing. 

DJJ 
Greg Martin, Charlotte Sun, (941) 225-8131, seeking information regarding 
DJJ budget cuts and whether or not cuts would impact the G Pierce Wood 
project.  Responses:  # of beds to come on line:  254; # of staff to be 
employed:  428 (of which 161 are already hired); timeframes for hiring: 161 
already hired; and for the remaining positions, the vast majority of 
effective hire dates will be in January and February 2002; timeframes for 
opening the DJJ Programs: 130 beds are targeted for opening in February 2002 
--124 beds are targeted for opening in April 2002; number of GPW buildings 
DJJ will occupy: 19.  Also asked total positions cut: 660; current GR 
budget: $578 million; GR cut: $60.5 million; percent of cut: 9.1%; total 
including trust: $669 million; % cut 7.6%.  Wanted to know how DJJ could 
continue to meet mission -- discussed share sacrifices; focus on public 
safety, etc.  Request comment from Secretary.  Explained Secretary's tight 
schedule and said that I would make the request. 

Erin Thomas, Florida Public Radio, Gainesville, (352) 392-5212, asked 
questions regarding the news story in the Ocala Star Banner about an 
incident at Marion Youth Development.  Responded that there had been an 
incident reported, that it was under investigation and faxed a copy of the 
redacted incident report.  Wanted to know if staff abusing youth was common. 
Explained that juveniles were encouraged to report and thing they felt was 
not appropriate those reports were reviewed and investigated.  Explained 
staff training in restraint techniques. 

David Twiddy, Tallahassee Democrat, (850) 509-5812, informed him that his 
request to send a photographer to Tallahassee AMI Impact program had been 
approved contingent on protection of the confidentiality of youth. 

Andie Atwater, Ft. Meyers News Press, (941) 335-0410, called and left voice 
mail. Phone call was returned twice to her voice mail. 

Denes Husty, Ft. Meyers News Press, (941) 992-1345, wanted to know standard 
process for youth arrested.  Explained process.  Was concerned because a 
judge has "sentenced youth to 21 days in secure detention and then release 
to the mother" prior to trial on January 3.  (21 days expire on December 26) 
Explained that the youth had been remanded to secure detention for 21 days 
-- the max allowed by law.  He asked about charging youth as adults and I 
explained that the decision was one the prosecutor would need to make. 
Questions were all in reference to youth setting their home on fire in the 
Ft. Meyers area.  Declined to addressed the specifics and only provided 
information regarding the general process. 

Joe Falick, Tampa Tribune, (850) 222-8382, seeking a phone number or a way 
to contact a DJJ employee who worked in Tampa.  Said that the employee had 
called and left a message for him, however, the number was not correct.  Did 
not find the employee listed in DJJs directory. 

Rick Cundiff, Ocala Star-Banner, 352-867-4130 wanted amount and copy of 
contract with provider, Career Systems, of Marion Youth Development Center 
(gave him amount, $8,653,500 for 3-year contract for 104 beds; obtained copy 
of contract that he will make arrangements to pick up) 

Valerie Lacy, TV 20 WCJB of Gainesville, Ocala bureau, 352-368-2020, wanted 
copy of DJJ's IG incident report on alleged youth beating at Marion Youth 
Development Center. (provided to her) Also has filed public record request 
for all incident reports within the past year at same program. (will begin 
to process request 

DOH 
CN-Morrill, Children's Forum Magazine, requesting live birth and SIDS data 
for 1997 and 2000. 

Stephanie Erickson, Orlando Sentinel, any cases of flu in Florida yet? Yes, 
8 cases. 

Lawrence Goodman, Pause Magazine, a magazine for people with HIV/AIDS, about 
AIDS Drug Assistance Program in Florida. 


Mark Hollis, Ft. Lauderdale Sun-Sentinel, Tally, Tobacco cuts and their 
impact on the program.

From:	David Bundy <David.Bundy@chsfl.org>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 5, 2001 5:23 PM
To:	Jeb Bush

Dear Governor Bush: 


We are writing to you in keeping with a discussion that we had in your 
office last year.  We had met with you regarding the process of implementing 
community-based care, and you had requested at that time that we let you 
know of issues that needed to be addressed to keep the implementation on 
track. 

An extremely important issue has come to our attention as we move forward 
with implementing comunity-based care projects in additional communities 
(Daytona Beach, Tampa, Pensacola and Palm Beach).  Private providers are 
currently being required to secure a performance bond equal to 25% of the 
community-based care contracts.  There are a number of detrimental impacts 
of this requrement.  They include: 

        1.  The costs of securing the bond.   The lead agencies are being 
asked to secure and pay for the bonds.  The cost of the bonds is 
approximately $15 per $1,000 of coverage, which would create $1.5 million of 
costs being diverted from service provision (based on $400 million) of CBC 
contracts. 

        2.  Many CBC systems are being developed using separately 
incorporated entities.  They are unable to secure the performance bonds and 
the bonds are only attainable when a third party provides a guarantee for 
the bond.  The bonding companies are requiring guarantees from 
community-based agencies against their limited assets. 

        3.  With agency assets pledged against the bonds we are concerned 
about the mpact on our ability to continue to raise funds privately if a 
donor feels that their contribution could be lost. 

While we understand the state's need for some form of protection against the 
default of the CBC initiative, the current requirements will dramatically 
limit the ability of community-based agencies to assume the lead agency 
role.  Strong participation of experienced community-based agencies is 
essential to successfully complete the vision of community-based care. 

We would be happy to meet with you or a member of your staff to discuss this 
issue further. 

Thank you very much for your attention to this matter. 



David A. Bundy 
President/CEO 
Children's Home Society of Florida 
1485 S. Semoran Blvd., Suite 1448 
Winter Park, FL  32792 


Howard Olshansky 
CEO 
Children's Place at Homesafe 
2309 Ponce de Leon Avenue 
West Palm Beach, FL  33407 


Gary Bembry 
Chief Financial Officer 
Lakeview Mental Health 
1221 W. Lakeview Avenue 
Pensacola, FL  32501

From:	Manzano, Jesse <jesse.manzano@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 5, 2001 4:20 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	Busse, Mark; Hirst, Elizabeth; Jimenez, Frank; Turbeville, Greg
Subject:	New Ocala Star-Banner response

Gobernador, 

We have prepared the following extended outline for a new response to the 
Ocala Star-Banner Editorial. 


        These would be the themes for each paragraph: 

        a) Same intro: Your November 25 editorial, "On the backs of the 
vulnerable," does not paint n accurate picture of how we are striving to 
preserve essential services to our people despite the need to cut our budget 
for this fiscal year. 

        b) We are faced with tough choices, but by abiding by our 
principles, the legislators have done an outsanding job at protecting the 
budgets for our schools and for the services we provide to Florida's most 
vulnerable. Examples: our schools saw their budgets cut by only a fraction 
of the amount originally projected, from XX% to only XX% (other examples if 
available) 

        c)  However, It is important to remember that FL's budget is still 
growing and that even with the cuts made this session, we are still 
providing better services to more Floridians than at any other time in 
recent history. Economic development and tax cuts are more important today 
than ever before because they not only stimulate growth, but also help us 
fund Florida's priorities. 

        d) Thanks to the Legislature, Florida has today a balanced budget 
and enough money to stimulate its economy and protect its citizens. These 
are no small achievements, especially during a time when our nation is at 
war and we are experiencing an economic downturn.  

Please let us know if this a better approach, sir, so that we can beign to 
draft it. 

Thank you, 

Jesse MP 


  


Jesse Manzano 
Deputy Speechwriter 
Office of Governor Jeb Bush

From:	Audubon of Florida <advocacy@audubonofflorida.org>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 5, 2001 4:18 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Audubon of Florida On-line Advocacy Center Launched!

Hi Jeb, 

Audubon of Florida On-line Advocacy Center Launched! 
http://ga1.org/natureadvocate/home.html 

I am pleased to announce the launch of our new on-line Advocacy Center. As a friend, supporter, and/or advocate in either the Florida Conservation or Everglades Conservation Network, you have been automatically added as a participant in our new on-line Advocacy Center. Your participation preferences have not changed and you can continue to choose to participate in either citizen advocacy network or both. 

We have upgraded our communication abilities and you will find this new web based advocacy technology easy to use and effective for communicating with decision-makers and keeping track of what, when, and to whom communications are sent.  As part of our Advocacy Center you have your own "Activist" web page to keep track of the following:

1. Your contact information- email/address changes, how you like to receive electronic mail [html (like a web page) or text]

2. What Audubon campaigns you have participated in 
3. When you participated in each campaign 
4. Learn what the result of your participation was, track how a campaign is going 
5. Look up your elected officials 
6. Additional advocacy resources for each campaign issue 

To take advantage of this effective advocacy tool, log-in to the site below and access the Advocacy Center. Initially, you will need to obtain a password to take full advantage of your Advocacy Center's features: 

SINCE YOU HAVE ALREADY BEEN AUTOMATICALLY SIGNED UP FOR THE NEW ADVOCACY CENTER CLICK ON "FORGOT YOUR PASSWORD?" TO GET STARTED. 

http://ga1.org/natureadvocate/home.html 

Thanks for participating! 

Shannon Mayorga 
Conservation Associate 
Audubon of Florida 
800-753-5499 
http://www.audubonofflorida.org

Governor Bush, 

I am the guy who back before you ran for office, sent you a letter, that I 
supported you, I believed in you and when the day came, I voted for you. 
Then later, when you went into office, you allowed me to bring my boy and 
wife over and have our picture taken.  When you implimented making 
modifications to the career service system, I sent you a letter that I 
backed you and you sent it back to me, with your signature and a thank you. 
And for the last 4 years, the department I work for, began to be sunset, and 
tho I knew I would loose my job, I supported you.  On Friday November 30, I 
issued the last State Building Permit, So now I have to try and find myself 
another job.  

Now that the position that I have done for the entire state has been done 
away with and a guy like myself will be required for each of the indivual 
counties and municipalities, I have found a job at Florida State University, 
where I will be able to continue to do what I have done, and bring with me 
what I have learned to a Dept. that does not have a clue as to the 
permitting and building inspection process.  I would like to ask if you 
would help me to obtain the position as building inspector for the States 
University Systems New Inspection and Permitting program.  

The person that is doing the hiring at FSU is Mr. Tom Deckert, who is FSU's 
New Building Code Administrator.  Mr. Deckerts Phone number is (850) 
644-7686, and his e-mail is: tdeckert@admin.fsu.edu. 

If it not to much, I would appreciate a vote of confidence from you to Mr. 
Deckert.  If I am out of line by asking this, and you would not feel right 
doing so, then that is no problem also.  

Reguardless of my future, be it with FSU or with another firm or agency, I 
assure you that I will continue to support you and back that promise up with 
my vote. 

May the Great God Bless you abundantly as he has myself. 

Sincerely,

Subject:	RE: George Lewis

In fact, he sent the evidence to the lab on 2 separate occasions in hopes of getting some results.  Nothing was found either time.  I gave this information to Mr. Gott and told him if he was in possession of DNA results exonerating George Lewis, he should contact the State Attorney's Office asap.
 
Wendy

Governor, 
You may recall suspending Mr. Brown after he was charged with sexual battery 
and aggravated battery (both felonies) for attacking his girlfriend in 
January.  He was the man that shoved dirt down the victim's throat and 
digitally penetrated the victim's vagina.  The State Attorney's Office 
accepted a plea to a misdemeanor battery charge in July, but you agreed to 
leave the suspension order in effect based on our belief that Mr. Brown had, 
in fact, committed a felony.  (As you know, you can suspend county officers 
if they commit a felony but not if they commit a misdemeanor.)  Wendy and I 
were prepared for a trial on Monday, held before the Senate's special 
master,  to prove the felony charges and get Mr. Brown permanently removed 
from office.  

Today, Mr. Brown resigned his position.  He recently got a copy of all the 
evidence that Wendy and I planned to present, and many people (including the 
victim) received subpoenas this week for the trial.  I believe he finally 
realized the strength of our case and decided not to have all the dirty 
laundry aired at a public trial.  On your behalf, we filed an Executive 
Order today officially declaring his seat vacant. 

The State Attorney's Office has asked local law enforcement to make extra 
patrols by the residence of Mr. Brown and the victim to respond to any 
domestic violence that might arise from the resignation.  One of the reasons 
the victim did not want to cooperate was because of Mr. Brown's position as 
a County Commissioner.  If there is more violence, perhaps she will be more 
likely to cooperate since he is no longer a County Commissioner.

-----Original Message----- 
From: Fred Dickinson [ mailto:Dickinson.Fred@hsmv.state.fl.us] 
Sent: Tuesday, December 04, 2001 8:38 AM 
To: Jeb Bush 
Subject: RE: Issuing Driver's Licenses to people holding Visas about 
toexpire 



Per our Driver License Strategic Plan filed with the Florida Department of 
Law Enforcement, one of our tasks to aid in the state's efforts to 
strengthen domestic security is to begin limiting the duration of driver 
licenses to the duration of pertinent Immigration and Naturalization Service 
documents.  

The computer software modifications we began in mid-November to accomplish 
this procedural change have just been completed.  The first test of this 
rollout began yesterday at our Pembroke Pines driver license office and all 
went well.  We will phase-in all other driver license offices over the next 
two weeks and anticipate completing the rollout by December 15, 2001.  

If you have any questions, please let me know. 

Fred Dickinson 


>>> "Jeb Bush" <jeb@jeb.org> 12/01/01 12:59PM >>> 
Re: Issuing Driver's Licenses to people holding Visas about to expireThank 
you for writing. We have changed the procedure to make the visa expiration 
date be the same as the drivers license date. I will check to see why the 
motor vehicle offices are not complying with the change. Thank you for 
bringing this to my attention. 

Jeb Bush

regarding state business are public records available to the

that VISIT FLORIDA is tasked to accomplish.

local CVBs to senior private sector execs).  The marketing committee is led 
by the VP of Seaworld for Marketing.  As well, the Chair of VISIT FLORIDA is

annually.  I believe Fahlgren was the selected proposal, but they were 
definately not a shoe-in.

to get Florida back on track.  Respectfully said, it should not be about 
Fahlgren, but about all of us and what can we do to make a difference to the 
state--whether with VISIT FLORIDA or not.

-----Original Message----- 
From: PB@GRBnet.com [ mailto:PB@GRBnet.com] 
Sent: Wednesday, December 05, 2001 10:36 AM 
To: Pamella Dana (E-mail) 
Cc: Jeb Bush (E-mail) 
Subject: Yesterday in Orlando, President Bush said, "I hate the 
bureaucracy." 


Dear Pamella Dana: 

   As you may recall, my agency has expended considerable effort and time 
attempting to help the State of Florida jumpstart its tourism business. 

   Results: 0. 

   While our ideas have been warmly embraced by the marketing staff at 
FLAUSA, we have encountered the sternest and stiffest bureaucratic 
resistance imaginable from the higher-ups, who apparently don't want to be 
bothered with anyone or anything that might possibly upset the status quo. 

   Yesterday in Orlando, President Bush said, "I hate the bureaucracy."  He 
was referring to the plight of a small businessman whose SBA application had 
gotten lost in the quagmire of Washington red tape.  That quagmire exists 
everywhere, including Tallahassee. 

    Elected representatives are keenly sensitive to the needs and opinions 
of their constituents.  Appointed officials less so.  Tenured bureaucrats 
hardly at all.  The latter are concerned primarily with their own 
perquisites, powers, protocols, procedural niceties and personal position in 
the political pecking order. 

   Sadly, there is really only one effective way to influence any 
bureaucracy - other than appeal directly in person, on-air, to The President 
of The United States. 

   Tomorrow morning we email and mail the following to every newspaper, wire 
service, radio & TV news department in Florida.  Since you have been 
reasonably up and up with me, I'm giving you the courtesy of a first FYI: 

_______ 

Anyone in who works in Florida's tourism industry should know that the 
$20,000,000  emergency marketing fund voted on yesterday by the legislature 
may or may not  be spent on ads that actually bring tourists to Florida.  It 
all depends... 

According to the marketing department of FLAUSA, the quasi-governmental 
marketing co-coordinator for the Department of Tourism, every dollar in 
state funds must be matched by a dollar or more in corporate funds. 

So the state's agency of record, Fahlgren & Geiger in Tampa, must first sell 
their creative ideas to co-op sponsors such as Holiday Inns, Budget Rent a 
Car, and Delta Airlines.  If Fahlgren is successful they, and they alone, 
get $20 million + $20 million in windfall billings. 

But what if corporate sponsors are tapped out?  What if they don't 
particularly care for Fahlgren's jingles or TV spots?  Then nothing could 
happen.  According to FLAUSA's rules, no other marketing, advertising and 
promotional firms are allowed to contact, present ideas to, and solicit 
co-op funding from anyone on Fahlgren's proprietary list of corporate 
contacts. 

Fahlgren won the state's business fair and square - during peacetime when 
tourism was booming and just about any ad could get people to fly or drive 
here.  Today we're in a war and a recession.  The stakes are huge.  There's 
no guarantee that Fahlgren can attract $20,000,000 in co-op dollars, or that 
their ideas, and theirs alone, will motivate terrified tourists in Georgia, 
New York to Toronto to come back to Florida. 

Florida can't afford to bet its entire tourism industry on one ad agency. 

The Department of Tourism should immediately issue an RFP to all ad agencies 
and marketing firms in the state; invite everyone to Tallahassee in 30 days; 
give everyone a chance to pitch their ideas to all the corporate marketing 
directors and tourism officials - all at once. 

We want tourists to vote for Florida's best with their dollars.  Why 
shouldn't't corporate sponsors be given the same opportunity? 

_______ 

    Do I expect anything good to come out of this for The Burkhard Agency? 
Not really.  We've already been ushered in the front and out the back door. 
But.... 

    When I was growing up in Massachusetts, one of my neighbors down the 
street kept chickens. 
Teddy Wheeler and I used to sneak into the coop late and night and blow a 
whistle as loud as we could. 

     It was sorta fun to watch what happened next. 



Peter A. Burkhard 
President & Creative Director 
The Burkhard Agency, Inc. 
37 North Orange Avenue 
Suite 760 
Orlando, FL 32801 
(407) 895-3092 
FAX:  896-3123 
peterb@burkhardagency.com 
www.burkhardagency.com 
Advertising One-on-One 

From:	Nina Oviedo <oviedon@sso.org>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 5, 2001 1:54 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	Melissa Freedman; Brewser Brown; Brian Yablonski; Frank R. Jimenez; Kathleen Shanahan
Subject:	GOVERNORS' ONLY CALL---ESEA

Governor----------There was a Governors only call with the WH this morning.  I covered for the office.  It was a quick call.  
 
The WH updated Govs on education legislation.  Theyre hoping to get Govs to call delegation members and urge them to pass ESEA before Congress goes home for Christmas.
 
The bill as currently conferenced has a 38% increase in the programs for No child left behind; a 16% increase in IDEA; and 21% overall increase in ESEA.  The bill also provides greater, enhanced flexibility to the states.
 
Very few questions were askedactually 2:
 
*	If a state has already developed tests, will the current tests be allowed under the legislation?           WH responded that provided the tests meet the standards, they will be allowed.
 
*	Is the Administration keeping track of the dollars sent directly to the districts?        WH responded that it would be difficult given that there are dollars provided to the districts in almost all titles of ESEA.  But, the WH will contact the Sec of Educ to see if some tracking system could be established.
 
I later followed up with a phone call to the WH to clarify that the bill contains language reimbursing those states that have already developed standards and tests----  providing states dollars to develop tests is not the same as reimbursements.  They assured us that the dollars are indeed flowing to states that have already developed tests.  $3m will come our way and some additional amount will be provided based on a formula of population and poverty.
 
I asked Melissa to follow up with Congressional staff and make sure the language stays in.
 
WH also urged communicating with delegations in support of TPA; and, there may be another Governors only call on Thurs or Friday with Mark Weinberger, Asst Sec, Treasury, re economic stimuli.  (One Governor immediately talked about the costs to states on current economic stimulus proposals.)
 
Nina.
From:	Langston, Don <Don.Langston@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 5, 2001 1:42 PM
To:	Jeb Bush; Brogan, Frank; Shanahan, Kathleen; Yablonski, Brian; Jimenez, Frank; Baur, Katie; Arduin, Donna; Turbeville, Greg
Cc:	OPB Finance and Economic Analysis
Subject:	Business Groups--Economic Survey Results

This is a report on the results of the eighth week of economic surveys conducted by the Florida Retail Federation, National Federation of Independent Business, Associated Industries of Florida, the Florida Chamber of Commerce, and the Florida Hotel and Motel Association.  We have not reported the survey results in over a month because of some data collection problems.  The surveys will continue through the end of December.

For the four weeks ending November 26, the survey results across all industry groups show stability in sales and employment (compared to the same period last year).  Conditions do not seem to be getting noticeably worse or better right now. For sales compared to the same week last year, 40% of respondents indicated that they had lower sales, compared to 42% a month ago.  The negative responses for employment (26% of respondents) are about the same as the 24% recorded a month ago.  

On the upside, though, responses regarding the economic outlook have improved some.    

The occupancy survey results below show there has been some recent improvement in occupancy rates in central Florida, but occupancy rates and average daily room rates across the state are still significantly below last year's levels.  The FHMA also reports an improving outlook in the industry though current conditions are not good.

Don: 
We saw some improvement on Thanksgiving week, although not as much as we would have wished, particularly in South Florida where rates remain very depressed. This week's results are: 

1) Sales indicators: 
NORTH FLORIDA: 
Week ending Sept. 16 - Occupancy down 26% and average daily rate (ADR) unchanged. 
Week ending Sept. 23 - Occupancy down 15% and ADR down 5%. 
Week ending Sept. 30 - Occupancy down 12% and ADR down 4%. 
Week ending Oct. 7 - Occupancy down 17% and ADR down 9% 
Week ending Oct. 14 - Occupancy down 21% and ADR down 8% 
Week ending Oct. 21 - Occupancy down 27% and ADR down 8% 
Week ending Oct. 28 - Occupancy down 18% and ADR up 2% 
Week ending Nov. 4 - Occupancy down 12% and ADR down 18% 
Week ending Nov.11 - Occupancy down 7% and ADR down 8% 
Week ending Nov. 18 - Occupancy down 17% and ADR down 7% 
Week ending Nov. 25 - Occupancy down 16% and ADR down 3% 
CENTRAL FLORIDA: 
Week ending Sept. 16 - Occupancy down 35% and ADR down 18% 
Week ending Sept. 23 - Occupancy down 48% and ADR down 30% 
Week ending Sept. 30 - Occupancy down 40% and ADR down 22% 
Week ending Oct. 7 - Occupancy down 32% and ADR down 17% 
Week ending Oct. 14 - Occupancy down 23% and ADR down 19% 
Week ending Oct. 21 - Occupancy down 22% and ADR down 12% 
Week ending Oct. 28 - Occupancy down 20% and ADR down 11% 
Week ending Nov. 4 - Occupancy down 22% and ADR down 8% 
Week ending Nov.11 - Occupancy down 20% and ADR down 15% 
Week ending Nov. 18 - Occupancy down 15% and ADR down 14% 
Week ending Nov. 25 - Occupancy down 12% and ADR down 9% 
WEST FLORIDA: 
Week ending Sept. 16 - Occupancy down 42% and ADR down 8% 
Week ending Sept. 23 - Occupancy down 39% and ADR down 15% 
Week ending Sept. 30 - Occupancy down 29% and ADR down 10% 
Week Ending Oct. 7 - Occupancy down 19% and ADR down 5% 
Week ending Oct. 14 - Occupancy down 17% and ADR down 3% 
Week ending Oct. 21 - Occupancy down 19% and ADR down 4% 
Week ending Oct. 28 - Occupancy down 23% and ADR down 4% 
Week ending Nov. 4 - Occupancy down 21% and ADR up 5% 
Week ending Nov.11 - Occupancy down 18% and ADR down 3% 
Week ending Nov. 18 - Occupancy down 17% and ADR down 7% 
Week ending Nov. 25 - Occupancy down 18% and ADR down 2%

Week ending Sept. 23 - Occupancy down 52% and ADR down 11%
