Week ending Nov.11 - Occupancy down 18% and ADR down 4% 
Week ending Nov. 18 - Occupancy down 28% and ADR down 15% 
Week ending Nov. 25 - Occupancy down 22% and ADR down 16% 
2) Statewide, payrolls REMAIN LOWER, and have now been reduced an estimated 23% statewide. 
3) Advance bookings for the next 90 days remain LOWER by about 9% statewide, but are improving. 
4) The outlook for the next 6 months to a year remains WORSE, but is improving (estimated down by 5%). 
Gary Smith 
Executive Vice President 
Florida Hotel & Motel Association 

From:	Audubon of Florida <advocacy@audubonofflorida.org>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 5, 2001 1:30 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Jeb, Help us Protect Florida's Bays and Estuaries!

Dear Jeb, 

Proposed Development Threatens Florida Bays and Estuaries! 
Cape Canaveral Hospital Project threatens Indian River 
Aquatic Preserve, a designated Outstanding Florida 
Waterway.  

You can take action on this alert either via email 
(please see directions below) or via the web at: 
http://ga1.org/campaign/flbays_estuaries/wsd5s21bw6 

Visit the web site below and tell your friends to take 
action on this important campaign! 
http://ga1.org/campaign/flbays_estuaries/forward/wsd5s21bw6 

We encourage you to take action by January 1, 2002 

Protect Florida's Bays and Estuaries! 

---------------------- 

Proposed Development Threatens Florida Bays and Estuaries! 
  
Destructive "in-fill" project threatens Indian River 
Aquatic Preserve, a designated Outstanding Florida 
Waterway. 

---------------------- 

INSTRUCTIONS TO RESPOND VIA THE WEB: 
If you have access to a web browser, you can take action 
on this alert by going to the following URL: 

http://ga1.org/campaign/flbays_estuaries/wsd5s21bw6  

INSTRUCTIONS TO RESPOND VIA EMAIL: 
Just choose the "reply to sender" option on your email 
program, and edit the letter below as you wish. Do 
not delete "-YOU MAY EDIT THE LETTER BELOW-" and "-END 
OF LETTER-". Please do not add your name and address 
to your letter. Our system automatically does this 
for you.  

We STRONGLY encourage you to make edits directly to 
our sample letter below, and put the alert talking 
points into your own words. An individualized letter 
is worth ten computer generated letters. Of course, 
hundreds of unedited letters will still create a large 
impact, so please reply even if you don't have time 
to personalize the letter. 

Your letter will be addressed and sent to: 
Secretary David Struhs 
  

-------YOU MAY EDIT THE LETTER BELOW--------- 

I am writing to urge you to recommend that the Governor 
and Cabinet deny the request of Cape Canaveral Hospital 
/Health First Inc. to engage in a submerged land exchange 
that would allow it to fill in fragile Aquatic Preserve 
areas surrounding Cape Canaveral Hospital. The proposed 
"open water fill" in a Florida estuary, Aquatic Preserve, 
Outstanding Florida Waters area, would constitute a 
major reversal of state policy that has protected our 
bays and estuaries for over 30 years.  

The proposed state land exchange is of little functional 
value to the public and certainly does not justify 
a decision resulting in filling 8.8 acres of the Banana 
River, within the Indian River Aquatic Preserve. The 
likelihood that Cape Canaveral Hospital/Health First 
Inc. could ever obtain permits to develop the 37 acres 
of areas covered by heavy sea grass is slim, and therefore, 
the "trade" is not worth considering.  

Cape Canaveral Hospital/Health First Inc. is NOT in 
a "hardship" situation. This massive health care organization 
maintains at least 4 major hospital or health care 
campuses in Brevard County. The size of its 11 acre 
fill pad at Cape Canaveral Hospital in the Banana River 
does NOT limit its capability to deliver countywide 
health care services; it can simply provide them at 
one of its other many locations. Further, Health First, 
Inc. owns substantial vacant property nearby in Brevard 
County, and the City of Cocoa Beach. 

Even on the 11-acre fill pad at Cape Canaveral Hospital 
itself, there are substantial opportunities to locate 
additional facilities WITHOUT placing any more fill 
in the river. Much of the space on this site is used 
in a very inefficient manner, including large areas 
of unused paved parking. If this site were more efficiently 
utilized, much if not all of the expansion proposed 
by Health First, Inc. could be accomplished without 
filling the Banana River. 

It is highly questionable for the state to support 
expansion of a health care facility on a low-lying 
island in the middle of the Banana River. This site 
would be subject to massive storm surges in the event 
of a major hurricane impacting this portion of the 
Brevard County coastline. While successful evacuation 
of the patents and workers at this facility might be 
possible in advance of a storm event, the inevitable 
damage to the health care facility itself would represent 
huge financial loss to the community, not to mention 
interruption of health care services. The state should 
not make a decision, which encourages or facilitates 
the further expansion of a health care facility at 
this obviously dangerous, and inappropriate location. 
  

-------END OF LETTER------------------------- 

Sincerely yours, 

Jeb Bush 
  

If you would like to unsubscribe from Audubon of Florida 
Advocacy Center, you can respond to this email with 
"REMOVE" as the subject, or you can visit your subscription 
management page at:  

http://ga1.org/pvtm/index.tcl?akey=wsd5s21bw6

From:	LucyTimes@aol.com
Sent:	Wednesday, December 5, 2001 1:24 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	need a comment

It would appear you needed votes from Democrats to get the intangible tax bill thru the house??? Thought you were going to make it without them...we need a few comments from you on it - I am in the office, 224-7263 - how about giving me a call?????
From:	Jay Brady <JBrady-GCBE@worldnet.att.net>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 5, 2001 12:50 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	secretary@DBPR.state.fl.us; mckay.john.web@leg.state.fl.us; carlton.lisa.web@leg.state.fl.us; miller.lesley.web@leg.state.fl.us; Donna Clarke; bennett.michael@leg.state.fl.us; detert.nancy@leg.state.fl.us; flanagan.mark@leg.state.fl.us; pthompson@fhba.com; constantine.lee.web@state.fl.us; purvisgray@mindspring.com; swt@phkplaw.com; montanaro.kayla@leg.state.fl.us; mizerek@mail.doe.stae.fl.us; sorensen.ken.@leg.state.fl.us
Subject:	Impact Fee Legislation Needed Now

The Honorable Jeb Bush 
The Capitol 
Tallahassee, FL  32399 

Dear Governor Bush: 

Our mutual friend, DBPR Secretary Kim Binkley-Seyer, advised me that she 
forwarded to you a copy of my recent interview in the Sarasota Herald 
Tribune ("Getting Growth to Pay for Itself--and Setting the Price", Nov. 18, 
2001).   If you have had a chance to peruse the article then you have a good 
understanding of the basis of my concern that the imposition of impact fees 
for roads, schools, etc. by local governments is getting more and more out 
of control every day. 

In the wake of recent economic turmoil, and higher workers' compensation and 
other insurance costs to take effect January 1st, exacerbated by the higher 
costs to be imposed by the new Florida Building Code, we need State impact 
fee legislation enacted as soon as possible. 

As a member of the Sarasota County School Board Capital Budget Committee, 
and as a local resident with children in the public schools, I certainly 
empathize with school districts' needs for more capital and operating 
funding, especially right here in Sarasota County.  Recent efforts to 
consider school impact fees in Sarasota and Manatee Counties following Lee 
County's recent $2,100+ per unit school impact fee just enacted are 
misdirected, knee-jerk reactions to the current school funding crisis.  If 
public schools exist because public education provides a public benefit then 
we must conclude that public education should be funded by the broadest 
funding sources, such as the property tax and the sales tax. 

Impact fees should have no place in this discussion without evidence that 
every home yields public school children.  In fact, a great deal of evidence 
to the contrary exists.  All impact fees do is steal money from people who 
in all probability have no impact on the school system.  The State should 
not be allowing local governments to rob innocent people, and that is 
exactly what is transpiring across our State. 

If impact fee supporters were truly interested in being sure that those 
causing the impact paid for that impact, then it would be infinitely more 
reasonable to charge a school enrollment fee that covers the pro rata share 
of capital and operating expenses.  And if we choose to do that, then we 
have effectively chosen to privatize the public school system. 

Florida needs to re-enact a moratorium on school impact fees while 
legislation is drafted to solve the operating and capital school funding 
issues.  The two mill limitation on capital funding (Section 236.25(2) F.S.) 
should be targeted as the primary source for addressing the construction 
issues.  Schools today cost a lot more than they did when the two mill limit 
was enacted.  New technology alone adds significant new costs that were 
never envisioned even 10-15 years ago.  If 2.2 mills, or some other millage 
rate solves the problem, then let's look into it. 

The State, I believe, should seriously consider establishing a base level of 
service for elementary, middle and high schools (maximum number of students 
per classroom, for example) that the State commits to funding, much as like 
the State requires local governments to establish cost feasible levels of 
service for other local infrastructure.  Any higher levels of service that a 
local school board wishes to adopt should be funded locally with few strings 
attached by the State. 

With regard to other impact fees, particularly for roads, the abuses I have 
witnessed in Sarasota and Manatee Counties and elsewhere in calculating and 
administering these fees demands action.  Sarasota County, contrary to its 
own past practice, and in conflict with its own commissioned fiscal and 
economic impact study of growth, now refuses to include credits for other 
tax payments being used to fund the same road capacity improvements paid by 
impact fees.  We have been advised by legal and economics experts that this 
is clearly contrary to Florida case law.  Manatee County has adopted road 
fee increases to go into effect January 1st that increase fees 25-40 percent 
based on their decision to update only one single variable in their fee 
formula, while ignoring a number of other factors that would have reduced 
the fees.  We are now faced with the prospect of hiring our own costly 
consultants to challenge their faulty update methodology. 

The Manatee County School Board was told this week by a consultant that they 
could adopt fees anywhere between $1,000 and $5,000!  Lee County School 
Board was well on their way to adopting even higher fees than they 
ultimately did before they were shown by the Florida Homebuilders' 
consultants that the Board's consultants had made egregious errors in their 
calculations.  More litigation is likely. 

Obviously, there is way too much leeway in arriving at these kinds of 
dollars.  We would much rather see an "Impact Fee Fairness" Bill adopted, 
which we have drafted and are reviewing with local legislators, than to file 
lawsuits. 

At least a dozen other states have impact fee enabling legislation that 
define the ground rules for calculating and administering impact fees. 
Florida statutes only allow it as a "development regulation" and leave it up 
to the courts to sort out the rest.  The courts alone cannot be expected to 
rule on every impact fee calculation issue and put the building and 
development communities in a costly litigious contest with the local 
agencies that (sometimes reluctantly) issue their permits. 

Of course, I could go on and on, but out of at least some respect for your 
time I will end here with the hope that this issue can be addressed soon by 
the legislature and receive your administration's support.  I would be 
pleased to assist you and your staff, the legislature and others in any way 
I can in this effort to correct a terrible injustice that is being placed on 
an industry that does so much for our State's economy and families. 

Very truly yours, 

GULF COAST BUILDERS EXCHANGE, INC. 



John A. "Jay" Brady, AICP 
Executive Director 





From:	Busse, Mark <mark.busse@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 5, 2001 1:16 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	Hirst, Elizabeth; Gates, Lisa; Manzano, Jesse; McDougal, Kim; Shanahan, Kathleen
Subject:	RE: Palm Beach Post article

Governor -- 

There are many ways we can go in this response, and since you didn't respond 
to the Ocala one (we're redrafting), I thought I would get a pre-approval on 
an outline, which will also help OPB: 

1)  Refute one key fact in Date's analysis to cast doubt on the whole thing. 
[Kim -- help, please] Do not go point-by-point.  Stay big picture. 
2)  When times are good, we spend a lot of money.  When times are bad, we 
preserve education funding as much as possible.  The vision is the same:  no 
matter what the economic circumstances, education spending is my priority. 
Cannot be refuted. 
3)  What Date's analysis really shows is that large education increases go 
hand in hand with economic prosperity.  That's why economic prosperity is so 
fundamental, and why tax cuts must also be a priority.  Again, the goose 
that lays the golden egg. 
4)  Our students are learning more.  Acccountability.  Learning gains.  $$ 
are merely a means to an end.  The end is the key. 
5)  The Future.  Yes, schools reaped a windfall over the last three years. 
Our goal: 
        -- replicate the windfall -- economy, stimulus 
        -- spend a huge chuck of the next windfall on public schools 
        -- but only in a way that increases student achievement 
6)  Ultimately, Date shows us the map we followed.  Let's continue to follow 
it.  Subtext:  critics, media have no map, they're just whining in the back 
seat saying are we there yet 

Please advise, Governor, when you have a chance... 

-- Mark

From:	Dana, Pamella <pamella.dana@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 5, 2001 12:43 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	Hirst, Elizabeth; Shanahan, Kathleen
Subject:	FW: Yesterday in Orlando, President Bush said, "I hate the bureaucracy."  

Peter is a nice guy and we have spoken on several occassions whereby I put 
him in touch with VISIT FLA.  He can get loopy and, in some cases, 
aggressively defensive...and is currently mad at VISIT FLA because they 
won't take on his marketing services, ideas.  I have seen his pitch and am 
inclined to not to disagree with VISIT FLA assessment.  I have asked VISIT 
FLA (to include Fred and Thom) to quell this today if possible. 

-----Original Message----- 
From: PB@GRBnet.com [ mailto:PB@GRBnet.com] 
Sent: Wednesday, December 05, 2001 10:36 AM 
To: Pamella Dana (E-mail) 
Cc: Jeb Bush (E-mail) 
Subject: Yesterday in Orlando, President Bush said, "I hate the 
bureaucracy." 


Dear Pamella Dana: 

   As you may recall, my agency has expended considerable effort and time 
attempting to help the State of Florida jumpstart its tourism business. 

   Results: 0. 

   While our ideas have been warmly embraced by the marketing staff at 
FLAUSA, we have encountered the sternest and stiffest bureaucratic 
resistance imaginable from the higher-ups, who apparently don't want to be 
bothered with anyone or anything that might possibly upset the status quo. 

   Yesterday in Orlando, President Bush said, "I hate the bureaucracy."  He 
was referring to the plight of a small businessman whose SBA application had 
gotten lost in the quagmire of Washington red tape.  That quagmire exists 
everywhere, including Tallahassee. 

    Elected representatives are keenly sensitive to the needs and opinions 
of their constituents.  Appointed officials less so.  Tenured bureaucrats 
hardly at all.  The latter are concerned primarily with their own 
perquisites, powers, protocols, procedural niceties and personal position in 
the political pecking order. 

   Sadly, there is really only one effective way to influence any 
bureaucracy - other than appeal directly in person, on-air, to The President 
of The United States. 

   Tomorrow morning we email and mail the following to every newspaper, wire 
service, radio & TV news department in Florida.  Since you have been 
reasonably up and up with me, I'm giving you the courtesy of a first FYI: 

_______ 

Anyone in who works in Florida's tourism industry should know that the 
$20,000,000  emergency marketing fund voted on yesterday by the legislature 
may or may not  be spent on ads that actually bring tourists to Florida.  It 
all depends... 

According to the marketing department of FLAUSA, the quasi-governmental 
marketing co-coordinator for the Department of Tourism, every dollar in 
state funds must be matched by a dollar or more in corporate funds. 

So the state's agency of record, Fahlgren & Geiger in Tampa, must first sell 
their creative ideas to co-op sponsors such as Holiday Inns, Budget Rent a 
Car, and Delta Airlines.  If Fahlgren is successful they, and they alone, 
get $20 million + $20 million in windfall billings. 

But what if corporate sponsors are tapped out?  What if they don't 
particularly care for Fahlgren's jingles or TV spots?  Then nothing could 
happen.  According to FLAUSA's rules, no other marketing, advertising and 
promotional firms are allowed to contact, present ideas to, and solicit 
co-op funding from anyone on Fahlgren's proprietary list of corporate 
contacts. 

Fahlgren won the state's business fair and square - during peacetime when 
tourism was booming and just about any ad could get people to fly or drive 
here.  Today we're in a war and a recession.  The stakes are huge.  There's 
no guarantee that Fahlgren can attract $20,000,000 in co-op dollars, or that 
their ideas, and theirs alone, will motivate terrified tourists in Georgia, 
New York to Toronto to come back to Florida. 

Florida can't afford to bet its entire tourism industry on one ad agency. 

The Department of Tourism should immediately issue an RFP to all ad agencies 
and marketing firms in the state; invite everyone to Tallahassee in 30 days; 
give everyone a chance to pitch their ideas to all the corporate marketing 
directors and tourism officials - all at once. 

We want tourists to vote for Florida's best with their dollars.  Why 
shouldn't't corporate sponsors be given the same opportunity? 

_______ 

    Do I expect anything good to come out of this for The Burkhard Agency? 
Not really.  We've already been ushered in the front and out the back door. 
But.... 

    When I was growing up in Massachusetts, one of my neighbors down the 
street kept chickens. 
Teddy Wheeler and I used to sneak into the coop late and night and blow a 
whistle as loud as we could. 

     It was sorta fun to watch what happened next. 



Peter A. Burkhard 
President & Creative Director 
The Burkhard Agency, Inc. 
37 North Orange Avenue 
Suite 760 
Orlando, FL 32801 
(407) 895-3092 
FAX:  896-3123 
peterb@burkhardagency.com 
www.burkhardagency.com 
Advertising One-on-One 

From:	Dana, Pamella <pamella.dana@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 5, 2001 12:39 PM
To:	screedon@flausa.com; amott@flausa.com; bnocera@flausa.com
Cc:	thom.stork@seaworld.com; fred.lounsberry@universalorlando.com; sgilmore@fahlgren.com
Subject:	FW: Yesterday in Orlando, President Bush said, "I hate the bureaucracy."  

I would suggest that someone quell this today lest we deal with it later 
after some newspaper runs.  I realize the history of Mr. Burkhardt, and 
understand he is bitter because VISIT FLA has opted not to pursue his 
marketing services, but I still believe contact with him is needed.  Has 
anyone explained to him that VISIT FLA annually solicits RFPs for 
advertising/marketing firms--and that you have just completed the latest 
solicitation?  Perhaps now would be a good time.

-----Original Message-----
From: Dan Beldy [mailto:DBeldy@humwin.com]
Sent: Friday, November 16, 2001 2:16 PM
To: 'jeb@jeb.org'
Subject: Enterprise Florida introduction / UnitedWeRide / Sept 11th
Jeb,
 
We met briefly on your trip to Silicon Valley with Enterprise Florida this year.   Hope things are well in Florida.  I am a partner at Hummer Winblad Venture Partners, was the former Navy fighter pilot, US Naval Academy graduate, served in Jacksonville Florida, started UnheardSoldier effort last December related to military ballots.
 
Realize your time is at absolute premium but wanted to make you aware of another effort I kickstarted but now has life of its own.  We are aggregating high profile support / board involvement as we speak.  Would like to get your input on a few fronts so let me explain some detail.
 
Immediately after Sept. 11th events, I started organizing a national bicycle ride called UnitedWeRide  <http://www.unitedweride.org/> www.unitedweride.org 501(c)(3) with mission statement / charter to assist families impacted by terrorism, and also create national participatory tribute to those lost that day.  Originally was going to be grassroots effort but response was incredible so shifted quickly to larger, organized, professional event.  
 
The format, plan is to have bicycle riders leave from several major cities next summer (San Fran, Seattle, Los Angeles, Denver, Austin, Miami, Atlanta, Chicago, Boston) and ride through cities large / small, routes pass through Oklahoma City, United Airlines Flight 93 crash site, Arlington National Cemetery, the Pentagon, Gettysburg, Liberty Bell, and all routes will converge at Ground Zero weekend of Aug 3-4, 2002 in New York City.  All 50 states to participate, plan to get Governor support within each state for permits / routes.  
 
We also plan to have select riders carry a memorial stone for each individual lost in war on terrorism (this would include Sept. 11th, but also other losses, Anthrax, servicemen and women lost in battle, leading up to next summer).  I have approached the families of some friends lost about this, and the families of some of the passengers from UA Flight 93 to get their perspective / support.  And also to get sense of whether they would have an interest in getting a particular family member / team together to "carry", in tributary, honor guard fashion, their individual memorial (which some very much do, all are supportive of effort).
 
UnitedWeRide has the event planning group that put on 1996 Olympic bike events, San Francisco Grand Prix supporting this, and we are putting A+ support structure in place to pull this off.  So far response has been overwhelming.  New York City said they would 'open their arms' to this next August.  Lance Armstrong, Tour de France winner 3 years running, will be part of final ride weekend.  Plan to make formal press announcement by end of year.
 
We are also approaching individuals to present a world class Board / Honorary Chairperson in major cities represented in the ride (some high profile personalities that represent all that is great about USA).  Board member commitment no more than 3-4 Board meetings leading up to next summer, Honorary Chairperson will be personality in particular city that will show up and kick off ride that day in that city.  We are approaching Astronaut Jim Lovell and retired General Norman Schwarzkopf for example as well as leaders in industry to participate.  
 
Would like to get your input on someone you think would be Honorary Chairperson for the City of Miami, a key origination city.  And your input as Governor on the overall effort.  It would be great to get a state Governor champion to support and help rally the nation's Governors behind UnitedWeRide.
 
I know the President is too busy to focus on this, but we are approaching Lee Haney, the current Chairman of the President's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, to determine if there is interest in supporting, being involved in UnitedWeRide.
 
(btw, I have no personal interest in recognition, etc., from this...none.  This is for the country and the families.  It is already shaping up that the existing supporting cast, high profile folks will take center stage and I can fade into background.)
 
UnitedWeRide is already an official corporation.  Right now there are core groups in New York and Silicon Valley that are helping this move forward.  This may be the largest cycling event / peacetime domestic sporting event in history if the event planning projections play out.
 
Do you have 5 minutes to discuss / any initial reaction to the event itself or suggesting on who best to represent Miami?  Happy to discuss with appropriate person / staff when able and provide more details.

Regards,

Dan
 
Dan Beldy
Hummer Winblad Venture Partners
http://www.humwin.com
dbeldy@humwin.com
415-979-9600 (phone)
415-979-9601 (fax)

From:	BillLongLFD@aol.com
Sent:	Wednesday, December 5, 2001 12:03 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Governor
Attachments:	DBPR Landrum.doc

Dear Governor Bush:

       With all that is going on in the Great State of Florida, the Nation, and the World I will try to keep this e-mail brief.  In your speech to the Florida League of Cities Downtown Redevelopment Seminar held in Miami you stated that your e-mail is one of the best ways to get in touch with you.
       As an elected official I know first hand how hard it is to keep track of everything that is going on.  However, when I feel someone is treated improperly I work hard to rectify the situation.  
       You can imagine how hard it is to survive as a small business man these days.  As if the economy were not bad enough, one of your agencies is causing me unnecessary problems.  I submitted an application to the Department of Business and Professional Regulation, Board of Funeral Directors and Embalmers to open a new cinerator (crematory) facility.  In my twenty-one years in this profession I have received one minor complaint which currently pending against me.  The Departments Legal Advisor (Charles Tunnicliff) has specifically stated to my attorney that the staff of the Department is improperly using a statute to deny my final inspection.  I invested $100,000.00 in the construction and equipment for the cinerator facility.  I hired two additional staff members to operate the facility.  When I made application to the Department in May/2001 I was told my inspection would take place in 30 days.  Well, its now December and I have been forced to sell the crematory at a loss, I have suffered tens of thousands of dollars in lost income, and I am being forced to terminate the two employee's.  As if that were not enough, the Department is denying my request to have my $400.00+ application fee refunded.  They have taken no action on my application.  I should at least be entitled to a refund of my application fee.  
       Again, (in summary) I lose a new business venture, I lose tens of thousands of dollars in income, I am adding two more people to the unemployment lines, and I can't even get my lousy 400+ dollars back.  Needless, to say I am appalled at the Departments handling of this matter.
       Governor Bush, I believe you are a sincere, honest man, who cares a lot about all of us.  I support you and all that you have tried to do to downsize and limit government spending.  I have been one of your most outspoken supporters in local and statewide political circles.  Of course having the former Chairwoman of the Brevard Republican Executive Committee as a mother; in her eyes Republicans can do no wrong (especially a Bush)!  Please take this matter under consideration.  I want to continue to be in your corner as we go into this election year.  I need your help!  Persons working for you should promote commerce and the economy not help tear it down.

"God Bless America"

Sincerely,
William Long

City Councilman
Member, IFDF - Political Action Committee
Board Member, Volusia League of Cities



From:	Ward, Kevin D <kevin.ward@qwest.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 5, 2001 11:51 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	FLA-USA...

Governor - 

I think that you are right on target with your new tourism initiatives.  To 
me, FLA-USA stands for FLORIDA --- "Unlimited State Appeal".  It's appeal is 
UNIQUE as well, but I think it's more accurate to say - UNLIMITED. 

Our family in fact had two week-long vacations this year and both were 
within Florida.  I've now been to 33 different countries and over 40 states, 
but I find that Florida itself offers more than enough variety, 
entertainment and sheer vacation value.  It's like multiple states & nations 
all rolled into one. 

Except for the Inaugural Ball back in January, the next Bush Inaugural to 
come - and your two future Inaugurals... I can't think of a really good 
reason to travel beyond our borders.  *** I actually wouldn't mind making it 
to the "Rose Bowl" (since the Canes have been my favorite team since the 
days of Jim Kelley), but tickets to that one aren't likely and Pasadena is 
just too far... 

This is exactly why I was so keen on that Florida Film Commissioner or 
Deputy Commissioner opportunity... there's just no other place on Earth like 
FLA-USA... Florida has it all and moreover - it can appear on film like 
anywhere you ever would want to or need to go... 

Please keep up the effective cheerleading on Florida's behalf and keep us 
all on the right track.  Florida will rebound soon and stronger than ever.  

Take care - 

Kevin Ward 

From:	Fred Dickinson <Dickinson.Fred@hsmv.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 5, 2001 11:32 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: Issuing Driver's Licenses to people holding Visas abouttoexpire

Governor: Drivers licenses are being issued concurrent with INS document expiration dates in two offices statewide with an additional ten offices coming online 12/10. The remaining 150 offices will begin issuing said licenses 12/18. As part of the Task Force plan submitted to FDLE, those driver license applicants who present foreign national documents for identification purposes will receive a non-photo paper driver license at the office. Highway Safety Dept. will then verify the identity documents within 30 days, central issue a digitized photo driver license and mail same from Tallahassee. This process is on the same time schedule as above. Should you need more detail as to which offices come online on specific dates please advise.Fred.

: 
>>> "Jeb Bush" <jeb@jeb.org> 12/04/01 09:21PM >>> 
when will people seeking licenses whose visas expires earlier than the 
standard time get a license that runs concurrently with their visa? 
  

Jeb Bush 

*********************************************************** 
Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law. 
Most written communications to or from state officials 
regarding state business are public records available to the 
public and media upon request.   Your e-mail communications 
may therefore be subject to public disclosure. 

-----Original Message----- 
From: Fred Dickinson [ mailto:Dickinson.Fred@hsmv.state.fl.us] 
Sent: Tuesday, December 04, 2001 8:38 AM 
To: Jeb Bush 
Subject: RE: Issuing Driver's Licenses to people holding Visas about 
toexpire 



Per our Driver License Strategic Plan filed with the Florida Department of 
Law Enforcement, one of our tasks to aid in the state's efforts to 
strengthen domestic security is to begin limiting the duration of driver 
licenses to the duration of pertinent Immigration and Naturalization Service 
documents.  

The computer software modifications we began in mid-November to accomplish 
this procedural change have just been completed.  The first test of this 
rollout began yesterday at our Pembroke Pines driver license office and all 
went well.  We will phase-in all other driver license offices over the next 
two weeks and anticipate completing the rollout by December 15, 2001.  

If you have any questions, please let me know. 

Fred Dickinson 


>>> "Jeb Bush" <jeb@jeb.org> 12/01/01 12:59PM >>> 
Re: Issuing Driver's Licenses to people holding Visas about to expireThank 
you for writing. We have changed the procedure to make the visa expiration 
date be the same as the drivers license date. I will check to see why the 
motor vehicle offices are not complying with the change. Thank you for 
bringing this to my attention. 

Jeb Bush

Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law. 
Most written communications to or from state officials 
regarding state business are public records available to the 
public and media upon request.   Your e-mail communications 
may therefore be subject to public disclosure.

From: Beatrice <mailto:beatrice@nivets.com>

Hello Lori,
 
Reading the first Email that was send to me. I saw that you were talking about oversees. Maybe you don't know but I am originally
from Europe. 
 
To briefly give a broad overview of the program:  The A.B.L.E. (Achieving Beyond Limited Expectations) Foundation, Inc. establishes, oversees, manages, and assists in the funding of each A.B.L.E. Center.  Strict quality control is essential to insure that our programs and services are provided in top-notch fashion.  The creation of each A.B.L.E. Center is simply a process of duplication.  The system has been developed and we are now ready to implement the creation of the Centers throughout the state in each community.  It is a very simple process to follow, but it does take commitment from the community and the families who will benefit from each Center.  So, if you are interested in helping to spear-head, so to speak, this project in YOUR community, please let us know as soon as possible.

----- Original Message ----- 
From: The A.B.L.E. Foundation, Inc. <mailto:webmaster@ablefoundation.org>  
To: Beatrice <mailto:beatrice@nivets.com>  
Sent: Tuesday, December 04, 2001 6:45 PM
Subject: Re: Osceola County ABLE Center

Hi Beatrice -
 
From reading your email, I can see why so many people are emailing me with compliments about you and your commitment to help people with disabilities!  You are busy gathering information and the people who can help make this awesome A.B.L.E. Vision a reality in Osceola County!
 
Great news about the meeting room.  We'll provide the refreshments.
 
We need to reach out to parents and families with children of all ages with disabilities - adults especially, too.  Encourage people to reach out to other people they have never really stopped to talk to.  Asking people if they have heard about the A.B.L.E. Vision and how it can benefit the community is a great way to get a conversation started.  
 
To answer your questions from your other email I received today:
 
We have A.B.L.E. Centers in various stages of opening in Illinois, California, Alabama, Georgia, and New York, so far with plans to open in all 50 states and Canada.
 
As a foundation, we are automatically a not-for-profit organization.  We are fully funded.  We are a group of philanthropists who are providing the seed money and the funding for this project.
 
We have the funding and will purchase the land the Centers will be built upon.
 
We have the funding to open the centers.  We need to make sure that the communities we choose to open a center in are able to keep it open.  Our concept is unique and it is not comparable to any other program currently open anywhere in this country serving people with disabilities.
 
We are volunteers in that we are financially independent and are able to volunteer our time without worrying about compensation.  
 
We are a private board of directors.  We do not solicit board members.
 
The A.B.L.E. Vision is a gift from God.
 
Our son, Daniel, who is 23 years old, is the inspiration for the A.B.L.E. Concept.
 
Our system works because it has taken more than 10 years to research, develop, and fine tune.  It is based upon success principles that are proven to be true.  We are here to serve, we are not self-seeking, nor do we seek fame or fortune.  We have no personal agendas - this is truly a gift from God - we are simply the vessles He is using.
 
As far as the actual buildings for the A.B.L.E. Center, we have architectural drawings of the A.B.L.E. Vision.  Approdx. 10-25 acres are necessary depending upon the needs of the communities we will be serving and the extent of the programs and services we will provide.
 
It is refreshing to see that you have questions and that you are thinking about this project in depth.  Ask any question you would like - that's perfectly fine!
 
Beatrice - you are doing a great job so far gathering informatin and people together and coordinating the meeting room and date and for getting the word out.  I saw the message on the hawke list today.  
 
We are open to questions, comments, and suggestions.  We are here to serve the needs of the community.  We are NOT funded by the government or any other agency - private or public.  We are free to dream big and to make those dreams a reality - together!
 
Keep doing what you are doing.  With the news about the state funding cutbacks, people are really getting desperate for help and for programs and services.  A.B.L.E. is the answer.
 
We are NOT affiliated in any way with the ABLE trust.  That is a state agency/organization.  Our name is a acronym for Achieving Beyond Limited Expectations.  
 
We can't wait to meet you and the dynamic Osceola group!
 
Warm regards,
Lori Bennett
Ambassador of Hope

-----Original Message-----
From: L. C. Alexander [mailto:l1alex@infi.net]
Sent: Tuesday, December 04, 2001 10:04 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: A editorial copy and a query.


Another Whats going on in Lake Panasoffkee, Governor Bush? 
Some time ago the Blade asked this same question. Its appearance on the web aroused the ire of some individuals, so in the thinking of this editor it was believed some education benefits toward what public disclosures can provide was accomplished. Due to a number of recent questions being raised by some Lake P citizens, however, maybe the belief was similar to the old adage of yelling against the wind? 
To recap, the state legislature some two years ago said in passing a Bill that was to provide about $26 million dollars over five years (paraphrased here) that the Lake was a state treasure owned by all its citizens, and the sad, man mangled mess needed restoration before it was totally lost. A lake restoration committee set-up began, that to shorten a long involved session of political finagling, ended up as being less in number of members as originally planned by governor appointment, all placed in office by the local county commission. Not unexpected, some well-known local power players, according to citizen activists, ended up in a majority of those seats that has guided matters ever since. 
Their first project decided upon was to restore sections on the lakes east side around Colemans Landing, an uninhabited shore a far piece for any boat trailering, that had public access right of way and was at one time a prime fishery area. Unfortunately, due to contentions that native aquatic plants must be allowed to repopulate the dredged areas, public access there is still a figment for future decision. Waterfront dwellers on the west shore where a major Sumter County population resides are mad. Especially canal property owners who cant get anything done, once privy to clean, clear runs to open water but now landlocked by excess weeds and muck buildup, are not happy to know that as a practical matter, only fish camp owners and their customers for the most part are reaping any benefits from this cost-overrun, millions of dollars operation. Some fish camp owners they point out who set on the restorations committee. 
Recently the chorus of questioners has widened and deepened apparently. It now is being noised about that as dredging activity has been transferred to the west side of the lake, clearing of the channel from one of said fish camps to open water, and a open lakefront restoration along another committee members property ongoing, is stirring real heat to an already hot mix. A mix that embroils state and county money, hard to track according to these activists with agencies like Swiftmud and the Fish and Game Department trying to roil the pot on the side. 
Yep, Governor! If any parts of the above are true, Id say you and some others got a big problem. Come to think of it, even the perception evidently affecting a bunch of folks, smells pretty bad in these volatile times. What do you say? LCA[] 

Governor Bush: A letter advising the Attorney Generals office of criminal actions in the above program from a Mr. Knute Dobson of Lake Panasoffkee has been copied to me as the Citrus-Sumter Blade editor. Complaint is made this notification is being ignored by the AG. Could your office look into these matters? L. C. Alexander[]

From:	Susan Goldstein <skgoldstein@hotmail.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, December 5, 2001 10:06 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Thanks for budget crisis rescue

Dear Jeb, 
Hope all is well with you and your family.  Thank you for the consideration 
you have given to autism and the entire DD population in the special session 
and the budget crisis.  Your influence and leadership have not gone 
unnoticed. 

We have been trying to amass local dollars, both public and private, to fund 
programs for children that will suffer i.e. child care and summer programs, 
extended school year, etc.  Now is a perfect opportunity to encourage the 
local community leadership to fill in the gaps for those programs that have 
experienced cuts. 

The good new is property values are at an all time high in Broward and we 
have a new children's taxing district.   Bad news is the new council and the 
county commission feel that if they step up to the plate and fund lost 
dollars, the state will abandon their responsibility, when it is in a 
position to fund. 

Efforts have been initiated to bring their attention to these pressing 
concerns and hopefully we will be successful. The disabled population is not 
represented on the council and, as I predicted, have been left out of the 
mix. Our highly successful Inclusive Childcare Project is in trouble.  Since 
there is no special needs catagory, we structured a request around their 
guidlines in the abused and neglected category (which many become), they 
then informed us they would not accept lost dollar applications.  We have 
over 350 children in this program and a waiting list.  Your support for this 
effort with the Children's Services Council here in Broward would be greatly 
appreciated. 

Unfortunately, some have the feeling that dollars would be better spent on 
children that are not so "hopeless" and can transition into the community.  
Disabled children through no fault of their own are not being treated 
equitably in this process. 

Which brings me to this quote I wanted you to see that offended many parents 
who have fought so long in education and have the same hopes and dreams for 
their children as everyone else. 
********************************************************************** 
Quote from Chair of President Bush's Commission on Special 
Education 

Gov. Branstad (former governor of Iowa) has been appointed to serve as 
chair of the Administration's new special education commission. 

Following is a quote from Gov Branstad (Iowa) from an interview 
transcript. The entire transcript is available at: 

http://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/education/schools_1-16.html 

GOV. TERRY BRANSTAD: In our state nearly 60 percent of the budget goes 
for education. And what we find is people are willing to invest in 
quality education, but they are also fiscally conservative. They want to 
see results. They want to see achievement for the dollars that they put 
in. I think that the federal government in its mandates in the area of 
special ed has driven up costs needlessly. I think that needs to be 
reviewed. 

I want to see every child have an opportunity to learn. All special 
ed children do have a right to an education, but to spend tens 
oft thousands of dollars on kids that really are not going to be able to 
support themselves or be able to really learn a great deal at the 
expense of the general education of the rest of the students is not 
fair. 

And so that has to be addressed. A lot of people are afraid of it, 
of being, you know, accused of being insensitive or whatever. I was 
in Sioux City, Iowa, yesterday, and I heard from a Teacher of the Year, 
Nancy Mounts, who had been Teacher of the Year, and the 
superintendent there about how their school is being squeezed 
because of the federal mandates in the area of special ed and 
how there needs to be more flexibility and latitude given to local 
school districts in that area. 

******************************************************************** 


Jeb, if you ever cross paths with Governor Branstad, maybe you could mention 
that all children can learn and although many do not learn through 
traditional methods, no child should be left behind.  They should never be 
penalized or treated as damaged goods with no hope or potential. 

A sincere and heartfelt "Thank You" for all you do and for your past 
support.  You have my undaunted support and commitment for your re-election. 
  Please let me know what I can do to help you here in Broward. 
Good Luck and have a blessed holiday! 

Susan

From:	SandyF5977@aol.com
Sent:	Wednesday, December 5, 2001 8:58 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Education -- State Diplomas

Dear Governor Bush: 

With more and more people choosing home school for their children, I would like to suggest a change in the Florida High School Diploma (GED) program.   Many of the home schoolers prescribe to a rigorous course of study yet they are only eligible for the GED Diploma, which to the best of my knowledge, can only be obtained by those under 18 by attending special GED classes.    The problem with this is twofold -- 1.) Many home schoolers curriculum is much more challenging than the GED classes and taking those are only a waste of time 2.) the General Studies Diploma only test for basic skills.   

My suggestion is that the state offer two different tests -- keep the General Education Diploma program with its study classes as is, and add a new test, for the more challenging curriculum and allow students 16 and older to take it so that they can continue their studies at colleges and universities when they are ready. 

Thank you for your consideration. 


Sandra M. Faulkner

>       $4,482,300 Cumulative Amount of Approved Loans

> cumulative total of 2.9 million dollars in loan monies.  I cannot help but

> with the SBA.  Hector Barreto and his team have been incredibly helpful,

-----Original Message-----
From: L. C. Alexander [mailto:l1alex@infi.net]
Sent: Tuesday, December 04, 2001 10:04 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: A editorial copy and a query.


Another Whats going on in Lake Panasoffkee, Governor Bush? 
Some time ago the Blade asked this same question. Its appearance on the web aroused the ire of some individuals, so in the thinking of this editor it was believed some education benefits toward what public disclosures can provide was accomplished. Due to a number of recent questions being raised by some Lake P citizens, however, maybe the belief was similar to the old adage of yelling against the wind? 
To recap, the state legislature some two years ago said in passing a Bill that was to provide about $26 million dollars over five years (paraphrased here) that the Lake was a state treasure owned by all its citizens, and the sad, man mangled mess needed restoration before it was totally lost. A lake restoration committee set-up began, that to shorten a long involved session of political finagling, ended up as being less in number of members as originally planned by governor appointment, all placed in office by the local county commission. Not unexpected, some well-known local power players, according to citizen activists, ended up in a majority of those seats that has guided matters ever since. 
Their first project decided upon was to restore sections on the lakes east side around Colemans Landing, an uninhabited shore a far piece for any boat trailering, that had public access right of way and was at one time a prime fishery area. Unfortunately, due to contentions that native aquatic plants must be allowed to repopulate the dredged areas, public access there is still a figment for future decision. Waterfront dwellers on the west shore where a major Sumter County population resides are mad. Especially canal property owners who cant get anything done, once privy to clean, clear runs to open water but now landlocked by excess weeds and muck buildup, are not happy to know that as a practical matter, only fish camp owners and their customers for the most part are reaping any benefits from this cost-overrun, millions of dollars operation. Some fish camp owners they point out who set on the restorations committee. 
Recently the chorus of questioners has widened and deepened apparently. It now is being noised about that as dredging activity has been transferred to the west side of the lake, clearing of the channel from one of said fish camps to open water, and a open lakefront restoration along another committee members property ongoing, is stirring real heat to an already hot mix. A mix that embroils state and county money, hard to track according to these activists with agencies like Swiftmud and the Fish and Game Department trying to roil the pot on the side. 
Yep, Governor! If any parts of the above are true, Id say you and some others got a big problem. Come to think of it, even the perception evidently affecting a bunch of folks, smells pretty bad in these volatile times. What do you say? LCA[] 

Governor Bush: A letter advising the Attorney Generals office of criminal actions in the above program from a Mr. Knute Dobson of Lake Panasoffkee has been copied to me as the Citrus-Sumter Blade editor. Complaint is made this notification is being ignored by the AG. Could your office look into these matters? L. C. Alexander[]

From: Mattingly, Rebecca [mailto:rebecca.mattingly@myflorida.com]
Sent: Tuesday, December 04, 2001 5:36 PM

Subject: RE: Los Angeles Representative





>  -----Original Message----- 
> From:         Mattingly, Rebecca  
> Sent: Tuesday, December 04, 2001 5:22 PM 
> To:   Shanahan, Kathleen 
> Subject:      RE: Los Angeles Representative 
> 
> Kathleen: 
> 
> Any chance that I can get an FTE for this position?  
> 
> As you know, this position is an OPS position which actually costs us 
> more, and I've got the hourly cap stipulation.  Plus, the position is a 
> professional one.  I need to keep this position as employer-employee 
> direct supervision.  According to Ken Allman, I cannot do a sole source 
> for this service.  I'm working with Pam on her suggestion that this 
> position be in Enterprise Florida with our supervision; however, upon 
> second thought, that could be ripe for attacks from industry. Plus 
> Enterprise would want to oversee the position and they no nothing about 
> the industry, the position, the deliverables, etc. 
> 
> If we get nothing else this year, please, please allow us one additional 
> FTE for this position.  
> 
> RDM 
> 
>        -----Original Message----- 
>       From:   Mattingly, Rebecca  
>       Sent:   Friday, March 30, 2001 5:47 AM 
>       To:     Shanahan, Kathleen 
>       Subject:        RE: Los Angeles Representative 
> 
>       Kathleen: 
> 
>       I know that you have requested more information from Ken Allman on 
> this. Please allow me to bring further perspective to this. 
> 
>       The previous administration fully funded an LA representative as an 
> FTE.  Unfortunately, that administration allowed the state film office to 
> deteriorate to utter ruin.  The previous operation was the Florida 
> Entertainment Industry Council, which operated as a direct support 
> organization under contract to OTTED.  Due to mismanagement, law breaking 
> and other sordid activities, the former Florida Entertainment Industry 
> Council (FEIC) was abolished, the contract cancelled.  The state suffered 
> extreme embarrassment in the media and loss of business.  The industry 
> became disorganized, emotional and dysfunctional.  This is the hole that 
> I've been digging from, the mess that I've had to clean up.  There is 
> plenty of documentation to provide the ugly details of the entire debacle 
> in OTTED and in the Chief Inspector General's Office. 
> 
>       The only thing that continued to "work" effectively was the LA 
> representative.  In 1995-96, after the abolishment of the FEIC, the local 
> film offices pooled their tiny resources to continue funding this 
> operation.  Florida was the first state to have a local market 
> rep.;however, she stayed the course.  The local film offices formed an 
> association called the Florida Film Commissioners Association (FFCA). 
> Susan went unpaid many times simply because the resources were not there. 
> To increase funding for the LA operation, the FFCA broadened its 
> membership to include more industry participation.  They became known as 
> Film Florida  Association.  
> 
>       Needless to say that after all of this occurred, no one in the 
> industry, nor any local film office had much trust in state government. 
> The industry was apathetic, membership in groups and associations dropped. 
> The Governor and others from EOG met with many industry professionals and 
> local film offices to get their input on creating a new film office. He 
> also went to LA to meet with top studio professionals, as well as with 
> Susan Simms to discuss this issue.  When I and the new Florida Film 
> Advisory Council came along, our initial position on the matter of a rep 
> in LA was that yes, Florida needed to continue this initiative.  We 
> believed that the responsibility of operating any field office was the 
> state's, regardless of where it is.  Film Florida did not want any part of 
> this idea at first.  They wanted us to prove that we could be trusted.  I 
> talked to the Governor to get his opinion. His suggestion was to not "take 
> over" but to work with them in a cooperative manner, since it was them 
> "who saved Rome when Rome was burning."  Susan continued on as a Film 
> Florida employee.  We worked with her on projects and maintained 
> communication. 
> 
>       Months and months of proving ourselves and negotiations have since 
> occured. During that time, Film Florida experienced financial problems and 
> found that they could no longer support the LA representative.  We (Film 
> Commission & Advisory Council) reiterated that we believed it is the 
> responsibility of the state film office to support all field offices 
> outside of Florida.  We arrived at a middle ground, a testing ground,  via 
> the short-term SNAPs agreement.  We contracted with Film Florida 
> specifically for LA representative services.  We agreed that after this 
> short term agreement, we would assess the situation and make a decision to 
> move forward in a manner that was best for the state.  Film Florida, the 
> local film offices and the Advisory Council agreed that it was best to 
> return the responsibility of operating the LA field office back to the 
> state film office.  Recognizing that the we would not received any 
> additional FTE's, I worked with Ken and Catherine Heth in Purchasing to 
> come up with a way to obtain an employee-employer set up for this 
> operation, which is why we went with the OPS recommendation. 
> 
>       So essentially, since 1993-94, Susan Simms has represented Florida, 
> our only consistent outreach over the years.  Kathleen, I am certainly 
> willing to do whatever it takes at this point to move this initiative 
> forward. Clearly, I recognize that this is your call; however, I must 
> express that we've finally got everyone who has a say in agreement after 
> an entire year of back and forth talks.  My fear is that if we change our 
> minds now on this, or waiver, we will send the wrong message.  In 
> addition, Susan will be left in limbo and without employment as the 
> expectation has always been that this transition into the state film 
> office would occur. 
> 
>       Thank you for indulging me by reading this.  I look forward to 
> receiving your decision. 
> 
>       RDM 
>

From: PeggyStanton@aol.com [mailto:PeggyStanton@aol.com]
Sent: Tuesday, December 04, 2001 4:38 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: No Subject



Dear Governor Bush: 

Just a quick refresher ..this is the third year I have alerted you to Kids 
for Peace Pilgrimage Week which, this year runs all this week, Dec. 3-7. 

Last year, if you recall, the children wrote letters to the President 
suggesting how he could bring peace and reconcile the country after such a 
tortuous election and we sent copies, at your request, to you. You were kind 
enough to send a handwritten note which meant a lot to the children. 

I have just heard your brother today suggesting that Americans pray that God 
will put a protective shield over America. He should know that there are 71 
Kids for Peace Schools throughout the nation praying...somewhere between 35 
and 40,000 children. They are also selling a bumper sticker created by a 5 
year old which reads "Peace, please! Do it for us kids - Tommy". The profits 
are being sent to the President's Afghan children's fund. 

Florida once again leads the nation in little peace pilgrims...some 20,000 in 
this state alone, with Pennsylvania second and Texas a distant third. 

Schools were urged to invite you to one of their events this week. I hope 
they did as seeing is believing. My husband, who served with your father in 
Congress and has seen a great deal, said he was "overwhelmed" by a pilgrimage 
he attended in Miami. Mrs. Don Shula who is on our board is greatly 
responsible for 26 schools in Miami-Dade county becoming Kids for Peace 
schools. 

If you wish to follow the week through the Internet, please visit our 
website..www.peacethroughlove.org and click on FrontPageNews 

Bill and I send best regards to your Mom and Dad. Your brother is in our 
prayers everyday. 

Peace! 

Peggy Stanton

From: Dileva, Mike [mailto:DILEVMI@mail.northgrum.com]
Sent: Tuesday, December 04, 2001 1:13 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: michael.sole@dep.state.fl.us; cangelm@sso.org; vhoa@aol.com
Subject: Beach Erosion



Dear Governor Busch, 
I live at 877 N Miramar Ave #404, Indialantic Fl 32903.  I work at Northrop 
Grumman as an Engineer and live in the Villager Condo on the beach in 
Melbourne.   The Villager is in jeopardy of being breached by the Atlantic 
Ocean.  We need Emergency funding now to prevent our home from being taken 
by the sea.  
I am well aware of the recent events that have changed our lives forever. 
However, this is a vital natural resource for the entire State of Florida. 
We must preserve it before it is to late.  We are very close to losing the 
remaining Dunes that separate us from the ocean.  Help us to keep our homes 
and maintain this natural resource, we need funding to stop this erosion 
today. 
Thank you for your consideration.       

                                Respectfully, Michael E Di Leva   Phone # 
321 724-6472 

From:	frenc71@dellepro.com
Sent:	Wednesday, December 5, 2001 3:23 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	frenc71@dellepro.com
Subject:	Past criminal from 20 years ago

Dear Gov. Bush (Jeb) ,
 
My name is Ed French (Edwin C. French III) ,
I am writing as per several sources state that you are probably the only person that can help and might consider helping me with this problem . I am originally a born-and-raised Floridian who now resides in the State of Arizona . Nearly all of my childhood family ties remain in Orlando and surrounding areas .
 
In 1981 , I was sentenced after submitting a guilty plea for a white-collar non-violent crime for which I served time on in the Deland facility for Volusia County . The Honorable McFerrin Smith was acting Judge in this case during Sept. of 1981 . Four months after I was introduced to facility my case was reviewed , between going from Maximum security at time of intake to Trustee in three months , my 1 year sentence was commuted to probation and I was released the morning before Christmas .
 
Jeb , since that time ( 20 years ago ) , I have been a productive taxpayer , model employee , devoted husband and most recently an exuberant and loving father to my 9 year old daughter Meaghan who I adore . Other than an occasional traffic citation in the first 10 years , I have not had to visit a courtroom except to seek visitation for my wife Krista's Grandaughter .
 
Now that I have given you some background on myself  we come to the issue at hand . I am a mature and responsible parent , husband and citizen . I have never had a violent background or tendency . My last 3 employers cover over 11 yrs in customer service : Tucson Medical Center - 6yrs        American Airlines- 2+ years     Spherion (corporate travel agency for Amex) 3 yrs .
 
For the vast majority of these past 20 years I have had all of my Civil Liberties restored except for the Right to Bear Arms .
I live in a fairly remote area just southwest of Tucson Az. and between our location gradually becoming more urban , the state of our World today and an overwhelming desire to be able to feel safe in our home , I am asking for your help in the only way I know how . I am hoping that somewhere deep down you can relate to what I am talking about at some level .
 
Several years ago I had inquired as to the steps neccessary to re-obtain the last liberty I was still missing and was referred to ATF for more info . They stated at that time that the only way to do this was to be granted Clemency or a Pardon from the State in which the crime was committed . I left Florida in 1985 and have been an Arizona resident since 1986 . In all this time I have been back to visit my folks on a fairly regular basis and have always respected the laws and citizens of Florida .
 
I am not exactly sure what measure you would need to use to accomplish my request should you choose to help me , but any help and/or advise is welcome . Just on a side - note , Jeb , if this is something you can't do or aren't comfortable with , I'll understand . I am just a good man that made a huge mistake early in life and have paid for it ever since .
 
Thanks for taking the time .
Respectfully ,
                                                                                            Ed French
                                                                                            3402 S. Bradford Drive
                                                                                            Tucson , Az. 85735
                                                                                             1-520-908-9662 - home
                                                                                             1-520-331-2720 - cell             frenc71@dellepro.com  or   frenc71@hotmail.com

Good "Evening Governor!

From:	s.m.barnette@att.net
Sent:	Tuesday, December 4, 2001 9:33 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	unacceptable direction, for Lake Rouseau

Dear Governor; Thank you for sending the staff from fish 
& wild life & DEP to our NOV 6, 2001 meeting for WHOA. 
The gentlemen were very nice, and started off seemingly 
objective, but as the meeting progressed they talked 
themselves out of doing anything different. And then 
told us "we should be happy with the status quo". We 
have held 2 workshops & meetings since then, and our 
participants overwhelmingly found each time, the status 
quo, unacceptable. We have strong beliefs that there is 
a more economical, effective way to clean up our lake, 
from this constant mess of weeds and muck. We don't like 
hearing "this new program (essentially the same process) 
will take 4-5 yrs to implement", or putting the blame on 
some other condition, while we feel they are just 
putting us of until they can retire. It is felt they are 
being well paid to do a job, that falls far from success 
in resolving our problem. We have some suggestions that 
deserve to be heard, and possibly tried, and are willing 
to bring our staff to the capital for a presentation, if 
necessary. But we certainly need a change of direction, 
that will yield RESULTS.I'm writing you this letter on 
behalf of our WHOA participants at our meeting this PM. 
Regards Stuart Barnette Director of WHOA 
PS We like all of your other accomplishment.

-----Original Message-----
From: Marstiller, Simone [mailto:simone.marstiller@myflorida.com]
Sent: Tuesday, December 04, 2001 4:28 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: McDonough, Jim
Subject: Drug Treatment Initiative Oral Argument on 12/10/01



Governor: 

As you know, we filed a brief in the Fla. Supreme Court on your behalf 
opposing the drug treatment initiative.  Oral argument is scheduled for 
Monday, Dec. 10 at 9:00 a.m.  We requested oral argument when the brief was 
filed in order to preserve the opportunity.  However, four of the five 
parties opposing the initiative -- including the EOG -- are scheduled to 
argue and have been alotted 5 minutes each.  The other parties' briefs -- 
especially that of Save Our Society from Drugs -- largely cover the same 
territory covered in our brief, although they make additional arguments, as 
well.  Because of the overlap, and because FDLE and the Prosecuting 
Attorneys Assn can adequately advance the concerns of the executive branch, 
we propose waiving or yielding our time to the other parties to best utilize 
the time given to the initiative's opponents collectively. 

Please let me know whether you agree or disagree.  Thank you. 

Simone Marstiller 
Legal Affairs

-----Original Message-----
From: Karen Kellams [mailto:KellamsK@dor.state.fl.us]
Sent: Tuesday, December 04, 2001 3:44 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Updates



Governor, 
I wanted to share some information on a few cases that you had referred 
to us: 

We are getting regular payments for a custodial parent in Casselbury 
but we have to continue to seek assistance from Pennsylvania's child 
support agency because the noncustodial parent pays less than 
court-ordered.  The children are over 18 but the father owes more than 
$130,000 in arrears!  The custodial parent knows we're doing all that we 
can and that we will continue with our efforts. 

I'm still plugging away on the case with Ms. Calloway.  It's an 
interesting one.  We've been able to collect over $10,000 on her behalf 
in the last year from court-ordered purges.  The father still won't pay 
on a regular basis but Ms. Calloway knows we are still plugging away... 

On a very good note, one of the cases you referred to us from a mother 
who wrote to you from North Carolina about a year ago reached a 
successful conclusion.  The noncustodial parent paid $15,000 to the 
custodial parent a few weeks ago to pay off all the back child support 
owed.  She was very happy to get this money.  This case is now closed. 

On another note, I know that Jim appreciates your support of the 
Department's proposal to implement an administrative support process. 
Many of the calls and e-mails I receive are from frustrated parents 
waiting for their cases to go to hearing.   Anything that can be done to 
make the establishment process more efficient will improve our level of 
service.  

I wish you and your family a very happy holiday season, 
Karen Kellams

-----Original Message-----
From: Martin, Mike V. [mailto:MVMartin@mail.ifas.ufl.edu]
Sent: Tuesday, December 04, 2001 3:21 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: FW: McKay's "shotgun" comments




Governor Bush, as you can see from the e-mail below many of our very good 
people are upset over Sen. MCkay's suggestion-however intended-that someone 
shoot a shotgun through IFAS on a Friday afternoon. 
These remarks serve no good purpose. 

I know its not your responsibility to monitor the utterance of the Senate 
Prez but I thought you ought to know 

Cheers 

Mike Martin VP 
-----Original Message----- 
From: Frazer, Nat [ mailto:FrazerN@wec.ufl.edu] 
Sent: Tuesday, December 04, 2001 2:26 PM 
To: 'mvm@gnv.ifas.ufl.edu'; 'jcj@gnv.ifas.ufl.edu' 
Subject: McKay's "shotgun" comments 


FYI Several staff and faculty members in my department have stopped me in 
the hall today to express their outrage over Senator McKay's comments in the 
Gainesville Sun encouraging folks to take their shotguns into IFAS on a 
Friday after 4PM..  

1.  They resent the implication that IFAS folks do not work hard for their 
paychecks (and they are not aware that the Senator ever visited our building 
before making such a remark). 
2.  They feel that if any of them had made similar comments about the 
Florida Senate, that they would have been slammed into jail for threatening 
public officials carrying out their duties in a public building.  They want 
to know how anyone can get away with making such comments, especially in the 
wake of September 11th. 
3.  Several of the women who work on the first floor in my building  have 
said they now feel unsafe -- from crazies who might "take the hint" from 
McKay; I would not be surprized if some of my employees do take off this 
Friday and go home before 4PM. 

In the best of times, folks would be worried about losing their jobs; in 
these times of terrorism and other acts of public violence, this was an 
especially insensitive remark for a leading public official to make. 

Folks in my department have been pretty calm and fearless about all this 
budget-cut stuff -- they're pulling together, willing to endure the 
belt-tightening for the sake of the IFAS team, etc. (Several have inquired 
about the possibility of voluntary furloughs or going part time to prevent 
others from losing their jobs, etc.) But this latest cavalier comment from a 
key Florida legislator has REALLY ticked them off and contributed to a 
marked decline in morale. 

I know my staff and faculty are not alone in their feelings about this 
issue.  I assume other personnel in other departments are equally outraged. 

-- 
Nat B. Frazer, Professor and Chair 
Department of Wildlife Ecology and Conservation 
Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences 
University of Florida 
PO Box 110430 
Gainesville, FL 32611-0430 
(352) 846-0552 
FAX (352) 392-6984 
FrazerN@wec.ufl.edu

Jeb Bush

-----Original Message----- 
From: Yablonski, Brian [ mailto:brian.yablonski@myflorida.com] 
Sent: Monday, December 03, 2001 10:48 AM 
To: Oviedo, Nina; jeb@jeb.org 
Cc: Branker, Laura; Shanahan, Kathleen; Jimenez, Frank; Dana, Pamella; 
Freedman, Melissa 
Subject: RE: Cong Putnam/TPA 

I assume right now, florida agriculture community is biggest opponent of 
this.  if that assumption is correct, i would suggest doing a separate short 
paragraph to address the governor's intention to advocate for terms that 
will protect florida growers against unfair trade practices such as dumping, 
etc.  or, even better, is there anything we can say now, such as the 
president has assured us that they will vigorously protect against unfair 
trade practices.  i don't know what conversations we have had with 
administration on this. 

by way of history, Clinton promised to protect florida growers from dumping 
as part of their "look the other way" support on NAFTA.  Clinton then did 
little to help once the dumping began.  Growers are weary of similar 
overtures from new administration and similar failure to follow through.  we 
need to assure them that this is not the Clinton admininstration and that 
they will take dumping and other unfair trade practices very seriously. 
-----Original Message----- 
From: Nina Oviedo [ mailto:oviedon@sso.org] 
Sent: Friday, November 30, 2001 2:55 PM

Subject: RE: Cong Putnam/TPA 


Team----Attached is the proposed letter on TPA.  Pls review very 
carefully---you know the players far better than us. 
Frank/Laura----if Gov approves, who has lead on finalizing? 

Governor-----According to Hill polling by the National Journal, only 5 of 
our 23 Members are solidly behind TPA.  1 leans yes; 7 are undecided; 5 lean 
no and 2 are solidly against; 3 are unknown.  Across the board, WH does not 
have the votes yet...rumors are that they're short 30 votes.  But, there are 
lots of "leanings" and undecideds still out.   The vote is scheduled for 
Thursday, Dec 6.  See below re delegation. 

Solid Yes-----Diaz-Balart, Goss, Keller, Dan Miller, Shaw 

Lean Yes-----Crenshaw 

Undecided----Boyd, Davis, Meek, Hastings, Young, Jeff Miller, Mica 

Lean No------Brown, Putnam, Deutsch, Stearns, Foley 

Solid No-----Thurman, Wexler 

Unknown----Bilirakis, Ros-Lehtinen, Weldon

From:	Roberto Veliz <veliz@bellsouth.net>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 4, 2001 7:56 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Final Closure & Sentencing Hearing

Dear Governor Bush, 

I just wanted to inform you of the final outcome of Mayra's case.  The 
judge agreed to the state's plea bargain for the defendant to serve two 
years followed by 4 yrs. of probation.  I can only say that I felt and 
still feel that this was not a justifiable plea for the severity of the 
crime committed.  However, I accept the final decision and I feel that 
at least I did everything in my power to increase and/or obtain some 
time of prison punishment for this defendant.  I know that Mayra would 
be proud of me.  Please note that I am extremely grateful to you and 
your staff for their support and professionalism.  Once again, if you 
should need my assistance during your re-election campaign and/or for 
anything else, please do not hesitate to contact me.  I will always be 
grateful to you and your staff.  Words cannot express my gratitude. 
Respectfully, Mayra Capote.

Subject:	Update!

Good "Evening Governor! 
Great job today at the Prevention Conference!  The NBC affliate ran a lengthy 
piece on the evening news on the Oxycontin issue and also covered the 
conference.  Mrs. Bush's speech this afternoon was great.  She was the only 
first lady to receive a standing ovation and it was apparent that she has 
made a great impression on the workers in the field.  The same station also 
covered your trip to Disney and the Operation Paycheck site.  Good coverage! 

Excellent news late in the day -- Judge Moreno threw out most of Giever's law 
suit in his ruling on our motion to dismiss.  I know that you get sick of the 
legal side of things -- but this is huge.  His ruling is precedential and if 
eventually upheld in an appellate court will give states the ability to do 
their job and protect kids rather than litigate.  Gievers has 21 days to 
re-file.  It will be interesting to see how the press handles this tomorrow.  
We are getting it done! 

Get some much needed rest tonight -- it was a great day for Florida.

From:	farrardm@bellsouth.ney
Sent:	Tuesday, December 4, 2001 7:02 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	CUTTING SCHOOLS' BUDGETS

This message was sent to you by Davud Farrar using the E-Mail To A Friend feature on The Miami Herald http://www.miami.com/herald 

A message from Davud Farrar: 

Dear Govenor, 

Below is my response to the Herald's 12/04/01 article. I hope it gets printed. 

ex animo 
davidfarrar 

Re: Cutting Schools Budgets, 12/04/01 

To the Editors, 

TEACHERS RECENT PAY RAISES 

Under the fiscal crisis our school system is now under, I can well understand why so many people -- including the Heralds editorial staff -- believe it is best to allow the threat of pay raise rescission motivate School Board officials into finally cleaning up its fiscal bungling. But no such thing will happen. What will happen is a wholesale raid on the classroom in order to protect the teachers pay raises, i.e. the 10 percent reduction in the schools operating budgets, while mounting a propaganda campaign, with the implicit help of the Miami Herald, to convince us nothing of significance has been taken out of the classroom. 

Classroom teachers will have to make do with less under this scenario but they will have their pay raises and School Board officials and teachers union lobbyist will be armed with plenty of political cannon fodder to successfully attack politicians in the spring for not supporting public education. This has been the tried and true way School Board officials have used pending fiscal deficits in the past to secure future funding without the need to seriously address their fiscal mismanagement.  Of course, the losers in all of this are public school students themselves. 

This scenario will most certainly be played out again unless something is done to break the cycle. What is needed is to separate teachers pay raises from schools operating budgets and require any pay raises to be won or lost at the ballot box. Teachers should be accountable locally for their pay raise.  They should give up their recent pay raises and focus in on winning a pay-raise ballot initiative -- led to victory, hopefully, by the new Superintendent

We have a wonderful chance here for the people of this school district to inject real accountability into their pubic school system.  All we need is a little leadership from our School Board and, dare I say it, the Miami Herald's editorial staff.  

ex animo 
davidfarrar 




-------------------------------------------------------------------- 
Published Tuesday, December 4, 2001 

CUTTING SCHOOLS' BUDGETS 

DIFFICULT CHOICES, RESPONSIBLE DECISIONS     In anticipation of losing millions from their budgets to help cope with the state's budget crisis, public schools in Broward and Miami-Dade counties are considering significant and painful spending cuts. In both cases, however, administrators are taking sensible approaches that target nonessential programs while protecting basic education. 

-------------------------------------------------------------------- 
The full article will be available on the Web for a limited time: 
http://www.miami.com/herald/content/opinion/editorials/digdocs/045658.htm 
-------------------------------------------------------------------- 

(c) 2001 The Miami Herald and wire service sources.  All Rights Reserved.
