From:	zztp1 <zztp1@netzero.net>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 4, 2001 6:11 PM
To:	wendy.berger@myflorida.com
Cc:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Response To Your E-Mail

Mrs. Berger,
 
While I agree with most everything your e-mail contained, I must defend my position and responses to a certain degree. Yes you have spoken with me as stated, yes I do feel that your involvement DID influence to Sheriff to FINALLY investigate  the "pavillion" matter. In fact, the Gibbs family moved out last week end, most likely due to this pressure. However, as far as my own personal harassment by the Sheriff and now the County still continues daily as in :
TODAY - 2 PM a code enforcement officer came to my home , told me I did not have an occupational license, refused to look at the license I attempted to show him, threatened to take me to court, and finally said I assulted him, called the Sheriff and now I wait to see if the State's Attorney files 3rd Degree Felony charges against me for this phony stunt. This is not all .... since last we spoke I have been followed by Sheriff vehicles at close range (10 ft) for 4-5 miles, disregarding those who passed us at speeds beyond the posted limit, just to harass me. My phone is suspect to an illegal wire tap, the Sheriff's dept. spends a lot of time here on occasion, but they do so to question people coming and going if "they are happy with the Sheriff's Dept visibility, and are they happy with their Crime Watch Chairman" .... ME ! This hardly constitutes stepped up patrols. They told one newspaper that my whole reason for doing this was because I did not like children AND I am running for an office and there's Much More. I called you after T'giving but got no response. I am under fire & I need help...  When there's no response, I tend to think the worst. I got your e-mail Sunday nite. I called McLaughlin both Monday & today, and left messages. No Response yet. It's hard to have faith in anyone if they don't call you back, especially when you are faced with these types of problems, just for trying to clean up your community.
I hope to hear from you. Just keep in mind, each day is quite an event for me! I am under attack by those who claim to serve our communitys' best interest. The Sheriff lied to you, harasses me and this community, and we cannot get it stopped. It's not easy to be patient with all this going on.
 
Richard Dissinger 
From:	Center for Education Reform <CER@lb.bcentral.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 4, 2001 6:13 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Education Reform Newswire

The latest news in education from The Center for Education Reform, http://www.edreform.com. 

CER NEWSWIRE 
Vol. 3, No. 47 
December 4, 2001 
__________________________________________ 
* CHARTERS: San Francisco area charters are holding their first symposium to educate the public about their schools and the role they play in bringing genuine education reform to their community. State Board of Education president Reed Hastings and Oakland Mayor Jerry Brown will address the crowd, and school directors will be on hand to answer questions. 

If you're in the area, the event is being held at the Delancy Street Foundation at 600 Embarcadero Street, from 7-9 p.m. Email garyllarson@hotmail.com for more info.

Indianapolis holds great promise for reform as Mayor Bart Peterson's review panel recommends the city's first four charter schools for approval, including two grassroots organizations and two charters partnered with private companies. The move comes just a few days after a rancorous crowd of school district superintendents demanded the legislature put a moratorium on any charters until the state can guarantee  what seems to most people an outrageous demand  that they won't lose money in their districts just because children decide to go to a charter school.

The suggestion that districts should receive money for children they don't educate is foolish, and the district's claims of financial woe might be better targeted toward school improvements and savings. But they fear that given the chance to leave their schools for another choice, many will, which should immediately raise a red flag to any good tax paying Hoosier who thought their money paid for education, not systems. The good news is that the state's legislative leaders of both parties, the governor and even their Washington representatives are wholeheartedly in favor of the charter reform model for public education. 

Go to http://www.projecte.org for more info. 

* TEACHING: Joining the chorus of advocates for alternative certification, the Progressive Policy Institute hosted a forum in Washington last week, where Dr. Rick Hess from the University of Virginia presented his paper, "Tear Down this Wall: The Case for a Radical Overhaul of Teacher Certification." Hess says a new way of recruiting a more expansive pool of talented, qualified individuals to teach our nation's children is necessary. All candidates should possess a college degree, demonstrate mastery of skills on content knowledge exams, and complete a criminal background check. After that, districts should be free to choose qualified individuals. Hess' proposal was applauded by Teach for America president Wendy Kopp, but mildly objected to by David Imig of the American Association of Colleges for Teacher Education and a representative of the school employees union. The AFT rep made little effort to hide her disgust of Hess' new model. 

For the full report, go to: http://www.ppionline.org/documents/teacher_certification.pdf 

* URBAN SCHOOL REFORM: Pennsylvania's plan to take over the Philly schools and allow performance-based contracts with private groups to help turn around the schools has been put on hold until December 21. Those who have a stake in the status quo have turned out to bitterly protest. Meanwhile in Kansas City, sources from the State Board of Education hinted that continued failure to meet performance standards could result in the splitting the district into smaller districts, turning it into a charter district, or a combination of both.

* ACHIEVEMENT: And in case it isn't clear what the fuss is all about in these communities, more evidence of American public education's continued mediocrity comes from another international evaluation of 32 industrialized countries. America's 15-year-olds perform at average levels compared to international peers in demonstrating the ability to apply reading, math and science to real-life situations. Experts have long argued as to the cause of this mediocrity, saying that the application of real learning can come only when students' knowledge is well-ingrained; deep not just wide. Finland, Canada and New Zealand scored above the U.S. in reading. In math, Japan and Korea were among the eight countries scoring higher than the U.S., with five nations significantly below. Other key findings and more details can be found at http://www.latimes.com/news/printedition/asection/la-000096433dec04.story?coll=la%2Dnews%2Da%5Fsection

For the report, go to: http://nces.ed.gov/surveys/pisa/ 
------------ 
The CER Newswire may be redistributed in its entirety with proper attribution. If you have been forwarded this message from a friend and would like to subscribe to receive future Newswires, you can join at http://www.edreform.com/newswire.htm.

The CER Newswire is published by The Center for Education Reform, the nation's leading authority on school reform. CER is dedicated to making schools better for America's children by improving educational access and excellence for all. CER works with parents, teachers and policymakers to advance meaningful education improvement initiatives. For more information on CER and education reform, visit our website at http://www.edreform.com.

From: Yablonski, Brian [ mailto:brian.yablonski@myflorida.com]

Subject: RE: Cong Putnam/TPA 

I assume right now, florida agriculture community is biggest opponent of 
this.  if that assumption is correct, i would suggest doing a separate short 
paragraph to address the governor's intention to advocate for terms that 
will protect florida growers against unfair trade practices such as dumping, 
etc.  or, even better, is there anything we can say now, such as the 
president has assured us that they will vigorously protect against unfair 
trade practices.  i don't know what conversations we have had with 
administration on this. 

by way of history, Clinton promised to protect florida growers from dumping 
as part of their "look the other way" support on NAFTA.  Clinton then did 
little to help once the dumping began.  Growers are weary of similar 
overtures from new administration and similar failure to follow through.  we 
need to assure them that this is not the Clinton admininstration and that 
they will take dumping and other unfair trade practices very seriously.

> position be in Enterprise Florida with our supervision; however, upon

> Enterprise would want to oversee the position and they no nothing about

>        -----Original Message----- 
>       From:   Mattingly, Rebecca  
>       Sent:   Friday, March 30, 2001 5:47 AM 
>       To:     Shanahan, Kathleen 
>       Subject:        RE: Los Angeles Representative 
> 
>       Kathleen: 
> 
>       I know that you have requested more information from Ken Allman on 
> this. Please allow me to bring further perspective to this. 
> 
>       The previous administration fully funded an LA representative as an 
> FTE.  Unfortunately, that administration allowed the state film office to 
> deteriorate to utter ruin.  The previous operation was the Florida 
> Entertainment Industry Council, which operated as a direct support 
> organization under contract to OTTED.  Due to mismanagement, law breaking 
> and other sordid activities, the former Florida Entertainment Industry 
> Council (FEIC) was abolished, the contract cancelled.  The state suffered 
> extreme embarrassment in the media and loss of business.  The industry 
> became disorganized, emotional and dysfunctional.  This is the hole that 
> I've been digging from, the mess that I've had to clean up.  There is 
> plenty of documentation to provide the ugly details of the entire debacle 
> in OTTED and in the Chief Inspector General's Office. 
> 
>       The only thing that continued to "work" effectively was the LA 
> representative.  In 1995-96, after the abolishment of the FEIC, the local 
> film offices pooled their tiny resources to continue funding this 
> operation.  Florida was the first state to have a local market 
> rep.;however, she stayed the course.  The local film offices formed an 
> association called the Florida Film Commissioners Association (FFCA). 
> Susan went unpaid many times simply because the resources were not there. 
> To increase funding for the LA operation, the FFCA broadened its 
> membership to include more industry participation.  They became known as 
> Film Florida  Association.  
> 
>       Needless to say that after all of this occurred, no one in the 
> industry, nor any local film office had much trust in state government. 
> The industry was apathetic, membership in groups and associations dropped. 
> The Governor and others from EOG met with many industry professionals and 
> local film offices to get their input on creating a new film office. He 
> also went to LA to meet with top studio professionals, as well as with 
> Susan Simms to discuss this issue.  When I and the new Florida Film 
> Advisory Council came along, our initial position on the matter of a rep 
> in LA was that yes, Florida needed to continue this initiative.  We 
> believed that the responsibility of operating any field office was the 
> state's, regardless of where it is.  Film Florida did not want any part of 
> this idea at first.  They wanted us to prove that we could be trusted.  I 
> talked to the Governor to get his opinion. His suggestion was to not "take 
> over" but to work with them in a cooperative manner, since it was them 
> "who saved Rome when Rome was burning."  Susan continued on as a Film 
> Florida employee.  We worked with her on projects and maintained 
> communication. 
> 
>       Months and months of proving ourselves and negotiations have since 
> occured. During that time, Film Florida experienced financial problems and 
> found that they could no longer support the LA representative.  We (Film 
> Commission & Advisory Council) reiterated that we believed it is the 
> responsibility of the state film office to support all field offices 
> outside of Florida.  We arrived at a middle ground, a testing ground,  via 
> the short-term SNAPs agreement.  We contracted with Film Florida 
> specifically for LA representative services.  We agreed that after this 
> short term agreement, we would assess the situation and make a decision to 
> move forward in a manner that was best for the state.  Film Florida, the 
> local film offices and the Advisory Council agreed that it was best to 
> return the responsibility of operating the LA field office back to the 
> state film office.  Recognizing that the we would not received any 
> additional FTE's, I worked with Ken and Catherine Heth in Purchasing to 
> come up with a way to obtain an employee-employer set up for this 
> operation, which is why we went with the OPS recommendation. 
> 
>       So essentially, since 1993-94, Susan Simms has represented Florida, 
> our only consistent outreach over the years.  Kathleen, I am certainly 
> willing to do whatever it takes at this point to move this initiative 
> forward. Clearly, I recognize that this is your call; however, I must 
> express that we've finally got everyone who has a say in agreement after 
> an entire year of back and forth talks.  My fear is that if we change our 
> minds now on this, or waiver, we will send the wrong message.  In 
> addition, Susan will be left in limbo and without employment as the 
> expectation has always been that this transition into the state film 
> office would occur. 
> 
>       Thank you for indulging me by reading this.  I look forward to 
> receiving your decision. 
> 
>       RDM 
>

From:	Manzano, Jesse <jesse.manzano@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 4, 2001 5:35 PM

Subject:	RE: Farmworker meeting memo

There were no representatves of the Coalition of Immokalee Workers. The 
groups represented were the Farmworker Self-Help Inc. (Pasco) , Farmworker 
Association of Florida (Apopka) and the United Farm Workers of America 
(Quincy). However, these 3 groups (plus the Coalition) have joined together 
to form the 'Farmworkers United for Justice', a group to serve as a 
collective lobby for all of them.

From:	nunya <da@digitalexp.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 4, 2001 5:35 PM
To:	president@whitehouse.gov
Cc:	lawson.alfred.web@leg.state.fl.us; kendrick4house@msn.com; Jeb Bush; bobgraham@senate.gov; billnelson@senate.gov; tammy.mcathley@mail.house.gov
Subject:	We need help

Importance:	High

 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
Sandra Allen
P. O. Box 935
Eastpoint, FL 32328
(850) 670-4185
 
George W. Bush
1600 Pennsylvania Ave.
Washington, DC 20500
 
December 4, 2001
 
Dear Mr. President:
 
My husband and I are commercial oyster harvesters born and raised in Franklin County, Florida.  We harvest oysters on the Apalachicola Bay, and we have been stricken with drought conditions, small craft advisories and red tide for the past two and a half months.  Due to these extreme conditions we have unable to work because of bay closures, high winds and slack sales of our product due to bad press.  Small portions of our bay have recently been opened for harvest but sales have drastically been reduced due to unfavorable press releases thus customers fear of our product.  
Governor Bush has declared our county a financial disaster, which brought in little true financial assistance to the seafood workers of this area.  The only thing that I could find that would actually assist some in our community was SBA loans, but when the bay closes again for harvest that will be another bill we will not be able to pay added to the ones we already have. 
I applied for financial assistance on November 22, 2001 and yet to get an appointment.  I have given the HRS my life history and still they want more paper work. Forgive me for being nave to the system but this is my first time asking for any state assistance.  I was under the impression that when you apply for assistance after a disaster was declared you would get assistance before the next year.  I have qualified for food stamps but no financial aid for my bills that are now due.   I had to borrow money in order for my bills to be up to date last month- and now they are due again.  This was a loan, not an income; it will have to be paid back, but thats not how HRS saw it.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
I have written to Governor Bush in formal letters and informally through email and yet to get a reply from him or his office.  I have also sent carbon copies to all my elected state officials and only one has responded to my pleas for help. Will Kendrick is our State Representative and he is the only person to acknowledge me in anyway.  I have spoken with him many times in reference to this issue and he is very concerned about our area.
He is only one person and he can only do so much alone.  We need your help!

Im attaching the letters I have written to the Governor and also the ones that I have written to Mr. Kendrick.  If there are any questions please feel free to call me anytime. 
 
Sincerely,
 
Sandra Allen
 
 
cc:        Jeb Bush
            Will Kendrick
            Al Lawson
            Bill Nelson
            Allen Boyd

-----Original Message----- 
From: Yablonski, Brian [ mailto:brian.yablonski@myflorida.com] 
Sent: Monday, December 03, 2001 10:48 AM 
To: Oviedo, Nina; jeb@jeb.org 
Cc: Branker, Laura; Shanahan, Kathleen; Jimenez, Frank; Dana, Pamella; 
Freedman, Melissa 
Subject: RE: Cong Putnam/TPA 

I assume right now, florida agriculture community is biggest opponent of 
this.  if that assumption is correct, i would suggest doing a separate short 
paragraph to address the governor's intention to advocate for terms that 
will protect florida growers against unfair trade practices such as dumping, 
etc.  or, even better, is there anything we can say now, such as the 
president has assured us that they will vigorously protect against unfair 
trade practices.  i don't know what conversations we have had with 
administration on this. 

by way of history, Clinton promised to protect florida growers from dumping 
as part of their "look the other way" support on NAFTA.  Clinton then did 
little to help once the dumping began.  Growers are weary of similar 
overtures from new administration and similar failure to follow through.  we 
need to assure them that this is not the Clinton admininstration and that 
they will take dumping and other unfair trade practices very seriously. 
-----Original Message-----

Governor-----According to Hill polling by the National Journal, only 5 of 
our 23 Members are solidly behind TPA.  1 leans yes; 7 are undecided; 5 lean 
no and 2 are solidly against; 3 are unknown.  Across the board, WH does not 
have the votes yet...rumors are that they're short 30 votes.  But, there are 
lots of "leanings" and undecideds still out.   The vote is scheduled for 
Thursday, Dec 6.  See below re delegation. 

Solid Yes-----Diaz-Balart, Goss, Keller, Dan Miller, Shaw 

Lean Yes-----Crenshaw 

Undecided----Boyd, Davis, Meek, Hastings, Young, Jeff Miller, Mica 

Lean No------Brown, Putnam, Deutsch, Stearns, Foley 

Solid No-----Thurman, Wexler 

Unknown----Bilirakis, Ros-Lehtinen, Weldon

FLORIDA PUBLIC SERVICE COMMISSION ELECTS NEW CHAIRMAN 

TALLAHASSEE The Florida Public Service Commission (PSC or Commission) 
today elected Commissioner Lila A. Jaber to serve as Chairman for the 
two-year term, beginning January 2002. 

Commissioner Jaber was first appointed to the PSC by Florida Governor 
Jeb Bush in February 2000 to complete a term ending in January 2001. She 
was reappointed by Governor Bush for a term ending January 2005. 

Her term as Chairman will begin with a ceremony at the January 8, 2001, 
PSC Commission Agenda Conference. The ceremony will commence at 9:00 
a.m., in Room 148 of the Betty Easley Conference Center, located at 2540 
Shumard Oak Boulevard, in Tallahassee. 


# # #

From:	PeggyStanton@aol.com
Sent:	Tuesday, December 4, 2001 4:38 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	No Subject

Dear Governor Bush: 

Just a quick refresher ..this is the third year I have alerted you to Kids 
for Peace Pilgrimage Week which, this year runs all this week, Dec. 3-7. 

Last year, if you recall, the children wrote letters to the President 
suggesting how he could bring peace and reconcile the country after such a 
tortuous election and we sent copies, at your request, to you. You were kind 
enough to send a handwritten note which meant a lot to the children. 

I have just heard your brother today suggesting that Americans pray that God 
will put a protective shield over America. He should know that there are 71 
Kids for Peace Schools throughout the nation praying...somewhere between 35 
and 40,000 children. They are also selling a bumper sticker created by a 5 
year old which reads "Peace, please! Do it for us kids - Tommy". The profits 
are being sent to the President's Afghan children's fund. 

Florida once again leads the nation in little peace pilgrims...some 20,000 in 
this state alone, with Pennsylvania second and Texas a distant third. 

Schools were urged to invite you to one of their events this week. I hope 
they did as seeing is believing. My husband, who served with your father in 
Congress and has seen a great deal, said he was "overwhelmed" by a pilgrimage 
he attended in Miami. Mrs. Don Shula who is on our board is greatly 
responsible for 26 schools in Miami-Dade county becoming Kids for Peace 
schools. 

If you wish to follow the week through the Internet, please visit our 
website..www.peacethroughlove.org and click on FrontPageNews 

Bill and I send best regards to your Mom and Dad. Your brother is in our 
prayers everyday. 

Peace! 

Peggy Stanton 
  

From:	Marstiller, Simone <simone.marstiller@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 4, 2001 4:28 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	McDonough, Jim
Subject:	Drug Treatment Initiative Oral Argument on 12/10/01

Governor: 

As you know, we filed a brief in the Fla. Supreme Court on your behalf 
opposing the drug treatment initiative.  Oral argument is scheduled for 
Monday, Dec. 10 at 9:00 a.m.  We requested oral argument when the brief was 
filed in order to preserve the opportunity.  However, four of the five 
parties opposing the initiative -- including the EOG -- are scheduled to 
argue and have been alotted 5 minutes each.  The other parties' briefs -- 
especially that of Save Our Society from Drugs -- largely cover the same 
territory covered in our brief, although they make additional arguments, as 
well.  Because of the overlap, and because FDLE and the Prosecuting 
Attorneys Assn can adequately advance the concerns of the executive branch, 
we propose waiving or yielding our time to the other parties to best utilize 
the time given to the initiative's opponents collectively. 

Please let me know whether you agree or disagree.  Thank you. 

Simone Marstiller 
Legal Affairs

Scheduled to follow up with specific site recommendations Dec 17.  Tentative site evaluation visit Jan. 21 - 22.  Our contact is Russ Lockridge, VP, HR.  Fun guy on the phone.  I mentioned Manny Fernandez (Director, Executive Committee, Chair Corporate Governance committee) ... Russ said he was with him yesterday.  I am not absolutely sure if he (Fernandez) knows about "Orbit", but if he should bring it up to you, put your best sales pitch on him.  [Key criteria: a class A office building (will lease)on the water within a walk to a marina where they can show off 8 to 16 products, in a community with good airport, quality of life and good schools, and incentives are important. Two phases: 1) 50 employees, early next year and 2) additional 150 employees, summer '03]

 -----Original Message-----
From: Jeb Bush [mailto:jeb@jeb.org]
Sent: Monday, December 03, 2001 9:16 PM
To: Steve Mayberry
Subject: RE: CONFIDENTIAL: Prospect follow up



thank you Steve for your followup. David Struhs is prepared to speak to the company should it be necessary. 
 

Jeb Bush 

***********************************************************
Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law.
Most written communications to or from state officials
regarding state business are public records available to the

-----Original Message-----
From: Steve Mayberry [mailto:SMayberry@floridabusiness.com]
Sent: Monday, December 03, 2001 6:09 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: Pam Dana (E-mail); John Anderson; Roger Miller
Subject: CONFIDENTIAL: Prospect follow up



Regarding the prospect you called me about this morning: 

After researching the company and recent history in Florida, I called the 
contact the CEO gave you. We had a brief conversation before he had to 
leave, but he will get back to me this evening or tomorrow. I also left a 
message for Stu Turley, to let him know you had followed up and see what 
else he could tell me.  

Here's a stroke of luck that we may, if we get the chance, use at the right 
time:  Manny Fernandez (Gartner, UF Trustee) is on the prospects Board, 
their executive committee, and chairs their "Corporate Governance" 
committee. 

Regarding the permitting issues, I spent considerable time getting briefed 
by their local attorneys, Wade Hopping and Gary Hunter. I asked Gary to 
provide me with a written summary of their issues which will probably be 
more accurate than my retelling of the story.  Hopefully, the client will 
allow this, and you can use it to assess the situation.  This is one side of 
the story, and I am sure DEP has a different perspective. 

The permitting problem that I was aware of when you called me had to do with 
the company not getting air permits before they began an expansion about 2 
years ago. They were under the impression that their existing permits would 
be sufficient.  That situation was corrected.  [FYI: this is a "Title V" air 
emission facility....fiberglass emissions are a bit nasty.] 

More recently they have had problems with manatees and US Fish and Wildlife 
and local manatee clubs.  I am told the company has asked for help from your 
office to get US F & W  to respect Florida rules (speed) within the barge 
canal.  This issue has been very difficult for them, and remains a problem. 

But they are really unhappy about the "raid" you mentioned.  And if their 
lawyers account is reasonably accurate, they have every reason to be. 
Apparently a busload of DEP law enforcement officers, complete with flack 
jackets and guns, with press there to witness, descended upon one of their 
plants in response to a caller who alleged they were dumping hazardous 
waste.  DEP reps apparently mentioned to the press, and they reported, that 
this was a "criminal investigation" involving "suspected felonies".  That 
was in February, '01.  My understanding is that prior to the "raid", when 
the company first heard about the allegations, they did their own testing 
(after informing DEP in case they wanted to witness) and found nothing.  And 
apparently DEP didn't either.  The company feels their reputation was 
needlessly damaged and that the whole thing was mishandled.  

So, we have a lot to overcome to convince the CEO to invest more in Florida. 


Steve Mayberry 
Senior Vice President 
ENTERPRISE 
FLORIDA, Inc. 
The Atrium Building, Suite 201 
325 John Knox Road 
Tallahassee, Florida 32303 
850.488.6300 FAX 850.922.9595 



From:	Dempsey, Hayden <Hayden.Dempsey@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 4, 2001 4:04 PM
To:	Jeb Bush; Brogan, Frank; Shanahan, Kathleen; Turbeville, Greg
Cc:	Florez, Alan
Subject:	The Plan

Spoke with Paul.  The House will publish the Margarden and Detert bills 
tonight for first reading.  The bills will be taken up on second reading 
tomorrow.  Tomorrow the House will take up bills in the following order: 
Security, conforming cut bills, Maygarden bill, and finally the Detert bill. 
The House will lay the Detert bill on the table and take up the companion, 
the Pruitt bill.  If possible, they will roll all bills to third reading 
tomorrow and pass them out.  If can't get 2/3's to roll to third, they bill 
pass these bills Thursday.  The Detert deferral bill is closed; no 
amendments will be allowed. 

Spoke to Chairman Goodlette re: capitol security.  Relayed your concerns 
with commission.  He appreciated.  Said this was being driven by Speaker's 
office.  Discussed your concerns with Paul.  No resolution in sight. 

Building codes.  Paul suggests you discuss your concerns with the Speaker. 
He thinks Speaker inclined to accept bill. 

Kid Care: Medicaid bill up in House tomorrow.  I expressed our concern with 
the local match requirements.  He said he would raise with Speaker.  The LG 
is meeting this afternoon with Silver and Murman at 4:30. 

From:	Karen Kellams <KellamsK@dor.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 4, 2001 3:44 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Updates

Governor, 
I wanted to share some information on a few cases that you had referred 
to us: 

We are getting regular payments for a custodial parent in Casselbury 
but we have to continue to seek assistance from Pennsylvania's child 
support agency because the noncustodial parent pays less than 
court-ordered.  The children are over 18 but the father owes more than 
$130,000 in arrears!  The custodial parent knows we're doing all that we 
can and that we will continue with our efforts. 

I'm still plugging away on the case with Ms. Calloway.  It's an 
interesting one.  We've been able to collect over $10,000 on her behalf 
in the last year from court-ordered purges.  The father still won't pay 
on a regular basis but Ms. Calloway knows we are still plugging away... 

On a very good note, one of the cases you referred to us from a mother 
who wrote to you from North Carolina about a year ago reached a 
successful conclusion.  The noncustodial parent paid $15,000 to the 
custodial parent a few weeks ago to pay off all the back child support 
owed.  She was very happy to get this money.  This case is now closed. 

On another note, I know that Jim appreciates your support of the 
Department's proposal to implement an administrative support process. 
Many of the calls and e-mails I receive are from frustrated parents 
waiting for their cases to go to hearing.   Anything that can be done to 
make the establishment process more efficient will improve our level of 
service.  

I wish you and your family a very happy holiday season, 
Karen Kellams

-----Original Message-----
From: Dawn Taylor [mailto:dawna@dotstar.net]
Sent: Thursday, November 08, 2001 4:34 PM
To: Govenor Jeb Bush
Subject: Parent with a question


Dear Governor Bush,
I have corresponded with you many times and am always greatful to your office for an answer to questions I have.
I am not versed in all the avenues that the legislature works, but I am trying to learn.
As I have told you before, I have a child with a disability and he is my center of focus most of the time.
Recently I ran across a Statute in the 1999 Florida Statutes and State board of Education Rules ( exerpts for Special Programs).
The statute is , or was, 236.145, regarding Residential nonpublic school contract reimbursement.  The  interesting part is a School district may be eligible for 60% of the cost of the contract for a disabled child to attend a private school.
Now, as far as I can tell the law was repealed in 2000, under S1770.
When I looked this up to see why, it said the statute was outdated along with many others, and that the Department of Education said the statute is no longer used.
But, I recently received information from the Department of Education stating that there were many counties that have received this 60% reimbursement for disabled children for the year 99-2000.
What can I do as a citizen, if the bill was passed under the pretense of nonuse, when in fact that was not true?
This statute could be very valuable for families that need private placement. Even though the McKay scholarships are around now, which was a wonderful idea, there are not any schools that will accept my child.
I hope you understand my question and can provide me with a direction.
Sincerely, Dawn Taylor
3428 Bowker Drive
Pensacola, Fl 32506

>  -----Original Message----- 
> From:         Coker, Travis [ mailto:Travis.Coker@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US] 
> Sent: Tuesday, December 04, 2001 12:08 PM 
> To:   OPB Committee Coverage Group; OPB Public Safety 
> Subject:      Senate Criminal Justice          December 4, 2001        37 
> LL SOB     9:00 am 
> 
> Meeting Logistics 
> Committee: Criminal Justice (S) Analyst: Travis Coker Unit: 
> PSU   Date: 12/04/2001 Time: 09:00 AM Location: 37 LL-SOB (Room A)    
> 
> Meeting Description 
> Topic: Criminal Justice Keywords: Criminal Justice    
> 
> Announcements 
> The meeting was called to order by Chairman Crist at 9:10 am.  In 
> attendance were Senators: Futch, Meek, Smith and Wise. 
> Future Meetings/Bills considered 
> The first bill discussed was SB 56 C by Senator Cowin.  SB 56 C provides 
> that it is a second degree misdemeanor for any person to prohibit the 
> display of the United States flag.  The bill was amended to prescribe the 
> first, second and third offenses.  A first offense carries a fine not to 
> exceed $5,000 and the second offense carries a fine not to exceed $10,000. 
> The third offense provides for a $10,000 fine.  It was amended without 
> objection.  
> 
> The bill received an unanimously favorable vote. 
> 
> The next bill discussed was SB 196 by Senator Villalobos.  SB 196 relates 
> to the exclusionary rule.  The exclusionary rule operates as a judicially 
> created remedy designed to safeguard against violations of 4th Amendment 
> rights.   The bill amends the evidence code to prohibit the application of 
> the exclusionary rule in a case where a law enforcement officer makes an 
> arrest based upon reasonable reliance upon information from the Division 
> of Drivers Licenses or Dept. of Motor Vehicles.  The bill allows that if 
> the information from the state agency is incorrect , evidence from an 
> arrest (based on that info) shall not be suppressed by the application of 
> the exclusionary rule.   It was amended with one technical amendment 
> without objection.  
> 
> The bill received a unanimously favorable vote. 
> 
> The next bill discussed was SB 106 by Senator Smith.  SB 106 relates to 
> the Criminal Punishment Code.  The Criminal Punishment Code requires that 
> a scoresheet be used to compute a sentencing score for each felony 
> offender whose offense was committed on or after October 1, 1998.  The 
> bill amends current law to allow the court to impose a sentence without 
> the scoresheet if the state and the defendant waive its preparation.  The 
> scoresheet must be prepared and filed within 14 days after sentencing. 
>  
> The bill received a unanimously favorable vote. 
> 
> The next bill discussed was SB 174 by Senator Smith.  Senator Smith made a 
> motion to Temporarily Postpone the bill. SB 174 was Temporarily Postponed 
> without objection. 
> 
> The next bill discussed was SB 302 by Senator Burt.  Senator Smith made a 
> motion to Temporarily Postpone the bill. SB 302 was Temporarily Postponed 
> without objection. 
> 
> The next bill discussed was SB 394 by the Criminal Justice Committee.  SB 
> 394 reenacts the public records exemption in s. 914.27 F.S., for 
> information that discloses information about a victim or a person in the 
> witness protection program held by: 
>  a state or local law enforcement agency; 
> state attorney; 
> statewide prosecutor; 
> Victim and Witness Protection Review Committee or 
> FDLE.  
>  
> The bill received a unanimously favorable vote. 
> 
> The next bill discussed was SB 396 by the Criminal Justice Committee.  SB 
> 396 reenacts s. 944.031 F.S., which authorizes the Florida Violent Crime 
> and Drug Control Council to close to the public that portion of any 
> meeting of the Council in which active criminal intelligence information 
> or active criminal investigation is presented and discussed. 
> 
> The bill received a unanimously favorable vote. 
> 
> The next bill discussed was SB 408 by Senator Crist.  SB 408 would amend 
> the laws describing the power and duties of the Secretary of the 
> Department of Corrections (DOC).  The bill was amended by a strike all 
> amendment.  The bill was adopted with Senator Meek dissenting.  The bill 
> allows for the DOC Secretary to designate persons within the DOC Inspector 
> General Office to have arrest authority as well as investigative duties 
> for offenses within prison facilities and extending outside the property 
> bounds in the case of an escape.  The bill exempts privately operated 
> prison facilities.  There were concerns from Senator Meek about 
> correctional officers making accusations against other officers and 
> possible abuses of such powers.  He continued to say that he has real 
> fears of the character and quality of the DOC investigating and policing 
> itself.  The bill is reported to alleviate a strain upon local law 
> enforcement agencies such as Sheriff agencies.  The bill would allow the 
> DOC to designate a person that would have arrest authority in a case such 
> as a civilian/visitor to a facility and found to have drugs in an attempt 
> to smuggle them in to an inmate.  In the past, a local police department 
> or sheriff deputy would have to be called.  
> 
> Senator Meek asked John Washington of the DOC, how many instances of this 
> have occurred?  Mr. Washington replied he did not know, but he would find 
> out and get that information to him. 
> 
> The bill is supported by the Sheriffs Assn. The PBA, the Police Chiefs 
> Assn. and the DOC. 
> 
> The bill received a favorable vote with Senator Meek dissenting. 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> Presentations unrelated to Bills 
> 
> Media Present 
> 
> Other items of Interest 
> 
> 
> 
> History Section 
>

> 12/04/2001 11:54:35 AM        Document saved - Travis Coker 
> 12/04/2001 12:06:16 PM        Document saved - Travis Coker

> 
>       Senate Session 12/3/01 
>       3:00 PM to completion of the day's business 
> 
>               1.      Call to Order - 3:01 PM 
>               2.      Roll Call - 39 members present 
>               3.      Prayer - by Sen Wasserman-Schulz 
>               4.      Reports of Committees - none 
>               5.      Motions Relating to Committee Reference - none 
>               6.      Messages from the Governor and Other Executive 
> Communications - none 
>               7.      Messages from the House of Representatives - Sen 
> Smith requested adoption of House Resolution 79C 
>                     (Reconciliation Day) to set aside a day of 
> reconciliation on December 4, 2001. Motion ADOPTED by 2/3 vote.  
>               8.      Matters on Reconsideration -none 
>               9.      Consideration of Bills on Third Reading -see below 
>               10.     Special Order as determined by the Committee on 
> Rules and Calendar. 
>                       Sen McKay said the security bills would be taken up 
> first.  
>               11.     Bills on Second Reading - 
>                       Sen Wasserman-Schultz requested SB 82C re: Economic 
> Stimulus be taken up.  Referred to Committee 
>                       on Commerce & Economic Opportunities and 
> Appropriations Committee. 
>                       Sen Pruitt requested SB 80-C relating to intangible 
> tax exemptions be taken up.  Referred to Committee 
>                       on Finance & Taxation. 
>               12.     Correction and approval of Journal - no corrections; 
> journal approved 
> 
>        Bills on Third Reading 
>           SB 6C Terrorism/Pretrial Detention  
>                       Defines "terrorism" in the Florida Criminal Code; 
> provides for pretrial detention of persons charged with act of terrorism 
>                       Unlike the federal definition, the state definition 
> requires actual intent 
> 
>                       AMENDMENT 255718 by Sen Smith corrects title to 
> "Florida Criminal Code"  ADOPTED 
> 
>                       Sen Brown-Waite stated that the state's definition, 
> unlike the federal definition, requires actual intent.  
>                       PASSED UNANIMOUSLY 
>                            
>           SB 8C Sentencing/Act of Terrorism  
>                       Sen Brown-Waite introduced bill that reclassifies 
> acts, which facilitate or further terrorism as a felony.  No debate. 
>                       PASSED UNANIMOUSLY  
> 
>           CS/SB 10C Poisoning   
>                       Prohibits introduction, addition or mingling of any 
> poison, bacterium, radioactive material, virus, chemical compound, or 
> specified products into food, drink, medicine, or water systems and 
> provides penalties 
> 
>                       Sen Brown-Waite said the bill extended merely 
> extended the statute to cover poisoning.  Many people thought we already 
> had this on the books, but we don't. 
>                       PASSED UNANIMOUSLY  
> 
>            SB 12C Communications Interception  
>                       Adds aircraft piracy to list of crimes for which 
> interception of communications may be authorized; adds solicitation to 
> commit certain offenses to list of crimes; allows judge, in investigations 
> of acts of terrorism, to authorize continued interception anywhere within 
> state of wire, oral, or electronic communications under specified 
> conditions 
> 
>                       Sen Brown-Waite introduced bill making it possible 
> to intercept communications when evidence shows that an act of terrorism 
> is being committed.  
>                       PASSED UNANIMOUSLY 
>           CS/SB 14C Agriculture & Consumer Services Dept.  
>                       Authorizes department to adopt rules/requirements 
> governing aircraft used for aerial application of pesticides and rules for 
> storage requirements 
> 
>                       Sen Gellar noted that the bill authorizes the 
> department to formalize their temporary rules 
> 
>                       AMENDMENT 075920 by Sen Gellar to replace the word 
> "for" with "by"  WITHDRAWN 
> 
>                       Sen Sebesta:  Is this bill supported by the crop 
> dusters?  
>                       Sen Gellar:  Yes. 
> 
>                       Sen Campbell: Some of these crop dusters don't have 
> the money to provide this elaborate security.  Are we regulating crop 
> dusters to financial ruin. 
>                       Sen Gellar:  This is a toned-down version of the 
> original bill.   
> 
>       PASSED (37 yeas, 1 nay) 
>                           
>           CS/SB 16C Public Records/Security System Plans 
>                       Exempts security-system plans from public records 
> requirements and exempts portions of 
>                       any meeting that would reveal confidential 
> security-system plan 
> 
>                       AMENDMENT 121740 by Sen Smith includes "the physical 
> security of the facility" ADOPTED 
>                       AMENDMENT 461304 by Sen Smith adjusts title 
> ADOPTED 
> 
>                       This bill sponsored by Sen Brown-Waite also covers 
> security system plans owned by private companies used by state agencies. 
> The bill establishes a 2006 repeal date. 
>                       PASSED UNANIMOUSLY 
> 
>           CS/SB 18C Public Records/Emergency Management Plans 
>                       Exempts portions of comprehensive emergency 
> management plan which addresses response of public or private hospital to 
> act of terrorism from public-records requirements 
> 
>                       AMENDMENT 762096 by Sen Smith clarified that 
> responses of a hospital to an act of terrorism is not exempt.  ADOPTED 
>                        
>                       Sen Brown-Waite introduced the bill. 
>                       PASSED UNANIMOUSLY 
>                       
>           CS/SB 20C Public Records/Pharmaceutical  
>                       Information on the amount, type, capacity or 
> location of pharmaceutical materials/ 
>                       supplies/equipment used in response to an act of 
> terrorism, maintained by counties or municipalities that are directed by 
> the Department of Health, are exempt from public records requirements. 
> 
>                       Sen Brown-Waite explained to members that the 
> Committee on Criminal Justice summarily rejected any bill that took the 
> exemption laws too far.  The committee focused on only those areas that 
> truly needed to be kept from public disclosure to protect the safety of 
> citizens. 
> 
>                       AMENDMENTS 330024 and 973674, introduced by Sen 
> Smith clarified that the exemption pertained to information at the local 
> level.  They do not exempt information regarding the state's total overall 
> pharmaceutical purchases.  ADOPTED 
> 
>                       Sen Latvala:  Why is it important to make this bill 
> retroactive? 
>                       Sen Smith: to encompass information that may be 
> slated for use in pending court cases 
>                       Sen Latvala asked if the amendment dealt with the 
> amount of supplies available. 
>                       Sen Smith:  Yes, but only information at the local 
> level, not the state level.    
>                       Sen Villalobos wanted to make sure that the 
> Legislature still had the ability to question agencies about 
> pharmaceuticals as it relates to the budgetary process. 
>                       Sen Smith:  Yes, information at the state level will 
> continue to be forthcoming. 
> 
>                       Although the bill was originally TP'd for further 
> clarification, Sen McKay brought the bill up again later and it PASSED (38 
> yeas, 1 nay).  
> 
>           SB 22C Public Records/Law Enforcement  
>                       Exempts from public information any records obtained 
> from one agency to another when an investigation is ongoing.  Temporarily 
> shields information until investigation is completed. 
>                       Sen Brown-Waite introduced the bill and noted that 
> it sunsets in 2006.   
>                       Sen Cowin:  Will records be available after an 
> investigation is completed? 
>                       Sen Brown-Waite:  Yes.  
> 
>                       PASSED (37 yeas, 1 nay) 
> 
>           SB 24C Domestic Security/Counter-terrorism 
>                       Provides legislative intent re: counter-terrorism 
> efforts & initial responses to acts of terrorism within or affecting the 
> state; requires security assessments of buildings and  facilities owned or 
> leased by state agencies or local governments; requires the Florida 
> Department of Law Enforcement (FDLE) to establish a regional domestic 
> security task force in each FDLE operational region. 
> 
>                       Sen Christ said the bill places the position of 
> Chief of Domestic Security in the law.  
> 
>                       AMENDMENT 440988  deletes the emergency management 
> part of the bill.  ADOPTED 
> 
>                       AMENDMENT 613630 makes FDLE responsible for 
> coordinating the efforts at the state and local level.  ADOPTED 
> 
>                       Sen Rossin:  Does the bill give FDLE authority to 
> direct other coordinating agencies?  Who would be in charge in a local 
> situation?  Would a local deputy take orders from the Chief of Police or 
> from the FDLE?  
>                       Sen Christ:  No, FDLE is directing the coordination, 
> not directing the actual event.  
> 
>                       Sen Wasserman-Schultz:  Have we set up an inherent 
> conflict on the scene?  
>                       Christ:  No, this bill is a coordinated initiative. 
> It does not give FDLE direct supervisory control of all situations.   
> 
>                       Sen Dawson:  Is there anything in this bill or any 
> of our security bills to create uniformity within the state?  Who is in 
> charge for the state to set the rules, guidelines and security measures so 
> the public will know what the rules are? 
>                       Sen Christ:  No, there is no legislation today, but 
> we are creating the task force that will work through this by developing 
> guidelines and procedures.  This legislation does not create the policies; 
> it merely sets up the mechanism for the creation of future policies. 
>                         
>                       Sen Gellar asked if he could enter an amendment to 
> remove the words "and direct" from the bill.   
>                       Sen Browne-Waite:  We need coordination and 
> cooperation between law enforcement agencies. 
> 
>                       Sen Wasserman-Schultz:  When push comes to shove, 
> who would have the final authority - the sheriff or the FDLE? 
>                       Sen Christ:  I believe the Sheriff would have to 
> listen to the FDLE.   
> 
>                       Sen Meek: This language has been approved by all of 
> law enforcement officers and I trust this bill.  
>                       Sen Smith: The bill is simply a mechanism to make 
> the system work well. 
>                       Sen Christ:  In closing, the Senator stated that the 
> bill was a codification of the Governor's Executive Order and will move us 
> forward to a better plan. 
> 
>                       PASSED 
>           SB 26C Domestic Security/Counter-terrorism 
>                       Creates and provides functions of the Florida 
> Domestic Security & Counter-Terrorism Intelligence Center within FDLE; 
> requires Center to create, operate and maintain a statewide database. 
> 
>                       Sen Christ explained that the bill goes further to 
> define what terrorism is and does not change the exemption laws. 
>                       PASSED UNANIMOUSLY  (38 yeas, 0 nays) 
> 
>           SB 28C Public Records/Inspection/Copying 
>                       authorizes delay in inspection or copying of public 
> records under limited circumstances; establishes procedures & standards; 
> limits applicability of provision; provides statement of public necessity 
>                       TP'd by Sen Carlson 
> 
>           SB 30C Compensation of Legislative Members  
>       Introduced by Sen Carlton, the bill eliminates the pay raise for 
> senators. 
>       PASSED (34 yeas, 4 nays) 
> 
>           SB 32C Vessel Registration Fees  
>                       A conforming bill that provides for return of 
> certain vessel registration fees to Florida county; clarifies distribution 
> & uses of funds in Marine Resources Conservation Trust Fund 
> 
>                       Sen Clary introduced the bill.  He explained that 
> legislation passed in 2001 enablinged the counties to collect certain 
> registration fees rather than the Fish & Wildlife Conservation Commission 
> (FWCC).  However, according to Clary, the annual fees ($1.3 million) 
> should go to the Manatee Trust Fund.  The bill does not increase fishing 
> registration fees. 
> 
>                       Sen Campbell:  Why now?  Are we trying to sneak 
> something through during Special Session. 
>                       Sen Clary:  FWCC needs this clarification because of 
> the large cuts that the agency is taking in the Special Session. 
> 
>                       The bill FAILED initially (15 yeas, 20 nays), 
> HOWEVER the bill passed after being reconsidered by the members (see 
> below) 
> 
>                       Sen King requested that the bill be reconsidered. 
> Motion to reconsider passed.  
> 
>                       Sen King:  Prior to last session, the $ had always 
> gone to the FWC.  However during last year's regular session, a bill 
> passed that moved the annual revenues to the counties.  
> 
>                       Sen Miller:  Was the intent last year to send the 
> moneys to the counties? 
>                       Sen Clary defered to Sen King:  FWCC misinterpreted 
> the bill.  However, the intent was to send it to the Manatee Trust Fund.  
> 
>                       Sen Pruitt:  It was never legislative intent for FWC 
> to send the money to the counties.  
>                       Sen Campbell said he was concerned with the 
> precedent that the body was setting.  This is why we have committees.  We 
> should be careful not to try to get bills through that we haven't talked 
> about.  
> 
>                       Sen McKay wants to hear from the Presidents of the 
> Appropriations committee and the Rules committee to ensure that this bill 
> is appropriate to be taken up by this body now.  
> 
>                       PASSED  (30 yeas, 7 nays) 
>           SB 34C Pilot Program/Attorneys Ad Litem  
>                       Introduced by Sen Cowin, the bill provides that the 
> Attorneys Ad Litem for Dependent Children program be funded according to 
> specific appropriation   
> 
>                       Sen Cowin said the action should save the state $1.6 
> million in General Revenue annually.  
> 
>                       PASSED (37 yeas, 2 nays) 
> 
>          SB 36C Extended Homeownership Assistance 
>                       Introduced by Sen Clary, the bill was to create the 
> Expanded Homeownership Assistance Program within Florida Housing Finance 
> Corporation; provide for loans to eligible borrowers for down payments or 
> closing costs related to the purchase of residences; provides for 
> repayment of loans; authorizes fee; requires deposit & authorizes 
> expenditure of certain revenues

> with HB 65C.

http://www.sptimes.com/News/120101/Opinion/Saving_kids_by_comput.shtml 

Saving kids by computer 

 St. Petersburg Times, published December 1, 2001 


   Florida children will suffer if lawmakers pull the plug on the state's 
bungled child-welfare computer system instead of insisting on a plan to fix 
it.   Florida lawmakers are right to demand answers about the state's 
child-welfare computer system. The project has been a breathtaking example 
of government bungling -- and that's putting it charitably. But lawmakers 
will only make matters worse if they shut down the project or slash funding 
to the point of crippling it. A lot more than state dollars would be 
wasted. 

   Children's lives may be lost as well. 

   Lawmakers in both Houses met this week to figure out why, after 11 years 
of failed attempts and millions of dollars already invested, the promised 
state-of-the-art tracking system remains far from complete. 

   "In this time of a budget crunch, [when] we're cutting direct services 
to pregnant moms and seniors, we can't be putting millions and millions of 
dollars into a computer program that doesn't show results," an 
understandably frustrated Rep. Nan Rich, D-Weston, told her colleagues on 
the House Child and Family Security Committee. 

   The urge to cut Florida's losses and run might make sense if the new 
computer were not so critical to the state's ability to protect at-risk 
kids. Once fully on-line, it will replace six unconnected and outmoded data 
systems the Department of Children and Families has used, with little 
success, for decades. Instead of rifling through masses of paper resembling 
phone-book yellow pages, DCF workers will be able with a few keystrokes to 
find out and record important information about each child. Investigators 
will know more about the child's history before investigating abuse 
complaints, and workers may better follow kids as they move through the 
system (while supervisors better track caseworkers). At the start of the 
21st century, you might assume the state already had such capabilities, but 
you would be wrong. 

   Until recently, DCF could barely say how many children were in the 
system, much less track the full history and case plan of each. Though DCF 
is in the process of turning over many duties to community-based agencies, 
the new statewide system remains critical, especially since troubled 
families often move from one community to another. 

   Statistics out this week punctuate the need to speed up the conversion. 
Eighty percent of the 60 Florida children who recently died from abuse or 
neglect might have been saved had investigators been more thorough and 
observant, according to the State Child Abuse Death Review Team. The 
automated computer would have helped. 

   "If we could get this done yesterday we would," DCF Chief Information 
Officer Randy Niewenhous, told the Times. "Why? Because this is about 
saving the lives of kids."

From: Greg McDonald [ mailto:gmcdonald@stateline.org] 
Sent: Tuesday, December 04, 2001 12:49 PM

Mark -- Thanks much for the gov's comments. They are the most 
thoughtful we've received. We'll post them on the site in a few days, 
and we're also thinking about running them in the annual State of the 
States report we put out at the end of every year. Thanks again, and 
our best regards to Mr. Bush. By the way I covered his father's 
presidency for the Houston Chronicle. I'm the guy rumored to have 
passed on my illness to him during the infamous trip to Japan and 
other points eastward in the fall of 91. As I recall, though,he 
already had it and may actually have given it to me. We were aboard 
Air Force One enroute from Australia to Singapore, or it may have 
been Korea to Japan (We traveled so much it all blends together after 
a bit) when both of us wound up in sick bay together. We looked at 
each other, shook hands and started laughing. He told his doc, Burton 
Lee, to treat me first cause, he said, I looked worse than he did. 
All I know is a few days later I was throwing up myself at about the 
same time he was doing the same thing at the Japanese State dinner in 
his honor. 
I told him later that he at least got to go to sleep that night. I 
had stay up and file a story his fainting spell. That was one 
miserable trip. 
Anyway, Thanks for the help.

-----Original Message----- 
From: cust@sunsentinel.com [ mailto:cust@sunsentinel.com] 
Sent: Saturday, December 01, 2001 9:39 AM 
To: elginojones@yahoo.com 
Subject: NAACP: Lauderdale officials should be fired 


From: Customer Service 



-------------------- 
NAACP: Lauderdale officials should be fired 
-------------------- 

By Gregory Lewis 
Staff Writer 

November 30, 2001 

The Fort Lauderdale NAACP called for the dismissals of several Fort 
Lauderdale city officials who have been cited in the past for discriminatory 
practices, including the city attorney. 

The Thursday night action was an amendment to a recommendation by the 
national legal team and the local National Association for the Advancement 
of Colored People executive board. 

The members insisted the civil rights organization take a stronger stand by 
asking that city officials be terminated. 

Janice Boursiquot, who was the only member to vote against the 
recommendation as initially presented Thursday got "amens'' from the 
audience as she explained that the action wasn't strong enough. 

"Many people have been damaged by blatant discrimination,'' she said. "Those 
managers caused a lot of pain for a lot of people. It is time for them to 
feel pain." 

The NAACP supported some of the recommendations in a report from Judge Henry 
Latimer. The report found that the city mistreats all of its employees, 
recommended a major restructuring of top management at City Hall and called 
for the expansion of the city's Equal Employment Opportunities office. 

In addition to the firings, the NAACP will ask the city to: 

Employ a full time independent counsel to review and handle complaints of 
discrimination for one year; 

Terminate employees who engage in any illegal employment practices; 

Implement sensitivity training for all city employees; 

Be on alert for retaliatory action against whistleblowers. 

Assistant City Manager Bud Bentley said of the NAACP action: "Overall we're 
happy and pleased the NAACP is taking the interest to look at and advise us 
on the Latimer report." 

But, Bentley said, he was concerned that "specific people" were named when 
the organization hasn't made any determination for cause. 

NAACP state president Adora Obi Nwese encouraged the chapter to take strong 
action saying "we are in a war.'' 

She said she was "sick and tired of being sick and tired'' of institutions 
that "think they can get away with discriminatory treatment and racist 
behavior.'' 

Said Fort Lauderdale chapter president Bill McCormick: "What transpired here 
is the members said they trust the NAACP to fight for us,'' he said. 

Gregory Lewis can be reached at glewis@sun-sentinel.com or 954-356-4203. 



Copyright (c) 2001, South Florida Sun-Sentinel 

Visit Sun-Sentinel.com

Subject: RE: Cong Putnam/TPA 

I assume right now, florida agriculture community is biggest opponent of 
this.  if that assumption is correct, i would suggest doing a separate short 
paragraph to address the governor's intention to advocate for terms that 
will protect florida growers against unfair trade practices such as dumping, 
etc.  or, even better, is there anything we can say now, such as the 
president has assured us that they will vigorously protect against unfair 
trade practices.  i don't know what conversations we have had with 
administration on this. 

by way of history, Clinton promised to protect florida growers from dumping 
as part of their "look the other way" support on NAFTA.  Clinton then did 
little to help once the dumping began.  Growers are weary of similar 
overtures from new administration and similar failure to follow through.  we 
need to assure them that this is not the Clinton admininstration and that 
they will take dumping and other unfair trade practices very seriously. 
-----Original Message----- 
From: Nina Oviedo [ mailto:oviedon@sso.org]

From:	Dan Scupin <dscup@home.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 4, 2001 12:32 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Comments on another "big brother" Bush program..

Jeb, 
Your new "big brother" prescription drug program is a typical stupid 
government policy.  The only thing this will accomplish is to increase 
the suffering of the people that actually need the pain killing drugs. 
Such "big brother" legislation only scares doctors from prescribing 
needed medication because they don't want to be possible "victims" of 
overzealous "drug cops".  Thus the only doctors that will prescribe 
effective pain medications will be the "pain specialists".  You are 
probably not aware of the "pain specialist" racket but the net effect is 
that the cost is so high that most uninsured patients choose to suffer 
or go to the black market to get pain medication.  I'm sure your 
brilliant program will cause a huge increase in marijuana usage.  It's 
called the law of unintended consequences.  The stupidity of this new 
government program is unbelievable. But I guess you are pandering as 
usual! 
Dan

-----Original Message----- 
From: Martha Pratt [ mailto:martha@jeb.org] 
Sent: Wednesday, November 28, 2001 8:35 AM

-----Original Message----- 
From: Valerie Adams [ mailto:valadams@tampabay.rr.com] 
Sent: Wednesday, November 28, 2001 8:07 AM 
To: Martha Pratt; Martha Pratt 
Subject: Welfare computer funds in peril. Sun-Sentinel 11/28/01 


Welfare computer funds in peril 
By Mark Hollis 
Tallahassee Bureau 
Posted November 28 2001 

TALLAHASSEE  State legislators are asking why Florida government has 
spent 
11 years and more than $230 million but still hasn't finished building a 
state-of-the-art child welfare computer system. 

Incensed by repeated delays and cost overruns in developing the giant 
database, members of a House panel on Tuesday warned that if they don't 
see 
progress, they might halt spending on the program. 

"I want to reduce the funding level," said Rep. Nan Rich, a Weston 
Democrat. 
"In this time of a budget crunch and we're cutting direct services to 
pregnant moms and seniors, we can't be putting millions and millions of 
dollars into a computer program that doesn't show results." 

Republican budget writers also called for immediate accountability 
measures 
and threatened budget cuts. 

"We want to see a decrease in child abuse -- that's the bottom line," 
Rep. 
Sandra Murman, R-Tampa, said of her expectations for the system. 

Responding to a story in Sunday's Sun-Sentinel, legislators questioned 
why 
the state recently replaced three of the project's top managers, who 
combined made about $700,000 a year, with a three-member team from IBM 
at a 
cost of $1.8 million a year. 

Rep. Nancy Detert, R-Venice, chairwoman of the Child and Family Security 
Committee, also described as excessive a projected $22.5 million-a-year 
cost 
of maintaining the completed system. 

The electronic system will replace a patchwork of paper files and a half 
dozen other computer systems. 

It is supposed to allow workers instant access to all information about 
abused and neglected children in Florida and thousands of foster-care 
families. 

Because of repeated delays, management turnover and other problems, the 
completion date for the project, originally set for 1998, has been 
pushed to 
2005. 

"In the time and money that's been spent, we could have done EPCOT and 
Disney World both," Detert said. 

Department of Children and Families officials insisted that the project 
is 
extremely valuable to case workers and that they have made extraordinary 
progress in getting the system set up -- at least in its early phases -- 
since Gov. Jeb Bush took office. They said the first phase of the 
project 
has been in operation since summer. 

DCF Secretary Kathleen Kearney, a former judge in Broward County, said 
that 
when she took office in 1998 the state had accomplished little more than 
having purchased some of the computers. 

"We've taken a phoenix and risen it from the ashes," Kearney said. 

Yet Kearney said she recognizes public dissatisfaction with the project. 

Murman questioned the purpose of developing such a centralized computer 
system when the state is decentralizing social services functions and 
turning over responsibilities to local agencies and nonprofit 
organizations. 

"Philosophically," Murman said, "something is wrong with that system." 

Mark Hollis can be reached at mhollis@sun-sentinel.com or 850-224-6214. 


Copyright  2001, South Florida Sun-Sentinel

-----Original Message-----
From: Dan Beldy [mailto:DBeldy@humwin.com]
Sent: Friday, November 16, 2001 2:16 PM
To: 'jeb@jeb.org'
Subject: Enterprise Florida introduction / UnitedWeRide / Sept 11th
Jeb,
 
We met briefly on your trip to Silicon Valley with Enterprise Florida this year.   Hope things are well in Florida.  I am a partner at Hummer Winblad Venture Partners, was the former Navy fighter pilot, US Naval Academy graduate, served in Jacksonville Florida, started UnheardSoldier effort last December related to military ballots.
 
Realize your time is at absolute premium but wanted to make you aware of another effort I kickstarted but now has life of its own.  We are aggregating high profile support / board involvement as we speak.  Would like to get your input on a few fronts so let me explain some detail.
 
Immediately after Sept. 11th events, I started organizing a national bicycle ride called UnitedWeRide  <http://www.unitedweride.org/> www.unitedweride.org 501(c)(3) with mission statement / charter to assist families impacted by terrorism, and also create national participatory tribute to those lost that day.  Originally was going to be grassroots effort but response was incredible so shifted quickly to larger, organized, professional event.  
 
The format, plan is to have bicycle riders leave from several major cities next summer (San Fran, Seattle, Los Angeles, Denver, Austin, Miami, Atlanta, Chicago, Boston) and ride through cities large / small, routes pass through Oklahoma City, United Airlines Flight 93 crash site, Arlington National Cemetery, the Pentagon, Gettysburg, Liberty Bell, and all routes will converge at Ground Zero weekend of Aug 3-4, 2002 in New York City.  All 50 states to participate, plan to get Governor support within each state for permits / routes.  
 
We also plan to have select riders carry a memorial stone for each individual lost in war on terrorism (this would include Sept. 11th, but also other losses, Anthrax, servicemen and women lost in battle, leading up to next summer).  I have approached the families of some friends lost about this, and the families of some of the passengers from UA Flight 93 to get their perspective / support.  And also to get sense of whether they would have an interest in getting a particular family member / team together to "carry", in tributary, honor guard fashion, their individual memorial (which some very much do, all are supportive of effort).
 
UnitedWeRide has the event planning group that put on 1996 Olympic bike events, San Francisco Grand Prix supporting this, and we are putting A+ support structure in place to pull this off.  So far response has been overwhelming.  New York City said they would 'open their arms' to this next August.  Lance Armstrong, Tour de France winner 3 years running, will be part of final ride weekend.  Plan to make formal press announcement by end of year.
 
We are also approaching individuals to present a world class Board / Honorary Chairperson in major cities represented in the ride (some high profile personalities that represent all that is great about USA).  Board member commitment no more than 3-4 Board meetings leading up to next summer, Honorary Chairperson will be personality in particular city that will show up and kick off ride that day in that city.  We are approaching Astronaut Jim Lovell and retired General Norman Schwarzkopf for example as well as leaders in industry to participate.  
 
Would like to get your input on someone you think would be Honorary Chairperson for the City of Miami, a key origination city.  And your input as Governor on the overall effort.  It would be great to get a state Governor champion to support and help rally the nation's Governors behind UnitedWeRide.
 
I know the President is too busy to focus on this, but we are approaching Lee Haney, the current Chairman of the President's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, to determine if there is interest in supporting, being involved in UnitedWeRide.
 
(btw, I have no personal interest in recognition, etc., from this...none.  This is for the country and the families.  It is already shaping up that the existing supporting cast, high profile folks will take center stage and I can fade into background.)
 
UnitedWeRide is already an official corporation.  Right now there are core groups in New York and Silicon Valley that are helping this move forward.  This may be the largest cycling event / peacetime domestic sporting event in history if the event planning projections play out.
 
Do you have 5 minutes to discuss / any initial reaction to the event itself or suggesting on who best to represent Miami?  Happy to discuss with appropriate person / staff when able and provide more details.

Regards,

Dan
 
Dan Beldy
Hummer Winblad Venture Partners
http://www.humwin.com
dbeldy@humwin.com
415-979-9600 (phone)
415-979-9601 (fax)
 
From:	Branker, Laura <laura.branker@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 4, 2001 10:22 AM
To:	Jeb Bush; Brogan, Frank; Shanahan, Kathleen; Brown, Brewser; Hirst, Elizabeth; DiBenigno, Arlene
Subject:	FW: Miami Herald Pan American Hospital closes 12 medical clinics
Attachments:	Miami Herald Pan American Hospital closes 12 medical clinics.htm




message from AHCA... 
> 
> United Health Care notified AHCA that the Pan American Clinics had closed 
their doors effective this morning to United patients.  United was 
terminating this contract 'for cause', and would provide AHCA a transition 
plan. These clinics provided both PCP (primary care) services, as well as 
some specialty services.  
> 
> The contract was terminated effective immediately, for breech of 
> contract...a great many of the PCPs had left the clinics and 3-4 clinics 
> had closed.  Medicaid and Medicare members can go to the Miami-Dade 
> Centers, of which there are 10 and the Commercial members can access the 
> contracted IPA network.  All oncology members have been transitioned to 
> Mercy Hospital for treatments. 
> 
> United has added extra people to customer service, the AHCA call center 
and 
> Benova have been notified of the problem and the potential for a lot of 
> extra calls. 
> 
> The Department of Health and licensure units will be notified of the 
> closing.  As more of the transition plan comes together, we will be 
> notified. 
> 
> As of November, United has 17,229 enrolled Medicaid members in Dade 
County.  DOI shows there are 155,000 commercial and 46,500 Medicare 
> members.
