----- Original Message ----- 
From: The A.B.L.E. Foundation, Inc. <mailto:webmaster@ablefoundation.org>  
To: Beatrice <mailto:beatrice@nivets.com>  
Sent: Sunday, December 02, 2001 7:00 PM
Subject: Re: Osceola County A.B.L.E. Center!

Hi Beatrice -
 
GREAT!  We'll mark January 15, 2002 on the calendar for the Osceola A.B.L.E. Center introductory meeting!  You may want to be gathering the list of contact names, addresses, phone #'s, email addresses, etc. so that once the official announcement is made December 25, we can notify them of the 1/15/02 meeting.
 
Regarding the entrance ticket:  there are many people who, for various reasons, attempt to tear down or destroy good things.  Some people act that way out of jealousy, low self-esteem, retaliation, etc.  Some people simply fail to understand the true meaning of things and then spread gossip, or simply the wrong information.  It's like the telephone game we would play as children, when a sentence is whispered in the ear of the first person and then passed on to the next person, and so on around the circle.  By the time the last person received the whispered message and spoke it out loud, it was completely changed around and different than when it started!  We must protect the people who will be served and benefit from the programs at the A.B.L.E. Center.  One of the ways to do so is to share the A.B.L.E. Vision with the people who will benefit directly or who will be involved with the development of the Center.   
 
When we make the announcement throughout the organizations, agencies, media, etc. throughout the community, those interested in attending MUST R.S.V.P. and will be provided either an email confirmation that is numbered, or will receive their confirmation number by US mail or telephone.  They will simply provide their confirmation number and name at the door of the meeting.  It's very easy to do and helps us provide security and privacy of the information provided at the meeting.  When people share information about themselves and their family situation or child with a disability, they need to know that there aren't people in the room who would use that information to harm them.  Believe me, this has happened to other organizations, and we don't want it to happen to us.  
 
There is no charge to attend the meeting and learn about the A.B.L.E. Vision.  With the state of Florida experiencing so many funding cutbacks, people are desperate to receive services for their children, and it is extremely important that we are organized and know the people we are working with and are meeting at the meetings.  You'll see what I mean about why this is so important as we get further along.  
 
The A.B.L.E. Centers are open to Members only.  Membership is free and open to the public, and no one is denied the opportunity to become a member of the A.B.L.E. Network.  Again, you'll understand more about this as we go along.  It is to protect and serve the people better.  We are looking for winners, not whiners.\
 
The communities will be building the actual center!  The communities will be very involved in all areas of the development and construction of the actual Center!  It is like an old-fashioned community barn raising!  In the process of the development and construction of the A.B.L.E. Centers we will be changing the way society views and treats people with disabilities.  We will be educating the community at the same time!  For the most part, communities shun people with disabilities.  Just look around - parades, community functions, etc., do not promote the incorporation of people with disabilities.  We have activities that promote inclusion and embrace the true spirit of cooperation and community.
 
There is so much information to share with you.  You may want to be looking for people who have leadership qualities such as you do.  These talents are truly gifts from God!  You'll want to find 6-8 leaders with the talents and time to devote to the project.  We are all volunteers serving our community.  Once the Center is open, there will, no doubt, be some of these volunteers who will want to be employed at the A.B.L.E. Center.  
 
Basically, Beatrice - what programs and services would you want for your child (of any age) with a disability and for your family if money were of no concern?  Think about the future.  Dream big ~ our children deserve no less than the best life has to offer.  The best of your dreams is what the A.B.L.E. Centers will offer!  We will serve the needs of children and adults with disabilities and their families - whatever those needs may be.  We help them to help themselves - long term.  We are not a hand-out, but rather, a hand up.
 
We will be working with each family with a child with a disability to help them achieve beyond limited expectations society places upon them.  You may want to encourage people to reach out to families with a child with a disability who they never took the time to meet or get to know yet.  Just think how many more people we can reach if each family with a special needs child reached out to one new family each week.  Just think how quickly we would be able to touch the hearts of families who didn't know who to go to for help, to get their questions answered, who thought no one else understood what they are going through, or who thought no one else in the community cared.  Parents of children with disabilities have so much knowledge and experience that we must reach out and share it with younger families to help them avoid some of the problems, frustrations, and concerns we had and stuggled through.  Our mission is to help children and adults with disabilities achieve beyond limited expectations - one family at a time!
 
Sorry to write such a long email!  There is so much excitement to share!
 
Warm regards,
Lori Bennett
Ambassador of Hope

From: Turbeville, Greg [mailto:Greg.Turbeville@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US]

 -----Original Message-----
From:   Benard, Andrew  <mailto:%5Bmailto:andrew.benard@myflorida.com%5D> [mailto:andrew.benard@myflorida.com] 
Sent:   Monday, December 03, 2001 5:25 PM
To:     Turbeville, Greg
Cc:     Shanahan, Kathleen; Jimenez, Frank
Subject:        Background info on OxyContin legislation package to be announced in Orlando tomorrow
Greg,
Per your request, here are some bullets regarding the process by which this legislation was developed:
(OxyContin is a breakthrough chronic pain management medicine developed by Purdue Pharma, with an explosion in use of product from its intro in 1996 - see attached sales graph in Tab 6 of accompanying Goldenrod handout)
1) The impetus for legislation was: a) a dramatic, sharp spike in overdose deaths reported in state since Summer, 2000; b) OxyContin abuse is a phenomenon largely driven through prescription fraud by addicts and a few bad doctors violating legal and ethical codes by grossly over prescribing these drugs - either deliberately, in a willfully ignorant manner, or in simple ignorance of proper pain management practices; and finally C) the seemingly lethargic ability of the Board of Medicine to shut down these bad doctors.
2)  Office of Drug Control, with SEN Burt providing support for any resultant legislation, initiated an broad effort to turn this problem around.
It has attempted to do this by:
        A) receiving a comprehensive brief from the Board of Medicine's Quality Assurance Committee in the early August on what the disciplinary process is for doctors accused of malfeasance and/or nonfeasance; and getting commitments from the group to be part of the process to make improvements so as to avoid the horror stories this Office has been made aware of, of bad doctor abuses occurring around the state; setting stage for recognition  by the medical community that more must be done to "police its own" in a more effective manner
        B) making OxyContin abuse a priority of the Drug Policy Advisory Council meeting in Tampa on 27 August, with the Council fully supporting a comprehensive fix to long standing problems in how the prescription drug system functions in Florida, and the underlying problems with chronic pain management;  this then reinforced the public hearing process.
        C) Board of Medicine convened a series of open hearings on the problem around the state in late summer and fall to vette the various recommendations pouring forth from the medical and law enforcement communities on fixing this problem.  The Bd. of Medicine has been very proactive in this regard; FDLE, AHCA, and DOH have all also stepped up to the plate to help design an effective piece of legislation.
No doubt, the medical community - to include especially the FMA, Bd. of Pharmacists, and the Nurses Assoc. - and others I can't remember off the top of my head - also all wanted to participate in this process, and did so. In conversation I had with their reps., it was clear they wanted to be intimately involved in this effort, so as to not have overly onerous rules/laws foisted on them  - and they were by being full participants.
I myself represented this Office at the first meeting in Ft. Lauderdale on 29 August, attended by all of the above, plus SEN Burt and AG Butterworth. Ideas were discussed, tabled for review for legal sufficiency, common sense checks.
        BOTTOM LINE:  This legislation pulls no punches, and has been developed with the participation of all of the above groups.  I do not know how many have seen the text, but the three bills incorporate many of the 61 suggestions adopted through the Bd. of Medicine's hearing process.  The substantive bill is the crux, with many ideas put forward - such as tamper proof prescription pads - which have been in effect for many years in other states.  I can think of nothing in the legislation that is "revolutionary" or which is not currently in practice in some other state.
The Electronic database is accompanied by a public records exemption bill to assuage the civil liberties concerns with centralized medical database repositories being maintained by the state.  Finally, Criminal penalties have been strongly pushed by SEN Burt, and are a good response to the horror stories these various public hearings brought to light from law enforcement, concerned health care practitioners, and people who have lost loved ones to Oxy ODs.
 
Technical questions raised by Governor on bullet four as to which specific violations are meant I'm still waiting for an answer from author of that portion. 
From:	Thomas, Brad <Brad.Thomas@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 4, 2001 9:45 AM
To:	Jeb Bush; Arduin, Donna; Turbeville, Greg
Subject:	Sex offender legislation research
Attachments:	summary sheet repeat sexual offenders.doc


Governor, 

Per your direction, here is the research we have compiled on the proposal to require mandatory sentences of 25 years to life for offenders who are convicted of a second, significant sexual felony. The latest bill draft would not affect any first-time offenders.

The data demonstrates that it is the repeat offenders who are most likely to be referred and committed. Although repeat offenders comprise 40% of those referred to the Dept. of Children and Families, 61% of those referrals are sent to the state attorneys for further action. The bottom line is that 71% of those committed have multiple offenses, while only 17% have a single offense. [Only 7% have a single offense if juvenile records are considered.]

The proposed draft utilizes the reformed chapter on lewd/lascivious crimes that better recognizes the severity of certain crimes. 

No proposal can guarantee that we won't capture some offenders who would not have been referred and committed. This proposal, however, is limited to repeat offenders who are convicted of at least two serious sexual felonies.  

Please let me know if I can provide more information. 

  


*	40% of persons referred to the Department and Children and Family Services for evaluation have multiple sexual offense convictions.
*	61% of cases referred to the Office of the State Attorney by the multi-disciplinary team had multiple sex offense convictions.
*	71% of committed violent sexual predators had multiple convictions. 
*	Only 17 % of sexually violent predator had a single count conviction ultimately resulting in commitment.  
*	When juvenile sex offense records are considered as prior criminal records, sexual predators with a single count sex offense conviction comprise 7% of the committed population. 
*	72% of the cases referred for evaluation and rejected by Department of Children and Family Services for further consideration, had single sex offense convictions.


The PSU proposal excludes certain "less severe (comparatively speaking)" felony sex offenses from the mandatory such as felony pornography possession/distribution charges and lewd and lascivious exposure in the presence of a child. However, it would apply to all sexual battery offenses and lewd and lascivious molestation or battery (which is the greatest contributing offense to this population).  The proposal cannot guarantee the prolonged incarceration of everyone who would be Ryce-bound. It also may provide for prolonged incarceration of those who might not have ultimately been Ryced. Be that as it may, it represents the best determination to pre-identify this population and should for the most part do just that (as indicated above). 

<<summary sheet repeat sexual offenders.doc>>

i want to bring to your attention to the direction (what i know is mostly rumor) that the p rule is heading.   dep had some meetings (operated by some consultants) with "interested parties" and many presentations were made and there was lots of discussion.

From:	David Steinfeld <david@apimaging.com>

Subject:	under siege

Honorable Governor Bush, 

Our County Park is under siege by the political games played in Dade County. 
The Parks Department along with the Honorable Gwen Margolis have 
orchestrated a plan to commercialize Haulover Park in Dade County. The park 
is bordered by the ocean and Intercoastal and provides access to many 
minority groups living west of Biscayne Boulevard. I solicited their 
comments through a public awareness campaign held on Labor Day. Their 
suggestions were that the county should concentrate their efforts on better 
bathrooms, sand boxes for the kids, picnic tables and more. They are not 
aware of the assault on their access through increased parking concessions, 
privatized dock space that will destroy the breathtaking views of the 
intercoastal, and an overall commercialization of the Park. 

The FDEP West Palm Beach, recently denied an application for an expansion of 
the dock facility that presently houses a GAMING vessel, which was in the 
park ILLEGALLY, and authorized by the county. 

I ask you to further review, contest, and revoke an existing permit that 
allows the county to expand the Marina additionally for private use with 
over 150 new slips for rent, a 350' intrusion into the intercoastal, 300 
yard driving range with a 60' net, and other commercial operations at the 
park. These proposed changes do not serve the PUBLIC interest and 
generations to come will suffer if their allowed to proceed unchecked. 

Please Help 

David Steinfeld

Surfside, FL. 33154

From:	Fred Dickinson <Dickinson.Fred@hsmv.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 4, 2001 8:38 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: Issuing Driver's Licenses to people holding Visas about toexpire

Per our Driver License Strategic Plan filed with the Florida Department of Law Enforcement, one of our tasks to aid in the state's efforts to strengthen domestic security is to begin limiting the duration of driver licenses to the duration of pertinent Immigration and Naturalization Service documents.  

The computer software modifications we began in mid-November to accomplish this procedural change have just been completed.  The first test of this rollout began yesterday at our Pembroke Pines driver license office and all went well.  We will phase-in all other driver license offices over the next two weeks and anticipate completing the rollout by December 15, 2001.  

If you have any questions, please let me know. 

Fred Dickinson 


>>> "Jeb Bush" <jeb@jeb.org> 12/01/01 12:59PM >>>

motor vehicle offices are not complying with the change. Thank you for 
bringing this to my attention.

electric skillet (MADE IN INDIA), He sat down with his calculator (MADE IN

  and wondered why he can't find a good paying job ( in AMERICA) !!!

Dear Jeb,  I am concerned about the practice of issuing drivers licenses to 
people with Visas that are about to expire.  Yesterday I was in the Drivers 
License Bureau and observed many people with Visa's that expire this month  
yet still given a Florida License that is good for four years.  About 30 
percent of the people coming into this office were from other countries.  If 

the Visas are expiring within a week or two, why is Florida issuing a 
license 
to drive?  Thank you for your attention to this concern.  
Attorney Linda McIntyre,  Coral Springs, Florida 

From:	Medows, Rhonda M.D. <medowsr@fdhc.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Tuesday, December 4, 2001 7:46 AM
To:	laura.branker@myflorida.com; Jeb Bush
Subject:	Re: FW: Update on Nursing Home Issues

There are other nursing homes that would meet the Gold Seal criteria of not 
having major (class 1) deficiencies in care but most are concerned about 
meeting the new requirements of 1202 ie: 
-nurse staffing requirements 
-liability insurance requirements 

They are probably not going to apply until they are sure they can meet at 
least the staffing requirements on a consistent basis 

I have already met with both the for profit and the not-for-profit nursing 
home associations and have encouraged them to have their members apply 
--------------------------

-----Original Message----- 
From: Branker, Laura [ mailto:laura.branker@myflorida.com] 
Sent: Monday, December 03, 2001 7:04 PM 
To: Jeb Bush; Brogan, Frank; Shanahan, Kathleen 
Cc: Dempsey, Hayden; Brown, Brewser; Branker, Laura 
Subject: FW: Update on Nursing Home Issues 




- Gold Seal - 
 We have 5 applications.  One with no financial information to submit (VA 
nursing home), three being reviewed to determine if they meet the financial 
criteria, and one for which we are awaiting additional information from the 
applicant.  We are working on the next meeting January 16th (location to be 
determined).   Although the panel wanted to wait for roughly 10 applications 

to come in before they met again, we're moving forward with the five.  The 
plan is, at the next meeting, the panel will review the applications and 
them select a sub-committee to conduct a site visit.  Then, at a subsequent 
meeting, the facility has an opportunity to make a presentation, the 
subcommittee will give a report on the site visit, and the panel will vote 
to recommend to the Governor.  That would be followed by an appointment by 
the Governor's Office.  Unfortunately, it will still take a few months. 


Dr,Rhonda M. Medows, 
Secretary 
Agency for Health Care Administration 
State of Florida

From: ABELCOMM@aol.com [ mailto:ABELCOMM@aol.com] 
Sent: Monday, December 03, 2001 7:48 PM 
To: Stutler, Denver 
Subject: Re: Beach Erosion 


Denver, 

Thank you for your response.  We need emergency funds and permits right now. 

A 13 story 97 unit building full of senior citizens will fall into the ocean 
if we think we have time and not to act right now to repair the damage that 
has been caused by the jetties at the port in Cape Canaveral.  We need funds 
now.  We have no money allocated for this tragic situation. 

We need the officials to act promptly and properly.  We have talked with 
engineers that used coquina rock in the past and it has held up the best.  We 

desire to follow their advice of a wall with rock and sand in front with seat 

oats and plants to secure the dune.  We only have 29 feet left and with the 
size of our building we need a larger foundation of land for safety and 
security.  

We cannot wait until 2003 or even a few months - We must act now.  The home 
owners are gathering together and petitions are being put together.  Many of 
the home owners wanted to share their feelings but did not know how or to 
who.  They will be calling.   We have no choice but to seek the highest level 

of action and hold those in the decision making positions accountable. 

 I am one of the youngest owners and I felt compelled to stand up for the 
elderly in this building.  They would have no where to live if the building 
is condemned.  Our insurance does not cover beach erosion and we could stand 
to lose our insurance all together if the government does not secure the 
dunes now.  It is truly a scary situation. 
Channel 13 and the Orlando Sentinel reported on our building today and other 
networks have called.  I pray I can say that the government did the right 
thing.  We need funds and repair today not tomorrow.  Please feel free to 
call me. 

I will be at 321-728-0909 until Tuesday night and back at 407-539-3994 after 
that.  It will be cheaper for the government to act now and not wait until we 

lose the whole dune and then the government has to spend more.  We need to 
learn from the Airport security mistakes and not overpay by waiting to long 
to do something to prevent problems. 

Thank you for your time and consideration in advance.  Blessings! 
Sincerely, 
Andrea Gagliano 
abelcomm@aol.com 
407-539-3994, or 321-728-0909

From:	JeffKasky@aol.com
Sent:	Monday, December 3, 2001 11:16 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Report from the Front Lines

In a message dated 12/3/2001 8:48:42 PM Eastern Standard Time, jeb@jeb.org writes: 




send it to this address. It will come to me. 




Dear Gov. Bush: 

Thank you for taking the time to read this.  Im going to be as brief as possible. 

Consider this a report from the front lines of adoption.  I am in the trenches, working to help women and children every single day of every single week, including but not limited to holidays and weekends.  My day to day activities are not hypothetical, they are the real thing. 

The adoption bill which you allowed to become law last session is an impracticable nightmare.  WOMENARE HAVING ABORTIONS because we cant help them with their adoption plans.  We're too busy printing reams of meaningless paperwork and going to court for unnecessary hearings.  Plus, the fathers have all the rights anyway, so the desire of the birth mother is one step away from irrelevant. 

We, the front-line adoption professionals, are so mired in nonsensical paperwork and meaningless pleadings and filings that we are unable to do our jobs.  Adoption fees have increased significantly due to the extraordinary amount of time it takes to comply with this ridiculous law. 

If I was only working on one adoption at a time, the law would be reasonably straightforward, and, although it includes a bunch of meaningless and extraneous procedures which serve to do nothing but waste our time, it could be followed in some cases.  But Im notonly working on one adoption, Im working on 25-30, and compliance with this law is IMPOSSIBLE. 

This letter is obviously not meant to be a treatise on the ups and downs of this law.  I just want you to know that this law is worse than you can imagine, and that Skip Campbell lied and lied and lied to you and everyone else when he told you that it would streamline adoption.  My office is hiring an extra legal secretary just to keep up with the meaningless pleadings, hearings, orders, and exhibits, and the cost of the new employee will have to be passed on to the adoptive families. 

This bill never should have become law.  Someone needs to repeal it and let us get back to doing our jobs. 

If you want details, let me know and we can sit down together.  Ill go over the life-span of an adoption case with you  not hypothetically, like Skip, but FOR REAL.  Youll see what Im talking aboutI promise! 

Thanks for reading 

Jeffrey A. Kasky, Esq. 
One World Adoption Services, Inc. 
(A Florida-licensed not-for-profit child placing agency)

From: Doreen Rutledge [ mailto:Doreen_Rutledge@dcf.state.fl.us]

Subject: NBC donation 




We can not do any releases or other coverage. I heard from NBC this morning 
and they wanted to pull the donation because we are a state agency and not 
a 501C3 non profit. I have scrambled around to line up some of my community 
501C3's to accept the donation for us. They are afraid that should any 
press coverage result stating we (DCF) had received a donation from them 
they would be swamped with calls from other states and governors. I assured 
them we would handle it through other avenues and I would get back to them. 
As of right now the State foster parents association, Special Opportunity 
Fund of South Florida and the Foster Care Council of Southwest Florida will 
accept the donation. My office will still manage it but officially it is 
theirs. The National Guard called this morning and will assist within 
allowable guidelines. Thanks Governor! 
I will let you all know the final arrangements. 
Doreen

- Gold Seal - 
 We have 5 applications.  One with no financial information to submit (VA 
nursing home), three being reviewed to determine if they meet the financial 
criteria, and one for which we are awaiting additional information from the 
applicant.  We are working on the next meeting January 16th (location to be 
determined).   Although the panel wanted to wait for roughly 10 applications 
to come in before they met again, we're moving forward with the five.  The 
plan is, at the next meeting, the panel will review the applications and 
them select a sub-committee to conduct a site visit.  Then, at a subsequent 
meeting, the facility has an opportunity to make a presentation, the 
subcommittee will give a report on the site visit, and the panel will vote 
to recommend to the Governor.  That would be followed by an appointment by 
the Governor's Office.  Unfortunately, it will still take a few months. 


Dr,Rhonda M. Medows,

From:	Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>

I thought you would like to see the attached. We are making progress making government be run in a businesslike way. Whether it be our technology reforms, Service First or HR outsourcing, we can improve services at a much lower cost. I hope you will become a partner in this, my friend.

-----Original Message-----
From: Bahrami, Kimberly [mailto:Kim.Bahrami@MyFlorida.com]
Sent: Monday, December 03, 2001 6:09 PM
To: Jeb Bush; Brogan, Frank
Cc: Shanahan, Kathleen; Castille, Colleen; Henderson, Cynthia; Tom McGurk; Medows, Rhonda M.D.; TIM MOORE; Crist, Charlie
Subject: STO Aggregated Oracle Purchase Results



Just a quick note to let you know about actual savings produced when people 
from different agencies work together in technology. The State Technology 
Office combined our Oracle software license purchase last week with those of 
the Agency for Workforce Innovation, Agency for Healthcare Administration, 
Florida Department of Law Enforcement, and the Department of Education. 
Because of the size of the individual purchases, each agency was able to 
negotiate a discount.  However, by combining the purchases, the STO was able 
to negotiate an additional $640,000 in savings this year.  Over the next 
three years, an additional savings of $400,000 in lower maintenance fees 
will also be realized.  The cooperation between these agencies has allowed 
us to save the state significant dollars.  I want to thank Tom McGurk, 
Rhonda Medows, Tim Moore and Commissioner Charlie Crist and their staff for 
helping in the coordination of this effort. I also want to thank Cynthia 
Henderson and DMS purchasing staff for their assistance in coordinating this 
multi-agency project through the purchasing process. 

By working together to aggregate purchases for commonly used technologies 
within the agencies, I am confident this is the first of many statewide cost 
savings ventures to follow!  

Kim

-----Original Message-----
From: Mattingly, Rebecca [mailto:rebecca.mattingly@myflorida.com]
Sent: Monday, December 03, 2001 7:48 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: Dana, Pamella; Shanahan, Kathleen
Subject: FW: Production Partners Program



Governor: 

Finally some success.  We have successfully negotiated the launch of a new 
program between Florida's production and advertising agency community.  It's 
called Production Partners and it is designed to foster greater networking 
and communication between the two divergent groups.  The info below was sent 
out today to all of our local film offices and to the membership of the 
Advertising Federation - Florida Chapter.  A press release will follow in 
the coming days. 

RDM 



Subject: Production Partners Program 


Dear Film Commissioners and 4th District AAF Club Presidents: 

The September 11th terrorist incident has brought all citizens throughout 
the USA closer together to fight a common enemy.  Throughout the country 
though, an unanticipated repercussion of September 11th has been a down turn 
in business activity for many industry sectors.  As a result of this, the 
film & entertainment production industry and the advertising industry have 
experienced a lackluster fourth quarter for new business activity in 2001. 
To address this business downturn, the Governor's Office of Film & 
Entertainment has worked to begin a process of collaboration with the 
advertising industry to reach out to keep Florida business in Florida. This 
new collaboration is geared to help you take control, to help Florida's 
indigenous film & entertainment and advertising industries get better 
acquainted with one another, and to increase awareness to the quality media 
resources that are in your own community.  We want to help you form new 
partnerships of mutual interest and forge new friendships in the name of 
marketing in your own back yard. The Sept. 11th terrorist incident has hurt 
both our industries and this is one way to fight back!  

The Governor's Office of Film & Entertainment* (OF&E) is pleased to begin 
implementing the "Production Partners Program" in conjunction with the 
American Advertising Federation, District 4-Florida** (Ad Fed). We 
look forward to joining our Ad Fed partners and hope this new collaboration 
will be of benefit to both organizations. 

This historic cooperative effort will be started with initial pilot programs 
in fourteen rural/urban areas of the state containing both local film 
commission offices and Ad Fed Clubs. The hope is that both groups will 
increase business activity between each other and learn more about one 
another's resources.  Both the Ad Fed Club member chapters and the Film 
Commission industry organizations have much more in common with one another 
than has been fostered or pursued in the past. 

Please refer to the attached document for your review***, which outlines the 

specifics of the program and how it will be rolled out at the local Film 
Commission offices and Ad Fed Club chapters level.  We look forward to this 
being a positive and beneficial effort for our industries and assisting you 
any way we can. 

Sincerely, 
Robert Grimm 
Deputy Director 
Governor's Office of Film & Entertainment 
1-877-FLA-FILM 
robert.grimm@myflorida.com 

Barb Scherer 
Public Relations Chair 
4th District, American Advertising Federation 
407-426-7272 
bnscherer@aol.com 

*On November 7th, the Film Commissioners Council of Film Florida unanimously 
voted to support a cooperative effort to foster communications understanding 
and networking between the local Florida Film Commission offices throughout 
the State and the American Advertising Association, District 4, Florida 
Chapter, local Advertising Federation Clubs.  On November 8th the statewide 
film &  entertainment association Film Florida unanimously voted to support 
the collaboration. 
  
On November 9th the Florida Film & Entertainment Advisory Council (which 
advises & Supports the Governor's Office of Film & Entertainment) voted 
unanimously to support the collaboration between the Ad Fed Clubs and the 
Local Film Offices.  

**On November 11th the American Advertising Federation, District 4-Florida, 
voted unanimously to support a collaboration with the Governor's Office of 
Film & Entertainment and Florida's local Film Commission offices to support 
business activity with the Florida's local Ad Fed Clubs. 

- Film Florida is an industry association created in 1997 to fill a gap in 
film & entertainment industry communications and is comprised of Florida 
film industry leaders and organizations, film & entertainment labor 
organizations and Film Commissioners that work to promote Florida's  film & 
entertainment industry. 

- The Governor's Office of Film & Entertainment as a result of legislation 
supported by Governor Bush and passed during the 1999 Legislative Session. 
The OF&E was established under the Executive Office of the Governor 
(s.288.1251, F. S.).  Administratively housed under the Office of Tourism, 
Trade and Economic Development, the OF&E is directed, among other things to 
develop and implement a 5-Year Strategic Plan, work with local entertainment 
industry offices to provide service to the industry, promote Florida's 
production locations to the national and international television, movie and 
digital production media industry, and to serve as a liaison between 
government, the entertainment industry and labor interests. 
  
- The Florida Film & Entertainment Advisory Council was formed as a result 
of legislation signed into law by the Governor Jeb Bush, July 1, 1999. 
Created in accordance with Chapter 288.1252 of the Florida Statutes, the 
Florida Film Advisory Council consists of 17 members, seven appointed by the 
Governor, five appointed by the President of the Senate, and five appointed 
by the Speaker of the House of Representatives.  In addition, the Film 
Commissioner, a representative of Enterprise Florida, Inc., and a 
representative of the Florida Tourism Industry Marketing Corporation serve 
as ex officio, nonvoting members of the Council.  The Council serves as an 
advisory body to the Governor's Office of Tourism, Trade, and Economic 
Development and to the Office of the Film Commissioner to provide industry 
insight and expertise related to developing, marketing, promoting, and 
providing service to Florida's entertainment industry. 

- The American Advertising Federation is a national organization that 
advances the business of advertising as a vital and essential part of the 
American economy and culture.  It serves as the unifying voice for 
advertising.  To fulfill its mission, AAF has as its highest priorities:  
effective government and public relations, professional development and 
recognition, public service, social responsibility, high standards and 
providing benefits and services to its members.  The 4th District of AAF is 
comprised of 23 local club chapters throughout Florida and the Caribbean, 
representing over 2,200 members.  The membership is diverse and comprised of 

all facets of the advertising industry, such as ad agencies, 
advertisers/clients, production companies, media, printers, photographers, 
interactive & web developers, independents, market researchers and p.r. 
firms.

contact 
either Robert Grimm or Barb Scherer.

December 3, 2001 

Governor Jeb Bush

Dear Governor Bush: 

Congratulations on a job well done Governor!  While the Special Session 
of the Legislature has not yet come to a close, it is apparent to this 
Republican observer it will be a tremendous success for the sunshine 
state, thanks mainly to your leadership and the team work of President 
McKay and Speaker Feeney. 

There is however one issue in the CS/SB 2C Conference Report that was 
hastily crafted in the final hours over the weekend that deserves some 
close scrutiny.  The proviso on line item 570 of Section 6 of the 
General Government budget contains language that automatically cancels 
all contracts between the state and private firms to operate prison 
facilities in Florida. 

While this proviso is intended to save the state money and there is a 
provision that allows for a re-issuing of the RFP's to private 
companies, there is some ambiguous language regarding who would set the 
standards and criteria for the new RFP's.  This ambiguity could (and I 
feel would) lead to a point where there is a "non-response" situation 
for all proposals.  In that case, the proviso then calls for the 
Department of Corrections to step in and take over some, if not all of 
these facilities.  All of this would occur prior to next summer. 

In my opinion, private prison companies have been a terrific asset to 
our state, and so I would ask that you please examine this situation 
closely.  If your conclusions determine the same type of uncertainty in 
this wording, I would urge that you please reject the proviso language 
on line item 570 and request the Legislature to take a second look.  I 
think a full and fair hearing from all sides of the privatization issue 
next session would undoubtedly lead to a better work product for the 
people of Florida. 

Thank you for your consideration and if you need any additional 
information, I would be happy to oblige.  Again, congratulations on a 
great special session and I hope you and your family have a very Merry 
Christmas. 

Sincerely, 


Tom Slade

   I remember coming to you with a plea for help.  I remember how stern and

to cover its ass.  Let me give you a quick idea as to what I've lost during 
this ordeal: my truck, my job, my dignity, and my freedom.  I can't do this 
anymore.  Your agencies have blantently and provably broken the law, 
violated my rights & civil liberties, harbored an abusive individual and 
lied to cover it up in a swamp of paper work, broken promises and mis 
represented statements.  When the inspector general showed up at my house, 
his only concern was finding a fall guy in the matter; Delisa Mathews will 
be the target I'm sure.  When they dealt with Nancy and Al, it was purely a 
"prove DCF didn't relatiate" routine.  Now, when I talk to Sue Grey & 
BaryBeth on the matter, it's "we don't know anything" or "we can't tell you 
anything".  Well, tell me this Jeb, how is it that I've commited NO CRIME, 
I've done EVERYTHING that DCF has told me and I'm STILL paying for this??? 
No more.  I've waited long enough and sacrificed everything I can.  Is this 
the type of organization that runs the state I live in?  Well, it seems that 
my hands were bound 8 years ago when I was raped & they're still bound 
today.  I'm turning Charlie over to DCF as it's clear that I have no help in 
this matter and DCF has a state budget.  Personally, I hope you feel a 
little better knowing that an 8 year child can't be protected in your state 
because you don't have a clue as to what goes on behind your back.  As for 
me, I'll spend the next 5 or so years trying to recover what has taken me a 
lifetime to aquire and as for Charlie, all I can do is hope he makes it. 

Thanks for your help, 
John Greiner 

If you can't/won't help me, at least prevent this from happening to other 
innocent people.

From: Steve Mayberry [mailto:SMayberry@floridabusiness.com]
Sent: Monday, December 03, 2001 6:09 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: Pam Dana (E-mail); John Anderson; Roger Miller
Subject: CONFIDENTIAL: Prospect follow up



Regarding the prospect you called me about this morning: 

After researching the company and recent history in Florida, I called the 
contact the CEO gave you. We had a brief conversation before he had to 
leave, but he will get back to me this evening or tomorrow. I also left a 
message for Stu Turley, to let him know you had followed up and see what 
else he could tell me.  

Here's a stroke of luck that we may, if we get the chance, use at the right 
time:  Manny Fernandez (Gartner, UF Trustee) is on the prospects Board, 
their executive committee, and chairs their "Corporate Governance" 
committee. 

Regarding the permitting issues, I spent considerable time getting briefed 
by their local attorneys, Wade Hopping and Gary Hunter. I asked Gary to 
provide me with a written summary of their issues which will probably be 
more accurate than my retelling of the story.  Hopefully, the client will 
allow this, and you can use it to assess the situation.  This is one side of 
the story, and I am sure DEP has a different perspective. 

The permitting problem that I was aware of when you called me had to do with 
the company not getting air permits before they began an expansion about 2 
years ago. They were under the impression that their existing permits would 
be sufficient.  That situation was corrected.  [FYI: this is a "Title V" air 
emission facility....fiberglass emissions are a bit nasty.] 

More recently they have had problems with manatees and US Fish and Wildlife 
and local manatee clubs.  I am told the company has asked for help from your 
office to get US F & W  to respect Florida rules (speed) within the barge 
canal.  This issue has been very difficult for them, and remains a problem. 

But they are really unhappy about the "raid" you mentioned.  And if their 
lawyers account is reasonably accurate, they have every reason to be. 
Apparently a busload of DEP law enforcement officers, complete with flack 
jackets and guns, with press there to witness, descended upon one of their 
plants in response to a caller who alleged they were dumping hazardous 
waste.  DEP reps apparently mentioned to the press, and they reported, that 
this was a "criminal investigation" involving "suspected felonies".  That 
was in February, '01.  My understanding is that prior to the "raid", when 
the company first heard about the allegations, they did their own testing 
(after informing DEP in case they wanted to witness) and found nothing.  And 
apparently DEP didn't either.  The company feels their reputation was 
needlessly damaged and that the whole thing was mishandled.  

So, we have a lot to overcome to convince the CEO to invest more in Florida. 


Steve Mayberry 
Senior Vice President 
ENTERPRISE 
FLORIDA, Inc. 
The Atrium Building, Suite 201 
325 John Knox Road 
Tallahassee, Florida 32303 
850.488.6300 FAX 850.922.9595

-----Original Message-----
From: Turbeville, Greg [mailto:Greg.Turbeville@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US]
Sent: Monday, December 03, 2001 5:28 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: FW: Background info on OxyContin legislation package to be announced in Orlando tomorrow




fyi

 -----Original Message-----

From:   Benard, Andrew  <mailto:[mailto:andrew.benard@myflorida.com]> [mailto:andrew.benard@myflorida.com] 

Sent:   Monday, December 03, 2001 5:25 PM

To:     Turbeville, Greg

Cc:     Shanahan, Kathleen; Jimenez, Frank

Subject:        Background info on OxyContin legislation package to be announced in Orlando tomorrow

Greg,

Per your request, here are some bullets regarding the process by which this legislation was developed:

(OxyContin is a breakthrough chronic pain management medicine developed by Purdue Pharma, with an explosion in use of product from its intro in 1996 - see attached sales graph in Tab 6 of accompanying Goldenrod handout)

1) The impetus for legislation was: a) a dramatic, sharp spike in overdose deaths reported in state since Summer, 2000; b) OxyContin abuse is a phenomenon largely driven through prescription fraud by addicts and a few bad doctors violating legal and ethical codes by grossly over prescribing these drugs - either deliberately, in a willfully ignorant manner, or in simple ignorance of proper pain management practices; and finally C) the seemingly lethargic ability of the Board of Medicine to shut down these bad doctors.

2)  Office of Drug Control, with SEN Burt providing support for any resultant legislation, initiated an broad effort to turn this problem around.

It has attempted to do this by:

        A) receiving a comprehensive brief from the Board of Medicine's Quality Assurance Committee in the early August on what the disciplinary process is for doctors accused of malfeasance and/or nonfeasance; and getting commitments from the group to be part of the process to make improvements so as to avoid the horror stories this Office has been made aware of, of bad doctor abuses occurring around the state; setting stage for recognition  by the medical community that more must be done to "police its own" in a more effective manner

        B) making OxyContin abuse a priority of the Drug Policy Advisory Council meeting in Tampa on 27 August, with the Council fully supporting a comprehensive fix to long standing problems in how the prescription drug system functions in Florida, and the underlying problems with chronic pain management;  this then reinforced the public hearing process.

        C) Board of Medicine convened a series of open hearings on the problem around the state in late summer and fall to vette the various recommendations pouring forth from the medical and law enforcement communities on fixing this problem.  The Bd. of Medicine has been very proactive in this regard; FDLE, AHCA, and DOH have all also stepped up to the plate to help design an effective piece of legislation.

No doubt, the medical community - to include especially the FMA, Bd. of Pharmacists, and the Nurses Assoc. - and others I can't remember off the top of my head - also all wanted to participate in this process, and did so. In conversation I had with their reps., it was clear they wanted to be intimately involved in this effort, so as to not have overly onerous rules/laws foisted on them  - and they were by being full participants.

I myself represented this Office at the first meeting in Ft. Lauderdale on 29 August, attended by all of the above, plus SEN Burt and AG Butterworth. Ideas were discussed, tabled for review for legal sufficiency, common sense checks.

        BOTTOM LINE:  This legislation pulls no punches, and has been developed with the participation of all of the above groups.  I do not know how many have seen the text, but the three bills incorporate many of the 61 suggestions adopted through the Bd. of Medicine's hearing process.  The substantive bill is the crux, with many ideas put forward - such as tamper proof prescription pads - which have been in effect for many years in other states.  I can think of nothing in the legislation that is "revolutionary" or which is not currently in practice in some other state.

The Electronic database is accompanied by a public records exemption bill to assuage the civil liberties concerns with centralized medical database repositories being maintained by the state.  Finally, Criminal penalties have been strongly pushed by SEN Burt, and are a good response to the horror stories these various public hearings brought to light from law enforcement, concerned health care practitioners, and people who have lost loved ones to Oxy ODs.


Technical questions raised by Governor on bullet four as to which specific violations are meant I'm still waiting for an answer from author of that portion.

From: Moore, Tim [mailto:TimMoore@fdle.state.fl.us]
Sent: Monday, December 03, 2001 4:42 PM
To: Jeb Bush; Lauer, Stephen
Cc: Domestic Security Advisory Panel; Domestic Security Co-Chairs; Kathleen M. Shanahan (E-mail)
Subject: RE: GOVERNORS ONLY CONFERENCE CALL WITH GOVERNOR RIDGE TODAY



Governor Bush.......Chief Lauer and i were on the call and  the issue deals 
with another "general, non-specific" alert based upon the holiday season and 
the historical activity of the Al Queida around this time of the year. 
Governor Ridge was clear that the information was "not specific" to any 
particular State and that, should information become available specific to 
any state or location, he would contact us. 

Governor Ridge will be having a press conference immediately to advise the 
nation of this alert. 

While he said he could not reveal the sources, the "credibility of the 
information rises above the norm". 

He emphasized the fact that America "remains on alert".  The top things Gov 
Ridge recommended was 1) to constantly remind our citizens that we are at 
war, 2) now is not the time to pull back from our efforts accross the 
Country, especially as it relates to critical infrastructure protection. 

Governor Ridge stated that his challenge is now to "develop a language" for 
alerts in the future that would be more meaningful. 

Several questions from Governors around the Country reference the need for 
more specifics when these types of Alerts are issued to avoid losing 
credibility. 

Thanks.....tim

-----Original Message-----
From: Sole, Michael 
Sent: Monday, December 03, 2001 10:36 AM
To: Stutler, Denver
Cc: McNeal, Tony
Subject: RE: Beach Erosion


Denver,
 
This morning, I contacted Tony McNeal (permitting administrator with Beaches and Coastal Systems).  He had previously spoken with Ms Blake regarding her inquiry into coastal armoring at the Villager Condominiums in Indialantic.  Unfortunately, the Villager Condominium has not yet submitted a permit application to the Department.  While the Governor has declared a coastal emergency, the local governments apparently have not approved emergency armoring for the Villager Condominium due to the distance of the bluff to the condominium (approximately 29 feet).  I spoke with Ms. Blake this morning and advised her the she could still apply with the Department for armoring under the emergency order.  We had a general conversation about the requirements and options available to her (wood retaining wall, rock revetment, etc.).  Also, we chatted about the need to demonstrate vulnerability in order to be eligible for coastal armoring.  She and the residents of the Villager are concerned that they cannot wait until the scheduled 2003 beach restoration project.  She will be putting together a permit application and submitting it to the Department within the near future.  I encouraged her to contact me if she had any questions or ran into any problems.
 
Let me know if you have any questions.
 
Thanks
 
Mike

-----Original Message-----
From: Martha Pratt [mailto:missmartica@hotmail.com]
Sent: Sunday, December 02, 2001 8:36 AM
Subject: A shameful retreat on arsenic/St Pete Editorial



A Times Editorial 


A shameful retreat on arsenic 
 St. Petersburg Times, 
published December 2, 2001 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 

The arrogance and greed that have come to grip the Florida Legislature were 
on full display Tuesday in Tallahassee. There, lawmakers siding with 
big-business lobbyists killed a bill to outlaw arsenic-laced wood from 
Florida's public playgrounds. 

Of course, "We Bring You Arsenic" is not the message of their ad campaign. 
It's just the result. Lawmakers on the House Agriculture Committee should be 
ashamed for putting the $4-billion wood-treatment industry before the health 
of Florida's children. The Florida Chamber of Commerce blew a terrific 
chance. It could have improved the image of Florida business by showing that 
corporations were responsible enough to balance their profits with public 
safety. Instead the chamber threw its weight behind chemical processors and 
the forestry industry. Rep. Larry Crow of Palm Harbor watched the committee 
kill his bill 6-3. 

The bill is dead, but with any justice the fallout won't be far away. 
Florida is on the leading edge of the treated-lumber debate. More 
arsenic-treated wood is sold here than anywhere else. A series of stories by 
the St. Petersburg Times' Julie Hauserman has prodded federal, state and 
local regulators to take a fresh look at the safety of arsenic-treated wood. 
The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency is testing playgrounds across the 
country, Congress wants some answers and two of the largest home-improvement 
chains face class-action lawsuits by consumers who claim the lumber leaked 
harmful chemicals onto their property. Lawmakers will regret their vote if 
claims of safety by the industry are blown apart by the courts, regulators 
or science. 

There's nothing particularly radical about wanting safer alternatives to 
treated wood. What's perverse about Crow's opponents is that they want to 
see harm before doing the right thing. 


_________________________________________________________________ 
Get your FREE download of MSN Explorer at http://explorer.msn.com/intl.asp 

From:	Mattingly, Rebecca <rebecca.mattingly@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Monday, December 3, 2001 7:48 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	Dana, Pamella; Shanahan, Kathleen
Subject:	FW: Production Partners Program
Attachments:	ProductionPartners-final12-03-01.doc

Governor: 

Finally some success.  We have successfully negotiated the launch of a new 
program between Florida's production and advertising agency community.  It's 
called Production Partners and it is designed to foster greater networking 
and communication between the two divergent groups.  The info below was sent 
out today to all of our local film offices and to the membership of the 
Advertising Federation - Florida Chapter.  A press release will follow in 
the coming days. 

RDM 



Subject: Production Partners Program 


Dear Film Commissioners and 4th District AAF Club Presidents: 

The September 11th terrorist incident has brought all citizens throughout 
the USA closer together to fight a common enemy.  Throughout the country 
though, an unanticipated repercussion of September 11th has been a down turn 
in business activity for many industry sectors.  As a result of this, the 
film & entertainment production industry and the advertising industry have 
experienced a lackluster fourth quarter for new business activity in 2001. 
To address this business downturn, the Governor's Office of Film & 
Entertainment has worked to begin a process of collaboration with the 
advertising industry to reach out to keep Florida business in Florida. This 
new collaboration is geared to help you take control, to help Florida's 
indigenous film & entertainment and advertising industries get better 
acquainted with one another, and to increase awareness to the quality media 
resources that are in your own community.  We want to help you form new 
partnerships of mutual interest and forge new friendships in the name of 
marketing in your own back yard. The Sept. 11th terrorist incident has hurt 
both our industries and this is one way to fight back!  

The Governor's Office of Film & Entertainment* (OF&E) is pleased to begin 
implementing the "Production Partners Program" in conjunction with the 
American Advertising Federation, District 4-Florida** (Ad Fed). We 
look forward to joining our Ad Fed partners and hope this new collaboration 
will be of benefit to both organizations. 

This historic cooperative effort will be started with initial pilot programs 
in fourteen rural/urban areas of the state containing both local film 
commission offices and Ad Fed Clubs. The hope is that both groups will 
increase business activity between each other and learn more about one 
another's resources.  Both the Ad Fed Club member chapters and the Film 
Commission industry organizations have much more in common with one another 
than has been fostered or pursued in the past. 

Please refer to the attached document for your review***, which outlines the 

specifics of the program and how it will be rolled out at the local Film 
Commission offices and Ad Fed Club chapters level.  We look forward to this 
being a positive and beneficial effort for our industries and assisting you 
any way we can. 

Sincerely, 
Robert Grimm 
Deputy Director 
Governor's Office of Film & Entertainment 
1-877-FLA-FILM 
robert.grimm@myflorida.com 

Barb Scherer 
Public Relations Chair 
4th District, American Advertising Federation 
407-426-7272 
bnscherer@aol.com 

*On November 7th, the Film Commissioners Council of Film Florida unanimously 
voted to support a cooperative effort to foster communications understanding 
and networking between the local Florida Film Commission offices throughout 
the State and the American Advertising Association, District 4, Florida 
Chapter, local Advertising Federation Clubs.  On November 8th the statewide 
film &  entertainment association Film Florida unanimously voted to support 
the collaboration. 
  
On November 9th the Florida Film & Entertainment Advisory Council (which 
advises & Supports the Governor's Office of Film & Entertainment) voted 
unanimously to support the collaboration between the Ad Fed Clubs and the 
Local Film Offices.  

**On November 11th the American Advertising Federation, District 4-Florida, 
voted unanimously to support a collaboration with the Governor's Office of 
Film & Entertainment and Florida's local Film Commission offices to support 
business activity with the Florida's local Ad Fed Clubs. 

- Film Florida is an industry association created in 1997 to fill a gap in 
film & entertainment industry communications and is comprised of Florida 
film industry leaders and organizations, film & entertainment labor 
organizations and Film Commissioners that work to promote Florida's  film & 
entertainment industry. 

- The Governor's Office of Film & Entertainment as a result of legislation 
supported by Governor Bush and passed during the 1999 Legislative Session. 
The OF&E was established under the Executive Office of the Governor 
(s.288.1251, F. S.).  Administratively housed under the Office of Tourism, 
Trade and Economic Development, the OF&E is directed, among other things to 
develop and implement a 5-Year Strategic Plan, work with local entertainment 
industry offices to provide service to the industry, promote Florida's 
production locations to the national and international television, movie and 
digital production media industry, and to serve as a liaison between 
government, the entertainment industry and labor interests. 
  
- The Florida Film & Entertainment Advisory Council was formed as a result 
of legislation signed into law by the Governor Jeb Bush, July 1, 1999. 
Created in accordance with Chapter 288.1252 of the Florida Statutes, the 
Florida Film Advisory Council consists of 17 members, seven appointed by the 
Governor, five appointed by the President of the Senate, and five appointed 
by the Speaker of the House of Representatives.  In addition, the Film 
Commissioner, a representative of Enterprise Florida, Inc., and a 
representative of the Florida Tourism Industry Marketing Corporation serve 
as ex officio, nonvoting members of the Council.  The Council serves as an 
advisory body to the Governor's Office of Tourism, Trade, and Economic 
Development and to the Office of the Film Commissioner to provide industry 
insight and expertise related to developing, marketing, promoting, and 
providing service to Florida's entertainment industry. 

- The American Advertising Federation is a national organization that 
advances the business of advertising as a vital and essential part of the 
American economy and culture.  It serves as the unifying voice for 
advertising.  To fulfill its mission, AAF has as its highest priorities:  
effective government and public relations, professional development and 
recognition, public service, social responsibility, high standards and 
providing benefits and services to its members.  The 4th District of AAF is 
comprised of 23 local club chapters throughout Florida and the Caribbean, 
representing over 2,200 members.  The membership is diverse and comprised of 

all facets of the advertising industry, such as ad agencies, 
advertisers/clients, production companies, media, printers, photographers, 
interactive & web developers, independents, market researchers and p.r. 
firms. 

***Should you have any problems opening the attached document, please 
contact 
either Robert Grimm or Barb Scherer.

Dear Governor Bush, 

I was recently at a Restoration of Rights workshop in St. Petersburg and a 
couple of questions arose that I thought would best be answered by you. 

From the discussion, it sounded like applicants who submit their paperwork 
don't hear from the Clemency Board about a number of different items such as 
the following: if their applications have been received; if there is any 
paperwork missing; when their petitions will be heard; or if the 
applications have been refused, why they were refused. 

If this is accurate, as Governor, what is your position on the Clemency 
Board's lack of response to applicants? Are there good reasons for the lack 
of response? Is there something else that applicants need to do to receive 
status updates from the Clemency Board during the process? 

Thanks very much for your consideration. I look forward to your response. 

Happy Thanksgiving. 

Kathy Honan

The City of Tampa in conjuction with Hillsborough Community College

the

just 
west of Raymond James Stadium.  It is my understanding that three of the 
five 
state agencies housed on the 35 acre parcel have either relocated or are 
in 
the process of relocating from the main building, freeing up 
approximately 20 
acres of the total land area and leaving 2 Department of Corrections 
facilities located along Dr. Martin Luther King Boulevard. 

HCC had approached you in the past concerning their interest about use 
of a 
portion or all of this 35 acre parcel to develop an educational and 
amateur 
sports complex on the site.  This use is consistent with 2 earlier 
resolutions passed unanimously in 1994 and 1998 by the Governor and 
Cabinet 
sittin as the Board of Trustees of the Internal Improvement Trust Fund, 
offering the 35 acre parcel to the Tampa Sports Authority.  These 
resolutions 
indicated that each of the 5 state agencies needed to commence 
relocation 
plans to make the property available for the future development of an 
amateur 
sports facility. 

HCC has incorporated your earlier direction to pursue public/private 
initiatives for this project.  Together with Dr. Gwendolyn W. 
Stephernson, 
President of HCC, we have discussed several opportunities for 
incorporating 
this directive with our vision of an educational/amateur sports complex. 

Both HCC and the City of Tampa, recognize the overall benefit to our 
community, particularly to the area youth for development of an 
educational 
and amateur sports-related endeavor on this site, which will also have 
an 
overall positive impact on the citizenry of the state of Florida. 

        

From:	Dana, Pamella <pamella.dana@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Monday, December 3, 2001 7:16 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	Shanahan, Kathleen; Buckey, William; Gillman, Marla; Castille, Colleen; Hirst, Elizabeth
Subject:	nas key west land transfer

Governor, 

NAS Key West informed me today that the transfer of some land from NAS Key 
West to the city will not happen next month as planned.  The US Atlantic 
Fleet has re-evaluated the need for the land and will keep it indefinately. 
I called Admiral Natter, Commander of the Atlantic Fleet, who noted that the 
Secretary of the Navy feels the need to keep the land in Navy control (in 
aftermath of 9/11)--to accommodate increased ships naval ship docking and 
other defense activity.   I would think increased activity will be good for 
local economy (with tourism on the decline).  Navy has agreed to allow for 
dual use of facilities with city as before. 

There may be some local grumbling at first on the holding of land (some 
would like the base gone completely so that they could utilize housing and 
airport for residents/tourism).  I am working with the base and local 
chamber to put together something that shows the current economic impact of 
the military to the community (and if they were to pull out altogether, what 
that would mean economically). 

I called Rep Sorensen and discussed and have also placed calls to the Mayor 
and Chamber president of Key West to make sure that there is minimal 
problems. 

From:	Branker, Laura <laura.branker@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Monday, December 3, 2001 7:04 PM

Subject:	FW: Update on Nursing Home Issues

Follow Up Flag:	Follow up
Flag Status:	Flagged


- Gold Seal - 
 We have 5 applications.  One with no financial information to submit (VA 
nursing home), three being reviewed to determine if they meet the financial 
criteria, and one for which we are awaiting additional information from the 
applicant.  We are working on the next meeting January 16th (location to be 
determined).   Although the panel wanted to wait for roughly 10 applications 
to come in before they met again, we're moving forward with the five.  The 
plan is, at the next meeting, the panel will review the applications and 
them select a sub-committee to conduct a site visit.  Then, at a subsequent 
meeting, the facility has an opportunity to make a presentation, the 
subcommittee will give a report on the site visit, and the panel will vote 
to recommend to the Governor.  That would be followed by an appointment by 
the Governor's Office.  Unfortunately, it will still take a few months. 


Dr,Rhonda M. Medows, 
Secretary 
Agency for Health Care Administration 
State of Florida
