Subject:	STATEMENT BY HOMELAND SECURITY DIRECTOR TOM RIDGE
Attachments:	pic24541.pcx

FYI: Attached you will find a transcript of Gov. Ridge's statement to the press 
after the Governor's only conference call. 
As you can see, he commended the Governors for their work in strengthening and 
improving Homeland Security. 

---------------------- Forwarded by Deborah A. Spagnoli/WHO/EOP on 12/03/2001 
06:20 PM --------------------------- 


(Embedded image moved to file: pic24541.pcx)   Rachael L. Sunbarger 
12/03/2001 05:54:33 PM 


Record Type:   Record 


To: 

cc: 
Subject:  STATEMENT BY HOMELAND SECURITY DIRECTOR TOM RIDGE 





                                THE WHITE HOUSE 

                         Office of the Press Secretary 

                                                                  For Immediate 
Release                          December 3, 2001 



               STATEMENT BY HOMELAND SECURITY DIRECTOR TOM RIDGE 


                        The James S. Brady Briefing Room 



4:55 P.M. EST 


     GOVERNOR RIDGE:  I've just completed a conference call with the nation's 
governors to let them know what I'm here to share with the American people.  I 
might add, I also wanted to commend them for their work in improving and 
strengthening homeland security since September 11th.  We've been in frequent 
communication either with the organizations or with individual governors, and I 
think their work to date has reflected the kind of relationship between the 
federal and the state and local government that we need to make a permanent part 
of our homeland security defense. 

     Over the last several days our intelligence in law enforcement agencies 
have seen an increased volume in level of activity involving threats of 
terrorist attacks.  The information we have does not point to any specific 
target either in America or abroad.  And it does not outline any specific type 
of attack. 

     However, the analysts who review this information believe the quantity and 
level of threats are above the norm and have reached a threshold where we should 
once again place the public on general alert, just as we have done on two 
previous occasions since September 11th. 

     During his address on homeland security in Atlanta, President Bush promised 
the American people that when we have evidence of credible threats we will issue 
appropriate alerts.  That is exactly what we're doing here today. 

     The President also reminded all of us that a terrorism alert is not a 
signal to stop your life.  It is a call to be vigilant, to know that your 
government is on high alert and to add your eyes and your ears to our efforts to 
find and stop those who want to do us harm. 

     Our government is taking precautions.  This afternoon, the FBI is issuing a 
terrorist threat advisory update to 18,000 law enforcement agencies across the 
country through the National Law Enforcement Telecommunication System known as 
NLETS.  Law enforcement agencies have been instructed to stay on the highest 
alert and to immediately notify the FBI of any unusual or suspicious activity. 

     Again, I emphasize this perhaps to my own peril, but, again, the threats we 
are picking up are very generic.  They warn of more attacks, but are not 
specific about where or what type.  We do know that the next several weeks, 
which bring the final weeks of Ramadan and important religious observations in 
other faiths, have been times when terrorists have planned attacks in the past. 

     One example is December of 1999.  Authorities in Jordan, Canada and the 
United States uncovered and prevented plans for a series of attacks related to 
the dawn of the new millennium.  Those plans were thwarted when intelligence 
learned about them, and law enforcement arrested the suspected terrorists. 

     Now, obviously, the further removed we get from September 11th, I think the 
natural tendency is to let down our guard.  Unfortunately, we cannot do that. 
We are a nation at war.  We are the targets of enemies who have demonstrated 
they have no remorse about killing thousands of innocent civilians.  The 
government will continue to do everything we can to find and stop those who seek 
to harm us.  And I believe we owe it to the American people to remind them that 
they must be vigilant, as well. 

     I also know the very first question the American people will ask, so 
Governor Ridge, besides being vigilant, what else should my family and I do? 
The answer is you should report any suspicious activity or behavior to local 
authorities.  And perhaps as importantly, you should heed the words of your 
President, who has called on all of us to rely on our good judgment and our 
common sense to continue to live in a spirit of courage and optimism and 
resolve, to defeat the enemy. 

     Q    What makes these threats credible, besides the volume?  And are they 
coming from any specific terrorist group or cell, for example, al Qaeda? 

     GOVERNOR RIDGE:  Every single day the intelligence community gathers 
information and makes judgments -- renders judgments about their credibility and 
their relevance.  And the accumulation of information we've received over the 
past 
couple of days has risen to the level where we thought it was appropriate to 
again put out a general alert. 

     It comes from multiple sources, and obviously there are men and women 
within the community whose business it has been for years to take a look at that 
information and draw conclusions and determine what we should do about it.  But 
it is just the volume, as well as, obviously, the credibility associated with 
some of the information we've received that led us to have this discussion 
around which there was no disagreement -- that it was at the volume and at the 
level we should remind America we're still at war, we're still at risk, be 
vigilant, be aware. 

     Q    Is there any connection between this new warning and the Israeli 
attacks and the Israeli response to the Palestinian suicide bombings? 

     GOVERNOR RIDGE:  There is nothing in the information that we received that 
would draw a specific connection.  But it is important, I think, to note that 
from time to time, and even in a very vigilant society that's had to deal with 
acts of political terrorism, not for months, but for decades, that the 
unthinkable can happen and innocent people can be killed. 

     Q    Governor Ridge, do you feel that there has been, as you said, law 
enforcement agencies letting down their guard, and the public letting down their 
guard, since Ashcroft announced that there was a heightened state of alert a 
couple weeks ago?  Do you feel that the American public has kind of moved in a 
sense of comfort since that heightened state of alert and nothing has happened? 

     GOVERNOR RIDGE:  Well, I think that America generally has remained at a 
state of readiness and alert and, fortunately, has basically accepted the 
President's encouragement to go live your lives -- at least the retail sales on 
the day after Thanksgiving suggested that a lot of people were back into a 
routine normally associated with this time of the year. 

     But I think it is very predictable and very understandable and very human, 
the further you get, the further away you are from an event, that distance and 
time may even unconsciously erode your commitment, erode that wariness, that 
attention span.  And so, again, to remind everyone we're still at war, we're 
still at risk.  The one war/two battlefields, you know, you've seen pictures of 
those Marines and those soldiers digging in, they don't have to be reminded 
because they've got a conventional battlefield.  Ours is still an unconventional 
battlefield and I think it's very appropriate that we remind all Americans to be 
at alert. 

     Q    Governor Ridge, to follow up, the last time you were here in the 
briefing room you told us that we were on a state of alert indefinitely.  Did 
you ever specifically ask local or federal officials to back off of that state 
of alert?  Or have they backed off in any way? 

     GOVERNOR RIDGE:  I would suspect, depending on the state and depending on 
the decisions that some of the governors may have made in terms of the resources 
and the people they've committed to defending what they consider to be points of 
vulnerability in their states, they may have made some adjustments.  And, 
basically, in my conversation with my colleagues a few minutes ago, I said now 
is not the time to back off.  I believe you're out there, I believe you're 
vigilant, but over the next several weeks, based on this information, it's my 
recommendation you remain at the state of readiness. 

     And the other recommendation, frankly, was to remind their citizens, no 
matter where you live, it can be a big state with a dense population, or you can 
be a smaller state with a lot of rural communities.  We have no way of assuring 
or guaranteeing or pinpointing where the terrorists will attack. 

     Q    Can I ask you about the anthrax?  Are you guys now satisfied that 
Ottilie Lundgren's case came from cross-contamination?  And is that, frankly, 
more of a reason for people to worry about the mail than less? 

     GOVERNOR RIDGE:  Based upon the identification of the letter that followed 
the Daschle letter, and its delivery to the home in her neighborhood, it 
certainly offers a plausible explanation for what transpired.  But it's also, at 
least to date, in conflict with the fact that they'd taken swabs in her house 
where the mail may have been deposited, and other places, and there are no 
traces in her home.  So I think it adds some credibility to an explanation, but 
it does not confirm that explanation. 

     Q    Governor, can you help us and the American people understand the scope 
of this new information?  Does this increased level picked up by intelligence 
services emanate from one part of the world, or is it communications with 
terrorist cells around the world?  And do any of the communications -- is the 
source of those communications here in the United States? 

     GOVERNOR RIDGE:  The information we receive is literally from, as you 
report and as you know, from all around the world.  The sources, in terms of 
their geography, are no different than anything that we received in the past. 
But -- I mean the origin.  But the sources are more credible, and we might just 
say the decibel level is higher, as they talk about potential attacks. 

     Again, the origin is pretty much the same in terms of the location of where 
the information may have been gathered.  But the -- those people involved in the 
communication we deemed as more credible.  And it's also the volume over the 
past couple of days. 

     Q    If I could follow up on that, if I may.  As you evaluate when to come 
before the American people and issue the kind of alert you're issuing here, is 
it a function more of quantity of intelligence, or quality?  Can you give a -- 
if you have any kind of a framework that you can share with us, we'd certainly 
love to know about that. 

     GOVERNOR RIDGE:  Well, it's a very appropriate question.  Suffice it to say 
that judgments are placed upon the different kinds of communication, the 
different kinds of information received on a day-to-day basis.  And, obviously, 
within the intelligence community we've got a lot of very talented people with a 
great deal of experience and are very intuitive.  A lot of them are very 
intuitive about the kind of information they've received, and their ability to 
connect the dots is based upon experience, as well. 

     And sometimes there's legitimate disagreement within the community as to 
whether or not they're specific enough or credible enough, or rise to a level 
where you've got to bring this matter before the American public.  And, 
unfortunately -- giving you a general answer to a specific question, it's more 
of an art than a science -- but the conclusion of everyone who has looked at 
this information over the past couple days was, again, a time to remind America 
we're at war, we're fighting them in Afghanistan, we've got to fight them in 
America, and one of the best ways to combat your enemy is to be alert and be 
mindful -- be situationally aware. 

     Q    Is this information specifically connected, did you say, to the 
observations of Ramadan or other holidays?  And did you consider the impact on 
holiday retail sales of making this warning, and how did that discussion go? 

     GOVERNOR RIDGE:  Certainly, the convergence of different religious 
observations over the next couple of weeks is -- and the impact that that has on 
the celebration of faith and holidays is something that we certainly took into 
consideration. 

     But you know, terrorists, even if there was a specific timetable or a 
specific holiday toward which they were pointing -- I mean, I think we know, 
based on previous experience, that if we were able to disrupt that activity, and 
if they had to postpone it, they would wait until they were prepared and could 
strike. 

     So, yes, it was considered.  We don't believe there should be, nor there 
will be, any change in anybody's plans to participate in their religious 
holidays and to enjoy the seasons and their families.  But, again, the 
convergence of information suggests, ladies and gentlemen of America:  We're at 
war.  Be on alert. 

     Q    Governor Ridge, how should the public understand the process, this 
alert process?  You come out and give us alerts from time to time, and tell 
people what you're told them today.  But alerts never seem to get lifted; we 
just get new ones to replace the old ones.  And I'm just wondering if you worry 
about people becoming jaded as a result of this process. 

     Q    What's the President's role in -- 

     GOVERNOR RIDGE:  The President -- this matter was presented to the 
President this morning, and he approved our decision to go forward and make the 
announcement.  Discerning specific, credible information and concluding that it 
gives rise to a reminder to America that we're still at war, is a -- as I said 
before, is an art, it's not a science.  And it would be so much easier, 
admittedly, if there were more specifics we could refer to.  But there are not. 

     These are shadow soldiers.  This is a shadow enemy.  As a soldier, from 
time to time, in my personal experience and a lot of other soldiers have 
experienced in a more conventional wartime situation, offer -- often, you are 
given information about the location of the enemy, the size of the enemy, 
perhaps how the enemy is equipped.  This is a little bit different time. 

     But, again, as we make those calculations and draw those conclusions, 
there's not always broad-based agreement that this is a credible threat.  We 
viewed these as credible, and that's why we're just asking America to be on 
alert, be ready. 

     Q    Is this more serious than the other two threats, though?  Is this 
alert -- threat alert more serious than the previous two? 

     GOVERNOR RIDGE:  You know, conceivably, if you take a look, this has been 
the third alert, clearly.  But every day, we accumulate information.  Every day, 
the analysts take a look at the sources.  Every day, they try to put the dots 
together.  But it's not every day that either Attorney General Ashcroft or I 
have come out to the podium.  And it has been the aggregation of this 
information and the unanimous conclusion by the experts over the past couple of 
days as they've looked at it, it's now time to come back out and tell -- remind 
America we're still at war and be on alert. 

     Thank you very much. 

                            END                  5:11 P.M. EST 









From:	Steve Mayberry <SMayberry@floridabusiness.com>
Sent:	Monday, December 3, 2001 6:09 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	Pam Dana (E-mail); John Anderson; Roger Miller
Subject:	CONFIDENTIAL:  Prospect follow up

Regarding the prospect you called me about this morning: 

After researching the company and recent history in Florida, I called the 
contact the CEO gave you. We had a brief conversation before he had to 
leave, but he will get back to me this evening or tomorrow. I also left a 
message for Stu Turley, to let him know you had followed up and see what 
else he could tell me.  

Here's a stroke of luck that we may, if we get the chance, use at the right 
time:  Manny Fernandez (Gartner, UF Trustee) is on the prospects Board, 
their executive committee, and chairs their "Corporate Governance" 
committee. 

Regarding the permitting issues, I spent considerable time getting briefed 
by their local attorneys, Wade Hopping and Gary Hunter. I asked Gary to 
provide me with a written summary of their issues which will probably be 
more accurate than my retelling of the story.  Hopefully, the client will 
allow this, and you can use it to assess the situation.  This is one side of 
the story, and I am sure DEP has a different perspective. 

The permitting problem that I was aware of when you called me had to do with 
the company not getting air permits before they began an expansion about 2 
years ago. They were under the impression that their existing permits would 
be sufficient.  That situation was corrected.  [FYI: this is a "Title V" air 
emission facility....fiberglass emissions are a bit nasty.] 

More recently they have had problems with manatees and US Fish and Wildlife 
and local manatee clubs.  I am told the company has asked for help from your 
office to get US F & W  to respect Florida rules (speed) within the barge 
canal.  This issue has been very difficult for them, and remains a problem. 

But they are really unhappy about the "raid" you mentioned.  And if their 
lawyers account is reasonably accurate, they have every reason to be. 
Apparently a busload of DEP law enforcement officers, complete with flack 
jackets and guns, with press there to witness, descended upon one of their 
plants in response to a caller who alleged they were dumping hazardous 
waste.  DEP reps apparently mentioned to the press, and they reported, that 
this was a "criminal investigation" involving "suspected felonies".  That 
was in February, '01.  My understanding is that prior to the "raid", when 
the company first heard about the allegations, they did their own testing 
(after informing DEP in case they wanted to witness) and found nothing.  And 
apparently DEP didn't either.  The company feels their reputation was 
needlessly damaged and that the whole thing was mishandled.  

So, we have a lot to overcome to convince the CEO to invest more in Florida. 


Steve Mayberry 
Senior Vice President 
ENTERPRISE 
FLORIDA, Inc. 
The Atrium Building, Suite 201 
325 John Knox Road 
Tallahassee, Florida 32303 
850.488.6300 FAX 850.922.9595

& Growing a Small Business, which I have found very helpful.

had no phone service as of April this year due to being unemployed on the 
fourth of February when the company I was driving for closed its doors.

he has a phone line.  I travel twenty-three miles to his house about once 
a week to check my e-mail and use the Internet.

when I found out about the program. On August 29, I was given an 
appointment for September 14 with Carolyn Wilkerson, which was changed to 
September 18.  After making several phone calls to the Cross City office 
I received an appointment and was evaluated on November 21 by Sherry 
Inman. I am currently awaiting the results of this evaluation, which I 
was assured that it would be this week.  Ms. Inman mentioned something 
about the possibility of employment testing water at various locations. 
I have been unable to find a listing on the Internet for anything like 
this. There has been no listings of jobs for which I am qualified or able 
to preform within a fifty mile radius of Cross City. 
I have been continually turned down by local business because of my 
service connected disabilities. Yet the VA only pays me about $98 a 
month.  I have been refused assistance by ever program I have been able 
to find out about. 
My wife Diane was hurt on the job at Great Bear Industries in Cross City 
which limited the jobs she can preform.  On top of that she was struck by 
a car as a pedestrian which compounded her disabilities. Neither 
insurance has fully taken care of her medical bills. Thank God Suwanee 
River Economic Council has put her on call as a care giver which allows 
her to earn $40 for each day they call on her. 
Now I need a job as soon as possible as we are about to lose our home and 
car.  We have no heat as we can not afford to purchase the minimum amount 
of LP gas, but at least Florida Power and the local water department is 
working with us. We need any kind of help or assistance we can get.  We 
are both willing to work but the system refuses to employee us.  Messages 
can be left for us at Diane's mother's number(352)498-2168.  Thanking You 
in advance for any and all assistance you may provide. With All Due 
Respect, Joseph Blitch, PO Box 248, Cross City, FL 32628.

From:	Bahrami, Kimberly <Kim.Bahrami@MyFlorida.com>
Sent:	Monday, December 3, 2001 6:09 PM
To:	Jeb Bush; Brogan, Frank
Cc:	Shanahan, Kathleen; Castille, Colleen; Henderson, Cynthia; Tom McGurk; Medows, Rhonda M.D.; TIM MOORE; Crist, Charlie
Subject:	STO Aggregated Oracle Purchase Results

Just a quick note to let you know about actual savings produced when people 
from different agencies work together in technology. The State Technology 
Office combined our Oracle software license purchase last week with those of 
the Agency for Workforce Innovation, Agency for Healthcare Administration, 
Florida Department of Law Enforcement, and the Department of Education. 
Because of the size of the individual purchases, each agency was able to 
negotiate a discount.  However, by combining the purchases, the STO was able 
to negotiate an additional $640,000 in savings this year.  Over the next 
three years, an additional savings of $400,000 in lower maintenance fees 
will also be realized.  The cooperation between these agencies has allowed 
us to save the state significant dollars.  I want to thank Tom McGurk, 
Rhonda Medows, Tim Moore and Commissioner Charlie Crist and their staff for 
helping in the coordination of this effort. I also want to thank Cynthia 
Henderson and DMS purchasing staff for their assistance in coordinating this 
multi-agency project through the purchasing process. 

By working together to aggregate purchases for commonly used technologies 
within the agencies, I am confident this is the first of many statewide cost 
savings ventures to follow!  

Kim

the operation of a girls high-risk facility in St. Johns.  Tone is

will be sent to other facilities distances away from home.

was going to deal with the huge number of cuts-- what is the implementation

determinations.  Did we have vacancies sufficient to off-set the position 
cuts?  Explained that vacancies did not necessarily equate to positions cut 
-- example an office secretary in Tallahassee probably could not fill a 
vacant certified detention worker position in Orlando.  What would be DJJs 
lay-off strategies? Explained that leadership was working on that. How did 
it feel to be the agency hardest hit by cuts?  Said that I did not know that 
way true and that all shared in the sacrifices that were being made and we 
would continue to work to see that the public was protected and that the 
needs of youth were met.  Asked if I had anything to add on background -- 
answer "No."

Dear Jeb,  I am concerned about the practice of issuing drivers licenses to 
people with Visas that are about to expire.  Yesterday I was in the Drivers

yet still given a Florida License that is good for four years.  About 30

the Visas are expiring within a week or two, why is Florida issuing a 
license

From:	Turbeville, Greg <Greg.Turbeville@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US>
Sent:	Monday, December 3, 2001 5:28 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	FW: Background info on OxyContin legislation package to be announced in Orlando tomorrow

 -----Original Message-----

From:   Benard, Andrew  <mailto:[mailto:andrew.benard@myflorida.com]> [mailto:andrew.benard@myflorida.com] 

Sent:   Monday, December 03, 2001 5:25 PM

To:     Turbeville, Greg

Cc:     Shanahan, Kathleen; Jimenez, Frank

Subject:        Background info on OxyContin legislation package to be announced in Orlando tomorrow

Greg,

Per your request, here are some bullets regarding the process by which this legislation was developed:

(OxyContin is a breakthrough chronic pain management medicine developed by Purdue Pharma, with an explosion in use of product from its intro in 1996 - see attached sales graph in Tab 6 of accompanying Goldenrod handout)

1) The impetus for legislation was: a) a dramatic, sharp spike in overdose deaths reported in state since Summer, 2000; b) OxyContin abuse is a phenomenon largely driven through prescription fraud by addicts and a few bad doctors violating legal and ethical codes by grossly over prescribing these drugs - either deliberately, in a willfully ignorant manner, or in simple ignorance of proper pain management practices; and finally C) the seemingly lethargic ability of the Board of Medicine to shut down these bad doctors.

2)  Office of Drug Control, with SEN Burt providing support for any resultant legislation, initiated an broad effort to turn this problem around.

It has attempted to do this by:

        A) receiving a comprehensive brief from the Board of Medicine's Quality Assurance Committee in the early August on what the disciplinary process is for doctors accused of malfeasance and/or nonfeasance; and getting commitments from the group to be part of the process to make improvements so as to avoid the horror stories this Office has been made aware of, of bad doctor abuses occurring around the state; setting stage for recognition  by the medical community that more must be done to "police its own" in a more effective manner

        B) making OxyContin abuse a priority of the Drug Policy Advisory Council meeting in Tampa on 27 August, with the Council fully supporting a comprehensive fix to long standing problems in how the prescription drug system functions in Florida, and the underlying problems with chronic pain management;  this then reinforced the public hearing process.

        C) Board of Medicine convened a series of open hearings on the problem around the state in late summer and fall to vette the various recommendations pouring forth from the medical and law enforcement communities on fixing this problem.  The Bd. of Medicine has been very proactive in this regard; FDLE, AHCA, and DOH have all also stepped up to the plate to help design an effective piece of legislation.

No doubt, the medical community - to include especially the FMA, Bd. of Pharmacists, and the Nurses Assoc. - and others I can't remember off the top of my head - also all wanted to participate in this process, and did so. In conversation I had with their reps., it was clear they wanted to be intimately involved in this effort, so as to not have overly onerous rules/laws foisted on them  - and they were by being full participants.

I myself represented this Office at the first meeting in Ft. Lauderdale on 29 August, attended by all of the above, plus SEN Burt and AG Butterworth. Ideas were discussed, tabled for review for legal sufficiency, common sense checks.

        BOTTOM LINE:  This legislation pulls no punches, and has been developed with the participation of all of the above groups.  I do not know how many have seen the text, but the three bills incorporate many of the 61 suggestions adopted through the Bd. of Medicine's hearing process.  The substantive bill is the crux, with many ideas put forward - such as tamper proof prescription pads - which have been in effect for many years in other states.  I can think of nothing in the legislation that is "revolutionary" or which is not currently in practice in some other state.

The Electronic database is accompanied by a public records exemption bill to assuage the civil liberties concerns with centralized medical database repositories being maintained by the state.  Finally, Criminal penalties have been strongly pushed by SEN Burt, and are a good response to the horror stories these various public hearings brought to light from law enforcement, concerned health care practitioners, and people who have lost loved ones to Oxy ODs.


Technical questions raised by Governor on bullet four as to which specific violations are meant I'm still waiting for an answer from author of that portion.

Governor Jeb Bush

Dear Governor Bush:

Congratulations on a job well done Governor!  While the Special Session of the Legislature has not yet come to a close, it is apparent to this Republican observer it will be a tremendous success for the sunshine state, thanks mainly to your leadership and the team work of President McKay and Speaker Feeney.

There is however one issue in the CS/SB 2C Conference Report that was hastily crafted in the final hours over the weekend that deserves some close scrutiny.  The proviso on line item 570 of Section 6 of the General Government budget contains language that automatically cancels all contracts between the state and private firms to operate prison facilities in Florida.

While this proviso is intended to save the state money and there is a provision that allows for a re-issuing of the RFPs to private companies, there is some ambiguous language regarding who would set the standards and criteria for the new RFPs.  This ambiguity could (and I feel would) lead to a point where there is a non-response situation for all proposals.  In that case, the proviso then calls for the Department of Corrections to step in and take over some, if not all of these facilities.  All of this would occur prior to next summer.

In my opinion, private prison companies have been a terrific asset to our state, and so I would ask that you please examine this situation closely.  If your conclusions determine the same type of uncertainty in this wording, I would urge that you please reject the proviso language on line item 570 and request the Legislature to take a second look.  I think a full and fair hearing from all sides of the privatization issue next session would undoubtedly lead to a better work product for the people of Florida.

Thank you for your consideration and if you need any additional information, I would be happy to oblige.  Again, congratulations on a great special session and I hope you and your family have a very Merry Christmas.

Sincerely,


Tom Slade

-----Original Message----- 
From: david.twiddy@dot.state.fl.us [ mailto:david.twiddy@dot.state.fl.us] 
Sent: Monday, December 03, 2001 4:22 PM 
To: greenthb@verizon.net; frank.jimenez@myflorida.com; 
tom.barry@dot.state.fl.us; kenneth.morefield@dot.state.fl.us; 
ricky.langley@dot.state.fl.us 
Subject: RE: FW: Save Our Neighborhood letter 


Dear Ms. Ciemniecki: 

Governor Bush has requested that I respond to your letter and email dated 
November 26, 2001.  We appreciate your concern on how this project may 
affect your community. 

In 1999 Manatee County requested the Florida Department of Transportation 
(FDOT) to perform a Project Development and Environment (PD&E) Study on the 
Upper Manatee River Road/Fort Hamer Road corridor upon the completion of a 
feasibility study performed by Manatee County in 1998. The Upper Manatee 
River PD&E Study established a project study area bound by I-75, SR 64, Rye 
Road, CR 675 and US 301.  Within this study area four (4) alternatives, 
I-75, Rye Road + CR 675, and Rye Road + Golf Course Road and the Upper 
Manatee River Road/Fort Hamer Road corridor were examined.  Each of these 
alternatives were examined and compared based on environmental impacts, 
social impacts, construction costs, and local and regional traffic 
efficiency. 

During the traffic analysis phase of the project the following scenarios 
were used: 

                  I-75:  Eight and ten lane alternatives 
               Upper Manatee River Road/Fort Hamer Road:  Four and 
               six lane improvements and a two, four and six 
          lane bridge. 
                  Rye Road + CR 675:  Four lanes 
                  Rye Road + Golf Course Road:  Four lanes 

Based on the level of development (currently under construction and 
approved for construction) within the study area, population estimates 
provided by Manatee County and the 2000 US Census, it was determined that 
the Upper Manatee River Road/Fort Hamer Road corridor was the most 
appropriate corridor to benefit both local and regional traffic needs. 
Since 1979 a total of 19 residential and commercial developments have been 
approved within the study area.  These 19 developments represent, at total 
approved build-out, over 10,000 single family homes and 1,500 multi-family 
units(apartments). 

The recommended lane configuration for the 2025 design year was identified 
as six lanes from SR 64 north to Old Tampa Road, with and six lane bridge 
crossing, and four lanes from Old Tampa Road north to US 301.  This lane 
configuration is consistent with the need identified in the 
Sarasota/Manatee MPO 2025 Financially Feasible Long Range Transportation 
Plan. 

According to the Sarasota/Manatee MPO 2025 Financially Feasible Long Range 
Transportation Plan a total of 26 lanes are needed for all of Manatee 
County by 2025.  Six of these lanes are identified east of I-75 at Upper 
Manatee River Road/Fort Hamer Road.  Currently there are only 12 lanes 
crossing the river and only an additional 10 lanes are affordable 
county-wide. 

The current construction cost estimate (exclusive of right-of-way cost) is 
$44.2 million for the Upper Manatee River Road/Fort Hamer Road corridor 
with six lanes from SR 64 north to Old Tampa Road, inclusive of a six-lane 
bridge crossing, and four lanes from Old Tampa Road north to US 301.  By 
comparison expansion of I-75 to 10 lanes would cost $98.3 million, a four 
lane improvement to Rye Road and CR 675 would cost $90.7 million and a four 
lane improvement to Rye Road and Golf Course Road would cost $126.3 
million. 

Improvements to SR 64 and SR 70 are also part of the transportation 
solution for the east/west movements and do not address the localized and 
regional needs for north and south movements within this portion of Manatee 
County. 

The recommended six and four lane typical sections for Upper 
Manatee River Road/Fort Hamer Road also include sidewalks and designated 
bicycle lanes on both sides of the road for pedestrians. 

The exact location of the proposed bridge crossing was based on several 
factors including available right-of-way, location and orientation of the 
existing river channel and environmental criteria.  Based on emergent 
wetland and floodplain impacts, the Upper Manatee River Road/Fort Hamer 
Road crossing is least impactive of all potential crossings of the four 
corridors analyzed.  The FDOT has received letters from the United State 
Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS) and the National Marine Fisheries Service 
(NMFS) stating that the project has no significant impact to the natural 
environment or the habitat of any listed threatened or endangered species. 

Noise issues are a concern to the FDOT and a complete noise impact study is 
being performed as part of the study.  Representatives from the FDOT will 
be available to discuss the results of the analysis at the Public Hearing 
in the Spring of 2002. 

On April 13, 2001 the Bradenton Herald ran an article that the Manatee 
Historical Society had determined that the Fort Hamer site was somewhere on 
the recently completed Waterlefe golf course.  The Upper Manatee River PD&E 
has received a letter of "no effect" from the State of Florida's State 
Historic Preservation Officer (SHPO).  This letter was based on the 
research done as part of this PD&E study and based on the research 
performed in conjunction with many of the 19 developments mentioned above. 

I hope this addresses some of the concerns voiced by you and your 
neighbors.  Thank you for your involvement in this project and I would 
encourage you to attend the Public Hearing in the spring of 2002. 


David A. Twiddy, Jr., P.E. 
District Secretary, District One 
Phone:  SC557-2201 or (863) 519-2201 
Fax:  (863) 534-7265 
E-mail:  david.twiddy@dot.state.fl.us

From:	Moore, Tim <TimMoore@fdle.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Monday, December 3, 2001 4:42 PM
To:	Jeb Bush; Lauer, Stephen
Cc:	Domestic Security Advisory Panel; Domestic Security Co-Chairs; Kathleen M. Shanahan (E-mail)
Subject:	RE: GOVERNORS ONLY CONFERENCE CALL WITH GOVERNOR RIDGE TODAY

Governor Bush.......Chief Lauer and i were on the call and  the issue deals 
with another "general, non-specific" alert based upon the holiday season and 
the historical activity of the Al Queida around this time of the year. 
Governor Ridge was clear that the information was "not specific" to any 
particular State and that, should information become available specific to 
any state or location, he would contact us. 

Governor Ridge will be having a press conference immediately to advise the 
nation of this alert. 

While he said he could not reveal the sources, the "credibility of the 
information rises above the norm". 

He emphasized the fact that America "remains on alert".  The top things Gov 
Ridge recommended was 1) to constantly remind our citizens that we are at 
war, 2) now is not the time to pull back from our efforts accross the 
Country, especially as it relates to critical infrastructure protection. 

Governor Ridge stated that his challenge is now to "develop a language" for 
alerts in the future that would be more meaningful. 

Several questions from Governors around the Country reference the need for 
more specifics when these types of Alerts are issued to avoid losing 
credibility. 

Thanks.....tim

From:	George Zoley <gzoley@wackenhut.com>
Sent:	Monday, December 3, 2001 3:41 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Need for veto of Line Items 570 and 189B

Dear Governor Bush: 

During the conference committee process this past weekend, amendments were 
made in the areas of privatized corrections and the Sexually Violent 
Predator (SVP) project/program which we urgently ask you to veto. 

1)  Section 6 - General Government, Line Item 570: Special Categories 
(Correctional Privatization Commission) directs the Correctional 
Privatization Commission to re-bid by mid-March 2002 all existing private 
prison contracts, thus canceling even those contracts that are in the middle 
of their contract terms. 
*       The language requires that the new bids achieve a 7% cost savings that 
will be determined soley by OPPAGA in consultation with the Dep't of 
Corrections and the Auditor General. 
*       This process is completely disruptive and unfair to all existing private 
contractors who won their current contracts, and is unnecessary. 
*       Under current law, OPPAGA conducts an audit to verify that private 
contractors achieve a 7% savings with the opportunity for the CPC to comment 
on the report and make any necessary adjustments. 
*       To our knowledge, all private prison contracts are achieving the 
statutorily required 7% cost savings at this time. 
*       If the 7% savings are not achieved, the current contracts allow for 
appropriate reductions under the threat of contract termination. 
*       Thus, there is absolutely no need for any further legislative directives 
to the CPC on this issue. 
* 
*       The cancelation of major privatization contracts in mid-term that were 
competitively bid and awarded sends a terrible message to the business 
community as to the state of Florida honoring its contractual commitments. 
Governor, we urge you to veto Line Item 570 and the accompanying language of 
the Conference Report. 
* 
*       2)  Implementing Act, 4C, Section 5, contains language that is tied to 
Line Item 189B and does the following: 
*       Cancels the existing procurement for the development and operation of a 
600-bed Sexually Violent Predator facility which we were awarded by the CPC 
in a competitive bid and after having spent a half million dollars; 
*       Instead, directs DCF to issue a new RFP on just the operation of the 
existing SVP facility; and 
*       Directs the DOC to develop a plan to construct a new major institution 
adjacent to the Desoto Correctional Institution. 

This language constitutes another cancelation of a major privatization RFP 
after an initial award by the CPC and defense of the award through an 
administrative appeal process at great expense to our company and the state 
of Florida.  This sends another terrible signal to the business community as 
to the state of Florida's commitment to privatization.  Our company is fully 
capable of providing for the professional development and operation of an 
SVP facility as set forth in our accepted RFP proposal. We are still 
awaiting an opportunity to begin the negotiations to reach a mutually 
agreeable cost-effective SVP program for the state of Florida.  Governor, we 
urge you to veto Line Item 189B and the accompanying language of the 
Implementing Act. 

I can be reached at the following numbers: 

Home:  (954) 785 5667

George C Zoley, CEO & Vice Chairman 
Wackenhut Corrections

From:	Robinson, James <RobinsJ@mail.doe.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Monday, December 3, 2001 3:08 PM
To:	Zan100@aol.com
Cc:	ccristjr@tampabay.rr.com; Horne, Jim; Jinks, Carol; Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: DOE General Counsel 

Dear Mrs. Knox: 

Commissioner Crist is fully committed to the safety and security of our 
school children, and this commitment is reflected, in part, by his careful 
oversight of a highly skilled and dedicated professional practices section 
within the Department responsible for prosecuting misfeasance and 
malfeasance by teachers throughout the State of Florida.  My office is 
responsible for assisting the Commissioner and staff in this crucial effort. 
Yes, we are public servants, and, as such, we work for you and all other 
residents of this fine state. 

We take this responsibility seriously.  Thus, I was troubled to hear of your 
concern over your treatment by members of my staff.  As public servants, we 
cannot let our frustrations get the better of us.  Mrs. Roberts' comment, 
which she did not intend you to hear, was, in fact, directed at you as you 
suspected.  She no doubt tried to cover herself out of embarrassment when 
she realized you were not on hold.  She apologizes for her statement, and I 
ask that you overlook it as uncharacteristic of a public servant with over 
32-years experience in the Office of General Counsel.  By way of 
explanation, if not excuse, I know that she was very nervous and upset after 
talking with you once again.  It is sometimes difficult to be the person in 
the middle.  

I've spoken with Mr. Stowers, who denies using any curse words in his 
discussion with you, although he admits telling you that your repeated 
telephone calls and e-mails concerning the Busshaus case have diverted 
considerable time and attention away from prosecuting far more egregious 
cases of teacher wrongdoing.       

As I wrote in my last letter to you, I would take your calls if I had 
anything new to report on the status of the Busshaus case.  When you called 
last week, I had nothing to report and asked Mrs. Roberts to refer your call 
to Mr. Stowers in case he did have new information.  In making the referral, 
I told Mr. Stowers to tell you that we could not continue to have you take 
up such an inordinate amount of our work time for no apparent reason other 
than to vent your frustration with the Department's handling of the Busshaus 
litigation.  Surely you understand there are other members of staff and the 
public who deserve attention from the Office of General Counsel, and I have 
a responsibility to see that they get it. 

As you know, we hope to get on the February agenda of the Education 
Practices Commission with a settlement agreement, a copy of which I sent you 
a couple of weeks ago.  I understand the agreement has been signed by Mrs. 
Busshaus and her attorney.  If approved, the agreement would result in a 
letter of reprimand, substance abuse evaluation and treatment, periodic 
testing, and 3-years probation. 

There is nothing else to report, nor will there be before the Commission 
meeting.  Once again, please forgive the breach of decorum. 

Sincerely, 

James A. Robinson 
General Counsel 


             

  

-----Original Message----- 
From: Zan100@aol.com [ mailto:Zan100@aol.com] 
Sent: Saturday, December 01, 2001 9:37 PM 
To: Robinson, James 
Cc: ccristjr@tampabay.rr.com; Horne, Jim; Jinks, Carol; jeb@jeb.org 
Subject: DOE General Counsel 


Mr. Robinson: 

    You and your staff are  public servants.  As  public servants 
responsible 
for prosecuting disciplinary actions involving wrongdoing by educators, you 
and your staff act on behalf of and for the protection of children who 
attend 
public schools.  My family is included among those who should be the 
beneficiary of the work that you and every other lawyer and staff member in 
your office have been hired to perform.  I would expect that you and your 
office staff would understand your relationship to the citizens of this 
state.  

    Obviously your staff does not understand that relationship.  As evidence 

I draw your attention to the unacceptable behavior exhibited by your staff 
during a telephone call with me this past week.  During that conversation 
your secretary, Paula, told me that she was going to put me on hold for a 
moment.  Then I heard her say "Sorry, there is a pain in the  ass woman on 
the other line." When I informed her that the "pain in the ass woman" she 
was 
speaking of was still on the line, she backtracked and said she had been 
talking about another woman who had made a public records request pertaining 

to FCAT.  Perhaps she was.  It really does not matter.  I am sure the "other 

woman" is also a citizen of this state who deserves the same respect and 
service as any other person seeking information from their government.  But 
that respect is apparently lacking within your department. 

    Another example of your department's disrespect for citizens expressing 
interest in your department's performance was the unacceptable language used 

by Mr. Stowers, who I understand is a lawyer in your office,  to sum up his 
opinion about my perseverance in the case involving my daughter's former 
teacher.   He stated that my perseverance in following up on that teacher's 
case has cost your department thousands of dollars and that the progress of 
the case  is "none of your damn business".  Mr. Stowers followed up on that 
comment by threatening to swear out a "harassment" complaint because of 
telephone calls that I have made in an effort to make sure that your 
department follows through on what he characterized as "just a piddly 
little 
DUI case".  For the record, Mr. Stowers felt it necessary to yell during the 

majority of the conversation despite my requests that he stop yelling.  I am 

unsure if you informed Mr. Stowers of your letter to me, copied to Robin 
Safley and David Ashburn, requesting all my inquiries regarding this matter 
only go through you.  For the record, I was doing that.  Your secretary, 
Paula, asked me the day before to call back in an hour or so to find out 
what 
the status of the settlement agreement was.  The next day your secretary, 
Paula, directed my return call to Mr. Stowers.  I was informed by Mr. 
Stowers 
of the state's threat to swear out a complaint.  

    Those types of  comments are completely outrageous, unacceptable and an 
affront to me and every other citizen in this state.  I would suggest that 
you have a heart to heart talk with your staff and then issue an immediate 
apology.  You, as department head, set the tone for what you will tolerate 
with respect to staff behavior.  At this time I find your staff's behavior 
to 
be completely unacceptable. 

    Please govern yourself accordingly. 
    
                        Sincerely, 

                        Shannon Knox    

P.S.  If the case involving my daughter's former teacher's is, in fact, 
"just 
a piddly little DUI", why will it have taken over a year to reach the 
settlement?

Subject:	MAIL ORDER PILOT PROGRAM FOR DIABETES

Dear Jeb.....
It is my understanding that the mail order pilot program for diabetes for patients along the I-4 corridor (Central Florida) requires that patients receive their diabetic medications and supplies through an out of state provider Health Alliance.  Not only is that an outrage for businesses within this state but that it makes no sense at all medically.- it is dangerous to the patient.  Our pharmacy presently provides medication management for the Senior Resource Alliance which includes 5 counties in Central Florida.  We monitor not only their diabetes but also the diseases which are a direct result on non-compliance,  inappropriate use of medication, failure to properly educate, etc.  And- it is at no charge to anyone including the Medicaid program. There is no way to control the health of these people with the therapy bifurcated and with incomplete patient history at our pharmacy.   It is inconceivable that you would allow this to go to a company which up to this point has not performed in a satisfactory matter when you have a woman owned business in this state (and a staunch Republican member of the Republican Congressional Committee Business Advisory Council) right here in Central Florida (Orlando).  I understand that you will be in Orlando tomorrow and I would hope that you would have a few moments to speak with me as I have been invited by Rich Crotty to attend-as a member of OCREC.  Please e-mail me concerning this.  Thank you.
N. Lois Adams

Subject:	Advertising Activity Report November 12 - 30, 2001

Over the past few weeks we have continued to work with the travel industry relative to potential partnerships and the $20 million co-op advertising plan.  The Co-op Advertising Guidelines were forwarded to the industry during mid-November and to date we have been in discussion with 65 tourism organizations/companies relative to the economic stimulus monies.  Currently we have received 40 proposals from the industry which are now under review and some decisions will be made and announced by next week.  

We shall keep you appraised of the partnerships involved in the deals, along with the total dollars anticipated.  I would expect that we will continue to receive various proposals from the industry throughout the first quarter of 2002.

Our marketing strategy continues as previously reported and the only other significant activity is that we have approximately 1,000 offerings in our Hot Deals section of the Website, and are completing other offerings with the Florida Department of the Lottery for a January announcement of the FLAUSA game.

Our next update will be Monday, December 17.  If you have any questions, please advise. 

Thank you.

Marie Dinon
 
 

Hi, my name is Jeb Bush and Im the Governor of Florida.  

 

When Ponce de Leon first happened on our Gulf Coast, he was searching for the Fountain of Youth.  Each year many visitors to our state, realize what he really found was a paradise.  

 

For more than 30 years my family and I have vacationed in beautiful Southwest Florida.  

 

Its glistening beaches and emerald waters are rated among the best in the world, and its mild, tropical climate insures nearly everyday is filled with sunshine.

 

Whether youre interested in a quick, get-away vacation or life-long move, this island coast is a great destination.  Youll find a blend of upscale and down home.  Depending on you taste, you can choose from exclusive golf communities, quite tree shaded neighborhoods or sun-drenched shores.  

 

Discover for yourself why so many corporations are recognizing the benefits of relocating to Southwest Florida.  

 

At work or at play, Floridas Gulf Coast is a great place to live and do business.  

 

Come on down!  

 

Discover Southwest Florida.

Dear Governor Bush:

1. Negroid ----->2. Mongoloid -----> 3. Caucasoid 

I am a little confused.  When did Hispanic become a race?  I was taught that Hispanic's are of the Caucasian race. Why is it a prerequisite that the person replacing Jodi Gleason be Hispanic? I certainly would hope that the best candidate be chosen regardless of what box they check on their questionnaire. I do not think we should be forced into any decision based on the outcry of any ethnic group, that has been mistakenly added as an additional choice for race. I think that you should talk to the Indians from Guatemala, that reside in Lake Worth, and ask them how they feel about being labeled Hispanic.

There appear to be candidates who are campaigning for the appointment, that have had a very short residency in Palm Beach County. Is the motive for seeking appointment purely self-serving?

I would hope that you would interview members of any prior boards that all of the candidates have served on in the past. Contact the schools that their children attend.  See how involved they are, and whether their involvement is positive or negative. I would hope that you would not force an appointment on Palm Beach County that will serve no purpose other than to appease an ethnic group. I would certainly expect you to choose a candidate that has a proven history of commitment to the students in Palm Beach County.

Please do your homework thoroughly prior to making this appointment, which has tremendous impact on the residents and children of Palm Beach County. Please do not turn this into a popularity contest amongst your colleagues. I would suggest qualifications, such as having been a former educator, as Mr. Cantley was, would better serve in justifying your appointment, than what ethnic group the person belongs to.


Sincere Thanks,


Chelle Konyk

-----Original Message-----
From: Martha Pratt [mailto:missmartica@hotmail.com]
Sent: Sunday, December 02, 2001 8:36 AM
Subject: A shameful retreat on arsenic/St Pete Editorial



A Times Editorial 


A shameful retreat on arsenic 
 St. Petersburg Times, 
published December 2, 2001 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 

The arrogance and greed that have come to grip the Florida Legislature were 
on full display Tuesday in Tallahassee. There, lawmakers siding with 
big-business lobbyists killed a bill to outlaw arsenic-laced wood from 
Florida's public playgrounds. 

Of course, "We Bring You Arsenic" is not the message of their ad campaign. 
It's just the result. Lawmakers on the House Agriculture Committee should be 
ashamed for putting the $4-billion wood-treatment industry before the health 
of Florida's children. The Florida Chamber of Commerce blew a terrific 
chance. It could have improved the image of Florida business by showing that 
corporations were responsible enough to balance their profits with public 
safety. Instead the chamber threw its weight behind chemical processors and 
the forestry industry. Rep. Larry Crow of Palm Harbor watched the committee 
kill his bill 6-3. 

The bill is dead, but with any justice the fallout won't be far away. 
Florida is on the leading edge of the treated-lumber debate. More 
arsenic-treated wood is sold here than anywhere else. A series of stories by 
the St. Petersburg Times' Julie Hauserman has prodded federal, state and 
local regulators to take a fresh look at the safety of arsenic-treated wood. 
The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency is testing playgrounds across the 
country, Congress wants some answers and two of the largest home-improvement 
chains face class-action lawsuits by consumers who claim the lumber leaked 
harmful chemicals onto their property. Lawmakers will regret their vote if 
claims of safety by the industry are blown apart by the courts, regulators 
or science. 

There's nothing particularly radical about wanting safer alternatives to 
treated wood. What's perverse about Crow's opponents is that they want to 
see harm before doing the right thing. 


_________________________________________________________________ 
Get your FREE download of MSN Explorer at http://explorer.msn.com/intl.asp 

From:	Ric Cooper <rcooper@cooperandhayes.com>
Sent:	Monday, December 3, 2001 1:22 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	Kathleen Shanahan
Subject:	Penelas' PRE-K Program

Jeb... 

Mayor Penelas has been aggressively seeking support for a voluntary early 
childhood (pre-K) development and education program. He's provided a "white 
paper", as well as his info relative to getting a pre-K program on the 
ballot in the near future. Others have indicated to me that this idea has 
actually been floating around Tally for several years. Based on what has 
been provided, this seems to be a good, viable program. 

That said, Micky Arison, myself and other friends who have been approached 
don't want to lend our support unless this is something that you are 
supportive of, or at least "neutral" on. We'd appreciate it if somebody 
could let us know. 

Hope things are going well...hope to see you tomorrow in Orlando. All my

Ric 

From:	Medows, Rhonda M.D. <medowsr@fdhc.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Monday, December 3, 2001 1:19 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	laura.branker@myflorida.com
Subject:	Nurse Practitioners/FMA and DEA/Controlled Medication prescribing


I know you did not ask my opinion but.... 

I have had the pleasure of working closely with 2 Nurse Practitioners who 
were wonderful clinicians. 
We worked well as a team. They reviewed their diagnosis and treatment plans 
with me for all the patients they treated. 
After getting to know them and working beside them, I had little concern 
that they would go beyond their training. 

Not all doctors have worked as closely with their nurse practioners and not 
all doctors who are supposed to be 
supervising nurse practitioners are on site in the facility where the care 
is being rendered -although I thought they were required to be. 

I suspect the biggest concerns/objections physicians will raise are 
-Any expansion in the scope of practice that may be perceived as an increase 
in competition 
-Nurse Practioners still have to be supervised by doctors and doctors will 
still ultimately be held responsible for the patient's well being. 


#1 is just the natural order of things.  The health care industry is 
evolving like other industries and people's roles will change 

#2 might be more acceptable if the level of supervision and accountability 
between doctors and nurses was clarified or enhanced. 
     For example, patient medical notes from each nurse practioner's 
patient visit have to be reviewed and/or co-signed by doctors now.  
     Maybe it could be required that the nurse practitioner have her/his 
notes and cases presented to the physician for review within a clearly 
defined time period like within 
     24 hours, by close of business, or at the end of a shift so that any 
questions or concerns the physician may have about the treatment course can 
     be addressed sooner rather than later.  Florida Statutes define the 
supervisory role physicians have to play. Maybe expanding on it or 
clarifying it will help. 

Not all physicians are represented by the FMA. In fact most aren't  Some 
depend heavily on nurses as patient care extenders in order for their 
practices (and their patients) to survive 
Dr,Rhonda M. Medows, 
Secretary 
Agency for Health Care Administration 
State of Florida

I assume right now, florida agriculture community is biggest opponent of this.  if that assumption is correct, i would suggest doing a separate short paragraph to address the governor's intention to advocate for terms that will protect florida growers against unfair trade practices such as dumping, etc.  or, even better, is there anything we can say now, such as the president has assured us that they will vigorously protect against unfair trade practices.  i don't know what conversations we have had with administration on this.
 
by way of history, Clinton promised to protect florida growers from dumping as part of their "look the other way" support on NAFTA.  Clinton then did little to help once the dumping began.  Growers are weary of similar overtures from new administration and similar failure to follow through.  we need to assure them that this is not the Clinton admininstration and that they will take dumping and other unfair trade practices very seriously.

From: Kathy Honan [mailto:khonan@tampabay.rr.com]

To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Question



Dear Governor Bush, 

I was recently at a Restoration of Rights workshop in St. Petersburg and a 
couple of questions arose that I thought would best be answered by you. 

From the discussion, it sounded like applicants who submit their paperwork 
don't hear from the Clemency Board about a number of different items such as 
the following: if their applications have been received; if there is any 
paperwork missing; when their petitions will be heard; or if the 
applications have been refused, why they were refused. 

If this is accurate, as Governor, what is your position on the Clemency 
Board's lack of response to applicants? Are there good reasons for the lack 
of response? Is there something else that applicants need to do to receive 
status updates from the Clemency Board during the process? 

Thanks very much for your consideration. I look forward to your response. 

Happy Thanksgiving. 

Kathy Honan

-----Original Message----- 
From: Sharpe, Bob [ mailto:sharpeb@fdhc.state.fl.us] 
Sent: Monday, December 03, 2001 12:18 PM 
To: 'michael.hansen@laspbs.state.fl.us' 
Cc: Blanton, Travis; Medows, Rhonda M.D. 
Subject: Medicaid Eligibles in KidCare 


Here is the deal.  It appears that children already in KidCare, Title XXI, 
who become Medicaid eligible can stay in KidCare and we can get the higher 
match during the remainder of their continuous eligibility period (i.e., 12 
months) [according to CMS Regional Office, other states have been approved 
for this].  Have to ask for Federal approval.  But children can't initially 
choose KidCare if they are Medicaid eligible.

From:   Mimi Jackson [ mailto:mjackson20@juno.com]

Subject:        funding Pitcher Plant Prairie 

Dear Mr. Glisson, Honorable Gov. Jeb Bush, and Florida State Legislators: 

        I live in west Escambia County where the surrounding Pitcher 
Plant properties abound. Not only am I in favor of funding for the 
acquisition of more acreage for the purpose of "preservation of the 
plant", but I am also in favor of acquisition to help preserve the NAS 
that is so important to our economy. Furthermore, there seems to be so 
many difficulties with containing the development of Perdido Key and 
Perdido Bay areas, the added benefit of funding the acquisiton of the 
prairie property would be to aid the county in curbing over development. 
Another benefit is to lessen traffic problems on Sorrento Road West. I 
support all efforts to fund the purchase of Pitcher Plant Prairie 
properties. Thank you for your interest. Be assured that we residents and 
garden club members are extremely supportive of all you do in the 
interest of our environment and protection against over development. 
Sincerely, Mimi Jackson, 5161 Pale Moon Dr., Pensacola, Fl. 32507.

-------------------------------------------------------------------- 
Published Saturday, December 1, 2001 

Playhouse eviction threatened 

In an escalation of a monthslong dispute between the Coconut Grove Playhouse and the state, Secretary of State Katherine Harris is now threatening the theater with eviction. A lawyer for Harris notified leaders of the state-owned Playhouse in a letter Thursday that if they don't agree to certain conditions involving the property by Friday, he would recommend eviction.

From:	Simnszz@aol.com
Sent:	Monday, December 3, 2001 12:28 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Please Help Romanian-Amerocan Teen volunteer
Attachments:	RE: Nick's Backpack story on Internet (2.55 KB)

Dear Governor Bush, 
Nick's story has gone to over 100,00 thousand websites.  We have heard from Uganda, Australia, Arizona, Russia, Romania, and Brazil.  The only ones we haven not heard from yet are influential people who can help us transport the backpacks safely to Romania.  We just sent the following letter to Bart Conners and Nadia Comaneci.  Hopefully they will respond.  Several other celebrities who are humanitarians have also been contacted.  We hope you or one of these other contacts will help us.  It would be good publicity for Florida since a young Florida teen volunteer is making such an incredible difference in this world.  His volunteerism can change the world for millions of orphans worldwide. 

We know that you are extremely busy.  We just need to know if you can help us.  If you can, please let us know as soon as possible.  We want to deliver supplies to Romania by Christmas. Thank you for listening and may you and your family have blessed Christmas. 

Peace and blessings, 
Connie Simon 


Dear Mr. Conners and Ms. Comaneci, 

We know that you rarely respond to private email.  However, this is an urgent matter and we hope you will make an exception. Our son, Anton Nicolai (Nick) Simon, was adopted from a Romanian orphanage in 1990. He spent his first 5 1/2 years in one of Romania's poorest orphanages. Last summer, he heard about the children who weren't adopted.  They are kids our son's age who are being released to the streets without any family, skills or education. Many live in sewers beneath Bucharest and beg for food to survive.  This upset our son, Nick, tremendously. 

He decided to do something to help them.  He started a program called Backpack Carepak to collect new and nearly new backpacks, scarves, gloves, sweatshirts, combs, caps, and socks to help them endure the harsh winter months ahead.   

Nick's story has inspired many people to better appreciate how wonderful it is to have the gift of a family.  Hundreds of young people in our local schools have donated winterwear and backpacks.  Now our greatest obstacle is finding transportation.  We were going to have a concert to raise money for transportation costs, but the anthrax threat and high cost of insurance and security put that idea on hold indefinitely. 

Please read Nick's story located at the following web site.  It will take just a couple of minutes and we hope that you think it is worthwhile. 
http://joanbramsch.com/helpothers/backpack.shtml 

After reading it, if you want to help us, our greatest need is transportation.  If you know anyone with airline connections to Bucharest or a large plane that will transport supplies from Florida to Romania, would you please make the contacts to help us? We would deeply appreciate any help you can give Nick's project.   

Many people have been helping to make this project a success.  Kids at one school raised 500 dollars in pennies to buy backpacks.  An elderly lady knitted 100 hats for street kids.  A woman from Minnesota has made over 300 polar fleece scarves. Groups of all ages want to help these kids because Nick has inspired them to care about others who have so little. 

Nick is an outstanding young man who has overcome incredible challenges.  We are very proud of him.  We think he was the only one to get out of Orphanage #4 because he was meant to be a spokesperson for those who have no voice.  Nick wants to make a difference in this world.  Will you help him if you can?   

Nick wants to help the orphans in Romania first and then expand humanitarian aid in the future to orphans in China, Brazil, Afghanistan, Russia, and Africa.  There are millions of abandoned children worldwide in desperate need of help.  Not one major advocacy program exists today to advocate solely for orphans or abandoned children.  Nick wants to start one and will call it O.W.L.S. for Orphans Without Love or Shelter.   

Over the years, advocates have helped many worthy causes such as whales, turtles, trees, owls.  They have saved many species from harm or extinction.  We think even more people care about orphans.  We want to join together to advocate for children worldwide who need protection and shelter. Incredibly, a former orphan from Romania is leading the way. 

Thank you for reading this email and if you can help us locate a plane to deliver Backpack Carepaks to Romania before Christmas, we would be so grateful.  Any help or direction you can give this project will be deeply appreciated.  God bless you and your family. 

Most sincerely, 
The Simon Family 
Connie, Paul, Nick, and Liana 
3165 Hanging Moss Circle 
Kissimmee, FL 34747 
(407) 518-1801

From:	Doreen Rutledge <Doreen_Rutledge@dcf.state.fl.us>

Cc:	Cecka Green; Kathleen Kearney; Jeb Bush
Subject:	NBC donation


We can not do any releases or other coverage. I heard from NBC this morning 
and they wanted to pull the donation because we are a state agency and not 
a 501C3 non profit. I have scrambled around to line up some of my community 
501C3's to accept the donation for us. They are afraid that should any 
press coverage result stating we (DCF) had received a donation from them 
they would be swamped with calls from other states and governors. I assured 
them we would handle it through other avenues and I would get back to them. 
As of right now the State foster parents association, Special Opportunity 
Fund of South Florida and the Foster Care Council of Southwest Florida will 
accept the donation. My office will still manage it but officially it is 
theirs. The National Guard called this morning and will assist within 
allowable guidelines. Thanks Governor! 
I will let you all know the final arrangements.

industry and innovative ideas.  Limited finance background.

NASA Chief of Staff)--strong space, commercial finance and bonding 
experience.

-----Original Message----- 
From: DOH Bulletin 
Sent: Friday, November 30, 2001 11:58 AM 
To: DL All DOH Employees 
Subject: Pay Increase 



From: Governor Jeb Bush [ mailto:Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com] 
Sent: Friday, November 30, 2001 11:52 AM 
Subject: Pay Increase 


November 30, 2001 

To All State Employees: 

I am pleased to report that all eligible non-temporary state employees 
earning $90,000 a year or less have received a pay increase of 2.5 percent, 
effective November 1, 2001.  I believe it's important to preserve the pay 
increase passed by the Legislature in May for those earning more modest 
salaries.  

However, special appreciation must be extended to those forgoing their 
annual pay raise to help balance our state budget.  As you know, a decline 
in state revenues due in large part to the terrorist attacks of September 11 
and the drop in airline travel has necessitated cuts in the current year's 
budget.  

Those who join me in making this sacrifice are helping us preserve essential 
services to our people, while funding our new initiatives in domestic 
security and economic stimulus.  Floridians will be safer, and the coming 
economic recovery will be accelerated for all our people, in part because of 
this sacrifice. 

I hope every state employee shares with me a renewed sense of purpose 
following the terrorist attacks of September 11.  It is a great privilege to 
serve the people of the Sunshine State, and an even greater privilege to 
serve during times that challenge us.  Your hard work and dedication is 
valued. 

Sincerely, 
Jeb Bush

From:	Dana, Pamella <pamella.dana@myflorida.com>

-----Original Message-----
From: Donna Ross [mailto:ross@floridaattractions.org]
Sent: Monday, December 03, 2001 9:32 AM
To: ross@floridaattractions.org
Subject: Attraction Business Status Report #6


Florida Attractions Association 
Business Status Report #6 

The Florida Attractions Association is a trade association, founded in 1949,  representing more than 80 family-oriented attractions including astronaut, historical, cultural, military and scientific museums; castles; collections of the unique and different; dinner entertainments; dolphin and marine parks; exhibitions of alligators, lions, monkeys, parrots, butterflies and manatees; gardens; Indian villages; sightseeing trains, cruises, airboat and trolley tours; theme parks; water parks; and zoological parks. 
  


ATTRACTION BUSINESS INDICATORS  
(Based on  25 Benchmark Attractions) 


Attendance % Change 2001 vs 2000 


Week of 


11/21-11/27 
-05  Statewide 
 00   North 
 00  Central/Central East 
-15  Central West 
-15  Southwest 
-10  Southeast 
-05 The Keys 


Notes: 
>  Thanksgiving weekend helps most attractions 
>  Concerns about school group business continue to worry smaller attractions 
  


11/14-11/20 
-20  Statewide 
-20   North 
-30  Central/Central East 
-15  Central West 
-15  Southwest 
-25  Southeast 
-10 The Keys 


Notes: 
>  Discounting kicks in 
>  Some attractions notice increased traffic due to pre-Thanksgiving activities 
  


11/7-11/13

Notes:

-25   North

+05  Central West 
-15  Southwest

-40 The Keys 


Notes: 
>  Severe winds and other problems in North Florida 
>  Hurricane Michelle forces evacuations and closures in The Keys and affects business in South Florida 
>  Halloween helped! 
>  South Florida attraction writes, "Hoping for a turn-around in mid-December."

>  Discounting continues 
>  Some local advertising kicks in

-20  Statewide 
+10  North

-15  Southwest

-05 The Keys 


Notes: 
>  First time we've seen positive numbers since 9/11 
>  In North region, Panhandle down while St. Augustine is up 
>  School holidays help 
>  High hopes for Halloween special events 
  


10/10-10/16 
-20  Statewide 
-05  North 
-20  Central/Central East 
-15  Central West 
-15  Southwest 
-25  Southeast 
-10 The Keys 


Notes: 
>  Anthrax continues to be a concern 
>  Bookings for holiday events continue to be slow 
>  Fantasy Fest will help the Keys 
>  Resident market continues to be extremely important 
>  More joint promotions with each other for attractions 
  


10/3-10/9 
-25  Statewide 
-10  North 
-35  Central/Central East 
-15  Central West 
-5  Southwest 
-25  Southeast 
-25  The Keys 


Notes: 
>  Anthrax  in the news 
>  More layoffs at attractions and nationally 
>  More attractions reduce hours of operations 
>  In Central West, reports of no Europeans; most business is resident and those who drove 2-3 days to get there 
>  Speculation that travelers are concerned about their finances/jobs 
>  In Southwest, some corporate end-of-summer picnics cancelled due to layoffs, money donated to relief funds, feelings that it is inappropriate to celebrate at this time 
>  In Southwest, no cancellations reported, but bookings for special events are significantly down 
>  More Halloween promotions planned 
>  When asked about prospects for the rest of 2001, respondents expect business to improve somewhat or stay about the same 
>  When asked about prospects for 2002, respondents expect business to improve somewhat or stay about the same

-05  Central West 
+10  Southwest 
No change  Southeast 
No change  The Keys 


Notes: 
>Larger attractions minus 
>Smaller attractions plus 
>Some small attractions up 5% 
>Most report business was soft starting in July 
>Advertising on hold 
>Most close on 9/11

From:	Stutler, Denver <Denver.Stutler@dep.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Monday, December 3, 2001 10:50 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	Sole, Michael; Bedwell, Allan; FL_DEP

Governor:
 
Mike Sole contacted Ms. Blake this morning.  The following e-mail summarizes the status.
 
Let us know if we can provide any additional help.
 
Denver
-----Original Message-----
From: Sole, Michael 
Sent: Monday, December 03, 2001 10:36 AM
To: Stutler, Denver
Cc: McNeal, Tony
Subject: RE: Beach Erosion


Denver,
 
This morning, I contacted Tony McNeal (permitting administrator with Beaches and Coastal Systems).  He had previously spoken with Ms Blake regarding her inquiry into coastal armoring at the Villager Condominiums in Indialantic.  Unfortunately, the Villager Condominium has not yet submitted a permit application to the Department.  While the Governor has declared a coastal emergency, the local governments apparently have not approved emergency armoring for the Villager Condominium due to the distance of the bluff to the condominium (approximately 29 feet).  I spoke with Ms. Blake this morning and advised her the she could still apply with the Department for armoring under the emergency order.  We had a general conversation about the requirements and options available to her (wood retaining wall, rock revetment, etc.).  Also, we chatted about the need to demonstrate vulnerability in order to be eligible for coastal armoring.  She and the residents of the Villager are concerned that they cannot wait until the scheduled 2003 beach restoration project.  She will be putting together a permit application and submitting it to the Department within the near future.  I encouraged her to contact me if she had any questions or ran into any problems.
 
Let me know if you have any questions.
 
Thanks
 
Mike
 
-----Original Message-----
From: Stutler, Denver 
Sent: Saturday, December 01, 2001 2:27 PM
To: Sole, Michael; Bedwell, Allan
Cc: Cooper, Cameron
