-----Original Message-----
From: VillagerHOA@aol.com [mailto:VillagerHOA@aol.com]
Sent: Friday, November 30, 2001 8:51 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Beach Erosion
Dear Mr. Bush, 
Thank you for your response to my email but the concern we have is that with 
29 feet between our building and the cliff edge we well not be able to 
withstand two more seasons of Northeasterly storms and God forbid we have to 
endure a hurricane.  
Also help me understand why it is, that it is so difficult to obtain permits 
for preventive measures rather than waiting for emergency conditions.  Our 
building is 13 stories and for us to wait until the cliff edge is 10 to 15 
ft. from the building before  armoring structures are considered, seems to be 
very foolish.   Everywhere I turn I am told no armoring structures, then I go 
down to Melbourne Beach and they received a permit from the DEP for an 
armoring structure.  But, this permit was not obtained until he was in an 
emergency condition.  Please, any help you can direct me to would be much 
appreciated.  We believe NOW is the time to act. 
Sincerely, 
Nancy Blake 
Villager Homeowners Associaion 
877 N. Hwy A1A, #1300 
Indialantic, FL 32903 
(321) 724-1880 
From:	Yablonski, Brian <brian.yablonski@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Monday, December 3, 2001 10:48 AM
To:	Oviedo, Nina; Jeb Bush
Cc:	Branker, Laura; Shanahan, Kathleen; Jimenez, Frank; Dana, Pamella; Freedman, Melissa
Subject:	RE: Cong Putnam/TPA

I assume right now, florida agriculture community is biggest opponent of this.  if that assumption is correct, i would suggest doing a separate short paragraph to address the governor's intention to advocate for terms that will protect florida growers against unfair trade practices such as dumping, etc.  or, even better, is there anything we can say now, such as the president has assured us that they will vigorously protect against unfair trade practices.  i don't know what conversations we have had with administration on this.
 
by way of history, Clinton promised to protect florida growers from dumping as part of their "look the other way" support on NAFTA.  Clinton then did little to help once the dumping began.  Growers are weary of similar overtures from new administration and similar failure to follow through.  we need to assure them that this is not the Clinton admininstration and that they will take dumping and other unfair trade practices very seriously.
-----Original Message-----
From: Nina Oviedo [mailto:oviedon@sso.org]
Sent: Friday, November 30, 2001 2:55 PM

Subject: RE: Cong Putnam/TPA


Team----Attached is the proposed letter on TPA.  Pls review very carefully---you know the players far better than us.  
Frank/Laura----if Gov approves, who has lead on finalizing?
 
Governor-----According to Hill polling by the National Journal, only 5 of our 23 Members are solidly behind TPA.  1 leans yes; 7 are undecided; 5 lean no and 2 are solidly against; 3 are unknown.  Across the board, WH does not have the votes yetrumors are that theyre short 30 votes.  But, there are lots of leanings and undecideds still out.   The vote is scheduled for Thursday, Dec 6.  See below re delegation.
 
Solid Yes-----Diaz-Balart, Goss, Keller, Dan Miller, Shaw
 
Lean Yes-----Crenshaw
 
Undecided----Boyd, Davis, Meek, Hastings, Young, Jeff Miller, Mica
 
Lean No------Brown, Putnam, Deutsch, Stearns, Foley
 
Solid No-----Thurman, Wexler
 
Unknown----Bilirakis, Ros-Lehtinen, Weldon

From: Ronald Reid [mailto:flash415@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Thursday, November 29, 2001 10:23 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: BOARD OF GOVERNORS FOR THE CITY OF TAMPA PORT AUTHORITY 


    
To The Honorable Governor Jeb Bush;
    Dear sir, I, Ronald B. Reid as a member of the Republican Party and a member of the Tampa Bay Black Republican Club am asking for you to appoint Gladstone A "Tony" Cooper Jr. to the position of BOARD OF GOVERNORS FOR THE CITY OF TAMPA PORT AUTHORITY.
    
    I know Tony Cooper to be a motivated businessman fluent in the language of Spanish who with a background in banking, vast international business experience and has traveled to over 37 countries.  He has over 10 years experience in international trade with the last 12 years focusing on construction and real estate management.  
 
    I also know Tony Cooper to be a man of community involvement serving along side me in the Tampa Bay Black Republican Club and being a active member of the Hillsborough Republican Party shining a positive light on our party and our community through his leadership and involvement.  
 
    Therefore I believe there could be no other choice as qualified to represent this party and your administration in this position.  
 
                                                                                       Thank you for your time 
                                                                                           Ronald B. Reid

From:	Jimenez, Frank <frank.jimenez@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Monday, December 3, 2001 10:11 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: A citizen's plight, I need help.

The Dept. reached out to Mr. McCool and explained several serious misconceptions he had (about the number of times they had taken down his marker and the way they had treated other people's markers).  They told him that they wouldn't interfere with his marker during the holidays.  They explained the DOT Marker Program, which was established precisely so that people could have markers, without being allowed to put up anything they feel like putting up without limits.  I think DOT helped.  The only other response would have been "You can put up whatever you want."  But if they aren't telling every other Floridian this, why is Mr. McCool entitled to be told this?  I will get with DOT and see how the follow-up went with him.

-----Original Message-----
From: Dennis McCool [mailto:DMcCool@cfl.rr.com]
Sent: Tuesday, November 06, 2001 3:25 AM
To: help@eog.state.fl.us; admin@eog.state.fl.us; bushj@eog.state.fl.us
Subject: A citizen's plight, I need help.


I need help in getting DOT off my case and figuring out why the memorial cross which I put on the side of the highway at the location of my son's death (to a traffic accident) keeps being removed.  I understand the Party Line. There is a regulation......yadda... yadda... yadda. Yet there are scores of other locations in Central Florida where the roadside memorial are not removed.  I have replaced the little white cross 15 times along with a $30 arrangement of silk flowers and I will continue to replace the memorial and flowers.  I just don't understand why the DOT is being so vigilant in my case and totally ignoring all the others. MOST notably there are two locations where Orange county police officer have been killed. Not only is there a massive collection of flower and crosses at these locations, the Orlando Sentinel even did a story about how those memorials were part of the grief and healing process for the family and friends of the deceased.  
I have to read that, agree with everything they say and then go out in a day or two and spend more time and money trying to keep one step ahead of the DOT highway pickup crew.  It isn't fair. PERIOD.  My 18 year old son dying in a car accident wasn't fair either, but there is no one to talk to about that, it can't be undone. 
It's not like this is an eyesore or a cluttered mess. It is a simple white cross and bouquet of silk flowers.  We long ago removed all the little momento the high school kids put out and we keep it neat, so no one has reason to complain. 
SO, my question.  How do I get DOT to leave this roadside memorial alone.  It isn't hurting anyone. It doesn't look bad. And it is much smaller than most of the other similar roadside memorials in this area (which do not get removed).
 
Please help.
The location is at the intersection of SR 46 at Lake Forrest Blvd. (one mile west of I-4 on Route 46)
Thank you.
Dennis McCool
407-302-3400

From:	McFadden, Liza <liza.mcfadden@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Monday, December 3, 2001 9:51 AM
To:	Willet Andrea (E-mail); Broward, Maureen Kohler; Collier, Susan McManus; Don Pemberton (E-mail); Ekholm Janet (E-mail); Fred Sanguiliano; George Ed and Marnie (E-mail); Griffin Karin (E-mail); Jack Kane (E-mail); Joe York; Juhan and Pat Mixon (E-mail); Lois Gracey; Polk - MargaretAnn Wheeler; Radar Nicole (E-mail); St. Lucie - Judi Miller; Vicki Drake

Importance:	High

I just talked with the House budget writers and the budget is one the desk 
of legislators at this time.  The final cuts are as follows: 

$62,500 Governor's Mentoring Initiative 
$1.3 Take Stock in Children 
$1.0 Big Brothers 
$502,000 Boys and Girls Clubs 

When I have an official copy, should it differ in any way from the above, I 
will let you know immediately. 

Obviously, one policy was not used across the board.  GMI took a cut in the 
base of about 5%; Take Stock and Big Brothers lost all new funding; and Boys 
and Girls Clubs lost approximately half of new funding. 

Liza McFadden 
Executive Director

From:	Yablonski, Brian <brian.yablonski@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Monday, December 3, 2001 9:27 AM
To:	Shanahan, Kathleen; Jeb Bush
Cc:	Branker, Laura; Jimenez, Frank
Subject:	RE: Fearing Medflies, Ag Officials Yank Fruit From Grocery Shelves - from Tampa Bay

spoke to terry 
they have found flies and larvae in florida, nc and maryland 
fruit is from Spain and it appears that it was not "cold treated" as it 
should have been or the cold    treatment failed. 
grocers are being asked to double bag and destroy all Spanish clementine 
fruits 
USDA is currently doing what they call a "trace back" to find out who and 
what screwed up.  TR    believes they will find it fell apart at AFIS level 
at ports. This issue began last week and        she expressed that AFIS did 
not get info to Florida quick enough -- she has had conversations       with 
Bobby Acord, head of AFIS, and they have agreed to expedite info. 
USDA has ordered a "stop sale" on ALL citrus coming from Spain 
Florida Ag is increasing its monitoring of fruits and keeping a close watch 
on this. 
When medfly outbreak occured a number of years ago, there was aerial and 
ground spraying of      Malathion -- it was a pr nightmare akin to citrus 
canker

Dear Governor Bush: 

We survived a day with each other! I think we should both be proud. 

If my interview day is any indication, you are reading this email while 
signing letters, talking on the phone, and getting briefed by your staff. . 
. . You're a heckuva multi-tasker. 


I wanted to thank you again for the unlimited access on Friday. The stories 
we ran that day were spectacular. The one I'm planning to write today will 
be even better (it's the feature piece that will definitely include some 
shoe-shine humor). I was impressed with your handling of budget issues and 
your rapport with Frank Brogan. The friendship you two share is obvious. 
Since this email is considered a public record, and I have to maintain my 
objectivity, I cannot tell you what I think of you. . . . Suffice to say, 
you always have a spot at the Germaise dinner table when you visit Tampa. . 
. AND your dad has every reason to be proud of you. 

Enough sucking up. You have 399 other emails to read today. 

Thanks for the interview, 

Don Germaise 
WFTS TV

From:	Bob Crawford <Bcrawford@citrus.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Monday, December 3, 2001 9:23 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Dear Governor:

Dear Governor: 

We completed the Department of Citrus television commercial shoot and it's now in production at the Shoot Florida studios in Miami. We employed more than 60 Floridians for this effort and spent a higher percentage of revenue in Florida than ever.

Our advertising agency, The Richards Group, is from Dallas, Texas, and was hired back in 1996. We remain committed to more focus on Florida businesses.

Also, President Bush's nomination of me to the Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corporation (Farmer Mac) has been blocked by Senator Daschle. Senator Daschle's position is since the slot requires a Democrat, it should be "one of their Democrats."

Senator Bill Nelson talked to Senator Daschle on my behalf and Senator Daschle said "he would have none of it." 

So it goes. 

Best regards, 
Bob

From:	Jimenez, Frank <frank.jimenez@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Monday, December 3, 2001 9:05 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	FW: Memorial Marker



-----Original Message----- 
From: tom.barry@dot.state.fl.us [ mailto:tom.barry@dot.state.fl.us] 
Sent: Tuesday, November 20, 2001 2:07 PM 
To: DMcCool@cfl.rr.com 
Cc: jeb@jeb.org; jimenef@myflorida.com 
Subject: Memorial Marker 


Mr. McCool: 

Governor Bush has asked me to respond to you recent email (attached below) 
regarding the marker you have placed in the median of State Road 46 in 
Seminole County.  First, we wish to express our sympathy for your tragic 
loss. 

The Department's Memorial Marker program was instituted several years ago 
due to safety concerns as a result of the placement of private markers 
along our highways.  In addition to the act of placement itself, some 
markers were of such a size and structure that they constituted hazards. 
Others obstructed sight distance at intersections.  Additionally, there 
were maintenance concerns, and objections expressed by nearby residents and 
businesses.  In some instances, markers were being placed over the 
objections of the victim's family. 

Still, the Department recognized the need for some people to express their 
grief in this manner.  Our program standardized the markers, and served the 
dual purpose of promoting safety on our highways.  I am aware you have 
elected to participate in this program, and a marker has been placed along 
SR 46 per your request.  Most of those who have participated in our program 
have expressed understanding of our inability to selectively permit private 
markers that are seemingly unobtrusive and present no obvious safety or 
maintenance problems. 

It is our hope you will come to understand that our policy is intended as a 
sympathetic yet responsible option.  Your email indicated your marker had 
been removed on far more occasions than those for which our staff was 
responsible.  This may happen again, or your marker may be cited as an 
example of why others should be allowed.  You yourself cited examples that, 
as our staff was able to explain, were not on the State Road system.  We 
cannot prevent the removal of the marker by others, nor can we ignore 
protests of selective enforcement.  In the absence of any of the concerns 
to which we are obliged to be responsive, I have asked our District staff 
to allow your median marker to remain in place through the holiday season. 

I send you our sincere wishes for a blessed holiday, and our hope the 
passage of time will help heal the pain of such a loss. 

Sincerely, 

Tom Barry 
Secretary 
Florida Department of Transportation 
tom.barry@dot.state.fl.us 








-----Original Message----- 
From: Dennis McCool [ mailto:DMcCool@cfl.rr.com] 
Sent: Tuesday, November 06, 2001 3:25 AM 
To: help@eog.state.fl.us; admin@eog.state.fl.us; bushj@eog.state.fl.us 
Subject: A citizen's plight, I need help. 


I need help in getting DOT off my case and figuring out why the memorial 
cross which I put on the side of the highway at the location of my son's 
death (to a traffic accident) keeps being removed.  I understand the Party 
Line. There is a regulation......yadda... yadda... yadda. Yet there are 
scores of other locations in Central Florida where the roadside memorial 
are 
not removed.  I have replaced the little white cross 15 times along with a 
$30 arrangement of silk flowers and I will continue to replace the memorial 
and flowers.  I just don't understand why the DOT is being so vigilant in 
my 
case and totally ignoring all the others. MOST notably there are two 
locations where Orange county police officer have been killed. Not only is 
there a massive collection of flower and crosses at these locations, the 
Orlando Sentinel even did a story about how those memorials were part of 
the 
grief and healing process for the family and friends of the deceased. 
I have to read that, agree with everything they say and then go out in a 
day 
or two and spend more time and money trying to keep one step ahead of the 
DOT highway pickup crew.  It isn't fair. PERIOD.  My 18 year old son dying 
in a car accident wasn't fair either, but there is no one to talk to about 
that, it can't be undone. 
It's not like this is an eyesore or a cluttered mess. It is a simple white 
cross and bouquet of silk flowers.  We long ago removed all the little 
momento the high school kids put out and we keep it neat, so no one has 
reason to complain. 
SO, my question.  How do I get DOT to leave this roadside memorial alone. 
It isn't hurting anyone. It doesn't look bad. And it is much smaller than 
most of the other similar roadside memorials in this area (which do not get 
removed). 

Please help. 
The location is at the intersection of SR 46 at Lake Forrest Blvd. (one 
mile 
west of I-4 on Route 46) 
Thank you. 
Dennis McCool 
407-302-3400 

From:	Jimenez, Frank <frank.jimenez@myflorida.com>
Sent:	Monday, December 3, 2001 9:05 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	FW: FW: A citizen's plight, I need help.



-----Original Message----- 
From: tom.barry@dot.state.fl.us [ mailto:tom.barry@dot.state.fl.us] 
Sent: Friday, November 16, 2001 2:44 PM 
To: Bush, Jeb 
Cc: jimenef@myflorida.com 
Subject: Re: FW: A citizen's plight, I need help. 



Governor, 

The marker program was begun about five years ago because we had major 
safety concerns for motorists stopping to place memorials on our highways. 
It has generally been well received by families and friends.  Markers can 
have name(s) on them if the relatives desire. 

Mr McCool has requested, and we have installed, the Department's standard 
memorial marker on the side of SR 46.  We continue to have concerns that he 
is placing his memorial in the median of the highway.  My staff has talked 
with him at length, but he believes that he should be allowed to place the 
marker where he wants it. 

We have also found out that someone other than the Department has been 
removing his markers.  His e-mail says it has been removed 15 times, but we 
have removed it no more than four or five times.  The other locations he 
mentions in his note to you are not on the state highway system 

We plan to leave the site alone through the holidays. 

TB 




  

                    "Bush, Jeb"

-----Original Message-----
From: Kathy Honan [mailto:khonan@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Tuesday, November 20, 2001 9:48 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Question



Dear Governor Bush, 

I was recently at a Restoration of Rights workshop in St. Petersburg and a 
couple of questions arose that I thought would best be answered by you. 

From the discussion, it sounded like applicants who submit their paperwork 
don't hear from the Clemency Board about a number of different items such as 
the following: if their applications have been received; if there is any 
paperwork missing; when their petitions will be heard; or if the 
applications have been refused, why they were refused. 

If this is accurate, as Governor, what is your position on the Clemency 
Board's lack of response to applicants? Are there good reasons for the lack 
of response? Is there something else that applicants need to do to receive 
status updates from the Clemency Board during the process? 

Thanks very much for your consideration. I look forward to your response. 

Happy Thanksgiving. 

Kathy Honan

To: Jeb Bush
Subject: BOARD OF GOVERNORS FOR THE CITY OF TAMPA PORT AUTHORITY 


    
To The Honorable Governor Jeb Bush;
    Dear sir, I, Ronald B. Reid as a member of the Republican Party and a member of the Tampa Bay Black Republican Club am asking for you to appoint Gladstone A "Tony" Cooper Jr. to the position of BOARD OF GOVERNORS FOR THE CITY OF TAMPA PORT AUTHORITY.
    
    I know Tony Cooper to be a motivated businessman fluent in the language of Spanish who with a background in banking, vast international business experience and has traveled to over 37 countries.  He has over 10 years experience in international trade with the last 12 years focusing on construction and real estate management.  
 
    I also know Tony Cooper to be a man of community involvement serving along side me in the Tampa Bay Black Republican Club and being a active member of the Hillsborough Republican Party shining a positive light on our party and our community through his leadership and involvement.  
 
    Therefore I believe there could be no other choice as qualified to represent this party and your administration in this position.  
 
                                                                                       Thank you for your time 
                                                                                           Ronald B. Reid

Dear Governor Bush, 

I was recently at a Restoration of Rights workshop in St. Petersburg and a 
couple of questions arose that I thought would best be answered by you. 

From the discussion, it sounded like applicants who submit their paperwork 
don't hear from the Clemency Board about a number of different items such as

paperwork missing; when their petitions will be heard; or if the 
applications have been refused, why they were refused. 

If this is accurate, as Governor, what is your position on the Clemency 
Board's lack of response to applicants? Are there good reasons for the lack 
of response? Is there something else that applicants need to do to receive 
status updates from the Clemency Board during the process?

Kathy Honan

From:	Cheryl Gerstner <cigerstner@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Monday, December 3, 2001 7:51 AM

  Gov. Bush:  Thank you for your reply and continued assistance.  I will lookforward to hearing from Mr. Stutler.  I realize there are others involved in this issue.  I continue to look for  someone in authority to look at the facts and realize that moving this structure will not provide additional stable habitat for turtles.  Again my thanks.  Cheryl Gerstner

-----Original Message-----
From: Cheryl Gerstner [mailto:cigerstner@yahoo.com]
Sent: Friday, November 30, 2001 5:50 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Gerstner Seawall: Indian River County


Dear Gov. Bush: Since January of 1997, I have been trying to complete my
seawall needed to protect what is left of my oceanfront property & my home
in Indian River Bounty. I have been in communication with you on this
matter since February 2000. As you may recall, this 5 year controversy is
over the position of the DEP that the wall is 15 feet too far seaward, and
therfore represents a "take" of turtle habitat. We have through your
efforts, those of local officials, and our own been given a permit to move
the wall as few as 8 feet. We continue to request that we be allowed to
complete the wall in its as-built location for several reasons. The primary
reason is the expense. At $850 a foot, it would cost $78,200 to move this
wall even 1 foot. Some quotes are as high as $1000.00 a foot. We have also
resisted moving the wall for reasons of value to our primary asset, because
we have documented the inconsistencies regarding the placement of permitted
wals elsewhere, and because we know that moving our wall is not going to
make a significant difference. The scuttlebut is that the unwillingness of
the decision makers to reach the obvious conclusion regarding the "Gerstner
Wall" is their fear of setting a precendent. It is not this decision that
willset a precendent; the inconsistent application of the rules and regs has
already established that "opening". What hasn't yet happened is a court
case to expose those Inconsistencies. Noone wants to be the one to take on
that task, and is it really necessary? Chairwoman Ginn if in Tallahassee
today and may contact you to make this same appeal. I know there are
agencies that could not tolerate a $100,000 budget cut. Please consider
what it represents to me and my family and weigh that cost against the gain.
You are acutely aware of the critical condition of our beaches. Seawalls
are only temporary structures that buy time until the conditions dictating
their need can be cured. We need sand by-pass srojects at inlets &
nourishing programs. I would not contact you again if I did not think it
was going to take your influence to get this done. Thank you, Cheryl
Gerstner 




_____

-----Original Message-----
From: Katherine Blyth [mailto:Katherine_Blyth@notes.compaid.com]
Sent: Monday, December 03, 2001 12:53 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Don't let STO slip away - it's such a good plan....






From: Katherine Blyth@CAICORP on 12/03/2001 12:52 AM 

Dear Governor Bush, 

Living and working in Tallahassee for over 18 years, I can tell you that a State 
Technology Office is needed.  So much redundancy can be eliminated  The IT 
community within the State has pretty much written off the idea with the sudden 
departure of Roy Cales. 

Please consider me for the position of Chief Information Officer for the State 
of Florida.  I have thought long and hard about this decision, to serve the 
citizens of Florida, and feel my qualifications can be well utilized. 

I truly believe in your model to have state government run like a business. 
This can be accomplished.  With an Information Technology (IT) budget of over 
$800 million, a significant savings can be realized by selecting someone that 
knows Florida, IT and how Florida/IT has worked and can work! 

I have bid on many IT opportunities with the State - winning many!  From my 
vantage point there are many things that can change - some very small - that can 
substantially save money.  The STO office is a great idea and is needed! 

Prior to joining Computer Aid, Inc three years ago, which I am currently 
Business Unit Manager of Florida, I owned and operated a certified minority IT 
firm.  I have many good ideas to bring to the One Florida initiative as well. 

Being in private industry the last 14 years, in Tallahassee, when we hire 
someone to provide IT service to the State we try to find someone with State 
experience.  Because we know that person will understand the State and bring 
this value to our organization.  I can bring that value to the State.  I 
understand private industry's view of IT.  With my knowledge gained from working 
for the State and servicing the State, I can bring these experiences to the CIO 
position. 

I also know how to make a profit - realizing this is not what the State wants to 
accomplish - these strategies can be brought to the State to reduce cost and 
bring better service to the citizens of Florida! 

My background includes: 
-    registered Republican when I was 18, 
-    Florida citizen for 26 years (since I was 13), 
-    worked for the State Government 
     (Department of Environmental Regulation - 1983-1987), 
-    been working with the State, at an IT consulting firm, for over 10 years, 
-    started, ran, and sold a successful IT company (MBE certifed), and 
-    been part of the

-----Original Message-----
From: MorningFM@cs.com [mailto:MorningFM@cs.com]
Sent: Sunday, December 02, 2001 7:47 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: traffic light



Jeb, 

Would you help me in expediting the process of approving a traffic light? The 
area of concern is the N. Monroe / Universal Rd. (between Tallahassee mall 
and Hooters) This unique portion of N. Monroe is home for 12 restaurants. 
Turning left to access any of these establishments has resulted in many 
wrecks and close calls. A few of which I've personally witnessed while 
dining. Entering and leaving these restaurants during peek periods also 
results in delays and drive-thru backups. For example; the delay in leaving 
the Chic-Fil-A in the morning is 7 minutes waiting for the light at John knox 
to turn. 

I'm no traffic engineer but I believe the time duration of the light would be 
quick since Universal doesn't cross N. Monroe. So rather than a 4 way it 
would only be a 3 way light signal. Its location is precisely halfway between 
Northwood shopping center and John Knox Road. With 12 restaurants now on that 
stretch, a left hand turn during breakfast, lunch or dinner has become a life 
threatening task. Even if this light could be activated during those times 
and remain a flashing yellow the rest of the day would be an improvement. 

Eating establishments are: EL Chico, Arby's, Chic-fil-A, Roadhouse, Boston 
market, DQ, Miami subs, 4TH Quarter, Woody's BBQ, Rallys, Silver Slipper, 
Lindy's. 

Thanks for anything you can do, let me know what I can do as well. 

John Dawson

From:	eisinger <eisinger@hodg-podg.com>
Sent:	Sunday, December 2, 2001 6:40 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Non-profit response to my request to support Gov. Bush in blocking all "turkeys"

Dear Governor:
 
I failed in my attempt to gain the support of my non-profit peers to support your outlawing all turkeys this year if there are to be cuts in social service or education funding. Here's their explanation - some of us are asking for turkeys for this coming year. This may be our only opportunity to offset threatened cuts. It was unanimous - no one would support me. It's pathetic - executive directors are forced to abandon their values and ethics to do whatever it takes to gain much needed funds. They are more than willing to take a long shot at sneaking in through the turkey door rather than meet the issue of  funding cuts head on. I am embarrassed, but I hope that you can understand their desperation - it doesn't matter to them that this is a special year (I tried to explain that we are at war, the Florida economy is down - turkeys may have been the name of the game in the past - but not this year). After so many years of same rates for clients we have diligently served, they feel they have no choice but to go for turkeys - no matter what.                    
 
I still think the right thing to do is to freeze all talk of turkeys for the 2002-2003 budget.
 
Best regards,
 
Fred Eisinger
 
 
Seagull Industries  
From: eisinger <mailto:eisinger@hodg-podg.com>  
To: Jeb Bush <mailto:jeb@jeb.org>  
Sent: Thursday, November 29, 2001 5:54 PM
Subject: cuts to social services, education - turkeys?

Dear Governor:
 
Tonight on the evening news we are hearing about a state legislature that is prepared to make major cuts in spending on education and social services, while approving lots and lots of turkeys. I know how you feel about this. Tomorrow Florida ARC and representatives of Florida ARF will meet in Tampa. I will certainly raise this issue for discussion. I will call for the drafting of a position paper that supports you in not granting one turkey this year. What unmitigated gaul. Talk about being the laughing stock of the nation. What would any right-minded individual think about us if we allowed these duly elected representatives of ours to be so ruthless and self-serving. This is an issue worth demonstrating over, if necessary. I hope it doesn't come to that, but if it does - I hope that my fellow agency professionals will raise their voices in protest. The many must not be sacrificed for the benefit of the few. 
 
Sincerely,
 
Fred Eisinger
Executive Director 
Seagull Industries for the Disabled, Inc.

-----Original Message-----
From: Turbeville, Greg [mailto:Greg.Turbeville@LASPBS.STATE.FL.US]
Sent: Sunday, December 02, 2001 6:07 PM
To: Jeb Bush; Brogan, Frank
Cc: McDougal, Kim; Brown, Brewser
Subject: K-20 Education Flexibility 




Contrary to what was printed in the Feller's article in the Tampa Tribune today, I was told by Kathleen Daly that USF had a draft of our K-20 Education Flexibility language last Tuesday.  Several universities (FSU, UNF, & USF at a minimum) had been reviewing it during the week.

Some of the SUS folks, obviously, don't like the new paperwork that is required by the legislation.

-----Original Message-----
From: Doreen Rutledge [mailto:Doreen_Rutledge@dcf.state.fl.us]
Sent: Sunday, December 02, 2001 4:33 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: Kathleen Kearney
Subject: HUGE DONATION



I know the Secretary emailed you about the huge donation we are going to 
receive from NBC and the TODAY Show. Sam Sagenkahn is the one who is in 
charge of the toy distribution. We will be receiving the majority (or a 
good part of) the Ringling donation which was about $650,000. The way we 
got it was when they announced that this donation would benefit children 
from Florida to Maine I called them and told them they weren't doing their 
part for Florida's kids. I almost croaked when they called me at home this 
morning and told me they would ship me 32,000. toys. THIRTY TWO THOUSAND 
PIECES!!! This is soooo fantastic! Anyway,  now I have another problem, I 
have to get this stuff all over the state. When I was in Jacksonville 
Friday for the ceremony honoring the Florida Air National Guard they 
happened to mention that you were their boss. Makes sense. SOOOO. What are 
the possibilities of you letting them help (if I can get some of them to 
volunteer) to  get this shipment spread out different places where there 
are kids that need it. I can have the toys drop shipped to 2 places and 
then I have to arrange distribution from there. Pensacola, Miami, 
Gainesville, Fort Peirce and Fort Myers will probably get a larger share 
but all the districts will get some. 
Can I ask the National Guard? 
We also received word on Friday that Sears is shipping another load of 
clothes and uniforms etc. south for us out of Atlanta right after 
Christmas. The last load was valued at $948,000.00. 
Not bad eh? 
Well thanks for the support and keep up the good work! 
Doreen Rutledge

Thought you'd like to know that "Last Night in Cuba" has been nominated 
for an Emmy .  It's also been selected to be shown during WPBT's pledge 
campaign (and  offered as a "gift" for donors) and has been accepted for 
screening in several big-time festivals throughout the U.S. (including 
New York, Los Angeles, San Francisco, etc.).  Part two of the trilogy is 
well into production (will deal with three generations of different 
groups of women and their experiences in leaving Cuba). Hopefully, it 
will be complete (remember, it's being produced by students who also 
have to go to school) in time to celebrate your second term as 
Governor.  Would love to show it also in Tallahassee. 

All the best, 
Bob

-----Original Message-----
From: Martha Pratt [mailto:missmartica@hotmail.com]
Sent: Sunday, December 02, 2001 8:22 AM
Subject: Senate soap opera: `Lust for Power'/Peter Wallsten's column



ublished Sunday, December 2, 2001 



Senate soap opera: `Lust for Power' 

The Florida Senate, historically a tight-knit fraternity that rarely airs 
its dirty laundry, is swirling in a soap opera of personal feuds, 
Machiavellian maneuverings and political intrigue.Nobody knows who the next 
Senate president will be, or when exactly the designation will take place. 
But everybody involved realizes that whoever is elected could transform the 
face of Florida government.Traditionally, the new president is designated at 
least a year before legislative elections, and then officially chosen by a 
vote of the 40-member Senate in the days following the statewide 
elections.But now the elections are in 11 months, and no president has been 
designated. Instead, three very different men are locked in a dead heat, 
lining up support based on old friendships, political alliances and 
contrasting ideologies.The showdown, one senator put it last week, is a 
fascinating display of the ``lust for power'' that drives so many 
politicians.What is at stake?The very culture of the Senate as the 
moderating force in the state capital -- especially since conservative 
Republicans took over the House in 1996 and Jeb Bush won the governor's 
mansion in 1998 -- could change forever as term limits and an increasingly 
powerful group of conservative former House members-turned-senators move 
into leadership.The Republicans vying to be Senate president are Daniel 
Webster, a socially conservative former House speaker from Orlando; Jim King 
of Jacksonville, a more moderate but unabashedly pro-business former House 
majority leader; and Tom Lee of Plant City, a moderate maverick who is a 
relative political newcomer.Each represents a different style, and each has 
about a third of the GOP caucus in his camp. So far, the tally is Webster 
nine, Lee eight, King seven.MANY LAYERS There are several complicated levels 
of dynamics making this a difficult task.It is widely believed that Bush 
wants Webster to hold the gavel. The two are ideologically compatible, and 
Webster would likely carry the governor's agenda rather than obstruct it, 
like Presidents Toni Jennings and John McKay have done on issues such as 
campaign finance reform, growth management and taxes.Some say privately they 
have heard from Bush emissaries, gently suggesting that good job 
opportunities await them in Tallahassee or Washington if they help 
Webster.Asked last week if he has a preference in the race, Bush said: ``I 
just want them to pick someone.'' King said recently it would be a ``stupid 
political miscalculation'' for the governor to get involved in the 
race.King, meanwhile, is beloved by the Capitol's lobbyists for his desire 
to please businesses and has the support of a group of senators that 
believes Webster is too conservative.The King-Webster feud dates to the 
mid-1990s when Webster narrowly beat out King to be Republican leader in the 
House.Then there's Lee, who some view as a middle-of-the-road alternative. 
He is supported by a cadre of longtime senators who think Lee, not a former 
House member, can best preserve the traditions of the Senate.Some of Lee's 
supporters, however, face term limits next year. They will be here to vote 
for his designation, but will be replaced by freshmen whose votes, come next 
November, will be up for grabs.That means Lee could be designated, but 
Webster or King could take the presidency.Webster has one more advantage: As 
chairman of the Senate committee redrawing district lines, he will have 
great influence over which new senators get elected. That would likely 
include several former House comrades, who would cast Webster votes.Then 
there are the Democrats, the minority party. While they will not participate 
in the ceremonial designation -- a job only for the GOP caucus -- their 
votes could be used for an unprecedented coalition built to install a 
moderate president.``All of our options are open,'' said the Senate 
Democrats' next leader, Ron Klein. ``Certainly there have been conversations 
in our caucus about that, and some have suggested we approach one of the 
candidates about that.''MCKAY STRONG Perhaps the biggest winner is John 
McKay, the current president.Without an obvious successor, there is nobody 
to start sucking away his power.Typically a Senate president is at his most 
powerful during the year preceding  his term -- as he doles out jobs and 
promises -- and the first year of the term.McKay's grip on power remains 
firm, and he hopes his legacy will be a massive reform of Florida's tax 
system next year. But until a successor can be found, the Senate's future 
remains murky.Peter Wallsten is chief of The Herald Capital Bureau.

From:	Beatrice <beatrice@nivets.com>

----- Original Message ----- 
From: The A.B.L.E. Foundation, Inc. <mailto:webmaster@ablefoundation.org>  
To: Beatrice <mailto:beatrice@nivets.com>  
Sent: Sunday, December 02, 2001 10:07 AM
Subject: Re: Osceola County A.B.L.E. Center!

Good morning Beatrice -
 
I am so excited ready your email!  I can't wait to talk with you more about the A.B.L.E. Center for Osceola County.  As you can imagine, we need to keep this hush-hush for now because it is not fair to other communities.  But, you can definitely start thinking about "your" center!  We would like for you to be one of the leaders of the A.B.L.E. Center in Osceola county.  Your dreams of opening a special center for disabled people will now come true!  We have the system for funding, we have the organization, we have the resources to make the dream a reality.  There is a special group of philapthropists who wish to remain anonymous, who are providing the seed money for the 12 Centers.  This is such an awesome opportunity, Beatrice, and can you just imagine the impact we will have on each community and the lives of children and adults with disabilities and their families!  No longer will they be at the mercy of anyone else to provide for their needs.  No longer will they have to beg for services, programs, and funding for their needs.  
 
What town do you live in?  Our family is in Levy county which is just south west of Ganiesville and west of Ocala - it's about 1 1/2 to 2 hours from Orlando.  Our oldest 2 sons live in Orlando with their families.  We are so blessed to have them close by to visit with them often.  In fact, we just threw a surprise Sweet 16 birthday party for our son, Jonathan's girlfriend, Chantelle.  She was soooo surprised and it was a big success. She is such a sweet girl and her mom is an ESE teacher for the local high school.  
 
Thanks for the survey list.  You do have a lot of contacts and connections.  This is vital to the success of the A.B.L.E. Centers in each community.  The communities will be building the actual center!  Would you like to plan on January 15 for us to make the introduction to the community about the Osceola County A.B.L.E. Center?  We will have to hold the meeting in a place that will be able to accomodate many people as we expect a large turnout.  The meeting will be by invitation only and people MUST R.S.V.P. to receive their entrance ticket.
 
We'll talk more about the January meeting, if that is what you would like to do for that meeting.  Let me know if this is agreeable to you, and possible places to hold the meeting.
 
Warm regards,
Lori
 

----- Original Message ----- 
From: Beatrice <mailto:beatrice@nivets.com>  
To: The A.B.L.E. Foundation, Inc. <mailto:webmaster@ablefoundation.org>  
Sent: Sunday, December 02, 2001 1:40 PM
Subject: Osceola County

Hi Lori,
 
Unfortunately we don't have a newsletter yet, but I know quite a bit of people and agencies that would put the advertisement in their newsletter or spread the word like CARD, FND, FDLRS, Family Care Council (I'll be pretty soon a member of the FCC for District seven). I also advertise in the local newspaper and as a Master Gardener for Osceola County, I can get a lot of help from
my friends and extension Agent Eleanor Foerste who is a wonderful Lady and knows a lot of people from the County.
I also post my flyer at the Library and I distribute 420 flyers through the schools, I had target the profound disables Children because I felt that they are the one with the greatest needs. I know also some people from 4C, since I took a lot
of classes there and recently I got my CDA (Child Development Associate). I have on my list 50 parents who contacted me, so
I could send an invitation to each of them. I know also a few Support Coordinator from DD who can tell the parents about the
A.B.L.E foundation, and I can have flyers posted in a few doctors offices and ask a few parents to post a flyer at grocery stores,
beside that I also know the director of Children First and therapists who can spread the word among their clients.
All I needed now is to compose the flyer for Tuesday January the 15th, do you have a sample that I can use?
My first language is French and you probably notice that I make mistakes in English, but I usually summit my flyer before distribution to the Superintendent of the ESE department for corrections and approval.
As far as work, I couldn't work outside home anymore because of the needs of my Child, beginning of this year Greta became
diabetic. I opened a Family Day Care and I decided to take care only of children with disabilities because like I said earlier,
they are the one who have nothing for them in our County, so far I am taking care of a young lady who is 18 with CP and is in
a motorized chair, I am also a Medwaiver provider, respite and companion and I take care of a 15 years old who in mentally
challenge and his sister 11 who is physically impaired and mentally challenged (there are not on the list that I give you since
their mom didn't do the survey yet). I take care of them during the weekend and I also am a companion for a wonderful 60 years old with CP who enjoy everything and always wants to help. So, I work after school and also on the weekend and that is all for the
moment. It does give me plenty of time to do many things when the children are at school. 
My dreams is to have a Center for the disables because at home there is some limitations, like for example I don't have a wheelchair ramp or an adapted play ground or adapted computer or adapted bathroom. My plan was to open a non-profit organization and open a thrift shop to support the center as well as organizing an annually raffle, and make plants to sale, even grow grapes to make juice and wine. I know there is a lot of possibilities. 
Hope that your questions are answered and I can't wait to hear from you.
 
Beatrice

may therefore be subject to public disclosure.

-----Original Message-----

-----Original Message----- 
From: Valerie Adams [ mailto:valadams@tampabay.rr.com] 
Sent: Tuesday, November 27, 2001 9:34 AM 
To: Martha Pratt; Martha Pratt 
Subject: Editorial: On the backs of the vulnerable. Start Banner 
11/25/01 


Ocala Star Banner 
Our Opinion editorial 11/25/2001 

On the backs 
of the vulnerable 

Gov. Jeb Bush believes he's fixed the state's budgetary woes by 
convincing 
enough Florida House members to postpone a $128 million reduction in the 
state intangibles tax on those who own more than $20,000 worth of stocks 
or 
bonds. 

That's good news, for sure. Divisiveness over the intangibles tax cut, 
especially between House Speaker Tom Feeney and Senate President John 
McKay, 
turned the first special session into a knock-down, drag-out political 
brouhaha, an embarrassment to the concept of public service. More 
important, 
what are we doing giving breaks to rich folks at a time when we must cut 
essential public programs that help poor and neglected children and old 
people, not to mention sick people? 

So while Bush and the Legislature, which convenes for a second special 
session on the budget Tuesday, may have found a balancing act that will 
meet 
constitutional muster by eliminating $1 billion in red ink, they should 
contain any celebratory exuberance. 

The fact is most of the spending cuts proposed will add up to one thing: 
The 
state budget, for the most part, will be balanced on the backs of those 
least able to help themselves - the young, the old, the impoverished. 

While Bush has been busy brokering a deal on the intangibles tax and 
talking 
it up, we have heard nothing about finding a way not to cut $167 million 
from our public classrooms, which already get short-shrift from the 
Legislature. Not a word about how to avoid cutting $66 million from a 
Department of Juvenile Justice that is stretched too thin and dealing 
with 
Florida's fastest-growing criminal segment. What about the $7.5 million 
slashed from the state's $30 million prescription drug program for poor 
elderly residents or the $20 million lost in prescription drug 
assistance 
for the poor? No deal brokered in any of these. 

With Bush up for re-election next year, look for a lovefest in 
Tallahassee 
this week after the Feeney-McKay public-relations debacle the last time 
around. People don't like it when their leaders squabble over how to 
hurt 
them the least. 

What would be refreshing, instead of manufactured pleasantries, would be 
for 
the Legislature to look for some real, people-friendly ways to reduce 
public 
spending over the long haul. 

The state is scheduled to spend $300 billion in the coming year on 
acquisition of sensitive lands. A good cause, but not good enough to 
take 
food, health care or protection away from our youngest and our oldest 
citizens. 

Florida TaxWatch, a respected nonpartisan watchdog group, has a number 
of 
big-ticket budget paring suggestions - 23 pages worth - that warrant 
consideration. 

TaxWatch, for instance, suggests trimming 20 percent of all university 
funding for non-instructional activities. That, it estimates, would save 
$105 million. Tax Watch also suggests assessing bad drivers a special 
license renewal surcharge similar to one in New Jersey. It would rake in 
an 
estimated $100 million a year. 

By going to an automated motor fuel tax reporting system, Tax Watch 
estimates the state would generate some $30 million a year in tax money 
now 
lost to error and evasion. 

Florida allows some of the heaviest trucks in the nation on its roads. 
They 
cause much of the $200 million in highway damage each year. TaxWatch is 
proposing the state increase penalties for overweight trucks (they 
haven't 
been raised in 50 years) and, in turn, raise another $56 million a year 
in 
tax revenues. 

Here's one that caught our eye. While most state employees pay a portion 
of 
their health insurance, legislators and their staffs, senior management 
and 
Select Exempt Service employees, Lottery workers and others - a total of 
35,000 employees - receive free health and life insurance. Free! Making 
these employees pay their fair share would save anywhere between $41 
million 
and $54 million a year. 

This is just a beginning of creative and sensible ways to save state tax 
dollars and balance budgets without hurting those most in need of the 
public's aid. The Legislature should slow down, quit bickering, be 
public 
servants instead of politicians and closely examine all of its spending. 
The 
load's getting too heavy on the kids and the old folks.

-----Original Message-----
From: Mark Hartnett [mailto:mhartnett@pbpost.com]
Sent: Wednesday, November 28, 2001 11:03 AM
To: Jeb Bush; elizabeth.hirst@myflorida.com; katie.baur@myflorida.com
Subject: Palm Beach Post FCAT analysis



Governor Bush: 

    We have undertaken a statistical analysis of the relationship 
between FCAT scores and student economic status at every elementary and 
middle school graded by the state in 2000-01. Our study shows, in 
general, that the poorer elementary and middle schools score lower than 
their wealthier counterparts on the FCAT math and reading tests. We used 
free or reduced price lunch rates as an indicator of schools' economic 
status. 
    We would appreciate your comments. It would best if you could speak 
to us on the phone, but if that is not possible, we've included our 
questions below. We'd also be glad to explain our methodology in greater 
detail to you or an associate. 

A summary of our findings: 
 In the three years since the state implemented its accountability 
plan, the richer half of middle schools have received more than twice as 
much recognition money as the poorer schools  $30.7 million compared to 
$11.9 million. In that same time, the richer half of elementary schools 
have received $77.2 million, while the poorer half have received $40.2 
million. 
(We could not analyze high school data because the DOE does not keep 
free and reduced price lunch statistics at the high school level, where 
free lunch is not a good measure of student wealth.) 

 In 2001, "A" elementary schools had a median of 38 percent of their 
students on free and reduced price lunch, compared to 89 percent at "D" 
elementary schools. The median for all elementary schools statewide is 
58 percent. 

  For every one percent increase in the number of students on free and 
reduced price lunch at Florida middle schools, mean scores on the eighth 
grade reading FCAT drop by nearly a point. 

    Educators we have interviewed agree with you that any accountability 
program must hold every student to the same high standards. But what 
about the teachers? Is it fair to judge a teacher who works with 
disadvantaged kids by the same standards as a teacher who works with 
privileged ones? 

    Some local school officials say that the proposed new grading system 
won't affect the perennial "A" schools, whose teachers don't have to 
bring their more affluent students as far as schools with students at an 
economic and educational disadvantage. Could the accountability program 
encourage teachers to leave low-performing schools, where they must work 
much harder to get the same results from their students? 

    Certainly, all children can learn. But our study shows that many 
students from poor families are not learning at the same rate as their 
wealthier peers. How far do you expect the proposed changes to the 
accountability plan to go toward closing that gap? 

    Would you expect the proposed grading system to eliminate the gaps 
in the distribution of bonus money shown by our study between schools 
with many poor students and those with more affluent students? 

Sincerely, 

Kathleen Chapman 
kathleen_chapman@pbpost.com 
(561) 223-3560 
1-800-932-2489 ext. 3560 

William M. Hartnett 
william_hartnett@pbpost.com 
(561) 223-3564 
1-800-932-2489 ext. 3564 

The Palm Beach Post 
Martin County Bureau 
2101 S. Kanner Highway 
Stuart, Fla. 34994 
Fax: (561) 287-0241 

From:	Jan & Bill Benet <jab@webenet.com>

Subject:	Threat from Below

A grave concern...Please feel free to pass this along. Thanks 

Jan & Bill Benet 

"Researchers calculate that the average age of the water bubbling at Silver 
Springs is about 20 years. That means some of whats coming up represents 
human abuse thats decades old. Nobody is exactly sure where todays nitrate 
comes from, but most suspect runoff from highways, farms, golf courses, 
yards and water retention ponds." 

FLORIDA TREND MAGAZINE 
DECEMBER 2001 ISSUE 
https://www.floridatrend.com/issue/default.asp?a=4485 <https://www.floridatrend.com/issue/default.asp?a=4485&s=2> &s=2 

Threat from Below 
Fertilizer-related nutrients and diminished water flow are threatening 
Floridas once-pristine springs. 
By John M. Dunn 

Few people know Silver Springs like Guy Marwick. After all, he and his 
buddies spearheaded the grass-roots effort to persuade state officials to 
buy 1,200 acres at the headwaters of the springs to protect it from 
development. Ten years ago, he was the prime mover in getting the Silver 
River Museum and Environmental Education Center built  a facility at the 
Silver River State Park near the springs. As the museums director, Marwick 
has guided thousands of school kids on boat trips down the crystalline 
Silver River, which flows from Silver Springs. 

Recently, several local and state lawmakers have also come aboard. What they 
see distresses them. Its hard to look at a beautiful waterway and see 
death coming, says state Rep. Nancy Argenziano of Crystal River. 

Whats tarnishing Silver Springs, Marwick tells his audiences, is an 
insidious threat creeping up from the very aquifer itself. The hazard is an 
ever-growing infusion of nitrate  a major ingredient in fertilizers  that 
keeps percolating into the porous 1,200 square miles of the Silver Springs 
Groundwater Basin. Eventually, the nitrate flushes into subterranean 
recharge waters and emerges dissolved in the mighty gush of Silver Springs  
stimulating the growth of algae and tarnishing water quality. 

A normal amount of nitrate is .02 milligrams per liter of water, explains 
senior state biologist and the states top defender of springs, Jim 
Stevenson. But once you reach 1.0, you experience ecological decline. And 
that, he adds, is the current reading at Silver Springs. The springs now 
pump out up to 820 tons of nitrate every year. 

Silver Springs isnt the only spring with the problem. A recent study 
prepared by a 16-member Florida Springs Task Force for the states 
Department of Environmental Protection reveals that most of Floridas 600 
springs now suffer from a decline in water quality thanks to nutrients 
such as nitrate. In fact, 10 of the states 33 first-magnitude springs  
those with a flow rate of at least 100 cubic feet per second  have nitrate 
levels that rival or surpass those of Silver Springs. Nitrate levels at 
Fanning Springs in nearby Levy County, for example, are over four times 
higher. 

Vulnerable to contamination 
Silver Springs international fame as Floridas oldest and longest-running 
theme park, however, gives it a higher profile. Though passengers on its 
glass-bottom boats still gaze down through what appears to be beautiful, 
clear water, the springs are unquestionably declining. 

Were losing the color of the palette of the springs, says Marwick. Much 
of the beauty of the whiteness of the sandy bottom that once glistened with 
mussel shells is now covered with algae. The eel grass also has a heavy coat 
of algae. Many aquatic plants are missing from the river that were once here 
10 years ago. 

Gone too are the mullet, striped bass, eels, channel catfish and manatees  
though their disappearance may have more to do with the presence of upstream 
Rodman Dam in Putnam County. 

Silver Springs location makes it especially vulnerable to contamination. 
For one, the regions aquifer lies close to the land surface. In addition, 
the area has a lot of sinkholes, caves and other cavities created by 
dissolved limestone that allow polluted water to seep quickly into the 
aquifer. 

Researchers calculate that the average age of the water bubbling at Silver 
Springs is about 20 years. That means some of whats coming up represents 
human abuse thats decades old. Nobody is exactly sure where todays nitrate 
comes from, but most suspect runoff from highways, farms, golf courses, 
yards and water retention ponds. 

If all this isnt bad enough, Silver Springs, like so many other springs, 
has another big problem: Its water flow is also at a 67-year record low, 
says Trudy Phelps, a hydrologist with the U.S. Geological Survey. Its peak 
flow was 1,200 cubic feet per second; the average is 899; but in June, it 
was 350. The ongoing drought and increased water consumption from a growing 
population are to blame. 

More troubles could be on the way. For one thing, bottled water companies 
are increasingly helping themselves to Floridas diminishing spring water. 
They can do this, says Argenziano, because they are exempt from the states 
local source first legislation, which restricts the direct removal of 
water from its source. Its time to close that loophole, she says. 

Meanwhile, many local governments in Floridas big, urban areas keep 
prowling for new water sources. Most recently, Wayne Harris, an appointee of 
Gov. Jeb Bush to the Alafia River Basin Board, stirred things up with his 
proposal to establish a statewide water conservation and distribution plan. 
Part of his plan calls for skimming off water at Silver Springs and 
transporting it through aqueducts along I-75 to storage areas created out of 
old phosphate pits. Though the idea has generated criticism, some state 
legislators are interested. 

In search of a solution 
The Florida Springs Task Force wants to protect and restore Floridas 
springs instead of tapping them. However, the group says without new funding 
to do the necessary research, monitoring, restoration and acquisition of 
water recharge basins, We wont save Floridas springs. To raise the $4.42 
million needed to get the job done, the task force recommends, among other 
things, a 25-cent increase on auto tags, a fertilizer tax and federal help. 

Floridas troubled springs have caught the attention of Bush. Last year, he 
helped push through the Florida Springs Initiative, which provides $2.5 
million meant to aid the states springs. About a third of the $92,000 
earmarked for Silver Springs will help finance an ongoing Geological Survey 
study that seeks to pinpoint the nitrate sources. But with a topography 
like the Silver Springs Groundwater Basin, it could be hard to point 
fingers, says Geological Survey hydrologist Phelps. In one respect, its 
too late to do much about the nitrate already in the aquifer anyhow. 

Even if the study does reveal the origins of nitrate sources, taking 
corrective action could prove tough. Local governments, for instance, can 
curtail the use of fertilizers on public lands, but they may have to rely on 
persuasion to reduce private use. Only one real solution exists, says 
Argenziano, who sits on the House Environmental Protection Committee. At 
some point, well have to mandate that you cant use this kind of 
fertilizer  and thats something hard to do politically. 

As bleak as the situation is, Floridians have no alternative but to try to 
save Floridas springs, says Steve Specht, spokesman for the Silver Springs 
attraction, whose owner, Jacksonville-based SmartParks, leases the site from 
the state. We cant keep going the way weve been going. If we do, well 
all be to blame, and well all pay the consequences.

I need help in getting DOT off my case and figuring out why the memorial cross which I put on the side of the highway at the location of my son's death (to a traffic accident) keeps being removed.  I understand the Party Line. There is a regulation......yadda... yadda... yadda. Yet there are scores of other locations in Central Florida where the roadside memorial are not removed.  I have replaced the little white cross 15 times along with a $30 arrangement of silk flowers and I will continue to replace the memorial and flowers.  I just don't understand why the DOT is being so vigilant in my case and totally ignoring all the others. MOST notably there are two locations where Orange county police officer have been killed. Not only is there a massive collection of flower and crosses at these locations, the Orlando Sentinel even did a story about how those memorials were part of the grief and healing process for the family and friends of the deceased.  
I have to read that, agree with everything they say and then go out in a day or two and spend more time and money trying to keep one step ahead of the DOT highway pickup crew.  It isn't fair. PERIOD.  My 18 year old son dying in a car accident wasn't fair either, but there is no one to talk to about that, it can't be undone. 
It's not like this is an eyesore or a cluttered mess. It is a simple white cross and bouquet of silk flowers.  We long ago removed all the little momento the high school kids put out and we keep it neat, so no one has reason to complain. 
SO, my question.  How do I get DOT to leave this roadside memorial alone.  It isn't hurting anyone. It doesn't look bad. And it is much smaller than most of the other similar roadside memorials in this area (which do not get removed).
 
Please help.
The location is at the intersection of SR 46 at Lake Forrest Blvd. (one mile west of I-4 on Route 46)
Thank you.
Dennis McCool

From: Mathis, Linda [mailto:MathisL@dms.state.fl.us]
Sent: Wednesday, November 28, 2001 8:36 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: STO and Bobby 



Dear Governor Bush: 

Thank you for forwarding my e-mail to the appropriate persons who handle the 
Times Direct system.  I have spoken with Donna Livingston at DMS about the 
issue and hopefully they will test the system with the Bobby program to make 
it more accessible.  It may not cost a lot of money either since many of the 
changes that the Bobby Program includes are simple.  I strongly encouraged 
her to work on this problem since the state does not want to be put in a 
position of looking as though it does not care if it complies with federal 
laws.  The ADA is not a voluntary law.  I don't think the state can argue 
hardship either because it knew before the system was purchased that the 
Bobby program should be included and used to make it accessible. I don't 
know why the STO did not check this before they bought the program.  

I have a friend who works for the Department of Health and she is having the 
same problem with their statewide program used for case management.  The 
department of Health was told before they ever purchased this case 
management program that it was not accessible to the disabled however, they 
purchased it anyway. Since that department receives federal money they are 
in an awkward position because they could be sued under several different 
laws including the OFCCP and probably the DOJ. Ninety per cent of her job is 
computer work and since they have installed this new program she is unable 
to do her job because the entire program is icon based and totally 
inaccessible to blind persons who use speech programs.  It also uses a blue 
screen which makes Braille displays unusable and prevents her from using an 
Optacon which is an old device that people used to use to read displays 
before speech programs were created.  This lady, Ms. Elizabeth Bowden,  has 
worked with the Vocational Rehabilitation program for ten years and now 
because of this badly designed Department of Health Case Management system, 
she will probably have to be moved to another position through no fault of 
her own and will have to move from the job that she does very well.  She is 
a VR Technician and has handled the job well until now. By the way, the 
Comptroller's office program for Employee Earnings Statement review works 
very well and is totally accessible.   

I am letting you know these things, because  the STO is falling down on the 
job in making the state's computer systems more efficient and user friendly. 
Some of the staff  also have the attitude that its just not important and 
we've never had a blind employee before so we just didn't know.   I think it 
is very important especially when the state may be subject to being sued 
when that is not necessary if precautions  are taken. Also,not having had to 
deal with disabled employees before is not an excuse especially when there 
are programs like Bobby available to assist in making programs compliant. 

Sincerely, 

Linda Mathis

-----Original Message-----
From: Jeb Bush [mailto:jeb@jeb.org]
Sent: Tuesday, November 27, 2001 8:28 PM
To: Katie Baur (EOG) (E-mail)
Subject: FW: Editorial: On the backs of the vulnerable. Start Banner
11/25/01


a good one to respond to . 

Jeb Bush 

***********************************************************

Most written communications to or from state officials
regarding state business are public records available to the
public and media upon request.   Your e-mail communications
may therefore be subject to public disclosure. 



-----Original Message-----
From: Martha Pratt [mailto:martha@jeb.org]
Sent: Tuesday, November 27, 2001 9:38 AM
Subject: FW: Editorial: On the backs of the vulnerable. Start Banner
11/25/01




-----Original Message-----
From: Valerie Adams [mailto:valadams@tampabay.rr.com]
Sent: Tuesday, November 27, 2001 9:34 AM
To: Martha Pratt; Martha Pratt
Subject: Editorial: On the backs of the vulnerable. Start Banner
11/25/01


Ocala Star Banner
Our Opinion editorial 11/25/2001

On the backs
of the vulnerable

Gov. Jeb Bush believes he's fixed the state's budgetary woes by
convincing
enough Florida House members to postpone a $128 million reduction in the
state intangibles tax on those who own more than $20,000 worth of stocks
or
bonds.

That's good news, for sure. Divisiveness over the intangibles tax cut,
especially between House Speaker Tom Feeney and Senate President John
McKay,
turned the first special session into a knock-down, drag-out political
brouhaha, an embarrassment to the concept of public service. More
important,
what are we doing giving breaks to rich folks at a time when we must cut
essential public programs that help poor and neglected children and old
people, not to mention sick people?

So while Bush and the Legislature, which convenes for a second special
session on the budget Tuesday, may have found a balancing act that will
meet
constitutional muster by eliminating $1 billion in red ink, they should
contain any celebratory exuberance.

The fact is most of the spending cuts proposed will add up to one thing:
The
state budget, for the most part, will be balanced on the backs of those
least able to help themselves - the young, the old, the impoverished.

While Bush has been busy brokering a deal on the intangibles tax and
talking
it up, we have heard nothing about finding a way not to cut $167 million
from our public classrooms, which already get short-shrift from the
Legislature. Not a word about how to avoid cutting $66 million from a
Department of Juvenile Justice that is stretched too thin and dealing
with
Florida's fastest-growing criminal segment. What about the $7.5 million
slashed from the state's $30 million prescription drug program for poor
elderly residents or the $20 million lost in prescription drug
assistance
for the poor? No deal brokered in any of these.

With Bush up for re-election next year, look for a lovefest in
Tallahassee
this week after the Feeney-McKay public-relations debacle the last time
around. People don't like it when their leaders squabble over how to
hurt
them the least.

What would be refreshing, instead of manufactured pleasantries, would be
for
the Legislature to look for some real, people-friendly ways to reduce
public
spending over the long haul.

The state is scheduled to spend $300 billion in the coming year on
acquisition of sensitive lands. A good cause, but not good enough to
take
food, health care or protection away from our youngest and our oldest
citizens.

Florida TaxWatch, a respected nonpartisan watchdog group, has a number
of
big-ticket budget paring suggestions - 23 pages worth - that warrant
consideration.

TaxWatch, for instance, suggests trimming 20 percent of all university
funding for non-instructional activities. That, it estimates, would save
$105 million. Tax Watch also suggests assessing bad drivers a special
license renewal surcharge similar to one in New Jersey. It would rake in
an
estimated $100 million a year.

By going to an automated motor fuel tax reporting system, Tax Watch
estimates the state would generate some $30 million a year in tax money
now
lost to error and evasion.

Florida allows some of the heaviest trucks in the nation on its roads.
They
cause much of the $200 million in highway damage each year. TaxWatch is
proposing the state increase penalties for overweight trucks (they
haven't
been raised in 50 years) and, in turn, raise another $56 million a year
in
tax revenues.

Here's one that caught our eye. While most state employees pay a portion
of
their health insurance, legislators and their staffs, senior management
and
Select Exempt Service employees, Lottery workers and others - a total of
35,000 employees - receive free health and life insurance. Free! Making
these employees pay their fair share would save anywhere between $41
million
and $54 million a year.

This is just a beginning of creative and sensible ways to save state tax
dollars and balance budgets without hurting those most in need of the
public's aid. The Legislature should slow down, quit bickering, be
public
servants instead of politicians and closely examine all of its spending.
The
load's getting too heavy on the kids and the old folks.
From:	Jeb Bush <jeb@jeb.org>

-----Original Message-----
From: Mark Hartnett [mailto:mhartnett@pbpost.com]
Sent: Wednesday, November 28, 2001 11:03 AM
To: Jeb Bush; elizabeth.hirst@myflorida.com; katie.baur@myflorida.com
Subject: Palm Beach Post FCAT analysis



Governor Bush: 

    We have undertaken a statistical analysis of the relationship 
between FCAT scores and student economic status at every elementary and 
middle school graded by the state in 2000-01. Our study shows, in 
general, that the poorer elementary and middle schools score lower than 
their wealthier counterparts on the FCAT math and reading tests. We used 
free or reduced price lunch rates as an indicator of schools' economic 
status. 
    We would appreciate your comments. It would best if you could speak 
to us on the phone, but if that is not possible, we've included our 
questions below. We'd also be glad to explain our methodology in greater 
detail to you or an associate. 

A summary of our findings: 
 In the three years since the state implemented its accountability 
plan, the richer half of middle schools have received more than twice as 
much recognition money as the poorer schools  $30.7 million compared to 
$11.9 million. In that same time, the richer half of elementary schools 
have received $77.2 million, while the poorer half have received $40.2 
million. 
(We could not analyze high school data because the DOE does not keep 
free and reduced price lunch statistics at the high school level, where 
free lunch is not a good measure of student wealth.) 

 In 2001, "A" elementary schools had a median of 38 percent of their 
students on free and reduced price lunch, compared to 89 percent at "D" 
elementary schools. The median for all elementary schools statewide is 
58 percent. 

  For every one percent increase in the number of students on free and 
reduced price lunch at Florida middle schools, mean scores on the eighth 
grade reading FCAT drop by nearly a point. 

    Educators we have interviewed agree with you that any accountability 
program must hold every student to the same high standards. But what 
about the teachers? Is it fair to judge a teacher who works with 
disadvantaged kids by the same standards as a teacher who works with 
privileged ones? 

    Some local school officials say that the proposed new grading system 
won't affect the perennial "A" schools, whose teachers don't have to 
bring their more affluent students as far as schools with students at an 
economic and educational disadvantage. Could the accountability program 
encourage teachers to leave low-performing schools, where they must work 
much harder to get the same results from their students? 

    Certainly, all children can learn. But our study shows that many 
students from poor families are not learning at the same rate as their 
wealthier peers. How far do you expect the proposed changes to the 
accountability plan to go toward closing that gap? 

    Would you expect the proposed grading system to eliminate the gaps 
in the distribution of bonus money shown by our study between schools 
with many poor students and those with more affluent students? 

Sincerely, 

Kathleen Chapman 
kathleen_chapman@pbpost.com 
(561) 223-3560 
1-800-932-2489 ext. 3560 

William M. Hartnett 
william_hartnett@pbpost.com 
(561) 223-3564 
1-800-932-2489 ext. 3564 

The Palm Beach Post 
Martin County Bureau 
2101 S. Kanner Highway 
Stuart, Fla. 34994 
Fax: (561) 287-0241

From: Barbara Lumpkin [mailto:blumpkin@floridanurse.org]
Sent: Sunday, December 02, 2001 10:23 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: RE: 


Dear Governor,
 
My biggest concern was that I had misrepresented your position. As mentioned I would understand a change because the battle being waged against us is very intense and many legislators seem to find it intimidating. Representative Carole Green called me on Friday and said, "this really is a David and Goliath fight we are in". I was so humbled and honored when Arlene called Friday to offer me the opportunity to greet the President this next Tuesday in Orlando and at the same time was so disappointed that I must be in Tallahassee for the House Committee hearing on our bill that my emotions just unloaded on her. I really appreciated the call Friday evening and your response here. My thoughts and prayers are with you during these very demanding and challenging times and your support is very appreciated. I will not let words confuse or discourage me again. I don't shy always from good, honest debate and I know that maybe not this year but in the near future with sponsors like Representative Green we will prevail. Again I am so honored that you would have given me the opportunity to greet the President and I thank you very very much.
 
Sincerely,
 
Barbara Lumpkin

-----Original Message-----
From: Wm. D. Walker [mailto:redhawk103@home.com]
Sent: Saturday, December 01, 2001 11:48 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Cc: Steven Houghland
Subject: Closing of the Pilot Projects 6 months early


Dear Governor, I'm sure with all the budget cuts you don't want to hear one more complaint.  I have just heard from my Vice-President off the Family Care Council who just attended the State Wide Family Care Council Chair meeting in my place in Orlando today.  She said that Carl Littlefield made the announcement there that as of January 2002 all the Pilot Projects would cease and those clients would be returned to the Home and Community Based Waiver program in their Districts.  Sir we were promised by the State of Florida that these pilot projects would continue through June 2002 , and that at that time the state would transition us into the new and improved system that will reflect the results of the pilot projects.
My major concern is that those people who will not be eligible to return to the Med-waiver program will be left high and dry with no support services at all and even those that are eligible will loose a lot of the services they currently have.
I also heard that the 6,000 that were suppose to come off the waiting list for services from Developmental Disabilities in March of 2002 was not going to happen.  Sir I thought that decision was mandated by a court order.  How can the Legislature just ignore that and do they not realize how many hundreds and thousands of people this will be placing at risk and how many will end up in institutions because of this.  Why then is all the millions of dollars being funneled into Del Marva and Maximus
when it could be put to better use helping those that need the help.  I really hate to see how many more class action law suits this is going to generate against you and the State of Florida and how much money is going to be wasted in the court battle resulting from this.   Your Friend Darrell Walker
                                                         Chairman
                                                         Family Care Council
                                                         District 1
