From: unclestv@htn.net [mailto:unclestv@htn.net]
Sent: Sunday, December 02, 2001 1:13 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Short note for hellp if you can.


Governor.
The Wauchula brunch headed by Joe "The Democrat" Davis got the SFCC board to agree to buy his property in a residential area of Wauchula.  To me this is ridiculous.  It will throttle expansion and cause residences to complain about the number of cars and kids going and coming. They did not survey the county as to where the college should be located. 
There is another gift of property on US 17 but there seems to be some dead line on some matching funds that have caused some on the board to hurry and select site.  Why cannot the matching funds be held in abeyance for some additional time?  That would not cause them to hurry in making the site selection and maybe they would go back and rescind the vote to take Davis's site..
I have talked to William "Bill" Ammons in your office and am impressed with his concern and willingness to talk to the two members of the board that voted against the Davis site.  They are Chairman Gary Delatora, Hardee member and Joan Hartt, Highlands member.
Bill Ammons can give you a more detailed report, he talked to Gary and Joan.
 
 
Steve Roberts Jr.
" I am always pleased by the very best"
 
PS.Since the State will become owner of the buildings and the site, it would seem the state would want to have room to expand, not congest a residential area and have access to the property from the main road arteries.

From: Jack Eichert [mailto:jack@intersyte.com]

Subject: RE: Bridging the Digital Divide


Governor Bush,
 
I am sorry that we were not able to conclude a successful meeting with Ms. McDougal. Much has transpired since our first exchange of emails. While we were in Tallahassee quite a few times, things just never materialized and schedules seemed to flee our control.
 
I am fully prepared to show you and Mr. Horne, as well as the entire education system throughout Florida, a viable way to bridge the "Digital Divide" with Wireless Internet Access, a central LMS (Learning Management System) and LCMS (Learning Content Management System) and a central communication service second to none.
 
I really believe InterSyte's UniverCT solution will provide a core foundation to build a "Revenue Stream" for the State, somewhat like the Lottery system, and fulfill the objective of One Technology for Florida's Department of Education.
 
As our favorite former speaker Newt said in a conference Wednesday at the Broward Convention Center, "... education should be available to everyone, twenty four / seven. We have the technology." 
 
I would like to propose a solution that requires very little costs up front to initialize. Then, once the program has been formalized at the executive level, the solution would be self supporting from a financial aspect early on. Translation: A solution that generates revenues, reduces existing costs, and provides for the prime objective of "quality education for all".
 
I am frustrated with the results of our approach, but my spirits and insights are higher now than ever.
 
I'm looking to you for input on how to proceed. I believe time is of the essence for all involved and will follow your advise to the best of my and InterSyte's ability.
 
Thank you for your invaluable time reading this email. My hope is to solve some of the more pressing and wide spread issues you and your colleagues have regarding these matters. We realize, it's not about promises. It's about "deliveries".
 
Sincerely
 
Jack Eichert
The Internet Promises. *InterSyte Delivers.



727-421-8436

jack@InterSyte.com
http://www.InterSyte.com

*InterSyte, Inc has received Dunn & Bradstreet's highest marks in the evaluation areas of "Problem Responsiveness, Attitude, Delivery Quantities, and Total Costs". See D&B's Past Performance Evaluation as included in our responses to R.F.P.'s and R.F.I.'s.

Dear Governor,
 
I'd like to discuss with you how we can leverage STATUS to further your pursuit in conquering the Digital Divide. InterSyte is one of only thirty-one contractors authorized by the U.S.-D.O.T.'s TASC, to offer eLearning and eLearning Management Systems.
 
With little to no capital outlays, we can deliver solid distance learning solutions and, in a separate program, wireless Internet connectivity. InterSyte would like to propose a solution to create revenue streams in every school building within every school district throughout the State of Florida.
 
InterSyte has solid concepts to address the following issues:
 1. Broad-based K-12 Learning Systems via distance learning technology
 2. Wireless Internet connectivity for every child, teacher and administrator in every school building.
 
Please advise on your availability to discuss via phone or in person. The CEO of InterSyte and myself will contact you at your convenience.

Dear Governor, I'm sure with all the budget cuts you don't want to hear one more complaint. Sir we were promised by the State of Florida that these pilot projects would continue through June 2002 , and that at that time the state would transition us into the new and improved system that will reflect the results of the pilot projects.
My major concern is that those people who will not be eligible to return to the Med-waiver program will be left high and dry with no support services at all and even those that are eligible will loose a lot of the services they currently have.
I also heard that the 6,000 that were suppose to come off the waiting list for services from Developmental Disabilities in March of 2002 was not going to happen.  Sir I thought that decision was mandated by a court order.  How can the Legislature just ignore that and do they not realize how many hundreds and thousands of people this will be placing at risk and how many will end up in institutions because of this.  Why then is all the millions of dollars being funneled into Del Marva and Maximus
when it could be put to better use helping those that need the help.  I really hate to see how many more class action law suits this is going to generate against you and the State of Florida and how much money is going to be wasted in the court battle resulting from this.   Your Friend Darrell Walker

                                                         District 1

-----Original Message----- 
From: Steve Mayberry [ mailto:SMayberry@floridabusiness.com] 
Sent: Friday, November 30, 2001 9:28 AM 
To: Pam Dana (E-mail) 
Subject: Enron ... from Business Week 


ENRON: RUNNING ON EMPTY 
As the collapsed energy giant seems headed for liquidation, many losers 
count their losses 
By Peter Coy and Emily Thornton in New York and Stephanie Anderson 
Forest in Dallas, with Christopher Palmeri in Los Angeles, and bureau 
reports 

The fall of Enron-to 61 a share on Nov. 28-has already wiped out more 
than 99% of its stock-market value. Some $3.5 billion of its bonds are 
trading at just a quarter of their face value. Banks that lent billions 
to Enron will have to fight for a share in bankruptcy court. Enron's 
biggest lenders are J.P. Morgan Chase & Co. and Citigroup, which 
together have an estimated $1.6 billion in exposure. Of that, $900 
million is unsecured, according to sources. Other losers: Enron's 
customers, who traded everything from electricity, gas, and metals to 
telecom bandwidth, credit insurance, and weather derivatives.  In 
addition to clamoring creditors, Enron faces class actions by 
shareholders and employees, whose pensions were heavily invested in 
Enron stock. That raises questions about how much value is left in the 
company, which will probably be dismembered and sold off in parts. The 
end came quickly because Enron had overextended itself-and because 
investors and customers lost faith  in its secretive and complex 
financial maneuvers. With legions of traders working out of a Houston 
skyscraper, the company put together trades so exotic that they 
mystified many Wall Street veterans. 

Plus: SKILLING: THE MAN WHO KNEW...HOW MUCH? 
By Wendy Zellner in Dallas 

After stunning investors and employees with his abrupt resignation as 
CEO on Aug. 14, Jeffrey K. Skilling flatly denied that the announcement 
would damage the nation's largest energy trader. So much for Skilling's 
reputation as a visionary.  As bankers, investors, employees, and 
trading partners scramble to salvage what they can, it's increasingly 
hard to believe that Skilling, 48, didn't have an inkling of the 
disaster that lay ahead for the powerhouse he helped create. He 
continues to insist that he left for personal reasons: "Absolutely. 
That's the truth," he told BusinessWeek in a brief interview. And he 
won't talk about Enron's spectacular meltdown. Enron's collapse will 
only add to the pressure for Skilling to tell what he knew and when he 
knew it. There's no denying that he holds some responsibility for the 
mess. As a member of Enron's board, he supported the creation of at 
least some of the off-balance-sheet partnerships that apparently hid 
Enron's debt and allowed it to overstate profits by more than $600 
million over four years. And he, along with Chairman Kenneth L. Lay, 
approved then-CFO Andrew S. Fastow's management of some of those 
partnerships, even when other executives warned of a conflict of 
interest. 


Steve Mayberry 
Senior Vice President 
ENTERPRISE 
FLORIDA, Inc. 
The Atrium Building, Suite 201 
325 John Knox Road 
Tallahassee, Florida 32303 
850.488.6300 FAX 850.922.9595 



From:	Zan100@aol.com
Sent:	Saturday, December 1, 2001 9:37 PM
To:	RobinsJ@mail.doe.state.fl.us
Cc:	ccristjr@tampabay.rr.com; Jim.Horne@flboe.org; Carol.Jinks@flboe.org; Jeb Bush
Subject:	DOE General Counsel 

Mr. Robinson: 

    You and your staff are  public servants.  As  public servants responsible 
for prosecuting disciplinary actions involving wrongdoing by educators, you 
and your staff act on behalf of and for the protection of children who attend 
public schools.  My family is included among those who should be the 
beneficiary of the work that you and every other lawyer and staff member in 
your office have been hired to perform.  I would expect that you and your 
office staff would understand your relationship to the citizens of this 
state.  

    Obviously your staff does not understand that relationship.  As evidence 
I draw your attention to the unacceptable behavior exhibited by your staff 
during a telephone call with me this past week.  During that conversation 
your secretary, Paula, told me that she was going to put me on hold for a 
moment.  Then I heard her say "Sorry, there is a pain in the  ass woman on 
the other line." When I informed her that the "pain in the ass woman" she was 
speaking of was still on the line, she backtracked and said she had been 
talking about another woman who had made a public records request pertaining 
to FCAT.  Perhaps she was.  It really does not matter.  I am sure the "other 
woman" is also a citizen of this state who deserves the same respect and 
service as any other person seeking information from their government.  But 
that respect is apparently lacking within your department. 

    Another example of your department's disrespect for citizens expressing 
interest in your department's performance was the unacceptable language used 
by Mr. Stowers, who I understand is a lawyer in your office,  to sum up his 
opinion about my perseverance in the case involving my daughter's former 
teacher.   He stated that my perseverance in following up on that teacher's 
case has cost your department thousands of dollars and that the progress of 
the case  is "none of your damn business".  Mr. Stowers followed up on that 
comment by threatening to swear out a "harassment" complaint because of 
telephone calls that I have made in an effort to make sure that your 
department follows through on what he characterized as "just a piddly  little 
DUI case".  For the record, Mr. Stowers felt it necessary to yell during the 
majority of the conversation despite my requests that he stop yelling.  I am 
unsure if you informed Mr. Stowers of your letter to me, copied to Robin 
Safley and David Ashburn, requesting all my inquiries regarding this matter 
only go through you.  For the record, I was doing that.  Your secretary, 
Paula, asked me the day before to call back in an hour or so to find out what 
the status of the settlement agreement was.  The next day your secretary, 
Paula, directed my return call to Mr. Stowers.  I was informed by Mr. Stowers 
of the state's threat to swear out a complaint.  

    Those types of  comments are completely outrageous, unacceptable and an 
affront to me and every other citizen in this state.  I would suggest that 
you have a heart to heart talk with your staff and then issue an immediate 
apology.  You, as department head, set the tone for what you will tolerate 
with respect to staff behavior.  At this time I find your staff's behavior to 
be completely unacceptable. 

    Please govern yourself accordingly. 
    
                        Sincerely, 

                        Shannon Knox    

P.S.  If the case involving my daughter's former teacher's is, in fact, "just 
a piddly little DUI", why will it have taken over a year to reach the 
settlement?

Subject: A Florida Keys Opportunity; Florida Tourism Commission



Realizing you must be inundated with e-mail, I wanted to make sure you 
received the following, since I had not heard back from you... 


Gov. Bush: 

I wanted to make you aware of an opportunity as well as followup on a brief 
discussion we had back in late September, prior to the Florida Tourism 
Commission meeting at Amelia Island. 

First the opportunity. 

More than 500 volunteers, in the Florida Keys, recently completed the bulk of 
construction on a new two-acre playground in Marathon. Most of the park and 
its play accessories were concepted by elementary school kids, with final 
design and engineering plans completed and supervised by a professional 
playground design firm. The new facility is to be dedicated before Christmas 
and given the nature of this project, I thought you might wish to preside 
over the ceremony. The date is somewhat flexible, so perhaps it can be 
considered by you and your schedulers. The park's location is quite close to 
Florida Keys Marathon Airport, making transportation  simple. Perhaps you or 
a staff member might let me know if this can be considered. 

Next, the followup. 

Prior to the Florida Tourism Commission meeting, we chatted about the need 
for a Florida Keys tourism representative to serve on the Florida Tourism 
Commission. The Keys has no representation on the board and given the role 
that Monroe County plays in Florida tourism, I am asking for your assistance 
to help make this happen. Ideally we feel that Harold Wheeler, director of 
the Monroe County Tourist Development Council would make an ideal candidate. 

With regards,

From:	MRSHORN@aol.com
Sent:	Saturday, December 1, 2001 8:35 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	LTGOVFTB@aol.com
Subject:	Professional Practices Services & a Brevard case


  Dear Jeb and Frank, 

      I know you fellows are busy tending to many issues and it has been a tough haul having to initiate special sessions over the state budget shortfall. You have my sympathy, considering this all this hullabaloo is taking place just before the 2002 election. Ugh. 
       Anyway, I just have to address a situation taking place with the PPS which involves an investigation of a Brevard teacher, Sharon Busshaus. My daughters attend the school where this teacher is employed. I have to tell you guys, this teacher's reputation for drinking on the job is well known in the community. 
       I spoke to Jim Horne at the ELC conference for several minutes about this case, and he appeared to be aware and concerned about the investigation. I shared that I had been told that Mr. Robinson, General Counsel for PPS had actually referenced an email I'd sent to Charlie Crist some weeks ago where I stated that this "case" should NOT be considered a parent's "personal vendetta" against a teacher. However, in a response to Mrs. Knox, he used the term "personal vendetta", mentioned MY email, which I believe was absolutely unnecessary. Mrs. Knox has  taken it upon herself to bring a BAD situation to the forefront so it could be addressed. There are several parents concerned about the unprofessional conduct of this teacher over the years. This is much MORE than a DUI situation. Let me explain. 
      This past Thursday I picked up my daughter Arielle and on the way to her piano lesson she asked to stop at Kentucky Fried Chicken for something to eat. While there, a very "chatty" teenager was sweeping the floor and asked Arielle if she liked the popcorn chicken. She replied "yes", but that it was spicey. I asked the girl if she attended Satellite High School, the high school which my daughter's middle school "feeds". She said yes, that she was in 10th grade. She then asked my daughter if she attends DeLaura Middle School. My daughter said "yes." She asked who some of her teachers were. Arielle named a few. The girl said "Do you have Busshaus?" Arielle said know. Not wanting to act as though I was familiar with this teacher, I asked her why she asked. The girls replied, and I quote "Well, she's a drunk...we used to talk about the "clear coffee" she used to drink." She then told me how the teacher would stumble around the room, had fallen down a couple of times and also that Ms. Busshaus would doze off during class. 
      I realize that since this student, the KFC employee, Margaret, is in 10th grade, that this had to have taken place 3 years ago. But it distresses me knowing that this teacher has a file that is considerably thick, with letters from parents...yet the administration chooses to give the teacher good evaluations, year after year. It does seem to amount to dishonesty on their part. It bothers me that students, for several years have had to observe the alcoholic behavior of this teacher. 
      Let me go back a little further. 
      A former band parent president from Satellite HS, Pat Connelly, who is a friend of mine....when I called her earlier this school year to see if any of her three children had been taught by Ms. Busshaus, she said yes, that her son (now at FSU) had her. When I asked what he/she thought of this teacher her words were, "she's a drunk." Now I have to ask, why has this sorry situation not been addressed by the district the last several years?  Are the school administrators afraid to contend with the teacher's union who continually protect teachers who fail to educate children? 
       Please know that I am sympathetic to alcoholics being familiar with the disease. My mother was afflicted and my own childhood was impaired. Yet I also have great compassion for hundreds of kids who have had to observe this teacher's hangovers, her emotional outbursts (I am told that she cries in class) and loss of instruction over the years. 
       I am deeply concerned about the way Mrs. Knox is being treated by the staff and counsel at PPS. There really is no excuse to treat a concerned parent with hostility and ridicule using legalese. Mrs. Knox is married to an attorney and neither of them are impressed with the manner in which their inquiries are being handled. 
       As President of IVBE, whose membership continues to grow, I have great interest in how parents are being served statewide. I have to say that I am disappointed in PPS right now, because I have always believed that the State of Florida employees have better manners than local personnel at our school districts. 
       Should I go out personally into the community of Satellite Beach and round up a few former students of Ms. Busshaus to provide some personal, real-life statements regarding their experiences in this teacher's classroom? I say this because this investigation has overlooked the very individuals who are have been impacted- the students who were assigned to her classes. 
       When I spoke to Jim Horne in Atlanta, he seemed concerend about Mr. Robinson's demeanor over this case, and I assumed he'd be addressing the situation when he returned. I wish someone would look into this matter because several employees, including a Mr. Stowers, are doing a very POOR job of representing the PPS for the Florida Dept of Education. When a state employee threatens a parent with a harassment complaint, I'd say that something is very out of whack, wouldn't you? 
        Is this how the "state" deals with parents they find to be a nuisance? Or is this how a few unprofessional employees decide to "personalize" a situation because they have not been trained well enough in dealing with a public that has been asked to require "accountability" from the education system? 
        Anyway, please look into this situation if you would, okay? We will need every vote we can get for the Bush/Brogan team and situations like this make our Republican administration appear as hostile to the public it serves. 
        Thanks fellows. 
         Your friend, 
                Shelley

-----Original Message-----
From: wayne calabrese [mailto:whcanetoad@yahoo.com]
Sent: Saturday, December 01, 2001 9:13 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Wackenhut award of SVP project (George Zoley)



Dear Governor Bush:

I regret to inform you of my extreme frustration and need of your help regarding the Sexually Violent Predator (SVP) program for Florida.

Wackenhut subsidiary Atlantic Shores Healthcare (ASH) has been for some time trying to accomplish two objectives:

1.  Persuade DCF to confirm our selection by the Correctional Privatization Commission (CPC)as the winner of the SVP procurement (due to having received the highest number of points) and begin the negotiations allowing us the opportunity to propose a new permanent SVP facility that is cost-effective for the state of Florida.

*	DCF staff argue that because you previously vetoed $10,000 in SVP funds for CPC, you effectively removed any legal authority for continuing the SVP RFP process; 

*	Further, DCF staff assert that you are now opposed to a new facility because of cost issues - before allowing us an opportunity to negotiate a cost-effective solution that would fulfill an important need, create hundreds of construction jobs, and be funded through bond financing. 

*	We have spent one year competing on the SVP RFP (still authorized pursuant to last year's legislation), incurred over $500,000 in expenses in-house and with builders/architects, received the highest number of points among all competitors, and were selected by the CPC for contract award; 

*	We need your help, and/or the legislature, to direct DCF to begin the negotiation process subject to achieving a cost-effective solution for the state.

2.  Persuade DCF to allow us to take over the emergency SVP contract/program in Desoto County, given that we have won the competition for the development and operation of the permanent SVP contract/program.

*	The existing emergency SVP contract/program in Desoto County is operated by an out-of-state company who received the contract without competition under a 30-day cancellation provision; 

*	DCF staff assert that they would like to re-bid the existing emergency SVP operations-only contract; 

*	We hope that you can persuade DCF to allow our Florida company, who won the competition for the permanent SVP contract/program in Desoto County involving the same sexual offenders (including facility operations and development) to assume the emergency contract over a 60 to 90 day period with a cost reduction to the state; 

*	We are deeply disturbed over so much preference being given to an out-of-state company when our Florida company won the competitive bid and is fully capable of delivering professional services with a cost savings to the state.

I would appreciate a meeting with you on this subject, or you can reach me on my cell phone number (954) 253 7634.

Sincerely,

George C Zoley, Chairman - Atlantic Shores Healthcare (a Wackenhut subsidiary)

Thank you and enjoy the weekend.
 
Laurel A. Kruse, MD
Pediatrician and parent of two children with disabilities

Following is a letter our condo associations sent to get help requarding our dangerous beach erosion.  We need your assistance in helping us get emergency permits to save our 13 story building from falling into the ocean.  We can not wait for another storm.  It would not be wise or responsible to act carelessly by putting this off as we have more residents and lives that will be effected by this.  Why are they treating us in such an irresponsible way. -----Original Message-----
From: Cheryl Gerstner [mailto:cigerstner@yahoo.com]
Sent: Saturday, December 01, 2001 2:32 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Gertner Seawall



Dear Sir:  Received a bid of $180,000.00 to complete our seawall.  One-half of that cost is to move the 92 feet currently installed approximately 10 feet closer to my house.  The price has tripled in the 5 years I have been embroiled in this debate, and the condition of the beach continues to deteriorate.  The stand of those opposed to letting me finish my wall in its as-built location is that they will gain habitat if I am forced to move the wall.  This is not true, the erosion is too aggressive.  In 1996 the coastal engineer for Indian River County, made an official statement that beaches in Sector 7 will lose 6 to 8 feet per year, NO STORM EVENTS!  Someone needs to look at all the science & information as a whole and not select only the information that serves their purpose.  It isn't fair to you, or to those effected by the resulting decisions.  I am asking again for your assistance.  Look forward to seeing you at the Beckers, December 14th.  Cheryl Gerstner

From:	LizaTally@aol.com
Sent:	Saturday, December 1, 2001 3:05 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	liza.mcfadden@myflorida.com
Subject:	mentoring - time sensative - Legislative request

Governor - 

Spent much of this morning trying to rescue mentoring funds in the 
legislature.  A quick recap: 

First Special Session:  Our biggest hold out has been Rep. Lynn - despite the 
stalwart and vocal support of her committee members.  We then were prepared 
to run an amendment on the floor - and had LaCasa's assistance - to limit the 
mentoring cuts to 20%.  This would have been amendment #4 prior to the House 
ending the Special Session early. 

Second Special Session:  Thursday the House passed a floor amendment which 
brought the mentoring programs up to 100%!  Our mentoring group includes: 
Gov's Mentoring Initiative, Take Stock, Big Brothers and Boys and Girls Clubs 
- for the most part these are run together in one package.  

Yesterday, the House sent this to the Senate which came back with an offer to 
allow the mentoring groups to keep 95% of last year's base but cut all new 
funding.  This morning I talked with Cheryl of Feeney's staff (Feeney was in 
the air on way to Tallahassee) and she went down to talk with Rep. Lynn for 
me.  Apparently, and I did not know this, Fasano had just been in and asked 
Lynn the same thing.  Cheryl said Lynn was a bit put out (feeling not in 
charge, I believe) but asked her to bump it up to Feeney.  Cheryl said a call 
from the Lt. Gov to Feeney should solidify it, but I talked with Hayden who 
told me the LG might not be seeing Feeney before 12:00 tomorrow, but that you 
were playing golf with him and might discuss it. 

Cheryl also talked with LaCasa who is supportive - had the eternal question 
of where the money would come from - but is (and has been) willing to 
support. 

Although you and I talked about a 5% cut to mentoring, I know our group is 
willing to take up to a 20% off the total for each program.  I talked with 
Kim McDougall and she suggested perhaps we ask Feeney for 10%.  The critical 
thing is that the legislature expanded these programs to go to more areas 
(Big Brothers) or statewide (Take Stock) with the last legislative session so 
we would not only have to fire all the new hires, but cut into the base to 
make up the difference for what was spent the first half of the year. 

I cannot seem to access my work email from home today, so if you would 
respond to this personal account, I would appreciate it.  Because of the time 
sensitivity, if I do not hear back from you by 5:00, I will call to ensure 
you have this information. 

Thank you!  Liza  



(Governor Mentoring Initiative funds  we use to incentivize League of Cities, 
military, provide training for the school districts, provide coordinators in 
rurual areas of the state and more.)

>*** DECEMBER 4th TO BE "NATIONAL DAY OF RECONCILIATION" *** 
> 
>On November 14, the House of Representatives and the United States Senate 
>passed an unprecedented concurrent resolution establishing a "National Day 
>of Reconciliation," to take place Tuesday, December 4, 2001.  On that day, 
>our nation and elected representatives will pause to seek God's blessings 
>in prayers for unity, forgiveness, reconciliation and charity. 
> 
>We urge Presidential Prayer Team members to tell their friends and 
>colleagues, so that all of America will rightly honor this important event 
>in the history of our nation, along with both houses of Congress. 
>> 
>--The Presidential Prayer Team www.presidentialprayerteam.org 
> 
> 
>READ THE NATIONAL DAY OF RECONCILIATION RESOLUTION: 
> 
>"CONCURRENT RESOLUTION Resolved by the House of Representatives (the 
>Senate concurring), that on a day of reconciliation selected jointly by 
>the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President pro tempore 
>of the Senate, and with the Chaplain of the House of Representatives and 
>the Chaplain of the Senate in attendance--(1) two Houses of the Congress 
>shall assemble in the Hall of the House of Representatives; and (2) during 
>this assembly, the Members of the two Houses may gather to humbly seek the 
>blessings of Providence for forgiveness, reconciliation, unity, and 
>charity for all people of the United States, thereby assisting the Nation 
>to realize its potential as the champion of hope, the vindicator of the 
>defenseless, and the guardian of freedom. 
> 
>     Concurrent Resolution - Providing for a National Day of 
>Reconciliation. Resolved by the Senate (the House of Representatives 
>concurring), 
> 
>       SECTION 1. USE OF ROTUNDA OF THE CAPITOL. 
>The rotunda of the Capitol is authorized to be used at any time on 
>November 27, 2001, or December 4,2001, for a National Day of 
>Reconciliation where-- (1) The 2 Houses of Congress shall assemble in the 
>rotunda with the Chaplain of the House of Representatives and the Chaplain 
>of the Senate in attendance; and (2) During this assembly, the Members of 
>the 2 Houses may gather to humbly seek the blessings of Providence for 
>forgiveness, reconciliation, unity, and charity for all people of the 
>United States, thereby assisting the Nation to realize its potential as-- 
>(A) the champion of hope; (B) the vindicator of the defenseless; and (C) 
>the guardian of freedom. 
> 
>       SECTION 2. PHYSICAL PREPARATIONS FOR THE ASSEMBLY. 
>Physical preparations for the assembly shall be carried out in accordance 
>with such conditions as the Architect of the Capitol may prescribe." 
> 
>(SENATE CONCURRENT RESOLUTION NUMBER 83) 
> 
>------------------------------------------------ 
> 
>VISIT THE PRESIDENTIAL PRAYER TEAM WEBSITE:  See our website at 
> http://www.presidentialprayerteam.org with prayer updates and more 
>information about the President, all focused on prayer and our nation's 
>heritage of faith. 
> 
>------------------------------------------------ 
> 
>TO JOIN THE PRAYER TEAM:  To join (there is no charge or obligation) and 
>receive a free members-only window decal and prayer updates, go to 
> http://www.presidentialprayerteam.org/register.asp 
>

-----Original Message-----
From: Mallot, Jerry [mailto:JMallot@jacksonvillechamber.org]
Sent: Friday, November 30, 2001 5:36 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: 



Governor, I and others in the Economic Development process, are very 
concerned about a proposal  by the Legislative Budget Commission General 
Government Subcommittee to eliminate the transfer of funds to OTTED for the 
Road Fund. The speed, flexibility and focus on job creation (not just 
building roads) would likely be compromised if it were combined with another 
program there. We hope you will oppose this proposal and help keep one of 
the most important, proven incentives operation under your office.

Dear Mr. Bush, 
Thank you for your response to my email but the concern we have is that with 
29 feet between our building and the cliff edge we well not be able to 
withstand two more seasons of Northeasterly storms and God forbid we have to 
endure a hurricane.  
Also help me understand why it is, that it is so difficult to obtain permits 
for preventive measures rather than waiting for emergency conditions.  Our 
building is 13 stories and for us to wait until the cliff edge is 10 to 15 
ft. from the building before  armoring structures are considered, seems to be 
very foolish.   Everywhere I turn I am told no armoring structures, then I go 
down to Melbourne Beach and they received a permit from the DEP for an 
armoring structure.  But, this permit was not obtained until he was in an 
emergency condition.  Please, any help you can direct me to would be much 
appreciated.  We believe NOW is the time to act.

From:	Stutler, Denver <Denver.Stutler@dep.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Saturday, December 1, 2001 2:12 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: Gerstner Seawall: Indian River County

Governor:
 
Our position has been that they can have the wall as long as state and federal fish and wildlife agencies say it is ok.  They are the agencies that have objected to the seawall location.  It is my understanding that the County included this in a county-wide plan that has been approved by the appropriate agencies (we are not one).  I thought that was concluded in the last 90 days. I have already requested an update and will communicate that to you and Mrs.. Gerstner.  Let me know if you would like to discuss further.
 
Denver

-----Original Message-----
From: Cheryl Gerstner [mailto:cigerstner@yahoo.com]
Sent: Friday, November 30, 2001 5:50 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Gerstner Seawall: Indian River County


Dear Gov. Bush:  Since January of 1997, I have been trying to complete my seawall needed to protect what is left of my oceanfront property & my home in Indian River Bounty.  I have been in communication with you on this matter since February 2000.  As you may recall, this 5 year controversy is over the position of the DEP that the wall is 15 feet too far seaward, and therfore represents a "take" of turtle habitat.  We have through your efforts, those of local officials, and our own been given a permit to move the wall as few as 8 feet.  We continue to request that we be allowed to complete the wall in its as-built location for several reasons.  The primary reason is the expense.  At $850 a foot, it would cost $78,200 to move this wall even 1 foot.  Some quotes are as high as $1000.00 a foot.  We have also resisted moving the wall for reasons of value to our primary asset, because we have documented the inconsistencies regarding the placement of permitted wals elsewhere, and because we know that moving our wall is not going to make a significant difference.  The scuttlebut is that the unwillingness of the decision makers to reach the obvious conclusion regarding the "Gerstner Wall" is their fear of setting a precendent.  It is not this decision that willset a precendent; the inconsistent application of the rules and regs has already established that "opening".  What hasn't yet happened is a court case to expose those Inconsistencies.  Noone wants to be the one to take on that task, and is it really necessary?  Chairwoman Ginn if in Tallahassee today and may contact you to make this same appeal.  I know there are agencies that could not tolerate a $100,000 budget cut.  Please consider what it represents to me and my family and weigh that cost against the gain.  You are acutely aware of the critical condition of our beaches.  Seawalls are only temporary structures that buy time until the conditions dictating their need can be cured.  We need sand by-pass srojects at inlets & nourishing programs.  I would not contact you again if I did not think it was going to take your influence to get this done.  Thank you, Cheryl Gerstner 




  _____

From:	Lynette Brown <lbb3516@garnet.acns.fsu.edu>
Sent:	Saturday, December 1, 2001 1:06 PM
To:	laura.branker@myflorida.com; frank.jimenez@myflorida.com
Subject:	Elder Affairs

Hello Laura & Frank:  

        I know that you guys have a lot to deal with right now, however, it is 
because of the impact the legislative process will have on all agencies, 
that I felt it is important that I communicate with you that I am indeed 
ready to be a part of the leadership team addressing the issues that will 
affect our State as a whole, and particularly the Department of Elder Affairs. 
  
         My peripheral view of the legislative process propels me to want to 
further communicate our need for a "qualified" individual, who shares and 
supports the Governor's vision to serve as Secretary of Elder Affairs.  In 
light of the economic challenges facing our State and the budget the 
governor and legislature is crafting to accommodate the shortfall, it is 
critical to have a team that will work cohesively to carry forth the 
Governor's priorities.  I am committed to doing that. There is not doubt, 
that I have a solid formal educational foundation (accounting, business 
administration, communication, human resources development, organization 
development, planning, etc.) and work experiences that encompass both the 
legislative and administrative processes in government.  I am no stranger to 
public and private sector partnerships/initiatives that seek to balance 
interests of businesses and community organizations and members. 

        I think the tenants of Florida's Golden Choices would serve as an 
excellent framework for prioritizing the allocation of resources, program 
development and implementation within the provisions of the new budget.  
I firmly believe that it is important to have input from citizens whose 
benefit our services are intended.  It is going to be more important now 
than ever before to serve as a catalyst to help citizens make informed 
decisions and develop solutions to their problems or needs by providing 
access to information and services with the least red tape.  I would seek to 
include this as a hallmark in our service delivery strategies.  Re-framing 
the roles and perceptions about the roles of our elderly would be 
effectuated by preserving ties between community (institutions, businesses, 
schools and youth) and our elderly citizens. I realize that our elderly 
provide a vast reservoir of abilities and experiences of great benefit to 
our State.  I would encourage those actions that would cultivate them in our 
initiatives. 

        Lastly, providing choices in selecting the appropriate level of care 
for our frail and ill will stimulate competition and ultimately, offer 
quality options for our elderly and their families.  Supporting our elderly 
to age with dignity in terms they identify, maintain their independence to 
the maximum point feasible, in an environment that is safe from abuse, 
neglect and other crimes would be the underpinnings of initiatives that I 
would favor and eagerly pursue. 

        Let me again, affirm my belief and dedication to this administration and 
request your willingness to work with me.  Armed with the shared view of 
Governor's vision and mission, I believe we will work well together to serve 
our citizens, building on the existing efforts and making refinements at the 
right time for the right reasons. 

        As Secretary of Elder Affairs -- a team player, I will diligently 
seek to effectively balance the interests of the myriad of stakeholders 
(i.e. elders, legislators, area agencies, and federal agencies/grantors) 
through proper planning and open communications every step of the way.  I 
don't know all the challenges we will face, however, I do know that working 
together we can achieve great things for our State and its elderly citizens. 

        Again, I am asking for the opportunity and I am hopeful that I will 
be appointed Secretary of Elder Affairs.  Again, thanks for meeting with me. 
I look forward to hearing from you soon.  Lynette

Dear Jeb,  I am concerned about the practice of issuing drivers licenses to 
people with Visas that are about to expire.  Yesterday I was in the Drivers 
License Bureau and observed many people with Visa's that expire this month  
yet still given a Florida License that is good for four years.  About 30 
percent of the people coming into this office were from other countries.  If 
the Visas are expiring within a week or two, why is Florida issuing a license 
to drive?  Thank you for your attention to this concern.  
Attorney Linda McIntyre,  Coral Springs, Florida

From:	Bonnie Rodriguez <bkmarinecenter@worldnet.att.net>
Sent:	Saturday, December 1, 2001 12:49 PM
To:	Jeb Bush
Cc:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	copy of letter sent to: St. Johns Water Management District
Attachments:	Sun Stationary.jpg

Importance:	High

Bonnie Rodriguez
                                            739 Shady Nook Lane
                                            Clermont, FL 34711
                                            352-242-5166
                                            mcrod@worldnet.att.net
 
December 1, 2001
 
Kirby B. Green III
St. Johns River
Water Management District
P.O. Box 1429
Palatka, FL 32178-1429
 
Dear Mr. Green:
Im writing you regarding Permit Application 66769. I understand this permit gives Dueren & Davis, L.L.C. of Winter Garden an allocation of millions of gallons of water per day for the year 2002. Not to mention further allocations of water in the years to follow. Water that is desperately needed in this area, water that would further endanger the chain of lakes.
 
With the enormous shortage of water in this area, how do we justify more water for golf courses? I understand that we need growth in this area. However, I wonder if anyone is taking a look at the environmental damage that we are doing to the chain of lakes in Clermont. How many more golf courses do we need? Between water being diverted at Polk County, new development sprouting up at every corner and more golf courses...how long before there is not enough water to even drink!
 
These decisions made by the water management district will impact the whole community. As a small business owner, I can tell you our business is almost bankrupt because all the lake ramps are now closed and people cant boat. Not to mention the value of lake front property has dropped and continues to drop. Please, do not tell me this is because of a drought! While I may agree we have not had substantial rainfall lately, we all know water is 
 
-2-
being diverted out of this area and no one person or agency has wanted to deal with this in an open and fair manner. We also know the city is growing at an alarming rate and all those new homes consume water. However, allocating more water for more golf courses is a travesty! How do we justify this?
 
I hope you reconsider this permit. Please take a moment to think this over and perhaps even do another environmental impact study. Im sure you will find the damage done to the lakes could be stopped if not reversed with a little planning. Ive heard several impact studies have been done. However, Ive heard nothing about what the results of these studies have demonstrated. I would like to see the water management district and local governments begin to work together on some of these critical water issues. I do understand your job is not to put limits on growth. However, it is your job to keep our lakes striving and protect our natural resources. Siphoning water out of Cherry Lake will be the disaster for this chain of lakes and our community.
 
Thank you very much for your attention. If you have any questions, please contact me at 352-242-5166. Im sending a copy of this letter to the governors office in hopes that perhaps some other agencies may be willing to help with this issue.
 
 
 
Bright Blessings,
 
 
Bonnie Rodriguez
 
 
cc: Jebb Bush
Bob Graham
Bill Nelson

Subject: RE: [Fwd: Building Administrators Exam Application]



Governor, 

I am writing to let you know this matter has now been resolved.  

The Building Code Administrators and Inspectors Board met by telephone 
conference this morning to consider Mr. Lee Wansor's application to be a 
building code administrator.  After reviewing the new materials submitted by 
Mr. Wansor and speaking with him about his supervisory experience, the Board 
voted unanimously to approve his application. 

As always, if we may be of additional assistance, please do not hesitate to 
have someone from your office contact me. 

Respectfully submitted, 

Hardy Roberts 
General Counsel 
Department of Business and Professional Regulation

-----Original Message----- 
From: Jeb Bush [ mailto:jeb@jeb.org] 
Sent: Thursday, November 08, 2001 4:46 PM 
To: 'Roberts, Hardy' 
Cc: 'Binkley-Seyer, Kim'; 'Rush, Cecilia' 
Subject: RE: [Fwd: Building Administrators Exam Application]

Jeb Bush 

-----Original Message----- 
From: Roberts, Hardy [ mailto:Hardy.Roberts@dbpr.state.fl.us] 
Sent: Thursday, November 08, 2001 3:55 PM 
To: 'jeb@jeb.org' 
Cc: Binkley-Seyer, Kim; Rush, Cecilia 
Subject: FW: [Fwd: Building Administrators Exam Application] 


Governor, 

Secretary Binkley-Seyer is out of town and has asked that I respond directly 
to you to avoid any further delay. 

Mr. Lee Wansor writes regarding what he believes is a questionable practice 
by the Board of Building Code Administrators and Inspectors.  Upon review, 
the Department finds he has a point bearing further inquiry. 

While we do not have records available to speak to events transpiring in 
1993, we are aware of the circumstances behind the recent denial of Mr. 
Wansor's application to be a Building Code Administrator.  Specifically, Mr. 
Wansor's application was denied for two reasons: (1) lack of experience; and 
(2) an insufficient affidavit verifying work experience. 

First, Mr. Wansor represents that he has 18 years of relevant experience 
where 10 years are required by statute.   The relevant statute also requires 
five (5) years of supervisory experience.  The Board considered Mr. Wansor's 
application and determined he lacked the necessary experience by unanimous 
vote.  His application, however, reveals that he may have the necessary 
experience. 

Second, Mr. Wansor was required to submit an affidavit verifying his work 
experience.  A certain type of building professional must sign the 
affidavit.  Unfortunately, a proper party did not sign Mr. Wansor's 
affidavit.  This procedural defect can be easily remedied. 

The order of intent to deny Mr. Wansor's application was sent out on 
November 6, 2001.  The order informs Mr. Wansor of his right to have a 
hearing and bring this matter to the Board's attention once again. 

We are writing Mr. Wansor directly to inform him of his rights and the above 
issues regarding his application.  We also will be having a meeting shortly 
between Board counsel, the Board's Executive Director, and myself to revise 
the Board's application review procedures.  We specifically intend to 
explore whether Board counsel may be more fully incorporated into the 
application review process.  We believe this would allow ambiguous 
qualifications to be resolved one way or the other prior to the issuance of 
a denial order. 

Our correspondence to Mr. Wansor will follow immediately and we will be sure 
to copy you. 

Hardy Roberts 
General Counsel, DBPR

Dear Governor Bush: 
Hope all is well in your world at this time.  Things have to be pretty busy for you; however, I hope you do get some time for Christmas fun this month!!!! 

I was at a tree trimming party last night....if you go to one, Hershey has an ornament full of kisses that was the hit of the party--we were an easily entertained group....and met a couple of public school teachers.  Very nice ladies that took their jobs VERY seriously. 

Ever since I met you in Orange Park while running for Governor and you told me how the way the children are taught in the schools had changed so drastically since we were in school...and may I mention it wasn't ALL THAT LONG AGO (hahahaha)...it has bothered me.  Well, to make a short story long, here is our conversation you will definitely find interesting: 

The teacher I met is Kimberly Dennis of John Love Elementary in Jacksonville, Florida.  This school is about 1/2 mile from Alltel Stadium.  I asked Kimberly if she had the choice to have anyone in the State involved with the school who would she want...she said the parents!  Then I asked her who did she think, in the State, if she could get anyone involved, could motivate the parents to get involved, her first and quick answer was BUSH.  I asked her why.  Kimberley gave me the example that if she asks the parents to send a poster to school, they don't comply.  But, when the Principal requests the same thing, they respond.  Then I asked, "OK, if you could get Bush what environment would the parents attend and be most motivated in, the school?  a church?"  She said the school, a neutral place.  I asked her if the Mayor would have the same impact, and she didn't seem to think the impact would be as great as if you were there.   

Jeb, this is a teacher from an inner city school who truly cares about her students.  Perhaps if you are in area at some point you would be able to help Kimberley motivate the parents.  Her e-mail address is denniskimberly@hotmail.com.  I assure you that at the point Kimberley made these statements, she did not know that I am a Bush supporter, nor that we had worked together on Nursing home issues.  I did tell her after this conversation of my involvement within the system (no specifics) regarding Nursing homes.  Let me know your thoughts... 

I hope you don't mind my forwarding these type of ideas to you.  It looks, too, like a great way for you to get exposure in downtown Jax, an area that is heavily democrats.  Knowing you, though, you wouldn't need an election to consider this type of event!!!!   

All right, well that's enough cheerleading....I continue to support our economy, and am off to Christmas shop again....HAVE A GREAT WEEK!!!!

We all have truly entered another era, one of greater fiscal responsibility and accountability. Attached are two letters I have sent to support my children with disabilities, and children like them, in community programs.  Much of my children's services are school based and I have needed to spend enormous amounts of time advocating for them.
 
I appreciate your efforts and funding of programs for children with disabilities.  I urge you to remember many of them can truly become independent and productive in society with appropriate supports and programs given early for skill, self-esteem, and social development.
 
Thank you and enjoy the weekend.
 
Laurel A. Kruse, MD
Pediatrician and parent of two children with disabilities


 
From:	wayne calabrese <whcanetoad@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Saturday, December 1, 2001 9:13 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Wackenhut award of SVP project (George Zoley)

Dear Governor Bush:

I regret to inform you of my extreme frustration and need of your help regarding the Sexually Violent Predator (SVP) program for Florida.

Wackenhut subsidiary Atlantic Shores Healthcare (ASH) has been for some time trying to accomplish two objectives:

1.  Persuade DCF to confirm our selection by the Correctional Privatization Commission (CPC)as the winner of the SVP procurement (due to having received the highest number of points) and begin the negotiations allowing us the opportunity to propose a new permanent SVP facility that is cost-effective for the state of Florida.

*	DCF staff argue that because you previously vetoed $10,000 in SVP funds for CPC, you effectively removed any legal authority for continuing the SVP RFP process;
*	Further, DCF staff assert that you are now opposed to a new facility because of cost issues - before allowing us an opportunity to negotiate a cost-effective solution that would fulfill an important need, create hundreds of construction jobs, and be funded through bond financing.
*	We have spent one year competing on the SVP RFP (still authorized pursuant to last year's legislation), incurred over $500,000 in expenses in-house and with builders/architects, received the highest number of points among all competitors, and were selected by the CPC for contract award;
*	We need your help, and/or the legislature, to direct DCF to begin the negotiation process subject to achieving a cost-effective solution for the state.

2.  Persuade DCF to allow us to take over the emergency SVP contract/program in Desoto County, given that we have won the competition for the development and operation of the permanent SVP contract/program.

*	The existing emergency SVP contract/program in Desoto County is operated by an out-of-state company who received the contract without competition under a 30-day cancellation provision;
*	DCF staff assert that they would like to re-bid the existing emergency SVP operations-only contract;
*	We hope that you can persuade DCF to allow our Florida company, who won the competition for the permanent SVP contract/program in Desoto County involving the same sexual offenders (including facility operations and development) to assume the emergency contract over a 60 to 90 day period with a cost reduction to the state;
*	We are deeply disturbed over so much preference being given to an out-of-state company when our Florida company won the competitive bid and is fully capable of delivering professional services with a cost savings to the state.

I would appreciate a meeting with you on this subject, or you can reach me on my cell phone number (954) 253 7634.

Sincerely,

George C Zoley, Chairman - Atlantic Shores Healthcare (a Wackenhut subsidiary)

-----Original Message-----
From: Pulga2@aol.com [mailto:Pulga2@aol.com]
Sent: Friday, November 30, 2001 9:03 PM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: Fwd: ACCOUNTABILITY - Open Christmas Message to Fla.Bureaucrats OODA


In a message dated 11/30/2001 8:48:02 PM Eastern Standard Time, Wldmjd writes: 




Subj: Fwd: ACCOUNTABILITY - Open Christmas Message to Fla.Bureaucrats OODA 
Date: 11/30/2001 8:48:02 PM Eastern Standard Time 
From: Wldmjd 
To: Pulga2 






----------------- 
Forwarded Message: 
Subj: ACCOUNTABILITY - Open Christmas Message to Fla.Bureaucrats OODA 
Date: 11/30/2001 7:31:10 PM Eastern Standard Time 
From: Wldmjd 
To: Purplecrip, kennethsmom@earthlink.net, CY SYKO <mailto:CY%20SYKO> , Pulga2, Deepmoss, AYGFury, De Semery <mailto:De%20Semery> , McCTee, mpauli1@email.msn.com, g8rleslie, JeremyAce4, Leah  <mailto:Leah%20Learn> Learn, THEREQUIP, SMEGROUP1, sambrola@adelphia.net 



It is dangerously close to Christmas.  I have come to hate Holidays from years and years of seeing the same-ol, same ol's getting and the same ol's not. Somehow, the system never seems to remember the disabled at Holidays except to put some of us caregivers through "The Grinch That Stole  Funds" spirits! 

It is very hard for some to buy Christmas EVEN IF they have the money.  Ever tried to shop with your disabled child at Christmas in the Mall?  Then - try to convince them that the big fat man in the red suit shoved it down your non-existant chimney? Ever noticed all the displays right in the middle of the aisles?  We do, we drag them on the back or side of the wheelchair. But, PCA is not for the Mom to "run errands".  Just tag along the child with you, even for that ob/gyn  exam. Cold and flu season falls at Christmas.  If you take them out and they get sick - it pallors the gifts under the tree.And - over the counter is general utility and will not be covered. 

So, in the spirit of Christmas a comin', I am giving free lessons and exercises to anyone that decides on funds for the disabled, makes decisions for the disabled, etc. that does not take care of the disabled.... kind of a "walk in our AFO'S".....read on and Merry Christmas! 

Exercise One: 
Purchase one mesh net bag with holes in it 
Catch one very large, peed-off, live octopus 
Place octopus in bag, make sure all tentacles are inside the bag and not injured in any way 
Everytime the octopus gets the bag wet (immediately and quite often), repeat the above steps 
Lesson Learned:  How to dress the disabled and why more than three incontinent briefs a day really is not excessive 

Exercise Two: 
Get one large bleach bottle and one large tablespoon and one piece of rope and a hook 
Cut a whole in the front of the bottle smaller than a teaspoon 
Hang the bottle from the rope and put the rope on the hook suspended from the ceiling 
Start swinging the bottle 
Each time the bottle swings toward you, place the teaspoon full of something very messy into the hole you cut out, make sure the bottle keeps moving 
Lesson Learned:  How to orally feed the disabled and why housekeeping service was thought of in the first place as necessary 

Repeat Exercise One because of the mess caused by Exercise Two. 

Exercise Three: 
Obtain many large army tanks.  If none are available - purchase roofing tacks 
Place tanks or tacks (both are better) randomly thru the house 
At night, after everyone is in bed, keep the lights out and stroll through the house barefooted 
When you stump your toe or hit a tack, do not scream, it will wake up the child. 
Lesson Learned: No reason someone would ask for large equipment for their child if it was not medically necessary 

Exercise Four: 
Go to the drugstore 
Take out your wallet 
Tell the pharmacist to help himself to the wallet containing cash and credit cards 
Lesson Learned:  Why OTC was thought of in the first place as necessary 

Exercise Five: 
Purchase a laundromat 
Lesson Learned:  That using 53 washers a day is par for the course and that is why laundry services and stipends were thought of in the first place as necessary 

Exercise Six: 
Try to get a butterfly to make butter on a plane.  Burn a hundred dollar bill when they can't. 
Use a witch doctor to do your heart surgery.  Burn a hundred dollar bill when you decide you would rather not. 
Coach a lightning bug to bring on thunder and rain...Another hundred 
Tell someone catsup is really for having a kitten for dinner...Another hundred 
Rearrange your furniture and have carpet laid in a mushroom.....Burn another hundred 
Lesson Learned: A Rehabilitation Engineer is not an engineer for structures and is burning money 

Exercise Seven: 
Purchase a small vehicle, a volkswagon is good 
Fill it with gas 
Loosen the gas cap so it leaks a little 
Attach the car to the front of your clothing and carry it arround forever 
Lesson Learned:  A mechanical lift to avoid constant lifting is  a good idea and that is why it was thought of in the first place 

Exercise  Eight: 
Purchase a burlap bag and 125 pounds of sand 
Insert sand into bag and wet thoroughly.  Leave the end of the bag open.  Set your alarm clock 
Turn the bag, at night, every 45 minutes to the other side of the bed.  Make sure none of the sand leaks out.  If so, and it will,repeat the above steps 
Lesson Learned:  See Lessons One, Two, Three, Five and Seven 

Exercise Nine: 
Purchase stress incontinent pads by the gross 
Check out the price of a good iliostomy 
Buy Preperation H by the cases and ask for it for Christmas 
Lesson Learned:  See Lesson Seven 

Exercise Ten: 
Destroy your address book and any links with friends 
Cancel all magazine subscriptions 
Send out letters not to invite you to anything in the future 
Start thinking of what you will tell everyone when your spouse runs to Mexico screaming "I'm outta here" 
Inform your elderly parents that you are not recalling bad childhood traumas but, that you will  not  be traveling to see them at  Holidays anymore 
Lesson Learned:  Respite is a good idea and that is why it was thought of in the first place 

Exercise Eleven: 
Purchase the biggest, most expensive, ugliest gas hog of a van that you can find 
Quit your  job because of a lack of a sitter for the child 
Hock everything of value 
Spend savings and college funds for children 
Lesson Learned:  Having to have a new van in order to get a lift is unrealistic 

Exercise Twelve: 
Place Governor Bush into an Intermediate Care Facility for The Developmentally Disabled 
Treat him as you would any other client 
Start immediatley working on getting him out of there 
Lesson Learned:  The true definition of "reasonable promptness" 

Exercise Thirteen: 
Turn down your brother-in-law mechanic that will take care of your car for $100.00.   
Take your car instead to a stranger that mucks the work and causes you to pay $3,000.00 
Turn down your teen age son that will cut the grass, the way you like it, for the cost of the gas only, $2.75. 
Hire a stranger to do it for $50.00 and then resod when it kills the grass.l 
Keep your home clean for the cost of supplies only or hire a maid that steals from you and costs you $300.00 (and the supplies) a week 
Lesson Learned:  It is cheaper to have the work done at home by the family and that is why HCBS was thought of in the first place 

Exercise Fourteen: 
Put a good attorney on speed dial 
Remove the words Federal Funds from all your literature 
Get your good suit cleaned for the Press 
Lesson Learned:  When lessons are not learned there are prices to pay 

Ho, Ho, Ho - 
Merry Christmas! 

Mary Daniels

-----Original Message-----
From: AndyNewman@aol.com [mailto:AndyNewman@aol.com]
Sent: Saturday, December 01, 2001 4:15 AM
To: Jeb Bush
Subject: A Florida Keys Opportunity; Florida Tourism Commission



Realizing you must be inundated with e-mail, I wanted to make sure you 
received the following, since I had not heard back from you... 


Gov. Bush: 

I wanted to make you aware of an opportunity as well as followup on a brief 
discussion we had back in late September, prior to the Florida Tourism 
Commission meeting at Amelia Island. 

First the opportunity. 

More than 500 volunteers, in the Florida Keys, recently completed the bulk of 
construction on a new two-acre playground in Marathon. Most of the park and 
its play accessories were concepted by elementary school kids, with final 
design and engineering plans completed and supervised by a professional 
playground design firm. The new facility is to be dedicated before Christmas 
and given the nature of this project, I thought you might wish to preside 
over the ceremony. The date is somewhat flexible, so perhaps it can be 
considered by you and your schedulers. The park's location is quite close to 
Florida Keys Marathon Airport, making transportation  simple. Perhaps you or 
a staff member might let me know if this can be considered. 

Next, the followup. 

Prior to the Florida Tourism Commission meeting, we chatted about the need 
for a Florida Keys tourism representative to serve on the Florida Tourism 
Commission. The Keys has no representation on the board and given the role 
that Monroe County plays in Florida tourism, I am asking for your assistance 
to help make this happen. Ideally we feel that Harold Wheeler, director of 
the Monroe County Tourist Development Council would make an ideal candidate. 

With regards, 
Andy Newman 
(305) 461-3300 
1-800-275-5397

From:	Dr. Alexandra Penn Williams <learn@iu.net>
Sent:	Saturday, December 1, 2001 2:24 AM
To:	Jeb Bush
Subject:	Teacher Education

Dear Jeb, 

I thought this abstract and its associated article were very interesting, so 
much so that I believe it to be worth your attention.  The more I travel 
from school to school throughout the state, the more I understand that real 
reform will only come with better teaching - and better teaching will only 
come with better teachers.  Sadly, this profession is presently being 
populated from the bottom up - and this must change!  In addition, I have 
begun teaching one course per semester at UCF in their College of Education. 
This has added to my dismay, as I have been able to see first hand the 
implausibility of what Colleges of Education portend to accomplish. I 
believe this article suggests an interesting alternative out of which there 
can be a myriad of solutions for raising the level of teacher talent and 
competency. 

As always, your friend, 
Alex:) 

P.S.  Hope you are doing well amongst the legislative choas.  I look forward 
to more peaceful, quiet times.  Don't you? 


"TEAR DOWN THIS WALL: RADICALLY OVERHAULING TEACHER CERTIFICATION 
Contrary to the claims of some critics, the problem of teacher 
certification is not the existence of schools of education and teacher 
preparation programs or their particular failings. The real problem lies 
in state laws that give these schools and programs a monopoly on training 
and certifying teachers. The arguments fall into two camps. Some propose 
abolishing schools of education or doing away with certification 
altogether. Others believe that adding new barriers to entry or creating 
advanced "master teacher" certifications will address the quality problem 
and increase the "rigor" of teacher preparation programs. According to 
Frederick Hess, neither of these approaches will adequately tackle the 
problems at hand. This paper proposes a third way: a "competitive 
certification" model that breaks the monopoly education schools hold on 
the supply of teachers with the aim of expanding the pool of potential 
teachers while also addressing the issue of quality. The goal is to 
increase the pool of qualified applicants for teaching jobs and at the 
same time increase the competition among providers of preparation and 
ongoing professional development for teachers." 
http://www.ppionline.org/ppi_ci.cfm?knlgAreaID=110 <http://www.ppionline.org/ppi_ci.cfm?knlgAreaID=110&subsecid=135&contentid=39> &subsecid=135&contentid=39 
64
